name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the report by Tamás Meszerics, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on achieving the anti-poverty target in the light of the increase in household expenditure (2015/2223(INI)) (A8-0040/2016).

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I think the topic we are going to discuss at this early hour on the last day of our part session this week is very important. First of all, allow me to thank everybody who has contributed to the work, especially the shadow rapporteurs, who have been very helpful, very flexible and very professional in working out a text which I believe can command a fairly large consensus in the House. This was not very easy to achieve. It was very important that the shadows put their work and their commitment into the whole topic. Although I am listed as the author, I have to thank all my colleagues in my Group and especially my advisers, who helped considerably in putting together a text which has a chance of passing, and which I hope will pass on the vote today. We are not getting any closer to the 2020 anti-poverty target. We are actually, by all important measurements, further away from the 2020 anti-poverty targets than when they were originally formulated. This is only partly due to the financial crisis of 2008 – after all, we are in the ninth year after the crisis – so we have a basic structural problem. The report is not on that, but one of the key elements in this attempt to reduce poverty in the European Union is related to basic resources, household costs and household expenditure. I believe that, fundamentally, energy and water are essential resources which are necessary for the survival of any household in the European Union. They are essential especially because we are more and more dependent, individually and in groups, on energy. At the same time, energy prices have been continually rising in the last almost half a decade, which makes the problem more serious than we would have thought at the time when the anti-poverty target was put together. At the time when this was formulated there was a widespread consensus that poverty is a complex global phenomenon which requires complex global treatment. So some of my colleagues, with an honest conviction, thought that selecting a particular type of poverty from the complex web of poverty might be a mistake. I would like to defend the view that energy poverty, or fuel poverty, is one of the most important elements in this, because it usually requires an upfront investment. Simple direct income support is not going to help those who are in this trap, because it requires an upfront investment. That is why what we are asking for primarily is to have a complex policy set which simultaneously attacks all the three elements of energy poverty, one of them being insufficient income, another being energy efficiency – basically the quality of the housing stock in much of Europe. Eastern Europe is significantly different in this respect to Western Europe. In Eastern Europe we do not have a meaningful social housing system, and that contributes to, and exacerbates, the problem. Finally, I would like to mention that we believe that a winter disconnection moratorium on heating is a must. Nobody should die in Europe because of not having heating available.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur, Mr Meszerics, for this very comprehensive report, which confirms once again that poverty is a complex phenomenon with several causes, such as the increasing household costs in Europe. I share your concerns about the rise in the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the European Union. Between 2008 and 2013 the prolonged crisis exacerbated the existing social challenges: poverty, exclusion and inequality. As a result, instead of progressing, we have drifted further away from the Europe 2020 target for reducing poverty. However, there are now some signs of stabilisation, and with concerted efforts we can still make real progress. I take note of your recommendation to invest fully in the fight against poverty and social exclusion – social inclusion is, of course, what we want. The Commission has put social fairness at the core of our agenda, and work has already started to deliver on this commitment. I am convinced that it is only by ensuring that social considerations are better integrated in all of the European policy areas that we can truly achieve the social Europe that we want. I am glad that your report supports our commitment to ensuring a social triple A for the Union. The European pillar of social rights lies at the core of our efforts to achieve that social triple A. The Commission launched a wide-ranging consultation on 8 March. We are counting on you and on Parliament to contribute to this discussion on the social values and rights that should underpin the social model in the 21st century. The draft European pillar of social rights puts a strong focus on fighting poverty and social exclusion. It sets out principles to ensure access to adequate social protection, including minimum income, social housing and activating and enabling benefits and services. It emphasises the work-life balance and family-friendly policies such as childcare and long—term care. Greater prominence is also being given to social considerations in and during the whole European Semester process. We acknowledge the rapporteur’s recommendation to carry out impact assessments of national minimum income schemes and we would like to stress that over the years the Commission has provided policy guidance to the Member States. I would like to mention here the 2008 recommendation on active inclusion, the 2013 Social Investment Package and the various country—specific recommendations addressed to several Member States within the European Semester process. Furthermore, the Commission is providing support to Greece to help it phase in a guaranteed minimum income scheme. In 2015 the Commission finalised a pilot project aimed at developing a methodology for comparable reference budgets across the Member States. A second phase of this project will be launched later this year. Furthermore, the Commission has been funding the development of the European Minimum Income Network. I am glad that the report highlights the importance of skills. I would like to stress that one of the most profound challenges we are facing, and one of our key goals, is to make sure that people in Europe have skills for jobs – skills for jobs which will improve their life chances. This will be at the core of the proposal that I will be presenting on a New Skills Agenda for Europe. I also take note of your call to hold a summit on poverty reduction. Over the last 15 years, the Commission has been helping to organise the European meetings of people experiencing poverty. These annual gatherings aim to step up the participation of people experiencing poverty in policy—making processes at local, national and EU level. I can confirm that they facilitate exchanges and mutual learning, stimulate joint projects and aim to assess different approaches to combating poverty in the light of experience on the ground. They feed directly into the Annual Convention for Inclusive Growth to ensure that the voices of people experiencing poverty are heard. They have also been tackling homelessness, which you rightly mention in your report as an extreme form of social exclusion. We are currently finalising an EU—wide study on housing evictions. Another study on cost—efficient housing policies will be ready by June this year. We have launched a joint project with the OECD to build a housing database entry and we are working together with the Mutual Information System on Social Protection (MISSOC) and Eurostat to further improve housing data. A social experimentation peer review of Housing First was hosted in March this year by Belgium. Finally, we take note of your recommendation to submit a communication on energy poverty. As announced in the communication setting out a new deal for energy consumers, the Commission is exploring how to improve European Union-wide data collection and monitoring of energy poverty. Furthermore, with the review of the Energy Efficiency Directive and the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive, the Commission intends to focus on customer protection, following up the analysis of the Member States’ implementation of their national action plans for the protection of vulnerable energy consumers. In conclusion, I would like to stress once more that it is the Commission’s firm intention to steer the Union more firmly towards social fairness. This means that no one should be left behind. This is a social, political and economic imperative. I therefore express our strong commitment to using all means at the Union’s disposal to fight poverty and social exclusion. I am very grateful that this report is stimulating the debate and helping us to stay on the right path.

name: Julie WARD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality. – Mr President, I would also like to thank my colleagues for our work together on this report, which cuts across many issues and needs a holistic approach. It is quite clear that we need fresh political ambition to eradicate poverty across Europe, and we must be absolutely clear that there is no way of alleviating poverty unless we also tackle gender inequality. The financial crisis and subsequent austerity measures have had a disproportionate adverse effect on women – far more than men – causing a feminisation of poverty. This report sets out how the European Union must work to address the concerns of vulnerable women, especially single mothers and caregivers and women suffering from multiple discriminations, who are so often left behind because of government policy. The report is another step in the EU’s history of advancing women’s rights and gender equality and is particularly important in the light of austerity. We need a European definition of energy poverty and we need it to include a gender perspective, reflective of the fact that female-headed households are more likely to be energy poor. These are some of the many concrete targeted policies that we propose, which also include investing in research into the causes of female homelessness. To conclude, the Commission and national governments must include a strong gender pillar in all of their social policy, demonstrating that the EU acts for its constituents and for social justice.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: on behalf of the EPP group. Mr President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his work and for his ongoing search for consensus. The fight against poverty in all its forms deserves us to overcome partisan divides. It must be a priority for ethical and human reasons, but also because poverty leads to a real economic mess. The main tools of this struggle are the development of employment and the guarantee of an income that allows us to live decently. The Europe 2020 targets are far from being met. If the European Union is to earn its social triple A, it must absolutely reverse this trend. We need to be aware that poor households are particularly affected by different types of costs. This is the case for energy and housing, but also for food, water, health care or public services. We need coherent policies that integrate all factors of poverty. Families living in poverty do not need speech. They need concrete and practical action. I hope that this initiative report will be heard by the Commission and by the Member States as a call to action. I will conclude, if I may, by recalling the words of the late Father Wresinski, founder of ATD Fourth World. He asks us to ask ourselves: what we do, what we say, what we propose enable the realization of a Europe where the poor will finally be freed, does it enable the realization of a Europe of human rights? Like him, we must consider poverty to be an attack on human rights.

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, who are we talking about when we talk about poor households? The proportion of the poor in the Union has increased by millions to more than 120 million. Fortunately, the Commission is committed to a social Europe of three A's, and now a real social pillar must be created.  We want the Commission and the Member States to organise a summit on poverty at the highest possible level to deal with social exclusion and the possibility of a decent life. Like the Economic and Social Committee, we want to set up a poverty observatory so that we can also tackle it.  Basic income and a sustainable social policy for states would ensure a decent life. Every month, more and more families have to count their spending, give up either food, medicines or heat, and more than 10% of EU citizens have difficulty heating their homes. That is why we support the intervention in energy poverty, and the report also calls for a ban on the switchover of winter heating. Households can improve energy efficiency, but the poor cannot afford this. We must also seek ways of this in Europe, including funding from countries other than the European Social Fund. The resolution clearly passed in committee. I also hope that this Chamber will support the Commission in defining energy poverty and seeking opportunities to tackle it.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President. Thank you very much, Commissioner, and of course thank you very much for all those who have been involved in the preparation of this report, in particular the rapporteur, Mr Meszerics, for this text, which could mark a milestone in the fight against poverty. A text that has brought together the will of many groups in Parliament, but that of all, beyond their ideologies, around a problem that we all share. The levels of poverty at the moment in one of the richest areas of the world, such as the European Union, are unacceptable. It is unacceptable, which leads us to something stated in this text: they must give priority to the fight against poverty over many other policies because it is the very foundation of freedom and solidarity and the principles that underscore the European Union that we do not have poor in our societies. The text basically has two aspects, which the Commissioner has seen very well. One is the struggle for a better world for the future. And we talk about structural solutions, such as the minimum income of insertion, the improvement of the housing park, a housing policy. And that is all very well, and I think the Commission needs to focus on it. But let me finish this speech by saying that poverty is a scourge of today, right now, and the poor are here today. And, therefore, in the text you will also find a whole series of non-economic measures, which are social. They can even be tax aid; but they are also subsidies, they are aids, they are social benefits, they are a better social salary to combat poverty today, here and now. And there we could also include different treatment of the female sex. This needs to be taken seriously, here and now, with concrete measures, and Member States must be forced to be much more intense, priority and urgent in the fight against poverty with concrete measures.

name: Lynn BOYLAN
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, I welcome this important report on combating poverty. In my home country, three-quarters of a million people are living in poverty. 13% of those are people with jobs, so we need to deal with the issue of decent living wages. Ireland’s rising poverty is coinciding with a severe crisis in housing and homelessness, as a result of government policies. I therefore particularly welcome the report’s acknowledgment that housing is a fundamental right and its call for the expansion of the supply of quality social housing. The relationship between the social housing stock and homelessness is undeniable. We have 6 000 homeless people in Ireland, 1 600 of whom are children. 140 000 people are on social housing lists, yet only 28 social houses were built. Family homes are being repossessed while rental tenants are pushed across the poverty threshold because of skyrocketing rents. We need to see housing as a right. I also welcome this report’s call for a moratorium on winter heating cut-offs. We also need real action on the crisis of poverty.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. - Mr President, I would like to thank the European There is a very important report here on Parliament's table today. In Europe, there are various estimates of between 50 and 120 million citizens affected by the problem of energy poverty. Energy poverty may take different forms in each Member State, which is why well-targeted, well-formulated European measures are needed, as well as measures taken by Member States to eradicate or reduce energy poverty in Europe.  Many people have already talked about social instruments, and I must note that what is most important about the various social transfers is that the right aim is to get public assistance to those who are actually in need.  Equally important are the means of protection that are included in the report: eviction restrictions and other means of helping to ensure that European citizens and families do not find themselves in an impossible situation. At the same time, in the long term, we have only one coherent, sustainable, effective instrument to reduce energy poverty, and this is not to help reduce or pay bills with public money, but to reduce energy use and to help citizens to access energy efficiency and renewables through appropriate forms of funding.

name: Petr MACH
text: on the efdd group. – When I read the report on the objectives of reducing poverty and increasing household costs, I thought that this was just some modern-day Communist manifesto that was produced on the green-left periphery of this Parliament, and I was therefore shocked when Commissioner Thyssen herself said that this report helps us to stay on track.  Do you really think that organizing a summit will help us to eliminate poverty – and I quote from the report? Do you really think you should call on the Member States to include women more in fields such as engineering? Do you really think member states should regulate rents? Do you really think that Member States should provide a so-called minimum income, housing benefit? Do you really think that the Member States and the EU should provide microcreals to poor people in order to make them even more indebted? I will tell you what I think this EP and the EU could do. Two simple things. First, abolish nonsensical taxes on electricity, gas, and coal, which make energy more expensive for households while costing so much that it brings nothing to state budgets. Secondly, abolish nonsensical quotas for solar electricity. This costs households tens of thousands of crowns a year extra to subsidize solar power, and moreover, if we abolish these meaningless quotas for expensive electricity, coal-fired power plants will once again have sales for coal, and coal mines will not have to lay off workers, and miners will have their incomes again. So let's start here with us.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, the Europe 2020 strategy plans to lift 20 million people out of poverty, and focuses on increasing the cost of housing, energy and education. It's good, it's pretty! Two areas of work are thus envisaged. First, to increase the incomes of poor households by encouraging the development of a framework directive on minimum income, which would be set at the national level, above the poverty line, and by strengthening social rights in order to guarantee state aid. Secondly, to encourage the reduction of expenditure, by ensuring a better allocation of the various European funds for the benefit of poor households, such as ESI funds, to combat energy insecurity, and by encouraging the fiscal shift which aims to tax the energy industries to reduce the burden on the cost of labour.  I'm sorry, but I'm saying here that you're wrong and you're dreaming. Indeed, poverty will continue to grow, as this crisis is fuelled by your austerity and ultra-liberal policies and aggravated by the arrival of migrants. European funds have only a minor impact on the policies of the Member States, and the establishment of a minimum wage or the tax shift is clearly a national responsibility. (The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: David CASA
text: mistoqsija karta blu. – Jiena naħseb illi l-qasam so大jali nkunu qegħdin nindukrawh jekk kull pajjiż Ewropew jara li dawk li suppost qegħdin iħallsu t-taxxi fuq l-income taghomħ, isir f'dawk il-pajjiżi, biex dawk it-taxxi nkunu nistgħu nużawhom għall-qasam so大jali. Irridu niġġieldu lil dawk i大-大ittadini Ewropej li jinvestu f'pajjiżi bħall-Panama biex il-flus tagħhom ma jkunux jistgħu jħallsu fuqhom taxxi kif suppost għandu jħallas kull ħittadin ieħor Ewropew.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: "blue card" answer. Mr Casa, thank you, but you are part of a group, the EPP, which leaves me to think, as they say in France, that "to go up to the coconut tree, you have to have clean braies".  Therefore, I do not believe that you have any lessons to give, and I invite you to have the information that you have verified, which, unfortunately, is false.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – I warmly congratulate my Hungarian colleague Tamás Meszerics on this report. It has also revealed shocking data on poverty and misery in the European Union. The number of poor people has increased from 117 million to 122.6 million in five years.  I would like to ask the President to warn our fellow citizens not to talk here, it is not possible to speak in this way if there is a café-like conversation in here. I keep talking loudly, and I ask you to stop the clock and tell the former speaker that I can't do it. So we have to respect each other, we have to respect our constituents by providing each other with normal circumstances to speak. Thank you very much! So these figures are shocking, it turns out that not only is poverty in the European Union decreasing, from 117 million to 122.6 million, over five years, 16.7% are currently living in poverty. Among other things, the report states that 60% of the inhabitants of the Member States most affected cannot heat their homes to the right temperature. I suppose you mean, for example, your own country, Hungary, or the countries that are considered to be second-class.  But let us be clear, you agree with me that these miserable circumstances are not the consequences of some kind of natural disaster, but the consequences of decisions. Among other things, the consequences of the Union's decisions, and this poverty, poverty and internal colonialism are at the heart of the Union. It pursues a neoliberal policy and economic policy based on money and profit-driven global free trade, rather than pursuing a people-centred policy and economic policy in which it asks what is good for people and not always what is good for profit and for large investors and multi-companies. Thank you.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Morvai, you were widely rewarded for the disturbance you received from the interview between two of your colleagues, I gave you 40 seconds more than the time you had, so I think you were rewarded.

name: David CASA
text: – Kif diġà ntqal, sfortunatament, il-miri ta' EU 2020 f'dak li għandu x'jaqsam mal-qasam tal-faqar għadna ma lħaqnihomx. Hemm bżonn li nieħdu miżuri biex naraw u nassiguraw li ħididini jkollhom ħajja diħenti, li jkollhom income ukoll di大enti, imma mhux akkost illi nagmħlu liħm-dini-dinidaditadaditadi bis fuq il-qasam so大jali. Hemm bżonn nappoġġaw suq vibranti, illi jkollna pagi aktar għoljin li jiggarantixxu dik il-protezzjoni so大jali.  Jiena naħseb li għandna bżonn ukoll nassiguraw li jkollna bilan大 bejn il-kompetittività u qasam ġust so大jali. Irridu naraw kif ħa nikkoordinaw aħjar il-fondi Ewropej illi għandna fl-Unjoni Ewropea. U jiena naħseb li l-ġlieda tal-faqar għandha tiġi indirizzata bi strateġija integrata li tiffoka fuq pjan olistiku li jintegra flimkien l-edukazzjoni, l-enerġija, it-trasport, il-qasam tax-xħogol u l-politika so大jali. (Il-kelliem a大大etta li jwieġeb mistoqsija "karta blu" (Artikolu 162(8) tar-Regoli ta' Pro大edura))

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: blue-card question. – Thank you very much for your availability, dear colleague. As a matter of fact, you have listed quite a few measures, but my question is: would you, or your Group, be in favour of a European minimum wage system?

name: David CASA
text: tweġiba karta blu. – Naturalment, dak huwa qasam illi jitkellem dwar kif nistgħu ngħinu liħinu liħinu-ħittadini tagħna, dak huwa qasam li jidħol taħt is-slipperjarjetà. Jiena naħseb illi għandna nħeġġu li kull pajjiż ikollu xi tip ta' skemi però m'għandna norbtu flower-ebda pajjiż Ewropew li bilfors irid jadotta dak it-tip ta' miżuri. Naturalment, hawk pajjiż jista' jara kif ikollu qasam so大jali b'saħħtu u rridu naraw li dak il-qasam ikun jgħodd għaħa-ittaħdini kollha Ewropej.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: – Mr President, the poverty data are disgraceful today in Europe and to see how it has increased in recent years is absolutely intolerable. Poverty is not only a statistic, it has a huge social impact; because it distorts demand and the economy; a huge institutional impact, because it disconnects many people from institutions; but it even has an impact on public health, because many people see their life expectancy diminished.  In the face of this, we have the option of continuing to make macroeconomic policies that have gone the other way, which have allowed poverty to increase over the years, or to establish European standards that combat and combat poverty in which one in four Europeans are located; in my country, in Spain, one in three. And to put in place a tool, a European minimum income system that protects citizens and assures them that, in the face of any problem or difficulty, or when they are unemployment, they will have the protection of the whole State, public administrations and Europe to guarantee them a dignified life.  (He agreed to answer a question posed under the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation))

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: "blue card" question. – Distinguished and dear colleague, apart from fighting for the structural things that you have said and what the company of my group will always have, do you also consider it essential to focus, with very concrete measures here and now, on the poor that we have, in order to alleviate, as the first priority, to alleviate that suffering in which your life has become?

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: "blue card" response. – Of course, of course. I believe that there is a macroeconomic problem of the policy that has been carried out over the last few years; that saying "you meet these deficit targets, but you have to combat poverty by 2020" has been counterproductive. But then we can do concrete things. We can do concrete things from here. Minimum incomes, the fight against energy poverty, a European observatory that allows us to see what is happening today and why it is happening. And this report contains a good compendium of concrete measures that we could push forward today from the European institutions.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: – Mr President, first of all I want to thank the rapporteur for his important report. It is important because it highlights the fact that one in six Europeans are either in poverty or at risk of poverty. In Ireland the figure is 16%. But crucially, the report points to concrete measures that can be taken to try to meet the EU 2020 anti-poverty targets. We are all aware that poorer households spend a higher proportion of their income on household costs, whether accounted for by utilities or housing or energy or food, than other households do. Therefore, a minimum income that takes into account the economic and social circumstances in each Member State and is based on a life-cycle approach is, in my opinion, a safety net. Certain practical suggestions, such as a winter heating disconnection moratorium, the possibility of extending the fund for the most deprived, and measures to reduce energy poverty, such as micro loans for investing in energy efficiency, are all important steps. Access to water and sanitation is a human right, and privatisation of these services has had a negative effect on households. Finally, I agree with the Commissioner. We need to upgrade our skills and invest in jobs and, crucially, decent work and decent jobs. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8))

name: Miapetra KUMPULA-NATRI
text: blue-card question. – I am very happy that Ms Harkin also took up the energy poverty issue, as it is a real fact that nowadays more than 10% of European homes have a leaking roof or bad condition walls and inside humidity. The shocking news from the UK is that research shows that one person dies every seven minutes during cold snaps in winter. So energy poverty is a fact. Are you ready to support it being defined, by the Commission, in such a way that we have a common understanding of what it means?

name: Marian HARKIN
text: blue-card answer. – Yes, I agree with you: we need the Commission to define it, and we certainly support the idea of a winter—heating disconnection moratorium. It will not solve all our problems, but at least it is a step in the right direction. It is an issue that we need to tackle, both at European and at national level, and I welcome some of the comments from the Commissioner on that particular point today.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, why in the southern countries with plenty of light, thousands of people are cold in their homes? Energy poverty rooted in rising poverty prevents households from paying for gas, oil or electricity.  In Greece, the risk of poverty reached 36%. In the European Union, some 22 million households suffer from the cold, while more than 40% of their disposable income goes for loans and rents.  The Meszerics report rightly says that energy poverty is due to poverty, inequality and unemployment. Nothing will change unless we fight for the social dimension of Europe. Unfortunately, the Commission's plan for a European Pillar of Social Rights prepares us for an icy winter, with even greater energy poverty. Let European citizens know that.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: – Mr. President, I congratulate my colleague Mesarić on his excellent report and I think that all the key facts related to the growing problem of domestic poverty have been highlighted. Excellent measures have also been proposed on how to address this problem. In particular, I consider the problem of energy poverty present in all Member States to be important and particularly prominent in South East Europe.  Member States often promote energy efficiency measures that imply good financial capacity for citizens and lack measures that focus on vulnerable and socially vulnerable consumer groups. Measures to combat energy poverty and measures to improve housing standards that would allow a higher share of domestic renewable energy use and reduce unemployment have been completely absent.  I support the initiative addressed to the Commission to accurately set the definition of energy poverty in order to identify and implement the Common European Policy as soon as possible and to start implementing the Common European Policy. However, efforts should be made in Member States to identify local problems, to help vulnerable citizens, and in particular to highlight the potentials of social entrepreneurship and alternative business models, such as cooperatives and mutual societies, in strengthening women's social inclusion and economic empowerment. (The Speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the blue card (Article 162(8) of the EEA). Rules of Procedure)).

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: A question raised by raising a blue card. – Dear colleague, you have raised a number of questions, which are certainly of interest to the people I represent in Slovenia. I would also like to share my view that, in the short term, in view of the growing number of older people who are poor, the Commission must adopt a strategy, a plan that will take into account demographic changes in Europe and an increasing number of elderly people without resources?

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. - Dear colleague, I fully agree with you that the Commission should pay particular attention to senior citizens who are socially disadvantaged. We know that we have consequences from the past, that their current pensions are too small to be able to pay their own energy bills, but also other bills.  So very little money leaves them for a normal life. So I think that this should not only be within the competence of the Member States, but also that the Commission should also encourage Member States to actually act in this direction. Thank you for your suggestion.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: Mr President, the urgency of unlivable situations for millions of Europeans who are facing energy insecurity in unsanitary housing or who do not have stable resources must alert us. Alas, the proposals put forward do not live up to this urgency, which requires that we focus on the priorities and misery of our fellow citizens, rather than welcoming that of the whole world without having the means to do so. These proposals are also ill-founded. We are told about minorities as vulnerable subjects in the same respect as disability, widowhood or illness, but more concrete things, which have real costs. But what minorities are we talking about? No definition is given, at the risk of distorting the objective of social policy: protecting individuals from social risks.  The poverty of single parents also seems to be surprising. The first answer is financial protection, but saying, for example, that work is the only way out of poverty for single mothers is a profoundly antisocial reasoning. Women should be allowed to choose between work and family life by, for example, introducing a parental wage.  Finally, let us not forget that the break-up of the family unit is a cause of poverty and social distress. Let us stop the libertarian policies proposed by the liberal social ideology that destroys natural solidarity.  It is the same machine that lets foreign speculators blow up the price of real estate and opens the doors of Europe to millions of illegal immigrants, without reducing poverty in our own neighbourhood.  Let's address the causes before we deal with the consequences.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: Mr President, 120 million Europeans are at risk of falling into poverty and 19 million Europeans are not hungry. The first tool we have at European level to help these people integrate is the European Social Fund, which enables professional integration. That is why, Commissioner, at the time of the review of multi-year policies mid-term, I am counting on your support to increase the share of cohesion funds earmarked for the Benefit of the European Social Fund from 23% to 25%. That is absolutely essential; it is the first aid that can be given to all those people who are at risk of falling into poverty. The second point is to sanctified 20% of the European Social Fund to help the poorest and poorest. The third point is that we should keep the aid fund for the poorest, because the heads of state and government were wrong to want to abolish these European policies.

name: Maria ARENA
text: Mr President, fighting poverty is above all about ensuring that Europeans do not fall into poverty. I therefore think it is important to talk about equality policies in the fight against poverty and, in particular, policies for redistribution of wealth. Here in this Parliament, we have been working on the issue of fairer taxation, a fight against tax evasion, a fight against tax avoidance that would allow for more robust state budgets. More robust state budgets allow for social security policies that are the best bulwark against poverty. When we have a social security system that guarantees a quality pension, that guarantees quality health care, that guarantees quality education, we have the guarantee that people do not fall into poverty.  Unfortunately, austerity policies have chosen the perspective of reducing spending. I think we need to learn from our mistakes and move towards policies that are revenue-enhancing policies and therefore fairer taxation.

name: Yana TOOM
text: – Mr President, I would like to highlight the importance of one of the key recommendations of the report, which concerns the winter heating disconnection moratorium. In my native Estonia, winters are rather cold – minus 20° Celsius is quite normal for us. This year, winter was even colder than usual. However, in the city of Kohtla-Järve, the residents of several apartment buildings were left without heat due to debts due to the local utility company. Low temperatures also caused damage to central heating radiators, and water pipes froze. People in Kohtla-Järve were lucky because local authorities were able to offer them social housing. This opportunity does not exist in practice in many Estonian municipalities. This is only one incident which has happened in Estonia this year. However, similar incidents were reported in many other European countries. The winter heating disconnection is often immoral, but it may, in many cases, also lead to human rights violations – not only the right to housing, but under some circumstances it may also violate the right to health and the right to life. Without doubt, the moratorium will help us to save people’s lives, health and property.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: – Mr President, when 122 million people, of European citizens, live in poverty, or at risk of poverty and social exclusion, the European project itself is at risk. The objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy are very ambitious and very well on paper, but they are of little use if, as in reality, Europe's orders are increasingly cuts and more austerity, which are the cause of poverty and inequality being triggered. It is necessary to stop the spiral of poverty suffered by so many European citizens, ensuring, for example, that vulnerable households have the minimum inputs of gas, electricity and water, or have a guaranteed income sufficient to live, for the needs of their families; or with green economy projects that generate jobs, such as thermal insulation of homes and are also environmentally friendly. If you tell me where we get money for all these things, I will tell you that tax evasion and evasion take a billion euros in Europe and in the case of my country, in Spain, they account for 56% of gross domestic product. It is a disgrace that Europe continues to cut into a social state and call for sacrifices from citizens as money escapes through the black holes of the privileged.

name: Karima DELLI
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the months are passing and our objectives of reducing the fight against poverty are always a little further away. What a shame! From 2008 to 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty or exclusion in the EU rose from 117 million to 123 million, despite the target of reducing it by at least 20 million by 2020. The situation in terms of energy insecurity is dramatic. It is estimated that more than 50 million Europeans are unable to pay their water and electricity bills.  To answer this question, yes, we need a European observatory of precariousness that sheds light on the social reality of this invisible suffering of energy poverty. Yes, it takes real financial investments to invest, in particular, in old buildings. This will reduce household energy bills, but also limit greenhouse gases and, icing on the cake, will allow us to create jobs that can't be relocated. So, Commissioner, in a context where the price of energy is about to explode, your role is twofold. First of all, you must encourage Member States to define what energy insecurity is, and thus to improve the performance of energy-intensive buildings, with long-term financial levers. The second thing, Commissioner, is to put in place measures that reduce energy costs for the most vulnerable households.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: – Mr President, in this very important and informative report there is one specific call to the Commission regarding the fund for European aid to the most deprived and the European Social Fund. The report asks for these two funds, as very important instruments, to be focused on alleviating a totally unacceptable situation. Can you tell us, Madam Commissioner, in the context of the review of the multiannual financial framework, what you are prepared to do to see that these funds are not only maintained but to ensure a very serious increase in both the resources and the implementing measures, so that there is the beginning of a change in the situation which we are now registering of more than 5 million people being added to the ranks of those at risk in poverty and all these totally unthinkable statistics about people freezing to death and not being able to pay their bills?

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on his work. Millions of Europeans are poor, people in unemployment, precarious workers, pensioners, young people and women. In short, the working majority live with concern and fear without knowing how they will get to the end of the month. The damage caused by their policies of permanent austerity to our social fabric, to our productive model is profound, but we must not resign ourselves: let us demand the right to a dignified life, to work with rights; job sharing, decent wages and collective bargaining are key to securing work, bread and roof.  The creation of a minimum income system that complements social protection and ensures an individual income of at least 60% of each State's median income, as requested in the report, is also essential. The Commission must already draw up a minimum income framework directive in the direction pointed out by the European Economic and Social Committee and other active actors in the fight against poverty. Only with another social model is it possible to end inequality and poverty in Europe. Today in Spain we remember precisely those who fought for a different social model, for a republic of workers. Cheers and Republic!

name: Arne GERICKE
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take back from the ECR Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the "Money, money, money, must be funny in a rich man's world" – a song you all know – "All the things I could do if I had a little money". Above all, many families in Europe are aware of the situation. Rising household costs that eat holes in the wallets. I do not need to explain why families in particular are affected. More family members means higher household costs. I am therefore pleased that, in the course of the negotiations, the concept of family has been included in the report on several occasions. We have to call that by its name. We must also say that poverty also arises on the revenue side. If families lack the money today, it is also because they have too little income. I therefore call for a national level of education for mothers and fathers. Household costs are more than just energy. At the same time, here in the European Parliament, we must ensure that subsidiarity is recognised. Not everything we would like to improve in the interests of families can be decided here. Nevertheless, we must give impetus. European policy, not just in today's report, concerns families in Europe. That is why I want a comprehensive European family strategy. But back to the report and the available housing. It is good that we are talking about using EU funds for energy refurbishment of social housing and its new construction. Therefore, let us focus on what we Europeans can change in order to reduce the cost burden of families!

name: Marijana PETIR
text: - Mr. President, increasing incomes in households considered poor is one of the key elements of the EU strategy by 2020, but the economic crisis continues to leave one in six EU citizens in squalor or at risk of poverty, with women and children in particular vulnerable.  Therefore, job creation and minimum income are key instruments for ensuring a dignified life for citizens, regardless of the minimum wage or minimum pension, to which I call for and ask that it not be lower than the poverty threshold in any country. Reducing household costs can also help fight poverty. Reducing energy poverty can contribute to meeting the EU's energy climate policy targets by 2020 and improving social policy, in terms of increasing household energy efficiency.  No one should remain excluded and therefore a measure should be considered to impose a moratorium on the exclusion of heating in winter to the most vulnerable, in order to ensure that no household can be excluded from the energy grid during the winter.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, quality of life must be a primary concern for all those who make public policies at national and European level. Combating poverty, regional disparities, was the concern of the Commission and the Council but, unfortunately, the results are not what citizens expect. European funds dedicated to combating poverty have not achieved their goal, as long as the 2020 targets cannot be achieved. We have asked President Juncker that the European Fund for Strategic Investments also contain the geographical criterion, not only first come, first served. The EU Treaty clearly sets out objectives for eliminating regional disparities and social cohesion. Without large investments in poor areas we will not be able to achieve social cohesion. Citizens, especially those in Eastern Europe, need higher wage incomes, and this can only be achieved with well-paid jobs. We also need to think about high welfare for people with disabilities. It is a mistake to concentrate European funds only in rich areas, because this will increase social exclusion. The Commission says it has placed social equity at the centre, but in addition to declarations, we need a concrete plan of measures. Primary needs are not yet solved. This is what is waiting for citizens.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, Mrs Thyssen, we are talking about reducing energy poverty, at a time when in Greece, more than 100 000 households do not have electricity since they have been impoverished by the Memorandum. With the decisions of the troika, which is also involved in the Commission, the excise duty on heating oil has been increased and thousands of Greeks are frozen every winter.  The troika, Mrs Thyssen, these days is pushing for vat to be increased to 24% for electricity and gas. What do you have to say about all this? In Greece, poverty reaps our people. More than 40% of the population, because of the memorandum, lives below the poverty line. Yet the troika also demands further reductions in pensions. How will millions of pensioners who get under 800 euros live? As for the minimum guaranteed income, it applies in Greece to very few people, when three million Greeks live below the poverty line, when the unemployed have reached one and a half million.  And all this is demanded by the troika in which the troika, Mrs Thyssen, is also involved. Bilingualism must finally be stopped.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, poverty demands from the authorities, and especially european political leaders, the courage to change the angle from which it has been seen. It requires a paradigm shift.  In fact, poverty is not just an economic problem. It is, above all, a qualified violation of human rights. It hurts its victims at the fundamental core, at the heart of their rights: that is, the dignity of human persons.  The first change that is needed today in the European Union itself is that it does not distinguish between those refugees fleeing war and political violence and those fleeing poverty and poverty and disease, epidemics of deadly diseases. All of them impose on us the fundamental duty of solidarity.  Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it is in poverty and misery that extreme forms of violence are born.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE/NGL). Mr President, today we are discussing poverty reduction in the European Union, but the reality is that poverty is constantly increasing because of the economic crisis and the austerity policies that are being pursued. What is worse, however, is that there are chaotic differences between Member States in the percentages of the population living below the poverty line.  These gaps widen over time, as the traditional economic lag of the Eastern European states is added to the ever-worse poverty of the Mediterranean South and a large proportion of the population in countries such as Ireland. Instead of convergence, we have a divergence, both between member states and within European societies. And this threatens to derail the process of European unification.  We need an increase in the Union's budget so that it can be financed by this pan-European minimum guaranteed income programme, through the imposition of a pan-European tax on stock exchange transactions and remittances to so-called tax havens.

name: Bronis ROPĖ
text: – Colleagues, the report by Tamás Meszerics, is an excellent example of the European Parliament taking up a debate on a problem that directly affects millions of our poor citizens. I would like to welcome the fact that Lithuanian legislation prohibits the disconnection of heating, as does cold water for residents. There is also a system of benefits in our country that reimburses heating costs. This is especially important given that about ten percent of their income is paid for by Lithuanians for heating. It is also important that the report calls for a minimum income for Europe. Of course, this needs to be done as soon as possible by linking income to the price index. I do not know why this has not been done so far. Perhaps because this would make it easy to make sure that many European citizens are in poverty, because their incomes are incredibly low. The European Union is investing heavily in poverty reduction in other countries, and I think it is high time that investment was directed to Europe itself.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you for what has been a very rich discussion. It has demonstrated our strong commitment, our joint commitment, to the fight against poverty and to making the Europe 2020 social goals a reality on the ground. The discussion has also highlighted the enormous toll that the crisis has had on our societies. There are some signs of stabilisation, and if we mobilise our energy we can still make real progress. Now more than ever we need to join forces and focus on the delivery of the strategy in a holistic way. Let me repeat that this Commission has set itself a clear ambition: a Europe worthy of a social triple A. This implies that social considerations have to be properly taken up across all policy domains. It implies that the welfare of people in Europe and the improvement of their everyday lives have to be at the heart of policy-making, and this is what we have set out to do. The focus of the Energy Union on addressing energy poverty is a concrete way of delivering on this commitment. It is clear that if we are to reach our ambitious social goals we cannot afford ‘business as usual’ thinking. We need a forward-looking approach investing in the skills that people and businesses need. We also need our social protection systems to be fair and adequate and to perform well – for men and women alike. The European pillar of social rights reflects this approach. Adequate and sustainable social protection is one of the three major headings of this pillar. Minimum-income schemes and access to housing, as part of the social protection system, have been included among the twenty policy domains, as have gender equality and work-life balance. President Juncker and I share the ambition of promoting and enriching the debate on these matters in your constituencies. Thank you very much, and let us continue to cooperate.

name: Tamás MESZERICS
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to assure the Commissioner that as long as the House passes this report, she can count on my cooperation with her at any time on any elements of the question. This was indeed a rich and thoughtful debate. I regularly learn a lot in this House, and this was one of those occasions. I would like to thank everyone who contributed. There is only one element that I would like to raise from the report, which has not been directly addressed so far, which is that on the energy poverty side we have a clear technical problem: we do not have a common definition. I would very much like the House to understand that, without having a common definition with which we can compare the situation across the board, we are not going to be able to tackle the problem seriously. It is the necessary beginning of the long, hard work that is needed on this. I would say to my colleague from the EFDD, who may already have left, that he might have been less surprised by the tone and the elements of this report had he been consulting his Group’s own shadow rapporteur, who did not find elements of the text to be part of a Communist manifesto. I would also say to my colleague, Mrs Morvai, that we agree that austerity measures do contribute to poverty, but such austerity measures are introduced and actually practised at Member State level. It is Member State governments which are responsible for the austerity measures most of the time. Therefore, much of the increase in poverty is also the responsibility of the Member States’ governments. Thank you again for your contributions. I hope that you will vote for the report in plenary.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 April 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. – This report aims to link social policy and energy policy in discussions at European level. The Communication from the Commission is a first step towards a European Pillar of Social Rights in order to strengthen the European social dimension through an integrated approach, modernising existing legislation and considering new measures to support greater coherence over time. More social commitments from the EU are a long-term unrealised political promise, so by creating a minimum income system and further improving social and labour rights and anti-discrimination legislation, the EU can aim to move to the next level of integration. Raising incomes for poor households is one of the most important aspects of the success of the Europe 2020 strategy and the fight against poverty for two of the following reasons: Since the onset of the crisis, inequalities in the EU have been increasing and one in six EU citizens are still living in poverty or are in the likelihood of experiencing it. The second pillar of the fight against poverty, especially extreme poverty, is effective reduction of household spending, better targeting of various funds for the most vulnerable households and removing obstacles to the effective absorption of resources. Better allocation of EU funds to households in energy poverty would also bring them closer to achieving these objectives. The initiative introduces the concept of a European winter heating cut-off moratorium, thus protecting households or households already experiencing energy poverty, which may be interrupted by public utility payments.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: in writing. – In the current economic and financial crisis, there are many families at European Union level who are having difficulty finding decent housing or keeping the home in which they live. It is important that the fundamental right of all European citizens to access decent housing as a precondition for human dignity is respected. As such, I believe that there must be as close as possible cooperation between the Commission and the Member States so that European citizens can rent housing at affordable prices, especially for low-income people. The social housing system for these people must allow for a sufficient number of affordable housing, and adequate social protection is essential in order to achieve the objective of reducing social exclusion, participation in society and greater equal opportunities. On the other hand, Europe needs adequate long-term housing and community policies on the existence of a system of quality housing, linked to reasonable rental policies when urgent social measures are needed.

name: Enrico GASBARRA
text: in writing. Today, however, there is a painful increase in the number of citizens in increasingly precarious economic and social conditions, undoubtedly due to the rampant economic crisis that has affected much of Europe and the austerity policies that have exacerbated many already particularly difficult conditions.  I firmly believe that, in order to deal with such an urgency, it is necessary to activate several channels, developing new dynamics and commitments that leverage wider, solid and integrated investments between the various specific actions, including alternative and combined measures to support the creation of a new European pillar of social law. I would like to refer, for example, to the increase in targeted support for people living in poverty, guaranteed minimum income measures, adequate health care and housing policies for the most at-risk groups, extension of the duration of the European Aid Fund for the most deprived, and support for social objectives in energy policy, ensuring not only environmental protection measures through the use of renewable sources of energy. , but also a further commitment to poverty prevention thanks to the commitment to the introduction of a possible European moratorium on the suspension of heating in winter for families in particular economic difficulties.

name: Filiz HYUSMENOVA
text: in writing. – Dear Mr President, Dear Colleagues, in the context of the economic situation in the EU, it is becoming increasingly difficult to talk about fighting poverty. In recent years, the cost of the most necessary goods and services has risen sharply. For countries such as Bulgaria, where living standards are much lower than the EU average, this has led not only to an increase in the cost of families, but to the inability to use basic utilities such as heating, transport, healthcare. The long-term unemployed and the elderly have been particularly affected. We must also add high levels of youth unemployment to them.  In order to achieve the Europe 2020 targets for reducing the number of people affected by poverty and social exclusion, we need bold measures, but also the share in practice. Member States need to make more effective use of the European Structural and Investment Funds to tackle energy poverty, expand the Fund to support the most deprived and develop active employment policies. Last but not least, there is a need to develop 21st-century skills among young people, training in entrepreneurship and improving awareness of launching and financing their own initiatives, as well as reducing the administrative burden on them, because only through a strong and functioning economy can we achieve the objective of combating poverty.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: Writing. – The European Parliament blames high overhead costs for the fight against poverty and notes that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States. Hungary, thanks to the success of the reduction in overheads, is among these countries, and it is therefore welcome that the report calls for the exchange of best practices between EU countries, following my amendment.  In accepting my amendment, the report also calls for the Commission to give Member States more flexibility in the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can use EU funds more specifically to reduce energy poverty or improve housing conditions. I must point out that, in line with the report, which urges Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, the Warm at Home programme will continue in Hungary, with the Ministry of National Development providing a grant of HUF 5 billion for the energy modernisation and renovation of family homes.  I think it is important to draw attention to the need, in parallel with the reduction in overheads, to provide consumption incentives to increase resources for durable goods or expenditure on domestic tourism. It is also important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it is essential to take into account the actual financial situation (home ownership, debts) rather than the current, partly self-declaration surveys.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. – The problem of energy poverty, to which the report commendingly devotes a great deal of space, is worth approaching from a different direction, from the point of access to fundamental rights. The process of legal extension cannot stop, economic and technological developments and the modernisation of society from time to time force the rethinking and supplementation of fundamental rights. For example, even in Europe, active and passive suffrage only became a universally recognised fundamental right in the second half of the 20th century.  I am convinced that the time has come to recognised access to energy, drinking water and the Internet as a fundamental right. Finland, Estonia, Greece, Spain, France, Belgium have already recognised one or the other as fundamental rights. This is not a function of financial opportunities, but rather of the political will of the extension of rights; India, Congo, Bolivia or Mexico, which are not at the forefront of the world in terms of GDP per capita, have also started to move in this direction. My party, the Democratic Coalition, has put in its programme the provision of a minimum amount of energy and drinking water, as well as the minimum bandwidth of internet access, free of charge to households in Hungary. South Africa provides 25 litres of water a day to all households free of charge, and in Belgium since 1997 the law has provided everyone with a minimum supply of water, electricity and natural gas free of charge.  In the near future, I would like to propose that the European Union also recognise access to energy, drinking water and the Internet as a fundamental right and call on the Member States to ensure a minimum of these public services free of charge.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: Written. "Heating costs are not the thing that revolves around the minds of a well-to-do citizen. Things are different in a poor household. Some time ago, Caruna, Finland's largest electricity transmission company, announced that it would increase prices by almost a third. It is a very big increase for an unemployed single parent or a single parent struggling with social assistance. It's paid for by pinching something else. Maybe food? Maybe clothes?  There are many good ideas in this Meszerics report. However, it contains few solutions that can eradicate poverty in the long term. The fact that the state is interfering in the relationship between the heat supplier and the client, or that EU funds are supporting the fall in household expenditure, is not a long-term solution to poverty. A more holistic vision is needed on how to tackle the root causes of poverty – such as poorly functioning labour markets and weak demand.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: Writing. – The 2020 strategy also has one of five measurable targets for reducing poverty, so we cannot pretend that this does not concern us, because it is energy poverty that is becoming an increasingly widespread problem in Europe. According to statistics, it affects up to 100 million Europeans, which is one in five citizens, which is why, with the EP resolution, we called on the Commission and the Member States to sign a memorandum and adopt the concept of a European memorandum in order to avoid disconnection from heating in winter to protect households that are already without energy or at risk of being disconnected from services due to energy arrears. Furthermore, in order to ensure more efficient, targeted and thorough monitoring of the use of structural funds in order to combat energy poverty, such as the warming of buildings, more efficient use of energy in apartments. At the same time, we called on the Commission and the Member States to devote the summit to the topic of poverty reduction and extreme poverty, and social exclusion and access to decent living standards. Individual Member States must adopt more comprehensive programmes at national and regional levels, as well as by using the European Structural Funds to reduce poverty and, above all, to support the most vulnerable sections of the population: children, the elderly, women and single mothers.

name: Jutta STEINRUCK
text: Writing. – In many Member States, social security and social protection systems have been severely undermined by budget cuts. Financially weak groups such as the unemployed, students, single parents, low-income families, widows or permanently ill people suffer particularly from high living costs. We therefore need a more efficient and targeted use of the European Structural and Investment Funds (ESIF) in order to tackle energy poverty effectively. The Socialists and Democrats have pointed out in their amendments that, in its resolution of 20 November 2012 entitled 'Towards a genuine economic and monetary union', the European Parliament has already called for a social pact for Europe as the fifth pillar of EMU, in order, among other things, to promote adequate living wage with a minimum income. The Socialists and Democrats also call for a "Social Progress Index" to include binding targets on social inequality in the Europe 2020 strategy and the Annual Growth Survey (JWB).

name: Romana TOMC
text: Writing. – When we talk about energy poverty, we must be aware that the latter is closely linked to general poverty. I believe that our objective, set out in the Europe 2020 Strategy, is becoming increasingly unattainable. This means that we must re-commit to the objectives already set and try to reduce the number of households affected by energy poverty. We must promote and supervise the purposeful use of the European Structural and Investment Funds in the Member States and ensure that stronger links between the market and sustainable energy investments are made. I also believe that we should increase investment in research into renewable energy sources. I would particularly like to highlight poverty among women. There are 12 million more poor women in the EU than poor men, which also put children at greater risk of poverty and social exclusion, especially in single-parent families. I therefore welcome the FEMM committee's proposal to include a pillar to address gender equality in the European Semester. I believe that it would provide for more ambitious action to tackle energy poverty, which disproportionately affects single women, single-parent households and women-led households.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: Writing. We are talking today about achieving the objective of combating poverty in view of the rising budgetary costs. I just say: everyone would be better off if fewer politicians were concerned about poverty reduction. What is causing rising budgetary costs? Electricity is unaffordable due to the energy transition, and VAT rates know only one direction: upwards. And the number of unnecessary state services is increasing – I am thinking only of the GEZ, that is, the cost of unsolicited state television. All of this has to be paid for by households because politicians have been thinking about what the state could still do. To think now about why household costs are rising is hypocritical at worst, at best blind to what you are doing. Let the people decide for themselves, let us tighten the belt of the state – and do so as quickly as possible. If we cut back on civil servants, we will reduce the expenditure. Then we can reduce taxes and levies, then vital goods become cheaper, then people will have more of their income from work. Labour must be worthwhile – but Germany has the world's third-highest taxes and taxes on income. We need to correct this so that people are able to live their lives as they wish.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the short presentation of the report by Nirj Deva, on behalf of the Committee on Development, on the Private Sector and Development (2014/2205(INI)) (A8-0043/2016).

name: Nirj DEVA
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, my report on the private sector in development breaks new ground. It provides a solution to the huge financial shortfalls in funding created by the development agenda for the next 15 years. The success of the millennium development goals in the past 15 years has provided ample evidence of how to get it right in the next 15 years, but one billion people still live on less than USD 1.25 per day and more than 800 million people do not have enough food to eat. Poverty is not eliminated by hand-outs. It is only wealth creation that ends poverty. We have 15 years to fix that with the new 17 sustainable development goals announced at the United Nations last year. But how can we fund this? Lofty ambitions to end poverty in all its forms everywhere come with a huge price tag. Climate change mitigation alone will cost USD 250 billion. The United Nations Conference on Trade and Development projects a funding gap – yes, I repeat, a funding gap – of USD 2.5 trillion for the sustainable development goals. This is a staggering sum, a sum that is beyond comprehension to our European taxpayers, a sum that the already struggling European taxpayer cannot even begin to shoulder. My report highlights that such a funding shortfall can be adequately met only if the private sector is involved in development, not through more taxes, but through partnership. But first we have to end the tax fraud in developing countries, which accounts for losses of nearly 1 trillion annually through illicit funding. Money that should stay in those countries is brought to Europe and other offshore accounts and hidden away by the elite of those countries. We have to make sure that those funds stay in those countries to be used for the development of those countries. Secondly, we have to demand that the OECD members match their 1970 pledge of 0.7% of GNI. Thirdly, the sustainable development goals will require the drive, the managerial skill and the commitment of our private sector partners, for it is the private sector which creates 90% of jobs and income for poor people in developing countries, alongside donors, civil society and trade partners. Fourthly, public-private partnerships must mobilise long-term – not short-term – private finance and hold the private sector accountable to public sector tendering processes, transparency and scrutiny. So this report calls for the private sector to invest in building and running schools; digging for wells and irrigating agriculture; building, running and maintaining hospitals and hospital services; building, owning, and operating roads, airports, and harbours; and setting up meat-, fruit- and vegetable-processing factories, all of which will create jobs and wealth in the developing countries, done in partnership with the public sector and pump-primed by EU development assistance. If we mean to offer the billion people still living in abject poverty the dignity of work and of earning a living wage, then we must seize this opportunity before us now and get on with it. I therefore commend this report to Parliament and, in doing so, I want to thank my colleagues in the Development Committee from all the political groups who have assisted and supported me in this, and I particularly thank Ms Ingrid Russell, my research assistant, for doing all the hard work.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: – Mr President, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur The private sector accounts for more than 80% of developing countries' GDP. This is the key to economic growth, trade development and innovation. However, local businesses often face challenges such as poor infrastructure and a lack of funding. Therefore, companies investing in these countries must be aware of social responsibility and act in a way that promotes sustainable economic growth and job creation, m.in the specificities of the conditions.  It is worth investing in regions where the potential for poverty reduction is highest, but without harming the environment. Building local capacity through education is beneficial for both sides: companies gain trained workers, giving them the chance to improve their living conditions. European companies should comply with established international standards wherever they operate. In this context, it is important to ensure that, in the event of abuse, victims have the right to compensation and access to justice in the country where the company took action.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: – Mr President, I would first like to congratulate the rapporteur. I believe and argue that the private sector is the only solution to combating poverty. The Sustainable Development Goals - sure, there are 17, the rapporteur said - but we need to see the results. SMEs in Europe are still fragile, poorly capitalised and without the power of innovation and retrofitting. Funding deficiency can be compensated by lowering tax pressure and eliminating tax fraud - we see what happens to the Panama phenomenon. Why couldn't fraud be eliminated and fiscal pressure low? Public-private partnerships are extremely important for the private sector. Creates added value and jobs. Poverty is directly linked to private sector development. Member States and the Commission must understand that supporting the private sector does not mean bringing money into people's pockets, but means the economic development of each Member State.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Mr President, the report continues the European Union's strategy in developing countries. A strategic copy of the neo-colonial policy distinguished by utilitarianism, from a cavalier approach that predisposes the world to a recipe for development to western European standards. But this model now also works in Europe itself. The only innovation of the report is that the private sector is now taking a leading role in investment, at the risk of losing full public control over the activities of European companies in third countries.  The Panama Papers have proved, once again, that multinational companies operate in a way that creates particular problems. Their investments in developing countries do not solve the problem of underdevelopment, but instead exacerbate it, while remaining blind, as companies and actions, to the ecological crisis, which also increases migration flows in the European Union to unmanageable levels.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: – Mr President, it is very clear that there is a huge financing gap for development. So, in addition to official development assistance, the private sector must be mobilised for development and solving global challenges. I think that, at best, an environment which is conducive to the private sector and business is one where good governance, accountability and transparency rules and which is predictable for all. However, I believe that, when enterprises enter into the field of development, they have to be practising due diligence, so that they really understand the conditions on the ground; that what they are doing has to be genuinely in favour of alleviating poverty, addressing climate change and creating local livelihoods, in a sustainable way, and also respecting the rights of indigenous peoples and women, etc.  I believe that, if we come to this kind of communication between the private sector and other development actors, we can really achieve something.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Mr Deva. Let me briefly outline to you three different models for alleviating poverty in the developing world and providing jobs: firstly, big Western investors, including multinationals, going to the area, utilising their agricultural land and natural resources and providing jobs for local people; secondly, lots of food, dumping on local markets and therefore preventing local farmers from growing; and thirdly, supporting local small and medium-sized enterprises and local farmers. Which of the three would you prefer and support?

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, it is with pleasure that I welcome the report on the private sector and development. It is a significant contribution to a full and coherent expression of the European Union’s institutions on the importance of the private sector’s role in development. The report reflects the priorities and challenges identified in the 2014 Commission communication, ‘A stronger role of the private sector in achieving inclusive and sustainable growth in developing countries’, and in the Council conclusions of June and December 2014. The main challenge in our cooperation with developing countries remains achieving inclusive and sustainable growth and creating decent jobs. For example, as it is expected that Africa’s population will double by 2050, we need to help it create at least 400 million new jobs. This requires sustainable investment to diversify our partners’ economies and link them to global value chains. Official development assistance is essential but not enough. Domestic resource mobilisation is key, and we must also catalyse private funding flows. The European Union blending framework is a successful tool for achieving European Union external policy objectives by leveraging public and private funds. Discussions in the EU platform for blending, involving the European Parliament, include exchanges on the issue of private sector engagement in blending. In this context, Mr President, I expect that, from the programmed resources for the 2014-2020 period, EUR 4.8 billion of EU grants could leverage at least EUR 66 billion in investments from financial institutions and private investors in partner countries in sub-Saharan Africa, Asia and Latin America. The Commission remains committed to ensuring and enhancing the local ownership of blended projects by involving partner countries and regional organisations. This strategy would be implemented also through innovative instruments such as ‘electrify’ or ‘agrify’ initiatives, which have been developed to promote private sector investments in rural electrification and agriculture. Structured dialogue and multi-stakeholder approaches with the private sector and civil society organisations are key elements in our strategy. We need partnerships that encourage businesses to put sustainability at the core of their strategies and to promote innovative, inclusive business models.
