The Commission will invest over EUR 2 billion to support global private sector development and facilitate responsible and inclusive partner sector investment in development by 2020. The Commission will implement this strategy through national and regional indicative programmes and through thematic programmes. European economic diplomacy can help mobilise European investments, with mutual benefits for the sending and receiving countries in terms of growth and jobs. The necessary support would be needed to allow these investments also to take place in economically riskier and emerging parts of the world. The intervention of the private sector is also crucial for the transformational objectives of the Social Development Goals and the climate change commitments. In this regard, coordination with the EU Member States and respect for the principle of subsidiarity are important elements of the Commission’s approach, fully in line with the SDGs and the Addis Ababa Action Agenda. The private sector is sending signals that it is ready to work with us to become a true financing and implementing partner in achieving sustainable growth in developing countries. I urge you to help seize this opportunity.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: That concludes the point. The vote will take place on Thursday, 14 April 2016. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. – The private sector plays a crucial role in development. I believe that the private sector’s central focus in development should regard poverty reduction and diminishing income inequality. However, there are other areas in which the private sector’s expertise and effectiveness are needed, such as climate change.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is the debate on seven motions for resolutions on Pakistan, in particular the attack on Lahore.

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Mr President, I am speaking today in my capacity as Chair of the Delegation for countries of South Asia, and I want to add my condolences and those of the delegation to the families and loved ones of those killed in the recent atrocity in Lahore, designed to attack children and families on the Easter public holiday, and also condolences for other recent attacks. We have been seeing an overall decrease in such attacks by violent extremists and have seen a more consistent and coordinated effort from the government and the army, and it is essential that they work together. We welcome the government’s commitment to reform the education system and curriculum to engender a wider understanding of human rights and respect for diversity. We welcome, too, the further commitments in terms of equality before the law and the promotion of human rights, which of course will need a strong and fully-independent human rights commission, as well as the implementation of the conventions that the government has signed up to, not least as part of the GSP+ agreement. We also hope that we will see a reconsideration of the death penalty and its eventual abolition.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: author. – Mr President, we are worried about the continuing violence and acts of terror in Pakistan, a great and important country and partner of the EU. The massacre on 27 March in Lahore targeted Christians, but most of the victims were Muslims. Our sympathy goes to them all. However, Lahore is not an exception. There are systemic violations of freedom of religion under which Christians, Ahmadis, Shia, Hindus and others are suffering. Outbursts of hatred and violence against minorities often find justification in discriminatory laws. It is especially crucial that we stabilise the situation of religious minorities by the revision of so-called blasphemy laws. The tragedy of Asia Bibi, the only woman who has been sentenced to death under the blasphemy law, is symbolic. She has been waiting on death row for six years now. Therefore, we call urgently on the Pakistani authorities to ensure a swift delivery of justice in her case. The situation of religious minorities is our shared concern, and I also call on High Representative Mogherini to fully engage with the Government of Pakistan in its efforts to eradicate intolerance and terrorism.

name: Charles TANNOCK
text: author. – Mr President, for those belonging to religious minority communities in Pakistan, life can be very difficult. This is true for the Shias, the Ahmadis, the Hindus and especially Christians. The horrifying terrorist attack in Lahore on Easter Day is sadly not an isolated incident and deserves our full condemnation in this House. Whilst it would be unfair to say that no action has been taken, I do call today upon the Pakistani Government to do more to foster an atmosphere of tolerance and respect for all communities. Part of the problem is the apparent inability to confront Pakistan’s deeply troubling legislation on religion, such as the blasphemy laws and the Hudood Ordinances – laws that should be repealed as a matter of priority. Salman Taseer, the assassinated politician who called for the abolition of the blasphemy laws and paid with his life for doing so, is much revered by many in Pakistan, but it is clear to me that the country is still infected by undercurrents of extremism. We have debated religious extremism and intolerance in Pakistan in this House on many occasions, and I really hope now that there is the will in that country and its Government for some change.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Mr President, I would like to thank the This is not the first time that we have dealt with Pakistan in the topical and urgent debate in this House. The focus is always on religious intolerance. The Taliban is a terrorist sect that threatens anything that stands in the way of their crazy interpretations of Islam. Alleged deviations from Islam and above all members of other religions are the target of their attacks. On Easter Sunday in Lahore, where people came together peacefully, Christians were the target. Among the victims were many others, Muslims were in the majority. This form of violence is abhorrent and criminal. We must do everything we can to ward off this threat, and we expect Pakistan to take a more rigorous approach to these terrorist groups.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: Author. Madam President, the attack in a park in Lahore killed 72 people, including 29 children, and injured more than 300.  The perpetrators of this horror claimed to be aimed at Christians, but the victims were predominantly Muslim. Fifteen days earlier, Shiite mosques were targeted. In Pakistan, it is an understatement to say that political and religious tensions are high. These tensions are rooted in the dangerous game of some Gulf countries, but also of the Pakistani government, which have supported or even financed terrorist groups that are now largely out of control. The current awareness is unfortunately accompanied by authoritarian excesses: the restoration of the death penalty, including for minors, the establishment of exceptional courts, abuses, blasphemy law against minorities, but also against progressives and journalists. Pakistan's accession to the GSP should be a negotiating tool in the hands of the European Union to stem this spiral of repression. More broadly, pakistan's historical role in destabilizing the region is well known. Current developments can make a difference; the European Union can help move things in the right direction.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: author. – Madam President, the Lahore attacks were a vicious and despicable assault on the people of Pakistan, and today the European Parliament sends its deepest condolences and support to the families of those that have lost their beloved and also to the hundreds of injured and their families. Unfortunately, this is only one more deadly attack in a long series, and there are no signs of improvement in the region. It is now urgent for Pakistan to face the reality and put an end to religious extremism and all kinds of radicalisation, otherwise we will be here again and again debating the situation in the country. That is why we call today on the Pakistani authorities to further engage in the ideological battle with extremism – the fight against terror – but also to tackle social economic exclusion and ensure religious tolerance. Let us be clear: Pakistan alone will not succeed. We need a strong engagement from all regional actors and the international community to significantly improve counter—terrorism cooperation. Finally, we Europeans also have an important role to play. That is why we call today on the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, the European External Action Service and the Council to fully engage with the Government of Pakistan in tackling the threat posed by terrorism and to further assist the Government and people of Pakistan in continuing their efforts to eradicate terrorism and radicalism.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, the Lahore bombing of 27 March, the day when most Christians celebrated Easter, was an horror. The main target was, of course, the Christian community. However, the victims belong to various religious communities in Pakistan. Religious extremism affects all Pakistanis in this way in equal measure. That is why I believe that the fight that the Government of Pakistan is waging against terrorism must be accompanied by a fight against religious extremism. As the recent bombing shows, pakistan needs to learn the lesson of tolerance towards minorities. All the more so because freedom of thought, conscience and religion are included in the Constitution of Pakistan. However, the so-called blasphemy law, under which Asia Bibi was also convicted, contradicts it. Our political group is calling for the liberation of Asia Bibi.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: – Madam President, as we feel the shock of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, let us recall that the Global Terrorism Index shows that only 0.5% of its victims are in Europe and the West, and that over 80% of the people killed by terrorists in the last five years have been Muslims. So we mourn the 72 victims in Lahore, terrorists who targeted a children’s playground at the height of holiday celebrations to inflict most harm on those who are most innocent. With all countries with whom we cooperate in fighting terrorism, we seek to uphold human rights and the rule of law, and we say the same to our friends in Pakistan in our resolution today. We oppose the death penalty and we ask Pakistan again to consider whether all executions are genuinely linked to terrorism, especially in the light of research from the Justice Project and from Reprieve that they are not. We call for clemency in the case of Abdul Basit, but we do so in steadfast opposition to terrorism and in full solidarity with Pakistan and all countries who suffer as its victims.

name: Bas BELDER
text: – A Pakistani Christian wrote to me this week: all hateful statements in Pakistani textbooks about Christians and other religious minorities in the country should be removed immediately. He is not right because, as the Bible says, hatred is the root of manslaughter, see the terrible attack in Lahore. Recent reports support the urgent warning against this mental poisoning of Pakistani youth. This brings me to a pressing question for the European Commission: will European money also go to the Pakistani education system and, if so, what demands does Brussels impose on this aid? We also leave out the more than twenty-four thousand madrassas, Islamic schools in the country, where hatred is often preached against Christians and other religious minorities in particular. Madam President, an inky black backdrop to the Lahore massacre!  Furthermore, I believe that Aisha Bibi and other falsely accused of blasphemy should be released and that the Pakistani government should be fully committed to their safety. [The speaker responds to a "blue card" question pursuant to Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure.]

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Madam President, besides the terrorist attacks in Pakistan, lots of people are leaving Pakistan; lots of migrants are coming to Europe from Pakistan besides Syrians, Afghans, and Iraqis. Do you not think that we should call on the Commission to enter into negotiations with the Pakistani Government in order to enable people to stay in their own country? The number of refugees and migrants from Pakistan is increasing daily.

name: Bas BELDER
text: "blue card" answer. For some time, I have been studying the situation in Pakistan, a country where there are even two states, the civilian government and the other, including military and terrorist organisations. The situation in Pakistan is therefore extremely urgent. The European Union and the European Parliament would do well to look at the real situation in Pakistanis, because this is a truly explosive situation!

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: - Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank you for your support. Let us be clear: in Pakistan, the attack on Easter targeted Christians on their religious holiday. With them and all other victims of religion who were at the scene, our deepest sympathies go out to the victims and their families. Innocently, they were murdered for one reason, tried by taliban killers to prevent them in their faith.  In Pakistan, the Taliban mentality, and radical movements in general, has been dramatically strengthened in recent years. We know that the government is making efforts, but it cannot control the escalating violence. There's hope, there's hope... As a result of this tragedy, a small but still existing movement, the Ruardari tehrík, was formed between Muslims and Christians, which means a movement for tolerance. Pakistan, Europe must do more and more to change this situation. Thank you for your attention.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: – Madam President, we strongly condemn the attack in Lahore and extend our deepest condolences to the families and friends of the victims. In the last three decades, the country has suffered immensely. Over 60 000 people have lost their lives and the loss to the economy is estimated to be over 110 billion. Pakistan is leading the fight against terrorism in the region. The EU and the international community need to support and acknowledge Pakistan’s overall progress in fighting terror. We have experienced the horrors of terrorism recently again in Paris and Brussels. Terrorism is a global problem. This is not a clash between different cultures or different faiths. This is simply extremists wanting to see other our societies break up, and creating division is what makes them strong. We need to work together to eradicate the root causes and prevent further radicalisation, stop terrorist financing and promote integration. EU and global leaders must now more than ever commit to offering support and assisting each other in defeating terrorism, and we must do so by promoting values of peace, freedom, human rights ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Amjad BASHIR
text: – Madam President, from Peshawar to Paris, from Brussels to Lahore, I have always been completely unambiguous in my condemnation of terrorism. They are inexcusable acts of barbarism that cannot be justified or explained in any way. The European Parliament’s response to the latest attacks in Pakistan should be no different. We should send a simple message, denouncing these crimes while expressing our solidarity with its people. There should be no strings attached. Unfortunately, some are using this opportunity to deliver a lengthy lecture to Pakistan on a wide range of domestic issues. Imagine if, in the wake of recent attacks in Europe, someone told us they felt sorry but our migrant policy and social integration failures were to blame for what had happened. We would not take kindly to it, and rightly so. Do not get me wrong: there is a time and place for socio-political debate on Pakistan, but now is not the time.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: – I welcome this resolution because it condemns the barbaric terrorist attack, which was largely the victim of Christians at Easter this year. Christians are the most persecuted group of people in the world. It is therefore a good thing that there is a voice in their defence from the Europe represented by the EP.  However, the purpose of these urgent resolutions is not to issue reports on the human rights or terrorist situation in a country, but to point out the current threat to specific persons. This objective is achieved in paragraph 9 of the resolution, where we draw attention once again to the case of Asia Bibi, who was sentenced to death not for terrorism, but for blasphemy. She has been waiting many years in prison for whether or not the sentence will be carried out.  In this context, it is to be hoped that the Pakistani Government's action plan to improve the protection of human rights will not remain on paper alone.

name: Sajjad KARIM
text: – Madam President, you are free to go to your temples or your mosques or any other places of worship in Pakistan. You may belong to any religion, caste, or creed: that has nothing to do with the State. Those are the founding principles of Pakistan to which we refer in our resolution. Every person killed, maimed or injured in these cowardly attacks in Lahore is a Pakistani. If we seek to split them into categories in our resolutions, we do a disservice to their memory. States and actors who support terrorist networks should know: slowly you are being exposed, your operatives are, and will be, captured, and eventually you will be exposed completely. When terrorists attack, be it in Paris or Peshawar, in London or Lahore, or indeed in Brussels, they attack us all, and we stand shoulder to shoulder as one to face them.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I naturally wanted to join in and thank you for all the speeches that have been strongly condemned to terrorism.  I also believe, however, that europe must issue a clear warning, namely that human rights must be defended not only on paper but also in practice. In the sense that we naturally appreciate the intentions of the Pakistani Government but, on the other hand, we expect concrete facts to show that respect for human rights is not only a statement of principle, but a fact of everyday life in Pakistan.  I am referring here not only to situations relating to religious discrimination but also to ethnic discrimination, because we must not forget – and I ask that Europe should be careful about this too – that there are situations such as that in Balochistan, where – also on the basis of many indications from Amnesty International – I believe that Europe must see us clearly , because it is a question of whether there really is discrimination that is not religious, but ethnic, but always discrimination is.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, the cowardly terrorist attacks on Christians on the Sunday of the Catholic Easter in Lahore remind us that Islamist terrorism is not only hitting Europe.  These attacks claimed the lives of more than seventy people, more than in the terrorist attacks in Brussels, however, this did not seem to be of particular interest to Europe. When the European Union fails to manage the displaced people of Syria's civil war, which is once twenty million, you understand what will happen if Pakistan destabilises its two hundred million inhabitants.  The possibility of generalised destabilisation in the Middle East and Central Asia must be prevented at all costs. For a start, the military interventions of foreigners will have to stop. Western services should also stop playing with fire, supporting Islamist organisations here and there, in the interests of short-term objectives.  Finally, all efforts that honestly attempt to overcome interfaith hatred and the rhetoric of cultural conflict should be supported.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, what happened in Pakistan on Easter Day is an attack, as we have seen, on Islamic terrorism. But once again in this House, with the exception of a few cases, we are afraid to say that it is Islamic terrorism.  There are people who kill Christians just because they're Christians. The same thing happens in Europe and what does Europe do? Nothing, look, he looks like a zombie looking around, but it's okay. Nothing will ever happen to the great European politicians, because the great European politicians are not going to the subways, they are not going to airports, where all the citizens pass, as we are. No, they have private aircraft, they operate in other ways and nothing happens to them, but what can happen to the citizens? Everything and more. And what do we do? Nothing. Europe does nothing, it cares highly, Christians continue to be affected and Islamic terrorists should also be punished with the death penalty. I say it again: even with the death penalty.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – I would like to say to my colleague that, as a European politician, I take the metro and also stand in line at the airport like any other EU citizen.  However, I consider it important that the EP will stand up against the terror that reigns against the religious groups that are persecuted in Pakistan, and that we call on the government in Pakistan to combat brutal violence more effectively.  Asia Bibi was mentioned here. We call for Asia Bibi to be released. It's a recurring challenge. Since 2010, Asia Bibi has been waiting for a decision on the death penalty, and we are against this death penalty because she is a woman who has done nothing but demonstrated her free faith and right to faith and her own religion, which is unfortunately persecuted in Pakistan.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: – Madam President, the Christian tradition of celebrating Easter turned into a tragedy when a suicide bomber killed more than 73 people, including 30 children. The attack on Christian families on Easter Sunday itself is further evidence of the extent of the immense hatred of Christians and the desire to exterminate them. In doing so, the extremists did not care what innocent Christians would suffer and innocent Muslims.  This gruesome slaughter, unfortunately, is just one in a series of attacks on Pakistani Christians. Christians make up only 2% of Pakistan's population, and attacks targeting Christians are increasing. The church in Lahore was already the target of extremist attacks last March when 17 people were killed.  This resolution is a small step towards raising awareness of what is happening, but it is not enough without effective action. Anti-extreme actions cannot depend on the borders and parts of the world where crimes occur. We must be united in protecting people's lives and protecting Christianity. I call on the Pakistani authorities to release Asia Bibi.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I think that the attacks in Brussels by the terrorists brought home to us what many people are suffering around the world. Whether it is in Brussels or Lahore, we obviously have to do everything we can to fight terrorism and also to try to win the ideological war against extremism, which is equally important. While the government in Pakistan is trying to introduce some reforms, particularly to ban child marriages and to protect women against all sorts of discrimination, we have to do far more to put pressure on these governments so as to ensure not only that there are reforms but that they are actually implemented. There is far too much discrimination, particularly against women, with women of minority religions being forced to convert to Islam and forced into marriage. We have a lot to do and we have to do everything we can to help.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the attack in Lahore on Easter Sunday, as in Peshawar in December 2014, targeted children – the most vulnerable members of society. The terrorists attacked the future of the country and its diversity. The Lahore attack aimed to kill members of the Christian minority, but it also killed many Muslims. The attack comes only two years after the deadly church bombings, also in Lahore. My colleague Federica Mogherini, the High Representative, in a statement extended her condolences to the families and friends of the victims and underlined our support to Pakistan in its fight against terrorism and in the promotion of our shared values, among which is diversity. We call on Pakistan to bring the perpetrators and instigators of these attacks to justice and to take firm action against the organisations that claim responsibility. We are very worried about the rising levels of religious violence and intolerance in some parts of Pakistan and we are closely monitoring these developments. Minorities in the country, including religious minorities, continue to suffer disproportionately and they are frequently targeted by extremist militants. We call on the government to step up efforts to ensure the security of all members of religious minorities. The 2016 GSP+ Report underscores that the human rights situation remains very challenging. We always raise human rights issues in our regular dialogue with Pakistan and encourage authorities to address the challenges, including those concerning the situation of minorities. The European Union regrets the lifting of the moratorium on the death penalty in Pakistan and the large number of executions this has led to. Pakistan is now the third largest executor. Just yesterday, four more prisoners convicted of murder were hanged. The European Union is opposed to capital punishment in all circumstances and has consistently called for its universal abolition. The European Union, in all its contacts with Pakistan, continues to underline the importance of reintroducing the moratorium on executions and of complying with the minimum standards. The European Union is also supporting several projects to improve awareness and protection of human rights, access to justice for vulnerable groups and to strengthen civil society organisations in Pakistan. The European Union bilateral development cooperation for the period 2014-2020 for Pakistan, with a total amount of EUR 635 million, has human rights and good governance as one of the three focal sectors. Human rights violations remain widespread in the country, despite some of the constructive initiatives underway. Pakistan has made some progress in strengthening the institutional framework for human rights, including by establishing a national commission for human rights. Furthermore, the government recently adopted an action plan to improve the human rights situation in Pakistan. The plan includes various measures, notably the development of a national plan of action for the promotion and protection of the rights of minorities. Some action has also been taken to address the widespread problem of hate speech. There have also been some advances on legislation to improve women’s rights. The European Union has also been calling for comprehensive action against terrorism, in full compliance with international law, fundamental values and international human rights standards. More emphasis will need to be put on the prevention of terrorism, in particular in the areas of countering radicalisation, recruitment and the financing of terrorism. Let me finally underline that the European Union has been, and remains, a staunch supporter of democracy and reform in Pakistan.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place today, Thursday, April 14, 2016.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The next item is a debate on seven motions for resolutions on the situation of human rights defenders in Honduras.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: Author. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We meet every month to talk about human rights, and this is the bright side of our Parliament, which has its drawbacks, but here we are together above political divisions and this is really a good showcase of our House. But I did not want to talk about us, but about people who are killed or persecuted for defending human rights, for defending the rights of Indians, they are both women and men. I think our voice here should sound particularly loud. We talked about the situation in Pakistan, about the situation of the Christians there. On other continents, specifically in Central America, such situations are also the case, and this resolution, which has been drafted beyond divisions, speaks of this.

name: Ulrike LUNACEK
text: Author. – Madam President, Commissioner, colleagues, visitors to the gallery, Honduras is a very beautiful country, but it is also known as one of the most violent countries in the world. Recent killings have caught the attention globally, and it must be acknowledged that the situation of violence and impunity has increased since the 2009 coup. In this resolution, we condemn the brutal massacre, on 3 March, of Berta Cáceres, an indigenous activist defending the environment, and also that of Nelson García, who was killed two weeks later, because they were fighting the Agua Zarca dam on the Gualcarque River. We also condemn the killing of one of the symbols of the LGBTI struggle, the transgender woman Paola Barraza, who was murdered on January 24. Today's resolution demands that the Honduran authorities deeply investigate all these killings and Honduran justice to impose a just condemnation on the perpetrators and also those who have ordered these murders. We want an independent international investigation, within the framework of the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights, and that the companies involved in large projects respect high social and ecological standards.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Honduras is a country in transition, unstable and far behind its capabilities. Human rights do not apply, the crime rate is high and there is no confidence in the judiciary. Against this background, a vibrant civil society is extremely important. But nowhere in the region is it more dangerous for human rights activists than in this country – whether they stand up for the rights of indigenous peoples, for the protection of the environment or against land grabs, for the rights of LGBT people, or for freedom of expression. There have been shocking cases of attacks on activists in recent months. These murders must be investigated, the perpetrators must be punished. Above all, however, we must encourage and support the government in developing an independent judicial system. The EU delegation in that country is very active in this area, and this is also very positive.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: Author. – I will be looking for my colleagues who have described the situation in Honduras well. I will only point out that this matter is current because a few weeks ago one of the key activists in the fight against large multinational supranational companies wanting to build a non-eological hydroelectric power plant in Honduras was murdered, and that was Berta Caceres, who was an internationally recognized activist, and she was the winner of international prizes. And although a few weeks ago the UN and the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights warned the Honduran government that this woman's life was in danger, unfortunately the Honduran police were unable to protect her and this woman was brutally murdered.  That is why this point is up to date today, and the Honduran authorities need to be called upon to investigate the matter, but above all to provide better protection for environmental and other activists in the future, as over 100 human rights activists have died in Honduras over the past few years.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: Author. – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin this speech by greeting the COPIN Congress, which is being held right now in Honduras. The murder of Berta Cáceres shows that Honduras is one of the most dangerous countries in the world for human rights defenders. Seven years after the coup d'etion in Honduras, the absence of democratic guarantees, fundamental freedoms and respect for human rights persists, as well as an alarming lack of political will to end impunity. The best tribute to Berta Cáceres and so many murdered activists is to follow her fight.  That is why we can not only and must demand an independent international investigation into its murder, but also the immediate paralysis of the Agua Zarca project and that the Council of the European Union does not apply to Honduras the Association Agreement with Central America as long as Honduras repeatedly fails to fulfil its human rights obligations.  From here I want to remind all the activists who are playing their lives to defend a decent future for their people and their people. From here, from Parliament, let it be heard: You are not alone!

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: Author. – Madam President, defending the environment and the rights of women, indigenous peoples and the LGBTI community comes at a high price in Honduras: death. A price paid by admirable activists such as Berta Cáceres, Nelson García, Paola Barraza and hundreds others killed in the last two decades. Certainly, Honduras is not an isolated case. In Mexico and Guatemala, the situation of impunity, vulnerability and persecution of human rights defenders is more than worrying, but denouncing the illegal and abusive practices of the hydroelectric, mining and agribusiness industry has become practically a death sentence in Honduras. The United Nations Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights were adopted five years ago to be implemented in all economic and trade agreements. Let us make these legally binding on companies and governments and be scrupulous in their compliance. Human rights defenders are the hope of Honduras, a country ravaged by violence and impunity. They are the engine of democratic change. Let us not forget for a second that it is our duty to protect them, and to do so we have committed ourselves. As Galeano said, "a lot of small people, in small places, doing small things, can change the world."

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – I am glad, for myself and for the European People's Party, that in the case of these two unscrepulous murders, the Honduran Government has proceeded very quickly in its investigation and is doing everything possible to catch the perpetrators, but above all to punish them.  I consider it essential that the Honduran Government did not rely on itself, but also invited representatives of the United States, the UNITED NATIONS and the Organisation of American States to participate in this process. By accepting the assistance of others, as in this case, the Honduran Government is very transparent, it will be able to implement more quickly all fundamental human rights, which unfortunately are not respected.  In this case, I must say that it is very important that such a procedure never happens again and that other activists who are fighting for human rights in Honduras do not pay for their fight with their own lives.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Madam President, "Berta Cáceres was an exceptional woman who fought for a better, more dignified, fairer Hondura for a country for all". These are the words of an old friend of his, Gustavo Castro, who first-handedly taught how unscrupulous gunmen ripped Berta's life, thus leaving orphans not only to his people, the Lenca, but to all those who defend human rights in Honduras, in the region and in the world.  Every time we lose someone like Berta Cáceres, a tireless fighter for the environment, for the rights of the most vulnerable – the world gets a little worse. Berta is a symbol that unfortunately represents the cruel end shared by hundreds of people both in her country and elsewhere in the world; people fighting for their land, for the rights of the most vulnerable, the rights of the LGBTI community, for freedom of expression and for the end of impunity. Berta died in La Esperanza. That's the name of the city where he lived. In the hope of getting a better Honduras.

name: Heidi HAUTALA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, the recent murder of Berta Cáceres, and its possible links to the Agua Zarca Dam project, highlight the need not only for better protection of human rights defenders but also for regulation for corporate responsibility for human rights, including the right of grievances when rights are violated. The project has been implemented without thorough consultation with the area’s indigenous Lenca population. A Finnish development finance company, Finnfund, is one of Agua Zarca’s funders. Finnfund claims to have carried out a due diligence process, but the question remains: why was the project considered to need  funding from Finnish development cooperation funds? It is good that Finnfund, along with several other funders, has now decided to freeze Agua Zarca’s funding for the time being. Possible continuation of the project should be treated with caution. Indeed, more needs to be done to ensure that business in developing countries is carried on in a responsible way that respects human rights.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: – Madam President, the rule of law, respect for human rights and tolerance of diversity are at stake in Honduras. This situation is unacceptable. It has to be denounced and fought.  The european parliament's frontal denunciation and position, taken in this resolution, is an important challenge for change. We cannot underestimate Europe's role as an ethical and legal reference in defending the basic rights of open and free peoples and societies. We must therefore consider in our economic partnerships how committed partners are to human rights and freedoms.  That is why this resolution cannot be exhausted on itself. It will have to have practical consequences if the Honduran government does not chill its way and does not guarantee the freedom of action of human rights defenders in their country.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the fight for human and environmental rights in Honduras is paying a heavy toll.  On 3 March, it was the activist Berta Cáceres. Berta Cáceres was working alongside honduras' peasant communities and indigenous movements in defense of human rights. According to the police, she died during an attempted robbery, but there is no doubt that she was killed for her social commitment. After her, other activists have been subjected to violence and the situation in the country is becoming increasingly dramatic.  According to the organization Global Witness, Honduras is the most dangerous state in the world for ecological activism. In recent years, several dozen people have lost their lives in Honduras in protest at the devastation of the territory sold off to multinationals. The Government of Honduras must commit itself to ensuring the safety of all human rights defenders, in particular those working in the field of environmental protection. Honduras must become a normal country and Europe must push for this to happen.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, in a country such as Honduras, with 22% illiteracy in rural areas and two thirds of its population living below the poverty line, human rights violations are, even today, a daily occurrence. Since the 2009 coup against Zelaya, rights violations and the climate of impunity have continued to grow in the country.  Moreover, this violation is being felt every day more and more. Especially with the murder of activist Berta Cáceres, who was a member of the popular opposition and a human rights defender in the country.  The European Union should therefore immediately take steps to stop the repression of human rights in Honduras, as well as to contribute to the investigation, in order to punish those responsible for the murder of Berta Cáceres and to stop the persecution of activists.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: – Madam President, the murder of Berta Cáceres did not cover the way, as permanent impunity in Honduras does not open up news, which, after the coup d'am to democratic President Manuel Zelaya, is now the most violent country in the world. More than sixty journalists killed since the coup, dozens of peasants, indigenous people, trade unionists, lawyers, LGTBI activists and women killed since 2009. Berta's case is doubly painful. They did not serve the protective measures requested by international organizations or the Inter-American System of Human Rights. We want an independent investigation, including those responsible and the company DESA. Impunity continues in Honduras, because murder comes out for free. The European Union should suspend agreements until this impunity is ended or at least show the same firmness as, impossed, it shows against countries such as Venezuela, where journalists and trade unionists are not killed and where those who do murder policemen or citizens are often beatings disguised as opposition.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we are dealing here with Honduras but, to my fellow Members themselves, I would like to ask: why is Europe doing business with China, when China makes all its colours and is not in a democracy?  Why have we made new agreements with Iran where homosexuals even hang? We have, among other things, a homosexual Italian Undersecretary who has now gone to Iran to shake hands, so he is a homosexual in Italy to take the money, evidently to be with the chair under his butt, and then he goes to Iran to shake hands with those who hang homosexuals. Or Saudi Arabia, but we do business with them. Now we are going to deal with Honduras, which then the UN said that the elections did them correctly, but what does Honduras have to do with it? You, depending on where you have to do business, then you talk about multinationals, but if it's full of multinational lobbyists out here and you go there and talk every holy day and then say that there are multinationals in Honduras that have to make dams, but you're hypocritical or what are you?

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the European Union was deeply saddened by the heinous killings in Honduras of human rights defenders Ms Berta Cáceres, Mr Nelson Garcia and LGBTI activist Paolo Barraza. Ms Cáceres was a prominent human rights defender, as we all know, and was very well known by the European Union for her courageous commitment in defending the environment and the indigenous rights of the Lenca community to which she belonged. In an immediate reaction to these odious murders, the European Union has called for a thorough, expedite and transparent investigation of the cases. It is of the utmost importance to give strong signals that impunity for these assassinations of human rights defenders will not prevail. The European Union continues to monitor with great attention the dire situation of indigenous leaders, members of the LGBTI community, journalists and justice officials who continue to be particularly affected by violations of human rights in the country. Precautionary measures granted by the Inter-American Commission on Human Rights should be immediately implemented to avoid any further killings. The situation also calls for an urgent implementation of the law to protect human rights defenders. The European Union has been very much involved in promoting this initiative through its Development Cooperation Programmes, which provided support for the drafting of the law. The overall human rights situation in Honduras remains characterised by widespread violence in which corruption and impunity play a considerable part. To address this, rapid progress should be made in the implementation of the recommendations issued in the Universal Periodic Review carried out in 2015, the vast majority of which have been accepted by Honduras. The Union also looks forward to the full operation of the office of the United Nations Human Rights Commissioner. The European Union has constantly advocated human rights and justice reforms in Honduras and stands ready to work together with the Honduran people to address these challenges. The Union and its Member States are the most important actors in development cooperation, including on human rights issues in the country. The European Union welcomes the recent agreement on the deployment of an Organisation of American States mission to support the fight against corruption and impunity in Honduras, known as MACCIH in its Spanish acronym, and the request for support from the Honduran authorities to this mission in the investigation of Mrs Berta Cáceres’s killing. In broader terms, the Union has taken proactive steps to protect human rights defenders worldwide. This includes the establishment, at the end of 2015, of a comprehensive human rights defender mechanism managed by a consortium of human rights NGOs which has now become fully operational.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate is over. The vote will take place today, 14 April 2016. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: in writing. – Human rights activism is a high-risk activity. The repression of activists takes various forms, from persecution, threats and smear campaigns to arbitrary arrests, torture, forced disappearances and homicides.  The situation of human rights defenders in Honduras is especially serious, as the regrettable murders of Berta Cáceres, Nelson Garcia and Paola Barraza remind us.  Despite some recent progress in legislation, in Honduras, as in Latin America in general, the rights defenders of indigenous peoples are the most at risk, often interfering with economic interests linked to extractive industries and the construction of large infrastructure.  I fully agree with the content of this resolution which, recalling the European Union Guidelines on human rights defenders, calls on the Honduran authorities to comply with the law and to ensure adequate protection for those who so altruistically defend the rights of others.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: Next item: debate on the 7 motions for resolutions on Nigeria.

name: Mark DEMESMAEKER
text: Author. – With its wealth of raw materials, Nigeria could be one of Africa's economic engines. We have heard president Buhari's ambitions here in this hemisphere when he gave his speech here in February. Unfortunately, the reality is different.  There is no prosperity, but poverty, environmental pollution, corruption, conflict and violence, the terror of Boko Haram, large-scale human rights violations. The various religious groups - Christians and Muslims - and the ethnic minorities are victims of it. I am therefore very grateful to all the members who have participated in an excellent joint resolution.  The Nigerian Constitution guarantees freedom of opinion and religion. It is the duty of the government to respect those rights and to protect its citizens. I therefore call on the President to step up the pace in the search for the kidnapped schoolgirls from Chibok. It is two years ago today that Boko Haram terrorists brutally snatched them from their families. These children belong to their parents, on the school benches, and not on the battlefield of Boko Haram!

name: Jean LAMBERT
text: author. – Madam President, as previous speakers have said: today is a day of reflection. It is the second anniversary of the abductions of the schoolgirls from Chibok and we are remembering them today, along with many others who have suffered at the hands of Boko Haram, and particularly the families of those whose fate is unknown. In responding to this, there is a great need for coordinated action both within the State of Nigeria itself and within the region. We know that there is real difficulty involved in deploying adequate state resources. Nigeria is a fossil-fuel-dependent economy. In our view it needs transition planning urgently, but prices have dropped; we know that there is gross inequality within the country, and there is an urgent need to tackle corruption in order to increase revenue. Furthermore, to improve the quality of governance, we need trusted institutions to tackle tensions, confront violent extremism and increase the general quality of life for Nigerians. So we welcome the current Government’s efforts, but we also want the EU Member States, and indeed our companies operating in Nigeria, to cooperate as well.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: Author. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Nigeria is Africa's largest economy and its most populous nation – a key country – and that is why it is particularly important that democracy and the rule of law can develop here. A few months ago, we had the President of Nigeria, Buhari, here in our house, and he gave us an impressive account of where he wanted to take the country. There are many dangers, corruption, inequality are widespread, and this is very serious because it is the gateway for the terrorists of Boko Haram.  It has still not been possible to stop this terrorist group. Tens of thousands of people have been killed, millions have been displaced, and it is worrying that women and children have also recently been used as suicide bombers. Nigeria must continue this fight very clearly, must make very clear progress here, because that is the most important prerequisite for democracy and the rule of law.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: Developer. – Madam President, it is still unknown where 219 of the 276 girls abducted from a school in Chibok by Boko Haram exactly 2 years ago are located. On behalf of the EPP Group, I would like to reiterate my solidarity with their families and the citizens of Nigeria. I also want to express my support for the government of President Buhari, who recently addressed this house and encouraged us with an ambitious reform agenda aimed at responding to the challenges facing Nigeria for many years and with terrorism and endemic corruption.  President Buhari has initiated some changes and we encourage him to continue and deepen the fight against corruption and against Boko Haram. Because, despite the first successes of the Nigerian military, the fight with terrorism is not over. The attack by Islamist militants in northern Nigeria is increasingly intense, with the number of attacks on Christians increasing, with Boko Haram indeed attacking anyone who does not share their ideology. European Union support for Nigeria in the fight against terrorism and extremism remains therefore needed.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: Author. – Madam President, this resolution means for victims the most basic support that we can sometimes feel we can offer them within the impotence we sometimes feel. For the Nigerian authorities, guidelines so that the prosecution of crimes does not lead them to commit others and thus enter a spiral of difficult exit. And above all for the Nigerian people, a clear support in the struggle for their rights that when it comes to truth it is up to them to deliver.  There is, however, a missing guide, but we are in time to change it and I look forward to your support for this amendment which explicitly mentions the need to determine the responsibility of governments and companies in third countries. Because the exploitation of natural resources, labour abuse and tax fraud contribute directly and indirectly to the rise of violence. That is why, I stress, I look forward to your support in approving the amendment calling for an international investigation of these issues under the auspices of the United Nations.

name: Marietje SCHAAKE
text: author. – Madam President, Nigeria is a country so full of potential through natural resources and an enormous human capital that it is sad to see how much of it is wasted through corruption, poverty and violent extremism. It is exactly two years since Boko Haram abducted the Chibok girls and we are still calling to bring back our girls – all of them. It is essential that children go to school and that radicalisation is prevented. The kidnapping, rape, violence and murder must end, and the path of extremist destruction that has displaced millions should be reversed. In fact, the surrender of hundreds of Boko Haram fighters is an important sign that the promises of a better life under Sharia law and extreme circumstances are empty lies that more and more people are recognising. The EU stands ready to help Nigeria in countering violent extremism, but we can only contribute fully when the rule of law and human rights are respected in the process. This includes the right to free expression. We therefore call on the Senate of Nigeria not to adopt laws chilling expression or criticism of the government.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: PPE Group. – Madam President, last year I had the honour of chairing the European Union's electoral mission in the elections in Nigeria and, above all, I would like to say that, despite the technical difficulties, the elections were entirely democratic and that the outgoing President, Goodluck Jonathan, accepted his defeat to General Buhari, which is somewhat unusual in African countries. President Buhari, who has recently intervened in this House, said that the two main priorities of his mandate are the fight against corruption and the fight against Boko Haram terrorists. Two years ago today Boko Haram abducted two hundred and seventy-six girls in Chibok and we still don't know anything about most of them, we also don't know anything about the four hundred children and women abducted in Damasak, and I ask the Nigerian government to reddoble its efforts to liberate them. Nevertheless, I believe that we should give a vote of confidence to President Buhari and his government in eradicating the scourge of terrorism and corruption in Africa's most populous country.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we recognise Nigeria's commitment to democratic transition and internal security.  However, violence is defeated only with respect for human rights and the primacy of the law, no impunity for those who fuel terrorism, nor for those who commit atrocities against the civilian population. The fight against terrorism must have a global approach strategy and it is our responsibility to combat its root causes and also against the financing of terrorist groups through natural resources. That is why it is necessary to restore a future, a hope and a dignity to millions of women and young people, guaranteeing them an education, relaunching interreligious dialogue, intervening for a fairer sharing of natural resources.  Boko Haram is not defeated today, two years after the abduction of the Chibok schoolgirls, many of them have not yet returned home, and may never return. Let us not forget them and let us not allow this to happen again.

name: Diane JAMES
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, for over 20 years the European Union has used development assistance as a lever to claim – and I emphasise to claim – to advance the cause of human rights. Every Thursday of every Strasbourg session we devote half a day to talking shop. We do not even walk the walk any more. We just do an awful lot of talking and not much else. The European Union and Nigeria signed an Accord back in 2009 called the EU—Nigeria Joint Way Forward. As a result, EUR 700 million went to Nigeria for 2009—13 and then another EUR 512 million for 2014—20. It was emphasised that the money was intended to deliver an improvement on human rights. Well, quite frankly, given that two years after all those girls were abducted – and it has taken footage in the press, across Europe, to show that some of them are still alive – they have been forgotten and are being ignored, where is the value for that money? Where is that EUR 512 million being spent? Quite frankly, it is another example in which the European Union says one thing but does not actually deliver.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, the continuing captivity of over 200 schoolgirls from the town of Chibok symbolises the senseless human suffering caused by terrorism in Nigeria. We hear frequent reports of some of the girls being forced to take part in suicide bombings, and facing rape, sexual abuse and forced marriage. We in this Parliament must ask whether we have done enough. It was good to meet with President Buhari when he was here, but we must also share our expertise with the Nigerian Government to ensure that it has the skills in counter—terrorism to combat this terrible evil. Many in the Chamber today have talked about poverty and social exclusion, but it is also important in Nigeria that we foster a free society, ensure that the fundamental freedoms of religion and conscience are upheld and, quite rightly, we debated this week terrorism in Europe. We should not forget the sectarian terrorism of fundamentalist Jihadists against those on the African continent.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Two years ago today, the town of Chibok gained worldwide sad fame. 217 mostly Christian schoolgirls were abducted by the Islamist terrorist organization Boko Haram. The good news is that they seem to be still alive if we can believe a video message from Boko Haram. The bad news: The Nigerian security forces still failed to free them.  President Buhari, who came into office last year through a peaceful change of power, had promised here in parliament in February to bring the girls back to their families. Unfortunately, despite some successes in the fight against terror and corruption in Nigeria, he has not yet succeeded. Our sympathies therefore belong to the parents and relatives of the girls.  However, we should also support the Nigerian Government in its fight against terror, corruption and poverty. North-east Nigeria must not become a western province of the Islamic State.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: – I would like to thank the authors of this resolution for really discussing this subject here almost exactly 2 years after the sad anniversary of the abduction of 200 girls from Chibok. The topic of Boko Haram belongs in this House as a general issue related to the Islamic State, to which we pay relatively close attention. We pay close attention to the situation in Syria, but we pay much less attention to Boko Haram. It is a bit of a shame, because Boko Haram is as dangerous an organisation as the Islamic State, after all, it is now formally claiming to be part of the Islamic State and is considered part of it. It is necessary to express support for the president, who is trying to fight crime in this country, but on the other hand, it should be remembered that we have a sad anniversary 2 years after the abduction and 200 girls have still not been found. It is therefore necessary to call on the President to do more.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, we have already dealt in this House with the violence perpetrated in Africa by the fundamentalist group Boko Haram, violence that is often perpetrated against women and children.  On April 14, two years ago, 219 schoolgirls were kidnapped in the Nigerian resort of Chibok by the Islamic extremist group. Unicef reports that the jihadist group used children in a suicide bombing, the UN describes the situation as terrifying. A humanitarian response must be provided as soon as possible in the Lake Chad region.  Words are no longer enough to express all our indignation; condemning violence and expressing regret for the victims, often defenceless children, is no longer enough. Indiscriminate violence cannot be tolerated and the European Union must support the Nigerian authorities and its President in neutralising those responsible and normalising the country, including through the coordination of the armies of neighbouring countries.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR). Madam President, despite the fact that Nigeria is a rich country with rich sources of wealth, such as oil, and huge revenues, its population lives in poverty, while corruption and the lack of democracy prevailing in the country are the fertilizer for terrorism and the development of Boko Haram. For the past ten years Boko Haram has been responsible for repeated armed and bombing attacks, as well as hundreds of deaths of the Nigerian population.  Of course, despite complaints from the UN Human Rights Council, Boko Haram continues, even today, to carry out attacks and killings against the Nigerian people as well as child abductions.  It is therefore necessary for the European Union to urge the Nigerian authorities to combat the causes of Boko Haram's strengthening, such as underdevelopment, corruption and the squandering of oil revenues, and to press the Nigerian Government, at last, to stop the violation of rights in this region.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: – Madam President, President Buhari's speech in this high house showed that his desire to lead Nigeria, in a way that actually leads Nigeria, leads his country, so that corruption is exterminated and human rights respected. I am deeply convinced that, after the fact that we have a peaceful handover of power in Nigeria, Nigeria can perhaps be a good example for the future of democratic relations in one state on the African continent. Of course, the burden that is unequivocal, which is a difficult situation in the economy and of course the presence of corruption, make the job difficult for President Buhari, and especially the battle against terrorism. That's why I think when we talk about how to counter terrorism, we have to do it everywhere and at all times. And that's why Nigeria, because of the perspective it has and as an example in Africa, needs our maximum support. I expect the Commission to lead such a policy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ceapann cúpla Feisire i mo ghrúpa nach bhfuil bunús tuarascála éigeandála againn anseo agus gur ceart é a fhágaint don Choiste um Ghnóthaí Eachtracha.  Bíodh sin mar atá, is dócha gur maith an rud é go bhfuil díospóireacht againn faoin Nigéir anseo inniu. Agus gan dabht, is tír thruamhéalach í ina lán slite. Mar a dúradh, tá acmhainní nádúrtha an-saibhir aici. Tá daoine iontacha sa tír, ach tá an tír á coinneáil siar ag dhá rud ach go háirithe: eachtraí Boko Haram agus mímhacántacht de gach saghas trasna na tíre.  Caithfimid troid i gcoinne Boko Haram, go háirithe gan ligean dóibh stát Ioslamach, mar a thuigeann siad é, a bhunú. Agus freisin, caithfidh gach duine troid i gcoinne na mímhacántachta. Deirtear go bhfuil siad ag cailliúint idir trí agus ocht mbilliún gach uile bhliain de bharr ola a ghoid. Dá bhrí sin is truamhéalach an scéal é, mar a dúras.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Madam President, we are marking the second anniversary of the abduction of 276 Christian girls from Chibok. For 219 of them, it is still unknown where they are. The situation in parts of Nigeria under Boko Haram terror is escalating, with Nigeria climbing on the "Global Terrorism Index" table where it ranks 3rd today. From the brutal Baga massacre in January last year to the burning of villages in February this year. Boko Haram in Nigeria attacks Christians, bombs and burns schools, hospitals, churches and entire villages.  Survivors testify to the terror of killing pregnant women and the screams of children powerless to save themselves. We can only assume what happens to the Chibok girls as well as the hundreds of other children abducted by Boko Haram. Forced marriages, rapes, slavery, and it is increasingly said that chibok girls are also being used as suicide bombers.   This has to stop. I call on High Representative Mogherini to take concrete action. Let's return the kidnapped children to their families, give the children back their childhoods and stop the terrors carried out by Boko Haram.

name: Eduard KUKAN
text: – Madam President, first I would like to offer my most sincere condolences to all victims of the brutal attacks of Boko Haram. It is appalling to see that over recent years the violence inflicted by this terrorist group has been really enormous. We have spoken at length this week about fighting terrorism. Atrocities committed in Beirut, Ankara, Istanbul, Paris, Brussels, Lahore and other world cities prove that the security of us all on all continents is at stake. The EU should make every effort to help root out this menace in Nigeria. We can offer the Nigerian Government our support in developing and implementing an effective counter-terrorism strategy. Such a strategy must be based on institutional reform and continuously pushing to eradicate terrorist ideology at its roots on the ground in Nigeria.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Madam President, while the violence perpetrated by Boko Haram Jihadist militants in Nigeria gained widespread international attention, the conflict in the north—east of Nigeria, over the control of land between the semi-nomadic Fulani herders and the non-Muslim farmers of north-eastern Nigeria, has best passed largely unnoticed for years. This is despite the fact that the violence by Fulani herders has increased exponentially, involving attacks against Christians, their farms, shops and homes. Only two months after President Buhari’s inauguration in May 2015, the actions of armed Fulani herdsmen led to the loss of around 500 lives in central Nigeria, according to Christian Solidarity Worldwide. Despite advances in security since Mr Buhari’s election, there is still much to be done to address this violence in the region and the sense of impunity surrounding it, so that justice and lasting peace is restored between conflicting communities.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, today indeed marks the second anniversary of the abduction of the 276 Chibok girls by Boko Haram. A memorial event at the school in Chibok is being held today to remind the world that 219 of the kidnapped girls are still  missing. The Union welcomes the progress made by the new Nigerian authorities in pushing back insecurity and freeing many civilians held captive by Boko Haram. Suicide attacks continue to be on the daily agenda in the north-east of Nigeria, an area where mass abductions of children and their use as suicide bombers, child soldiers and sex slaves are still dramatically frequent. That is why security and human rights were among the top issues addressed in the ministerial dialogue that the Vice-President of the Commission/High Representative of the Union for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, my colleague Federica Mogherini, held with the Nigerian Minister for Foreign Affairs on 15 March in Brussels. Together they condemned the horrific abuses committed by Boko Haram and emphasised the importance of a comprehensive region-wide approach with concrete actions in the political, socio-economic, security, environmental and humanitarian fields. Both parties also agreed that the fight against terrorism is a common challenge that can only be surmounted together when security forces abide strictly by international humanitarian law and respect human rights. Such a multi-faceted strategy needs the backing of the international community, and the European Union is ready to support this effort. This will be at the heart of the discussions at the next Security Summit in Abuja in May, at which the European Union needs to be represented at the highest possible level. At the ministerial dialogue, Federica Mogherini also reiterated the European willingness to continue providing support to the population in order to help stop the violence and rebuild a prosperous future. With our development assistance and humanitarian aid, and with all other European instruments at our disposal, we will assist the Nigerian authorities in their endeavours to tackle the current challenges. Finally at the ministerial dialogue, the High Representative and the Nigerian Foreign Minister also agreed to hold a dedicated human rights dialogue in Abuja sometime in 2016, in which a broader agenda of topics will be addressed. As you can see from what I have said, the European Union has been, and will remain, fully committed to pursuing its work with Nigeria on all the issues that you have highlighted in this debate.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: The debate will be suspended until after the vote.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The agenda calls Voting Time. (For voting results and other details about them: see minutes)

name: Jan Philipp ALBRECHT
text: – Madam President, just two sentences. This adoption of the European Data Protection Regulation is a huge step forward for the European Union and for fundamental rights in the European Union. It shows that we can deliver a legal framework for the digital age and that we can still deliver democratic decisions in the European Union, which is of huge value for citizens and consumers. (Applause)

name: Marju LAURISTIN
text: – Madam President, I am really happy that we have a full data protection package and in the end have achieved agreement spanning most of the political groups. I thank everybody for their contributions. I thank the Commission and the Council for their very good cooperation. We can really show that in Europe, in very hard times, we can have a proper balance between the security of citizens and protection of their basic human rights. So it is a European package and it is a real matter of pride.

name: Julia REDA
text: – Madam President, pursuant to Rule 190 of the Rules of Procedure, I request that the vote on the Trade Secrets Directive be postponed until the Commission has submitted a legislative proposal on whistle-blower protection. In the light of the LuxLeaks scandal, Parliament has asked the Commission to put forward such a proposal by June at the latest. We should not vote on an extension of trade secrets before this issue has been dealt with.

name: Sergio Gaetano COFFERATI
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the Socialist Group, as I said yesterday in the debate, formally asks the Commission to present a directive on whistleblowers, a directive that will be able to defend those who are not protected by the directive we are about to vote on.  For this very reason, not voting today on the trade secrets directive would be a serious mistake, we would leave small businesses in unfavourable competition, we would not protect whistleblowers as we can, and we would not even give protection to the workers who are affected. That is why I believe it is important to vote today, while the Commission must be committed to presenting its proposal on the whole issue of whistleblowers. I am opposed to the proposal made by Mr Beazley. Reda and I ask that we proceed with the vote.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: We will proceed with the vote. So I'm going to put the postponement proposal to a vote... (Mr. Lamberts noted that he raised his arm in support of the proposal and complained that the President had not seen it). Well, I haven't seen you, Mr. Lamberts, and apparently no one here has seen you. You have the floor now to defend this proposal.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: "Well, it's about time, thank you. Madam President, I am committed to offering you glasses, should they ever be.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: I propose that you go to the defence of the amendment (Mr Lamberts: "Sorry? There is too much noise; I can't hear you")... Ah, can't you hear me? Well you will also buy me a speaker, under these conditions.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I still believe that this House should be a place to listen. I have therefore listened carefully to Mr. Cofferati's arguments. I think it is absolutely a completely wrong signal from this House to adopt, ten days after the Panama Papers revelations, a text which, de facto, will make it more difficult for whistleblowers and newspapers, simply because it will place the burden of proof on whistleblowers, not on businesses.  I therefore think that it is, from a political point of view, completely foolish to adopt this text today.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: So we heard a speaker for and one speaker against. We will put to a vote this proposal to postpone the vote on the report. So we are voting on the postponement of the vote. The request for deferral is denied.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: Madam President, it seems to me that Mr Cofferati has made a proposal to the European Commission, and I think it would be important for the European Commission to be able to vote on this proposal.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. I can say that the European Commission will honour the commitments it has previously made as always, and if questions are asked here that go beyond that, then the Commission will take note of this and then it will take a decision on that in due course.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: – A Uachtaráin, chun é seo a chur i gcomhthéacs is inné a thug an tUachtarán Schulz le fios go raibh sé chun próiseas cleachtadh níos fearr i dtaobh dlí a chur i bhfeidhm. Is é seo an botún teicniúil maidir leis an gcéad leasú atá i dtuarascáil an Uasail Tarand agus deir sé: phasing out of the temporary derogation measures for the usage of the Irish language that were established by Regulation No 1 of 15 April 1958. Ar an céad dul síos níor tháinig Éire isteach san Aontas Eorpach go dtí 1973, agus mar sin tá an botún seo go huile is go hiomlán mícheart. Ní bhfuaireamar an maolú sealadach go dtí 2007. Ba mhaith liom aird a thabhairt ar seo: go dtarlaíonn na botúin seo go minic agus níl sé sásúil agus ní féidir glacadh leis seo mar tá impleachtaí aige ó thaobh leasuithe agus ó thaobh cúrsaí dlí.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Thank you, Madam, I take note of your remark; it will be corrected for that. I believe that, prior to the vote, Mr. Tarand wanted to speak.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: – Madam President, Article 96(3) of the Rules of Procedure stipulates that the President shall set a time limit for tabling amendments to the draft estimates – I underline the words ‘draft estimates’ – which means that the amendments, roll—call votes and oral amendments are admissible. Our roll-call vote request was wrongfully rejected, and I now wish to move an oral amendment to the following part of the draft estimates. It concerns the conditions for the release of the reserves in Article 216. The text to which the roll-call vote applies is the following: ‘The appropriations may be released following a Bureau decision on internalising the Members’ transport service’. This sentence should be replaced by the oral amendment I will now read to you: ‘The appropriations may be released following a decision of the Committee on Budgets’. Adopting that oral amendment would not make the report ideal, but it would do a lot to secure broader support in the final vote. Whether we support and admit it or not, the situation obliges us to turn to the Committee on Constitutional Affairs (AFCO) to interpret and clarify the Rules of Procedure. Apart from this, I wish everyone a fruitful vote, remaining loyal to their political priorities. Let us not forget that it is only money and, as Paul McCartney – famous in Panama – says ‘Money can’t buy me love’. (Laughter)

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: Mr Tarand, unfortunately, the services tell me that the amendment you have tabled is not admissible, since it is out of time under Article 96, paragraph 3.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: There is an oral amendment that we would like to take over. It removes 'and the doğan media groups'.

name: Elmar BROK
text: I would just like to say that there was no accidental coordination with the device here. I voted in favour of the Turkey report and I would ask that this be recorded in the Minutes.

name: József SZÁJER
text: – Madam President, I propose that the two remaining items be postponed to voting time in the next part—session. They will take more than 30 minutes to vote on and we have already lost one third of the House. I therefore propose we conclude here.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: Madam President, it is shameful to ask for the vote to be postponed! We've only been voting for an hour. What show do you give—you give to the audience that is there asking to postpone the vote, when we have only been voting for an hour? Let's go all the way!

name: Neena GILL
text: –  Madam President, although this regulation was approved without a vote, it is an important milestone that we have achieved. It is a regulation that ensures people’s rights are properly protected when their personal data is used. So what the European Parliament secured today is a key update in data protection legislation that is vital to make these rules fit for a digital age. The right to be forgotten, parental permission for a child to open a social media account, and the need for consent before processing personal data: these are all incredibly important. It shows that this Parliament is acting in the interests of consumers, giving them greater control over their personal data, enabling them to make the right choices and the right decisions for themselves, and for their families as well.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, i would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr The security issue of processing personal data has long been on the Agenda of the European Parliament, and it must be said that millions of people buy goods on the Internet every minute, every second, register for some activity, submit documents electronically and so on. And the problem in principle is that, in view of this constant development in the market and the legal system, there is absolutely no guarantee that these data will not be made available to third parties and to third parties. How often each of us has not been called by an unfamiliar person who has come to the front and has already known our names, phone numbers and everything. Why do these people have access to our data at all? Consequently, when we absolutely specifically allow an authority to process our data directly, only then is that data legal. Consequently, I was very happy to vote in favour of adopting this legislative resolution. Thank you!

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Dear Colleagues, What is the need for privacy? What is the need to protect privacy, privacy, privacy? a lot of people are asking me that question these days. Short story: I have heard from both men and women: how ashamed they were during the times of our past system, the so-called socialism, and how humiliating it was when it was customary to invite more patients at once for medical examinations. They had to undress in front of each other and talk about their illnesses. Why was that such a big problem? "Well, they all have bodies, they're single-sex, women have women's bodies, the disease is a natural thing, there's no shame in that," he said. Yet they felt, and rightly so, that their right to human dignity had been violated by reaching into their innermost, most intimate private sphere, so to speak, with this humiliating measure. I will continue from here for the next speech.

name: Peter JAHR
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which I think that today we have taken an important step in the first three reports, because the digital age does not only bring benefits.
