The advantage is clear: we can all get comprehensive information, we can exchange information around the world. Everyone knows exactly what the other is doing, if they want to know. That's the good side of the event.  The other side, of course, is: how do we house data protection in the digital age? How do we protect personal rights? I believe that today, with the three reports, we have taken an important step in this direction by creating legal certainty. Perhaps the saying applies to some Colleagues as a whole: a compromise is only good if all sides are dissatisfied.  It really seems to me that, in the digital age, we are creating a little legal certainty here. We will not, of course, discuss this issue in the European Parliament for the last time.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, having been involved as the rapporteur for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) on this subject from the start of the process four years ago to the final trilogue just before Christmas, it gives me great pleasure to be here today to see us adopting this very important report. It will, as has been said, set the rules for the new digital age. It ensures that data subjects have control of their data, but we not stifling the digital economy, which is of major importance. We have introduced many concepts, such as the right to be forgotten, the right to erasure, parental control to ensure that the abuse of young people online can be controlled, and, of course, also a concept known as the ‘one-stop shop’, which will be very important for businesses operating in the European Union. This is a very good day. It shows that, if we cooperate, we can get a good result.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: – Madam President, colleagues, and I agree that today is an important day for the protection of personal data. I voted for this report because I am convinced that a strong regulatory framework is needed to protect personal data.  On this topic, we must remain vigilant, especially when we take a look at recent events in Europe, of the events related to the leak of files related to offshore areas. Personal data is accessible and they are a large number, and therefore one can not always know, it would be even negligent, what can happen to them. Most importantly, the new rules introduce a liability regulation and, where there is an infringement, it will be penalised. This report is therefore of great importance to the lives of ordinary citizens who would suffer such abuses.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative package because it implies a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by law enforcement and judicial authorities.  This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects relating to the storage, processing and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over as relevant aspects of their lives as privacy is.  The way in which judicial and police authorities process citizens' personal data has a profound impact on citizens' fundamental rights. The new directive will help to ensure that these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide legislation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time we will have a harmonised system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the data protection package after four years of legislative work. On the one hand, it will protect the personal data of Europeans, especially against multinationals. We have made sure to strengthen the rights of Internet users by allowing them to better control their data: the right to erase, information on how their data is handled, the supervision of data transfers from Europeans to third countries, strictly limited profiling possibilities, penalties for offenders. With this reform, the Eu will have the highest standards of privacy protection in the world, which, given its demographic and economic weight, will influence standards on the rest of the world. On the other hand, because technology provides new means of surveillance to the police and justice, it was essential to build a foundation of guarantees for citizens' rights and freedoms, while allowing the security forces to exchange information more quickly and efficiently. We have struck the right balance between protecting the fundamental rights of citizens and strengthening the effectiveness of police and judicial cooperation throughout the European Union.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S&D), in writing. \u2012 I was in favour of this report on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data as it contains important legislation in the context of labour issues. This Regulation allows Member States to provide a greater level of protection of workers' personal data and rights and freedoms.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: Writing. \u2012 Today we have adopted a personal data package and this is a significant step that will ensure a smoother exchange of data between Member States and their authorities. Data protection is one of the fundamental rights of EU citizens and citizens have the right to expect adequate data protection. While there remain a number of concerns, whether among citizens and politicians or in new legislation, effective and comprehensive protection of personal data, I voted in favour of the package as a whole. In the face of current terrorist threats, there could no longer be any longer delays and doubts. Recent terrorist attacks could have been avoided if Member States had provided the data they had in their possession on terrorists, but this was not the case. Today, the issue of the security of Europe and our citizens is more relevant than ever, and I believe that the personal data package, albeit with shortcomings, will be useful in the fight against terrorism.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: In writing. I have obviously approved this regulation which will give citizens more power over the use and processing of their personal data. The new rules include provisions on the right to be forgotten, the clear and explicit consent of the person concerned regarding the use of his personal data, the right to be informed in the event of data piracy, stricter implementation of fines of up to 4% of a company's global turnover, or the guarantee that privacy policies are explained in clear and understandable language.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. \u2012 Today I supported the Albrecht report on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data. The measure adopted today repeals Directive 95/46/EC and sets out the new rules for the digital age, in a context in which the Internet and related technologies are becoming increasingly widespread. The main objective is the protection of citizens' data, through the establishment of rules that introduce numerous concepts such as the right to be forgotten, parental control and the provision of a minimum age for the use of online services. Particularly relevant for the business world is the one-stop shop system that in the new legislation will guarantee important services to entrepreneurs. The adoption of this report represents a great step forward in the field of data protection and ensures full implementation of the rights set out in the Treaty of Lisbon.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: in writing. We have decided to support this report with one vote in favour, given that the development of this report has been done in compliance with the views of most political positions and we believe that it is moving mostly in the direction we stand for. However, in some chapters concerning personal privacy, we believe that more firm progress must be made.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative package because it implies a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by law enforcement and judicial authorities.  This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects relating to the storage, processing and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over as relevant aspects of their lives as privacy is.  The way in which judicial and police authorities process citizens' personal data has a profound impact on citizens' fundamental rights. The new directive will help to ensure that these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide legislation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time we will have a harmonised system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted on this report on the recommendation for the adoption of a Council position with a view to adopting a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data. Since the adoption of Directive 95/46/EC on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and the free movement of such data, there has been significant changes in data protection, in particular technological improvements, more personal data collection and processing, including for law enforcement purposes, inconsistent sets of data protection rules and globalising markets and cooperation. Moreover, the application of the Directive has not achieved proper harmonisation, as the provisions of this document are implemented differently in the Member States. In this context, it has become more difficult for individuals ('data subjects') to exercise their right to data protection. Finally, this failure hampers the development of the single market, with companies (managing or processing personal data, 'controllers') and individuals facing different data protection requirements. The European Parliament welcomes the proposed transposition of reporting requirements to data protection authorities, with practical accountability and corporate data protection officers. The proposed regulation can be simplified by merging the right to information with document requirements, as it is essentially two sides of the same coin. This will reduce the administrative burden on controllers and make it easier for individuals to understand and exercise their rights.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: Writing. \u2012 Members supported the draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, drawn up by the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. Today's multitude of data, processed on a number of levels every day, is about the safety of the individual and we need to work actively to protect his privacy.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. \u2012 The new regulation on the protection of natural persons modernises and updates the principles contained in the 1995 Data Protection Directive, giving European citizens greater control over their personal data. In particular, the new legislation more clearly defines the rights of natural persons and the obligations of those who process data or who are responsible for their processing, by reorganising and supplementing methods to ensure compliance with the rules and the scope of sanctions against those who breach them. Among the new measures, some of the most interesting are the right for European citizens to transfer their data to a new Internet provider, the right to know whether their data has been hacked or the ban on mass surveillance and the introduction of a time limit for the storage of personal data. The new regulation, which applies to all companies that manage data of European citizens, even if they are not based on the territory of the European Union, is an important step forward in terms of clarification and updating the regulatory framework of a fundamental and highly sensitive sector.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The Data Protection package has had a very long parliamentary process and lasted a few years. In short, we are satisfied with the final result, because real data regulation is essential and necessary. The biggest problem we must point out is the legislative tortuousness of some provisions, but on the whole the protections in the management and processing of personal data and the consequent guarantees for the privacy of all citizens that are provided meet the minimum criteria that we have always required.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative package because it implies a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by law enforcement and judicial authorities.  This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects relating to the storage, processing and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over as relevant aspects of their lives as privacy is.  The way in which judicial and police authorities process citizens' personal data has a profound impact on citizens' fundamental rights. The new directive will help to ensure that these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide legislation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time we will have a harmonised system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. \u2012 After careful reading and discussion in this House, I voted in favour of the report on the motion for a resolution on the basis of the following considerations: the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data, as well as the free movement of data and therefore the related issue of privacy, in the form of aggregated data, and the systems used to defend them (encryption) , require solutions at European, if not global, level. This thinking is in line with ethical principles of careful assessment of the use of new technologies and with my recent question on PNR, in which I point out that pnr itself has considerable costs and takes a long time to implement that may not correspond to the real needs of law enforcement, especially in sadly known terrorist emergencies. A European impetus must therefore be called for to regulate access to encrypted communications, which must be made usable without creating vulnerabilities to the system, both in public and private hands. It is therefore necessary, with regard to the personal data protection package, to create a clear legal framework on their use, given that an aggregate amount of information could violate privacy, and paradoxically refine terrorist techniques.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which recommends that Parliament approves the Council position with a view to the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (General Data Protection Regulation).

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. \u2012 Eurobarometer data for 2015 show us that European citizens are particularly sensitive about the online disclosure and control of personal information. The protection of personal data is a fundamental right of the European Union enshrined in the Treaty of Lisbon. That is why the Commission's proposal to intervene with two new legislative instruments to protect both citizens and businesses is to be welcomed. The general regulation on data protection, first of all ensuring better information on what happens to personal data once shared, contains, among other things, two particularly interesting points: the so-called 'right to be forgotten' and the minimum age for the use of online services. A single set of rules that applies to companies offering online services in the Union can then facilitate cross-border data exchange and ensure greater economic and social integration. The new proposal for a directive, the first instrument for harmonising 28 different legal systems with regard to the exchange of data, facilitates the work of both national law enforcement agencies and European agencies at a time, such as the current one, which requires the greatest possible cooperation. I therefore voted in favour.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: Writing. \u2012 We support the report and consider that the Single European Passenger Name Registration System (PNR) is a necessary tool in the fight against terrorism, particularly in the wake of recent terrorist attacks.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this proposal for a regulation, on which Parliament had been working for almost four years. The time had come to replace the old 1995 directive, given that data traffic has changed a great deal since then and, at the same time, a balance has been struck between the sacrosanct right to protection of personal data, enshrined in the European Charter of Human Rights, and the unstoppable flow of data around the world. I believe that the European Parliament's negotiating team has done a good job, but I am prepared to call the whole text into question if problems of any kind emerge from the application.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this vote as a way to ensure the privacy concerns of citizens are protected whilst allowing authorities to have necessary access to data to ensure the safety of all Europeans.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. \u2012 In the year 2000 there were about four hundred million users on the internet, today there are more than three billion. In the last 15 years, the online world has changed radically. The European legislative instrument regulating it was more than 20 years old. This new regulation will address this misadjustment.  There are essentially two objectives of this regulation: on the one hand, to give consumers more control over their information and, on the other hand, to stimulate the digital internal market. This regulation certainly guarantees greater respect for citizens' rights, but will not allow continuous awareness and pedagogy work to be dispensed with, as it will not fully prevent misuse of personal data.  It will undoubtedly also stimulate economic development by harmonising the rules in a market of five hundred million. But it is not clear that it creates the ideal conditions for the flourishing of small and medium-sized enterprises that have to compete in a global market. In a way, I certainly support the adoption of this regulation, a very important step, but its implementation will require close monitoring.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour as the act was adopted in accordance with the Council's position.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. \u2012 With my vote in favour of this resolution, I wanted to support the European Parliament's approval of the Council's position at first reading for the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing and free movement of personal data. I believe, in fact, that this resolution represents an historic stage in providing a single legal framework in Europe that will eliminate the current divergences between national data protection legislation. This is a step towards an agreement between the privacy needs and consumer rights, on the one hand, and the needs of a competitive digital market and a transnational security system, on the other. European citizens will finally be informed about the use and violation of their personal data, without compromising the innovation of the digital single market and the fight against crime.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: I would like to write to the Commission. \u2012 This regulation is an update of the 1995 General Data Protection Directive. It has been more than 20 years since this directive was adopted. During this period, the use and dependence of the economy on data, including attitudes towards the use of personal data, has changed significantly. This Regulation reflects the changes and the need to ensure that individuals have adequate legal protection and the right to redress and that service providers provide clear guidance on how they are authorised to process personal data. I hope that the new rules will increase consumer confidence and create a level playing field across the EU, which will contribute to future investment in the Single Market. I voted in favour of the document.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: In writing. This codecision report concerns the protection of individuals with regard to the treatment of personal data by European institutions and bodies and the free flow of such data. It establishes the European Data Protection Supervisor (ECDP) and sets out rules to ensure the confidentiality of personal data. Considering that it is essential to guarantee internet users control over their personal data, I supported this report.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – Personal data is becoming increasingly important and so is its processing. As a legislator, I can only approve of adopting a regulation that increases the protection of our citizens in this regard, while at the same time ensuring the free movement of data. It will facilitate the well-functioning of the digital single market and ensure the protection of the EU citizen’s personal data.  To name only a few of these positive consequences; this regulation will give increased legal certainty to businesses across the EU, while giving the consumer the right of being informed when his/her information was to be hacked. In addition, there will be a smoother, easier exchange of information between both Member States and these businesses. I put my trust in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE), which has negotiated this deal thoroughly with the Council, resulting in an almost full consensus.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the agreement between Parliament and the Council on a new data protection regulation, better adapted to the digital age and which will replace the current directive, which dates back to 1995.  The provisions of the regulation create a high and uniform level of data protection across the EU, therefore bringing more clarity and certainty to businesses. They also give citizens greater control over their own private information and allow them to decide for themselves what personal information they want to share. These new rules include provisions on the right to be forgotten, the clear and explicit consent of the person concerned regarding the use of his personal data, the right to transfer his data to another service provider, the right to be informed in the event of data piracy, the guarantee that privacy policies are explained in clear and understandable language. , and a stricter framework to discourage violations of the rules with fines of up to 4% of a company's total global turnover.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. \u2012 The Regulation aims to ensure that citizens have greater control over their data, give more clarity and legal certainty to businesses and to make transfers to countries outside the EU subject to tighter requirements.  European rules on the protection of personal data - dating back to 1995, an era in which less than 1% of Europeans used the Internet - must be updated to respond to technological progress, globalisation and new methods of data collection, access and use.  The aim of this reform is to strengthen citizens' control over their data.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. \u2012 This report represents a strengthening of the right to the protection of personal data, even if guaranteed by a unified legal framework. It proposes that the European Commission should have the least possible interference in its implementation.  The new rules provide for the following measures: - Improving access to their data – people will receive more information, clearer and more understandable, on how their data is handled;  - The 'right to be forgotten' – when a person no longer wants his data to be processed and, if there are no legitimate reasons for its retention, he may claim and obtain the deletion of them; - The right to know if your data has been hacked – companies should notify the supervisory authority and the data subject of any personal data breaches that put people at risk; - The right to data portability will make it easier for people to transfer their personal data from one service provider to another. The proposed Regulation provides that supervisors may impose fines on undertakings that violate EU rules by up to 2 % of their overall annual turnover.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because I believe citizens are protected.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The overall objective of the Agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of personal data, in the areas of police and judicial cooperation, in criminal matters, with a view to preventing, investigating, detecting or prosecuting criminal offences. It does, however, circumvent the general principles of the protection of personal data.  The act demonstrates that commitments in areas of information exchange are subject, either to personal will or to national security accreditations, with a recent example of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where the secret services of Member States have not informed each other. The agreement does not really strengthen the risk-based approach, nor does it ensure its obligation, by design and by default, to protect data. In addition, the provision of harmonised criteria, conditions and restrictions is contrary to the provision in the agreement of the inclusion of private entities in the concept of "competent authorities".  In conclusion, cooperation is practically impossible, taking into account the simple example of the non-issue of Christoforikos by the German authorities in Greece, to investigate the SIEMENS scandal.  For all the above reasons my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this recommendation, since the adequacy of the level of protection afforded by a third country shall be assessed in the light of all the circumstances surrounding a data transfer operation. The Member States and the Commission shall inform each other of cases where they consider that a third country does not ensure an adequate level of protection. Given the many protection clauses to individuals with regard to the processing of personal data, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: Writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the adoption of the data protection package. The compromise text of the data protection dossier was formally approved by the European Council on 8 April, after which only Parliament's approval was required. Once approved in plenary, Member States will have two years (until 2018) to transpose it into national law. These rules supersede and modernise more than 20 years of EU data protection regulations, since at that time there was no mass internet use, neither Facebook nor Google. The aim is to guarantee individuals the opportunity to verify their personal data in the widest possible way, while at the same time ensuring that data processing does not hinder the growth of the Digital Single Market or the acquisition of data in order to counter a terrorist threat. The data protection package consists of a regulation on the protection and use of personal data and a public security data protection directive providing for the processing of information facilitating the flow of information between law enforcement and judicial organisations.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative package because it implies a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a Regulation addressing the processing of personal data by private actors and, on the other hand, a Directive covering the use of personal data by law enforcement and judicial authorities.  This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects relating to the storage, processing and cancellation of data. In addition, it gives citizens greater control over as relevant aspects of their lives as privacy is.  The way in which judicial and police authorities process citizens' personal data has a profound impact on citizens' fundamental rights. The new Directive will help to ensure that these exchanges are carried out under the umbrella of EU-wide legislation, a proposal which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time we will have a harmonised system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative package because it implies a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by law enforcement and judicial authorities.  This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects relating to the storage, processing and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over as relevant aspects of their lives as privacy is.  The way in which judicial and police authorities process citizens' personal data has a profound impact on citizens' fundamental rights. The new directive will help to ensure that these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide legislation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time we will have a harmonised system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of the resolution on the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and the free movement of such data and repealing Directive 95/46/EC (Data Protection Regulation). I believe that the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, and in particular their right to personal data protection, is fundamental in today's context, and at the same time I believe it is essential to guarantee freedom of movement within the borders of the European Union.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: in writing. We have decided to support this report with one vote in favour, given that the development of this report has been done in compliance with the views of most political positions and we believe that it is moving mostly in the direction we stand for. However, in some chapters concerning personal privacy, we believe that more firm progress must be made.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: In writing. I voted strongly in favour of this major data protection reform, which allows us to adapt to contemporary digital developments. Citizens are increasingly publishing personal information, and digital companies have set up a large-scale collection of personal information. It was therefore necessary to modernize inadequate legislation, dating back to 1995! This reform of European law obliges companies to inform their customers in the event of data piracy, allows the transfer of data in very limited cases and, above all, establishes a right to be forgotten and a right of citizens to control the information that is collected about them.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this regulation as the new rules represent a significant improvement on existing data protection legislation; the right to be forgotten, parental permission for a child to open a social media account, and the need for consent before processing personal data are all incredibly important.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative package because it implies a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by law enforcement and judicial authorities.  This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects relating to the storage, processing and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over as relevant aspects of their lives as privacy is.  The way in which judicial and police authorities process citizens' personal data has a profound impact on citizens' fundamental rights. The new directive will help to ensure that these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide legislation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time we will have a harmonised system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: In writing. For the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament, it was essential, in order to be able to fight terrorism and organised crime effectively, that the adoption of the directive on the use of passenger data be coupled with the adoption of a package on the protection of personal data. This is done with this regulation, for which I voted, which will protect the data of European citizens, especially in the face of the misuse that can be made by multinationals, but also by governments. The text will now protect their private lives, notably through a series of some of the highest standards in the world: the right to be erased, information on how data is processed, the supervision of data transfers from Europeans to third countries, strictly limited profiling possibilities, or penalties for non-compliance with the rules.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it aids security measures within the EU.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: In writing. I approved the recommendation of the rapporteur of the Green Group on Data Protection. I believe that this text is far from perfect, insofar as it imposes too heavy administrative constraints on European companies, particularly for small businesses in the digital sector, but it sets up a protective framework for the collection, transfer and exchange of personal data unparalleled in the world. I believe that great legal uncertainties remain in this regulation and I hope that the Member States, at the time of its implementation, will be able to exploit them in the interests of the competitiveness of European companies as well as European citizens, one not excluding the other.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: Written. ‒ I voted for the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading in order to adopt a regulation by the European Parliament and the Council on the protection of individuals concerning the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data and on the repeal of Directive 95/46/EC (GDPR) as we finally get one of the elements changing Directive 95/46.  Such an outdated directive was no longer adequately able to regulate and protect human rights in view of any changes that have taken place with the development of INFORMATION technology. Today we live in a digital society looking for new solutions that will reconcile both the privacy needs of citizens as well as opportunities for further development of an economy that is increasingly based on digital technology. This provides an advanced standard, an advanced solution that can become a model for legislation outside the EU as well.  Such a solution represents a balance between consumer rights and the needs of business entities. It is a basis for the protection of human rights because the protection of personal data constitutes the protection of personal identity. On the other hand, such a legal solution represents an incentive environment for the development of a digital society in the future.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: In writing. This data protection reform aims, on the one hand, to strengthen the fundamental rights of citizens and, on the other hand, to facilitate business activity by simplifying the rules applicable to the digital single market. This regulation has positive elements (strengthening citizens' rights, the same rules for all businesses, etc.) that will undoubtedly be highlighted by the media. However, pan-European legislation is yet another attack on national sovereignty, hence my abstention on this text.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The new EU data protection rules will meld different legal approaches in EU Member States into one single European rulebook and will give people back control of their personal information. Citizens will be able to decide which of their personal information they want to share. The new regulation includes, among other things, provisions on the right to be forgotten, the ‘clear and affirmative consent’ to the processing of private data by the person concerned, the right to transfer your data to another service provider and the right to know when your data has been hacked. The data protection package also includes a directive on data transfers for policing and judicial purposes which will help authorities transfer valuable personal data efficiently while respecting the fundamental right to privacy.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of my colleague Jan Philipp Albrecht's report on the protection of individuals in the treatment of personal data. This text sets up one of the strongest frameworks in the world for the protection of personal data. As a result, citizens and consumers will have greater control over what is done with their personal data. I welcome the adoption of this text which protects our fellow citizens and which I hope will set an example to be followed elsewhere in the world.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: In writing. I voted in favour of this general data protection regulation which, by putting in place a strong protection framework, will allow citizens to better control their personal data. It will standardise the rules in Europe by reducing red tape, which will also allow European companies to be more active in the digital single market.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: Writing. I can support data collections for crime prevention, but the proposal goes far too far and interferes too much with citizens' rights, in particular citizens' right to privacy. That is why I am opposed to the report.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. –Directive 95/46/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council aims to harmonise the protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data. The protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data is a fundamental right and is also inviolable, which must be recognized and guaranteed regardless of the nationality or residence of the data subject. Although its objectives remain valid at present, Directive 95/46/EC has not been able to prevent the division of the way in which the protection of personal data is applied within the EU, not least because it was designed and approved in the pre-Internet and social networks era, which have undoubtedly changed and revolutionised the way we process personal data and information. For these reasons, a revision of the legislation was necessary, which was made on the basis of the needs of the digital age in order to give citizens more control over their private information, with greater confidence and legal certainty for European companies as well.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: In writing. The new European data protection framework must give citizens more control over the use of their data, which must be achieved through their assent (for example, through a message appearing on a site warning them that their data can be used) and by the possibility of reversing this assent, thus a right to delete this data. This is called the right to be forgotten.  Any data transfer or loss by a company (for example, due to hacking) must also be notified. Finally, fines of up to 4% of global revenue will be possible for non-compliance, which can be huge for companies such as Google or Facebook. I therefore supported the adoption of these new rules, but I regret that they served as a bargaining chip, after they were blocked for four years in order to obtain Parliament's assent on the PNR dossier. I will remain vigilant about the application of these rules for the protection of the right to privacy, which are threatened on the other hand by the PNR.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: In writing. The report on the protection of individuals with respect to the processing of personal data has passed second reading, so there was no final vote. Nevertheless, I would like to take this opportunity to highlight the positive aspects of this regulation, which is in the direction of improved protection of personal data, and therefore of the privacy of citizens in France and Europe. I will mention a person's right to access his personal data, the right to erase it when it comes to inaccurate data, and the right to "digital oblivion", which protects children in particular. Another positive aspect is that companies located outside the European Union, but offering services within the European Union, will be subject to the same rules as European companies. It is important, however, that France and the other Member States can provide specific emphasis on the protection of personal data.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: In writing. I abstained. Indeed, this relationship oscillates between the benefits granted to citizens in the context of the protection of personal data and the infringement of national sovereignty in this protective role. As a result, the citizen would have a "right to digital oblivion", easier access to his data and a better knowledge of its use by a third party. As for companies, they will be obliged to apply the same legislation, to standardise their rules at European level, as well as for foreign companies based in Europe. Therefore, although these positive elements are interesting, it is impossible for me to condone a new infringement of national sovereignty.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative package because it implies a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by law enforcement and judicial authorities.  This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects relating to the storage, processing and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over as relevant aspects of their lives as privacy is.  The way in which judicial and police authorities process citizens' personal data has a profound impact on citizens' fundamental rights. The new directive will help to ensure that these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide legislation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time we will have a harmonised system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: in writing. One of the main purposes of European law in this area is to defend the fundamental right to data protection. Similarly, it is also intended to ensure the free movement of them between Member States. However, rapid technological developments have posed new challenges in this area. That is why this recommendation considers it necessary to establish a stronger and more coherent data protection framework in the EU.  The aim is to achieve the development of the digital economy in the internal market that gives citizens control of their own data and, moreover, strengthens the legal and practical certainty of economic operators and public authorities.  I support this report as it will help to form sound data protection legislation and avoid the risk of different levels of protection in the Member States.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: In writing. At the beginning of 2012, the Commission proposed a package of reforms including, on the one hand, a regulation establishing a general EU data protection framework and, on the other hand, a directive which addresses the processing of personal data for the purpose of combating crime. By strengthening users' right to inform themselves about what is being done with their data, these two texts will enable European citizens to better control their privacy and make them masters of their own data, ensuring that they consent to their treatment and guaranteeing them remedies against any misuse of their data. Thanks to their adoption, the planned measures will also be valid for all businesses. Foreign companies, especially the giants of the digital economy, who wish to process the data of European citizens will also have to comply with the new European requirements.  This legislative package therefore allows for a high level of protection for citizens and enhanced loyalty of competition in strategic economic sectors. I therefore vote in favour of these two texts.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. \u2012 I support the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data and the repeal of Directive 95/46/EC, because it is complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: In writing. I abstained on this text. This text proposes the establishment of a one-stop shop and European legislation on the processing of personal data. Some positive elements, such as the right to be forgotten for individuals, or an administrative simplification for companies. However, France already has comprehensive legislation in this area, on which it is not appropriate to encroach.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the update of the data protection regulation that recognises developments in technology and strikes a balance between protecting the needs of individuals and of businesses that process personal data

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: In writing. This regulation replaces the old 1995 directive, which was rendered obsolete by technological developments and was largely ignored by Member States, resulting in a lack of protection for citizens. The result of the trilogue significantly improves the European Commission's proposal, strengthening the parties on the right to be forgotten, the right to object and the explicit request for consent to individuals. It also offers guarantees to European residents when transferring their data to third countries. Finally, it includes an important passage for employees, who cannot be placed on a "black list" according to their "political orientation, affiliation and trade union activities". The report is going in the right direction to ensure more protection, I vote for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: In writing. The regulations are quite good, in a logic of data protection and the right to digital oblivion. The rules are considered with regard to individuals and companies. In short, this text seems pretty good to me.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. \u2012 Directive 95/46/EC, the main legislative instrument for the protection of personal data in Europe, was a milestone in the history of data protection. Its objectives are to ensure the functioning of the single market and the effective protection of the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons.  However, that directive was adopted 21 years ago, when the Internet was only taking its first steps. Today, in this challenging new digital universe in which we live, the rules in force do not ensure the degree of harmonization or effectiveness necessary to guarantee the right to the protection of personal data. The proposed Regulation modernises the principles laid down in the 1995 Directive, adapting them to the digital age and harmonising data protection legislation at European level. Data protection should be subject to strict standards to restore people's confidence in the way their personal data is used. This proposal for a Regulation aims to strengthen individual rights and consolidate the EU internal market, ensure stricter enforcement of regulations, simplify international transfers of personal data and establish international data protection standards.  Hence my vote in favour.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ There was an urgent need to update the European Union’s legislation on data protection. I supported this proposal as it provides a fair and balanced improvement of European Union legislation on data protection, which has been sorely missing.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: In writing. I welcome parliament's adoption of the General Data Protection Regulation. Updated in 1995 legislation, this new regulation has the merit of adapting the protection of personal data to the new situation of the digital age and its consequences on the personal data of individuals. These new rules strengthen both the rights of people whose personal data is processed and the obligations of those who process it. Legal certainty and penalties for violations are greatly improved and I welcome that.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: Writing. – The proposal for a European Parliament legislative resolution is an up-to-date response to the current challenges of protecting personal data in the EU. The challenging digital environment is constantly extinguling new cracks, with a lack of satisfactory harmonisation of the rules for its use and its effectiveness in order to ensure that the protection of personal data is sufficiently safeguarded. Directive 95/46/EC, to be replaced by new legislation, has been a great help in the area of the protection of personal data in the EU and the basis on which it is based is still up to date. However, the digital environment, by which I am thinking in particular of the use of e-mail communications, social networks and so on, requires a completely new approach. I particularly highlight the fact that the proposal for a regulation did not mention easier access to data, which means that users will have more information about how the data is processed and that information will be clear and comprehensible. I also see as a great benefit the so-called 'right to be forgotten', which allows a natural person to have his or her data deleted if he does not wish them to continue to be processed. The proposal also offers other new legal requirements that will improve the provision of services and the protection of personal data of ordinary individuals in the digital environment.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which was designed to bring Europe’s data protection laws into the 21st century. It involves two elements – one covering the processing of personal data by industry and government and a second one covering data used by police and criminal justice authorities. These new laws ensure strong protections for all EU citizens in how their data can be used by police and criminal authorities. This is essential as if the data of suspects, witnesses or victims is not handled correctly, this can compromise their safety as well as their right to privacy or a fair trial. For the first time we now have clear strict laws on how law enforcement agencies can access and use personal data that apply equally to all EU citizens. All police forces in Europe must now fully respect the fundamental right of protection of personal data.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: Writing. \u2012 On 25 January 2012, the Commission presented a proposal to replace Directive 95/46/EC with a regulation setting out the general EU framework for data protection. Parliament debated the proposal at first reading on 12 March 2014, but the Belgian Chamber of Deputies, the German Bundesrat, the French Senate, the Italian Chamber of Deputies and the Swedish Parliament submitted a reasoned opinion that the draft legislative act was incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. The Council's position at first reading of 8 April 2016 reflects the political agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council at the tripartit informal conciliation on 15 December 2015. The Commission agrees with the Council's position at first reading. In its recommendation at second reading, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs recommends that Parliament agree with the Council's position at first reading. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. \u2012 The protection of personal data, regulated by Directive 95/46/EC, was adopted 21 years ago. In view of the exponential growth and dominance of the digital world, that legal instrument, despite the objectives of that Directive remaining valid, needs an urgent update to ensure the right to the protection of personal data. I believe that individual rights should be strengthened, enforcement should be stricter, international transfers of personal data should be simplified and international data protection standards set. I stress the importance of creating a single pan-European data protection legislation that harmonises and replaces the 28 separate national laws and which should create an enabling environment for businesses that does not hinder their economic growth and enhances innovation.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: In writing. This regulation has positive elements (strengthening citizens' rights, same rules for all businesses, etc.). However, pan-European legislation is yet another attack on national sovereignty.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this regulation as the new rules represent a significant improvement on existing data protection legislation. The data protection regulation will ensure business, consumers and NGOs will have greater clarity thanks to the new rules which include the requirement that clear consent be provided for the processing of personal data. The legislation will also require parental consent to be given in order for a child to be able to open a social media account, and makes it clear that consumers now have a right to be forgotten. The regulation gives EU citizens new positive rights including the ability to know when your data has been hacked, the use of plain language in requests for personal data, the appointment of data protection officers in firms handling large amounts of data, and fines of up to four per cent of annual turnover for companies that do not respect the rules.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: In writing. Although it is regrettable that this text contains many legal uncertainties related to vague wording, it is the result of a compromise that has been very difficult to achieve. Negotiations on this text took four years and were long because of the attitude of certain political groups, which were paralyzing the process. I voted for this essential text which sets out a legal framework for the protection of personal data.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: In writing. Although the proposed regulation remains complex and presents a number of legal uncertainties, it also proposes a strong framework for the protection of personal data. I approved the sending at second reading, thus waiting for more clarity at the end of the next round of negotiations.

name: József NAGY
text: Writing. \u2012 Today, a new directive regulating the processing of personal data and their price between Member States has finally been adopted, which the European Parliament has been working on for years. The aim was to develop a harmonised data protection framework capable of facing the challenges of globalisation and rapid technological development. The world has changed a lot and today achievements such as Google and Facebook have become a part of our daily lives, so it is no surprise that the Data Protection Directive, which has been in force since 1995 and is changing from one Member State to another, seems outdated. I am pleased that the long work has paid off and that we have been able to decide on a well-developed, understandable proposal that is uniform for all Member States.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: Writing. \u2012 I supported the reform of the protection of personal data in the EU, which will allow citizens to have their personal data firmly under their control again, for example by ensuring easier access to their own personal data, by clearly defining the 'right to be forgotten' or by the right to be informed about the misuse of their own personal data. Businesses will certainly welcome the fact that by introducing a one-stop shop, they will only negotiate with one supervisory authority, saving an estimated EUR 2.3 billion per year.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: Writing. – I support the draft regulation tabled. Technological developments and globalisation have fundamentally changed the principles of the processing, access and use of personal data. A single data protection framework must therefore be established and applied in the EU. It should be noted that the new data protection rules will give internet users more control over their personal data. In addition, requirements will be laid down for the transfer of data to third countries. This will make it easier for consumers to use information society services and promote the growth of these services and innovations in Europe. The new changes will help to reduce the administrative and financial burden on businesses.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. \u2012 The legislative package passed in the European Parliament with the falsified title on "protection of personal data" also legitimises the generalised file of everything with the help of EU legislation. It introduces an exception to any protection if it 'constitutes a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society to avoid obstructing investigations, preventing and detecting criminal offences, protecting public order, national security, protecting the rights of third parties'. The exceptions are of such scope and generality that they essentially make the file a rule.  It also allows the collection and exchange of data relating to all political and social action. The rule is the transmission and exchange of data between the various secret and security services, not only eu Member States, but also third countries and imperialist organisations (US, NATO, etc.).  The target of repression mechanisms can be targeted without even being suspected of any act, simply "for reasons of public order and security"!  Monopolies and their associations see popular rights and freedoms as a danger to their power. That is why their defence is inseparable from the struggle to overthrow them, for radical changes in power and the economy.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. \u2012 In view of the Council's position expressed at first reading on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data and the free movement of personal data, I would like to vote in favour.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: Writing. \ u2012 I welcome the adoption of the PNR package and the use of private data. I am pleased that we have finally adopted the legislative package, albeit in a less ambitious form than our political group has wanted from the outset. There was far too much waiting and political calculation of certain political groups on this important subject, highlighting aspects of privacy restrictions. They have blocked progress in the area of data exchange, which is crucial for maintaining the security of our citizens. We will now be able to finally enter the interinstitutional negotiations and implementation phase. We must respond to the current security challenges with legislation that guarantees the safety of our citizens. For more security, I'm also willing to risk some privacy.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: Written. ‒I welcome the introduction of new legal frameworks in the area of personal data protection, as this will raise the level of security within the borders of the European Union and combat any misuse of our citizens' personal data in advance. I agree on the need to strengthen the European Union's policy based on the right to protect personal data, because it is this principle by which everyone has the right to the protection of their own identity that the European Union is guided.  I believe that the implementation of this proposal will lead to a significant improvement in legal certainty, a reduction in administrative burden and consistency in the implementation of data protection in the Union, all the more so as it protects the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular the right to the protection of personal data. A very important determinant of this proposal is the setting of additional conditions on the legality of the processing of children's personal data, which I especially welcome.  These measures also call on member states to establish better communication with each other in order for the system to fully function, and I believe that there will be better communication and cooperation.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. \u2012 The rapid pace of technological change has made it essential to update the legislation governing the processing and protection of personal data. The old 1995 directive, in fact, was approved when only a small percentage of citizens had access to the Internet and social networks, online banking and e-commerce did not yet exist. Today, the Internet affects almost every aspect of our lives, and an increasing amount of personal data is networked. It is of paramount importance that this data is treated appropriately. That is why updating the regulation is so important. It is up to the times and gives citizens back control over their personal data. For the first time, we also have a harmonised system of protection that covers all 28 Member States of the Union. Establishing a climate of trust in online environments is fundamental for economic development. Lack of confidence is holding consumers back from buying online and using new services and risks slowing down the development of innovative technology applications. The new package makes it clear to everyone that the EU is seriously committed to protecting the rights of European citizens, helping to create the necessary climate of trust.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: Written. ‒ With the adoption of this Regulation, which I support, a complete reform of the data protection rules that the EP has been working on for 4 years has been completed. The reform will replace the current data protection directive, which dates back to 1995, when the internet was still in its infancy, and adopted a general regulation designed to give citizens more control over their own information in the digitised world of smartphones, social media and internet banking.  The new rules include, inter alia, the right to erasure (the 'right to be forgotten'), 'clear and positive consent' to the processing of personal data by the questioned person, the right to transfer data to another controller, informing the data subject of personal data breaches, ensuring that the privacy policy is explained in clear and understandable language and stronger enforcement of the fine to companies up to 4% of the total annual turnover worldwide if they violate the rules.  This is a great success for the European Parliament and a vocal European "yes" for strong consumer rights and competition in the digital age. Citizens will be able to decide for themselves what personal information they want to share.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. \u2012 This report supports the strengthening of the right to the protection of personal data, even if guaranteed by a unified legal framework. It proposes that the Commission should have the least possible interference in its implementation and is expected to ensure the protection of personal data.  The new rules provide for the following measures: Improving access to their data - people will receive more, clearer and more understandable information on how their data is processed;  The 'right to be forgotten' - when a person no longer wants his data to be processed, and if there are no legitimate reasons for their retention, he may obtain the deletion thereof; The right to know if your data has been hacked - companies should notify the supervisory authority and the data subject of any personal data breaches that put people at risk; The right to data portability will make it easier for people to transfer their personal data from one service provider to another. The proposed Regulation provides that supervisors may impose fines on undertakings that violate EU rules by up to 2 % of their overall annual turnover.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. \u2012 The new EU data protection rules aim to give citizens greater control over their personal data and to create a high and uniform level of data protection across the EU in the digital age. The reform lays down minimum standards for the use of data for judicial and police purposes. The draft also provides for the establishment of a European Data Protection Committee, which will include representatives of all 28 independent supervisory authorities and replace the existing Article 29 committee. The project also includes the transfer of personal data to third countries and international organisations. For all these reasons, I voted in favour of the Regulation.

name: Franck PROUST
text: In writing. The European Parliament's vote comes more than four years after work began on reforming EU data protection provisions. The message here is very clear: the new provisions aim to increase the protection of European citizens so that they have control over their personal data. The level of protection must be high and uniform in the European Union. I therefore voted in favour of new rules that include provisions on the right to be forgotten or the right to transfer personal data to other service providers.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: In writing. I welcome the adoption of the new data protection regulation. This regulation harmonizes European legislation and allows individuals to exercise greater control over their privacy. As a result, Europeans now have a greater right to information and consent when processing their data, a right to use abuses and a right to object to profiling. Finally, sensitive data will be better protected. These are all measures that businesses and Member States in the European Union will have to respect. The regulation also supports the digital economy by ensuring free and undistorted competition in this sector, which will apply to all companies, including foreign ones. This will allow European companies to play an equal game with internet giants such as Facebook or Google. Deterrence sanctions are also provided in the text for companies that do not comply with the rules. Finally, this regulation is part of a data protection package, voted on the same day as the PNR at the initiative of the European Socialists and Democrats. This shows once again the commitment of MEPs to ensure data protection, which is all the more necessary in the digital age.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: In writing. This text is part of the data protection package, which plays a crucial role in the digital strategy for Europe, and represents a step forward in reducing the legal uncertainty caused by the fragmentation that characterizes the implementation of personal data protection in the EU. We parliamentarians have also highlighted the need to reduce the administrative burden, further harmonize the application of data protection rules, improve the effectiveness of their control and transparency.   We can only regret that this data protection package was not voted on at the same time as the PNR directive, as was originally hoped for by my political group in Parliament.  For all these reasons, I voted in favour of this text.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing. \u2012 European data protection rules date back to 1995. We need to ensure that users have greater control over their data and subject transfers to countries outside the EU to tighter requirements.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: in writing. I voted in favour of this legislative package because it implies a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by law enforcement and judicial authorities.  This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects relating to the storage, processing and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over as relevant aspects of their lives as privacy is.  The way in which judicial and police authorities process citizens' personal data has a profound impact on citizens' fundamental rights. The new directive will help to ensure that these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide legislation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time we will have a harmonised system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: In writing. I voted in favour of the adoption of this package, which will strengthen the data protection of European citizens, especially in the digital world. This revision of the general framework for the protection of personal data makes users in control of their data by strengthening the right to information about what is being done with data, by improving consent procedures and remedies. The new regulation also improves data portability and guarantees the right to oppose profiling as well as additional protection against the use of sensitive data. With this new regulation, the internet giants, even if they are located outside the European Union, will have to apply our rules. This is a significant step forward for citizens. This package also contains elements relating to the fight against crime. In this context, the data will be treated in a very controlled manner in order to avoid any misuse by the services concerned. Finally, it is expected that national data protection authorities will be strengthened and made more independent so that they can enforce the rules effectively.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which approves the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of the Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of natural persons, with regard to the processing of personal data and the free movement of such data by repealing Directive 95/46/EC. The proposed Regulation aims to modernise the principles laid down in the 1995 Directive, adapting them to the digital age and harmonising data protection legislation at European level.  I believe that data protection must, of course, be subject to strict standards and should convey to citizens a sense of security regarding the use of their personal data. At the same time, the proposal for a Regulation aims to strengthen individual rights and consolidate the EU internal market by ensuring stricter enforcement of regulations, simplifying international transfers of personal data and introducing international data protection standards. For all that is expressed, my vote was in favour of this report.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. \u2012 The Internet is no longer just a useful platform for searching for information, but a tool that is part of our lives and contains a part of them. People's rights must therefore find ways of adapting to these changes. That is why I voted in favour of Parliament's recommendation on this regulation, as it represents a further step forward for Europe in protecting people in the digital age. It aims to ensure respect for personal data (the right to be forgotten) and imposes as transparent and clear use as possible of it (informed consent), in order that the citizen-user can knowing and consciously decide on the use that is made of his data. This vote aims to standardise European personal protection policy, putting its rights back at the centre, including in the digital field, by providing a clear framework for EU businesses too, for the benefit of their competitiveness. Indeed, the opportunities offered to businesses by the digital market, in the light of greater integration of the single market, should not be underestimated. These opportunities can only be such, however, if they also guarantee respect for citizens' rights.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: in writing. We have decided to support this report with one vote in favour, given that the development of this report has been done in compliance with the views of most political positions and we believe that it is moving mostly in the direction we stand for.  However, in some chapters concerning personal privacy, we believe that more firm progress must be made.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. \u2012 I voted in favour of this report, which aims to update the Directive on the protection of personal data and to provide greater protection for natural persons. In recent years we have seen an exponential development of global data sharing, collection and flow. Current technologies allow both private companies and public authorities to use personal data, as never before, in carrying out their activities and, increasingly, private individuals themselves make personal information about them public on the network. This has made it necessary to regulate more modernly and uniformly at European level in order to protect citizens. The new regulation defines the rights of natural persons, such as the need for consent to the processing of personal data, the right to rectify and delete data and easy access to their personal data. The general obligations of those who process or are responsible for the data are also established, including the obligation to implement appropriate security measures according to the risk associated with the operations carried out and to communicate breaches of personal data.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: Writing. \u2012 I am pleased that the development of the protection of the personal data provided is supported. For this reason, I voted in favour of the proposal for this regulation. In fact, I consider it important that personal data providers have control over a transparent way of processing this data when using modern information technologies. The regulation also presents a clear way of controlling the transmission of sensitive consumer information.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The Commission's first legislative proposal on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of their personal data came in 2012. Since then, discussions have taken place in the Council, where national governments have long delayed the adoption of the final regulation. Since 2014, discussions on this matter have been frozen. Only the recent dramatic events in Paris and Brussels have revealed in full nudity the inability of security authorities to exchange the necessary information. In this context, the European Parliament calls for an end to the debate and the adoption of legislative measures to protect personal data. I therefore supported the Council's position at second reading, and I believe that we will finally move from words to deeds and that the regulation will be put into practice. This proposal is also part of a package, together with proposals for directives on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data for the purpose of crime prevention and on the use of airline passenger data. In order for security authorities to be able to effectively detect, investigate and prosecute terrorist offenders, it is essential that clear rules are established at European level within which national authorities can operate. National governments will need to show more determination and implement all these instruments without delay in order to be able to guarantee the security of their citizens.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - After four years of long and complex negotiation, today we finally approved the data protection package, which updates the European privacy legislation to the challenges posed by the digital evolution to the rights of citizens and businesses. The first element of the package is the regulation on the processing of personal data by industries and public authorities, which will ensure a high and uniform level of data protection across the Union. The regulation will allow citizens to better manage their data, while businesses will be able to seize the opportunities offered by the digital single market thanks to a simplification of administrative burdens. The new rules include in fact provisions on the right to be forgotten, conditions for a "clear consent" to the processing of private data, the right to be aware of the violation of one's personal data, the clarity of information relating to privacy policies, stricter application of these provisions and administrative fines of up to 4% of annual turnover for companies that violate these provisions. For these reasons, I voted in favor of the measure.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The new legislative framework for the protection of personal data is an important measure at European Union level and a response to the legal uncertainty and significant risks associated with online activities.The new rules on the processing and free movement of personal data not only guarantee better protection of individuals' data (prevention of data leakage and misuse), but also contribute to the creation of a digital single market by increasing confidence in online services.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
