text: written.- Having regard to the recommendation for second reading of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I supported the Council's position in first reading on the adoption of a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal dataDirective 95/46 / EC (General Data Protection Regulation).

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I voted against the proposal because the proposal unjustifiably increases the regulatory burden and is also a risk to internet freedom.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data.We need a solid and coherent framework for data protection in the European Union, which we will implement consistently.Only in this way will we strengthen the trust of our citizens, which has been at a low level in recent years.We must be extremely careful and sensitive when processing personal data, as privacy is a basic human right.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. - The proposed regulation replaces a directive (95/46 / EC), in which case it has greater legal weight, but basically comes to fill the gaps in the protection of personal data that the directive had. Specifics and characteristics: 1. The accountability of the controllers and the executors is strengthened, while imposing sanctions are instituted, which create incentives for the controllers to comply with the regulations. 2. Codes of conduct and certification mechanisms are introduced with a legally binding character, such as the right of "forgetfulness" (a person who no longer wants to process his data, they are deleted), but also to facilitate users' access to their data. 3. Enhanced and enforceable rights for citizens are provided for, as well as prohibitions on the processing of personal data for children. 4. In particular, the independence of the supervisory authorities is strengthened, so that each national authority works without interference, as was not the case in the case of breaches of personal data of Golden Dawn executives, during political persecutions.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the adoption of the recommendation on the Council's position, as the political agreement approved by the Council maintained the objectives of the Commission proposal, which I also support, mainly strengthening individual rights, consolidating the EU internal market, enforcing rules and global data protection standards.aimed at creating.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The Data Protection Package provides individuals with information on how their personal data is processed, it requires consent before personal data is used, it makes it easier for people to transfer their personal data between service providers and it provides individuals with the right to know when their personal data has been hacked. Furthermore, it is beneficial to businesses, as it sets a single set of rules across Europe, with one supervisory authority. This directive is in the interest of the consumer, who is granted a higher amount of control over his/her personal data. Greater consumer transparency and choice leads to more trustful, consumer-friendly and secure products and services. Having considered the benefits of the new rules, I support the Data Protection Package.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I of course voted in favor of the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data andto the free movement of such data and repealing Directive 95/46 / EC.It was high time for an update.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ On the same day as the vote on PNR, it was also important to vote the new EU data protection rules. Indeed, this will merge different legal approaches in EU Member States into one single European rulebook and will give people back control of their personal information. Europeans are more and more careful with the personal information they want to share and rightly so. The new regulation includes, among other things, provisions on the right to be forgotten, the ‘clear and affirmative consent’ to the processing of private data by the person concerned, the right to transfer your data to another service provider and the right to know when your data has been hacked. The data protection package also includes a directive on data transfers for policing and judicial purposes, which will help authorities transfer valuable personal data efficiently while respecting the fundamental right to privacy.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The protection of personal data and respect for private life are fundamental rights, and the European Parliament has always insisted on striking a balance between strengthening security, on the one hand, and protecting privacy and personal data, on the other.This Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data updates the 1995 General Data Protection Directive.It will strengthen the rights of citizens who will have better control over their data and will guarantee their protection of privacy in the digital age.Because in a global society where technological change is taking place at a rapid pace, it is extremely important to protect personal data, I supported this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- To vote on a recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data.), would support it.Having regard to the reasoned opinions submitted by the Belgian Chamber of Representatives, the German Bundesrat, the French Senate, the Italian Chamber of Deputies and the Swedish Parliament under Protocol (No 2) on the application of the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, stating that the draft legislative proposal is notin accordance with the principle of subsidiarity.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We have decided to support this report with a vote in favor, given that its development has been done respecting the opinions of the majority of political positions and we believe that it is for the most part moving in the direction we defend.However, in some chapters concerning personal privacy, we believe that more firm progress should be made.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The draftsman agrees with the Council's position at first reading and notes that the legislative act has been adopted in accordance with the Council's position.He therefore proposes that the legislative act be signed.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We have decided to support this report with a vote in favor, given that its development has been done respecting the opinions of most political positions and we believe that it is for the most part moving in the direction we defend.However, in some chapters concerning personal privacy, we believe that more firm progress should be made.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ After four years of work on this important piece of legislation, an agreement on the data protection regulation was found on 15 December. The regulation aims at high data protection standards harmonised throughout the EU Member States, and updates the current rules set in the 1995 Data Protection Directive. The standards for data protection will be higher than in the 1995 directive (at best) or equivalent (at worst). I voted in favour of the final text, which brings legal certainty and a level playing field as well as consistent enforcement throughout the EU.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Through this decision, Parliament proceeds to approve the Council's position at first reading on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.We are talking about an important decision that helps us to take another step forward in the protection of European citizens in this area, so I consider it necessary to vote in its favor.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: A regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors, and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of data. It also gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. It is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- The new European regulations on the protection of personal data are a fusion of the different legal methods that previously existed in the Member States into one common European code.This gives European citizens new control over their own personal data.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing.- After five years of negotiations, this report on the protection of personal data was finally adopted, despite the unwillingness of the States.The reform will replace the current data protection directive, which dates from 1995, with a general regulation strengthening and adapting data protection.This report is the result of a long battle in the European Parliament.In particular, it will make it possible to strengthen the participation of individuals in the protection of their own data, to clarify definitions and to provide more legal certainty.The powers and functions of the supervisory and data protection authorities are also strengthened.This regulation also insists on the application of the principles of necessity and proportionality in the transfer of personal data.I therefore voted for this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The proposal for a regulation aims to strengthen individual rights and consolidate the EU's internal market, ensure stricter enforcement of regulations, simplify international transfers of personal data and establish international data protection standards.We fear that, at this juncture, this regulation that centralizes processes and removes the mechanisms for the control of personal data from citizens may create conditions for security drifts that undermine rights, freedoms and guarantees.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The exception, for example to process someone's sex life if it is necessary for historical or statistical purposes or for the purpose of scientific research, is not meaningful and without any basis.The type of political conviction and the necessity due to labor law, apart from political public activity, also make no sense and should be rejected.In addition, the question remains whether this is still relevant in times of passenger data transfer or the agreement between the government of the Republic of Austria and the government of the United States of America on deepening cooperation in preventing and combating serious crimes.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Albrecht report on the protection of personal data, which aims to ensure that citizens have greater control over their data, to give companies more clarity and legal certainty and to subject transfers to countries outside the EU to tighter requirements.European rules on the protection of personal data - dating from 1995, an era when less than 1% of Europeans used the Internet - need to be updated to respond to technological advances, globalization and new methods of collecting, accessing anddata usage.The aim of this reform is to strengthen citizens' control over their data.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the free movement of such data.The field of personal data processing must also be regulated by listening to the right to privacy.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, the many threats to our security mean that it is vital that we continue to look into new ways to prevent crime, and we should grasp the opportunities offered to us by the digital age. But people are also concerned about government access to their data and misuse of that access and the impact on their privacy. This directive strikes the right balance between clear guidelines for law enforcement agencies on the one hand and the importance of protecting people’s privacy on the other. For progressives in the European Parliament, it was key to make sure that this directive goes hand in hand with the one on PNR, which allows us to share flight data, the aim being to ensure that we have more tools to track terrorists without forcing the rest of us to give up our fundamental rights and privacy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: - A Uacharáin, téann an tuarascáil seo dar ndóigh leis an gceann a chuaigh roimhe, agus tá áthas orm gur éirigh linn an da cheann a ghlacadh ar an la ceanna.Mar a dúradh, is é atá anseo ná rialacha soiléire a leagadh sios faoi conas gur féidir le fórsaí slándála agus rialtais úsáid a bhaint as an eolas atá ar an idirlíon agus mar sin de agus as na sonraí prínuairáleáideaíon.Dá bhrí sin is féidir linn a bheith cinnte go mbeimid children satáilte amach anseo mar tá na rialacha soiléir anois agus caithfear glacadh leo, agus mura nglacfar leo tá pionóis ann.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President.Theft of credit card data, illegal gaining of goods, even taking a loan, taking a mortgage loan - in my country, Latvia, too, it is unfortunately a daily occurrence and fraudulently, fraud is rampant.I believe that this recommendation for second reading is extremely important and, as the rapporteur, Marju Lauristin, said, it is a very good balance between the security and privacy of citizens.I therefore voted in favor and believe that we need to develop this approach in order to protect citizens from the theft of their private data, and we also definitely need a minimum legal level of protection of personal data for the prevention of criminal offenses, which is essential for the European Union.the aim.And I will repeat that I voted in favor.Thanks!

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - So the citizen says that I have nothing to hide, nothing to hide, I renounce my private secrets, my privacy, my privacy.I hand over this slice of my human dignity.I give all my thoughts and feelings to the government, the power, the secret services and, if necessary, international organizations.Feel free to listen, listen, read my email, do anything, as this will win my safety.Unfortunately, they are making a huge mistake, and there is no such causal link, as I will explain in the third part of my speech, but the state and the “Big Brother”, the “Big Brother”, can collect all the data andabuses this collected data, which in itself makes a person vulnerable, and this situation itself is a gross violation of human dignity.Thank you very much.

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Madam President! In and of itself, if you will, we have three construction sites in the digital age. First of all, of course, the citizens should also use the blessings of the digital age. It starts with online banking and goes through online shopping. We all have a cell phone and of course we use the flood of data for our purposes in a positive sense. Second, of course, we also have to protect the citizen from himself in part so that he does not fall into the clutches of criminal machinations. Because data is exchanged, and suddenly accounts are set up against the will of the consumer, then all of a sudden orders are triggered that were not triggered at all. So this protection is expressly significant and important. Thirdly, in order to prevent criminal activities, we must also find a regulation on how we exchange data and how society or, in the fight against crime, the police can access this data. We have to resolve this triad and I hope we have found a good compromise.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I supported this report in the same way as the previous report, I see it in a certain package, in a certain summary.It is undoubtedly a monumental legal work, because this regulation replaces the previous one and removes a number of white spaces, as well as a number of uncertainties.As far as this particular report is concerned, I think that the rules for preventive data protection are set, as well as, of course, the possibility for the state, in certain cases, to break this protection.It is always a question of how to adjust this balance, this balance in the current turbulent times.I believe that, of course, it is a priority to protect the security of our citizens.I do not want to say that data protection should be broken, but we must see it in the context of this particular time in which we find ourselves.I think that the limits that are set there are set correctly in balance.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, I fully agree with the text of this report and that is why I voted in favor of it with conviction. This Directive applies specifically to judicial judicial activities. That is why it is even more important to have the strong and clear legal framework voted on today, guaranteeing the highest opportunities for protection. We need better cooperation and a more critical approach to the collection, exchange and transfer of personal data, which in addition needs to be better differentiated through the proposed and voted differentiated categorization. There can be no compulsory transfers if these conditions are not met.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: A regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors, and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of data. It also gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. It is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the EU among the 28 partners

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S & amp; D), in writing. The Police and Criminal Procedure Directive refers to the protection of individuals against the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purpose of preventing, investigating, detecting or prosecuting criminal offenses or the enforcement of criminal sanctions, as well as the circulation of such data. This legislation is necessary to protect the fundamental rights of individuals, especially in the face of the latest technological changes, and the completion of the digital market.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this proposal, which aims to ensure a uniformly high level of data protection in this area, thus increasing mutual trust between police and judicial authorities in different Member States, facilitating the free movement of data and police and judicial cooperation. Today, we have adopted the personal data package, and this is a significant step that will ensure a smoother exchange of data between Member States and their authorities. Data protection is one of the fundamental rights of EU citizens and citizens have a right to expect adequate data protection. Although a number of concerns remain, both among citizens and politicians, or the new legislation will ensure effective and comprehensive protection of personal data, I voted in favor of the whole package. In the face of the current terrorist threats, it was no longer possible to procrastinate and hesitate any longer. Recent terrorist attacks could have been avoided if Member States had provided the data on terrorists in their possession, but this has not been done. Today, the issue of the security of Europe and our citizens is more relevant than ever, so I believe that the personal data package, albeit with shortcomings, will be useful in the fight against terrorism.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I have approved this directive, which will for the first time set minimum standards for data processing for police purposes in each Member State.This should make it possible to significantly increase the exchange of personal data between law enforcement authorities in the Member States, and therefore to work more effectively in the prevention of terrorist acts, while respecting fundamental rights.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We have voted in favor of this legislative resolution on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by authorities for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution ofcriminal offenses or the execution of criminal penalties, and the free circulation of these data.Throughout the process, Parliament introduced important measures to preserve the rights of people in the use of these data with limitations in the time of holding these data, classifying the data into categories to determine under what conditions they could be processed andeliminated, among other things, the transfer of information to third countries unless it has the authorization of the competent authorities, because it did not consider that it offered the necessary safeguards.Therefore, it was voted in favor at third reading.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: A regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors, and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. It is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report on the Council position for adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offenses and the free movement of such data. The purpose of the processing of personal data is to serve a person, i.e. The principles and rules on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of their personal data should respect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, in particular the right to the protection of personal data, regardless of their nationality or place of residence. This should help complete the area of ​​freedom, security and justice. It should be noted that rapid technological development and globalization pose new challenges for the protection of personal data. There has been a sharp increase in data collection and exchange. Technology enables competent authorities to access personal data on an unprecedented scale in the course of their activities. Thus, in order to ensure effective judicial cooperation in criminal matters and police cooperation, it is essential to ensure a uniform high level of protection of personal data and thus to facilitate the exchange of personal data between the competent authorities of the Member States. Therefore, equivalent protection of the rights and freedoms of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offenses or the enforcement of criminal sanctions must be ensured in all Member States.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The recently approved directive on the protection of personal data in the sector of counteracting illegal activities aims to protect data processed for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes or execution of criminal sanctions. In accordance with Article 8 of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, as well as with Article 16 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which establish the right of every person to the protection of personal data concerning him / her, it is It is essential to ensure a high and uniform level, at European level, of data protection for natural persons. At the same time, however, it is necessary, in order to guarantee greater security and prevention of offenses, to facilitate the exchange of personal data between the respective national intelligence services. In this sense, I believe that the directive in question strikes a good balance with respect to these two different needs, guaranteeing the right to privacy and, at the same time, giving the possibility to the police forces to better combat and prevent the emergence of illegal activities. .

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- The Data protection package had a very long parliamentary process that lasted a few years.In a nutshell, the final result sees us satisfied as true data regulation is fundamental and necessary.The major criticality that we must point out is the legislative tortuosity of some provisions, but overall the safeguards in the management and processing of personal data and the consequent guarantees for the privacy of all citizens that are provided meet the minimum criteria that we have always requested.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: A regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors, and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of data. It also gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. It is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the EU among the 28 partners

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - After careful reading and discussion in plenary, I voted in favor of the report on the motion for a resolution on the basis of the following considerations: in the light of the attacks in Paris and Brussels, Member States must share information more effectively. The creation of harmonized rules between Member States on the transfer and processing of data should facilitate this process, while ensuring that the fundamental rights of European citizens are not violated. But also the "Panama Papers" affair confirms the need for information to be managed adequately, also in consideration of the seriousness of the financial crimes that are revealing themselves. I expect the European Union and the Commission with its proposals to speak with one voice to protect European values ​​and restore consumer confidence, given that the fight against terrorism needs new tools and the security of the financial system and European banking is essential.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which recommends that Parliament approves the Council position at first reading with a view to the adoption of a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences or the execution of criminal penalties, and on the free movement of such data, and repealing Council Framework Decision 2008/977/JHA.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and believe that the single European Passenger Name Registration System (PNR) is a necessary tool in the fight against terrorism, especially in the wake of the recent terrorist attacks.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that in the Europe we live in, which is always open and open to cooperation, it is still necessary to better protect the privacy of individual citizens.Furthermore, this report lays a solid foundation for the processing of personal data for the purposes of investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes, since, especially due to recent events, greater prevention is required and it is therefore essential to seek a balance betweenthe protection of personal data and the use of these against crime.That is why I voted in favor, because I am convinced that this report is moving precisely in this direction, aiming at strengthening, guaranteeing and clarifying the rights of the persons concerned and establishing basic safeguards today.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this to ensure that authorities have access to the necessary data to keep Europe safe and protect our citizens.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - As recent events have tragically made clear, cooperation between Member States in the fight against organized crime, in particular against terrorism, still fails. This flaw is and was especially evident with regard to information sharing. Without prejudice to the need for new responses, the lack of mutual trust has long been clear. The lack of information that Europol is often faced with or the under-utilization of the Schengen Information System are paradigmatic examples. It will not be by decree that we will "create" more confidence, we can reinforce it through instruments like this directive, guaranteeing minimums in each Member State. But this directive is all the more important as new systems are approved and more and more information from citizens is processed. Ultimately, this directive guarantees that misuse can be corrected or sanctioned. It should also be noted that this directive is thus aligned with the new framework introduced by the Lisbon Treaty, that is, without pillars and with Parliament as co-legislator.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor as the act was adopted in accordance with the Council's position.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The processing of personal data for the purposes of prevention, investigation and prosecution of crimes is a matter of absolute importance for all European institutions. I believe that the approval can no longer be postponed. The events of recent months have shown the extreme fragility of our security systems and made it necessary to have an effective information exchange system between the Member States. The protection of individuals in the EU is a priority that has long awaited a homogeneous response from all Member States. It is clear that protecting the safety of citizens implies the use of a uniform data processing system, which puts an end to the current national divergences on the matter and which makes it possible to detect and prosecute crimes, including those of a terrorist nature. Above all, it is clear that this need must not be hindered, but rather go hand in hand with the right to privacy of European citizens.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- The directive creates the second half of the data protection package.It deals with the specific nature of police and judicial activities and sets out how personal data should be used in criminal proceedings and investigations.This proposal covers both cross-border and domestic data processing by the competent authorities of the Member States.I hope that the new rules will increase confidence in mutual recognition and cross-border law enforcement cooperation.Once adopted, the Directive will apply to measures such as Europol and EU-PNR as soon as it is adopted and enforced.I voted in favor of the draft.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This codecision report makes legal proposals to strengthen the protection of personal data within the Union, in particular when it is used to fight crime.It also aims to build trust between law enforcement authorities so that they can exchange personal data in their possession to fight crime.Considering that it is also necessary to lay down strict standards for the use of data for police and judicial purposes, and that citizens' rights relating to this issue must be respected, I supported this report.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – A coherent data protection framework also plays an important role in the prevention of crime. Having common standards as to how to share this information will only facilitate this. In essence, clear, cohesive, uniform and transparent legislation was needed in order to create a pleasant and efficient business environment. At the same time, we have now set up a framework within which our government agencies can operate, using data, in order to prevent crime. This precarious balance is the result of long negotiations.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the directive on data transfers for police and judicial purposes, which sets, for the first time, minimum standards for the processing of such data in each Member State. The new rules aim to protect individuals by providing clear rights and limits on the transfer of data for the purposes of preventing and detecting criminal offenses, investigating and prosecuting them, or carrying out criminal offenses. penals sanctions. They also include safeguards and preventive measures against threats to public security, while facilitating the establishment of easier and more effective cooperation between law enforcement authorities. The new directive will apply both to the cross-border processing of such data and to the processing at strictly national level and leaves the Member States the possibility of providing for stricter guarantees than those set out in the directive. In addition, it provides for the right of data subjects to obtain compensation if they suffer damage as a result of processing that does not comply with the rules.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The directive includes rules on data processing in the context of crime prevention.Personal data includes any information relating to a person, whether it concerns his private, professional or public life.It can be a name, a photo, an email address, bank information, messages posted on social networks, medical information or your computer's IP address.The reform regulates, among other topics, the consent of the holder, the right to erase data ("the right to be forgotten"), the right to portability, the right to be informed about personal data breaches, data transfercountries outside the EU and the sanctions applicable to companies.Companies that violate the rules may have to pay fines of up to 4% of their annual turnover.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The directive in question is part of the package of measures proposed by the European Commission to reform data protection, which includes a general regulation. For our part, we consider it important to ensure a high and homogeneous level of protection of the personal data of natural persons and to facilitate the exchange of that data between the competent authorities of the Member States, in order to guarantee the effectiveness of judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as well as police cooperation. To this end, the level of protection of the rights, freedoms and guarantees of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purpose of preventing, investigating, detecting and prosecuting criminal offenses or carrying out criminal sanctions, must be equivalent in all Member States. Effective protection of personal data across the EU requires not only that the rights of data subjects and the obligations of data controllers be strengthened, but that equivalent powers to control and ensure, in different Member States, are conferred. the application of the rules on the protection of personal data. The directive will allow police and judicial authorities to cooperate more effectively and faster, ensuring legal certainty.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted in favour because it is positive for citizens living within the EU.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. - The general aim of the agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of personal data, in the areas of police and judicial cooperation, in criminal matters with a view to preventing, investigating, detecting or prosecuting criminal offenses, but it violates the general principles of data protection personal. The act proves that commitments in the field of information exchange are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the bombers of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other. The agreement does not really reinforce the risk-based approach, nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default. In addition, the provision of harmonized criteria, conditions and restrictions is contrary to the provision, in the agreement, of the inclusion of private entities in the sense of "competent authorities". In conclusion, the cooperation is practically impossible, taking into account the simple example of the non-extradition of Christoforakos by the German authorities in Greece, to investigate the SIEMENS scandal. For all the above reasons my vote is against.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ There is a growing need for law enforcement authorities in Member States to process and exchange at rapidly increasing rates for the purposes of preventing and combating transnational crime and terrorism. In this context, clear and consistent rules on data protection at EU level will help fostering co-operation between such authorities. In addition, there are practical challenges to enforcing data protection legislation and a need for cooperation between Member States and their authorities, which need to be organised at EU level to ensure unity of application of European Union law. In certain situations, the EU is best placed to ensure effectively and consistently the same level of protection for individuals when their personal data are transferred to third countries. I therefore voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. – With today’s vote on processing of personal data for the purposes of crime prevention we reached an important balance between the high-level protection of personal data on one side and the need to give support to police forces in their investigations on the other side. We achieved a common frame to allow an efficient exchange of information among law enforcement bodies, securing personal data and giving police forces enough space to be effective and cooperative in their investigations. We are in favour of this final document, as it is important to give all possible support to law enforcement authorities, especially in the present emergency situation with regard to terrorism.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: A Regulation that addresses the processing of personal data by private actors and, on the other hand, a Directive that covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of data. In addition, it gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new Directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, a proposal that will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. This is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: A regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors, and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of the data. It also gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. It is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the recommendation for second reading on the Council position at first reading with a view to adopting the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by part of the competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes or the execution of criminal sanctions, as well as the free circulation of such data and I believe that the approval of this legislation, together with the vote on the PNR Directive, represents an important event for Europe. I therefore congratulate the rapporteur and the whole S & amp; D group for having waged a fair battle to couple the PNR legislation with a uniform legal framework for the processing of personal data which ensures a uniform data collection and retention system. in all States that respects the rights of citizens, first of all the principle of privacy. It is up to the Member States to implement these two instruments in their respective national laws, guaranteeing on the one hand the protection of citizens' rights and on the other hand genuine cooperation between the intelligence authorities.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We have voted in favor of this legislative resolution on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by authorities for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution ofcriminal offenses or the execution of criminal penalties, and the free circulation of these data.Throughout the process, Parliament introduced important measures to preserve the rights of people in the use of these data with limitations in the time of holding these data, classifying the data into categories to determine under what conditions they could be processed andeliminated, among other things, the transfer of information to third countries unless it has the authorization of the competent authorities, because it did not consider that it offered the necessary safeguards.Therefore, it was voted in favor at third reading.

name: Nathalie GRIESBECK
text: in writing.- I resolutely voted in favor of this major reform of data protection, which allows us to adapt to contemporary digital developments.Citizens are publishing more and more personal information and companies in the digital sector have set up a large-scale collection of it.It was therefore necessary to modernize inadequate legislation, which dated back to 1995!This reform of European legislation obliges companies to inform their customers in the event of data piracy, authorizes the transfer of data in very limited cases and above all, establishes a right to be forgotten and a right of citizens to inspect information.that are collected on them.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this directive as it will provide new safeguards for all EU citizens. It will ensure protections are in place for the processing of data for law enforcement purposes, providing clear and consistent guidelines for authorities while ensuring fundamental rights and privacy are upheld. This is also important in the context of PNR (passenger name records).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - This directive sets up a base of guarantees for the rights and freedoms of citizens, while modern technologies now allow the use of successful means of surveillance of the population by the police and the judiciary in order to ensure their safety, in the context of terrorist threat that we know. While it is important to be able to prevent attacks and crime by strengthening police and judicial cooperation within the European Union, it is also essential to simultaneously protect the fundamental rights of citizens. Indeed, a fault in the protection of the data of suspects, witnesses or victims can threaten their security, their right to privacy or that to a fair trial. This is why I voted for this set of laws and measures that govern access to this data by the security forces, while harmonizing the processes for processing and transferring this data between the 28 countries of the European Union for an easier exchange of information, in order to counter cross-border criminal initiatives.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ Data protection has become a hugely important area of EU policy and law. The repeal of Directive 95/46/EC allows for more practical and updated legislation to be passed into law and provide a system whereby citizens’ fundamental right to privacy is respected. This will allow people to regain control of their personal data and also bring EU legislation into the digital age.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - I approved the rapporteur's recommendation on the proposal for a directive on sovereign files, which supplements the existing national rules on data processing for criminal purposes. This directive establishes minimum data protection rules other than those covered by the regulation, which deals, for its part, with commercial uses. This text in fact governs, with a view to harmonization, the processing of data used in the context of police and judicial activities and which may be useful for investigations and prosecutions. I consider that if the first version was unacceptable because it did not respect the essential balance between the protection of personal data and their necessary use for security purposes, the version at second reading, which results from a agreement with the Member States, seems to me to be much more balanced, insofar as it corrects the risks weighing on the operational capacities of law enforcement agencies.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities. movement of such data and repealing Council Framework Decision 2008/977 / JHA, whereas this Directive, together with the Regulation on the Protection of Individuals with regard to the Processing of Personal Data, constitutes a package of legislative proposals replacing the obsolete Directive 95/46. The fact is that the law-making process is far slower than the changes taking place in the social and economic environment through the application of digital technology. There is an even greater danger that crime adapts far faster to the "benefits" of advanced information technologies. This Directive will contribute to strengthening the efficiency and effectiveness of the police force in the fight against crime and terrorism. This Directive provides a harmonized framework governing international policing in the digital society. It provides a framework that contributes to the security and protection of citizens. It includes the protection of privacy, personal freedoms and provides opportunities for quality police action.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- This directive guarantees the protection of personal data of people involved in criminal proceedings, whether as witnesses, victims or suspects.It will also facilitate the exchange of information between national police and judicial authorities.The directive also provides clear rules for the transfer of personal data by law enforcement agencies outside the European Union.On the one hand, this directive is designed to protect personal data;on the other hand, it is a new stage in the constitution of a European police and penal system, while this competence lies with the Member States.New attack on national sovereignty, therefore.I therefore naturally voted against this text.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I welcome the adoption of the report by my colleague Marju Lauristin on the protection of natural persons for the purposes of preventing criminal offenses.The report is a directive on the processing of personal data for preventive security purposes.I approve this proposal which aims to protect the fundamental rights and freedoms of natural persons, and in particular their right to the protection of personal data, and which guarantees the free exchange of such data by the competent authorities within the Union.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this directive on data processing, which complements and harmonizes national rules on data processing for criminal purposes to facilitate cooperation and the exchange of information between police authorities andjudicial.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I can support data collections for crime prevention, but the proposal goes far too far and interferes too strongly with civil rights, in particular with the right of citizens to privacy.I therefore reject the report.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ In the new digital age, it is our moral duty to protect the rights and freedoms of EU citizens. We should propose a general data protection regulation that creates confidence in citizens, gives them the right to transfer their data to another service provider and protects their personal data. Therefore, in order to be fully effective and efficient for citizens, the new data directive should set out clear rights and limitations on data transfers for the purpose of prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offences. Thus, in this manner, data transfers for policing and judicial purposes among law enforcement authorities of Member States will above all respect citizens’ fundamental right to privacy, and the fight against terrorism, cybercrime and cross-border crime will be well organised.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- The report on the protection of natural persons for the purpose of preventing criminal offenses passed second reading, so there was no final vote.I take this opportunity, however, to highlight certain aspects of this directive.This guarantees the protection of personal data in the context of criminal proceedings, for witnesses and victims as well as for suspects.In particular, it prohibits "profiling", which risks making any targeted approach in the fight against Islamist terrorism more difficult.I am also opposed to any new step in the constitution of a European police and penal system, which is a competence of the Member States.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- The text submitted to the vote guarantees the protection of the personal data of individuals involved in criminal proceedings, whether they are witnesses, victims or suspects.In addition, it facilitates the exchange of information between national police and judicial authorities and provides for the harmonization of 28 national data protection laws.In this way, personal data would be better protected and processed in a fair and lawful manner for a specific purpose, which would be monitored by independent national authorities.However, although the Commission promises us better security of personal data and respect for fundamental freedoms, it undermines national sovereignty, because the police and penal system is fundamentally a sovereign right.So I logically voted against.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: A regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors, and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of data. It also gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. It is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written.- The EU needs a more inclusive and coherent policy regarding the fundamental right to protect personal data.Currently, the scope of this legislation is limited and, at times, creates difficulties for the police authorities and other competent authorities in areas of judicial cooperation in criminal matters.It is important to reinforce the EU's position on the protection of personal data, including police repression and crime prevention, always respecting the limits set by privacy.I support this report as the measures promoted through it will facilitate cooperation in the field of fighting crime in Europe.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- I supported the draft legislative resolution of the European Parliament on the position of the Council in the first reading in order to adopt a directive of the EP and the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by competent persons / institutions.This makes crime prevention easier, the process of investigation, detection and prosecution easier.I consider the draft legislative resolution to be extremely important, because it ensures greater security, easier data processing and, ultimately, a reduction in criminal activities in the European Union.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing. - At the beginning of 2012, the Commission proposed a reform package comprising, on the one hand, a regulation establishing a general Union framework for data protection and, on the other hand, a directive which addresses the processing of data personal information for crime-fighting purposes. By strengthening users' right to information about what is done with their data, these two texts will allow European citizens to better control their privacy and make them masters of their own data, by ensuring that they consent to their processing and guaranteeing them remedies against any misuse of their data. Thanks to their adoption, the planned measures will also be valid for all companies. Foreign companies, and in particular the giants of the digital economy, which wish to process the data of European citizens will therefore also have to comply with the new European requirements. This legislative package therefore makes it possible to reconcile a high level of protection for citizens and enhanced fairness of competition in strategic economic sectors. I therefore vote in favor of these two texts.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing. - I support the recommendation for second reading on the position of the Council at first reading with a view to the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the purpose of prevention, investigation , the detection or prosecution of criminal offenses or the execution of criminal sanctions and for the free movement of such data, and the repeal of Council Framework Decision 2008/977 / JHA because it is complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This directive guarantees the protection of the personal data of persons involved in criminal proceedings, and facilitates the exchange of information between European police and judicial authorities.Once again, this is an attack on the sovereignty of the Member States which should be rejected.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of protecting the processing of individuals’ data (including victims, witnesses and suspects) by competent authorities in the interest of preventing and prosecuting criminal offences.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- The regulation on the protection of personal data is accompanied by a directive specifically concerning the processing of such data in the area of law enforcement and criminal law.The result of the trialogue considerably improves the Commission's proposal, in particular on the conditions of use of data (retention time, transparency), or even profiling.Certain aspects are still unclear, in particular the question of the transfer of information to third countries.However, this proposal constitutes a real improvement in the protection of personal data in the criminal field.I'm voting for.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The guarantee that this directive offers to data protection in criminal proceedings extends from the victim to the witness, including the suspects.It is true that the prohibition of the listing of the profiles of the individuals as for the ethnic origin, the religion and the political opinion can be harmful in a fight against Islamist terrorism.It prevents targeted surveillance, which would be more effective.Also, I am not in favor of this text.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The Data Protection Directive for police and judicial authorities is part of the package of measures to reform data protection, proposed by the Commission, and which also includes a general data protection regulation. This package of measures aims to create a solid, coherent, comprehensive and modern data protection framework for the European Union. It will benefit individuals by consolidating their fundamental rights and freedoms with regard to the processing of their personal data, as well as their confidence in the digital universe. It is essential to ensure a high and uniform level of protection of the personal data of natural persons and to facilitate the exchange of that data between the competent authorities of the Member States in order to ensure the effectiveness of judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as well as police cooperation. To this end, the level of protection of the rights and freedoms of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purpose of preventing, investigating, detecting and prosecuting criminal offenses or carrying out criminal sanctions must be equivalent in all cases. Member States. Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I gave my support to this legislative proposal as it improves the way in which the data of individuals are processed by authorities, in relation to crime prevention, investigation or detection.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- I welcome the adoption of the Directive on data protection for judicial and police purposes.Indeed, this legislation will make it possible for the first time to protect all data in the context of the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal acts.This is a further step in the protection of the fundamental rights of citizens.Furthermore, by establishing common rules on data protection, the exchange of information between Member States will be facilitated.Indeed, the lack of data protection can no longer be invoked to refuse or limit the exchange of data in the judicial and police framework.However, this is a priority in order to combat organized crime and terrorism more effectively.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - The Data Protection Directive concerning police and judicial authorities in criminal matters is a legal act designed to ensure modern and comprehensive data protection in the European Union. It will strengthen the fundamental rights and freedoms of individuals with regard to the processing of their personal data. One of the reasons why the institutions of the European Union have started to prepare different types of legislation to protect personal data is the fact that the processing of personal data that is not exchanged between Member States is currently not subject to EU rules. This in some cases causes practical difficulties for the police and other authorities, who have a difficult time determining whether processing is exclusively national or cross-border in nature. The more we use the digital environment, the more its legislation deserves attention. Misuse of personal data or various other forms of crime in this area are not uncommon. The detection of this type of crime requires the coherent high-level protection of personal data of individuals and the facilitation of the exchange of personal data between competent authorities. The new Data Protection Directive will help law enforcement authorities to cooperate more effectively with each other, leading to confidence-building and legal certainty.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, which will facilitate the exchange of information between countries and help ensure that national law enforcement agencies have the information they need on suspects involved in terrorism or cross-border crime, which is essential in order for the EU to harmonise rules on how police and criminal authorities can process and transfer data.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - On 25 January 2012, the Commission presented a proposal on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection, prosecution or enforcement of criminal offenses and on the free movement of such data. / 977 / JHA for the adoption of a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council repealing Council Framework Decision. Parliament discussed the proposal at first reading on 12 March 2014, while the German Bundesrat and the Swedish Parliament issued a reasoned opinion stating that the draft legislative act was incompatible with the principle of subsidiarity. The Council's position at first reading of 8 April 2016 reflects the political agreement reached between the European Parliament and the Council in the informal trialogue of 15 December 2015. The Commission agrees with the Council's position at first reading. In its recommendation for second reading, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament agree with the Council's position at first reading. I voted accordingly.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The package of measures to create a comprehensive, uniform and harmonized data protection framework for the European Union must ensure a high and homogeneous level of protection of the personal data of natural persons and facilitate the exchange of that data between authorities competent authorities in the Member States to ensure the effectiveness of judicial cooperation in criminal matters as well as police cooperation. I argue that the level of protection of the rights and freedoms of natural persons, whether in the processing of personal data, investigation, detection and prosecution, or in preventing or facing criminal offenses or carrying out criminal penalties, must be equal in all Member States . In order to ensure the proper application of the regulations, the rights of data subjects and the obligations of data controllers will have to be strengthened, as well as national authorities will have to be supported and empowered.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This directive is designed to protect personal data, but it is a new stage in the constitution of a European police and penal system, yet the competence of the Member States.Here then is a new attack on national sovereignty.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this directive because it will provide new safeguards for all EU citizens which ensure protections are in place for the processing of data for law enforcement purposes, providing clear and consistent guidelines for authorities while ensuring fundamental rights and privacy are upheld.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on a directive on the processing of personal data for the purposes of crime prevention.While crime, and in particular the risks of terrorism, are very present on European territory, the adoption of such a text is essential to facilitate the work of the police.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- The directive on the processing of personal data must ensure a balance between the protection of such data, on the one hand, and their use for security purposes, on the other.At the end of the first reading, the directive did not meet this imperative balance.On the other hand, the negotiations at second reading have enabled a rebalancing which I consider acceptable.I therefore approved the referral of the text.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- Technological development and globalization have posed serious security challenges for Europe, which we can only tackle together.The work of the authorities to prevent crime, detect specific cases, prosecute and enforce sanctions can only be truly effective if they have sufficient information.It is therefore very important to have a common European Union data protection framework that specifies the modalities and boundaries of data exchange activities.The proposal therefore has my full support.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- I support the draft directive that has been tabled.It should be noted that the reform of the protection of personal data in the EU is one of the most important priority issues in the field of justice.In addition, as the number of cyber attacks increases, more stringent data protection measures are needed.With the adoption of the new Directive, the general principles and rules on data protection will apply to cooperation between competent authorities in criminal matters, and the rules will apply to both domestic and cross-border transfers of personal data.This will create a common EU data protection framework and ensure a more efficient settlement of criminal cases.The new regulation will help prevent cyber-attacks and adequately protect and strengthen citizens' rights to online privacy.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. - The legislative package that was voted in the European Parliament with the false title for the "protection of personal data" legitimizes with the parliament of the European Union the generalized dossier of everything. It establishes an exception to any protection, if "it is a necessary and proportionate measure in a democratic society to avoid obstruction of investigations, prevention and detection of criminal offenses, protection of public order, national security, protection of the rights of others". The exceptions are of such scope and generality that they essentially reduce the dossier to a rule. It also allows the collection and exchange of data related to any political and social action. The rule is the transfer and exchange of data between the various secret services and security services, not only of the EU member states, but also of third countries and imperialist organizations (USA, NATO, etc.). Anyone can be targeted by the repression mechanisms without even being suspected of any act, simply "for reasons of public order and security"! Monopolies and their unions see in people's rights and freedoms a threat to their power. That is why their defense is inseparable from the struggle for their overthrow, for radical changes in power and the economy.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- On the proposal by my colleague Marju Lauristin, given the Council's position at first reading on the matter under consideration, I would like to vote in favor.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing.- I welcome the adoption of the PNR package and the use of private data.I am glad that we have finally adopted the legislative package, albeit in a less ambitious form than our political group wanted from the beginning.There was far too much waiting and political calculation by certain political groups on this important topic, which highlighted aspects of privacy restrictions.They have blocked progress in the area of data exchange, which is crucial for maintaining the security of our citizens.We will now be able to finally enter the phase of interinstitutional negotiations and implementation.We need to respond to current security challenges with legislation that ensures the safety of our citizens.For more security, I’m willing to risk some privacy as well.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support the amendment of Framework Decision 2008/977 / JHA as it contains certain shortcomings in its regulations and therefore does not allow for the full implementation of the measures needed in the prevention, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses. In the light of terrorist attacks, I believe that it is necessary to regulate all legal regulations, especially those that contribute to the security and protection of our citizens. I agree that it is necessary to strengthen the policy of the European Union based on the right to protection of personal data, because it is precisely this principle that everyone has the right to the protection of their own identity that guides the European Union. These measures also call on the member states to establish better mutual communication in order for the system to function fully, in this way we will achieve better communication and cooperation in the EU. I believe that the amendments to this framework will lead to a significant improvement in terms of legal certainty in the Union and will enable and facilitate the competent authorities to carry out their duties and work, which is necessary to protect the citizens of the European Union.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The directive on the processing of personal data by the authorities responsible for criminal proceedings and investigations ensures strong protection of the rights of all European citizens. This is a fundamental guarantee. If the data concerning suspects, witnesses or victims were not correctly processed, their security as well as their right to privacy or to a fair trial would be compromised. For the first time, strict rules are now established, which apply equally to all European citizens. And all police forces in Europe must respect these fundamental rights. This harmonization will make it much easier to exchange information between Member States, so as to ensure that law enforcement has the information they need to prosecute terrorist suspects and international criminals. The tragic events in Paris and Brussels have made it clear that the real problem is not the lack of information on suspected terrorists, but the fact that this information has not been used or shared effectively by the national police. The approved package will play an important role in correcting all of this by providing police and judicial authorities with harmonized rules on how to process and share data.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - I support the adoption of this directive, which will deal with cross-border data transfer within the EU and will, for the first time, set minimum standards for data processing for police purposes in each Member State. The new rules aim to protect individuals, whether victims, criminals or witnesses, by setting clear rights and restrictions on the transfer of data for the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses or the execution of criminal sanctions, including the protection and prevention of public safety facilitates smooth and effective cooperation between law enforcement agencies. The main problem with terrorist attacks and other international crimes is that Member States are reluctant to exchange valuable information. By setting European standards for the exchange of information between competent authorities, the Data Protection Directive will become a powerful and useful tool to help authorities transfer personal data easily and efficiently, while respecting the fundamental right to privacy.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The directive in question is part of the package of measures proposed by the Commission which aims to reform data protection, which includes a general regulation. It is essential to ensure a high and uniform level of protection of the personal data of natural persons and to facilitate the exchange of that data between the competent authorities of the Member States in order to ensure the effectiveness of judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as well as police cooperation. To this end, the level of protection of the rights and freedoms of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purpose of preventing, investigating, detecting and prosecuting criminal offenses or carrying out criminal sanctions must be equivalent in all cases. Member States. Effective protection of personal data across the Union requires not only that the rights of data subjects and the obligations of data controllers be strengthened, but that equivalent powers are also given in different Member States to control and ensure the application of the rules on the protection of personal data. The directive will allow police and judicial authorities to cooperate more effectively and faster, ensuring legal certainty.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The data protection directive for the police and criminal justice authorities is part of a data protection reform package proposed by the Commission, which also includes a general data protection regulation. Ensuring a uniform and high level of protection of personal data of natural persons and facilitating the exchange of personal data between the competent authorities of the Member States is essential in order to ensure effective cooperation between legal and police authorities in criminal matters. For this reason, the rights and freedoms of individuals, with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purposes of the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of crimes, must enjoy an equivalent level of protection in all Member States. . The reform package will benefit individuals by strengthening their fundamental rights and freedoms regarding the processing of personal data and their trust in the digital environment. For all of this I voted in favor.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- A directive on the processing of personal data for crime prevention purposes is included in the data protection package.Recent terrorist events have made it possible to observe the reluctance of certain Member States to exchange information that is sometimes necessary in the fight against crime and terrorism.I therefore supported this text, which will allow national authorities to exchange personal data, while of course respecting the fundamental right to privacy.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing.- This report approves the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of the European Parliament and Council directive on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecutioncriminal offenses or enforcement of criminal sanctions and the free movement of such data, and repealing Council Framework Decision 2008/977 / JHA.I voted positively.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: in writing. - Second part of the data protection package, which plays a crucial role in the digital strategy for Europe, this text is a step forward in the fight against terrorism at European level. While we can be satisfied with this progress, I nevertheless regret the absence of compulsory information sharing between national services. Therefore, in line with the ALDE group's policy, we will continue to support the mandatory sharing of information between Member States and make proposals to improve Europol so that it acquires a European investigative capacity.
