We can only regret that this data protection package was not passed along with the PNR directive, as was initially desired by my political group in Parliament. Given that it nevertheless constitutes a first positive step towards greater European integration on the security issue, I voted in favor of this text.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- European data protection rules date from 1995. We need to ensure that users have more control over their data and subject transfers to countries outside the EU to tighter requirements.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: A regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors, and a directive, which covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of data. It also gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. It is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the EU among the 28 partners.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which approves the Council's position at first reading on the adoption of the European Parliament and Council directive on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the purpose of prevention , investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses or enforcement of criminal sanctions and the free movement of such data, repealing Council Framework Decision 2008/977 / JHA. The Data Protection Directive for police and judicial authorities is part of the package of measures to reform data protection, proposed by the Commission, and which also includes a general data protection regulation, with a view to creating a framework sound, coherent, comprehensive and modern data protection for the EU. With the adoption of this directive, it will be possible to strengthen, more quickly and effectively, the cooperation between police and judicial authorities, generating a feeling of greater confidence and legal certainty among the population. For the reasons stated above, I attributed my vote in favor to the approval of this report.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We have voted in favor of this legislative resolution on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by authorities for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution ofcriminal offenses or the execution of criminal penalties, and the free circulation of these data.Throughout the process, Parliament introduced important measures to preserve the rights of people in the use of these data with limitations in the time of holding these data, classifying the data into categories to determine under what conditions they could be processed andeliminated, among other things, the transfer of information to third countries unless it has the authorization of the competent authorities, because it did not consider that it offered the necessary safeguards.Therefore, it was voted in favor at third reading.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- Thanks to this new directive on the processing of personal data of individuals, the free circulation of such information will be facilitated for the purposes of preventing, investigating and detecting crimes.However, the judicial and police authorities must both ensure that personal data are processed lawfully and collected for specific, explicit and legitimate purposes, and provide clear and understandable information to the data subject, who will have the right to request any limitation.of the treatment.I believe that, in the context of the fight against transnational crime and terrorism, clear and consistent rules on data protection at European level and closer cooperation between the competent authorities of each Member State are needed to ensure the safety of citizens.Therefore, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ The proposed directive allows law enforcement agencies to use the personal data we have online, in their pursuit of criminal offenders. They must be specific about their reason for requesting our personal data (e.g: suspected of committing a crime, or aiding and abetting), and the type of data collected must be proportionate and limited to certain categories. I hope that this measure will help disarm and defund criminal gangs and terrorists, particularly those who prey on the misery of others (people smugglers, human traffickers). Therefore I voted for this resolution.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The Commission came up with the original proposal for a Directive on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data for the purposes of crime prevention, investigation, detection, prosecution and the free movement of such data in 2012. Discussions on this measure have been frozen since 2014. Only recent dramatic events in Paris and Brussels have revealed in full nudity the inability of security authorities to exchange the necessary information. In this context, the European Parliament is in favor of concluding discussions and adopting legislative measures to protect personal data. I therefore endorse the Council's position and I believe that we will finally move from words to deeds and that the directive will be put into practice. This proposal is also part of a package, together with proposals for a regulation on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data and on the use of airline passenger data. In order for security authorities to be able to effectively detect, investigate and prosecute perpetrators of terrorist offenses, it is essential that clear rules be established at European level within which national authorities can effectively exchange available information that can contribute to the detection of serious crime. National governments can no longer turn a blind eye to the failures of the security forces. On the contrary, they will have to show more determination and implement all these tools without delay, as the security of citizens has become a top priority today.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - In the context of the personal data protection package, I voted in favor of the draft directive on the processing of personal data transferred for the purposes of judicial and police cooperation. It is a provision that establishes, for the first time, minimum standards for the processing of data of victims, witnesses and suspects in each Member State in the fields of crime prevention, contrast and repression, as well as the execution of criminal sanctions, favoring as well as cooperation between law enforcement agencies in the EU against transnational and terrorist criminal acts. Only by establishing common rules for the exchange of information between competent authorities will they be able to overcome the mistrust that has hitherto prevented genuine cooperation in judicial and police matters such as to prevent the occurrence of planned and committed crimes in more than one Member State . For these reasons, I have voted in favor of the proposed directive.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The new directive guarantees the right to the protection of personal data in the domestic and foreign processing of personal data in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters, as this area has not yet fall within the general legal framework for the protection of personal data.The purpose of the new regulation is, in addition to protecting the fundamental rights of individuals, to ensure the exchange of personal data for the prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses or the execution of criminal penalties, which will help facilitate cooperation in the fight against crime in Europe.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written.- Having regard to the recommendation for second reading of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, I supported the Council's position in first reading on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by the competent authorities for the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution of criminal offenses.and on the free movement of such data and on the repeal of Council Framework Decision 2008/977 / JHA.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I supported the proposal and welcome the streamlining of tools in the fight against organized crime.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the directive, which improves the exchange of information and cooperation between police officers and other criminal justice authorities within the European Union, with Interpol and also outside the EU, which will in turn improve the efficiency of law enforcement.Recent terrorist attacks have revealed the dire consequences of poor cooperation and the international nature of crime and terrorism.Of course, it must be ensured that only those data that are relevant and necessary are exchanged.It is therefore necessary to protect data, especially victims and witnesses, which the directive provides.Today's society is marked by the remarkable development of information technology, which represents a great progress, but also an increasing threat to the individual, which is most evident through interventions in the human private sphere.Privacy is a basic human right, so we must be extremely careful and sensitive when processing personal data.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. The general aim of the agreement is to ensure a high level of protection of personal data, in the areas of police and judicial cooperation, in criminal matters for the purpose of preventing, investigating, detecting or prosecuting criminal offenses, but it violates the general principles of personal data protection. The act proves that intelligence-sharing commitments are subject to either personal will or national security accreditations, with the recent example of the terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels, where Member States' secret services did not inform each other. The agreement does not really reinforce the risk-based approach, nor does it guarantee the obligation of data protection by design and default. In addition, the provision of harmonized criteria, conditions and restrictions is contrary to the provision, in the agreement, of the inclusion of private entities in the sense of "competent authorities". In conclusion, the cooperation is practically impossible, taking into account the simple example of the non-extradition of Christoforakos by the German authorities in Greece, to investigate the SIEMENS scandal.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the recommendation for a Council position.The Commission's data protection reform package aims to establish a modern, consistent and comprehensive EU data protection framework.I agree with this objective and, as the political agreement approved by the Council also maintains a high level of protection of personal data in the field of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters and facilitates the exchange of personal data between Member States' police and judicial authorities, I was able to supportit.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ The police directive will improve cooperation and efficiency between police forces of all Member States and will make for smoother exchange of information between Member States’ police and judicial authorities, which is crucial in the current security context. The directive is about ensuring the correct and lawful treatment of personal data in the law enforcement context, while respecting the fundamental right of privacy for citizens. As we do not have a common European Union framework on data protection or data processing for the police, I strongly support this directive.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- In this very important dossier, I have decided to vote for the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting the directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to processingpersonal data by the competent authorities for the purposes of preventing and detecting criminal offenses, investigating and prosecuting them or executing criminal sanctions, and for the free movement of such data, and repealing theCouncil Framework Decision 2008/977 / JHA.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ On the same day as the vote on PNR, it was also important to vote the new EU data protection rules. Indeed, this will merge different legal approaches in EU Member States into one single European rulebook and will give people back control of their personal information. Europeans are more and more careful with the personal information they want to share and rightly so. The new regulation includes, among other things, provisions on the right to be forgotten, the ‘clear and affirmative consent’ to the processing of private data by the person concerned, the right to transfer your data to another service provider and the right to know when your data has been hacked. The data protection package also includes a directive on data transfers for policing and judicial purposes which will help authorities transfer valuable personal data efficiently while respecting the fundamental right to privacy.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- I supported the Directive which gives citizens greater control over their own information in the digitalized world of smartphones, social media and internet banking.I believe that the new rules will protect individuals, whether victims, criminals or witnesses, by setting clear rights and restrictions on the transfer of data for the purpose of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution of criminal offenses or the execution of criminal sanctions, including protection and prevention of public safety.All of this will at the same time facilitate smooth and effective cooperation between law enforcement agencies.I believe that the introduction of this law will make the exchange of information much easier and, while respecting the fundamental right to privacy, the level of data protection in the European Union will be uniform.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- To vote on a recommendation for second reading on the Council's position at first reading with a view to adopting a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by competent authorities for the prevention, investigation, detection or prosecution.sanctions, and on the free movement of such data and on the repeal of Council Framework Decision 2008/977 / JHA, would support it.Having regard to the Council's position at first reading (05418/1/2016 - C8 0139/2016), Commission opinion (COM (2016) 0213), and Article 294 (7) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, the processing of personal data for the purposes of crime prevention isone of the key preventive measures and very important for the safety of EU citizens.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We have voted in favor of this legislative resolution on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal data by authorities for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution ofcriminal offenses or the execution of criminal penalties, and the free circulation of these data.Throughout the process, Parliament introduced important measures to preserve the rights of people in the use of these data with limitations in the time of holding these data, classifying the data into categories to determine under what conditions they could be processed andeliminated, among other things, the transfer of information to third countries unless it has the authorization of the competent authorities, because it did not consider that it offered the necessary safeguards.Therefore, it was voted in favor at third reading.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The author agrees with the Council's position at first reading and notes that the legislative act has been adopted in accordance with the Council's position.He therefore proposes that the legislative act be signed.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We have voted IN FAVOR of this legislative resolution on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with respect to the processing of personal data by the authorities for the purposes of prevention, investigation, detection and prosecution ofcriminal offenses or the execution of criminal penalties, and the free circulation of these data.Throughout the process, Parliament introduced important measures to preserve the rights of people in the use of these data with limitations in the time of holding these data, classifying the data into categories to determine under what conditions they could be processed andeliminated, among other things, the transfer of information to third countries unless it has the authorization of the competent authorities, because it did not consider that it offered the necessary safeguards.Therefore, it was voted in favor at third reading.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ The data protection directive negotiations came to an end on 15 December. The agreed text is not perfect but it still provides better data protection rights in the context of law enforcement activities than the current legislation. The main problematic element is the Council’s addition of Article 36aa which allows transfers of personal data to private entities in third countries. Despite this controversial article, I voted in favour of this directive.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Through this decision, Parliament proceeds to approve the Council's position at first reading on the protection of natural persons with regard to the processing of personal data.We are talking about an important decision that helps us take another step forward in the fight against crime, which is why I consider it necessary to vote in its favor.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this legislative package because it represents a historic agreement on the protection of the personal data of European citizens. It contains two elements: a Regulation, which addresses the processing of personal data by private actors, and a Directive, which covers the use of personal data by police and judicial authorities. This agreement sets the clock for the protection of personal data in the 21st century and affects all aspects related to the storage, treatment and cancellation of data. It also gives citizens greater control over such an important aspect of their lives as privacy. The way in which judicial and police authorities treat the personal data of citizens has a profound impact on their fundamental rights. The new directive will help these exchanges take place under the umbrella of EU-wide regulation, which will improve their effectiveness while protecting fundamental rights. It is the first time that we will have a harmonized system in the Union among the 28 partners.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- In the new digital age, it is our moral duty as liberals to protect the rights and freedoms of European citizens.In order to do this as effectively as possible, we must set clear rights and restrictions in law on the transfer of personal data for the purpose of the prevention, detection or prosecution of criminal offenses.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - I had already voted in favor of this directive on data protection in the framework of police and judicial cooperation in criminal matters. As with the general data protection regulation, it is a question of modernizing and strengthening the system by allowing exchanges between the different competent authorities of the Member States in criminal matters, in a more harmonized and coherent system and by submitting the persons responsible the processing of this data has more obligations. The powers of supervision and control of the application of personal data protection rules will remain entrusted to each Member State. Theoretically, data transfer should be strictly limited and should not become frequent and massive. The risk of profiling is also strictly controlled. I voted for this directive because it allows a minimum of supervision. However, I remain quite skeptical about its actual implementation in the Member States.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The proposal for a regulation aims to strengthen individual rights and consolidate the EU's internal market, ensure stricter enforcement of regulations, simplify international transfers of personal data and establish international data protection standards.We fear that, at this juncture, this regulation that centralizes processes and removes the mechanisms for controlling personal data from citizens may create conditions for security drifts that undermine rights, freedoms and guarantees.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The exception, for example to process someone's sex life if it is necessary for historical or statistical purposes or for the purpose of scientific research, is not meaningful and without any basis.The type of political conviction and the necessity due to labor law, apart from political public activity, also make no sense and should be rejected.In addition, the question remains whether this is still relevant in times of passenger data transfer or the agreement between the government of the Republic of Austria and the government of the United States of America on deepening cooperation in preventing and combating serious crimes.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. - I strongly supported the directive on the protection of trade and business secrets. The proposal, which unifies the policy of the 28 Member States on this issue, will provide solid guarantees of protection for companies, making European soil even more attractive for future investments. In the era of digitization, sharing and "given money", it was necessary to build a series of rules to protect businesses, especially small and medium-sized ones, from the risk of losing their professional secrets and, therefore, their wealth. With this directive, Europe becomes avant-garde in the world with respect to protection in the digital market, while maintaining its principles of freedom of expression and movement intact. Especially thanks to the commitment of the S & amp; D group, in fact, specific protections have been introduced both for journalistic activities and for whistle blowers and for workers in possession of sensitive data who want to change their professional environment.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Albrecht report on the protection of personal data, which aims to ensure that citizens have greater control over their data, to give companies more clarity and legal certainty and to subject transfers to countries outside the EU to tighter requirements.European rules on the protection of personal data - dating from 1995, an era when less than 1% of Europeans used the Internet - need to be updated to respond to technological advances, globalization and new methods of collecting, accessing anddata usage.The aim of this reform is to strengthen citizens' control over their data.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the legislative resolution on the adoption of a new directive concerning the processing of personal data for the purposes of crime prevention.Law enforcement requirements for the use of personal data to combat crime - including the fight against terrorism - need to be placed in a legal framework that protects EU citizens and prevents any unauthorized disclosure or unauthorized access to personal data.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - I would have been so happy to celebrate with my fellow Members who have been applauded for the adoption of this flight data record. I, too, would be so happy to think that terrorism is over now. You can go on vacation for families, we don’t have to worry anymore. Well, unfortunately, please, it's not like that. I have tried several times, including asking Mrs Mogherini, by the way, Mr Albrecht, who, as a great Democrat, is unwilling to answer a blue-card question if it is his political opponent. I wanted to know the basic question at this meeting: that once they can delimit precisely the circle, the few thousand people in Europe who are really dangerous for terrorism, see the case in Brussels, where these people were absolutely in the eyes of the authorities, then why don't they do something to them? So why wait until these well-known people from the Molenbeek district of Brussels, and the others who can be known exactly, even without PNR, are flying like the hairy Syria, and the Islamic State and Europe… We know about them, and yet they are free to walk. That should change, please, and not the completely innocent, unrelated passengers are already slowly checking the color of their underwear. There is no connection between our security and this. I'm sorry, though I want to.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Madam President, security is one of the key arguments for the United Kingdom to remain in the EU. Following the attacks in Brussels, it is even more evident that we need measures, and we need to work together to ensure that information-sharing between European countries operates properly. We need to give intelligence agencies the tools to track terrorists. By voting in favour of the PNR Directive, Labour MEPs proved wrong those on the right and the Eurosceptics, who had been misleading the public with a smear campaign claiming we had been blocking progress on this. Today we voted for a directive that allows us to gather and share flight data of potential perpetrators of terrorist attacks between all the EU countries, while making sure people’s privacy is protected through a strong directive protecting personal data. Today the EU made us stronger in the fight against terrorism, while ensuring that people’s privacy is protected.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Madam President!I would like to call on Madam President to remain more disciplined.We have several Members here who speak repeatedly, tell their life stories and exceed the time by 20 seconds.There are people in the room who would like to comment on the last topics and will not have the slightest chance.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: Madam President, I proposed that this proposal for the common passenger register be rejected, because I believe that it converts us all as suspected terrorists. I really believe that there is a use of the fear that we currently live to take away rights and freedoms. All authorities were aware of the suspects who ended up committing terrorist acts in Europe. In Madrid, the terrorists were already known to the French and British authorities. In London, terrorists were followed by the French police. In the first attack in Brussels, the French terrorist was known to the French authorities. In the case of Charlie Hebdo, the terrorists were known to the English authorities. In the case of Brussels, which we now live in recently, the Swedish authorities had information. In other words, there is information about the terrorism suspects, they end up committing the attacks, there is no exchange of information, there is no cooperation, and with this justification we ended up becoming all suspects and keeping the flight records of all passengers in the European Union, this year hundreds of millions of euros, and we have all become a territory of fear. Terrorism knows no borders, Madam President.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I voted in favor of this material because I believe that it is now necessary for us to have information on who flies where by which aircraft. At a time when data is sufficiently protected by previous legal texts, which have also been approved today, I believe that, given the continuing threat of terrorist attacks in Europe, it is essential for the police to be able to access information when investigating terrorist attacks and other forms of serious activity, who flew where. This is necessary at a time when, today, unfortunately, some young Europeans are flying to the Middle East, flying to Syria, cooperating in the troops and structures of the Islamic State, and then returning to Europe. It is also necessary for these people who return from Syria and other territories to begin an investigation into whether they worked for the Islamic State and, if confirmed, to be punished. The second part - punishment and examination - are necessary, otherwise sharing information will not matter.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President. Security or freedom - these two counts form one of the most fundamental equations in terms of national governance. Which one is more important? Which should be preferred? The thing is, both are undeniably important. In the case of the European Union, for decades we live as if in one of these counts - security - which seems, of course, permanent, but unfortunately it is not. And recent events, both in Paris and in Brussels, as well as in other European cities, show that we need to think about security, to make compromises in order to strike the best possible balance between security and freedom, without ignoring any of them. I am voting in favor of this document today because the passenger name record offers the same dilemma, but given what has happened recently, it is likely that the European Union needs such a register precisely in order to promote the security of our citizens. The most important thing in this regard is, of course, to guarantee the fundamental freedoms of our citizens. Thanks!

name: Peter JAHR
text: - Madam President! Yes, we need to use Passenger Name Record. Yes, we also need exchanges between the Member States. In the so-called passenger name records, all data and processes relating to a booking are electronically recorded by the airlines for service purposes and stored in the respective computer reservation systems via an agreement in a precisely timed period even after the flight has been completed. Two things are particularly important to me: First, there are strict data protection precautions including a mandatory data protection officer. And - just as important - there is a compulsory exchange of important and necessary data between the Member States, including with Europol. Because it is of no use if one member state has the information and does not pass it on to the other. It is just as important that we have included a revision clause after two years. That means: after two years we will see what has become of this agreement and whether data protection is really guaranteed.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, when we were debating these proposals I posed the question that, if we rejected the proposed legislation today, who would be the happier – the citizens of Europe, the data subjects, or the terrorists? The answer was obvious – the terrorists – because, if I am traveling from Dublin to Beirut, New York, Sydney, wherever, why should I be afraid if the authorities have that information? When you have nothing to hide, you have nothing to fear. I think now, at least, the authorities will be able to get their hands on data to track terrorists and would-be terrorists. I think that is a good thing and, as Mr Jahr said, the rules are laid out pretty clearly in relation to the use of the data.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - What we are discussing on this PDB topic is related to the previous one.I would like to state the thesis that if we really want to protect our freedom and our security, then we must, of course, protect them as a matter of priority and, if necessary, break to some extent otherwise protected rights.This is meant precisely by the right to information protection.If these databases exist, if they have passenger data and this data is relevant to investigating or even preventing and anticipating certain security threats, then linking this data and collecting it is the responsibility of the states, and I think it is good that we have this report.thus supported.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, colleagues, I strongly support this report. This proposal aims to establish clear and strict rules for the collection, use and protection of reservation data for passengers traveling to, from and within the European Union. In view of the increasing trafficking in human beings, as well as the recent attacks in Paris and Brussels, in which we are witnessing a real war inside Europe, it has become clear that we need strong measures to increase the security of the entire European Union. , and especially the protection of its external borders. This is extremely important in view of the situation we are in.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I consider it very important that today the EP agreed on a directive that will allow data on passengers on international flights outside the EU to be stored and shared.This is not a restriction of freedom, because everyone can continue to fly where they want, but it is really a minimal measure in the fight against international crime.I consider the fact that 461 Members finally voted in favor of the directive to be a very important and good signal, but I am very surprised that it took 5 years.I am afraid that without the victims of terrorism in Paris and, more recently, in Brussels, this directive would not have been agreed to this day.This is not a good example of how we should proceed in emergencies.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The collection of data provided by passengers (European PNR) is, according to the Commission, a way to collect data on individuals and increase the safety of European citizens.In our opinion, systemic and general data collection can be useful to ensure security if and only if there is a related obligation to cooperate and exchange relevant information.We believe this directive sacrifices the right to privacy without guaranteeing the safety of European citizens.For these reasons I would have decided to vote against.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as we Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments to combat terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that turns it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - Since it began to try to impose a Passenger Name Register (PNR) in the European Union, we have been against the few existing guarantees in terms of data protection and it represents a new increase in the capacity of the security forces of act in an opaque way and without guarantees of legality, using the fight against terrorism as an excuse. After the trilogue process we have not seen a reduction in the scope of the regulation, but quite the opposite, also registering intra-European flights, and without placing a clear limit on the nature of the data that will be stored, so the police will be able to collect and storing information that does not have to be relevant to counterterrorism intelligence. Finally, the possibility of transferring this data to a third party, even outside the European Union, is maintained, which is frankly worrying and deepens the policy of mass surveillance of the population, particularly social activists, by our governments or from third countries with the complicity of our governments. For all the above, we have voted against

name: Louis ALIOT
text: in writing. - I strongly opposed the text on the creation of a European PNR. This aims to collect the personal data of any air passenger entering or leaving the Union. The National Front's position is in fact very clear: this project represents a serious attack on the freedom of European travelers and would prove ineffective in the fight against terrorism. The attacks in Paris and Brussels, for example, could not have been avoided with such a device. In addition, some, like the UK, are rightly concerned that some government officials may be unreliable and may disclose information to facilitate further attacks. Finally, under the guise of the fight against terrorism, the PNR is more like an aerial outgrowth of the Schengen area and represents a new attack on the sovereignty of States. The PNR is indeed intended to be shared with the United States, without any reciprocity ... France, for example, already has its own PNR since 2006. Mass surveillance, danger to national security, attack on national sovereignty States: ENF deputies voted against this text.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing. - The adoption of the PNR is welcome, but it is far from being THE answer to terrorism. When we know that the English services were aware of possible attacks in Madrid, that the French police were on the trail of terrorists in London, that the weapons used in the Paris attacks were purchased in Germany or that the intelligence services Swedes refused to share information relating to one of the terrorists in the Brussels attacks, one is entitled to wonder about the cooperation between the Member States within the European Union. It is clear that defending our national attributes does not save lives, quite the contrary. In an open space, it is a European intelligence service that we need. It is fundamental to broaden the prerogatives of Europol and to create a European prosecutor to fight cross-border criminal activity. It is with more Europe that we will fight terrorism effectively. Controlling the circulation of firearms, drying up sources of funding, preventing radicalization are all challenges that we must meet together to make Europe an area of ​​freedom, security and justice.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S & amp; D), in writing. - I voted in favor of the compromise reached between the Council and Parliament on the establishment of a Common Passenger Register for international flights to and from Member States of the European Union. This new register will be able to assist the authorities of the Member States in identifying suspected criminal acts. Parliament's condition was that its adoption be combined with that of the legislative package on the protection of personal data, thus ensuring that the protection and processing of passengers' personal data is carried out under a strict legal framework, without the risk of invasion of privacy. European citizens.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - After terrorist attacks, calls for a better exchange of relevant information between the security authorities of the EU Member States have been repeated without any concrete action being taken. With this report on the exchange of passenger data, a first step has now been finally taken - after months of tug-of-war - towards a more efficient fight against terrorism in the EU. However, this must be followed by further steps, which should result in a European security service. In view of the increasing number of attacks, it is becoming clear that individual states cannot get terrorism under control on their own. Closer cooperation at European level and a systematic exchange of information between European security authorities are necessary in order to combat the cross-border phenomenon of terrorism. This exchange can be simplified by a centralized EU passenger name data system, for example in order to more efficiently control the movements of dangerous persons. I therefore support this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ After much consideration, I decided to oppose the PNR proposals for two main reasons: 1. I don’t believe that it will have the security benefits which have been claimed for it. Indeed, the free movement within the Schengen Area must be of far greater concern. The recent terror attacks would not have been stopped by PNR. 2. I have concerns over privacy and data retention. The lengthy ‘masking period’ ensures that personal data will be kept, and the legislation provides for that data to be shared with third countries. This leads to a loss of control over personal data and the risk of cyber-attacks and/or fraud. Finally, it grants power to the European Police Force, Europol.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- In order to combat the terrorist threat, Europe must have a single PNR (European register of air passengers).However, this resolution does not create a centralized European system, but the addition of 28 national PNRs, with the possibility, voluntarily but not automatically, of feeding a centralized information system.This is why I voted in favor of an amendment calling for the centralization of information and the mandatory sharing of data to avoid the creation of 28 national PNRs.Unfortunately, he was not selected.I therefore believe that this draft NRP is unsatisfactory, but essential, and that is why I voted in favor of this resolution.All the same, I call on Europeans to work together and to give Europe the means of a federal government.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal on the use of PNR data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorism and serious crime.PNR data are information provided by passengers traveling by air when booking a ticket and held by the air carrier.PNR data can also be used by law enforcement authorities, which is why the proposed directive lays down harmonized rules for such measures.Carefully analyzed PNR data can be an effective tool for detecting and tracking crime and terrorism.In addition, they can be used for retaliatory, real-time or proactive action to stop, monitor, interrogate and prosecute criminals.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP are not principally opposed to the use of PNR data on a bilateral basis, UKIP have voted against this legislative report. Our main concerns lie with two key areas of this legislation. The first issue is that this legislation will permit Europol, an EU agency that UKIP neither recognise nor respect, to access this data and thus provides an extension of their judicial powers. The second issue for UKIP lies with the length of time that the data will be held; we believe that this length of data retention is far too long and leaves many law-abiding citizens’ data at risk from cyber-attacks. We believe that this risk is significantly higher in certain Member States that do not have appropriate standards for data protection and security. In this respect, UKIP have therefore voted for amendments which significantly reduce the length of period for data retention.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing. - The Front National is hostile to the European PNR, which aims to collect the personal data of each plane passenger entering or leaving European space in order to fight terrorism and serious offenses for three reasons: it is freedom-killing because it infringes the privacy of passengers, collecting information on their religious affiliation or their state of health; it is also ineffective and aims more at extending the Schengen area at the air level - especially since France already has its national PNR - than to fight terrorism, which would be done more effectively by favoring careful surveillance suspects listed as "S"; finally, it undermines national security by allowing other European countries, some of which, by their own admission, are unreliable, such as the United Kingdom, to access information concerning passengers entering or leaving French territory. So I refused this generalized coping project.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the PNR directive because it is an additional tool to secure the European Union in the current context. But this text alone will unfortunately remain insufficient to prevent atrocities on European soil. The PNR will only be effective if the Member States exchange the crucial information that emerges from the national PNRs. This is a great challenge when we know, for example, how reluctant states are to feed Europol's databases on terrorism and foreign fighters returning to their countries of origin ("returnees"). The 28 must step up their efforts to make the exchange of information more effective in the detection of suspected terrorists. We will therefore remain extremely attentive to the use and effectiveness of this famous PNR but also to the exchange of information because this is one of the keys to our security. In addition, when it comes to establishing a system that will collect a lot of personal data, we can only welcome the fact that this vote takes place at the same time as that on the texts relating to the protection of personal data in order to guarantee respect for freedoms. fundamental. At all times, care must be taken to maintain a balance between the security of citizens and the preservation of their fundamental rights.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I voted in favor of the report that approves the proposal for a Directive that will regulate air passenger data (PNR, in its acronym in English) despite my reluctance and doubts about its future usefulness since it is not required to the Member States the obligation to share the data. I have done so as a gesture towards the progress and development of a true common intelligence system that is effective and facilitates a true exchange of adequate information. But after the hasty approval in 2006 of a data retention directive that was to serve to improve security, a decade and several attacks later, the regulation has not proven to be effective and its special gravity in the fundamental rights of the user has been in evidence. respect for privacy. The Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) overthrew it in 2014. I will continue working to ensure that the European Union has a Directive that guarantees an exchange of information between national intelligence services. For Europol to become the hub that facilitates and coordinates exchange without having to have 28 massive databases and without clear coordination.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - PNR codes, linked to the information that all passengers provide to airlines when booking flights, represent one of the most important tools for preventing and detecting serious crimes and terrorist-related actions. The Kirkhope report, which I supported in Parliament today, effectively describes the approved innovations in the collection, sharing and analysis of PNR information. Under the new directive, Member States must establish a Passenger Information Unit (UIP) with the task of collecting booking codes from airlines and keeping them for a period of five years. Six months after the transfer of the data, some elements, such as name, address and contacts, will be masked to ensure the protection of passenger privacy. The new procedure will allow data to be stored, processed and transferred more efficiently, while promoting passenger protection and better action by law enforcement and intelligence services.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - We voted against this despite the fact that this PNR in the EU was initially raised by the Commission as a way to fight terrorism and transnational crime. Finally, the speaker's text shows that the intention goes further. The text originally intended to harmonize the data collection obligations of airlines and operators operating from third countries. The Report, also in this case, has gone beyond the Commission's proposal, asking to extend the registration of passenger data to travelers between EU countries. The text determines the criteria on the basis of which these authorities can use such data, defined in a vague and broad way. The massive compilation of data that is proposed is disproportionate and unnecessary, ignoring the recommendations of the CJEU on proportionality in data collection. Due to all this series of vagueness, vagueness and attempts to present as a fight against terrorism a massive and indiscriminate collection of passenger data that exceeds proportionality and that it is not known for what purpose they will finally be used, that is why we have decided to vote in against.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - The European PNR aims to collect the personal data of all aircraft passengers entering or leaving European space. The data are: identity of the passenger and accompanying persons, itinerary, travel agency, means of payment, special requests on the meal for example. Nevertheless, I am hostile to the PNR. First of all, the European PNR is freedom-killing because it seriously undermines respect for the privacy of passengers (the information will be kept for 5 years). Second, the European PNR is ineffective because it does not allow a real fight against terrorism. Neither the attacks in Paris nor those in Brussels would have been avoided if it had existed. Terrorists generally do not come directly from a country by plane to get out of the plane to an attack site ... It would be more useful to favor targeted surveillance of terrorists and suspects on S files, for example. Finally, the European PNR undermines national sovereignty because it aims to save the Schengen area by creating a kind of air Schengen area. The European PNR is finally intended to be communicated to the United States, while in return the latter will not communicate their American PNR to the EU. So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The report on the use of the booking code data for the purposes of prevention, assessment, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crimes (PNR) does not present particular critical issues and is therefore acceptable.I therefore intended to support it with my vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as the Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against the terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that will turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the Commission proposal on the use of Passenger Name Record (EU PNR) data. It must be emphasized that the nature of criminal and terrorist activities has changed constantly in recent years. It has become bolder, more complex and increasingly cross-border in nature. Given the high costs associated with crime, it has been identified that more and more citizens want stronger action at EU level in the fight against organized crime and terrorism. PNR data are information provided by passengers traveling by air when booking a ticket and held by the air carrier. These data are primarily used by air carriers for operational purposes (they include information provided through 19 fields, such as travel date, itinerary, ticket details, contact details, travel agent information, means of payment used, seat number and baggage details), although they valuable to airlines, both commercially and statistically. The Commission's proposal essentially sets out two things: firstly, the harmonization of the obligation for air carriers operating flights to or from the territory of a third country to transfer PNR data to law enforcement authorities and, secondly, the criteria for law enforcement authorities to use such information, i. y. they may use it to prevent, detect, investigate and prosecute terrorist offenses and serious crime.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - Recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, so everything must be done for the security of European citizens. This is why information needs to be shared, for example through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, as the entry into force of European PNR can also be an important tool in the Member States' fight against terrorism. This will prevent those who have once been identified as potential terrorists from entering Europe, but are still able to move freely within the Union, taking advantage of the wave of migration and abusing the Schengen system. The compromise text of the PNR regulation was already in place in December, and now the formal consecration of the European Parliament can take place. European citizens have a legitimate expectation for today's decision-makers to protect them and give back their sense of security. This European Passenger Name Record system helps to do this, which is why I voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- Last week, in plenary, MEPs largely supported the European Parliament's draft legislative resolution on the use of Passenger Name Record data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crime.We cannot fight terrorism, which we face in Europe today, either by military force or by strengthening physical security.In addition to an appropriate migration policy, intelligence services and investigative offices across Europe have a role to play.With the adoption of the PNR legislative package, the authorities will be able to obtain information that is extremely important for the fight against terrorism.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - In the light of the recent dramatic events in Brussels, it was necessary to give a clear signal to the requests of our citizens for decisive interventions on the security front. The fight against criminal networks and terrorism must be pursued at EU level, providing the relevant agencies, such as EUROPOL, with all the necessary tools. It is in this sense that the directive approved today on the use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data for the purposes of crime prevention must be read. I would like to underline the work done by the S & amp; D group on this directive. Leaving emotionality aside, we have managed to combine in the text the need to ensure greater security with the right respect for the privacy of our citizens. In this way, contingent periods of information retention will be established, with rules for the protection of personal data that do not favor indiscriminate access to the personal sphere of everyone. The compromise reached covers the previous legislative vacuum that characterized the European situation, thus favoring the collection and sharing of data between states. These data will be more relevant, comparable and therefore able to provide the speed necessary to carry out incisive preliminary investigations, often indispensable for prevention activities.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- The recent terrorist attacks in Europe and in the world have shown all the vulnerability of the air system.I believe that in times of security crisis, it is necessary to establish mechanisms for data exchange.Also, I believe that the proposal sufficiently protects the privacy of citizens.

name: Marie-Christine BOUTONNET
text: in writing.- The PNR is a liberticidal, ineffective tool, undermining national sovereignty and potentially threatening our security.I therefore voted against.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that, in the light of the challenge posed by international terrorism, it is necessary to adopt countermeasures aimed at preventing and avoiding attacks such as those in Paris on 13 November 2015 and in Brussels on 22 March 2016. I therefore believethat, despite the doubts that remain regarding the protection of the privacy of European citizens, the use by law enforcement agencies of the Passenger Name Record (PNR) data can represent an important prevention tool.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The dramatic attacks in recent months in Paris and Brussels have accelerated the approval of the PNR register, an important new tool that will facilitate the collection of data from air travelers to and from the European Union, favoring police and traffic controls. various judicial authorities, thus making an important contribution to the fight against terrorism. Despite the positive elements that the new PNR introduces, I underline the presence of some criticalities, such as the fact that the new measure does not provide for a form of automatic exchange between member countries of their respective PNR data. Once again, the blind opposition of the more conservative fringes that sit in Parliament prevented the approval of an important element that would have further increased the effectiveness of the whole device. However, if the governments of the Member States do not decide to further deepen cooperation, dialogue and exchanging the data in their possession in a continuous and timely manner, we will never be able to give a complete and comprehensive answer to the difficult problems we are facing. The hope is to reach a single European intelligence as soon as possible.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing. - I strongly opposed this report which aims to create a European PNR (Passenger Name Record). This aims to collect the personal data of all air passengers entering or leaving the European Union. This project seriously undermines the freedom of European travelers and would prove to be absolutely ineffective in the fight against terrorism. The attacks in Paris and Brussels, for example, could not have been avoided with such a device. In addition, some member states, such as the UK, are rightly concerned that some state officials may be unreliable and may disclose information to aid in the planning of further attacks. Finally, under the guise of the fight against terrorism, the PNR is more like the aerial outgrowth of the Schengen area, which represents a new attack on the sovereignty of States. Without any reciprocity, the European PNR will indeed be shared with the United States. France, for example, already has its own PNR since 2006. Mass surveillance, danger to national security, attack on the national sovereignty of States: for all these reasons I have spoken out against this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- Vote in favor, the fight against terrorism requires the renunciation of the protection of privacy, we are at war and we must be very clear who are the people who enter and leave the EU.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as we Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with tickets can be useful in identifying risks. Beginning with the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspects. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that will turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- The PNR has finally been approved by our assembly after five years of deadlock in the European Parliament.We have been asking for an acceleration of the timetable for the adoption of this dossier for months.The left groups have in fact done everything they can to delay the implementation of the PNR directive.The PNR (Passenger Name Record) will make it possible to identify the identity of air passengers entering or leaving European space so that law enforcement authorities can use this data wisely.It is, for example, a way of detecting foreign fighters.This instrument will enable the authorities to fight terrorism more effectively.We cannot accept to suffer attacks like those in Paris and Brussels without doing anything.I obviously voted in favor of the PNR directive.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the new directive regulating the use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data for the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offenses and serious crime. It is an important new tool in the fight against terrorists and traffickers. By collecting, sharing and analyzing PNR information, our intelligence agencies are able to detect suspicious patterns of behavior that need verification. PNRs are not a magic formula, but Member States with national PNR systems have once again shown that such a system is highly effective. Understandable concerns have been expressed about the collection and retention of personal data. As a member of the S & amp; D group, I fought to vote on PNR in plenary together with the data protection package, because I strongly believe that the exchange of personal data must be accompanied by the creation of a clear legal framework on their use.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. This is a very important agreement that should have come sooner rather than later. The new rules on data protection will help us deal more effectively with organised crime. I believe this is an enormous step in our struggle against terrorism. Organised crime has become increasingly transnational in nature and it requires a transnational response. A legal framework will thus be created in order to allow for the exchange of PNR data between the Member States. I particularly welcome the measures that will ensure the security of data such as the appointment of a data protection officer.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: in writing. - After 8 years of interinstitutional blockage, the European Parliament has finally adopted the directive on the European PNR. I am very happy about it. The European PNR is certainly not a miracle solution, but its implementation will undoubtedly contribute to the fight against terrorism. Access to information provided by passengers to airlines will allow our authorities to better monitor members of terrorist groups, but above all to identify members not known to our services. I particularly welcome the fact that the directive can apply to intra-EU flights (that is to say from one Member State to another) and not only to those from third countries. Safeguards for the protection of personal data have also been put in place: beyond six months, the identity of passengers will be masked and can only be known under the warrant of a judge. In addition, the European PNR has as a corollary the Data Protection Directive, which will protect the privacy of all citizens. I regret, however, that the exchange of information between Member States is not compulsory. Likewise, the period of transposition of two years into national law seems long to me in view of the imminence of the danger represented by terrorism.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the introduction of the so-called Passenger Name Record (PNR), as we do not yet sufficiently share information between countries in the EU, which has unfortunately become very common during the recent terrorist attacks.Intelligence services do not have enough information about people who can pose a security risk and, as EU citizens, move freely inside and outside the Union.We have a huge debt here and it is too late to start doing something today, the proposal has been under discussion since 2011!Even so, I am glad that the PNR has finally been adopted.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – We should not have cleared this method of mass surveillance and dragnet data gathering whilst making the sharing of data optional, at the discretion of each Member State. This whole system could end up costing EU taxpayers a billion euro that are sorely needed in policing, intelligence, judicial and information-sharing capabilities. We need a targeted method, with judicial oversight, where chartered and private flights do not escape a dragnet that will ensnare us all instead. It is not a shortage of data that has hampered our counter-terrorist efforts, but the very lack of cross-border cooperation to share it which we have very much failed to mandate today, while diverting scarce resources on a blind database. We should not compound a heightened vulnerability from terror with self-inflicted weaknesses in our fundamental rights and liberal form of government.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - The use and exchange of passenger data has raised many perplexities and fears on the part of citizens and professionals for the various implications of the legislation on privacy protection. PNR data, i.e. information provided by passengers when booking air tickets, will be communicated by carriers to Member States and managed by a dedicated national authority - UIP (Passenger Information Unit) - which will use them to conduct investigations on people who could be involved in terrorist offenses or serious crimes. In fact, many countries already collect such data and in the absence of European provisions they have followed international standards. The directive, on the other hand, harmonises the collection and processing system and avoids disparities in the protection of personal data. It is an important tool for countering the terrorist threat, which however alone does not protect against possible attacks unless it is accompanied by greater collaboration between national law enforcement authorities and the intelligence systems of the countries of the Union. I voted in favor because I think it is a good compromise which has managed to strike a balance between data protection and security needs. It was neither an easy nor a foregone task.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report.It is a fact that the nature of criminal and terrorist activity is constantly evolving in recent years.It has become bolder, more sophisticated and acquires an increasingly transnational character.Citizens are increasingly wanting stronger action at EU level to tackle organized crime and terrorism.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The vote on the proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of data contained in passenger files (PNR data) for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist and other serious crimes is a particularly sensitive area which we are called to manage. I find the approach that the only solution is to gather data on travel, regardless of staff or non-staff, without further adequate guarantees, especially when we all know that continuous data production can not be effectively managed, nor given the desired results. In this light, this report does not contain the elements that will lay the foundations for a functional and effective response to the risks that exist and that is why I voted against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - It is one of the most delicate and at the same time most important topics we are dealing with given the recent terrorist attacks. This proposal deals with the use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data to prevent, detect, investigate and crack down on terrorist offenses and other serious crime. I am of the opinion that the basis of an effective form of combating this new type of crime is the exchange of information, without which any police system would be fruitless. This is the direction in which this report is moving and that is why I voted in favor because, if analyzed carefully, PNR data can be an effective tool for detecting and controlling criminal and terrorist activities. It is clear that more incisive action is needed today, and cooperation between Member States in exchanging this information is, in my opinion, the first step in this direction of preventing and prosecuting terrorist offenses. My political group did well to insist on the scheduling of this measure, which has long been forgotten in a drawer.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the implementation of an EU-wide passenger name record (PNR) system which will empower the authorities to better track terrorists and serious criminals by giving them access to flight data.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report because the directive is an effective tool in the fight against terrorism, organized crime and serious crime. I welcome the fact that, after long negotiations, we have now reached a compromise that balances the interests of the law enforcement authorities andof travelers taken into account.Unfortunately, the character of criminal and terrorist acts has constantly evolved over the past few years.These became more and more sophisticated and increasingly transnational.We are therefore forced to take appropriate measures to avoid or punish such actions.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – Whilst UKIP are not principally opposed to the use of PNR data on a bilateral basis, UKIP have voted against this legislative report. Our main concerns lie with two key areas of this legislation. The first issue is that this legislation will permit Europol, an EU agency that UKIP neither recognise nor respect, to access this data and thus provides an extension of their judicial powers. The second issue for UKIP lies with the length of time that the data will be held; we believe that this length of data retention is far too long and leaves many law-abiding citizens’ data at risk from cyber-attacks. We believe that this risk is significantly higher in certain Member States that do not have appropriate standards for data protection and security. In this respect, UKIP have therefore voted for amendments which significantly reduce the length of period for data retention.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing.- I voted for the establishment of the PNR, for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses.Under the new directive, airlines will have to provide the competent authorities with PNR data (identification code for each passenger relating to name, travel dates, itinerary, ticket information, travel agent with whom the flight was booked,payment used, seat number and baggage information) of flights arriving and departing from Europe, obviously all while protecting privacy and personal data, respecting people's privacy.This is a fundamental measure aimed at guaranteeing safety and control in the transport sector which, unfortunately, has over the years proved to be the object of attention by terrorists and violent organized groups.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - Since it began to try to impose a Passenger Name Register (PNR) in the European Union, we have been against the few existing guarantees in terms of data protection and it represents a new increase in the capacity of the security forces of act in an opaque way and without guarantees of legality, using the fight against terrorism as an excuse. After the trilogue process we have not seen a reduction in the scope of the regulation, but quite the opposite, also registering intra-European flights, and without placing a clear limit on the nature of the data that will be stored, so the police will be able to collect and storing information that does not have to be relevant to counterterrorism intelligence. Finally, the possibility of transferring this data to a third party, even outside the European Union, is maintained, which is frankly worrying and deepens the policy of mass surveillance of the population, particularly social activists, by our governments or from third countries with the complicity of our governments. For all the above, we have voted against

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution of 14 April 2016 on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of Passenger Name Record data for the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offenses and serious crimes. Indeed, recent events have shown us that terrorist networks exploit the possibilities of connection between EU countries, which have not been sufficiently controlled, to carry out their operations. The fact that the EU is unable to know who enters or leaves its borders greatly undermines the efforts employed in the fight against terrorism and other serious forms of crime. Therefore, the need arises today for the EU to develop a document, the Passenger Name Record, which lists information concerning individuals entering or leaving the territory of the EU. Moreover, it is important that these data are used for the sole purpose of ensuring better security for European citizens and respecting their privacy.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up.- Security and protection of life is a decisive factor in the elimination of terrorist offenses and serious transnational crime.The processing of personal data must be necessary and applicable at operational level.I voted for the collection of such data by air carriers and the transfer of this data to a single designated unit.The introduction of an PNR system at EU level is required by the current situation of acts of terrorism and violence and can lead to ensuring international security.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing.- The terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels have highlighted the presence of terrorism in the Union, so the issue of security needs to be taken more seriously.The security of European citizens is of paramount importance and every effort must be made at European and national level to ensure this.The 'PNR report' adopted today has a key role to play in this endeavor.Information is exchanged through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, thus preventing those who have already been identified as potential terrorists from entering the Union.Today, finally, after a long wait, the European Parliament also nodded at the compromise text of the PNR regulation, which the left has tried to crack down so far.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - The directive will require airlines to provide EU law enforcement authorities with basic data such as the ticket number, name and method of payment by passengers arriving or departing from the EU, to help authorities fight terrorism and serious cross-border crime. The proposed directive introduces clear rules for the collection, use and retention of PNR data, as well as a strong framework for data protection and passenger rights. The provisions of the directive cover a five-year data retention period, both in the case of terrorism and serious crime. After 6 months of storage, the data will be masked (anonymized) by the authorities. There is a specific, closed list of offenses for which data can be used in investigation and prosecution. There is a set of clear rules on data use, including the requirement for a DPO in the relevant law enforcement units, data management guidelines, independent supervision and monitoring, and an explicit reference to EU data protection law. The directive also provides for a review mechanism after 2 years. The review will assess the need to include non-carrier economic operators in the scope of the Directive and assess all aspects of the Directive in terms of proportionality and necessity, with particular regard to the requirements of the Court of Justice in relation to the Data Retention Directive. Due to the nature of the document, I voted for it.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - This legislative report concerns the use of passenger name records (PNR). PNR data is intended to fight serious crime and terrorism. This report introduces an obligation for air carriers to provide Member States with passenger data on flights to or from the territory of the Union. At the same time, we have taken measures to ensure the protection of privacy and personal data. This report also sets common rules for the establishment of national PNR systems by the Member States of the Union. Considering that these measures are necessary to make the fight against terrorism more effective, I regret that a left-wing coalition has so long opposed the putting to the vote of this report, despite the attacks and the strong terrorist threat, in particular in France and Belgium. I would like to remind you that PNR data cannot be used for purposes other than the fight against serious and terrorist offenses. Considering that the fight against terrorism requires quality work in terms of information and identification of individuals at risk, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
