text: in writing.- Finally, after years of negotiations and political blockages, the report on the use of passenger name record data, the European PNR, was adopted by the European Parliament.For years my political group and I have fought to achieve the adoption of this indispensable tool in the fight against terrorism in Europe.The European PNR will strengthen the security of European citizens by allowing the detection of air travel of suspects or people under surveillance.I regret that so much time has been lost.However, this instrument will not be sufficient to deal with the threat posed to our territory by foreign fighters.The European Union must now continue to work to strengthen its arsenal in the fight against terrorism and the prevention of radicalization.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I endorse the initiative for a directive on the retention and sharing of personal name record (PNR) data. The recent terrorist attacks and the inability of individual Member States to prevent these. Terrorists and criminal networks are working across borders and our security forces need to adapt to this. However, they can only do so if the legislator offers them the appropriate legal framework to do this. Therefore, I welcome an EU-wide decision to retain passenger data with regard to civil aviation. I do believe that our work is not done here, and that a next step will be a centralised EU database, so that we finally have an actual EU-wide solution. For the time being, this directive is a step in the good direction.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing. - I am happy that the PNR directive has finally been adopted. It is a necessary instrument for our intelligence and security services to collect and process information useful for combating terrorism and organized crime. This is an essential step in the fight against terrorism. Faced with this threat, the Union's response must be a firm response within the natural framework of our rule of law. The PNR can and should be improved. It is not yet a "European PNR", but 28 national PNRs whose interconnection remains to be organized. Even if this legislation provides for the possibility for several States to pool their data collection and processing unit, it will be necessary to end up with a “European PNR” and a compulsory exchange of data between States. The PNR can and should be supplemented by other measures, in particular the strengthening of Europol and Eurojust, the creation of a European prosecutor, the establishment of systematic control at Schengen borders, the harmonization of terrorist offenses and the creation of a file of foreign fighters. Parliament must continue to assume the responsibilities conferred on it by the Treaty so that Europe equips itself with the means to fight terrorism.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. - After five years of blockage by left-wing groups, the directive on the European PNR - the system for recording passenger data by air - has finally been adopted. The PNR will complete the European arsenal in the fight against terrorism. In particular, it will allow the detection of movements of dangerous or monitored individuals. This information could have been invaluable in preventing the attacks which have struck France and Belgium in recent months. However, I want to reassure those who fear a mass collection of their data, we have erected safeguards to guarantee the protection of this data such as the designation of an officer responsible for verifying the legality of the collection in each national unit. or the limitation of retention periods. I welcome the selflessness with which our political group succeeded in having this directive adopted, which is essential in the fight against those who threaten our freedoms. Finally, I would like to underline the irresponsible attitude of the left groups which, with low political maneuvers, have only delayed the adoption of this directive, which is unanimously considered essential to protect our security.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, so everything must be done for the security of European citizens. This is why information needs to be shared, for example through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, as the entry into force of European PNR can also be an important tool in the Member States' fight against terrorism. This will prevent those who have once been identified as potential terrorists from entering Europe, but are still able to move freely within the Union, taking advantage of the wave of migration and abusing the Schengen system. The compromise text of the PNR regulation was already agreed in December, but formal consecration by the European Parliament has been pending since then due to the irresponsible play of left-wing parties. We hope that the left will also finally understand that European citizens have a legitimate expectation towards today's decision-makers to protect them and give back their sense of security. This European Passenger Name Record system will help.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing. - The proposal for a directive on the European PNR has been on the table since 2011. It provides for the transfer and processing of air passenger data (date of travel, itinerary, contact details, eating habits, etc.) for the purposes of combating the terrorism and organized crime. The European PNR will strengthen the range of measures available to the European Union to fight terrorism, but it is not the only tool in this fight, which first involves the prevention of radicalization, the control of the circulation of firearms, the drying up of terrorist financing sources and better cooperation between intelligence, police and justice services. We also wanted to link the question of the PNR to that of the protection of personal data. Governing responsibly means achieving a good balance, in this case, between the protection of individual freedoms, the fight against terrorism and the security of citizens.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the PNR directive and rejected all the amendments tabled in plenary because adopting just one would have destroyed the whole agreement.The PNR does not deserve a religious war.In reality, the PNR is only one of the instruments necessary to help our intelligence and security services to collect and process information useful in the fight against terrorism and serious criminals.Of course, as I said, this instrument is not perfect.This is not, and I regret it, a European PNR, but 28 national PNRs whose interconnection remains to be done.I regret that the exchange of information between these 28 PNRs is not mandatory and that the transposition deadline is too long, but I prefer an instrument even imperfect if it can save lives than no instrument at all.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. - The proposal for a Directive on Passenger Name Record (PNR) requires the systematic collection, use and storage of data, such as contact details, flight dates and schedules, or credit card details used to pay for tickets, for passengers on flights across the EU. The use of this data should assist the security services in the fight against terrorism and other criminal activities, as it would facilitate the identification of potential suspects. I supported this proposal because it is an important tool in the fight against terrorism and organized crime. I consider the report to be balanced with the right of EU citizens to privacy, and I also believe that the PNR Directive is in line with the ruling of the European Court of Justice on the Data Retention Directive. I voted against the part concerning the mandatory transfer of data between states, because I believe that this sharing should remain on a voluntary basis.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- The European PNR aims to collect the personal data of all aircraft passengers entering or leaving European space.Not content with undermining the respect for the privacy of passengers, delivering to more or less reliable European States, very personal information (religion, health, etc.), the PNR is obviously ineffective in the face of today's terrorists.hui.On the contrary, it risks threatening the national security of states.Worse, it is intended to be communicated to the United States, which is unacceptable, insofar as it is not reciprocal.For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, so everything must be done for the security of European citizens. This is why information needs to be shared, for example through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, as the entry into force of European PNR can also be an important tool in the Member States' fight against terrorism. This will prevent those who have once been identified as potential terrorists from entering Europe, but are still able to move freely within the Union, taking advantage of the wave of migration and abusing the Schengen system. The compromise text of the PNR regulation was already agreed in December, but formal consecration by the European Parliament has been pending since then due to the irresponsible play of left-wing parties. We hope that the left will also finally understand that European citizens have a legitimate expectation towards today's decision-makers to protect them and give back their sense of security. This European Passenger Name Record system will help.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The Directive on the use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data requires air carriers to transmit to Member States data on travelers arriving or departing from the EU to help prevent and combat terrorism.Provisions have been introduced to clarify the requirements for the conservation, analysis, transfer and use of PNR data and to ensure the right to privacy and protection of personal data.The new rules require air carriers to transfer passenger data on extra-EU flights (from a third country to an EU Member State or vice versa) from their reservation systems to a specialized unit in the Member State of arrivalor starting, with a view to combating serious crime and terrorism.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: it seriously undermines respect for the private life of passengers, it does not make it possible to really fight terrorism and undermines national sovereignty.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Taking advantage of the legitimate feeling of insecurity motivated by the recent attacks on European soil - exacerbated both by the media and by certain political forces - the right and social democracy have approved the PNR proposal, registration of passenger identification, in plenary, previously rejected. Instigated by recent events, the defenders of this system advocate with the usual rhetoric, and under the pretext of "combating terrorism", the rapid implementation of the system as a way to prevent and prevent "terrorist attacks". It is yet to be proved that any of these visas would have been avoided had the system been in place. The proposal provides for the creation of passenger profiles, which make it possible to identify potential suspects of possible unlawful acts, by imposing the provision of data from airlines to Member States, for a period of 5 years, without guarantee of their safeguard. In practice, any and all citizens, European or foreign, traveling within the EU, are considered a suspect at the outset, which justifies the collection and maintenance of data, which will, far beyond combating terrorism, identify and create profiles , in addition to crime, trade unionists, political activists, among other social groups and individual citizens, serving a security vision and restricting rights, freedoms and guarantees. We voted against.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, as I consider the Passenger Name Register to be a very important tool to be able to strengthen security for European citizens.I believe that it is a measure that represents added value in the fight against terrorism and organized crime in the European Union.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing.- EU states will exchange data on flight passengers.The directive on PNR (passenger name record), essentially the collection and sharing of data / flight plans of passengers in Europe, provides for a single Community regulation for the collection and exchange of information by authorities, for prevention purposes, investigation and prosecution.A step forward in the fight against terrorism: the PNR tool will allow the so-called foreign fighters to fight tighter.Five years to vote on the measure in plenary is too long.In any case, today's is an important result that will give European citizens more security.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against because I believe it will result in more problems than it solves.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- The recent terrorist attacks in Paris and Brussels have shown us that terrorist activity in Europe has been constantly evolving in recent years.Terrorist attacks are becoming bolder, more sophisticated and transnational in nature.The European Union must make a much greater effort to tackle organized crime and terrorism.The European Commission is seeking to respond to this situation by proposing to use PNR data.PNR data is information provided by passengers when booking tickets, and airlines retain this information.Law enforcement authorities may also use PNR data and the proposed directive lays down harmonized rules for such measures.In close analysis, PNR data can be an effective tool for identifying and tracking crime and terrorism.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am refraining from the report which I consider to be good in some parts, but more could have been done towards greater control and security.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. Non-carriers and non-carriers are already collecting and processing PNR data, so the directive does not introduce anything innovative, as criminals and terrorists are not used to using carriers for their travels. Above all, however, the obligation to apply a personal data collection system to cross-border road and / or sea transport is not considered, as it would mean the automatic abolition of the Schengen acquis, nor does it make data exchange between Member States mandatory when there is tangible evidence of individuals, members of transnational crime. In addition, it is oxymoronic to stipulate that the results of PNR data processing can not be used to deny asylum to potential or systemically identified criminals or terrorists. The directive leaves gaps in the Union citizens' right to privacy and is not in line with the data protection directive. Finally, within the meaning of the sovereign state, each Member State should be able to exclude those minor offenses for which, taking into account its respective criminal justice system, the processing of PNR data would not be in accordance with the fundamental principle of TFEU, proportionality. For all the above reasons I voted against.

name: Ashley FOX
text: in writing. ‒ My Conservative colleagues and I voted in favour of this directive as it closes loopholes that were previously open to exploitation by criminals in order to avoid detection by law enforcement authorities. There exists clear evidence that the EU PNR, which shares less information than a Tesco clubcard, helps in the fight against crime, including terror suspects, murderers and human traffickers.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I expressed my support for the PNR (Passenger Name Record) directive and the data protection package. It is clear that we do not have enough information on terror suspects and the little we do have is not being used or shared effectively by national law enforcement agencies. The data protection package and PNR will establish a clear legal framework for how personal data can be used and shared. This will make it significantly easier for national law enforcement agencies to share information quickly and effectively. These measures are fundamental for the fight against terrorism. The PNR directive can be a useful tool in the fight against terror if the data collected is used and shared effectively by law enforcement agencies.  I expect national governments to make use of existing EU measures to fight terrorism.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - Recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, so everything must be done for the security of European citizens. This is why information needs to be shared, for example through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, as the entry into force of European PNR can also be an important tool in the Member States' fight against terrorism. This will prevent those who have once been identified as potential terrorists from entering Europe, but are still able to move freely within the Union, taking advantage of the wave of migration and abusing the Schengen system. The compromise text of the PNR regulation was agreed in December, but the formal consecration of the European Parliament has been pending since then due to the irresponsible play of left-wing parties. We hope that the left will also finally understand that European citizens have a legitimate expectation towards today's decision-makers to protect them and give back their sense of security. This European Passenger Name Record system will help.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - Recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, so everything must be done for the security of European citizens. This is why information needs to be shared, for example through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, as the entry into force of European PNR can also be an important tool in the Member States' fight against terrorism. This will prevent those who have once been identified as potential terrorists from entering Europe, but are still able to move freely within the Union, taking advantage of the wave of migration and abusing the Schengen system. The compromise text of the PNR regulation was agreed in December, but the formal consecration of the European Parliament has been pending since then due to the irresponsible play of left-wing parties. We hope that the left will also finally understand that European citizens have a legitimate expectation towards today's decision-makers to protect them and give back their sense of security. This European Passenger Name Record system will help.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as it is a major improvement in the security policies of the European Union.The PNR represents a great advance in terms of protection, and the collection of data in a centralized way and by all EU countries, with exclusively protection and security purposes, will help us in the future to combat terrorist acts and crimesgrave on European soil.It is perhaps the best example of what we can achieve when we work together, when we work with a common will.Advancing in the development of common policies is the way to advance in an integration that guarantees European citizens the exercise of their rights and their security.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a Directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as the Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against the terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal a rapid exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework for exchanging information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even the intelligence services of the 28. It is not just about increasing uncritically new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but it is necessary to improve the use made of existing instruments. That is why we Socialists support the strengthening of EUROPOL to turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as we Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that will turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Elisabetta GARDINI
text: in writing.- Today's vote on the PNR marks the victory of common sense in favor of the protection of citizens who, in the light of recent events, are calling for greater security.The European lefts have for years prevented us, by their vote against, from approving the directive on PNR.They sacrificed the possibility of having greater security in the name of an instrumental, ideological and irresponsible vision of the protection of privacy which today, with the use of technological tools such as cameras, cell phone localization and social media, appears anachronistic.It took three attacks in just over a year - and one of these, according to the French authorities, could have been avoided if the PNR had been in place - to make it clear to the European left that there is no room for ideological positions, when it is aI risk the lives of our citizens.Now it is up to governments to make the directive operational as quickly as possible.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the resolution on the second report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorism and serious crime, and I consider the approval of this instrument and the legislation on the protection of personal data to be a very important moment for the European Union. I believe that the PNR directive represents the solution to all problems and the final weapon against terrorism, however I strongly support the need to increase the sharing and circulation of information with respect to potential dangers between the authorities of individual states: the tragic facts Paris and Brussels clearly demonstrate how a better sharing and exchange of information and intelligence data would have saved many lives and perhaps even avoided attacks. I believe that the directive ensures a balanced legal framework for sharing and using this data. It is now up to the Member States to implement the legislation both at legislative and practical level, organizing a real and fruitful collaboration between the competent national authorities in order to guarantee the security required by all European citizens.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- Harmonizing the use of Passenger Name Records is an important step in the fight against terrorism and organized crime in the EU.With the data sets, the entry and exit of people into the EU but also within the EU can be monitored and tracked more closely and in more detail.Personal data will be stored for a period of six months.This makes law enforcement easier.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Passenger Name Record (PNR) Directive as I consider the creation of a European information sharing system to be essential, following rules common to all EU Member States. Even so, I have reservations about the final text, agreed and approved between the Council and the European Parliament, but in which many of the latter's demands have been blocked by the Member States. First, the sharing of information between Member States is neither mandatory nor automatic, leaving it up to each individual to define what he considers "necessary and relevant", which only consolidates distrust between partners, reluctance in sharing information, inability to act effectively and in concert, against the very essence of what was intended with this Directive. The Directive also fails in scope, omitting the possibility for Member States to regulate the transfer of PNR data in the case of private flights. We therefore run the risk of ending 28 different PNRs, uncoordinated and out of step with a European action plan to prevent radicalization and recruitment by terrorist networks.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - We voted against this despite the fact that this PNR in the EU was initially raised by the Commission as a way to fight terrorism and transnational crime. Finally, the speaker's text shows that the intention goes further. The text originally intended to harmonize the data collection obligations of airlines and operators operating from third countries. The Report, also in this case, has gone beyond the Commission's proposal, asking to extend the registration of passenger data to travelers between EU countries. The text determines the criteria on the basis of which these authorities can use such data, defined in a vague and broad way. The massive compilation of data that is proposed is disproportionate and unnecessary, ignoring the recommendations of the CJEU on proportionality in data collection. Due to all this series of vagueness, vagueness and attempts to present as a fight against terrorism a massive and indiscriminate collection of passenger data that exceeds proportionality and that it is not known for what purpose they will finally be used, that is why we have decided to vote in against.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this directive, it will ensure the processing and sharing of airline passenger name records between EU Member States in order to help identify passengers who are suspected terrorists on flights which originate from outside of the EU. There are also a number of safeguards to ensure that this complies with data protection rules and is proportional.

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as we Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that will turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - The fight against terrorism is a huge and complex challenge facing the EU as a whole and calling for a common response from all its Member States. In this context, the adoption of the European PNR is positive insofar as this mechanism will strengthen the range of measures available to the EU. That being said, let's be clear: the current situation will not be resolved overnight by adopting the PNR, a measure that is certainly welcome but is far from being the miracle solution. It is not important to collect as much data as possible, it is still necessary to know how to exchange and process them in an efficient and relevant manner. The real added value of the European PNR will depend in particular on the capacity of the Member States to strengthen the quality of their cooperation. It is in a global and coherent approach that we must rethink our action. Controlling the circulation of firearms, drying up terrorist financing sources and preventing radicalization are all projects that also call for real mobilization.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - Recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, so everything must be done for the security of European citizens. This is why information needs to be shared, for example through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, as the entry into force of European PNR can also be an important tool in the Member States' fight against terrorism. This will prevent those who have once been identified as potential terrorists from entering Europe, but are still able to move freely within the Union, taking advantage of the wave of migration and abusing the Schengen system. The compromise text of the PNR regulation was agreed in December, but the formal consecration of the European Parliament has been pending since then due to the irresponsible play of left-wing parties. We hope that the left will also finally understand that European citizens have a legitimate expectation towards today's decision-makers to protect them and give back their sense of security. This European Passenger Name Record system will help.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- We voted against this report because we consider it a violation of basic human rights.It does not retain the personal data of only those who enter the Union, but also of those who move within it.There is also no targeting as to which people the data will be used, thus giving the right to retain personal information for people not involved in terrorism matters.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the use of Passenger Name Records (PNR). Work on the PNR system has been going on for a long time, but so far we have not managed to reach a political compromise in this regard. Nevertheless, recent events in Brussels, Paris and many other places around the world show that the situation related to the terrorist threat is starting to change drastically and this change requires us to quickly develop effective solutions to protect the security of our citizens. There is no longer any room for "business as usual" or strictly political disputes, and we cannot afford to postpone this decision again. We need action here and now. Thanks to tools such as PNR, we are better able to fight terrorism and organized crime, as we are able to identify faster people who pose a threat to the security of our citizens. I understand and support the arguments about the need to respect the security of personal data, but I believe that the PNR Directive provides good standards in this regard as well.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, so everything must be done for the security of European citizens. This is why information needs to be shared, for example through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, as the entry into force of European PNR can also be an important tool in the Member States' fight against terrorism. This will prevent those who have once been identified as potential terrorists from entering Europe, but are still able to move freely within the Union, taking advantage of the wave of migration and abusing the Schengen system. The compromise text of the PNR regulation was agreed in December, but the formal consecration of the European Parliament has been pending since then due to the irresponsible play of left-wing parties. We hope that the left will also finally understand that European citizens have a legitimate expectation towards today's decision-makers to protect them and give back their sense of security. This European Passenger Name Record system will help.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - I am relieved that the directive on the European PNR has finally been adopted after more than five years of blockage by the left which voluntarily paralyzed the work by pure ideology. For those who fear a mass collection of their data, I will tell them that precautions to guarantee data protection have been taken, such as the designation of an officer responsible for verifying the legality of the collection in each national unit and the durations limited conservation. However, I regret the willful obstruction of certain deputies who, until the end, have tried to block the adoption of this text with fallacious arguments. How can we say, for example, that the PNR would not have prevented the attacks in Paris and Brussels, when the system does not exist? How to explain that this system “so faulty” inaugurated in the United States after the attacks of 2001 is replicated everywhere in the world? Our priority must be to fight against those who threaten our freedoms. However, freedom can only be real in a world that provides sufficient security to be able to express opinions and disagreements.

name: Richard HOWITT
text: in writing. ‒ Voting to make my constituents safer from terrorist and criminal threats is something which must be the highest duty of any politician for his or her constituents. The EU Passenger Name Record (PNR) Directive will ensure the processing and sharing of airline passenger name records between EU Member States. This will help identify passengers who are suspected terrorists on flights which originate from outside of the EU, before any damage can be done. Earlier attempts to win agreement foundered on proper questions about respect for civil liberties and privacy of data, but which I believe have now been properly answered by building necessary judicial safeguards into the agreement. I strongly believe national governments must also get serious about funding Europe-wide anti-terrorism bodies, and make better use of European instruments for sharing vehicle registration details, finger printing and DNA data. Our access as a member of the EU to these measures, now including PNR, highlights the necessity of Britain remaining within the EU. I am proud to have given this report my support.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that passenger name record data is crucial in order for law enforcement agencies to deal with the current terrorist challenges in Europe. Securing air transport is important in combating so-called ‘foreign fighters’ and disrupting terrorist networks.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the Draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of Passenger Name Record data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crime, as I consider ”Needed today. Today's global environment in which travel is becoming easier and cheaper, and where communication is becoming faster, also allows for the easy mobility of terrorism and serious crime. The current moment in which the EU is under the threat of terrorism is an additional argument for accepting this Resolution. Although I have doubts about enabling the use, collection and sharing of private passenger data, in conditions where there is a serious risk to the safety of citizens, I support the introduction of "PNR" as a measure that will certainly reduce that risk and I believe save many lives. The basis for the adoption of this Resolution is the protection of personal data. Some countries already have such a system and it is precisely such a system that has proven effective in preventing human trafficking, kidnapping, drug smuggling and murder. Disparities between Member States in the way they regulate this issue are fertile ground for criminal activity. I believe that such a system will certainly reduce the possibilities for terrorism and criminal activity. The implementation of the system for the use of data from the passenger data records should start immediately.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing. - Already collected by airlines to establish flight reservations, they are communicated to the relevant European state which centralizes them and then transmits them to other partner states which request them, whether in the EU or outside the EU. The European PNR is officially justified by the concern to fight against terrorism as well as against certain serious offenses (trafficking in human beings, participation in a criminal organization, cybercrime, child pornography, trafficking in weapons or explosives). The European PNR also threatens national security by allowing European states to access information about passengers entering or leaving France. The European PNR is finally intended to be communicated to the United States, whereas in return the latter will not communicate their PNR to the European Union. Obviously, such a collaboration cannot be accepted without reciprocity, which is more akin to subservience than to genuine international cooperation. This confirms that the European Union is more at the service of the United States and the pro-American lobbies than at the service of the European peoples. It seems logical that my vote was against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – Whilst UKIP are not principally opposed to the use of PNR data on a bilateral basis, UKIP have voted against this legislative report. Our main concerns lie with two key areas of this legislation. The first issue is that this legislation will permit Europol, an EU agency that UKIP neither recognise nor respect, to access this data and thus provides an extension of their judicial powers. The second issue for UKIP lies with the length of time that the data will be held; we believe that this length of data retention is far too long and leaves many law-abiding citizens’ data at risk from cyber-attacks. We believe that this risk is significantly higher in certain Member States that do not have appropriate standards for data protection and security. In this respect, UKIP have therefore voted for amendments which significantly reduce the length of period for data retention.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ The setting up of a European PNR, which will regulate the transfer of PNR data from the airlines to national authorities, as well as the processing of this data, is a very important tool in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. It will oblige airlines to hand national authorities’ passenger data for all flights from third countries to the EU and vice versa. I think it will significantly help EU intelligence services to detect patterns of suspicious behaviour and follow up on those. I hope Member States will make full use of exiting provisions on sharing of PNR data between their intelligence services. The recent terrorist attacks showed that no country can make it on its own. I believe this directive is up to the challenge we are facing and provides sufficient safeguards when it comes to data protection.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Kirkhope on the use of passenger name record data (EU-PNR). After years of ideological and populist blockade led by the left and the far right, I can only rejoice at the success of this vote and sadly that it took the left so much time and drama to uncover the meaning of the word "responsibility". While the PNR is not the miracle solution, it is an essential tool in the fight against terrorism, which has hit Europe and France hard in recent years. While we already exchange PNR data with the United States or even Canada, it was incomprehensible that Europe did not use this data to ensure its own protection. The necessary arrangements to protect the privacy of citizens have been taken and Member States will have to take their common interest seriously and effectively share important information between them. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I obviously voted in favor of the European PNR, which should allow passenger traceability in the context of the fight against terrorism and organized crime.If this tool should not be the alpha and omega of the fight against terrorism in Europe, it is necessary.Besides, I regret that we lost so much time on the PNR vote because of the blockage coming from a part of the left.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: in writing.- I support the new directive governing the use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data for EU prevention, detection, investigation and investigation of terrorism and other serious crimes.The new rules will require airlines to transfer passenger data to Member States' authorities for all flights between the EU and third countries.By collecting, sharing and analyzing passenger data, our intelligence agencies will be able to identify patterns of suspicious behavior.PNR is not the answer to all problems, but Member States with national PNR systems have repeatedly proved their effectiveness.The directive also provides data protection guarantees and is proportionate to the risk to which we are currently exposed.The aim is to harmonize EU Member States' rules on the collection and processing of PNR data.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- This report is rejected by me.The desired data collection will never represent an actual hurdle for criminals or terrorists, as they (1) use high-tech means and (2) can move freely by land within Europe.But what should be achieved with such an expanded data collection system is the collection of personal and sensitive data from all European citizens.The amount of data is also much too large to be evaluated accordingly.It would be more important to focus on the data of suspicious people.

name: Krišjānis KARIŅŠ
text: in writing. - In the plenary session of the European Parliament, I voted in favor of the directive establishing a Passenger Name Record at European Union level. I believe that this already excessive and unjustifiably delayed decision is very welcome and provides European law enforcement and other security authorities with a powerful weapon in the fight against terrorism and organized crime. Law enforcement authorities will now be able to access information on who will come to the European Union from third countries. The text of the directive makes it clear that the information contained in the register may only be used for the purpose of combating crime and terrorism, thus respecting the principles of data protection of citizens and preserving the right to privacy. The exchange of information will make it easier to track and detect individuals who are not yet in sight of law enforcement and other security authorities as potential terrorists or criminals. The disadvantage of the directive is that it excludes intra-EU flights, but this information will be able to be exchanged between services on a voluntary basis.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the directive, as it will provide a useful tool to assist police and intelligence agencies in tracking down possible terrorists and criminals. The directive also contains a number of safeguards to ensure it complies with data protection rules and is proportional. If the data is used and shared effectively by law enforcement agencies it will assist in the fight against terror, but should not be presented as a silver bullet. What the last few years have shown is that while measures have been adopted at EU level, national governments must make better use of European instruments to combat terrorism.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - I was sincerely shocked that, as one of the few Czech MEPs, I refused to support this proposal and voted against. Despite the heated debate in plenary, I refused to believe that the European Parliament would ignore all current ways of fighting criminals and move to supervising them all. At the same time, we did not talk at all about how to improve, for example, the cooperation of intelligence and security forces. Our problem is that one hand does not know what the other is doing, and we want to punish all EU citizens for that. We are also still not talking about the fact that the new generation of terrorists is a direct consequence of the poor integration of foreigners, especially in francophone areas. We are not even talking about the fact that one of the attackers in Brussels was expelled from Turkey as an unwanted person and the other even worked directly in the European Parliament over the summer. Instead of seeking solutions to these burning problems, MEPs today have called for greater control over those who are overwhelmingly innocent and want to live in peace and quiet. I am therefore sorry about the result of today's vote, and I hope that those who voted in favor of the proposal will derive political responsibility from this at the moment when this data is misused.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - Recent terrorist attacks have shown that there is no freedom without security, so everything must be done for the security of European citizens. This is why information needs to be shared, for example through the Passenger Name Record (PNR) system, as the entry into force of European PNR can also be an important tool in the Member States' fight against terrorism. This will prevent those who have once been identified as potential terrorists from entering Europe, but are still able to move freely within the Union, taking advantage of the wave of migration and abusing the Schengen system. The compromise text of the PNR regulation was already agreed in December, but formal consecration by the European Parliament has been pending since then due to the irresponsible play of left-wing parties. We hope that the left will also finally understand that European citizens have a legitimate expectation towards today's decision-makers to protect them and give back their sense of security. This European Passenger Name Record system will help.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The present report deals with the proposal for a directive that attempts to regulate the use of passenger name record (PNR) data at EU level and to harmonise Member States’ policies in this field. I strongly believe it is crucial not to adopt an amplified approach of an EU PNR system that could alienate fundamental rights under the pretext of the recent terrorist attacks. Deplorably, as it stands from the report, the PNR proposal does not meet the criteria of proportionality, mostly due to the fact that the personal data can be assessed in a non-targeted way. Additionally, the enlargement of the scope of the EU PNR scheme beyond international targeted flights in order to include intra-EU flights will finally lead to the collection of data of everyone flying between EU Member States. This fact raises an issue of compliance with the principle of necessity. Therefore, I voted against.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: in writing. - After years of work, the Parliament has managed to dismiss this important measure on the register of air passenger data. An essential directive to fill the gap or fragmentation of legislation in which many Member States find themselves and which represents a first step towards a harmonization of data collection and procedures. These measures will certainly play an important role in the fight against terrorism, however they should in no way be regarded as exclusive. Once collected, this information must be processed and transferred, and used effectively by the competent national authorities. Above all, the data being exchanged must primarily serve as a criminal intelligence tool and not as a border control tool. I also welcome all safeguards related to passenger data protection, especially those that prohibit the processing of data revealing racial or ethnic origin, political views, religion or philosophical beliefs, trade union membership, health, life or sexual orientation of the person concerned.

name: Merja KYLLÖNEN
text: written. - Parliament voted on this proposal for a directive on the day when, just a few weeks have passed, a literal act of several dozen lives in our home field. The March attacks took place at the airport and on the metro, which were selected as targets probably because of the large crowds they gathered. The aftermath of the attack at the devastated Brussels airport is extensive, and to ensure safety, all passengers are now being treated as suspects. The effects on people's daily lives and mobility are long-lasting. There are no resources to replace the effective and preventive exchange and analysis of information between authorities, let alone the way everyday life and "free movement" in Europe will become if every passer-by continues to be treated as a criminal. In this situation, I think knowledge is our best weapon in the fight against terrorism. Data collection and analysis helps to develop our security functions in a risk-based direction. Unfortunately, however, the proposal that has now been put to the vote does not sufficiently respect people's fundamental rights and the protection of privacy. The proposal for a directive contains a number of excessive details. The best experts in Europe consider the proposal to be a direct violation of fundamental rights, even illegal. For this proposal, we would have needed less but better. That is why I voted against the proposal for a directive.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour because we are living in a very insecure world – a world in which cross—border organised crime and terrorism are taking place. Therefore, we should support use of passenger name record (PNR) data at EU level in order to prove, detect and investigate suspects involved in illegal cross—border activities. In this regard, it is valuable to emphasise the fact that a common EU PNR system would harmonise Member States’ legal provisions and avoid legal uncertainty and security gaps, whilst at the same time safeguarding data protection. However, we should be convinced that Member States will inform passengers about the collection of PNR data and about their civil rights.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - Following the tragic events of terrorism, which hit some European capitals, there is a clear request from our citizens to increase security levels. For this reason, we have strongly asked for the so-called PNR, the register of flight passengers, to be released, and we have won the political battle after four years of work, reaching its approval. We now have an additional strategic tool for the fight against terrorism and organized crime, which will allow us to monitor suspects and their movements, to prevent possible attacks. The proposal creates a system whereby companies operating flights between a third country and at least one EU state are required to communicate PNR data (including name, address, route and credit card used) to law enforcement authorities and that allows you to determine the rules under which these authorities will be able to use the data received to investigate and prosecute potential crimes. We have given up a small portion of our privacy for important security reasons for all of our citizens.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the European PNR (Passenger Name Record), a platform for the exchange of air passenger data files on a European scale, which we, MEPs The Republicans, have always defended in order to strengthenthe means available to the European Union in the fight against terrorism.This project, on the table since 2011, has been blocked for far too long by the left, the liberals and the far right, who demanded the simultaneous adoption of safeguards for the protection of personal data.The insistence of the PPE Group helped to speed up awareness, and therefore the decision to vote.This European PNR will now allow the authorities of the Member States to detect the suspicious movements of tracked and dangerous individuals.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: in writing. - The European PNR "Passenger Name Recording" is a vast system for recording all passengers taking the plane in Europe, whatever their destinations: all passengers, from all European flights will be listed, and their data recorded for 5 years! Our concerns about the proportionality of the means (the recording of our movements), on the objectives summoned (the fight against terrorism) which make it possible to circumvent fundamental rights, and our reminders of the repeated judgments of the Court of Justice of the EU against this type of tools, were ignored. However, it would have been possible to develop a more balanced system by targeting thefts and people "at risk", rather than returning to a logic of "all suspects" based on mass registration. I would add that the investigations into the tragic events that affected Paris and Brussels show that data collection is not a problem: it is better sharing of these data between European services that is lacking. I therefore opposed this text and regret all the more that we took advantage of the emotion created by tragic events to facilitate its adoption.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing. - I voted against the report on the European PNR, which aims to collect the personal data of all aircraft passengers entering or leaving European space. This system seriously undermines the respect for the privacy of passengers. European states will know their movements, the identity of the people accompanying them, and even very personal information relating to their religious affiliation and their state of health (revealed by specific requests related to illness or disability). As in George Orwell's anticipatory novel “1984”, a “Big Brother” is thus forming at European level to systematically spy on the privacy of citizens. The PNR is also ineffective, because it does not allow a real fight against terrorism. Neither the attacks in Paris nor those in Brussels would have been avoided if it had existed. Rather than wasting time logging and monitoring hundreds of millions of passengers, of whom at least 99% are known to have nothing to be ashamed of, it would be better to focus on targeted surveillance of potential terrorists. The PNR undermines national sovereignty, because it aims to save the Schengen area by creating a sort of air Schengen area.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it decides the creation of the European PNR under the pretext of fighting terrorism.However, this is a particularly shocking mass filing because: 1) it violates the freedom and secrecy of the privacy of hundreds of millions of air passengers who have nothing to do with terrorism;2) it will be ineffective because it will cost a billion euros which it would have been wiser to devote to our intelligence services to identify terrorists and real suspects;3) it further undermines the sovereignty of France by attempting to save the Schengen area by giving it a sort of aerial overgrowth.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing. - The European PNR is an instrument which aims to collect the personal data of all aircraft passengers entering or leaving the European area. It contains precise details, such as the identity of each passenger, their travel agency, their itinerary, their means of payment and their specific requests related to their meals or their state of health. Already held by the airlines, they will be communicated to the European State which will redirect them to any partner State of the European Union or not, including the United States, which will benefit from this information without providing their national PNR. This text is liberticidal, it violates in all complacency the fundamental right of every human being to privacy and in doing so transforms the passengers into Orwellian puppets that can be manipulated by the "Big Brother". But he also wastes his time monitoring passengers, 99% of whom are innocent, instead of focusing on the real criminals recorded in the "S files". Finally, it creates a new zone without borders, by setting up an air Schengen area which further threatens the security of States. For all these outrageous reasons, I voted against.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as we Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that will turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as we Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that will turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - Since it began to try to impose a Passenger Name Register (PNR) in the European Union, we have been against the few existing guarantees in terms of data protection and it represents a new increase in the capacity of the security forces of act in an opaque way and without guarantees of legality, using the fight against terrorism as an excuse. After the trilogue process, we have not seen a reduction in the scope of the regulation, but quite the opposite, also registering intra-European flights, and without setting a clear limit to the nature of the data that will be stored, so the police will be able to collect and storing information that does not have to be relevant to counterterrorism intelligence. Finally, the possibility of transferring this data to a third party, even outside the European Union, is maintained, which is frankly worrying and deepens the policy of mass surveillance of the population, particularly social activists, by our governments or from third countries with the complicity of our governments. For all the above, we have voted against

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - Following the tragic events that have taken place in many European capitals, citizens are demanding that measures be taken at European level to end organized crime and terrorism. When a plane ticket is booked, passengers provide information kept by airlines for operational, commercial and statistical purposes. This data is the data known as PNR (Passenger Name Record). The aim of this report is to harmonize the obligation of airlines that make flights between the territory of a member state and a third country to transmit PNR data. One of the most relevant measures applied in this report is to include internal flights between EU member states, since they were not included in the scope of the text, a measure that will provide great advantages in terms of safety. In my opinion, the approval of this report is crucial as it defines the criteria by which law enforcement agencies can use this data in order to detect, investigate and prosecute both serious and criminal offenses. terrorism offenses.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data is a key instrument offered as a comprehensive and practical solution against terrorist activities and other criminal activities.Proper implementation of PNR will lead to greater security for the citizens of the Union and the preservation of the fundamental rights of individuals in the form of personal data protection.The implementation of the PNR Directive seeks to strike a balance between security and privacy for Union citizens.Without the application of this Directive, there would be no adequate safeguards and measures to record passenger protection.Using a standardized system at Union level achieves a "European solution", which is much better than 28 different solutions.The application of uniform rules fills the legal gaps that exist and allows for better coordination of information between Member States, so I supported this report.

name: Svetoslav Hristov MALINOV
text: In written form. - The proposal to regulate at European level the collection, sharing and analysis of air passenger reservation data has been on the negotiating table since 2011. My position has not changed since then. It has always been that the PNR (Passenger Name Record) directive is a necessary step in preventing and detecting serious crime and terrorism. Until recently, there was a parliamentary majority against the adoption of this directive. The opposition was provoked by serious concerns about the collection and storage of people's data. In response, the text we have adopted pays special attention to strict personal data protection measures. I welcome the adoption of this directive and I believe that it will increase the security of European citizens. This vote is a great victory for MEPs, who for more than seven years have not given up their demands for more efficient work and communication between the security services of the individual Member States. The directive should now be adopted swiftly in the Council as well, so that the Member States can begin the process of transposing it into national law as soon as possible.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- Transnational crime and terrorism are also becoming more sophisticated in the age of globalization.In order to prevent, detect and investigate this activity, it is necessary for law enforcement authorities to be able to use registered passenger data, but only in a way governed by law which does not constitute an unjustified and unjustified interference with their rights and which does not restrict the freedom of movement of persons.With the lawful use of the PNR system, this system can be an appropriate and effective means of preventing the detection and detection of transnational crime.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing.- The proposal for a directive on the European PNR has been on the negotiation table since 2011. It provides for the transfer and processing of air passenger data (travel date, itinerary, contact details, eating habits, etc.) for the purposes offight against terrorism and organized crime.This directive will strengthen the range of measures already available to the European Union to fight terrorism.It should thus help to identify new suspects hitherto unknown to the European authorities, and to reconstruct their movements more easily.This directive will therefore enable the EU to have an effective and operational tool, but also fair and proportionate, which ensures the right balance between the fight against terrorism and the protection of individual freedoms.I therefore vote in favor of this text.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I am voting against the second report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of data contained in passenger files (PNR data) for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist and other serious crimes, for reasonsI mentioned in detail in my speech at the Plenary Session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/4/2016, as well as because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.The European PNR aims to collect and store the personal data of passengers passing through European airspace.Liberticide, the device is above all ineffective: it would be better to target precise and specific surveillance on "S files" and other people monitored by the intelligence services.More seriously, the PNR even constitutes a threat to national sovereignty, since any authorized institution of a European state will have access to the data of passengers in transit through our territory.Note also that the United States will be able to have access to the PNR, while the converse is not true.The European PNR aims above all to save the Schengen area, by trying in vain to demonstrate its usefulness.But the PNR is all the more questionable as France already has its own system, since the law of January 23, 2006.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing.- Finally, after months and months of postponement, Parliament has finally approved the PNR directive.I am convinced that it will be a useful tool to assess any threats deriving from the so-called foreign fighters.In a moment of emergency we must give concrete answers to our citizens to guarantee their safety.

name: Emmanuel MAUREL
text: in writing. - Via the Kirkhope report, the proposal for a directive establishing a European PNR (Passenger Name Record) was adopted by the European Parliament. Accompanied by two texts intended to protect the personal data of European citizens, the PNR file will constitute an additional tool in the fight against terrorism. The principle is simple: air carriers will collect passenger data in the European PNR file, which the "passenger information units" of the Member States will be responsible for analyzing. These same units will have to implement solid guarantees in terms of respect for private life. That said, contrary to what many would have people believe, it is important to be honest about remembering that PNR is by no means a miracle cure. Moreover, the PNR alone would not have made it possible to thwart the attacks in Paris or Brussels. The real key lies in the treatment reserved for the data contained in the PNR file. In this regard, now that they have multiple instruments, European states have the responsibility to invest heavily in human and financial intelligence resources and, above all, to exchange information.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the PNR for the benefit of the security of European citizens, as it will be a very important tool in fighting crime and terrorism in the future.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - PNR (Passenger Name Record) data is the information provided by air passengers when booking their tickets, available to air carriers: travel dates, itinerary, contact details, means of payment, etc. The directive provides for the obligation for air carriers to transmit all PNR data to the bodies responsible for enforcing the law. Note that API (Advanced Passenger Information) data, which is biographical information extracted from the machine-readable part of a passport, is already transmitted to the authorities responsible for carrying out border checks and that many other European databases allow the identification and the interpellation of individuals: SIS II, ECRIS, SIE, VIS, ... Thus, this new directive only adds to the others, at a significant price (1 billion euros). 'euros) and without any assurance that it will prove to be more effective. On the contrary, the dizzying increase in the number of data to be processed only makes it more difficult to identify people presumed to be dangerous. In any case, terrorists do not fly, or else under a false name. In fact, this directive will only serve to monitor and further hamper the movement of citizens. I vote against this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The PNR is a measure that seems to us to be quite ineffective in the Schengen area.It is above all an invasion of privacy and allows global surveillance of citizens.I believe that if there is to be surveillance, it must be targeted to be legitimate and effective.Consequently, I voted against.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - PNR has been rejected by some left under the pretext of protecting personal data, which in many cases travel agencies already have, but which the left wants to transform into absolute rights. They are not. And collective security is a more relevant right. It would even be good for us to think what the victims would say if they could argue in this debate. I have already heard the extraordinary argument that, in the recent attacks, the terrorists were not from outside Europe. The terrorists born here also travel, they have to be controlled. When indoctrinated in Syria and elsewhere, terrorists here and abroad are one, in a criminal organization that has moral and material authors. They're all criminals. I would like to recall that in the September 11 attacks, 19 terrorists kidnapped the crews and passengers of 4 planes, murdered 3,000 people. Terrorists were not from here, they were from outside. The victims were from all over the world. I voted in favor, convinced that terrorism cannot be fought with fantasies or romantic proclamations.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ The use of passenger name record (PNR) data is an essential element of the fight against international terrorism. We cannot allow gaps that are present in our intelligence systems to continue to be exploited by terrorists and criminals. PNR addresses some of these gaps. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - It was a long battle, but it was worth it. The European PNR will not solve everything in the fight against terrorism, but it will definitely contribute to it. By giving access to the information provided by passengers to airlines, our authorities will not only be able to better monitor members of terrorist groups but, above all, they will be able to identify members of these groups not known to our services. Our only goal is to prevent further attacks. The PNR is a necessary instrument to help our intelligence and security services to collect and process information useful in the fight against terrorism and serious criminals. It is not, and we regret it, a European PNR, but 28 national PNRs whose interconnection remains to be organized. But we do not see why we should refuse to collect for ourselves information that we have been transmitting, still today and for years, to the United States, Canada and Australia.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - The security situation in Europe has been alarming for a long time, and the recent events surrounding the Brussels attacks have only reinforced the need to take the necessary steps in the legislative field as well. The new directive would entitle air carriers to provide so-called data from the personal records of travelers by the competent authority for the purposes of the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of criminal offenses and serious criminal offenses. The purpose of the new legislation is primarily to combat organized crime and terrorism, activities that have become increasingly complex, sophisticated and transnational in recent years. Data from personal records of passengers, t. j. data related to the normal booking of tickets and subsequently used by carriers for operational purposes could potentially contribute to the identification and tracing of criminal and terrorist activities in order to apprehend, monitor, investigate and prosecute the perpetrators of these crimes. The EU's response to the serious deterioration of the security situation on our territory is essential. We must avoid, as far as possible, the threat that events from Paris or Brussels will be repeated. We cannot allow our citizens to continue to live in fear of danger, because that is how terrorists win. I believe that disclosure of personal records is an effective tool for law enforcement authorities to be able to trace dangerous elements, which is why I am voting in favor of the report presented.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on the Passenger Name Record (PNR) Directive, which creates a legal framework for the use of data in the EU, which is an essential tool in the 21st century in order to fight against organised crime and terrorism.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I support the Commission’s Proposal on the Use of Passenger Name Record data (EU PNR). This complementing tool will enable law enforcement authorities to solve possible security gaps in a well-organised and competent manner. Moreover, it provides a harmonised legal base to fight against cross-border organised crime and terrorist offences. On the basis of solidarity and data protection clarification, the EU PNR was aligned with the Data Protection Package in the agenda and received a majority vote in Parliament.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The Commission has presented a proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crime.In its report, the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs proposes that Parliament adopt the proposal with 90 amendments.I voted accordingly.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - The objective of the European PNR is to collect the personal data of aircraft passengers entering or leaving the European area: identities, itineraries, travel agencies, means of payment, information on luggage and specificities related to meals and to health. Officially, this massive data collection should make it possible to fight terrorism and certain serious crimes. However, we are very hostile to the PNR for three reasons. First, it is liberticidal because it seriously undermines respect for the privacy of passengers by transmitting to States a great deal of private information which will be kept for five years. Second, it is ineffective and the perpetrators of the latest attacks could not have been detected with this tool. Rather than monitoring passengers, almost all of whom have nothing to reproach themselves with, better use should be made of the many information tools that already exist and which could be very effective. Thirdly, it is a nuisance to national sovereignty because its disguised objective is to save the Schengen area by creating an "air Schengen". We are radically opposed to this ineffective and liberticidal initiative.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing.- Today we voted to create the Passenger Name Record (PNR).After so many months of discussion and constant blockages, I am pleased that the proposal submitted by the EPP has finally been approved with the majority support from the European Parliament.Although PNR is not the solution to combat terrorism, it is a fundamental tool for increasing security in the European Union and preventing people from traveling to countries in order to enlist in terrorist organizations and later return to Europe without any kind of border control..This is a measure that aims to strengthen the Union's external borders, increasing our security and improving the exchange of information in the fight against terrorism.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- The European PNR is liberticidal because it seriously undermines respect for the privacy of passengers.It is also ineffective because it does not allow a real fight against terrorism.In addition, the European PNR undermines national sovereignty because it aims to save the Schengen area by creating a sort of air Schengen area.Finally, the European PNR is intended to be communicated to the United States, whereas in return the latter will not communicate their American PNR to the European Union.Obviously, such a collaboration cannot be accepted without reciprocity, which is more akin to subservience than to genuine international cooperation.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this directive as it will provide a useful tool to assist police and intelligence agencies in tracking down possible terrorists and criminals. If the data is used and shared effectively by law enforcement agencies it will assist in the fight against terror, but should not be presented as a silver bullet. The directive also contains a number of safeguards to ensure it complies with data protection rules and is proportional.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- After the terrible attacks that the European Union has known, in particular those in Paris in 2015 and in Brussels in 2016, and after long and difficult negotiations, hampered in particular by the elected socialists and ecologists, but also by the parliamentarians of the National Front, the European Parliament finally voted the Passenger name record.The PNR obliges air carriers to communicate data on their passengers, in particular their name, their address, their travel dates and routes, their identity document numbers to the European States concerned by a flight from or to aState which is not a member of the European Union.This tool is essential in the fight against terrorism.I therefore voted in favor of this report.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
