text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the Passenger Name Record.So much time wasted because of the blocking of this text by the left and the extreme right in the European Parliament.From the start, the French EPP delegation and the EPP group have wanted to move forward quickly on this essential file, we have been the driving force, it was our duty to the citizens.It is one more measure in our daily struggle against barbarism and terrorism.It is more than annoying to have waited for the worst to happen for the left to finally assume its responsibilities with regard to the protection of citizens.Today we have taken a big step towards the protection of Europeans, but the Member States must now transpose this text as quickly as possible into their national legislation in order for it to be truly effective.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - Given the recent and despicable attacks perpetuated on the borders of the European Union, we could only support the desire for greater sharing of data and information and closer cooperation at European level. The gravity of the terrorist phenomenon, the interconnectedness of the challenges connected to it and the common character of the threats and dangers to which the European people are subjected cannot, in fact, ignore common responses and measures. The vile attacks have, in fact, revealed the weakness of a security system based on fragmentation. However, we welcome the report only as a first step towards greater integration and sharing of information, in full compliance with the rights to privacy and data processing, more systematic and structured. Faced with the terrorist threat, in fact, there is no other possibility of a common front and struggle. In any case, we hope for a speedy adoption of the measure by the Member States and we invite national governments to make better and more effective use of legislative instruments, starting with the sharing of information on vehicle registration, already available

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- After waiting five years for certain political groups in the European Parliament to stop blocking the establishment of the passenger data register (PNR), we have finally succeeded in voting on the text which will make it possible to strengthen the security of European citizens.In the current context, strengthening security measures is essential, so the PNR will facilitate the task of intelligence agencies in identifying and assessing threats.However, PNR is not a silver bullet and we must be careful not to slacken our efforts.While its adoption puts us on the right track, intelligence cooperation between Member States remains essential, and EU action is no substitute for it.We are now counting on the Member States to put the PNR directive in place as quickly as possible and ensure as much security as possible on the territory of the European Union.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- I welcome the Passenger Name Record (PNR) report.We have succeeded in adopting a proposal that will enable the European Union to take more effective action against terrorism.The PNR will only make available to the authorities information that airlines have already had.The proposal is comprehensible and clear, and also ensures that fundamental freedoms will not be restricted in any way.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Passenger name records (PNR) consist of the information provided by passengers to air carriers during reservation and check-in procedures. Travel agencies and tour operators using charter flights will also collect and process PNR data from their passengers. I voted for this report that would oblige airline carriers to hand over their passengers’ data to EU countries in order to help the authorities to fight terrorism and serious crime.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up. - I abstained from voting in favor of this report because I was not satisfied with the final form of the text. Although I agree with the principle of the use of passenger register data by the authorities whose activity is the prevention, detection and prosecution of persons suspected of terrorism and serious crime, the fact that the amendment providing for the obligation of Member States to exchange such data rejected leaves this directive without the most important component. If the authorities of the Member States do not have this obligation, the recent cases in which terrorists have been targeted by other Member States will be repeated, but the information has not been made available to other states precisely because there was no legal obligation in this sense. In these circumstances, we risk having a directive regarding the processing and use of certain personal data, with a very unclear purpose, and with an extremely obvious risk of continuing to have terrorist networks among us.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing.- I supported the final compromise amendment to the Passenger Name Record Directive, as I consider it an important part of the mosaic of measures to help reduce the risk of serious crime, especially terrorism.Sharing the data that passengers already provide to airlines today will enable security forces to cooperate more effectively in detecting the movement of terrorist suspects.Passengers do not have to worry about their personal data.Long and complicated negotiations have led to the creation of reliable safeguards against their misuse.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: In written form. - I am voting in favor of a single register of air passenger reservation data (PNR), which aims to facilitate the tracing of suspected terrorists, drug traffickers and other criminals traveling to and within the Community. PNR data is information provided by air passengers when booking a ticket held by air carriers. They will provide the secret services with detailed passport and bank details of their passengers. The specialized agencies of all 28 Member States will have access to the national lists of each. The data will be kept for 5 years.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted against the proposal because PNR will prove to be an inefficient system of indiscriminate total surveillance of passengers.Terrorists will develop circumvention techniques in a very short time or simply use the open internal borders as transport routes.Overall, a clear setback for our civil liberties.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: in writing.- I voted against this report which aimed to adopt a proposal for a directive on the use of PNR data for the prevention and detection of terrorist offenses and serious forms of crime, also known as the "PNR" directive.This mechanism for the use of personal data, already in force in a number of Member States, has not proved to be effective in the fight against terrorism, and seriously undermines the protection of individuals.personal data and privacy of European citizens.This directive directly contradicts a recent judgment of the Court of Justice of the European Union which ruled on the massive collection of data targeting certain parts of the population, as is the case with the PNR.This new regulation is disproportionate and violates the European Charter of Fundamental Rights.

name: Maite PAGAZAURTUNDÚA
text: written.- None of the European citizens would understand that we voted against an instrument like the PNR.In these times we need it, because we need to help police and security work to achieve their objectives.This, of course, must be done wisely, fostering the trust of the Member States among themselves, and facilitating the exchange of information between the different national security and intelligence networks so that we can act better and in a more coordinated manner.Although we cannot forget that this is only one instrument that must be supplemented with others, which must have sufficient balance to respect sensitive data of our citizens.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.Common rules on passenger name records must be applied throughout the EU as an effective tool in the fight against terrorism and serious crime.It should be noted that the provisions of the new directive will ensure that air passenger data are transferred in advance to the competent authorities of the EU countries concerned, who will have to keep them for some time.When transferring passenger data, special attention must be paid to the implementation of security measures and to ensuring an adequate level of protection.In addition, the legal certainty of air carriers and the rights of individuals to the protection of personal data, as well as their physical security, must be ensured.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. - The new PNR dossier system, ie airline passenger records inside and outside the EU, is growing the network of repression of the EU and bourgeois governments against the people. Passenger data containing 19 categories of data will be retained and exchanged by the secret services of Member States and third countries for at least 5 years. Based on these, passengers will be categorized according to how many and which trips they make, their frequency, intermediate stations, days of stay, financial data, etc. The ground is also being prepared for the extension of the passenger dossier system to all modes of transport. The claim of the political representatives of the monopolies that the personal data of the passengers are immediately protected because after 30 days they will become "anonymous", while a person will be appointed "responsible for the protection of personal data" does not convince anyone. The aim of all these oppressive mechanisms is to restrict the popular freedoms and rights that monopolies, the EU and governments face as a threat to their power. That is why the popular struggle for their defense and enlargement is inextricably linked to the overthrow of the power of capital and the liberation from the shackles of its unions.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP are not principally opposed to the use of PNR data on a bilateral basis, UKIP have voted against this legislative report. Our main concerns lie with two key areas of this legislation. The first issue is that this legislation will permit Europol, an EU agency that UKIP neither recognise nor respect, to access this data and thus provides an extension of their judicial powers. The second issue for UKIP lies with the length of time that the data will be held; we believe that this length of data retention is far too long and leaves many law-abiding citizens’ data at risk from cyber-attacks. We believe that this risk is significantly higher in certain Member States that do not have appropriate standards for data protection and security. In this respect, UKIP have therefore voted for amendments which significantly reduce the length of period for data retention.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- Considering that, already in 2007, the Commission adopted a proposal for a Council framework decision on the use of Passenger Name Record data and that this proposal is now obsolete;considering that the use of such information would be aimed at intercepting, monitoring and prosecuting criminals;considering that in recent years there has been an increase in criminal and terrorist activities and that the use of passenger booking codes would allow for more effective monitoring of people, without thereby entering into conflict with the rules on the protection of personal data;finally considering that a decentralized operating system would imply a lower burden for the States than a centralized mechanism, I would like to vote in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The threat of terrorist attacks in the EU is at its highest level in 10 years. Following the recent terrorist attacks in Brussels and Paris, counter-terrorism has become of highest priority in the EU, stressing the urgent need for much stronger cooperation, exchange of information and a coordinated response. Although this directive is not the solution to all our problems with terrorism, it is an important step forward. It is a useful and necessary tool in the fight against terrorism and serious crime and, therefore, I voted in favour of the new directive regulating the use of passenger name record data in the EU.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing.- I welcome the adoption of the PNR package and the use of private data.I am glad that we have finally adopted the legislative package, albeit in a less ambitious form than our political group wanted from the beginning.There was far too much waiting and political calculation by certain political groups on this important topic, which highlighted aspects of privacy restrictions.They have blocked progress in the area of data exchange, which is crucial for maintaining the security of our citizens.We will now be able to finally enter the phase of interinstitutional negotiations and implementation.We need to respond to current security challenges with legislation that ensures the safety of our citizens.For more security, I’m willing to risk some privacy as well.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support this proposal to amend the Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of Passenger Name Record data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crime. The primary objective of this amendment is to guarantee security, protect life and increase public safety, and to create a legal framework for the protection and exchange of passenger data between Member States and law enforcement authorities, as well as between Member States and third countries if necessary and legally correct. and all for the purpose of raising the level of security of our citizens. I believe that the establishment of a data record system is necessary for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of perpetrators of terrorism and serious transnational crime. Although PNR data are key to increasing internal security in the Union, we have a duty to protect personal data and the dignity of people, so it is important to emphasize that these changes do not in any way jeopardize the right to privacy of our citizens. The collection and proper use of passenger name record data is part of a common European security strategy, and these changes are another step towards a safer Europe.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - I supported the PNR directive because I consider it a fundamental tool for monitoring our security, as I believe it is necessary to have a common and single European standard on this issue and not 28 fragmented regulations which of course would guarantee us much less effectively. On the other hand, we must not think that this legislation alone will enable us to defeat terrorism in Europe. A broader and more complex action of coordination of intelligence, police and investment in education can truly eliminate terror from our streets. Only real joint and joint action by each Member State can protect us from attacks such as those that hit Paris and Brussels. As repeatedly reiterated, our group strongly wanted the PNR directive to be approved at the same time as the data protection package, precisely because it is clear that our need for greater security does not imply a decrease in our right to privacy, although some freedoms such as we have known until now will inevitably have to change. I believe that with this vote we have taken a decisive step forward in the fight against terrorism, but we must not forget that it is only a small piece and that many other concrete actions will have to follow.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - Under the provisions of this Directive, Member States will have to set up a "Passenger Information Unit" (PIU) to manage PNR data collected from airlines. The data would be retained for a period of five years: in its original form for the first six months and then “hidden”, meaning that certain data from which the respondent could be directly identified would be hidden, such as name, address and contact details. The Directive states that these data transfers should be carried out only on a case-by-case basis and exclusively for the specific purposes of "the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses or serious criminal offenses". The directive will apply to all flights from third countries in the EU and vice versa, but also to flights within the EU. If a Member State decides to apply this Directive to intra-EU flights, it must notify the Commission in writing. EU Member States may choose to collect and process PNR data from travel agents and tour operators providing travel-related services, including flight reservations for which they collect and process PNR data. I believe that the reason for the adoption of this legislative package is proportionate to the risks we face, and I expect full respect for human rights in its implementation.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - Taking advantage of the legitimate feeling of insecurity motivated by the recent attacks on European soil - exacerbated both by the media and by the political forces of the social - democracy to the extreme right -, the right and social democracy have approved the proposal in plenary PNR, passenger identification record, previously rejected. Instigated by recent events, the defenders of this system advocate with the usual rhetoric, and under the pretext of "combating terrorism", the rapid implementation of the system as a way to prevent and prevent "terrorist attacks". It is yet to be proved that any of these visas would have been avoided if the system were in place. The proposal provides for the creation of passenger profiles, which make it possible to identify potential suspects of possible unlawful acts, by imposing the provision of data from airlines to Member States, for a period of 5 years, without guarantee of their safeguard. In practice, any and all citizens, European or foreign, traveling within the EU, are considered to be a suspect at the outset, which justifies the collection and maintenance of data, which will allow, far beyond the fight against terrorism, to identify and create profiles , in addition to crime, trade unionists, political activists, among others, serving the security posture and curbing freedoms and rights. We voted against.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - The unprecedented increase in terrorist attacks in Europe has opened up a long-running debate on so-called passenger name records. The new directive should ensure that data can only be processed for the purposes of the prevention, detection, investigation or prosecution of terrorism and other serious criminal offenses. In order to prevent possible misuse of personal data, all data will be stored in the first phase for half a year and then encrypted in anonymous form for another four and a half years, and very strict rules will be set for access to them. A clear system for the exchange of data between Member States will also be put in place, and in particular strong guarantees for the protection of personal data. Concerns about the lack of protection and misuse of passengers' personal data were the reasons why this directive has been blocked by Parliament for the last few years. We have now succeeded in making the vote common to that of the data protection package. I believe that this directive is an important step towards better protection for all EU citizens and that strict security will not lead to the leakage of sensitive data. It is the single system that the European Parliament is pushing for that should guarantee that there will not be 28 different records that cannot communicate with each other, are incompatible and, as a result, will not be effective in ensuring security.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The Commission's proposal has two main objectives: i) to harmonize the obligation of air carriers flying between a third country and the territory of at least one Member State to transmit PNR data to law enforcement authorities and ii) to identify the criteria in on the basis of which law enforcement authorities can use this information, in particular to prevent, detect, investigate and prosecute terrorist offenses and serious crime. The proposed system is mandatory and each Member State will have two years to set up an operating system. This is a great step forward in the fight against international terrorism and finally, overcoming the obstructionism previously expressed by the European Socialists and Democrats, the European Parliament has managed to approve this important piece of legislation. The measures taken regarding the transmission and use of PNR data do not hinder the freedom of movement and do not compromise the right of entry of citizens or their privacy, but help to protect their security. I strongly voted in favor of this resolution, aware of the fact that the EU still has a lot to do to be able to defeat all its internal and external enemies.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- Voting in favor of the European directive on the use of passenger name records (PNR) was obvious.This new instrument, the adoption of which has been blocked for so many years by the left and the far right, will be part of the arsenal of devices that Europe needs in the fight against terrorism.Airlines will now have the obligation to provide national authorities with passenger data for all flights from a third country to the territory of the European Union, and vice versa.It is now up to EU Member States to apply the European PNR as soon as possible.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst UKIP are not principally opposed to the use of PNR data on a bilateral basis, UKIP have voted against this legislative report. Our main concerns lie with two key areas of this legislation. The first issue is that this legislation will permit Europol, an EU agency that UKIP neither recognise nor respect, to access this data and thus provides an extension of their judicial powers. The second issue for UKIP lies with the length of time that the data will be held; we believe that this length of data retention is far too long and leaves many law-abiding citizens’ data at risk from cyber-attacks. We believe that this risk is significantly higher in certain Member States that do not have appropriate standards for data protection and security. In this respect, UKIP have therefore voted for amendments which significantly reduce the length of period for data retention.

name: Christine REVAULT D'ALLONNES BONNEFOY
text: in writing. - The European PNR strengthens the Union's toolbox in the fight against terrorism. I am in favor of this new instrument, which will help to identify people suspected of having links with terrorist groups and to more easily follow their movements. Thanks to the European Socialists, strong guarantees have been obtained in terms of the protection of personal data and respect for fundamental rights. It was for us an essential condition to make this tool fair and proportionate. We had also always insisted that the PNR be voted in conjunction with the data protection package. It is done today, and we welcome it. It will also be necessary to ensure close monitoring of the implementation of the NRP, both in terms of the results obtained and in relation to the requirement to respect individual freedoms. The ball is now in the court of the Member States, which must transpose this directive as soon as possible. The NRP can only be fully effective if they agree to work together and strengthen the quality of their cooperation. Finally, it is only one element of the Union's strategy against terrorism, which must be understood in a comprehensive and common way.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - The nature of criminal and terrorist activity has constantly evolved in recent years - it has become more daring and more sophisticated, showing an increasingly transnational nature. In view of the widespread cost of crime, the data show that citizens increasingly want to see stronger action at EU level to combat organized crime and terrorism. Therefore, I welcome the favorable vote in this report, which has two essential objectives: to harmonize the obligation applicable to air carriers operating flights between a third country and the territory of at least one Member State, concerning the transmission of data from identification of passengers to law enforcement agencies and to define the criteria according to which those bodies can use the information, namely for the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offenses and serious crime. The proposed system is mandatory, giving each Member State two years to create an operating system. However, Member States are allowed to use joint systems for the purpose of cost sharing.

name: Frédérique RIES
text: in writing. - I am one of the 461 MEPs who said yes to the European PNR on the collection, exchange and analysis of air passenger record data. The time to adopt this important tool in the fight against terrorists and traffickers had come. Need I remind you that the European Parliament had undertaken to finalize the agreement for 2015. It is the respect of the given word and the concern not to endanger this Council / EP agreement that led me to vote against amendment 54. Citizens expect a clear and firm response against terrorism. The PNR is a necessary instrument to help our intelligence and security services to collect and process information useful in the fight against terrorism and serious criminals. Moreover, such a system of access to information provided by passengers to airlines has existed for years between the European Union and the United States, Canada and Australia. Another step forward is that Member States will be able to go further and extend the PNR to "intra-EU flights" such as collecting and processing PNR data from travel agencies and tour operators. A responsible choice that must gain ground in the Member States, especially in Belgium!

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: in writing. - After many debates, Parliament finally adopted the PNR (Passenger Name Record) directive, which recent events have made all the more necessary. Indeed, this directive is central to strengthening passenger safety, particularly in the prevention and detection of terrorist attacks or serious forms of crime, thus ensuring a more secure common space. While we can welcome the positive signal from this vote, I deplore the play of the Member States on this file, which have considerably reduced the European scope and coordination of the PNR. Three shortcomings in particular: first, rather than a single European file being created as Parliament wanted, bringing together the data of all passengers, the Member States opted on the contrary for 28 national files, 28 PNR "in silos" ; second, the exchange of data and information is not automatic but at the discretion of States; thirdly, the legislative scope of the text leaves the door open to possible divergences in application, since it is a directive and not a regulation. Despite these shortcomings, this report remains a step forward for security in Europe and will hopefully serve as a start for further European integration on the subject in the future. For these reasons, I voted in favor of this directive.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- Passenger identification (PNR) data aggregates information provided by passengers and collected by air carriers during ticket booking (name, address, telephone, credit card number, luggage, itinerary).They cover travel from Member States to third countries and vice versa.The aim is to fight serious crime and terrorism.In an ideal world, this would be an unnecessary measure.Unfortunately, this is not an ideal world.It should be noted that during the negotiations with the Council, additional data protection safeguards have been added.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as we Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that will turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - I voted today in favor of the Passenger Name Record (PNR). Terrorism is complex. It does not have a single cause, and therefore does not call for an unequivocal response. The fight against terrorism requires the establishment of an arsenal of measures, of which the PNR is a part. This system which allows the European collection of information is not an end in itself, but it is wrong to consider that it violates individual freedoms in the name of alleged security. It is an indispensable additional tool for the anticipation of terrorist acts. For me, the key words are, in fact, anticipation and prevention, which requires strengthening intelligence resources, as well as capacities for processing and exchanging information. We need to go further by strengthening Europol, but also by laying the basis for a real European FBI. Finally, I am convinced that it is also important to work on the dialogue between philosophies, religions, education and culture. It is no wonder that totalitarians of all kinds start by burning the books.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: in writing. - I supported the adoption of this directive on passenger data. On the table since 2011, this directive should make it possible to collect, process and exchange air passenger data for the purposes of combating terrorism and organized crime. After long negotiations, the Socialists and Democrats managed to modify the text so that this tool is effective but proportionate. We have obtained strong guarantees in terms of personal data protection and respect for fundamental rights. Indeed, the rules of the European PNR will have to be aligned with the rules of the European package on data protection. From now on, the results of the processing of relevant PNR data can be shared between Member States in order to guarantee greater security for European citizens in the face of the serious terrorist risk we know today. This measure is therefore welcome, but it will not be sufficient and the Union will have to equip itself with a more complete arsenal to fight this threat.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - I was in favor of the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of passenger identification record data for the purpose of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offenses and serious crime. This is a directive, which will have to be transposed into the legal order of Member States within two years and which will require air carriers to transmit to Member States the data of travelers arriving or departing from the EU, with the aim of to help prevent and combat terrorism. The collective security of all of us must take precedence over the protection of personal data and I believe that this is an appropriate means to prevent, detect, investigate and suppress potential terrorist threats or serious crime, such as human trafficking, participation in a criminal organization, child pornography and arms trafficking. The legislative proposal was also concerned with improving aspects related to the guarantee of confidentiality and anonymity of passenger data, as well as the period of retention of personal data (5 years).

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - After five years of waiting, the European Parliament has finally adopted the directive on the use of passenger name data, the European PNR directive. In the legal arsenal which our democracies must have in order to fight terrorism, the PNR has its place. This instrument will make it possible to create a European register of air passenger data. Concretely, when a citizen buys plane tickets, he provides a set of personal data, namely: name, first name, date of birth, address, etc. The PNR will thus be a database bringing together the data of millions of citizens. The competent authorities of the European States will then be able to analyze this database and use it to identify potentially dangerous individuals and to detect their movements. It should also be noted that these data may only be used for the prevention, detection, examination and prosecution of investigations linked to the fight against terrorism or to serious transnational crimes. No one can reasonably claim that the PNR will eliminate the terrorist threat on its own, but its rapid implementation will make a concrete contribution to this.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - The extraordinary situation we are experiencing in Europe, symbolized by the attacks in Paris and Brussels, required Europe to raise its security standards to protect the freedom and life of all its citizens. That is why I voted in favor of a proposal that the EPP has long fought for, namely the establishment of the European Passenger Name Record (PNR) system for air carriers. It is not about collecting additional data. The collection of passenger data (in particular of air carriers) will have the sole purpose of finally making available the information already collected by the airlines, to help prevent serious crimes. Each EU Member State will therefore be called upon to make effective the sharing at European level of valuable information for the security forces, particularly in the fight against terrorism. In the spirit of a civilization founded on the right of the person, the directive explicitly includes, in addition to the reference to the right to the protection of personal data (privacy), also the reference to the international conventions signed by member states, including the Convention on Human Rights , to prevent any ideological abuse in the use of these data.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - We voted against this despite the fact that this PNR in the EU was initially raised by the Commission as a way to fight terrorism and transnational crime. Finally, the speaker's text shows that the intention goes further. The text originally intended to harmonize the data collection obligations of airlines and operators operating from third countries. The Report, also in this case, has gone beyond the Commission's proposal, asking to extend the registration of passenger data to travelers between EU countries. The text determines the criteria on the basis of which these authorities can use such data, defined in a vague and broad way. The massive compilation of data that is proposed is disproportionate and unnecessary, ignoring the recommendations of the CJEU on proportionality in data collection. For all this series of vagueness, vagueness and attempts to present as a fight against terrorism a massive and indiscriminate collection of passenger data that exceeds proportionality and that it is not known for what purpose they will finally be used, that is why we have decided to vote in against.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I voted in favor of the use of Passenger Name Records because it will better protect people in Europe from crime and terrorism.PNR will also help us solve crimes faster.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - Since it began to try to impose a Passenger Name Register (PNR) in the European Union, we have been against the few existing guarantees in terms of data protection and it represents a new increase in the capacity of the security forces of act in an opaque way and without guarantees of legality, using the fight against terrorism as an excuse. After the trilogue process, we have not seen a reduction in the scope of the regulation, but quite the opposite, also registering intra-European flights, and without setting a clear limit to the nature of the data that will be stored, so the police will be able to collect and storing information that does not have to be relevant to counterterrorism intelligence. Finally, the possibility of transferring this data to a third party, even outside the European Union, is maintained, which is frankly worrying and deepens the policy of mass surveillance of the population, particularly social activists, by our governments or from third countries with the complicity of our governments. For all the above, we have voted against

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the compromise reached on the PNR Directive on Passenger Name Record data which aims to uniformly regulate the processing and sharing of such data by Member States in the context of the fight against terrorism and serious crime. Thanks to this directive, airlines will be obliged to transfer PNR data, such as names, travel dates, itineraries and method of payment of passengers on non-EU flights, to the Member State where the flight is scheduled to land or take off. flight. In addition, each Member State will have to set up a Passenger Information Unit to identify individuals to be subjected to further verification by the competent authorities. I believe that this proposal represents a concrete step forward and a useful tool in the fight against terrorism and international crime, especially considering the recent events in Paris and Brussels, where the so-called "foreign fighters" or foreign fighters hit. I hope that with the PNR directive we will be able to identify not only people who are already suspicious, but also those who are not yet known to the authorities.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing. ‒ The passenger names register file has slowly moved through Parliament to today’s historic vote. This third part of the data protection package allows data that our airlines currently have to be shared with law enforcement agencies. So that when we take off, our name, ticket number, travel details are sent to the central anti-terrorism agencies. It is hoped that this will prevent potential terrorists from boarding a plane, or travelling undetected. In the light of the recent tragic attacks across our continent, maybe this measure will allow smart data to work for us, so that peace can conquer. Therefore I voted for.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I did not support this report, but this explanation of the vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia, which does not reflect the actual quality

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The Directive governing the use of airline passenger name record (PNR) data is an integral part of the toolkit in the fight against terrorist crime. Recent dramatic events have shown that there are serious gaps in European security. Although several shortcomings can be found in the current proposal, the basic objectives of the measure are covered, which is why I supported this form of legislative text. This tool concerns data provided by passengers, collected by air carriers and used for the issuance of air tickets and reservations. As this information is of a commercial nature and contains a lot of sensitive personal data, these records require maximum protection. On the one hand, it is essential to continue the determination to take an effective approach to the fight against terrorism, but on the other, we need to protect fundamental rights and ensure that the privacy of EU citizens is respected. Authorities using these alerts must ensure that citizens' fundamental rights to privacy are not violated and that PNR data are used only for law enforcement and security purposes in cases of terrorist offenses and transnational crime. At the same time, the use of this data for in-depth data analysis and profiling must be prohibited in all circumstances. In these circumstances, the measure should also contribute to a better internal security of the Schengen area.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The EU Passenger Name Record (PNR) Directive, as agreed in the trialogues, would oblige airlines to provide EU Member States with their passenger data in order to assist the authorities in the fight against terrorism and serious crime. This would require the systematic collection, use and storage of PNR data on air passengers, including for intra-EU flights. PNR data would thus be kept in a hidden form for 5 years. Following the recent terrorist attacks, this directive is in the legislative process and has dangerous provisions regarding the mass surveillance of all passengers in the EU. I agree to introduce targeted control measures in the context of the effective exchange of information between Member States, but I think this can be achieved by allocating the funds proposed for this directive to more targeted and effective measures for the activities of local police, joint investigation teams or greater coordination with Europol. This directive will provide profiling at airports, which could lead to stigmatization of citizens on the basis of name, origin or religion. I am against the current text of the directive because it is not necessary and the proposed system is not proportionate, I also have concerns about data retention and the inclusion of intra-EU flights within the scope of the directive. That is why I voted against the text.

name: Renato SORU
text: in writing. - Striking the best possible balance between ensuring security and protecting the privacy of European citizens has been the concern of the European Parliament in the long legislative process of approving the Directive on the use of Passenger Name Records (PNR), the system of exchange of information between the investigating authorities of the member states on airline passengers on international flights. That is why we have asked, as a social democratic group, for the simultaneous approval of the data protection package and the PNR directive, in order to create an adequate regulatory framework for data processing and the fight against transnational crime and terrorism. The PNR directive provides for the possibility for law enforcement agencies to have clear access for 6 months to all personal data of passengers on international flights for the purpose of prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution for serious crimes such as terrorism; beyond six months, these data will still be available for 5 years but through a more complex procedure and only for some specific crimes. Passenger information communicated by airlines to Member States will be handled by appropriate national authorities in compliance with specific criteria, conditions and rights for citizens.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - After the attacks in Brussels, it turned out that the intelligence services failed because they did not exchange information. To set up a separate database of flight data for each country in response to this is completely absurd. Storing all flight data in Europe for years is a very expensive bogus solution in the fight against crime and terrorism. We would much rather put the millions for such a PNR system into something that actually delivers, such as better European cooperation between police and judicial services. Despite the fact that the Civil Liberties Committee of the European Parliament already trashed the proposal to store all data on European air passengers in 2013, the proposal resurfaced after the Paris attacks. And this while the effectiveness of the system cannot be proven and it is a major invasion of the privacy of all Europeans. The 28 separate national systems would cost an estimated five hundred million euros. 28 separate national databases will actually ensure that more 'loose ends' arise and that will take more manpower away from traditional investigative work. And that is exactly what is lacking in the fight against terrorism, as has been shown time and again. So I voted against.

name: Sergei STANISHEV
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the PNR Directive because European Socialists have always seen PNR as an important tool to fight organised crime and terrorism but have criticised compliance with fundamental freedoms and personal data protection. Now our voice has finally been heard and the data protection package was coupled with the PNR one to ensure an adequate balance. PNR alone will not solve all of our security problems. However, it is a positive first step towards enhanced investigative and intelligence cooperation between European Member States and information sharing under the existing rules. Europe’s response to the security challenges we face does not end with PNR. Strengthening Europe’s external borders, for example, is essential in order to maintain the Schengen Area. But, ultimately, it is imperative that we strengthen our collective ability to prevent further terrorist attacks and provide the security and protection which our citizens legitimately expect from us. However, more surveillance alone will not solve our problems. European Socialists and Democrats are clearly saying ‘NO’ to massive surveillance of EU citizens. We support targeted, risk-based use of passenger data but at the same time we are determined to ensure adequate data protection.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The attacks in Paris and Brussels were also the result of a failure of cooperation between European secret services.The register of passenger names is the first step towards better control over who comes to the territory of the European Union.The new measure obliges airlines to provide EU countries with passenger data between the EU and third countries.The register will focus on people with a European passport, as most perpetrators of terrorist acts come from their ranks.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - The PNR Directive obliges air carriers to send passenger data by aircraft to the authorities of the Member State from which the passenger departs or arrives. I have clearly supported the draft directive, as it is a very important tool in the fight against terrorism, which can help to identify early those who are linked to the so-called Islamic State before committing terrorist attacks similar to those in Paris and Brussels. The PNR Directive is not self-saving, but in combination with intensified cooperation between the secret services and the police forces of the Member States, it may reverse the often cumbersome efforts to break up terrorist cells in the EU Member States. I believe that the final form of the directive strikes a delicate balance between strengthening security and protecting personal data. Terrorism is a growing threat, so we have no choice but to fight it by all available means, including those that entail the necessary restrictions on privacy rights. However, the idea of ​​whether terrorists do not actually win over us creeps into my consciousness.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - PNR data assist law enforcement authorities in the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of serious crimes, including terrorism, as these data can be compared with various databases of wanted persons and objects in order to collect evidence and, according to if necessary, find the accomplices of the perpetrators of the crimes and expose the criminal networks. For their commercial needs, airlines and non-air operators from their passengers already collect and process PNR data. Member States shall, in accordance with their national law, ensure the imposition of dissuasive, effective and proportionate penalties, including fines for air carriers and non-air operators that do not transmit the data required by this Directive to the extent that they have already collected or failed to collect them. transmitted in an appropriate format if they do not process them in accordance with the data protection rules laid down in this Directive. Member States may also continue to apply bilateral or multilateral agreements or mutual arrangements on the exchange of information between competent authorities if those agreements or arrangements are compatible with this Directive. PNR data can be a useful tool for the effective prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorism and serious crime, thus increasing internal security.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - In December last year, Parliament and the Council agreed on a directive on Passenger Name Record data requiring more systematic collection, use and retention of personal passenger data in air transport, including travel dates, itinerary, contact information and payment information. Such an information system can greatly assist in investigations, prosecutions, crime prevention, arrests, assessments of travelers, and determining the purpose of their travels. The PNR Directive contributes to the fight against organized crime and terrorism and to the creation and maintenance of international security, but it is crucial to ensure a balance between access to passenger data and the right of European citizens to privacy. I support this report on the use of passenger data for the purpose of the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crime. I believe that it is necessary to create a legal framework for the protection and exchange of Passenger Name Record data between law enforcement authorities and the Member States, which will contribute to the safety and security of life of all European citizens.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I supported the proposal.However, in order to effectively reduce the risk of terrorist attacks, it is also necessary to keep a thorough record of people who come to the European Union by other modes of transport.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the directive on the use of Passenger Name Record data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crime.I regret that we have not reached a consensus with other political groups in the past, as PNR is an important tool in the fight against terrorism.Despite the fact that the fight against terrorism is primarily the responsibility of the Member States, I am in favor of a common approach at European Union level.We need to strengthen the security of our citizens and uphold the fundamental values of freedom, democracy and human rights, and we need swift, decisive and effective action.In doing so, of course, we must respect international law and handle personal data with extreme care and sensitivity.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing. - I voted today in favor of the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of Passenger Name Record data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and serious crime, given the current need for this tool at Union level. This involves the introduction of PNR at Union level for flights to and from third countries. This is not a miraculous solution to all problems, but one of the measures that will help increase the security of EU citizens. Nominal data may only be used for the detection and investigation of terrorism and serious crime, and the handling and storage of such data are subject to strict rules on the handling of personal data. All data that can be used to identify individuals will be disabled after 6 months. These are similar measures as in the case of other similar databases.

name: Kay SWINBURNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive, which puts in place important rules on the use of passenger data and will help authorities to fight terrorism, human trafficking and catch serious criminals by collecting airline travel data.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing. Non-carriers and non-carriers are already collecting and processing PNR data, so the directive does not introduce anything innovative, in the sense that criminals and terrorists are not accustomed to using carriers for their travels. Above all, however, the obligation to apply a personal data collection system to cross-border road and / or maritime transport is not considered, as it would mean the automatic abolition of the Schengen acquis, nor does it make data exchange between Member States mandatory when there is tangible evidence of Member States. of transnational crime. In addition, it is oxymoronic to stipulate that the results of PNR data processing will not be able to be used for non-granting asylum to potential or system-recognized criminals or terrorists. The directive leaves gaps in the Union citizens' right to privacy and is not in line with the data retention directive. Finally, within the meaning of the sovereign state, each Member State should be able to exclude those minor offenses for which, taking into account its respective criminal justice system, the processing of PNR data would not be in accordance with fundamental principle of the TFEU, proportionality.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing.- I did not support the adoption of the motion for a resolution because, in its current form, I consider the guarantees provided regarding the use and protection of PNR data to be insufficient.It cannot be ignored that today there are governments and authorities in Europe that may be ready to use PNR data for other purposes in a given political situation.In my opinion, mass surveillance and the processing of personal data may be suitable for strengthening the feeling of fear and vulnerability among the population, while not substantially promoting the success of the fight against terrorism.However, the proposal does not contain any substantive proposals, such as a mandatory exchange of information between Member States' authorities, to make the fight against terrorism more effective.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - We cannot allow terrorism to rule the world. The Air Passenger Data Management (PNR) Directive is a very important instrument to strengthen the security of Europeans. Thanks to the analysis of the collected data, the anti-terrorist services will be able to identify and counteract suspicious patterns of behavior. The proposed legislation is not a panacea, but an extremely important tool in the fight against terrorism and organized crime. However, it should be remembered that there must be a balance between the genuine need to fight terrorism and the rights of citizens to privacy and functioning in a modern society. Citizens of democratic societies cannot be forced to relinquish their civil rights, human rights that have been pursued for centuries. There is a risk that legal solutions adopted due to the threat of terrorism may limit civil liberties. Therefore, in this regard, it is extremely important to be careful. The standards of personal data protection proposed in the directive are at a very high level. Mass data collection is not envisaged, but only allowing law enforcement agencies to access selected information. The Directive clearly states that data may only be collected, stored and processed for the purposes of preventing and detecting serious crime and terrorist acts

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This directive states that airlines must submit passenger name record (PNR) data in the form of passenger names, ticket numbers or payment methods for passengers leaving and entering the European Union, including European citizens. PNR data can help law enforcement authorities prevent, detect, investigate and prosecute serious transnational crime, by comparing them with various databases of persons and objects sought, to find the necessary evidence of criminal networks. This directive will help combat human trafficking and child trafficking, drug trafficking, paedophiles and murderers. Furthermore, it will represent an important tool in combating and preventing terrorism, as it will put in place a coherent and harmonised framework for PNR exchange between Member States. In light of the recent Brussels and Paris attacks, I believe that such information is crucial in order to protect the security of European citizens. In conclusion, I supported this directive.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - First of all, the 28 Member States have been far too timid in the exchange of data. The PNR will therefore only be effective if Member States exchange the crucial information that will emerge from the national PNRs. This is a big challenge when we know, for example, how reluctant states are to feed Europol's databases on terrorism and foreign fighters returning to their countries of origin. Finally, if the PNR is proving to be of some effectiveness for the aviation sector, it is still necessary that the terrorists use it, which was generally not the case in the last and tragic events. For these reasons, the 28 must step up their efforts to make the PNR and the exchange of information more effective in detecting suspected terrorists. In addition, when it comes to establishing a system that will collect a lot of personal data, we can only welcome the fact that this vote takes place at the same time as that on the texts relating to the protection of personal data in order to guarantee respect for freedoms. fundamental. At all times, care must be taken to maintain a balance between the security of citizens and the preservation of their fundamental rights.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Finally! After months and months of debates, I voted in favour of the setting up of a European PNR, which will regulate the transfer of PNR data from the airlines to national authorities as well as the processing of this data. If it is not a magic tool that will solve the security issues on our continent, I believe nevertheless that this will be an important instrument in the fight against terrorism and organised crime. At a time of a high security threat it will significantly help EU intelligence services to detect patterns of suspicious behaviour and follow up on these.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - The creation of a European PNR (recording of the names of passengers) will provide the Union with a new tool in the fight against terrorism. The European PNR should allow better identification of persons suspected of having relations with terrorist groups and better monitoring of their movements. This is not without danger for freedoms. Thus, the European Parliament and the Socialists demanded that this text on the PNR be voted at the same time as a legislative package on the protection of personal data. Thus, we guarantee a base of guarantees for the rights and freedoms of citizens in the context of new technologies by creating an obligation to erase information and limit the transfer of data, together with possible sanctions in the event of abuse. While allowing security forces to exchange information faster and more efficiently, we are equipping the European Union with the highest standards of privacy in the world. We are thus determining a new balance between freedom and demanding security, adapted to the world of the 21st century. But these provisions will have to be evaluated. Big Brother is on the lookout.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing.- Mr President, I supported the report because the LIBE Committee, of which I am a member, pointed out that the Stockholm Program called on the Commission to request the use of PNR data only for the prevention and detection of terrorism and serious crime.Let us remember that we are dealing with sensitive, confidential and highly personal data.PNR data is information provided by air passengers purchasing a ticket and held by airlines.It is good that the report makes it clear that the measures used must not impede the free movement of persons and should not infringe on citizens' right of departure, but must also serve solely to ensure the security of traveling citizens.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The purpose of this Directive is to guarantee security, protect the life and safety of the public and to create a legal framework for the protection and exchange of passenger name record data between Member States and law enforcement authorities.PNR data can assist law enforcement authorities in preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting serious transnational crimes, including terrorism crimes, as they can be compared with various databases of wanted persons and objects to find the necessary evidence and, according toif necessary, find accomplices of the perpetrators of the crimes and expose the criminal networks.The European Union is currently facing severe forms of organized crime and terrorism, so it is important to introduce the proposed system to prevent such acts.I note that special attention will be paid to compliance with personal data protection standards and that unauthorized persons will not be able to use data processing systems.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- If I were to vote, I would support the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of Passenger Name Record data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorist offenses and crime.They have become more daring and complex and have an increasingly international nature.The data show that, due to the huge cost of crime, more and more citizens want more decisive action at EU level against organized crime and terrorism.Therefore, under the Stockholm Program, the Commission was invited to make a proposal for the use of PNR data for the prevention, detection, investigation and prosecution of terrorism and serious crime.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ I could not support the report because the proposed PNR directive, even as amended by Parliament, does not guarantee a proper balance between human rights/freedoms and the public interest. The PNR directive will considerably affect data subjects’ privacy but in most cases this data cannot be efficiently used in the fight against serious crime and it will hardly enhance internal security.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - We voted against this despite the fact that this PNR in the EU was initially raised by the Commission as a way to fight terrorism and transnational crime. Finally, the speaker's text shows that the intention goes further. The text originally intended to harmonize the data collection obligations of airlines and operators operating from third countries. The Report, also in this case, has gone beyond the Commission's proposal, asking to extend the registration of passenger data to travelers between EU countries. The text determines the criteria on the basis of which these authorities can use such data, defined in a vague and broad way. The massive compilation of data that is proposed is disproportionate and unnecessary, ignoring the recommendations of the CJEU on proportionality in data collection. Due to all this series of vagueness, vagueness and attempts to present as a fight against terrorism a massive and indiscriminate collection of passenger data that exceeds proportionality and that it is not known for what purpose they will finally be used, that is why we have decided to vote in against.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ PNR data is unverified information provided by passengers, and collected by and held in the carriers’ reservation and departure control systems for their own commercial purposes. It contains several different types of information, such as travel dates, travel itinerary, contact details, the travel agent at which the flight was booked, means of payment used and baggage information.  I support the compromise achieved for this PNR report.  The recent attacks in Europe push us to act and stop delaying the implementation of PNR even further. Improved security is fundamental to safeguard democracy and freedom.  I support the binding obligation for Member States to share and exchange information and PNR processing.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- The European PNR aims to collect the personal data of all air passengers entering or leaving European space.They will be communicated to the European state concerned, which centralizes them and then transmits them to other partner states which request them, whether they are in the EU or outside the EU.This text is bad for three reasons: - the European PNR is liberticidal because it seriously undermines respect for the privacy of passengers;- the European PNR is ineffective because it does not allow a real fight against terrorism;- the European PNR undermines national sovereignty because it aims, as we have just explained, to save the Schengen area by creating a sort of air Schengen area.I strongly OPPOSED the adoption of the text.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - We voted against this despite the fact that this PNR in the EU was initially raised by the Commission as a way to fight terrorism and transnational crime. Finally, the speaker's text shows that the intention goes further. The text originally intended to harmonize the data collection obligations of airlines and operators operating from third countries. The Report, also in this case, has gone beyond the Commission's proposal, asking to extend the registration of passenger data to travelers between EU countries. The text determines the criteria on the basis of which these authorities can use such data, defined in a vague and broad way. The massive compilation of data that is proposed is disproportionate and unnecessary, ignoring the recommendations of the CJEU on proportionality in data collection. Due to all this series of vagueness, vagueness and attempts to present as a fight against terrorism a massive and indiscriminate collection of passenger data that exceeds proportionality and that it is not known for what purpose they will finally be used, that is why we have decided to vote in against.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report. The proposed system of collection of passenger name records is presented as the miracle solution to fight against terrorism. However, the EU PNR directive is far from being necessary and proportional, and the same concerns about data retention and mass surveillance that led the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) to reject the original proposal in 2013 are still present in the text.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- We undoubtedly spoke of a priority and a necessary matter on which we had to move forward in order to express our commitment to the fight against terrorism and to increase cooperation on these matters by the Member States.For all these reasons, I think it appropriate to vote in favor of this report.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - I have voted in favor of a directive to establish a European registry of the data of travelers who use the plane as a means of travel within the EU because, as we Spanish socialists have been defending, it is a useful instrument for the fight against terrorist threat that hits us. The personal data associated with the tickets can be useful when identifying risks. As of the approval of this instrument, the authorities will have at their disposal the agile exchange of information on suspicious persons. Faced with a common threat, which knows no borders, the EU must provide itself with a common framework to be able to exchange the information handled individually by the police and judicial authorities of each country and even by the national intelligence services of the 28 countries. To uncritically increase new instruments for the fight against terrorism, which have an impact on fundamental rights, but rather to improve the use made of existing instruments. For this reason, we Socialists call for a reinforcement of EUROPOL that will turn it into a sort of European FBI that is up to the challenge we face.

name: Inese VAIDERE
text: in writing. - People still remember the recent terrorist attacks in both Brussels and Paris, which killed innocent people. It is therefore clear that more needs to be done to protect citizens across Europe. The Passenger Name Record (PNR) is an important step in ensuring security. The register will contain information on people entering or leaving Europe, thus enabling the identification of persons previously suspected of involvement in terrorism or serious crime, as well as those who need to be further screened before being allowed to leave or enter the country. . The urgent need for a common PNR system in the EU is shown by the experience so far: EU countries exchange information inefficiently with each other, thus significantly slowing down the search for suspects. It is absurd that, before the terrorist attacks in Brussels, there were reports from foreign security services of suspicious people who had entered Europe, but the security services of the EU countries concerned were unable to use this information properly, resulting in loss of life. It is unfortunate that the left has been delaying the establishment of the PNR system for several years under the pretext of protecting personal data. In fact, it is clear that honest people have nothing to hide, and if planned terrorist attacks are detected through the PNR system, it will be to the benefit of common security. In addition, the system provides for the careful storage of data, making it available only to law enforcement authorities.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against the Report on EU PNR data, because I do not believe that the additional measures envisaged in the proposal for a new Commission directive would have a significant impact in the fight against terrorism, while they would certainly have a negative impact on citizens’ privacy. Furthermore, the strictly technical debate around the EU PNR report has been subject to excessive manipulation and politicisation. I remain of the opinion that the most successful way of fighting terrorism is to address its root causes.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I received many letters from my constituents on the issue of PNR. This directive hits at one of the key debates in recent years: the balance between the right to a private life and the right to ‘life, liberty and security of person.’ Both of these rights are very important, and I was mindful when considering my vote that we must be careful to ensure that we do not compromise the very society that we are fighting for when we look to improve our security. In the end however I felt that this measure was broadly sensible and proportionate to the threat that we face. That threat has been demonstrated both in the Paris attacks and the attacks in Brussels recently. We would be failing in our duty if, after that, we do not move to ensure the safety of the people of Europe.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- It is good that passenger data is exchanged and that is why I voted in favor of this proposal, but it is regrettable that it will be done with 28 databases instead of 1 European database and that data exchange is not mandatory.PNR is therefore not a panacea in the fight against terror.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The "Passenger Name Record Data" (PNR) directive will force airlines to provide national authorities with personal passenger data (identity, means of payment, complete itinerary, loyal passenger, baggage, code sharing, etc.) for all flights from a third country to the European Union and vice versa. A first text was rejected in committee in 2013. But after the attacks in Paris, the file was put back on the table under pressure from the French government on the grounds that the PNR would have made it possible to arrest the perpetrators of the attacks. It is false and untrue. The PNR only harmonizes national PNRs and therefore does not oblige States to share data. However, the perpetrators of the attacks traveled by train or car and were known to the police. The PNR could not have stopped them from acting. On the other hand, it is liberticidal, and with too long a data retention period, we will never be safe from misuse of this massive collection of data which is useless. Personalized targeting is necessary and human resources to analyze them, not to mention the essential police cooperation under judicial control. I therefore voted against.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- The criminal attacks in Paris, on January 7, first, November 13, 2015 afterwards, and from Brussels, on March 22, 2016, came to enliven the inflammatory rhetoric by implementing the PNR (Passengers Name Record) system.Instigated by the events, the defenders of this system strongly advocate, under the pretext of "combating terrorism", the rapid implementation of the system as a way to prevent and prevent "terrorist attacks" such as those in Paris and Brussels.The facts make it clear, however, that none of those criminal acts, from Paris or Brussels, would have been avoided if this system had already been implemented.Furthermore, to date, there are no studies that justify the hypothetical effectiveness of implementing the PNR system according to reality.What is certain is that the PNR is a system that violates citizens' rights, freedoms and guarantees.For these reasons, the vote against.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Both the Commission proposal and the legislative resolution must be rejected.PNR turns out to be a Big Brother system, which will be one thing above all: inefficient.Terrorists or even serious criminals will not go about their business by voluntarily disclosing their data (or their actual data) to the authorities.You simply march through the open borders without PNR or other data overhead.Since credit card numbers and sexual orientation are also required as data, the amount of data to be processed is simply utopian.In addition, a PNR central office is being promoted, which can act as an independent authority, whereby the member states no longer have anything to report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- Today I voted against the proposal to introduce the possibility for states to collect and exchange PNR data - a personal identification code - on a European basis.I voted "no" because I am convinced, also on the basis of recent experiences, that it is not the massive collection of data that prevents attacks and guarantees the safety of citizens.Instead, greater international cooperation, widespread intelligence work and prevention and inclusion work would be needed.In short, it takes politics.Today's vote was "emotional".A vote in the wake of the sad recent events in Brussels.I do not think, however, that we should legislate like this.As I have been able to say several times, the protection of citizens must not be at the expense of our personal and fundamental freedoms.This is why I decided to vote "no", also going against the opinion of my own group.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - I have rejected the European Parliament report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the use of Passenger Name Record for the purposes of preventing, detecting, investigating and prosecuting terrorist offenses and serious crime. I clearly reject the unjustified collection of passenger data. It is a clear violation of personal data protection. Passenger data contain all information that must be made available by the passenger. They can be used in an uncontrolled manner by state authorities, and in the case of airlines, for commercial purposes. In plain language, this means that information such as means of payment and contact details are also available to third parties. The argument that storage of all passenger name records without exception is helpful in the fight against terrorism sounds convincing at first, until you realize that terrorists nowadays avoid all forms of public transport. I am opposed to PNR and have rejected this report in plenary.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Passenger Name Record (PNR) data processing directive. The legislation will oblige airlines to transmit passenger data on transcontinental flights to the authorities of European countries, in order to facilitate the fight against terrorism. The inter-institutional process was very long and tiring. We have tried to reconcile the need to develop more stringent security measures with the need to protect the privacy of our fellow citizens. The Group of Socialists and Democrats played an important role in this, firmly affirming the principle that security without respect for the democratic principles of the rule of law is unacceptable. With this vote, we have dismissed a package that is certainly more balanced than the initial proposal. The attention of Socialists and Democrats on the subject, however, will remain very high. From now on, it will be necessary to better coordinate the security policies of the various member states to ensure the most effective response possible to the global challenges we are now facing.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the long-awaited directive on the use of Passenger Name Record (PNR) data for the prevention, detection and investigation of terrorist offenses and serious crime. I welcomed the fact that, after more than five years of work, the directive has finally reached the stage of voting in plenary, mainly because, in my opinion, it will be a very valuable tool in preventing terrorist attacks such as the recent Paris and Brussels attacks. I think it is high time to adopt these rules, because on their basis the Member States will be able to detect the so-called foreign fighters who had previously escaped attention, and as they were not among the suspects, Member States had limited opportunities to track them down. In my opinion, the proposal was drafted very well and I am very glad that it has not been able to be swept off the table at the last minute. I think that, thanks to clearly defined rules, it does not pose any risk of misuse of their personal data or any new obligations, but, on the contrary, a major step forward in protecting their security and combating terrorist acts.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - Terrorism and organized crime are two deadly phenomena for democratic and peaceful societies. In this unequal struggle, he is losing more and more and we must look for tools that will allow us to better detect and combat threats to the security of our citizens. PNR data is a source of information that allows services to find a threat and eliminate it before a tragedy occurs. I understand the concerns about protecting privacy and pushing the boundaries of state access to personal data, but when people are dying, we have to accept this compromise. The role of politicians is to ensure that these data are used properly and do not fall into the wrong hands.
