We are at war with an enemy who does not choose anything, who does not respect our freedoms and rights, and our lives. We must sacrifice some of our ideas and dreams for the effectiveness of our actions. Naturally, this boundary cannot be shifted indefinitely. Any formation and service that has access to PNR data must be subject to democratic control and operate within the law. I believe that we are able to provide such control. Obviously, the implementation of these provisions must not create any new obligations for airlines or passengers. Member States should make every effort to ensure that the transmission and exchange of these data do not constitute an excessive administrative burden. I voted in favor of these solutions as proposed.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Kirkhope report on the use of passenger identification record data, which requires air carriers to transmit to Member States the data of travelers arriving or departing from the EU to help prevent and combat terrorism, as it constitutes a compromise between the right to security and the right to privacy of citizens. These data consist of information provided by passengers and collected by air carriers when booking tickets, such as name, address, telephone number, credit card number, luggage, travel itinerary, (there are 19 categories of data listed in an Annex to the Directive). The new rules require air carriers to transfer passenger data on extra-EU flights (from a third country to an EU Member State or vice versa) from their reservation systems to a specialized unit in the Member State of arrival or starting, with a view to combating serious crime and terrorism.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the adoption of this act, which will allow the use of data from the register of air passenger data.I believe that after the adoption of the PNR, the lives of our citizens will be safer, as the security intelligence services will finally have access to comprehensive passenger data, which so far only airlines have had.Based on travel pattern algorithms, in conjunction with passenger credit card usage data, addresses and criminal files, and so on, security authorities will integrate this information into a consistent analysis of the situation and be able to accept a security risk assessment.This will prevent many planned terrorist attacks.In addition, the new approach will bring to the radar individuals who have not yet been linked to more serious forms of crime or terrorism, but are still part of it.

name: Marisa MATIAS
text: - Madam President, I think it is a shame that, eleven days after the Panama scandal, the Panama papers, this House has passed a directive that makes life easier for multinationals and life for alerters and journalists much more difficult. and citizens. It is that this directive not only protects the specific interests of multinationals more, but it completely alters the burden of proof, placing that burden on the side of journalists and alert launchers. Access to information is also becoming more difficult. So, after Lux Leaks, Swiss Leaks, Panama Papers, we may, probably, never have to watch any of these scandals again, because those who turn what is of public interest information into public information are now criminalized and paid sanctions. I would say, Madam President: intellectual property is already safeguarded. So there was no need to go to trade secrets, because they have to do exclusively with information, and in this sense we are a little poorer in our democracy.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President. I want to say that trade secrets are, in fact, the cornerstone of any company's functioning and productive activities. It can also be applied to specific inventions, including non-public financial data that does not need to be declared in any format, and much more. It should be noted that, as in the case of individuals, companies inevitably have a right to privacy and, in the context of this report, to the protection of their trade secrets. I agree that the protection of trade secrets against their unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure should not extend to matters such as freedom and pluralism of the media, the autonomy of the social partners, or information, knowledge, experience, skills - everything, everything, everything employees have acquired in the past. jobs. The same applies, for example, to the independent making of similar discoveries outside the company concerned. But overall, I welcome this document and, of course, I voted in favor. Thanks!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, this is indeed a very important piece of legislation because protecting trade secrets is vital and this will deter third parties more effectively from misappropriating and dishonestly exploiting trade secrets within the European Union. As an Irish MEP, I support the compromise reached on the proposal. A number of Irish comments were taken on board and addressed in the compromise text, for instance with regard to the litigation limitation period. I am also very glad that key compromises were reached on legal redress against the theft and misuse of a trade secret, protecting freedom of expression and information, and preserving workers’ mobility. Dá bhrí sin is dóigh liom go bhfuil an-jab déanta againn anseo arís agus is féidir lenár ngnólachtaí a bheith sásta leis.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, I supported my colleague Le Grip's report, as I believe that the regulation and protection of trade secrets and know-how is crucial for the development of European business and for the promotion of competitiveness in Europe. This proposal is crucial as it will discourage industrial espionage and unfair competition, which SMEs in particular find difficult to deal with. The protection of labor mobility, freedom of expression and information, and fundamental guarantees for whistleblowers are all elements that make the proposal extremely valuable.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The directive has as its object the protection of the "trade secret", that is the set of information and know-how that represent an asset for the company.Although we warn that this directive promotes the legal protection of SMEs' trade secrets, the instrument of legal action is, in our opinion, easily manipulated.Specifically, the legal action in question can harm individuals who do not harm any legitimate corporate interest, including journalists, workers who want to change companies and whistle-blowers.For these reasons I would have abstained.

name: Clara AGUILERA
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated once again the important role that informants and the press play. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and the freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempt from the scope of this Directive. The S & amp; D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to access. disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against this report because it supposes an arbitrary definition of industrial secrecy that can revert in favor of tax evasion, as well as give more power to private companies against potential informants.After the successive scandals in Luxembourg and Panama, the need to protect the informants who have brought this information to the public has been demonstrated, however this proposal for a Directive does not protect the aforementioned informants, since they did not provide "illegal" information.In this way, this Directive gives tremendous power to private companies that, in the name of competitiveness, can take all kinds of legal actions against the aforementioned informants.It is because of the dire need to protect these contemporary heroes in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – Sinn Fein voted against this controversial bill. In essence the provisions contained within this report effectively criminalise whistle-blowers. Whistle-blowers and journalists could be criminalised if they publish information that companies deem to be secret.  As has been noted by a number of NGOs, the Trade Secrets Protection Act would have potentially criminalised the release of the Panama Papers:  This legislation will make it possible for corporations to define any information they do not want released as a trade secret, and then prosecute journalists or whistle-blowers who release it to the public.  This chilling censorship of freedom of expression is one that must be fought at all times. Freedom of expression is one of the essential foundations of any democratic state. My party knows first-hand the dangers of this fundamental freedom being curtailed. Legislation was introduced in order to censor Sinn Féin. Such draconian measures seek only to undermine democracy. Freedom of expression is the basic right to communicate and should be respected by all those who value democracy. This regressive bill was approved by Parliament and so it will now need to be passed into law by national parliaments across the 28 nations of the EU.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing. - Despite the work of amending and improving the text carried out by my socialist colleagues, I have decided not to take part in the vote on this directive. In view of the stakes, I felt it necessary to further strengthen this legislative proposal. And the "Panama Papers" revelations only strengthened my analysis. If the draft directive voted on last Thursday suggests the protection of whistleblowers, a specific text on the protection of the latter would have been necessary. Today, only five Member States have specific legislation on the protection of whistleblowers; worse, seven Member States do not protect them at all. As such, I asked for the text to be referred to a parliamentary committee and its vote to be postponed, in order to condition its approval to that of a specific text on whistleblowers, for the sake of balance, as we did so by simultaneously passing the PNR directive and the personal data package. Unsuccessful, I resolutely decided not to take part in the final vote on the secret business directive, even though I supported all of the amendments improving the initial proposal of the European Commission.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - This guideline deals with the protection of confidential know-how and confidential business information from unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure. In short, the act deals with the fight against industrial espionage. Due to the fact that for many SMEs and startups this confidential information has an almost existential value, and in contrast to large corporations they have fewer resources to enforce and defend it, I believe the introduction of an EU-wide legal framework that provides uniform protection granted right. However, the right to freedom of expression and information should not be restricted, in particular as regards investigative journalism and whistleblowing activities. However, since the present text does not adequately protect these fundamental rights, I cannot fully agree with it. I also believe that the issue of trade secret disclosure should be discussed in the light of a European whistleblowing act, which is not the case here. For this reason I abstained from the vote.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ This report and legislative resolution concern a directive for the protection of trade secrets. However, as a ‘one—size—fits—all’ measure, it does not necessarily fit well with the business and employment practices of Member States to ensure protection of innovation. There has to be a concern that this legislation will favour big business, which has an ability to litigate which its SME colleagues often lack. It also inhibits the ability of highly-qualified workers to be mobile in the labour market; we risk, therefore, workers leaving the European Union to work in other jurisdictions. I therefore decided to vote against.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this text, negotiated by my colleague Jean-Marie Cavada, a former investigative journalist, because it improves the protection of whistleblowers, while allowing European economic players to enjoy a framework stable and unique regulatory framework. Confidentiality is an essential component of the business world. Many economic players, from large pharmaceutical laboratories to small manufacturers of local products, must protect their trade secrets, their plans and drawings, their copyrights and their strategy. However, the employee who decides to appropriate, for personal profit, the trade secret of his employer leads to a prejudice which can lead to the closure of a business and the destruction of jobs. Recent revelations, the Panama Papers, LuxLeaks and others, highlight the need for convergence in fiscal, social and regulatory matters. This is the direction to follow so that Europe becomes, in the era of globalization, a world power and resumes its place in history.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this proposal, which lays down new rules that will make it easier for companies affected by the theft of trade secrets to defend their rights in court and to obtain compensation for the damage they have suffered.These rules are supplemented by safeguards that will not restrict investigative journalism or prevent companies from reporting illegal activities.In coordinating these rules with the EU Council, the EP has sought to ensure that they do not restrict media freedom, investigative journalism or the protection of information sources.2015The agreement reached at the end of 2006 provides that the protection of business secrets will not apply if illegal activities of undertakings have been disclosed in order to protect the public interest.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this directive aimed at protecting the trade secrets of European companies, in particular SMEs, against economic espionage. This protection responds to a strong expectation of companies. The Directive organizes this protection by entrusting the judicial authorities of the Member States with the task of taking measures to prevent the unlawful disclosure of a trade secret. In addition, this directive guarantees the freedom of the press and whistleblowers when the disclosure of business secrets is of general interest, and in no way impedes the free movement of workers between companies. Finally, this protection of business secrets cannot restrict the protection of public health. Thus, there was nothing to prevent my voting in favor of this text which protects our industry and in particular SMEs, which are particularly concerned by trade secrets, which is often their only asset compared to their competitors. There is therefore no need to argue, as some have tried to do.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - The Belgian PS deputies abstained in this vote. On the one hand, we find this text, as edited by the S & amp; D group, positive. It combines the protection of trade secrets that companies and in particular SMEs really need in order to contribute to economic activity and job creation and to the protection, in this context, of workers, journalists and launchers. alert. Whistleblowers and journalists are in fact fully protected by Article 5, while the burden of proof is obviously the responsibility of the requesting party. The bashing it was subjected to is therefore incomprehensible to anyone who reads it carefully and shares the aforementioned issues! Yet we did not approve it. We believe that it is appropriate, a fortiori after the revelation of the leaks, to transversally protect whistleblowers. If necessary, the commission of inquiry that we obtained following the revelations of the Panama papers can only demonstrate the importance of protecting whistleblowers. That is why we abstained from a text that we considered useful but which should have been accompanied by a second initiative aimed at specifically protecting whistleblowers.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I am satisfied with the recent approval of the Trade Secrets Directive, a text that favors innovation and protects freedom of information. Legal protection is an essential tool to promote innovation, especially for SMEs that invest in R & D & I compared to those who want to take advantage of their effort and talent. The directive offers comprehensive protection, improving the initial proposal of the European Commission and favoring a competitive economy with high wages and stable employment. It is a relief for small businesses, often without the necessary financial means. Voting would not have been voting in favor of precariousness. In addition, the text includes the need to guarantee journalistic protection, another aspect of which to feel satisfied. Some called for the thorough inclusion of protection for whitsleblowers (alerters of bad business practices). I will vote in favor of such an initiative, but it is a different matter that must be legislated separately. Despite this, for the first time in a text, the protection of whistleblowers is mentioned, an issue that will undoubtedly need to be deepened in the future and that I will certainly support. What is meaningless is blocking a directive that fights precariousness using the fight against corruption as an excuse.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing.- The harmonious development of an efficient market economy requires that a difficult balance be struck between the free movement of information and the right to the protection of business secrets.That is why today I supported the Le Grip report on the proposal for a directive on the protection of confidential know-how and confidential business information against unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure.The directive aims to bring together national rules, which are very different from each other, by providing common definitions, measures and sanctions capable of offering greater legal certainty to operators and reinforcing the single European market.It is an effective tool that will guarantee at the same time the protection of the rights of workers, whistleblowers and freedom of the press without hindering those who report illicit or illegal practices carried out by their companies.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We voted against this proposal for a Directive aimed at protecting companies from the theft of secrets by their competitors in the market.The directive initially drawn up by the European Commission clearly favored the protection of economic rights at the expense of the political rights of citizens.Unfortunately, and despite some improvements, the text resulting from the inter-institutional negotiations and commitments reached subsequently continues to contain restrictions on fundamental rights that we consider unacceptable.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution.Indeed, if I was initially opposed to the original directive proposed by the Commission, an enormous parliamentary work was done on this text, which ultimately made it possible, thanks to the support of ENL deputies in particular, to protect the secrets ofbusiness and thus our SMEs against industrial espionage, while providing a new guarantee to "whistleblowers".Indeed, the right to reveal scandals in the general interest is now expressly recognized.Given this development and the transformation of the directive into a common sense text, I was able to support this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- This report clearly highlights how the protection of sensitive information in the commercial sector is a cross-border problem which needs to be solved at Community level.Our companies need a common system of rules and safeguards in all Member States, to prevent information covered by trade secrets from being stolen, and a legal instrument to be able to defend themselves internationally.I have always fought for the defense of our companies, hence my positive vote.

name: José BLANCO LÓPEZ
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have once again demonstrated the important role of informants and the press. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and the freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempt from the scope of this Directive. The S&D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to access. disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the protection of trade secrets against unauthorized receipt, use and disclosure. In order to protect trade secrets from misappropriation, some Member States have enacted legislation, but some Member States have not defined trade secrets and do not have binding legislation on protection against misappropriation of trade secrets. This situation creates gaps and obstacles to the effective functioning of the internal market. It is also appropriate to determine at Union level in which cases the acquisition, use and disclosure of a trade secret is lawful or unlawful and to limit the duration of redress procedures in order to achieve the objective of this Directive to ensure consistent protection of trade secrets in the European Union. Thus, it is important to establish a uniform definition of trade secret without restricting the object to be protected from misappropriation. Such a definition should be worded in such a way as to cover business information, technological information and know-how, taking into account both the legitimate interest in keeping such information secret and the legitimate expectation that such confidentiality will be maintained.

name: Simona BONAFÈ
text: in writing. - The draft directive approved today marks an important step towards the creation of a more uniform and effective legal framework, at European level, for the protection of professional know-how and confidential commercial information which are at the basis of the development and competitiveness of our companies. Parliament managed to make considerable improvements to the Commission's initial proposal, arriving at a balanced text, which, it should be emphasized, does not aim at defending illegal or improper conduct by companies, masking them in the form of trade secrets, but which has as its The aim is to protect the intangible assets of European companies, in particular SMEs, by guaranteeing them equal conditions and legal certainty within all Member States, to the advantage of the functioning of the single European market. Not only that: we were able to insert specific exceptions in the final text to protect the freedom of expression and information, of workers, as well as of those who disseminate certain information - not necessarily relating to illegal, but also irregular or incorrect conduct - in the public interest . The so-called "whistle-blowers" are therefore protected by the directive, even if we ask the Commission to present new proposals to deal specifically with the regime of guarantees to be reserved for these subjects.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- Since I am on the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, I have followed the work on the directive.The Commission's initial proposal was not very good, but I am very pleased that the priorities of my political group, the Socialists and Democrats, have been adopted.These proposals referred precisely to the exclusion of journalists and whistleblowers from the directive, the protection of small and medium-sized enterprises and workers' rights.We also sent a formal proposal to the Commission for an additional legislative proposal to protect whistleblowers.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe it is important, in order to maintain the high level of innovation of the European economy, that common legislation is adopted on the protection of trade secrets against the acquisition, use andillegal disclosure that allows for uniform discipline for all Member States.However, I find that it is necessary to find a better balance between the needs of secrecy and those of exchange between companies.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - Non-profit companies and research institutes invest in the acquisition, development and application of know-how and information, which are the bargaining chip of the knowledge economy and allow for a competitive advantage. It is precisely this capacity for investment, innovation and efficiency that constitutes the added value of most of the products - be they goods or services - made by European Union companies: goods and services that stand out in the world for their high level of quality , for the scientific and technological avant-garde, for the great wealth of knowledge and skills that are at its origin. These products, due to the investments in research and development by the companies that produce them as well as the high level of quality they represent, tend to have a significantly higher initial fixed cost for the producer compared to less expensive products. developed and of lower quality made in third countries. This is why it is in the urgent interest of all EU member states to protect the trade secrets and know-how of European businesses and to implement everything necessary to block the disclosure of illegal information, while also ensuring fair trials for all businesses.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution because it was the subject of a lot of parliamentary work, in which FN MEPs took part, to protect business secrets and thus protect our SMEs against economic espionage, while providinga new guarantee for "whistleblowers" by expressly recognizing their right to reveal scandals in the general interest.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - In today's knowledge-based economy, the ability of companies to innovate and compete can be severely affected when confidential information is either stolen or misused. Thus, the protection of trade secrets is of particular importance, especially for smaller companies in the EU, whose bases are less solid than those of a large company. Given the fact that there are currently differences in the legislation in force in the Member States regarding trade secret issues, but also that in some countries there is no specific legislation in this regard, this proposal is all the more important. This fragmentation only hinders the economic prosperity and development of the EU's single market. Last but not least, the improvements that the European Parliament has managed to make to the original text provide a solid and, at the same time, balanced framework. Supporting European protection, know-how, but not to the detriment of transparency, the distribution of information and the exercise of fundamental freedoms are important elements found in the final text, which is why I spoke in favor of this report.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - Vote in favor. In my opinion this is (for once) a regulatory intervention that respects the treaties. The problem of the protection of trade secrets is a cross-border problem. The holders of a trade secret need a system of rules and safeguards common to the 28 EU states. All this is even more important for a Member State like ours which seeks to make innovation and know-how a world-class excellence. In order to try to clarify some delicate aspects, various references have been added to the text to the need to protect fundamental freedoms and guarantee the right to information. Indeed, the rapporteur states that the French journalist who spread the news on the "LuxLeaks" scandal could not have been indicted (from Luxembourg) if this text had already been in force. Please take into account one fact: in 2013 a quarter of European companies were the victim of at least one case of stolen information and small and medium-sized enterprises are the most exposed. With this juridical instrument they could, perhaps, have at least some more tools to defend themselves even outside their own national borders.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated once again the important role that informants and the press play. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempted from the scope of this Directive. The S & amp; D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- The confidentiality of trade secrets is of considerable importance in order to protect companies against the theft of their information and innovations.We cannot decently ask for more competitiveness and innovation from our companies without offering them a legal framework adapted to the protection of their assets.Far too many companies are still victims of information theft.We need to protect our businesses while upholding the rights of journalists and whistleblowers to freedom of expression.In the current context, we see how their work has been of great use for the general interest, particularly in the area of taxation.The Trade Secrets Directive guarantees the freedom of expression provided for by the European Charter of Fundamental Rights while allowing companies to innovate without fear.I voted in favor of this text.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of this report to help companies obtain legal compensation for the theft or misuse of their trade secrets.With one in five companies being the victim of trade secret theft every year, this harmonization should allow for the creation of a safe and reliable environment for European businesses to have their intangible assets and know-how protected.Together with my colleagues in the S & amp; D group I have also fought to ensure that the safeguards provided by the text to protect the work of journalists and whistle-blowers are real and as unambiguous as possible.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ Sinn Fein voted against this controversial bill. In essence the provisions contained within this report effectively criminalise whistle-blowers. Whistle-blowers and journalists could be criminalised if they publish information that companies deem to be secret.  As has been noted by a number of NGOs, the Trade Secrets Protection Act would have potentially criminalised the release of the Panama Papers:  This legislation will make it possible for corporations to define any information they do not want released as a trade secret, and then prosecute journalists or whistle-blowers who release it to the public.  This chilling censorship of freedom of expression is one that must be fought at all times. Freedom of expression is one of the essential foundations of any democratic state. My party knows first-hand the dangers of this fundamental freedom being curtailed. Legislation was introduced in order to censor Sinn Féin. Such draconian measures seek only to undermine democracy.  Freedom of expression is the basic right to communicate and should be respected by all those who value democracy. This regressive bill was approved by Parliament and so it will now need to be passed into law by national parliaments across the 28 nations of the EU.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because I agree that the information which provides any company with a competitive advantage should be protected under law and any unlawful acquisitions of such information should be punished. I welcome the Commission proposal particularly because it provides a common definition of trade secrets which will help to avoid over- or under-interpretation of rules.

name: Jean-Marie CAVADA
text: in writing. - I welcome the vote on the draft "business secrets" directive. Long months of negotiations finally resulted in a balanced text, favorable to innovation and protecting freedom of information. In a complex competitive environment, legal protection of trade secrets is essential for innovation. As such, this directive offers the company's intangible assets full protection, covering the entire development phase of a process. A relief for start-ups and SMEs, which often lack the financial means necessary to protect them. We have ensured throughout the negotiations to impose safeguards guaranteeing the protection of journalistic investigation and, for the first time, the protection of whistleblowers is explicitly mentioned in European legislation. This is a decisive first step. We must now take advantage of this momentum to open the debate around a true European statute for whistleblowers within the European institutions.

name: Nessa CHILDERS
text: in writing. – EU companies face unfair competition if their knowledge is stolen through industrial espionage and that is why these practices are indeed illegal in EU countries. But this ostensible attempt at bringing EU-wide standards of protection for company secrets has turned into a much broader-reaching piece of legislation which fails to protect insiders who stand to lose their careers, income and face harassment and persecution when they blow the whistle on corrupt and unethical behaviour in their organisations.  There is one single argument which to my mind suffices to reject this legislation. It does nothing to protect the likes of Antoine Deltour, who is being prosecuted for theft of PricewaterhouseCoopers corporate secrets in Luxembourg, because his revelations of tax impropriety shed light on practices that were not illegal, although deeply unscrupulous. I do commend the efforts of progressive colleagues who worked hard to improve the text; for instance, as regards the protection extended to journalists. Still, in the absence of proper safeguards to protect workers who risk everything to tell the truth, this vote should have been postponed until they are brought forward. Because it was not, the directive should have been quashed.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and emphasize that trade secrets play an important role in protecting the exchange of knowledge between companies, and in particular SMEs, and research institutes, within and beyond the internal market, in the context of research and development and innovation.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - We voted today on the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of know-how and business information (trade secrets) against illegal acquisition, use and disclosure. It is obvious that such reports address very important issues of sound economic development, something that is directly related to transparency within states, but also to respect for citizens' rights. I believe that this report does not contribute to the adoption of sound control and protection policies for the benefit of citizens and the Member States. At the same time, it does not defend the interests of employees, while it does not have any provision regarding the protection of whistleblowers. For these reasons I decided to vote against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report on trade secrets because it seeks to pursue a point which I believe is fundamental for the development and growth of our countries under the banner of the European Union. It is clear, in fact, that collective development is easier and faster in a space of mutual sharing of commercial information and cooperation between the various companies scattered throughout the territory. In my opinion, however, it is also necessary to protect the so-called "trade secret" which rewards the initiative and innovation of the individual company and also allows the various products to be distinguished from each other also in the name of quality, a character to which I am particularly sensitive . This is why I expressed my favor, because this report seeks to find the right balance necessary between these two elements with the main aim of building the foundations for a further engine of development for the entire European Union, at the same time guaranteeing, in this space of sharing, an adequate level of defense against unfair trading practices. Indeed, I believe that protection against the unlawful acquisition, disclosure and use of trade secrets is essential to ensure a fair trading environment for businesses.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report on trade secrets because it offers concrete solutions for fighting industrial espionage, whilst guaranteeing freedom of expression and information – starting with the freedom of the press and the activities of whistle-blowers.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing. - Trade secrets play an important role in protecting the exchange of knowledge between companies, in particular SMEs, and research institutions within the internal market, in the context of research and development and innovation. Trade secrets are particularly important for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) and start-ups, which often lack specialized human resources or financial power to obtain, manage, apply and defend Intellectual Property Rights. I support the Le Grip Report because I believe that it is legitimate to protect trade secrets and because I believe that this new instrument will bring legal clarity and a level playing field to all European companies, increasing their interest in the development of research and innovation activities, deterring disclosure illegal trade secrets. I am pleased that a balanced text has been reached that does not undermine fundamental rights and freedoms, the public interest, in particular public security, consumer protection, public health, environmental protection, worker mobility and journalistic information / research. The figure of the whistleblower will also enjoy adequate protection.

name: Lara COMI
text: in writing. - This proposal for a directive is particularly important because its main objective is to identify rules which improve the competitiveness of our businesses. In particular, SMEs place great value on trade secrets as they allow the creator to profit from his creation and innovations, as well as to invest in research, development and innovation. Our main goal is to protect SMEs from fraudulent practices to which they are increasingly exposed, such as theft, economic espionage, violation of confidentiality obligations, or all those practices that are aimed at the illicit appropriation of secrets. commercial. Without legal instruments to protect trade secrets, effective and comparable throughout Europe, the incentives to undertake activities and investments in research and innovation can only diminish. It is therefore necessary to intervene on the fragmentation of the legal system and to approximate national legislative systems, as well as to define at European level the situations in which the acquisition, use and disclosure of a trade secret are lawful or illegal and to reduce the period of application of the appeal procedures.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I understand the criticisms made against this proposal. At the same time, European researchers and innovators, especially SMEs and start-ups need protection from the commercial theft of their invention. The proposed directive does not prohibit or inhibit the publication of confidential information where this is in the public interest. It does not prohibit the publication of information such as the Panama Papers, that is information (related to an invention, research or business know-how) the publication of which serves a public interest. But it does prohibit the publication of such information where this is tantamount to commercial theft of trade know—how. Europe has seen companies suffering commercial theft leading to job losses, social difficulties and loss of economic value, as well as instances where start-ups’ innovation is stifled through forcible take—over by big companies. I supported this Directive in the Committee on Legal Affairs (JURI) and in plenary to ensure that researchers, innovators and inventors are given a fighting chance of bringing about change in European societies while receiving the recognition they deserve for their work. The proposal protects two very important principles: publication of information in the public interest and recognition of European inventors, innovators and researchers.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against this report because it supposes an arbitrary definition of industrial secrecy that can revert in favor of tax evasion, as well as give more power to private companies against potential informants.After the successive scandals in Luxembourg and Panama, the need to protect the informants who have brought this information to the public has been demonstrated, however this proposal for a Directive does not protect the aforementioned informants, since they did not provide "illegal" information.In this way, this Directive gives tremendous power to private companies that, in the name of competitiveness, can take all kinds of legal actions against the aforementioned informants.It is because of the dire need to protect these contemporary heroes in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - Economic competition is currently characterized by the importance of knowledge and innovation. Know-how and the culture of knowledge are the elements that allow companies to obtain a competitive advantage and distinguish themselves from competitors. In this sense, it is important that companies and all persons who file a patent are guaranteed so that their experience and know-how are legally protected. Within the EU there are many differences in the way patents and know-how are protected and there is not even a common definition of the concept of trade secrets. To allow for a harmonization of patent and trade secret rules in the EU, I voted in favor of the legislative resolution of the European Parliament of 14 April 2016 on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of confidential know-how and of confidential commercial information (trade secrets) against unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up.- Illegal acquisition, use and disclosure of trade secrets is a risk factor as they lead to the commission of crimes such as theft, bribery, fraud.The manufacture or placing on the market of infringing goods is also an illegal use of trade secrets.I voted for the protection of these data, for their evaluation according to the degree of correctness and applicability.The acquisition or use of a trade secret by a third party may have a negative impact on the rightful holder, and such a measure shall support the avoidance of non-pecuniary and financial damage.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - The proposal for a directive is of particular importance as its main aim is to establish a set of rules to improve the competitiveness of European enterprises through innovation, thereby strengthening Europe's position as a leader in the global industrial market. In the process of researching and creating new ideas, products or services, we deal with a lot of information that is critical to the idea of ​​competitiveness or business that does not fall under the protection of intellectual property rights. Therefore, trade secrets are a complementary instrument to protect this information, and it was necessary and important for the Commission to regulate its acquisition, use or disclosure at EU level. The directive also provides a legal framework for victims of the theft of business secrets seeking compensation. Trade secret theft is an increasingly common problem in the EU. Given the nature of the document, I voted for it.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This codecision report determines the measures, procedures and remedies that must be made available to a holder of a trade secret, in the event of unlawful disclosure of this secret by a third party.The proposed directive presents a common definition of trade secrets and establishes the general principles applicable to civil law instruments, it sets a deadline of at least one year and at most two years for lodging appeals.It also requires Member States to provide mechanisms enabling judicial authorities to protect the confidentiality of business secrets disclosed before a court.Considering that the balance between the need to protect trade secrets from unfair commercial practices and respect for freedom of expression has been struck in this proposal, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported the text on the protection of trade secrets against unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure.This text presents a balanced compromise which makes it possible to effectively protect companies against industrial espionage while ensuring that fundamental freedoms, and in particular freedoms of expression and information, are not hindered.It was necessary for the European Union to equip itself with a harmonized legal framework in order to strengthen business confidence in the European market.However, it was also essential to put in place adequate safeguards to protect press freedom, as well as whistleblowers.Also, the protection of business secrets should therefore not be extended to cases where the disclosure of a business secret is in the public interest.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted in favour of this directive because I want to protect businesses and therefore employment in the EU. Businesses are the backbone of our economy and therefore deserve the required protection. In order to protect them, we need to protect their know-how, which they have invested in so heavily to acquire.  There seems to be much confusion with regard to what is actually protected. When referring to trade secrets, the legislator refers to information for which no obligation to disclose exists. In addition, it criminalises theft of our businesses’ know-how. It also provides a framework for measures, procedures and remedies if the latter regrettably were to happen. Besides the clear benefits of this directive, there were some concerns that were adequately addressed. One of these was the guarantee of employee mobility and ensuring the legitimate right to information. Finally, the position of SMEs has been taken into account with regard to their capacity to have access to justice.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing. - The concept of "trade secrets" refers to know-how and information which confer commercial and economic value on their legitimate holder. This is the name that should have been used. Of course, the European Union must take care to protect companies, whatever their size, when their know-how is likely to be affected. This directive therefore offers protection to the intangible heritage of the company, covering the entire development phase of a process. This is going in the right direction for European start-ups and SMEs, which often lack the financial means necessary to protect them. At the same time, the European Union must ensure that freedom of expression and information are fundamental principles which must be preserved at all costs. Thus, for the first time, the protection of whistleblowers is explicitly mentioned in European legislation. This is a first step which finally opens the door to a specific directive protecting the whistleblowers we are calling for.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Le Grip report on the protection of trade secrets. I believe that it provides a strong and concrete response in favor of the fight against industrial espionage which continues to affect our companies. Indeed, 25% of European companies were the subject of information theft in 2013! Thus, the adoption of this report will allow a harmonization of protection and sanction measures within European companies, which will see their intangible heritage and their know-how protected. Following the vote on this text, a real disinformation campaign has sprung up everywhere. I want to set the record straight: this directive unambiguously guarantees freedoms of expression and information, starting with freedom of the press. Regarding whistleblowers, this text does not create a statute but it is the first time that the legitimacy of whistleblowers has been recognized in a legislative text. This directive relates to "business secrets" and not to "whistleblowers". However, my colleagues and I have been asking for a text on the subject for several months, but the European Commission is very cautious fearing an overly political issue.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this text because I consider it a step forward, on the protection of companies and their know-how, in particular SMEs, while protecting journalists. In the present case, we must not only think at the level of France but also taking into account all the Member States. In many countries of the Union, this is an important first step in favor of press freedom and the protection of sources. As a reminder, the directive initially did not concern journalists or whistleblowers. It was the decisive action of the Group of Socialists and Democrats that made it possible to clarify these elements in their favor. However, it is now necessary to supplement this directive with another text in order to very officially and definitively protect whistleblowers. This request has been formally expressed by the S & amp; D group to the European Commission.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing. - I gave my support to the draft directive on trade secrets because I believe that at the end of a very long journey, the text on which the Council and Parliament have finally reached an agreement is both balanced and reasonable: it ensures the protection of trade secrets; it protects innovation and benefits SMEs and start-ups, which often do not have the financial means necessary to protect them; finally, it guarantees respect for freedom of expression and freedom of information. Several safeguards guaranteeing the protection of journalistic investigation have been introduced into the directive so that it is not seen as a Trojan horse against future scandals such as "Luxleaks" and other "Panama Papers". Finally, the specific situation of whistleblowers is explicitly mentioned in the text. This is a first step that opens a future debate on this specific issue.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- This directive aims to protect the trade secrets of European companies, including SMEs, against economic espionage.Amendments were tabled, in particular by FN deputies and adopted to resolve the difficulties observed.The text guarantees the freedom of the press and that of whistleblowers to divulge business secrets, in the general interest.Furthermore, the free movement of workers between companies is not hindered.On the contrary, it too is guaranteed.Finally, the protection of public health cannot be restricted in the name of the protection of trade secrets.For these reasons, the National Front was able to support this text for which I voted in favor.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: written. - The legislative initiative on the protection of trade secrets is based on an assessment of the importance of trade secrets for innovation and the competitiveness of companies, the extent to which they are used, their role and their relationship with IPR, the generation and economic exploitation of knowledge and intangible assets and the pertinent legal framework. The aim of this initiative is to ensure that the competitiveness of European companies and research organizations that are based on know-how and undisclosed business information is adequately protected and, in this way, improve the conditions and the framework for the development and exploitation of innovation and knowledge transfer in the internal market. Specifically, what is sought is to improve the effectiveness of the legal protection of trade secrets against misappropriation throughout the internal market, as well as to have a deterrent effect with regard to the illegal disclosure of trade secrets without undermining fundamental rights and freedoms or the public interest, such as public safety, consumer protection, public health, environmental protection and worker mobility.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- Protection against the illegal acquisition, disclosure and use of trade secrets is essential to enable a fair business environment for companies.However, companies are more interested in sharing trade secrets than in keeping them confidential.Transparency and access to information are also necessary to inform important public policies, such as those on the environment, health and consumer protection.For this reason, I believe it is necessary to find the right balance, in order not to allow abusive complaints about the improper acquisition or circulation of trade secrets and to prevent the information that must be shared and exchanged from being kept secret by means of protection that is too broad.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote for: aims to protect the trade secrets of European companies, including SMEs, against economic espionage.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This directive aims to protect knowledge and trade secrets from illegal use, acquisition and disclosure, namely to protect companies and non-commercial research institutions. According to the proposal, the investment in intellectual capital generates competitiveness and innovative performance in the market and in this way it enhances financial return, which is one of the fundamental reasons for the investigation. If there is no security in this process, it is argued, innovation is hindered. We talk about protecting small and medium-sized companies, when we know that the safeguarding of trade secrets and the extension of their scope, mainly serve large economic groups. Trade secrecy, to which everything must be subjected, until judicial action is absolute. Everything in defense of the supreme interests of capital. Of course, the directive's role in promoting the Digital Single Market is not overlooked. The Commission's proposal is not improved by the European Parliament's proposed amendments, which essentially confirm the logic of yielding to the economic and financial interests of large companies, disregarding the rights, freedoms and guarantees of workers, consumers and citizens generally. Neither position fully guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, whistleblowers, journalists. They do not guarantee the rights of citizens, their health or the environment. We voted against.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report because I consider the creation of definitions and mechanisms that allow better protection of trade secrets in the Union to be very important.I think it is an important step forward, since trade secrets did not enjoy protection as such until now.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report because it is essential that the protection of its intangible assets and know-how be ensured in order to guarantee effective development conditions for our companies.Within an increasingly global market, the definition at Community level of trade secrets is to be welcomed, as well as the regulatory harmonization itself as a whole, which puts an end to the differentiation of the levels of protection between the different Member States.Furthermore, I believe that the protection provided for the principle of "a general public interest" is important, that is, the fact of not applying the sanctions provided for by the directive when they serve to reveal fraud and illegal activities that may pose a threat to the proper functioning of the principle of free competition.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as the public will be denied access to vital information.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- This trade secret directive aims to provide protection for European businesses facing economic espionage, both at European Union level and internationally.There is currently no Europe-wide measure and the legislation in each Member State ranges from non-existent to very strict.This proposal has a high level of support from businesses, including a large number of small and medium-sized enterprises.There is a need to find a solution that strikes the right balance, so as not to open the door to unjustified proposals for fraudulent acquisition or dissemination of trade secrets, and to prevent the information that should be shared and exchanged from being too much to blame.broadly designed protection classified.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting in favor of the report which seeks to protect and also defend companies from cyber attacks in the EU.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. - I am voting against this report as I consider it to have all the negative guarantees to operate, through Article 9 Section 2 (Interim and Interim Measures), as a chariot to disrupt, delay and freeze completely legal commercial and business activities. natural and legal persons who can be described as competitors of the alleged offender. At the same time, theft, breach of contract, contract, embezzlement, fraud, etc. are already illegal acts, so we consider that this report (beyond the many legal gaps) is unnecessary and meaningless.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I strongly believe the Trade Secrets Directive will be fundamental in order to offer protection to European businesses faced with economic espionage, both at EU and international level. Currently, there are no Europe-wide provisions and the legislation in Member States varies from none to high protection of trade secrets. I welcome the fact that the directive proposes an unprecedented text on the protection of whistle-blowers, which could become a positive precedent. Moreover, it excludes media freedom and freedom of expression in a very clear way from the application of the directive.  Finally, I welcome the fact that it secures strong guarantees on workers’ mobility, and workers’ right to information and representation, as well as safeguards for disclosure to public authorities.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing.- I support any position based on defining rules that improve the competitiveness of European companies through innovation.They also reaffirm Europe's leadership in the global industrial market.Adequate protection of trade secrets is key for small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs).In general, they have to rely on these to a greater extent, as the use of intellectual property rights is mostly a costly resource for the management and protection of intellectual property rights.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report as the protection of trade secrets against illegal obtaining, use and disclosure is essential for companies to benefit from a fair trading environment.However, it is important to remember that the circulation of knowledge and information is also essential for the process of innovation and creation.Likewise, it should be remembered that according to the approved report, freedom of the press is protected in any case, as well as disclosure in order to reveal improper behavior, fraud, irregularity, fraud or illegal activity, provided that the defendant has acted inpublic interest.No one may rely on the protection of trade secrets to act in an opaque or fraudulent manner.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated, once again, the important role that informants and the press play. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. That is why I voted in favor of a directive that guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and freedom of the press. In addition, a clear legal framework is formalized that guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in a situation of public and general interest, are exempt from the scope of this Directive. We Socialists have also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could derive from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation and the protection of the right to disclosure of information related to the operation of the company by the workers to their representatives.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated once again the important role of informants and the press. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempted from the scope of this Directive. The S & amp; D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - Trade secrets are valuable assets owned by all businesses, regardless of industry or size. This information determines the company's ability to innovate, develop and compete domestically and internationally. Europe is strong in science and innovation with the potential to become a global leader. Currently, trade secrets are only legally protected where someone obtains confidential information in an unauthorized manner. One in five companies have reported at least one attempt to steal their trade secrets in the past ten years. Therefore, the conditions for conducting innovative business activities should be improved. There are significant differences in the legislation of the individual member states. Only some of them have a definition of trade secrets or provisions aimed at their protection. This means that they are not protected to an equivalent degree across the Union, fragmenting the internal market in this area and reducing the deterrent effect that these rules should have. In this context, the Commission adopted in May 2011 a comprehensive intellectual property strategy in which it committed itself to examining the protection of trade secrets. The current proposal is a further step towards realizing this commitment of completing a single market in intellectual property by introducing common definitions and rules in this area.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- A company's knowledge and information exchange is usually essential for its innovative development and progress.Considered against this background, business secrets must be kept and companies protected from the risk of illegal acquisition.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We voted against this proposal for a Directive aimed at protecting companies from the theft of secrets by their competitors in the market.The directive initially drawn up by the European Commission clearly favored the protection of economic rights at the expense of the political rights of citizens.Unfortunately, and despite some improvements, the text resulting from the inter-institutional negotiations and commitments reached subsequently continues to contain restrictions on fundamental rights that we consider unacceptable.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up. - The protection of trade secrets against illegal acquisition, use and disclosure has been a concern of mine both when I worked in the private sector and when I was Minister for SMEs in my country. I made several amendments to this report and voted in favor of the report because its adoption protects work and intellectual property, defines and clarifies what is a trade secret and protects the exchange of knowledge between businesses, especially for SMEs. research institutions, both inside and outside the market. The report clarifies how compensation is awarded in the event of the disclosure of trade secrets by anyone who is not legally authorized and, at the same time, does not impede the mobility of workers. I would like to emphasize the need to define in each company what are the trade secrets so that workers have knowledge and provide in individual employment contracts a confidentiality clause for all workers who have access to trade secrets, by exercising functions or duties on duty.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this legislative report because it defends worker mobility and ensures that big corporations cannot hide evidence of wrongdoing or pressure employees into not revealing fraud to the media.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this text, which aims to provide SMEs or large European companies with a harmonized legal framework which protects them from theft or unlawful disclosure of their data of commercial value. This text will allow our companies to fight against industrial espionage and protect their know-how. This will be particularly useful in certain highly exposed sectors, such as perfumery. However, the protection of business secrecy will give way to the right to freedom of information and that of whistleblowers to reveal "a fault, inappropriate behavior or illegal activity", when it comes to "to protect the general public interest". Nor will it infringe on the rights of staff representatives in the exercise of their function. Nor can the acquired know-how be used as a business secret to oppose the mobility of workers from one company to another.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - Far from the recent revelations of the "Panama Papers", this text will protect jobs, technologies, investments, while fighting against industrial espionage: this is its primary reason for being. This text also aims to guarantee protection to employees - both public and private -, consultants and managers - both internally and externally - by reversing the burden of proof in particular and by offering compensation in the event of reprisals on the part of of the company concerned. This text could finally be useful to protect whistleblowers, who will be protected everywhere in Europe in the event of disclosure of business secrets "in the public interest", even though only five Member States have specific legislation. on the protection of whistleblowers and that seven of them do not protect them at all. So it is with all these elements in mind that, rather than rejecting this text outright and choosing the path of simplicity, I supported all the rewriting work carried out by my colleagues to protect freedom. to inform journalists and their sources, while defending employment, industry and innovation in Europe.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written. We Swedish Social Democrats in the European Parliament chose to vote in favor of the report on directives to protect trade secrets that have not been disclosed from being illegally acquired, exploited and disclosed. From the outset, we have been critical of the Commission's original proposal, but succeeded in negotiating legislation with exceptions for whistleblowers and freedom of expression and the press. We also succeeded in securing wording about the right to collective agreements, the mobility of workers and for reporting to authorities. These demands, agreed by Parliament and the Council, are too important for us to jeopardize at second reading, as the probability of gaining a majority is considered non-existent. Furthermore, we believe that the definition of trade secrets is still too broad and may leave room for different interpretations. However, given the guarantees we have succeeded in achieving in other important parts of the legal text, we consider it unjustified to vote against the proposal in its entirety.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- We voted against the report as it lacks the importance it attaches to defending the interests of large companies, the anemic as well as the absent protection of citizens from secret corporate practices when these practices are classified as trade secrets.The same practice applies to the protection of "whistle-blowers" since the term is not even used in the text that was voted.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this directive, which lays down common measures against unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure of trade secrets, aims at striking the right balance between effective protection of the trade-secret holders’ interests and fundamental rights. Trade secrets are particularly important for SMEs and start-ups as these often lack specialised human resources and financial strength to manage and defend their IPRs in which they have invested a great share. Different Member States’ legislation creates an uneven level of protection of trade secrets against their unlawful acquisition, thus leading to fragmentation of the internal market for information and know-how. The harmonisation of EU trade secret law will improve conditions for firms to develop, exchange and use innovative knowledge; it will help businesses and innovators to boost confidence through legal certainty.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as the protective measures outlined aid workers when moving jobs whilst also promoting the business within the EU.

name: Mary HONEYBALL
text: in writing. ‒ Labour MEPs voted for the report on the protection of trade secrets against their unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure. When it comes into force, this directive will provide important protections and help boost innovation for British SMEs. Contrary to some claims, whistle—blowers and journalists are explicitly exempt from the scope of this law. Labour MEPs and our Socialists and Democrats Group colleagues have also managed to exclude media freedom and freedom of expression in a very clear way from the application of the directive, and have secured strong guarantees on workers’ mobility, workers’ right to information and representation, as well as safeguards for disclosure to public authorities. In addition, Labour MEPS are calling for the Commission to bring forward a legislative proposal to further protect whistle—blowers.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - Questioned many times about the proposal for a directive on the protection of trade secrets, I would like to clarify my vote. I have indeed decided to support this text because I believe that we must stop allowing our know-how and technologies to be stolen from us by individuals or companies with detestable methods. There is an urgent need to provide entrepreneurs, researchers and innovators with sufficient legal arsenal to be able to defend themselves against these attacks. When we know that 25% of European companies were the subject of information theft in 2013 and that cybercrime has become a constant threat, I find it staggering that we can be criticized for wanting to defend our companies and the jobs that depend on it. Contrary to what is propagated by the disinformation campaign led by the Greens, the text places freedom of expression and information at the heart of its reasoning. Thus, journalists are excluded and "whistleblowers" can violate these rules to "reveal fault, inappropriate behavior or illegal activity, provided that the defendant has acted in order to protect the public interest. general".

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report because I believe that it is paramount to protect European businesses that must deal with economic espionage. Also, it is important to note that the directive is compatible with the Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the draft European Parliament legislative resolution on the proposal for a directive of the Parliament and of the Council on the protection of undisclosed knowledge and experience and business information (business secrets) against unauthorized disclosure, use or disclosure because I consider it necessary to strike the right balance between . Business secrets are of particular importance for small and medium-sized enterprises and so-called startups, given that they often do not have the specialized human resources and financial capabilities to adequately protect their intellectual property rights. As a result of globalization, trade secrets are increasingly being targeted by fraud, theft and espionage, and there is a growing potential for these secrets to be misused in third countries. I believe that the differences in the legislation of the Member States on this issue lead to an uneven level of protection of trade secrets and, consequently, to the fragmentation of the internal market. I believe that the harmonization of European law relating to business secrets will improve conditions in the sector concerned and I therefore support this report.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing. - This directive aims to protect the trade secrets of European companies, including SMEs, against economic espionage. It uses the definition of trade secrets given by the "Agreement on Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights" (TRIPS), which has the advantage of being already recognized internationally. This is commercial information or know-how (technological or industrial processes) which have commercial value, are intended to be patented, and whose confidentiality must be guaranteed during the research and development phase. This protection corresponds to a strong expectation of European companies. Three problems were raised respectively by journalists (including Élise Lucet), unions and health professionals. The rapporteur of the Committee on Legal Affairs, Constance Le Grip (PPE), took them into account. Amendments were tabled (in particular by Gilles Lebreton and Marie-Christine Boutonnet) and adopted to resolve them. In the end, there is nothing to prevent the National Front from supporting this text. That’s why I voted in favor of this text.

name: Ramón JÁUREGUI ATONDO
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated once again the important role that informants and the press play. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and the freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempt from the scope of this Directive. The S & amp; D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to access. disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ Trade secrets and confidential business information are at the core of the competitiveness of any company. Today, one company out of every five is a victim of theft of trade secrets every year. Difficulties with getting redress against misappropriation of trade secrets need to be addressed. Thanks to this directive, trade secrets will share a common definition and same level of protection across all 28 EU Member States. This text will allow the creation of a safe, trustworthy and fair environment for European companies, by better securing their know-how while protecting whistle-blowers and journalists’ work. Indeed, for the first time, the protection of whistle-blowers is explicitly mentioned in an EU piece of legislation.
