This is, I hope, a first step towards a European framework for the protection of whistle-blowers.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Constance Le Grip on the protection of trade secrets against illicit acquisition, use and disclosure. Unauthorized use of confidential business information is likely to reduce the competitiveness of our SMEs and cause them economic harm. Industrial espionage can thus cost many jobs in Europe and encourage relocation. However, the text recognizes cases where the theft or disclosure of business secrets may be legitimate and cannot be hindered or condemned, as in the case of investigative journalism or whistleblowers. Strong exceptions are therefore provided to protect these cases, which guarantees the general balance of the text and protects the public's interest in becoming aware of certain information relating to trade secrets. This report was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report by my colleague Constance Le Grip.The agreement reached strikes the right balance between the necessary protection of know-how, innovation and confidential information, an essential issue for European companies, and the preservation of the fundamental freedoms of freedom of information and expression., essential to democracy.In addition, other economically important countries already have this type of legislation.The European Union cannot be the only area which does not have a minimum of legal convergence and uniform protection.

name: Jan KELLER
text: in writing.- I abstained from voting on the final proposal because, as a result, it provides companies with inadequate protection and allows them to sue anyone who uses or discloses information they consider to be a trade secret.This definition is so broad in the draft directive that it covers almost all inside information.The disclosure of such a broad trade secret is subject to heavy penalties.Exceptions for certain groups of people (employees, journalists, scientists, consumers and whistleblowers) do not provide sufficient protection.In my opinion, this directive threatens, among other things, the ability of journalists to publish information about unfair practices of companies and the ability of employees to use all their work experience in building a career.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- The protection of data, business and trade secrets is of vital importance for many companies of all sizes.With this regulation, this area will be better protected.At the same time, through the exceptions set out in Article 4, it is still possible to uncover grievances in the public interest (so-called whistleblowing) on issues such as corruption or human rights violations.In a common internal market, it makes sense to implement this regulation at European level.That is why I voted for the Le Grip report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - Today, we voted on a proposal for a directive harmonizing the regulation of trade secrets across the EU Member States. However, the Commission has not been able to convince me of the need for such an adjustment for several reasons. Firstly, it was based on a public consultation, in which only 386 respondents took part in their answers, which is not a particularly high number in the EU-wide context. According to the experience of experts on this issue, including those from the Czech Republic, Member States can satisfactorily regulate civil law themselves without significant obstacles to the functioning of the internal market, so compliance with the requirements of the principle of subsidiarity could be at least disputed. In addition, no major problem with existing legislation has been identified so far, including that differences in Member States' legal systems would be a major obstacle to cross-border investment in this area. In the proposal, I also find a number of risks - such as insufficient protection of journalists' access to information, rather negligible protection of employee mobility, where an employer can prevent employees from finding employment in the same field with another employer for up to 6 years. minimal or rather no whistleblower protection. Therefore, I was not able to vote in favor of the current version of the draft directive and I supported the negative amendment.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing. - Trade secrets, which also include manufacturing, and industrial secrets, unlike rights deriving from intellectual property, which confer the exclusivity of the possession of this right, award the ownership to third parties to be able to freely use and develop their formula, since it is not an exclusive right on creation. It is well known how the processing of sensitive data is allowed only by the owner and not by third parties unrelated to the owners of these rights, which is why the violation of these is to be considered as an unfair practice, ergo, as a violation of a right inalienable. Specifically, the report on the protection of trade secrets against the acquisition, use and disclosure of offenses establishes which protection instruments to adopt in the event that the latter are acquired illegally by third parties, such as the assignment of a compensation for damage caused to him.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing. - I obviously voted in favor of the text of the agreement reached in trilogue on the draft directive for the protection of professional know-how approved by a very large majority of my colleagues. This directive aims to provide common and concrete responses to fight industrial espionage while guaranteeing freedoms of expression and information, starting with freedom of the press. It will make it possible to harmonize the excessively disparate national protection and sanction rules in terms of the protection of know-how by constituting a legal base common to all Member States capable of establishing a climate of confidence in exchanges between European companies, by protecting thus their know-how and their intangible heritage. I fought to provide guarantees of full respect for the freedoms of information and expression, essential for the work of journalists. The compromise that we, European parliamentarians, obtained also provides for the protection of whistleblowers by recognizing their activity and the exclusion from the scope of the directive of the disclosure of faults, reprehensible acts or illegal activities made. in order to protect the general interest. Finally, this text enshrines the right to mobility of workers, which cannot be hindered on the pretext of holding "business secrets".

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: in writing. - By considering as a "business secret" everything that a company seeks to hide, and by making it possible to sanction any leak, the "trade secrets" directive makes it possible to muzzle workers worried about the practices of their companies and journalists who relay them. With this broad approach, it therefore goes well beyond the only necessary protection of intellectual property. The rule becoming the secret, any leak of a whistleblower will now have to be justified in the name of "the general interest", otherwise it could be heavily sanctioned. We are therefore witnessing a reversal of the burden of proof for employees who wish to denounce the activities of their companies, illegal or dangerous processes. These will have to justify themselves in court with the sole defense of an extremely vague legal concept, which is not the same everywhere (remember Luxembourg, which is currently suing Antoine Deltour) and in the face of multinationals capable of affording the best firms. lawyers. I therefore refused this text which threatens whistleblowers and the media which relay them. Protecting corporate intellectual property is important, but it should not come at the expense of public information and democratic debate.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted for the report on the protection of trade secrets against unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure.This is a text which constitutes a measure to protect businesses, especially SMEs, against economic espionage.For me, it is about ensuring the innovation of SMEs and their development possibilities.The directive leaves the Member States the capacity to prevent the unlawful use and disclosure of trade secrets and to sanction their use with concrete decisions.At the same time, it now provides enough guarantees to journalists and whistleblowers so that they can report these secrets in the event of illegal activity or professional misconduct.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution because it was the subject of a lot of parliamentary work, in which I participated, to protect trade secrets and thus protect our SMEs against economic espionage, while providinga new guarantee for "whistleblowers" by expressly recognizing their right to reveal scandals in the general interest.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- I voted for this resolution because it was the subject of a lot of parliamentary work, in which FN MEPs took part, to protect business secrets and thus protect our SMEs against economic espionage, while providinga new guarantee for "whistleblowers" by expressly recognizing their right to reveal scandals in the general interest.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated once again the important role that informants and the press play. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and the freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempt from the scope of this Directive. The S & amp; D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to access. disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated once again the important role that informants and the press play. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and the freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempt from the scope of this Directive. The S & amp; D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to access. disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted against this report because it supposes an arbitrary definition of industrial secrecy that can revert in favor of tax evasion, as well as give more power to private companies against potential informants.After the successive scandals in Luxembourg and Panama, the need to protect the informants who have brought this information to the public has been demonstrated, however this proposal for a Directive does not protect the aforementioned informants, since they did not provide "illegal" information.In this way, this Directive gives tremendous power to private companies that, in the name of competitiveness, can take all kinds of legal actions against the aforementioned informants.It is because of the dire need to protect these contemporary heroes in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - From the European Parliament and from the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection we have always fought to ensure that companies interact in a fair commercial environment. To guarantee a process of innovation and creation between companies, it is essential to circulate knowledge and information between them. However, this action cannot be done abusively because it has a counterproductive effect. This report seeks to establish a balance so that abusive claims do not arise in relation to the improper obtaining of trade secrets or their circulation. In addition, it incorporates numerous advantages for both companies and consumers since it will favor the mobility of workers and ensure fair judicial procedures, especially for small companies. The definition of "trade secret" will also be clarified so that large companies do not take advantage of small ones due to the legal uncertainty of the term. For all the above, I support this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - Companies and research institutions are constantly investing financial resources and time in the acquisition, development and application of knowledge and information. Information and knowledge are key to the development of an economy based on knowledge and innovation, thus gaining an advantage over other competitors. Information and achievements may be protected by patents, copyrights and design rights. In addition to "visible" information and achievements, companies may also hold so-called trade secrets that are strictly confidential and their availability is very limited. Business secrets can include information about technological knowledge, customer data, business plans, development strategies and market research. Protecting trade secrets from illegal acquisition, use or disclosure is key to operating in a dynamic business environment for all companies and research institutions. I supported this report because it defines the appropriate level of defense and the importance of trade secrets in the business environment.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- Protection of trade secrets against unauthorized acquisition, use and disclosure.Trade secrets represent a specific asset for each entity concerned, which increases its competitiveness and thus its market position. The present proposal regulates the institution of trade secrets in products and services.The proposal aims to strengthen the competitiveness of European businesses through more precise regulation and increased protection of trade secrets, while ensuring consumer protection.Disclosure of a trade secret shall be possible only if permitted by Union and Member State law, while preserving the protection of the rights of the holder of the trade secret.

name: Louis-Joseph MANSCOUR
text: in writing.- The purpose of this text is to protect data for commercial purposes and to combat industrial espionage.It represents an essential stake for innovation, the competitiveness of companies and therefore our jobs.However, the legitimate interest in protecting this information must not call into question the equally legitimate right to information on questionable practices (discriminatory pricing, tax optimization, etc.).The outcome of the negotiations between the European Parliament and the Council is particularly satisfactory on this last point.This new directive manages to reconcile better protection of the strategic capital of our companies and the full exercise of the right to freedom of expression and information guaranteed by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.I therefore vote in favor of this text.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- Referring to my speech at the plenary session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/4/2016, I voted in favor of postponing the vote on the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of know-how and business informationdisclosed (trade secrets) against their illegal acquisition, use and disclosure, in accordance with the relevant proposal of the rapporteur.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted for this text.Indeed, this resolution was the subject of a lot of parliamentary work, in which FN MEPs participated, to protect trade secrets and thus protect our SMEs against economic espionage, while providing a new guarantee to "whistleblowers "by expressly recognizing their right to reveal scandals in the general interest.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This directive aims to introduce a harmonized system for the protection of business secrets and know-how in Europe. Thus "natural and legal persons will have the opportunity to prevent information lawfully under their control from being disclosed to third parties or acquired or used by them without their consent and in a manner contrary to honest commercial practice". By this text, which claims to "protect business secrets", we see that it is in fact a matter of keeping multinationals the means to attack citizens who dare to denounce their actions. The lawsuits and prosecutions against whistleblowers revealing Luxleak, Swissleak, Dieselgate and other fraud cases are proof of this. Finally, I note that this European directive coincides precisely with a similar initiative taken by the United States government. Because the protection of trade secrets would allow European and American companies to cooperate more closely as regards research and innovation, all this within the framework of the TTIP of course. I vote against this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The communication from the Commission has been changed considerably.The voted report is a measure to protect companies, especially SMEs, against economic espionage.For us, it is a question of guaranteeing the innovation of SMEs and their development possibilities.The directive leaves the Member States the capacity to prevent the unlawful use and disclosure of trade secrets and to sanction their use with concrete decisions.At the same time, it now provides enough guarantees for journalists and whistleblowers to report these secrets in the event of illegal activity or professional misconduct.The press release from my colleague Gilles Lebreton of April 19, 2016 clearly details our position.Accordingly, I voted in favor.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - Europe has the necessary assets to become a world leader in terms of science and innovation. Achieving scientific quality is not only the goal of researchers, it is also a source of important gains for both the public and private sectors. However, companies' investment in research and development (R & amp; D) is insufficient when compared to what is practiced in their large trading partners, namely the United States and Japan. new products, processes, services and know-how. It is therefore desirable to improve the conditions for companies' innovative activities. As part of its broader Europe 2020 strategy, the Commission has committed itself to creating an Innovation Union designed to protect investments in the knowledge base, reduce cost fragmentation and make Europe a more rewarding place for innovation. Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I support this proposal as it protects research and business from unlawful exposure of their trade secrets. Crucially the proposal contains important safeguards for the protection of whistle—blowers and journalistic freedoms that will ensure that there will be no redress under this law, if the information in question is used for a public interest.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - Our SMEs, our start-ups which suffer from a lack of human and financial resources to protect their intellectual property, must be able to protect themselves and defend their rights in court against any economic and / or industrial espionage. They must be able to obtain redress in the event of misuse of their trade secrets, acts of corruption, breach of trust, theft, etc. There are many cases in which companies from third countries copy a European product completely illegally. This is hurting our businesses, our economy and our jobs in a globalized world. If Europe is to become a world leader in research and innovation, it needs an environment conducive to innovation. Our main objective in passing this directive was to create the conditions necessary to ensure the protection of trade secrets and the compensation of companies. It was essential to establish a sufficient and comparable level of remedy throughout the internal market in the event of unlawful use of trade secrets. Clear, organized and standardized protection of trade secrets against their misappropriation, encourages the exchange and transfer of commercial information and know-how on the territory of the Union, promotes the cross-border economy and discourages competition unfair.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - Trade secrets are a special property value that has the nature of an absolute right, and the entity to which it belongs can dispose of it at will and at the same time decide whether and to whom to make it available and determine the form of its secrecy. It is an inseparable part of business, which must be approached very sensitively within the legal framework, because insufficient or poor quality regulation can limit and endanger entrepreneurs. The aim of the present proposal is to establish a sufficient and comparable level of redress throughout the internal market in the event of misuse of trade secrets. The current national rules do not provide the same level of protection of trade secrets in the EU against misuse, which jeopardizes the smooth functioning of the internal market for information and know-how. The legislative proposal lays down good rules that will improve the competitiveness of European companies. I particularly appreciate that the rules apply not only to trade secrets related to products, but also to services. At the same time, the directive aims to ensure the protection of trade secrets already in the process of research and creation of new ideas, which will significantly protect especially small and medium-sized enterprises, who have significantly more limited financial and other means to protect their rights than large entrepreneurs.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the directive. It proposes an unprecedented text on the protection of whistle-blowers, which could become a positive precedent. Media freedom and freedom of expression are excluded in a very clear way from the application of the directive. The report presents strong guarantees on workers’ mobility and workers’ right to information and representation are secured, as well as safeguards for disclosure to public authorities.

name: Sorin MOISĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the directive on the protection of undisclosed trade secrets because we need to ease as much as we can the burdens faced by our key industrial sectors. We have very innovative and competitive companies that should be channelling their efforts into designing and developing new products rather than wasting resources in fighting against unfair commercial practices coming from third countries.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The EFDD, Verts / ALE, S&D, PPE, ECR, GUE / NGL and ALDE Groups have tabled motions for resolutions.In addition to the GUE / NGL, the other six political groups reached a compromise and drafted a joint draft.I voted in favor of this draft compromise.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing. - Economic espionage is a scourge for French and European companies, especially for SMEs, victims of aggressive economic espionage. Faced with this reality, the MEPs of the National Front took their responsibilities and decided to vote for the adoption of the directive on the protection of trade secrets. They thus protected the capacity for innovation and the development possibilities of our SMEs. At the same time, they took advantage of this directive to ensure that the European Parliament included measures to protect whistleblowers. With their support, the initial project of the Brussels Commission was thus profoundly modified to recognize whistleblowers the right to divulge business secrets "to reveal a fault, inappropriate behavior or illegal activity" for a purpose. of general interest. This is a new guarantee. If it had been adopted earlier, Antoine Deltour and Edouard Perrin, currently prosecuted in Luxembourg for exposing the LuxLeaks scandal, could rely on it. This directive therefore marks a step forward in the protection of whistleblowers. The National Front thus intends to ensure compliance with the ethics alert while fighting against economic espionage.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The protection of know-how and confidential information must be protected, as they provide a competitive advantage for companies that create or hold knowledge. Companies value this know-how and confidential information in the same way that they value patents and other forms of intellectual property rights, and use confidentiality as an instrument for managing business competitiveness and innovation in research. I advocate the creation of rules with the aim of harmonizing and standardizing national legal systems, in order to guarantee a sufficient and consistent level of recourse in the internal market in case of illegal acquisition, use or disclosure of a trade secret. It should be stressed that Member States must respect the safeguards established by this Directive when drawing up the combination of criminal measures with the civil and commercial aspects, in order to ensure an appropriate balance between the protection of trade secrets and the freedoms of business, expression and information.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing. - Three issues were raised respectively by journalists, unions and health professionals. The rapporteur of the Committee on Legal Affairs has taken them into account. Amendments were tabled and adopted to resolve them. Firstly, the freedom of the press and of whistleblowers to divulge trade secrets in the general interest is guaranteed by recitals 19 and 20 and by Articles 1, 5 and 18. In this respect, the Directive is more protective than was the vague provision (finally abandoned) relating to business secrets that appeared in the bill that led to the Macron law of August 6, 2015. Second, the free movement of workers between companies is not hampered by the protection of trade secrets; it is guaranteed by recitals 3,13 and 21 and by Articles 1 and 18. Third, the protection of public health cannot be restricted in the name of the protection of trade secrets, as clarified in recital 21 In the end, there is nothing to prevent my supporting this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this report to defend worker mobility and ensure that big corporations cannot hide evidence of wrongdoing or pressure employees into not revealing fraud, etc., to the media. A specific exception was included throughout the text allowing that the uncovering of wrongdoing is not considered to be an infringement of intellectual property, but is instead important in terms of freedom of expression and freedom of the press.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- In 2013, one in four European companies reported at least one case of information theft, which in particular resulted in a loss of turnover in 56% of cases and an increase in protection expenditure in 35%cases.This text protects companies against the unlawful obtaining, use and disclosure of undisclosed business information.It does not exempt companies from their legal transparency and disclosure obligations.In addition, the Commission provides an exemption for the legitimate use of freedom of expression and information: journalists who disclose business secrets cannot be penalized.This text strikes a balance between the protection of companies and freedom of information: that is why I voted in favor.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Constance Le Grip on the "Protection of undisclosed know-how and commercial information (trade secrets) against unlawful acquisition, use and disclosure". Any confidential business information which gives a competitive advantage to a company can be considered a trade secret (trade secrets include trade secrets, trade secrets and trade secrets). Unauthorized use of this type of information by anyone other than the holder is considered an unfair practice and a violation of trade secrets. Trade secrets are substantially different from IPRs, which confer exclusivity. The holder of a trade secret does not have an exclusive right over its creation. Its competitors, and other third parties, can therefore freely discover, develop and use the same formula. The Commission proposal sets out the measures, procedures and remedies which should be made available to the holder of a trade secret in the event of the unlawful acquisition, use or disclosure of this secret by a third party.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- The directive on the protection of trade secrets that we have adopted provides a more precise framework for what we call "trade secrets".Contrary to the criticisms that may have been voiced concerning the infringement of citizens' freedom of information, the directive guarantees respect for business secrets revealed before the courts, but as far as possible respects the balance with the fundamental right to freedomexpression.By adopting a common definition of trade secrets, we are also pushing back the risks of a legal vacuum.I therefore voted in favor of this directive, considering that its contributions were not only fair, but essential to ensure at the same time respect for freedoms and the activity of businesses.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - A trade secret is confidential information that can give a competitive advantage to certain companies - it can include industry secrets, trade secrets. These are key pieces of information in the competitive battle and key elements of a company’s competitive advantage. It is important to mention that a trade secret cannot be compared to intellectual property - a trade secret is not exclusive, it is not the exclusive property of a person, therefore it is necessary to regulate the use and protection of trade secrets in a precise and expedient regulation. not be accessed or used without authorization. The committee's proposal sets out measures, procedures and remedies for the trade secret holder in cases where the secret is used unauthorized - possibly through disclosure, unauthorized acquisition and use by third parties.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ Protection against unlawful acquisition, disclosure and use of trade secrets is key to allowing a fair commercial environment for businesses. I voted for this report that should clarify the definition of what should be considered as trade secrets.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up. - I supported this report because I believe that the protection of trade secrets against illegal acquisition, use and disclosure is beneficial for the proper functioning of the internal market and for ensuring economic growth. In this regard, today's report sets out the directives that Member States must follow in order to improve the protection of trade secrets. I appreciate the rapporteur's attitude, which proposes that future measures to be taken by the Member States ensure a fair balance between the protection of trade secrets and the freedom to conduct a business, between freedom of expression and freedom of information, with a concern for fundamental civil rights. (public safety, consumer protection, public health or environmental protection). I also welcome this directive as the legislative text aims not to affect the freedom of movement of workers and the freedom of establishment, two fundamental European rights.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: in writing. - I supported the proposal for a directive aimed at providing businesses with an adequate level of protection and effective remedies if their trade secrets have been stolen or misused. Trade secret protection is particularly important for small, less established businesses, which are much more dependent on trade secrets than larger companies - partly due in particular to the cost of obtaining a patent and protection against abuse. The loss of trade secrets and the possibility for competitors to access key inventions thus pose a huge economic risk for small and medium-sized enterprises. The available data confirm that new higher legal protection is much needed. A recent Commission survey found that one in five companies has been the victim of a trade secret attempt at least once in the last ten years. According to another study, this number is even increasing: in 2013, 25% of companies reported information theft, while in 2012 it was 18%.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I abstained from voting on this report.On the one hand, I understand that business secrets require special protection, especially in times of increasing industrial espionage.Nevertheless, I cannot agree with the report as it stands, as it could put any whistleblowers under too much pressure.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: in writing. - This report concerns a proposal for a directive on business secrets, introducing a harmonized system for the protection of business secrets and know-how in the European Union. Trade secrets are legal instruments that allow companies to protect some of their professional information and conceal it from third parties (journalists, civil society) but also to impose confidentiality on employees and their representatives. Trade secrets have, for example, been regularly invoked in the United States with regard to the composition of products used for the extraction of shale gas, despite the risks these products pose to the environment. In addition, business secrets are often used against journalists, unions or whistleblowers who publish information about illegal business activities, such as tax evasion. Thus, with such a directive, the cursor of protection is placed on the side of business and endangers the freedom of expression of journalists and whistleblowers who act in the common interest. I voted against this report.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - Considering that European companies invest heavily in innovation and know-how development; whereas such investments increase the competitiveness of businesses and that to defend their discoveries, they themselves resort to practices such as intellectual property law and trade secrets, the latter being particularly common among SMEs; also considering that the risk of undue and illicit disclosure of data by third parties can represent a deterrent for European entrepreneurs to the development of new ideas and projects; considering also that the TRIPS agreement already contains rules on trade secrets; considered it necessary to reiterate, in addition, that an integrated approach at European level would not only make the protection of entrepreneurs more effective, but would simplify the existing legislation in the various Member States; considering, finally, that the proposal for a directive in this regard is not in conflict with EU and national rules, in particular those which allow the disclosure of information to the competent authorities in specific cases; Finally, given that my colleague's proposal also serves to revive fair competition, I would vote in favor.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The unauthorised use of confidential business information by persons other than the holder is unfair practice and an infringement of trade secrets. Whether through thorough and costly research, long experience, or creativity, companies constantly develop information which can help them to perform better, faster or at lower cost. Since European companies are increasingly exposed to the misappropriation of trade secrets, I support their protection and, therefore, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I supported the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of undisclosed knowledge and experience and business information (trade secrets) from unauthorized acquisition, use or disclosure. The issue of protection of trade secrets is crucial for the success of a particular company in the market and its competitiveness in market competition, but also a challenge, both for the policy of hiring quality workers and their retention within the company. I support the proposal for a common definition of business secrets and the setting of general principles applicable to Member States in terms of enforcement instruments that should prevent the disclosure of business secrets. Protection procedures should not be administratively demanding, and care should be taken to protect business secrets during possible litigation. Finally, I note that employees should not be prevented from using the acquired experience and skills when changing jobs. It is precisely labor mobility that is crucial for a competitive EU economy, and the exchange of knowledge and the acquisition of work experience during a professional career contributes to the success of the individual, but also of the companies in which he is employed.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - The proposal to protect trade secrets from unauthorized acquisition, use or disclosure is particularly important for identifying rules that improve the competitiveness of European companies through innovation, and the wider improvement of the European Union's image as a world market leader in the industrial sector. During the process of researching and creating new ideas, products and services, there is a lot of information necessary to maximize future competitiveness, so trade secrets, their acquisition, use and publication, need to be protected and regulated at European level. Importantly, this Directive ensures that Member States respect freedom of the press and media, do not jeopardize or infringe fundamental rights and freedoms or the public interest, such as public safety, consumer protection, public health and the environment, and in no way without compromising worker mobility. For all the above, I welcome this directive of the European Parliament.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The directive in question aims to protect knowledge and trade secrets from illegal use, acquisition and disclosure, in particular to protect companies and non-commercial research institutions. According to the proposal, the investment in intellectual capital generates competitiveness and innovative performance in the market and, thus, it enhances financial return, which is one of the fundamental reasons for the investigation. If there is no security in this process, there is, they say, an obstacle to innovation. We talk about protecting small and medium-sized companies, when we know that safeguarding trade secrets and extending their scope serves, above all, large economic groups. The commercial secret to which everything must be subjected, until the judicial action, becomes absolute. Everything in defense of the supreme interests of capital. It is clear, of course, to mention the role of this directive in promoting the Digital Single Market. The Commission's proposal is not improved by Parliament's proposed amendments, which essentially confirm the logic of yielding to the economic and financial interests of companies, disregarding the rights, freedoms and guarantees of workers, consumers and citizens in general . Neither position fully guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, whistleblowers, journalists. They do not guarantee the rights of citizens, their health or the environment. We voted against.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - Although Europe is a leader in science and innovation, it lags behind other trading partners, such as Japan and the US, in terms of business involvement in these sectors. As a member of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, I very much welcome and support the proposal for this directive, which is also part of the wider Europe 2020 strategy, in which the Commission is committed to creating an Innovation Union. This directive is a further step towards creating a better environment for business innovation and a more favorable environment for new projects. The need to adopt this Directive stems from differences in the protection of business secrets between Member States. In particular, there are major shortcomings in the definition of trade secrets and the specification of when it is to be protected. Many Member States do not even have rules that seek to protect trade secrets during court proceedings, which discourages the injured party from seeking redress in court. That is why I find this proposal a great contribution to addressing these shortcomings at EU level. I would like to emphasize here that not only I but also the entire S&D Group have strictly ensured that the protection of whistleblowers and journalists is not violated, as they are clearly excluded from the scope of this law.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- Harmonization of legal procedures and remedies against the illegal acquisition, disclosure and use of trade secrets at EU level needs to be accompanied by a clear understanding of the scope and definition of the matter in question.Therefore, the definition of a trade secret needs to be clarified.The new directive will be the only point of reference at Union level, in the context of the negotiations for the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership Agreement (TTIP), and will ensure an adequate level of defense against unfair trading practices.Furthermore, it is important to underline that the protection of trade secrets does not create property rights, but intends to counter the illicit nature of their acquisition, disclosure and use.I therefore believe that it is right to vote in favor of the new directive.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: in writing. - I consider the protection of undisclosed know-how and business information to be an indisputable right of various companies, non-profit research organizations and other communities that invest considerable funds in the acquisition, development and use of this knowledge, and thus the inviolability of trade secrets should be guaranteed. ownership. At the same time, it is necessary to emphasize the introduction of legislation that addresses this issue. As we work to promote sustainable development, poverty reduction, small and medium-sized enterprises, the private sector and its cooperation with the public sector, the importance of protecting trade secrets needs to be emphasized, as this guarantees a clear competitive advantage for holders of this information. adversely affected their economy. The issue of trade secret protection should be actively addressed at the level of individual Member States in order to establish a quality and friendly environment for trade, business, science, research and investment in other sectors in all countries of the European Union.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the emergence of new rules which will help companies that are victims of the theft or abuse of trade secret data to obtain redress.In fact, one in five companies is a victim of theft of their trade secrets every year.By voting for this text, the European Parliament is promoting a safe and reliable environment for companies which must see their know-how fully protected.Also, freedom of expression and information are fully preserved.In this sense, this text does not contravene freedom of the press and the work of journalists, in particular in the investigations they carry out but also in matters of source protection, is protected.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - This Directive lays down rules on protection against the illegal acquisition, use and disclosure of confidential know-how and commercial information (trade secrets). Companies and non-commercial research institutions invest in the acquisition, development and application of know-how and information, which are the currency of the knowledge economy and provide a competitive advantage. This investment in the generation and application of intellectual capital determines its competitiveness and its innovative performance in the market and, consequently, its return on investment. I am pleased with the positive vote in this directive because, in addition to the above, it will not affect freedom of movement for workers or freedom of establishment. It is essential to raise awareness, especially for SMEs, of the possibility of recourse and redress in the event of illegal acquisition, use or disclosure of trade secrets.

name: Dominique RIQUET
text: in writing. - Contrary to what has been said on social media, this directive is a balanced text which both guarantees additional protection for SMEs and protects journalistic investigation and journalists' sources. Indeed, this directive intends to respond to the growing risks to which SMEs (especially the most innovative) are exposed due to globalization, in the face of unfair practices of stealing trade secrets, while fighting against unfair competition and ensuring greater harmonization and transparency within the Union. My political group in Parliament has helped ensure that all arrangements are in place to guarantee and preserve the right to freedom of expression and information. It is also the first time that a legal text specifically mentions and protects whistleblowers. Thus, the directive guarantees journalists full protection when their action is used to denounce an illegal practice and, more broadly, when it is motivated by the defense of the general interest (public safety and health, protection of consumers and the environment…). I voted for this text because it meets a real need for security for SMEs and guarantees freedom of expression and information in the Union.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- Although it is not a perfect directive (the definition of trade secrets remains too broad), S & amp; D has managed to introduce many safeguard points for media freedom of expression, protection of whistleblowers and the application of Union or European law.national law.It is the best possible result.At this point, the text could no longer be changed in plenary.S & amp; D would not get a majority to reject the directive and the only alternative would be a new negotiation without S & amp; D.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated once again the important role that informants and the press play. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and the freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempt from the scope of this Directive. The S & amp; D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to access. disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the Council's position at first reading with a view to the adoption of the directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of individuals with regard to the processing of personal datapersonnel by the competent authorities for the purposes of preventing and detecting criminal offenses, investigating and prosecuting them or executing criminal sanctions, and for the free movement of such data, and repealing Framework Decision 2008/ 977 / JHA of the Council.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this directive.While the initial European Commission proposal was far too vague and dangerous, the Socialist and Democrats group improved it considerably during the discussion.The text presented to the European Parliament therefore constitutes a satisfactory and balanced compromise.It aims to protect companies, and in particular SMEs, against industrial espionage while guaranteeing a high level of protection of the freedom to inform.By excluding freedom of the press from the scope of this directive and by introducing safeguards to protect whistleblowers, Parliament has made it possible to balance this text which will in fact make it possible to improve the situation of those whoact for the general interest throughout the European Union.

name: Fernando RUAS
text: in writing. - I supported the European Parliament's legislative resolution on the proposal for a European Parliament and Council directive on the protection of confidential business information and know-how (trade secrets) against its illegal acquisition, use and disclosure. In the era of globalization, in which there is a greater exposure of trade secrets to theft, espionage and other illegitimate appropriation techniques, it is important to create conditions for greater protection of trade secrets, which are an extremely relevant component for small and medium-sized companies, such as still with those that are in their start-up phase and that need protection of their intellectual property rights. More broadly, this proposal is part of the commitment to create a single market for intellectual property, which is solid, coherent, effective in the legal clarity and the level playing field that it confers on all European companies, defending their legitimate trade secrets more effectively across the European Union, without jeopardizing public interest and security or harming rights, fundamental freedoms and consumer protection.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - As explained in the report submitted to the Parliament, some Member States have rules to protect against the illegal appropriation of trade secrets, while others do not even have rules defining this concept. This situation creates gaps and damages the functioning of the internal market, as Europe is one of the most advanced areas in terms of research and innovation. This is why it was important, through the vote of Parliament, to approve the European Commission's proposal for a directive. My vote in favor therefore wants to pursue, in the spirit of the directive, the objective of giving our companies an extra guarantee to improve their competitiveness, offering them a clear and uniform legal framework at European level, which allows them to establish the criteria of confidentiality on which a company can rely in the relationship with its collaborators and with other companies. The European market is thus strengthened within the global industrial market.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We voted against this proposal for a Directive aimed at protecting companies from the theft of secrets by their competitors in the market.The directive initially drawn up by the European Commission clearly favored the protection of economic rights at the expense of the political rights of citizens.Unfortunately, and despite some improvements, the text resulting from the inter-institutional negotiations and commitments reached subsequently continues to contain restrictions on fundamental rights that we consider unacceptable.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against this report because it supposes an arbitrary definition of industrial secrecy that can revert in favor of tax evasion, as well as give more power to private companies against potential informants.After the successive scandals in Luxembourg and Panama, the need to protect the informants who have brought this information to the public has been demonstrated, however this proposal for a Directive does not protect the aforementioned informants, since they did not provide "illegal" information.In this way, this Directive gives tremendous power to private companies that in the name of competitiveness can take all kinds of legal actions against the aforementioned informants.It is because of the dire need to protect these contemporary heroes in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance that I have decided to vote against this report.

name: Remo SERNAGIOTTO
text: in writing.- The report voted today on the proposal for a directive on the protection of trade secrets is intended to harmonize national laws and protect European companies from industrial espionage.I voted in favor because, thanks to this directive, every Member State will be required to offer holders of trade secrets or confidential technical information strong legal protection in civil matters against the unlawful acquisition, use or disclosure of their secret information.In addition, a number of tools will be implemented to remedy the unlawful appropriation and use of trade secrets.In this way, researchers, companies and inventors will be uniformly protected at European level from the danger deriving from industrial espionage, which very often unfortunately discourages the creation of start-ups and innovative companies, engines of economic growth and employment.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Labour is working tirelessly at every level of government to defend worker mobility and ensure that big corporations cannot hide evidence of wrongdoing or pressure employees into not revealing illegal activities like fraud. I have joined my Labour colleagues by voting in favour of this legislative report because of my own personal commitment, which is in line with the work of the Labour Party.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing.- There is a lot of information that is necessary for the competitiveness of an idea or society and which is not covered by intellectual property rights protection and which needs to be protected.It is important and necessary to regulate at European level the acquisition, use and disclosure of trade secrets.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - The proposal of the directive brings a very broad definition of business secrets, and there is a danger that certain criminal activities in business will be protected by this directive. The interest of the public was endangered, because the whistleblowers were not adequately protected. With this directive, businesses have the exclusive right to secrecy, which calls into question fundamental freedoms versus the protection of business secrets. Also, the directive interferes in several areas, such as the right to access information, insufficient protection of whistleblowers, the ability of workers to change jobs due to possible disclosure of a trade secret. The proposal for a directive could be linked to the recent negotiations on trade secrets under TTIP. There is a trade secret initiative in the U.S. at the federal level as well. The proposal for the directive has been criticized by civil society and journalists, and an online petition has been launched, which so far has more than 150,000 signatories, with the aim of protecting whistleblowers at European level. Current scandals, such as LuxLeaks and Panama Papers, point to the importance of whistleblower and investigative journalism for the public interest. Due to the lack of whistleblower protection at European level, jeopardizing the public interest by denying the right of access to information and sending the wrong political message following the recent Panama Papers scandal, I cannot support this proposal for a directive.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I agreed with the proposal for a directive on the protection of business secrets, as the amendments have succeeded in incorporating a number of improvements to the Commission's original proposal. The Trade Secrets Directive aims to protect European businesses that may be exposed to economic espionage at European or international level. So far, there has been no measure at European level to address this issue. At the same time, legislation on this matter differs across Member States, as some have a high level of trade secret protection and some do not at all. I am therefore pleased that agreement has been reached on legislation that will protect innovative approaches by businesses in accordance with intellectual property agreements. I also welcome the fact that, despite the Council's opposition, the protection of whistleblowers has been maintained, in which this directive is unprecedented. Parliament has also managed to exclude freedom of the media and freedom of expression from the legislative text. Strong guarantees for workers 'mobility, workers' right to information and representation have been ensured. Overall, I consider the current form of the proposal to be balanced and I believe that it will have a positive impact on a wide range of companies.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - A trade secret contains valuable information for the company (undisclosed expertise and business information) that is treated as confidential, thus giving the company a competitive advantage. Until now, trade secrets have been protected in various EU Member States through a combination of civil, competition and / or labor law. The Commission published a proposal for a directive in November 2013, with a view to harmonizing the protection of business secrets at EU level in order to promote cross-border trade within the internal market. The directive would thus, for the first time, introduce uniform and harmonized legislation on the protection of business secrets at EU level. However, only a minimum level of harmonization is envisaged, so there could actually be differences between Member States. In addition, the definition of a trade secret is very broad. Exceptions for freedom of expression and information, for freedom of the press / media and for the protection of whistleblowing activities are not sufficient. Business secrecy would become the rule, without a satisfactory guarantee to protect citizens who disclose information in the public interest. This directive gives companies excessive rights of secrecy, but public interest in information could also lead to the abuse of unscrupulous companies across Europe. Among other things, the directive lacks a balance between the fundamental freedoms, which is why I voted against the adoption of the directive.

name: Bart STAES
text: written.- I am against this European law that should better protect trade secrets, because it makes it more difficult for whistleblowers to report abuses within companies.If this law is passed, it will be even easier for companies to keep abuses under wraps.While whistleblowers have recently been essential for revelations about cheating car manufacturers and tax-evading multinationals!They deserve protection instead of punishment.The Green Group in the European Parliament is asking for the vote to be postponed.We do not want the European Parliament to vote on the protection of trade secrets until a bill on the comprehensive protection of whistleblowers in the European Union is on the table.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- The protection of data, business and trade secrets is of vital importance for many companies of all sizes.With this regulation, this area will be better protected.At the same time, whistleblowing remains possible via the exceptions in Article 4.In a common internal market, it makes sense to implement this regulation at European level.That is why I voted for the Le Grip report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- One in five companies in the EU is a victim of theft of confidential business information.For this reason, it is important to enforce new European rules to help companies seek redress in the event of their trade secrets being unauthorized.Member States will therefore be obliged to provide injured companies with the possibility of redress through the courts.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: written.- The N-VA delegation has supported this report.It aims to counter the unlawful distribution of trade secrets.Such secrets are part of a company's capital and thus deserve protection.Nevertheless, the N-VA continues to consider it important that journalists and whistleblowers can still expose social problems without fear of legal prosecution.A balance was sought and achieved!For example, the very first article states that the directive does not apply to the media.In addition, the exceptions reiterate that the freedom of information is not affected.Finally, the introductory provisions also state that the Directive must not adversely affect whistleblower activities.Even when hindsight disclosures constitute legal business practices, the judge may choose to protect the whistleblower.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - Europe is committed to promoting science and innovation and has the potential to become a world leader in this field. However, the level of research and development carried out by companies within the Union is insufficient compared to some of the main trading partners, in particular the USA and Japan. The conditions for innovative business activities need to be improved, so in the context of the wider Europe 2020 strategy, the Commission has committed itself to establishing an Innovation Union by protecting investment in basic knowledge and creating conditions in Europe conducive to innovation. Intellectual property rights are a key part of innovation policy and seek to protect creative endeavors. Business secrets are extremely important for the protection of non-technological innovations. However, the current inconsistencies and fragmentation of the legal framework for the protection of business secrets impede the effective functioning of the internal market. It is extremely important to improve the intellectual property infrastructure and to review the protection of business secrets while making relevant information available to the citizens of the European Union. Following the above, I support this report.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the proposal and support the improvement of trade secret protection mechanisms.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of undisclosed expertise and business information (trade secrets) against their unjustified acquisition, use and disclosure.An important part of the intellectual capital of business entities in the economy are trade secrets, which are often used to gain a competitive advantage and to carry out research and development or innovation.This proposal will improve the competitiveness of the European economy through innovation, thus strengthening the EU's leading role in the global industrial market.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on protection against the unauthorized acquisition, use and disclosure of business secrets, which is a crucial area for the functioning of the internal market and the competitiveness of the EU. I agree with the additions that emphasize the importance of a balanced approach, because in addition to protecting against the unauthorized acquisition of trade secrets, it must also be borne in mind that knowledge and the flow of information are prerequisites for innovation. I also support the addition that, while some Member States already have legislation in place to protect against the misuse of business secrets, some EU countries have not even defined the concept of business secrets and have not introduced a system to protect against the misuse of business secrets. , binding legislation. These disparities hamper the effective functioning of the internal market, so there is a real need to define at EU level the situations in which the acquisition, use and disclosure of a trade secret is lawful or unauthorized. At the same time, I am in favor of ensuring that the measures contained in the directive cannot be applied in a way that unfairly restricts competition or hinders worker mobility.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - Protection against the unauthorized acquisition, disclosure and use of trade secrets is essential in providing companies with fair trading conditions. Of course, it should be remembered that the circulation of knowledge and information is also of great importance for the process of innovation and creativity. However, the companies themselves should decide when, with whom and what information they want to share. The Directive of the European Parliament and the EU Council on the protection of trade secrets offers specific solutions to combat industrial espionage. It should be emphasized that the rules on the protection of trade secrets have so far been included in many different legal acts adopted by individual Member States. Above all, there was no European definition of a trade secret, as well as a common catalog of actions that could be taken by the aggrieved entity. The creation of a common European framework for the protection of trade secrets in the form of directives is an important step towards building a secure environment for European companies, ensuring the protection of their intangible assets and expertise. At the same time, it should be noted that the adopted document contains appropriate mechanisms that minimize the risk of an inflow of unjustified claims regarding improper acquisition or circulation of business secrets.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up.- Debates on trade secrets highlight the need, but also the fragility of the balance between measures to maintain European competitiveness and the protection of fundamental rights.We cannot talk about economic performance without the freedom of the press and without protecting those who report irregularities.That being said, I am pleased to note that the political groups have succeeded in summarizing these needs in a text that lays the foundations for a clear and fair European system.Article 1 on the scope, but also Article 5 on exceptions are a step forward for actors engaged in commercial activities and a gain for European citizens.Although we do not yet have regulations at European level and the legislation in the Member States varies greatly, the current text of the directive is a positive precedent in trade secret legislation.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - Concerning the directive on "trade secrets" voted yesterday, it is necessary to protect SMEs, the main victims of the abusive disclosure of information (manufacturing process, prototype, list of customers, etc.) endangering the innovation in small businesses, competitiveness and employment. Freedom of expression must also be protected, as well as whistleblowers and journalists, thanks to whom scandalous behavior such as the Panama Papers and Luxleaks are regularly brought to light. It is useful to clarify that this text deals with "trade secrets" and contains for the first time in European law provisions which will protect whistleblowers. This is a first step. Nevertheless, it seemed to me essential that the Commission undertake to propose legislation of their own; what she did not do! This is the reason why I abstained. Our desire is to encourage whistleblowers and journalists so that they can continue their investigative work so useful to the general interest. I regret that a real campaign of disinformation has been carried out on the content of this directive; which deeply serves the citizen.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The establishment of European protection of trade secrets has worried many European Union citizens since its adoption last week. The aim of this law is to shield innovative companies against corporate espionage, by protecting their know-how and business information. This is particularly important for SMEs and start-ups, especially in the digital sector, as they have been suffering most from these unlawful activities and do not necessarily have the financial resources to patent their work or use other intellectual rights. Parliament also amended the text initially proposed by the Commission to make sure that our fundamental freedoms, such as freedom of the press and of information, the media’s liberty and pluralism, as well as investigative journalism continue being guaranteed. Moreover, this is the first time that the protection of whistle-blowers has been included in a legislative text at EU level.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: in writing. - A "trade secret" is information that companies protect to preserve, for example, their trade secrets. While the initial draft had major flaws, MEPs fought to amend the directive because the risk of endangering whistleblowers existed. Thus, the final text introduces new rights for citizens and journalists. For journalists, the text provides that the disclosure of the alleged business secret results from "the exercise of the right to freedom of expression" and specifies that the directive cannot achieve "respect for the freedom and pluralism of media". For whistleblowers, we are also creating new protections: “revealing a fault, inappropriate behavior or illegal activity” in order to “protect the general public interest” cannot be considered. as a breach of trade secrets. This text constitutes significant progress. It will protect companies' production processes, while providing protection for whistleblowers and journalists. However, there are still gray areas and the European Socialists call on the Commission to extend this progress: we are asking for a comprehensive text on the protection of whistleblowers!

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the proposal to protect unpublished knowledge and experience and business information (business secrets) from unauthorized acquisition, use or disclosure. Regardless of their size, companies consider trade secrets to be as valuable as other forms of intellectual property and use confidentiality as an instrument of business competitiveness and research innovation management. Business secrets are equally related to small and large companies as the use of intellectual property rights is generally expensive, and companies often do not have sufficient professional resources to manage and protect intellectual property rights. I consider it appropriate to define at Union level situations in which the acquisition, use and disclosure of a trade secret is authorized or unauthorized and that the period of application of legal protection needs to be limited so that this directive can fulfill its purpose of consistent protection of trade secrets in the European Union.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - If I were to vote on the Report on the Proposal for a Directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of undisclosed know-how and business information (trade secrets) against their unauthorized acquisition, use and disclosure, I would support it. Businesses and non-commercial research institutions invest in the acquisition, development and practical application of expertise and information, which is a currency-based economy and a competitive advantage. These investments in the creation and use of intellectual capital are crucial for their competitiveness and innovation performance in the market and thus the return on investment, which is the basic motivation for business research and development. It is appropriate to lay down rules at Union level for the convergence of national legislative systems in order to ensure a sufficient and consistent level of compensation throughout the single market for cases of unjustified acquisition, use or disclosure of a trade secret. To that end, a uniform definition of professional secrecy should be established, without limiting the content to be protected against misappropriation. Such a definition should be designed to cover business information, technological information and expertise where there is a legitimate interest in their confidentiality and a legitimate expectation that such confidentiality will be maintained.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing. ‒ In the absence of harmonisation of rules regarding trade secrets, European companies may not be protected from misappropriation in the same way throughout the European Union. This directive establishes legal remedies on a European level in order to guarantee a certain level of protection and a consistent framework. Concerns were raised as to whether the Directive would infringe on the right to freedom of expression and the right to information, however specific provisions in the Directive ensure that there are safeguards which protect these rights. Through those provisions it is ensured, for example, that journalists and whistle-blowers are protected in addition to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. Due to this well-balanced approach to the protection of rights of companies, the directive has to be supported. Especially in order to ensure the protection of smaller companies, which more often rely on trade secrets than on the IP framework due to the costs involved.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We voted against this proposal for a Directive aimed at protecting companies from the theft of secrets by their competitors in the market.The directive initially drawn up by the European Commission clearly favored the protection of economic rights at the expense of the political rights of citizens.Unfortunately, and despite some improvements, the text resulting from the inter-institutional negotiations and commitments reached subsequently continues to contain restrictions on fundamental rights that we consider unacceptable.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This directive aims to protect the trade secrets of European companies, including SMEs, against economic espionage.The text proposed better protection for whistleblowers, which I of course supported.I am obviously in favor of increased protection for our companies and especially our SMEs against economic espionage.France performs well in many cutting-edge fields such as aviation and IT and these companies must be able to exercise their know-how without fear of a potential threat of espionage.I therefore voted for this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- One of the keys to ensuring a fair business environment for businesses is protection against the unauthorized acquisition, disclosure and use of trade secrets.However, it is important to recall that the flow of knowledge and information is also essential for innovation and the creative process.Businesses often have more interest in sharing trade secrets than keeping them secret.At the same time, transparency and access to information are also needed for informed public policy-making, such as the environment, health and consumer protection.I supported it with my vote.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We voted against this proposal for a Directive aimed at protecting companies from the theft of secrets by their competitors in the market.The directive initially drawn up by the European Commission clearly favored the protection of economic rights at the expense of the political rights of citizens.Unfortunately, and despite some improvements, the text resulting from the inter-institutional negotiations and commitments reached subsequently continues to contain restrictions on fundamental rights that we consider unacceptable.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: written.- I voted against this report because I consider that it represents an excessive risk for informants, the whistelblowers who provide information to society that is essential to uncover unacceptable business behavior.Thus, Snowden, Deltour, Falciani, among many other informants, already threatened by different state legal frameworks, would also be excluded from the protection of a European legal framework.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- We are talking about an issue that requires progress at European level.It is necessary to advance in the harmonization of the protection of commercial secrets as this proposal does, since the European Single Market needs harmonization in this regard to avoid the illegal obtaining, use and disclosure of commercial secrets, especially taking into account the growingimportance and presence of information technologies in our society, which favor a growing interconnection at the community level.For all these reasons, I consider it necessary to vote in favor of said report.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - The recent revelations of the Panama Papers have demonstrated once again the important role that informants and the press play. It is imperative that individuals acting in the common interest are protected by law. For this reason, I have voted in favor of this directive, because it guarantees the protection of the rights of workers, informants and the freedom of the press, thus formalizing a clear legal framework, which guarantees that those who expose illegal or unethical activities, in the situation in which it is a question of defending a public interest in general, they are exempt from the scope of this Directive. The S & amp; D Group has also asked the European Commission to urgently present new proposals to guarantee these measures. It has also been possible to guarantee the autonomy of the social partners, the express exclusion of impediments to the mobility of workers that could arise from the original text of the Directive, the right to information and consultation, as well as the protection of the right to access. disclosure of information regarding the operation of the company by workers to their representatives, as part of the legitimate exercise of the functions of the latter.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of this proposal that aims to protect trade secrets.It is critical for our European companies to be protected from economic espionage.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - In the midst of the "Panama papers" scandal, the European Parliament voted by a large majority for "business secrecy". This directive will allow companies to protect and withhold certain information and impose confidentiality clauses on their employees and representatives.
