In other words, large companies will be able to hide crucial information, for example in health or environmental matters! For example, the chemical composition of products used for shale gas extraction is considered a trade secret in the United States. This directive therefore represents a direct threat to whistleblowers, journalists, trade unionists and company employees. The European Parliament has certainly achieved some progress, but they remain hypothetical until a text really protecting whistleblowers is adopted. It has been "promised" by the Commission for the month of June. The vote on the two texts should have been linked. I voted against this directive.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- This legislation represents a compromise to the economic and financial interests of companies.We vote against.It is not clear what the trade secret means.The rights of workers, whistleblowers, journalists are not fully safeguarded.It is not completely ensured that the rights of citizens, their health, the environment are guaranteed.It is a project that essentially starts from the economic interest and disregards the rights, freedoms and guarantees of workers, consumers and citizens in general.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- As such, I support the aim and purpose of the report, but I cannot support individual points.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Le Grip report on the protection of know-how and trade secrets against its illegal acquisition, use and disclosure, which proposes an unprecedented text for the protection of whistleblowers.I welcome the proposals put forward by the socialist group that have substantially improved the initial text proposed by the European Commission, particularly with regard to the exclusion of freedom of the press and the guarantees achieved regarding the mobility of workers, the right to information, as well as safeguardsregarding the disclosure of confidential information to public authorities.I also underline the call made by the socialist group for the European Commission to urgently propose a directive for the protection of whistleblowers.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- Innovative companies are increasingly exposed to unfair practices aimed at misappropriating trade secrets through theft, illegal copying, economic espionage or breaches of confidentiality requirements originating inside or outside the Union.That is why I supported the report on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of undisclosed expertise and business information, as I believe that it is necessary to ensure adequate protection of the confidentiality of business secrets.Business secrets play an important role in making a profit and maintaining business competitiveness.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - When it comes to the budget, the budget of the European Union or the European Parliament, the question always arises as to who pays the pilot? And they always look down on us, Central and Eastern Europeans, those from poorer countries, and we keep getting comments so that, let alone we do not talk, we do not make our own provisions, we do not think independently about migration and others, because we are so we pay little and bezzeg how much we get. It would be great now to finally be aware of this issue in a wide variety of areas. It's enough that I'm just talking about farmland. Either way, we have not been able to ensure that Hungarian arable land does not fall into foreign hands. These are things that don’t count when you look at how much we pay, how much sacrifice we make. But now a very serious movement is finally starting to review the accession treaty, so that Hungarian arable land can never fall into foreign hands. Thanks.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President.As with any institution dealing with a wide range of issues, of course, Parliament needs financial resources, but it should be noted that the current estimate includes a possible increase in next year's budget to EUR 1 900 873 000, which is an increase of 3.4%.It is clear that it is imperative for us MEPs to think about the economical use of economic resources.Consequently, I supported the amendments which did not make it compulsory for Members to fly in business class within the European Union; Members can, in principle, also pay for parking in Parliament - all of these ideas are deep, deeply sympathetic to me.I hope that my colleagues and Parliament as a whole will use these funds very carefully, sparingly and, in general, that I will, of course, support this Indrek Tarand report.Thanks!

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom díriú ar dhá phointe. An chéad phointe ná go bhfuil an-áthas orm gur ghlac an Pharlaimint leis na moltaí anseo inniu, agus ceann de na moltaí, baineann sé leis an teanga ina bhfuilim ag labhairt anois – an teanga ársa uasal Ghaelach. Don teanga sin, táimid anois ag cur airgead ar fáil; suas le EUR 3.7 milliún chun seirbhisí Gaeilge a bheith againn sa Pharlaimint agus san Aontas, go háirithe chun aistritheoirí a fhostú chun aistriúcháin a dhéanamh ar dhoiciméid oifigiúla. Taispeánann sé go bhfuil an tAontas i bhfabhar teangacha beaga, an Ghaeilge ach go háirithe, agus go bhfuil siad sásta airgead a chur ar fáil chuige. Dá bhrí sin, mo mhíle buíochas do gach duine as é sin a dhéanamh.  An dara pointe baineann sé leis an vóta faoin suíomh aonair i Strasbourg nó sa Bhruiséil. Vótáil 474 i bhfabhar agus 118 i gcoinne. Taispeánann sé go bhfuil sé in am dúinn deireadh a chur leis an dá shuíomh.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The reduction of the costs of politics is a battle that the Movement carries out in all necessary places.This forecast for the year 2017 describes an increase of 3.9% compared to the 2016 budget. Unfortunately, the expenditure for political parties and European foundations has not been rationalized, the allowances for Members have not been reduced andthe various expenses related to their function.For these reasons I would have decided to vote negatively.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I voted against Parliament's spending forecast for 2017 as in my opinion the resources available to Parliament are not being used correctly.It has increased exponentially in spending on security and cybersecurity, while also increasing the budget with unnecessary expenses such as the renovation of offices.But on the contrary, it has been decided to cut the item for interpretation and the proposal to introduce sign language has not been accepted.If it is necessary to make cuts, these should be made in the area of the salary of MPs or travel expenses, since Parliament continues to pay for bussiness flights for MEPs.Finally, we continue with the perennial problem of waste of maintaining the two seats of the European Parliament.For these reasons I have voted absolutely against.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: in writing. - I voted against this report on the forecast of revenue and expenditure for the European Parliament for the financial year 2017. This report indeed provides for an overall increase of 4.3% compared to the 2016 budget with a total amount of 1.9 billion euros! Even if among the main expenses mentioned is the increase in security and cyber-security spending, the strengthening of the means made available to Members in the exercise of their mandate is also topical as well as the strengthening of the attraction of the European Parliament for the public ... Paradoxically with the astronomical increase in the budget, this text encourages, in the most hypocritical way that it is, to seek means to make savings. The European Parliament must obviously put in place real measures aimed at containing expenditure, or even drastically reducing it, while ensuring the protection of the site and associated personnel. This is not the case in this forecast of Parliament expenditure, so I opposed this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Any budgetary increase at all is unacceptable in the current economic climate. I supported various amendments aimed at limiting increases, or at cutting costs. It is disappointing that the amendment to cut MEPs’ salaries and expenses was deemed inadmissible. I voted against the final report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, which only concerns the European Parliament's budgetary guidelines for 2017, not the final budget which will be voted on in the autumn. First of all, I welcome the fact that the increase in current expenditure forecast by the Secretary-General has been reduced from 1.9% to 1.4%. However, the introduction of Gaelic entailed an additional cost: it increased the level of credits by 0.2%. I regret it, but it is a legal obligation, Gaelic being one of the official languages ​​of the European Union. Security represents the biggest volume of increase. It had been the subject of an exceptional allocation of 15 million last year and was registered this year for an amount of 37 million raised to 47 million after the attacks of March 22. Due to events, we did not obtain the evaluations justifying this increase. The required analyzes must be carried out by the fall. If the security expenditure is not justified at that time, I will draw the consequences and reconsider my position. Finally, I am delighted that the Secretary General has made a commitment to change the presentation of Parliament's budget in 2018, separating current and investment expenditure.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the estimates of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017.The EP calls on the Secretary-General to present a proposal for the publication of the budget to the general public, ensuring that it is presented in a comprehensive, comprehensible and user-friendly way on Parliament's website so that all citizens have a better understanding of Parliament's activities, priorities and relevant spending models.I support the calls for a medium- and long-term budget plan, including clear information on security and cyber security costs.It is also important to develop reforms aimed at greater efficiency, environmental sustainability and efficiency.I agree that a lot of money could be saved if the institution had only one job instead of three (Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg).

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this resolution as paragraph 7 reaffirmed that the budget for the EU Parliament (which British taxpayers pay for) would increase overall. UKIP supported amendments which called for cuts to EU budgets, staffing and the abolition of the MEP chauffeur service. Whilst public services are being cut in the UK it outrageous for MEPs and EU bureaucrats to receive more money from British taxpayers.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- While the European Parliament continues to advocate a policy of budgetary austerity to respond to the current economic crisis, I can only oppose this report on the provisional statement of the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure for the2017, which provides for an overall increase in Parliament's budget of 4.3% compared to the 2016 budget, in order to strengthen the security and attraction of the European Parliament for the public and visitors or to increase the resources made availableof deputies during their mandate.Rather than favoring budget increases, Parliament must save on its own expenses and thus be less expensive on our taxpayers' money.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I approved this provisional statement for the 2017 revenue of Parliament.The report stresses that the latter must have sufficient means to exercise its primary mission of legislative body and budgetary authority and that, in the current economic context, these resources must be managed with rigor, pragmatism and efficiency.The report also observes that, while the desire to ensure a sufficient level of funding for Parliament is appropriate for the exercise of European democracy, efforts to seek ways to save money and to make the use even more efficientpublic funds are strongly encouraged.He also underlines that the major part of the Parliament's budget and its annual indexation are fixed by legal or contractual obligations which the European Parliament cannot influence during the budgetary procedure.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the Tarand report on the estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017. This is an important text which defines the amount of resources available in the Parliament's budget to ensure that Members and staff are correct progress of activities. Taking into account the new risk context linked to terrorist attacks, the new budget provides for an increase in the resources intended for strengthening security measures and in particular for IT security. In the current economic context, the commitment remains strong to manage resources rigorously and effectively, guaranteeing an adequate level of funding for the European Parliament and democracy and at the same time encouraging efforts to save and improve the effectiveness in the use of public funds. The report requests the Secretary General to formulate a proposal to publish the budget on the Parliament's website in a detailed and legible manner. This measure will enable all European citizens to gain a better understanding of activities, priorities and spending dynamics.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We have voted in favor of this report on the forecast of income and expenses of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017, because we welcome some measures of cuts in superfluous expenses that the rapporteur proposes, the general lines in which it moves are correct,and we choose to give our support at this point in the construction of the budget.This is not an obstacle for us to have shown our disagreement with several statements in this report, to which we table two amendments, since we consider that the budget of the European Parliament, in times of crisis like this, should always set an example of humility and austerity.and when these cuts are not an inconvenience to legislative work and parliamentary work and do not jeopardize jobs.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- This report concerns the forecast of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017. It reports that the General Secretariat of the European Parliament wants to increase the budget of the European Parliament to 1.9 billion euros, an increaseoverall 4.3% compared to the 2016 budget!The reasons given are the needs in terms of security, the increase in the means granted to deputies and the needs of Parliament to allow visits from citizens.Paradoxically, the report wants to encourage the means of making savings and making the use of public funds more efficient, nevertheless this is in total contradiction with the increase in the budget that it is operating even as the Union demands austerity from the peoples of Europe.growing.So I voted against it.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The report on the European Parliament's estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017 presents some interesting insights but totally lacks any criticism of unnecessary propaganda spending that could be easily cut.I therefore did not intend to support the text and I voted against it.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the estimates of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017. Parliament advocates transparency, accessibility and clarity of information and decisions, and therefore calls on the Secretary-General to present a proposal for the publication of the budget to the general public, ensuring that it is presented in a comprehensive, comprehensible and user-friendly way on Parliament's website. understanding of Parliament's activities, priorities and relevant spending models. The European Parliament considers that structural and organizational reforms aimed at greater efficiency, environmental sustainability and efficiency should be pursued after a thorough examination of the potential for synergies and cost savings. It should be noted that significant savings could be made if the institution had only one job instead of three (Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg). This process should be carried out without compromising Parliament's legislative powers, budgetary and scrutiny powers or the quality of working conditions for Members, assistants and staff. Parliament also urges the Secretary-General to submit a detailed report on the implementation of the administrative parts of the cooperation agreements between Parliament, the Committee of the Regions and the European Economic and Social Committee and to draw up possible agreements on further administrative cooperation in logistics, infrastructure or security.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- The statement of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017 reflects the agreement reached between the Bureau of the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgets on Parliament's draft budget for 2017.The main points of the agreement are: EUR 47.64 million in additional resources for security investments in 2017 and EUR 3.7 million for the introduction of Irish as an official language;not counting the above amounts on the other lines, reduces the draft of the Bureau of the European Parliament by EUR 20 million so that the budget increase in 2017 does not exceed 1.4% compared to 2016;and the introduction of a new budget line in the EP budget to finance construction.Based on the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported the report on the estimates of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017. As proposed by the Secretary-General in his report, the 2017 budget will continue and strengthen the institution's policy of saving in all areas where possible.to jeopardize the quality of the working environment of Members and staff.Four priority objectives are proposed: security and cyber security, the phasing out of the derogation for Irish, which is thus becoming a full-fledged official language of the EU, ongoing measures to support Members in their mandate, and increase the European Parliament's visibility.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the forecast of the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017 fits perfectly within the parameters set for Parliament's operating budget under the Union budget.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This report on the forecast of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament provides for a budget of around 1.9 billion euros for the 2017 financial year, an increase of 4.3% compared to 2016This budgetary inflation is intended to finance the increase in security and cybersecurity spending, to increase the means made available to Members in the exercise of their mandate or to strengthen the attractiveness of the European Parliament.While our fellow citizens undergo on a daily basis the austerity cures imposed by the Commission on the Member States, Brussels technocrats squander taxpayers' money by increasing the budget of the European Parliament.That is why I voted against this scandalous report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The priority objectives of the European Parliament's budget for 2017 should be to strengthen cybersecurity and security, make spending more efficient, increase the transparency of the institution's work and the attractiveness of the institution to the public and facilitate the work of Members in the mandate. The recent attacks in Brussels have raised a serious alarm about the safety of European Parliament staff and buildings. Strict security measures and an effective control system can prevent possible tragedies. Initiatives aimed at replacing paper with digital media, simplifying working methods, and reducing the number of working languages ​​would significantly contribute to reducing costs and streamlining activities. Support for Members should also include support measures tailored to the specific requirements of their work. I regret that sometimes the proposed solutions take less into account the cost-effectiveness, and the suggestions of the deputies are not implemented. I spoke in favor of this report because I am convinced that safety, efficiency and transparency are the priorities of the budget allocated to the European Parliament in 2017.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- I am voting against the usual own-initiative report which comments on the budget proposal for the coming year.The text also contains interesting references, but the tone and level of criticism are definitely insufficient.Certain levels of expenditure can only be reduced by drastic interventions, especially in sectors that the large political groups will never want to touch and which are linked to Parliament's "communication" projects through communication initiatives aimed at citizens for mere propaganda purposes (Parlamentarium, Casa dellaEuropean history, Information Offices).Not to mention the novelty of the internalization of the driver service "for safety reasons".

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this resolution in order to ensure that Parliament is equipped with the necessary resources to be able to carry out its fundamental function as a legislative body and budgetary authority. I stress that, in the current economic context, these resources should be managed with rigor, pragmatism and effectiveness. I recall that substantial savings could be made if we moved from three locations (Brussels, Strasbourg and Luxembourg) to one location. Along the axis that divides Brussels and Strasbourg, 5 000 people move every month with an annual cost that weighs on Parliament's coffers for 200 million euros. Economic waste is aggravated by the pollution of travel in a scenario that sees the EU committed to reducing carbon dioxide emissions by 40% by 2030. I remember that the odyssey between Brussels and Strasbourg by plane, train, car, truck It costs 19,000 tonnes of CO2 a year to transport Parliament's documents each time. If governments really intend to pursue efficiency and waste reduction - particularly within the EU institutions - a single seat for the European Parliament is a good place to start. This is what MEPs and citizens of Europe are asking for!

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it affirms that this budget will be a continuation and intensification of the institution’s policy of carrying out efficiency gains in all areas where these are possible without compromising the quality of the work environment of the Members and staff. The report sets out four priority objectives, namely: security and cyber-security; phasing out of the derogation for the Irish language; ongoing measures to empower Members in their mandate; and making Parliament attractive to the public and visitors. I believe that Parliament’s position is even more poignant when considering that its credibility as one arm of the budgetary authority depends to a large extent on its ability to bring its own spending under control.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Our Group and myself have voted against the report in order to express disagreement with the lack of transparency and delays in providing of information to the Members by the Parliament Bureau. I do support slight increase in expenditures presented as long as it means reinforcement of security and cyber security measures. On the other hand, I believe the EP should promote financial efficiency and avoid unnecessary spending. That’s why I have supported, for instance, the proposal not to reimburse business flights of MEPs when flying in Europe.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: in writing.- We support the report and emphasize the need to present accurately and transparently the evolution of the budget from year to year

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The report we voted on concerns the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure forecast for the financial year 2017. In recent years, the choices made at both state and Community level do not reflect the European idea as they are constantly at the expense of citizens, especially the weak. At the same time, not enough efforts have been made to provide the necessary funds to tackle unemployment or the refugee issue. This report does not focus on correcting the wrong policies and that is why I chose to vote against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this forecast of Parliament's revenue and expenditure because I think it is an excellent account of the financial objectives that the European Parliament has set itself for next year.In fact, I am of the opinion that this relationship allows a more rigorously controlled and more pragmatic management of resources in the name of saving and with the aim of greater effectiveness in the use of public funds.It was also for me a vote in favor of greater respect for fundamental principles such as transparency and readability.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It earmarks an additional EUR 3.7million for the Irish language in Parliament. It is very important that Irish has full working status in the EU and an improved level of services for those who use our native language. The funding will enable Parliament to employ more Irish language speakers and provide extra Irish—language services.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this resolution as paragraph 7 reaffirmed that the budget for the EU Parliament (which British taxpayers pay for) would increase overall. UKIP supported amendments which called for cuts to EU budgets, staffing and the abolition of the MEP chauffeur service. Whilst public services are being cut in the UK it outrageous for MEPs and EU bureaucrats to receive more money from British taxpayers.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I voted against Parliament's expenditure forecast for 2017 as, in my opinion, the resources available to Parliament are not being used correctly.It has increased exponentially in spending on security and cybersecurity, while also increasing the budget with unnecessary expenses such as the renovation of offices.But on the contrary, it has been decided to cut the item for interpretation and the proposal to introduce sign language has not been accepted.If cuts are necessary, these should be made in the area of MEPs' salaries or travel expenses, since Parliament continues to pay for MEPs for business flights.Finally, we continue with the perennial problem of waste of maintaining the two seats of the European Parliament.For these reasons I have voted absolutely against.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up.- Given the slowdown in economic growth facing Member States, the main benchmark is no longer the level of inflation forecast for 2017. I voted in favor of a budget transparency, by publishing it on Parliament's website in adetailed and easy to use by all citizens.Given recent events, updating the concept of global security is a priority.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing.- The Tarand report on Parliament's estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017 reflects the agreement between Parliament's Bureau and its Committee on Budgets on Parliament's draft budget for 2017.The agreement provides, among other things, an additional EUR 47.64 million for security investments in 2017 and EUR 3.7 million for the introduction of Gaelic as an official language.Not counting the above amounts on the other lines, the Parliament's Bureau's draft is reduced by EUR 20 million so that the budget increase in 2017 does not exceed 1.4% compared to 2016;and introduces a new budget line in the EP budget to finance construction.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- In accordance with the annual budgetary procedure, the BUDG committee prepares a draft report containing estimates of Parliament's expenditure for the following year.The report is based on the preliminary draft expenditure prepared by the Bureau on the basis of information supplied by the Secretary-General.Estimates for 2017 put Parliament's total budget at EUR 1 910 073 000.This will be an increase of 3.9% compared to the 2016 budget, with the largest increase expected due to the new security measures.The priorities for 2017 identified by the Secretary General are security and cybersecurity, the gradual phasing out of the Irish language derogation, strengthening the mandate of MEPs and making Parliament more attractive to the public and visitors.I voted in favor.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This own-initiative report stresses that the European Union and its Member States must assume more of their responsibilities in terms of security and defense.It calls on the Member States to use the tools of the common security and defense policy more effectively.It is indeed important that the funding of the Union's civilian missions and military operations be adapted to new needs.Considering that the European Union is experiencing unprecedented instability today, and that further action is necessary, I supported this report.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I voted against the resolution on revenue and expenditure for the financial year of 2017 for one very good reason. It lacks transparency with regard to the use of resources. To sum up a few of the problems with regard to this, I follow the comments of Nils Torvalds (ALDE MEP) in the plenary debate, who remarked that: ‘There is no differentiation between investments and current expenditure, there is no detailed information on how extraordinary expenditure is used in reality and no control on how different budget lines are used outside the original intention of the budget (Torvalds, 2016).’ As an MEP to whom transparency towards the EU citizen is of the utmost importance, I believe that my decision to vote against this resolution needs no further explanation.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing.- The Tarand report on Parliament's estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017 reflects the agreement reached between the Bureau of the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgets on Parliament's draft budget for 2017.The main points of the agreement are: to provide EUR 47.64 million in additional resources for security investments in 2017 and EUR 3.7 million for the introduction of Gaelic as an official language;not counting the above amounts on the other lines, reduces the draft of the Bureau of the European Parliament by EUR 20 million so that the budget increase in 2017 does not exceed 1.4% compared to 2016;and the introduction of a new budget line in the EP budget to finance construction.Based on the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: in writing.- Like almost all of the ALDE Group, I voted against the European Parliament's budget estimates for 2017 for three reasons.From a procedural point of view, it is surprising that the last arbitration results from a singular tête-à-tête between the rapporteur of the Committee on Budgets (whose powers I do not dispute) and the Secretary General of the Parliament without the slightestinvolvement of shadow rapporteurs representing different political groups.In terms of content, the reductions adopted do not seem to me to be appropriate given the way Parliament works.Others, more justified, have on the other hand fallen by the wayside.In terms of building and security policy, no serious information has been communicated to the Committee on Budgets to justify the amounts requested.All these reasons clearly justify, in my opinion, my negative vote.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: in writing.- This report on the forecast of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017 indicates that the General Secretariat of the Parliament wishes to increase the budget of this one to 1.9 billion euros for next year, ie an increase of 4.3% compared to 2016. I voted against this report which advocates the realization of savings and the rationalization of the use of public funds, while providing for an increase in the budget for 2017 to whichI do not wish to be associated.Of course, security costs are invoked, but they are accompanied by expenditure aimed at strengthening the attraction of the European Parliament for the public and visitors, which is by no means a budgetary imperative.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I did not support my colleague Tarand's report because I believe that the planned increase in the EP's draft budget does not reflect reality. According to the data, an increase of 3.9% is foreseen compared to last year's budget, with the largest share of this EUR 1 910 073 000 foreseen for new security measures. I agree that in today's situation it is important for our security to be up to standard, but I believe that it needs to be reorganized in a more functional way before additional funds can be invested in it. I also believe that funds can be saved by optimizing the work of part of Parliament's administration by streamlining language and translation services.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing.- The Tarand report on Parliament's estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017 reflects the agreement reached between the Bureau of the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgets on Parliament's draft budget for 2017.The main points of the agreement are: to provide EUR 47.64 million in additional resources for security investments in 2017 and EUR 3.7 million for the introduction of Gaelic as an official language;not counting the above amounts on the other lines, reduces the draft of the Bureau of the European Parliament by EUR 20 million so that the budget increase in 2017 does not exceed 1.4% compared to 2016;and the introduction of a new budget line in the EP budget to finance construction.Based on the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- The report contains Parliament's general directions regarding Parliament's budget for the financial year 2017. I have chosen to vote in favor of the whole report because the drafting process has been very deficient and because I do not consider it appropriate for Parliament to adopt such a detailed position.before the ordinary budgetary procedure has even started.I have in principle chosen to support writings that Parliament should place all work in one place, ie.stop moving to Strasbourg 12 times a year.I have voted against Parliament raising the budget for next year.I have also voted against some very detailed writings about compensation for travel etc.because I do not think it is relevant to deal with that kind of detailed issues.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The European Parliament's 2017 budget revenue and expenditure forecast has security and cybersecurity, the gradual abolition of the Irish language derogation, measures underway to provide more means for MEPs in the exercise of their mandate and to make Parliament attractivefor the public and visitors as main objectives.For its realization, 1 910 073 000 euros was proposed, which represents an overall increase of 3.9% in relation to the 2016 budget, of which 1.7% are considered ordinary expenses.The global increase is also justified by additional extraordinary investments of 47.6 million euros to strengthen security and cybersecurity, which corresponds to 2.6% of the global increase.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- I vote against because the report encourages us to look for ways to save money and to make the use of public funds more efficient without too much contesting the increase in the budget planned for 2017.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - This report insists on the importance of the European Parliament being efficient in the use of public resources and transparent in the rendering of accounts, a concern that, as it is generally stated, we subscribe. The dematerialization and digitalization of processes should, however, always avoid any kind of exclusion. But we cannot fail to denounce, once again, the harmful effects of cuts in budget lines such as translation and interpretation services, which seriously undermine the institution's working and working conditions and undermine the principle of multilingualism. We are sensitive to security issues, but we do not feed any insurance drift, which is also expressed here in Parliament. We firmly reject fears about the driver service and the decision to internalize those services. We defend the interests of those who work. It is unacceptable and shameful for Parliament to promote precariousness among its workers. Drivers hired from service providers are subject to immense precariousness and unfair inequality and discrimination. The European Parliament must set an example, respecting the rights of its workers and guaranteeing them conditions of stability.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as I do not agree with the budget.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. - At a time when most Member States of the Union, such as Greece, are in a state of extreme poverty and economic misery, the Secretary-General proposes an increase in the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure budget for the financial year 2017, totaling 3.4% compared to the 2016 budget. An increase of EUR 1 900 873 000, which of course did not take into account the financial constraints faced by the Member States. For the above reasons I am voting against the report A8-0131 / 2016.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ During the past legislature, Parliament agreed on a number of political priorities, which gave rise either to moderate budgetary increases or to budgetary savings. For 2016, priority should be given to the reinforcement of parliamentary work, in particular by enhancing Parliament’s legislative work as well as its capacity to scrutinise the executive, and the reinforcement of Parliament’s security of buildings and cybersecurity. In order to support the structural and organisational reforms aimed at achieving greater efficiency, environmental sustainability, and effectiveness, I voted in favour of the report.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing.- The Tarand report on Parliament's estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017 reflects the agreement reached between the Bureau of the European Parliament and the Committee on Budgets on Parliament's draft budget for 2017.The main points of the agreement are: to provide EUR 47.64 million in additional resources for security investments in 2017 and EUR 3.7 million for the introduction of Gaelic as an official language;not counting the above amounts on the other lines, reduces the draft of the Bureau of the European Parliament by EUR 20 million so that the budget increase in 2017 does not exceed 1.4% compared to 2016;and the introduction of a new budget line in the EP budget to finance construction.Based on the above, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing.- I have adopted the draft appropriations for Parliament's financial year 2017.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I have voted in favor of this report.Due to the difficult economic situation that the EU and many of its Member States are experiencing, the economic reality of the Union must be reflected in its budgets, trying to rationalize and prioritize its expenses.On the other hand, I find the proposal to simplify the European Parliament's budgets on the website very positive, as it is a good exercise in transparency.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The budget proposal is an important part of the EU budgetary policy to identify and monitor the use of funds.I support this decision to coordinate expenditure and income for 2017 and to receive a detailed overview.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We have voted IN FAVOR of this report on the forecast of income and expenses of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017, because we welcome some measures of cuts in superfluous expenses that the rapporteur proposes, the general lines in which it moves are correct,and we choose to give our support at this point in the construction of the budget.This is not an obstacle for us to have shown our disagreement with several statements in this report, to which we table two amendments, since we consider that the budget of the European Parliament, in times of crisis like this, should always set an example of humility and austerity.and when these cuts are not an inconvenience to legislative work and parliamentary work and do not endanger jobs.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this report as I fundamentally disagree that the budget of the Parliament should be increased by 3.9%, particularly in this climate of austerity. Some aspects of this report were positive, such as the necessity for security and cybersecurity to be proportionate to the risks and the call for MEPs to be more transparent with their use of the General Expenditures Allowance (something that Labour MEPs already report on).

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: in writing. - While efforts to make the use of public funds even more efficient is strongly encouraged, I believe that our institution also needs to acquire the means to match its responsibilities, which are those of a co-legislator, in particular with the strengthening of the teams in charge of parliamentary committees and legislative monitoring. That is why I voted in favor of this report and of several amendments aimed at bringing more transparency in the use of European public funds, in particular the overhead allowance of Members. I am also in favor of all expenditure making it possible to make the European Parliament more attractive to the public and visitors, in particular through Parlamentariums and the House of European History. Our institution must be accessible to everyone, including deaf and hard of hearing citizens, which is why I support the creation of an interpretation of our debates in international sign language. Due to recent terrorist threats to European institutions, I supported the extraordinary expenditure envelope for security investments. However, I have reservations about the proposal to internalize the driver service and replace the external provider with contract staff from Parliament.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: in writing.- The report is in opposition to our firm positions.It is based on the logic of the general budget of austerity and memoranda.For Parliament, we raise issues of waste of money and improving its functioning, but we do not agree with the logics of austerity.That is why we took a stand against the report.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution as it is a leading action to be made by the EU on the global stage. These new measures will provide greater procedures for transparency and efficiency. I had no objections to the final report.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted against the motion for a European Parliament resolution on the estimates of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017 because I believe it is extremely important to raise the level of transparency in this process and to make information much simpler and more open.I believe that budget forecasts should be transparent, in line with political priorities and focused on realistic and sustainable planning.The vote against this report is in line with the ALDE Group's position.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- The report encourages people to look for ways to save money and make the use of public funds more efficient without, however, contesting the delusional increase in the budget planned for 2017. It calls for greater intelligibility and accessibility to the publicthe content of the budgets of the European Union, in particular its evolution from one year to the next.Rather than favoring budget increases, the European Parliament must make savings in its own expenditure.I therefore voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this resolution as paragraph 7 reaffirmed that the budget for the EU Parliament (which British taxpayers pay for) would increase overall. UKIP supported amendments which called for cuts to EU budgets, staffing and the abolition of the MEP chauffeur service. Whilst public services are being cut in the UK it outrageous for MEPs and EU bureaucrats to receive more money from British taxpayers.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I recognise that with the current security situation in Brussels, Parliament needs further appropriations in order to deal with this. However, any further expenditure should be clearly explained and accompanied by justifications of costs. I agree with Parliament’s resolution concerning the internalisation of the chauffeur service. I do not feel it is appropriate to increase the spending on this service and would have concerns if the internalisation led to an increase in costs.   Finally, I echo the remarks in the resolution with regards to the transparency of the European Parliament’s budget and the budgetary process. It is important that elected representatives be given an objective overview of estimated costs as well as comparisons with previous budgetary years. I also fully support the proposal to have a user-friendly version of the budget displayed on Parliament’s website.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report by my colleague Indrek Tarand on the forecast of revenue and expenditure for the European Parliament for the financial year 2017. This report indicates that priority must be given to four points: improving safety andcybersecurity, remove derogatory measures for the Irish language, give Members more leeway in carrying out their mandate and make Parliament more attractive to the public.This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the Tarand report which concerns the forecast of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017. The Bureau of the Parliament and the Committee on Budgets have agreed on a 2017 budget for Parliament of 1 900 873000 euros, which represents an increase of 3.4% compared to the 2016 budget. In addition, extraordinary expenses for security and cybersecurity are planned for an amount of 47.6 million euros.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- There are good beginnings in the report on Parliament's estimates for the financial year 2017.In particular, priority objectives were proposed for the 2017 budget, including security and cybersecurity.However, the report does not show a concept for large savings in the EU budget.On the contrary, an increase in the total budget by EUR 1.9 billion is proposed, which corresponds to an increase of 3.4% compared to the previous year.In my opinion, this is completely unnecessary, as there are considerable savings potentials in the EU budget.These include, for example, cuts in the public funding of political parties and foundations at European level or a single location for the seats of the institutions of the European Union, which has already been called for by a large majority in Parliament in several resolutions.That is why I voted against this report.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - On 14 April 2016, we voted in plenary in Strasbourg on Parliament's annual estimate of revenue and expenditure, this time for the financial year 2017. As a faction long-term critical of the austerity measures introduced by the Troika in some Member States, we tabled several amendments the constant swelling of the EP budget. At least one positive thing can be found in the whole vote is that support for the establishment of only one European Parliament seat has passed. That is, criticism of the constant movement between Strasbourg and Brussels. However, as our key proposal, which points to the absurd situation of an increase of 3.4% in the new budget compared to the 2016 budget, did not pass, which does not take due account of the economic constraints of several Member States, I could not support this document. I believe that Members should set an example for citizens who are facing the catastrophic consequences of the economic crisis in a number of Member States.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- Parliament's budget has undergone a small increase compared to the previous year, essentially due to the increased need for security, both for Members and for the structure, staff and citizens who come to visit us.Recent terrorist attacks, including in the city of Brussels, highlight the need for increased security, and also cybersecurity, to protect sensitive documents from external attacks.As always, these resources are managed with intransigence and pragmatism, in order to allow an efficient performance of our activities and to avoid waste or disservices.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on the forecast of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017, which reports in particular that the general secretariat of this institution wants to increase the budget of the European Parliament to 1.9 billion deuros, an overall increase of 4.3% compared to the 2016 budget. Parliament therefore adopts the adage according to which "well-ordered austerity begins with others".This would finance the increase in security and digital security spending, the increase in the resources made available to Members in the exercise of their mandate, and the strengthening of the European Parliament's attraction for the public and visitors..Rather than favoring budget increases, the European Parliament should make savings in its own spending.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it unreasonably validates the 4.3% increase in Parliament spending in 2017 compared to 2016. Austerity is good for EU Member States, butnot for the European Parliament!This is what is called failing to set an example ... The Europeanist oligarchy cuts itself even further away from the peoples it is supposed to represent.

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- In a time of austerity, the secretariat of the European Parliament can find nothing better to do than increase the European Parliament's budget for 2017 by 4.3%, which would rise to 1.9 billion euros.The reason given is the financing of the increase in security expenditure, and cybersecurity, the increase in the means made available to Members in the exercise of their mandate and the strengthening of the attractiveness of the European Parliament for the public.and visitors.It is certain that in the midst of a crisis, European citizens will appreciate these measures.Parliament must make savings in its own expenditure, which is why I voted against this text.

name: Sander LOONES
text: written. - In difficult budgetary, economic and social times, when great efforts are required from European citizens, it is appropriate for every government to lead by example. Any fair budget must first and foremost consider its own expenditure. And this report scores absolutely below par in this area as well. According to this report, the revenue and expenditure estimates of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017 would not be lower, but 3.9% higher than in 2016. In view of the terrorist threat, additional security measures are indeed necessary. But the budget for this must primarily be sought within existing resources. In addition, an increase of 3.9% is completely disproportionate. Parliament has again not sufficiently explored where it can work more efficiently, nor did the report look for the cheapest option for new proposals. For example, Parliament in Brussels does not need an expensive, private chauffeur service at all, and the travel agency must stop reimbursing business class tickets for flights within the EU. The N-VA MEPs therefore voted against this report.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I voted against Parliament's expenditure forecast for 2017 as, in my opinion, the resources available to Parliament are not being used correctly.It has increased exponentially in spending on security and cybersecurity, while also increasing the budget with unnecessary expenses such as the renovation of offices.But on the contrary, it has been decided to cut the item for interpretation and the proposal to introduce sign language has not been accepted.If cuts are necessary, they should be made in the area of MEPs' salaries or travel expenses, as Parliament continues to pay for first-class flights for MEPs.Finally, we continue with the perennial problem of waste of maintaining the two seats of the European Parliament.For these reasons I have voted absolutely against.

name: Bernd LUCKE
text: written.- There are good beginnings in the report on Parliament's estimates for the financial year 2017.In particular, priority objectives were proposed for the 2017 budget, including security and cybersecurity.However, the report does not show a concept for large savings in the EU budget.On the contrary, an increase in the total budget by EUR 1.9 billion is proposed, which corresponds to an increase of 3.4% compared to the previous year.In my opinion, this is completely unnecessary, as there are considerable savings potentials in the EU budget.These include, for example, cuts in the public funding of political parties and foundations at European level or a single location for the seats of the institutions of the European Union, which has already been called for by a large majority in Parliament in several resolutions.That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- Following the discovery of benchmark manipulation by LIBOR, the EU introduced changes to the Market Abuse Directive to protect against the manipulation of indices as benchmarks in financial instruments and contracts.The report notes that the current changes are not enough and highlights the need for further strengthening of three more areas.According to the report, public administration and its impact on the market, transparency and efficiency towards end users should be strengthened and market requirements should be harmonized with state requirements.The report proposes to provide additional measures to ensure benchmarks and regulate their application, ensure the stability of benchmarks and their transparency.The integrity of benchmarks is key to determining market prices and financial instruments such as loans, credits, legal contracts and interest rates, so I supported the report.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I am voting against the report on the estimates of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 13/4/2016, and because thethis report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This is a proposal to increase the European budget for 2017 by 1.9 billion euros!This increase would be justified by security and cybersecurity spending, but also by more resources granted to deputies in the exercise of their mandates as well as by the costs associated with welcoming visitors.At a time of budgetary rigor, the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group, for its part, advocates operating economies for European bodies.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: in writing.- The European Parliament today voted on the guidelines for the 2017 budget. The points listed in the report will certainly lead to a very fruitful debate in the next budget session.In a time of persistent economic crisis, the European Parliament and all the institutions must lead by example by using their economic resources efficiently.This is why I voted in favor.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This report sets the guidelines for the preparation of Parliament's 2017 budget. Once again, the parliamentary majority which supports the general contraction of European and national budgets finds it normal that the Parliament's budget increases by 3.9% in 2017, after an increase of 3% in 2016. The Parliament's budget continues to grow. increase faster than inflation without us seeing what democratic progress it results. To justify this new increase, it is now security that is invoked. The report calls for a blind endorsement of a doubling of the security budget, while admitting that it does not have information on the expenditure envisaged for it! On many other topics, such as Parliament's sumptuary real estate policy, this report continues to desperately call for transparency, with price details for several deals still not known despite repeated requests. The positive efforts of the Green rapporteur to support "more organic food" in canteens and the translation of sessions into sign language are not enough to make up for the bureaucratic wandering of this institution, which is no more democratic than the rest of the institutional system of the country. 'European Union. I vote against.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The report on Parliament's finances is no different from the secretariat's proposals.I am opposed to the expenditure they recommend, which is already significant, to be reassessed by 4.3%.I find such a budget largely superfluous.I therefore voted against the report.

name: Nuno MELO
text: in writing. - The 2017 budget proposed in the Secretary-General's report is marked by the continuation and intensification of the institution's policy of making efficiency gains in all areas where this is possible without compromising the quality of the working environment for Members and staff. Four priority objectives for the 2017 budget are proposed by the Secretary-General, namely: security and cybersecurity, the gradual abolition of the Irish language derogation, measures underway to provide more means for Members in the exercise of their mandate and to make Parliament attractive for the public and visitors. In the current political and security context arising from the terrorist attacks in Europe, the budgetary process for 2017 should result in increased parliament security and cybersecurity. We must therefore find the best solutions to achieve the proposed objectives, so that we can maintain the excellence of the legislation and the commitments made to all European citizens. Hence my vote in favor.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as it reflects the fact that the Treaty of Lisbon established the Parliament as a true co—legislator. The report also notes the necessity to improve Parliament’s IT security infrastructure to ensure the maximum possible level of protection.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - With regard to issues concerning the financial aspects of the running of the European Parliament, I believe that there is a need for citizens to always be consistently and clearly informed about the objectives, priorities and structure of expenditure. Every financial year must be prepared with the utmost precision and transparency, as it is a matter for European citizens. With regard to spending on my activities as an MEP and the running of my office in the EP, I always try to proceed with the utmost rationality, prudence, responsibility and frugality, and I expect the same approach from my parliamentary colleagues. I consider the present proposal to be sensible, as it addresses, inter alia, the EP's property policy in some detail, where it pays attention to rationality and prudence in spending funds, as well as in the running of the whole institution, its staff or Members. I therefore express my support for the proposal and vote in favor of the report as it stands.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I am in agreement with the report on Parliament’s estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017. That is why I have voted in favour.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing.- The Committee on Budgets has prepared and submitted the draft budget of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017.I supported the proposal.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing.- This report globally deserves my favorable vote for the above, highlighting with just two notes the following: the current political and security context resulting from the terrorist attacks in Europe requires an increase in Parliament's security and cybersecurity in the 2017 budget process;and I highlight the importance of the European Parliament having the ability to control its own expenses, in order to gain credibility with institutions and citizens.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- The report encourages people to look for ways to save money and make the use of public funds more efficient without, however, contesting the delusional increase in the budget planned for 2017. It calls for greater intelligibility and accessibility to the publicthe content of EU budgets, in particular its evolution from one year to the next.Rather than favoring budget increases, the European Parliament must make savings in its own expenditure.I am therefore voting against this report, which is very far from it.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- The Bureau of the Parliament and the Committee on Budgets have agreed on a 2017 budget for Parliament of 1,900,873,000 euros.This report provides a forecast of the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure for the 2017 financial year and identifies priorities, such as the institution's security and cyber-security.So I voted in favor.However, I opposed an amendment which favored a single workplace for the European Parliament.Maintaining the Strasbourg headquarters, provided for by the Treaties, is essential to maintaining a Europe closer to the citizens, with institutions equitably distributed among the Member States.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- In the search for security, visibility and enhanced action by MEPs, Parliament has decided to increase its budget to meet the priorities that we have set for ourselves.Given the importance of our work in the European Parliament, but also the need to make the European Union even more attractive to our fellow citizens, I obviously voted in favor of the text.On the other hand, it appears crucial to reaffirm our attachment to the seat of the European Parliament located in Strasbourg.I regret that the majority of the European Parliament is turning away from this pillar of European construction, and I invite each of my French colleagues to show their attachment to respect for the Treaties and to the city of Strasbourg as the official seat of the European Parliament.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- The 2017 budget has, in my view, been drawn up responsibly, taking into account the measures needed to reduce expenditure in certain areas.That is why I supported the report.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ The Commission proposed during the previous legislative procedure the regulation on benchmarks, but due to the fact that the procedure was not finalised, it had to be started again from scratch with a new negotiating team. I have voted against this report on estimates of revenue and expenditure for the next financial year.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted against the proposal because, as in previous years, it will lead to a further expansion of the Brussels waterhead - in numbers, namely to an increase in the financial budget of almost four percent.In times of tight budgets and the inefficiency of the EU in solving pressing problems, this cannot be conveyed to anyone.

name: Younous OMARJEE
text: in writing.- This budget report covers the estimates of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the 2017 financial year. Such a budget must have three priorities: safeguarding European democracy, facing security challenges, and above all ensuring budgetary exemplarity.On this last point, I believe that a certain number of expenses are not useful, whether it be the transport of Members of Parliament, the increase in parliamentary assistance envelopes or the renewal of offices.I am also opposed to the cut in interpretation services, despite the adoption of my amendment on the introduction of international sign language interpretation for plenary debates.In view of these elements, I voted against the report.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this resolution as paragraph 7 reaffirmed that the budget for the EU Parliament (which British taxpayers pay for) would increase overall. UKIP supported amendments which called for cuts to EU budgets, staffing and the abolition of the MEP chauffeur service. Whilst public services are being cut in the UK it outrageous for MEPs and EU bureaucrats to receive more money from British taxpayers.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- Considering that the budget for 2017, as proposed in the Secretary General's report, would be characterized by the continuation and intensification of the policy aimed at greater efficiency in all sectors;having considered the need to revise some items of the budget, based on the new needs encountered from time to time;considering that it is essential to ensure transparency and take action in favor of IT security, I would like to vote in favor.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - The report, like the 2017 budget itself, is marked by the continuation and strengthening of the institution's policy on increasing efficiency wherever possible, without reducing the quality of the working environment of MPs and staff. Parliament should have sufficient resources to exercise all its powers and function properly. In doing so, care must be taken to be efficient in the use of public money. The budget needs to be transparent and understandable to users so that we can all better understand how Parliament spends money. Security and cybersecurity are particularly important in the light of recent terrorist attacks and a comprehensive evaluation of the envisaged security measures and an evaluation of their budgetary impact are needed. Supporting MPs in the exercise of their mandate and covering the costs of MPs should remain at the levels of 2016, and I believe that there is no need to increase it. Property management, staffing, transport services and communications are important items in Parliament's budget. They should be rationalized as much as possible while at the same time using the funds intended for that purpose efficiently.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The report stresses the importance of efficient use of public resources and the need for complete transparency in accountability. The dematerialization and digitalization of processes should, however, always avoid any kind of exclusion. We do not follow the systematic approach to austerity, continuing to reduce costs always under the same headings, as we do not subscribe to the ongoing insurance drift that also reaches the EP and which fortifies and closes access to a house that should be open. Those who should not, do not fear, often say. And this house has a lot to owe. Incomprehensible the decrease in personnel when the defenders of this project affirm a supposedly increasing importance and centrality of the EP (no more than smoke). This, together with the increasing use of service providers and job insecurity in the European Parliament, also speaks well of the options of the right-wing majority and of social democracy as far as workers and their rights are concerned.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing.- In accordance with the annual budgetary procedure, the BUDG committee prepares a draft report providing estimates of Parliament's expenditure for the following year.The report is based on the preliminary draft expenditure prepared by the EP Bureau on the basis of information provided by the Secretary-General.According to estimates for 2017, Parliament's total budget will be EUR 1 910 073 000, an increase of 3.9% compared to the 2016 budget, with the largest increase expected in expenditure on new security measures.The priorities for 2017 identified by the Secretary-General are security and cybersecurity, the gradual end of the derogation for the Irish language, the strengthening of the mandate of MEPs and making Parliament more attractive to the public and visitors.I hereby support this report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- MEPs are called upon to express their views on the management of the European Parliament as an institution.Thus, the adoption of the report on the forecast of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017 makes it possible to identify several priorities such as strengthening security or increasing the attractiveness of the institution.to the public and visitors.Also, the MEPs who voted for this report asked Parliament's Bureau for greater transparency in the use of the so-called "overhead" envelope.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this resolution as paragraph 7 reaffirmed that the budget for the EU Parliament (which British taxpayers pay for) would increase overall. UKIP supported amendments which called for cuts to EU budgets, staffing and the abolition of the MEP chauffeur service. Whilst public services are being cut in the UK it outrageous for MEPs and EU bureaucrats to receive more money from British taxpayers.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - Parliament's budget for 2017 was established by the Secretary-General and includes security and cybersecurity, the gradual abolition of the derogation relating to the Irish language, measures underway to provide more means for Members in the exercise of their mandate and to make Parliament attractive to the audience and visitors. However, and considering the current political and security context arising from the terrorist attacks in Europe, the budgetary process for 2017 should provide an increase in Parliament's security and cybersecurity. This report considers, however, that, in view of the economic slowdown in the Member States, the level of inflation forecast for 2017 should not be considered the main indicator for increases in current expenditure. Thus, the report sets the global level of its forecast of revenue and expenditure for 2017 at EUR 1 900 873 000, which corresponds to a total increase of 3.4% in relation to the 2016 budget, having obtained my positive vote.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - The European Parliament adopted the report on the Union's Amending Budget 1/2016 and the first funding under the new instrument to provide emergency aid within the Union to relieve countries, such as Greece , who are experiencing a massive influx of refugees and migrants. The EP thus approved the redeployment within heading 3 (security) of the multiannual financial framework of 100 million euros in commitment appropriations for the immediate financing needs under this new humanitarian aid mechanism on the territory. of the Union. In general, MEPs also called for a more sustainable legal and budgetary framework in order, in the future, to be able to mobilize humanitarian aid within the Union when circumstances require it. The vote on this amending budget also makes it possible to reinforce the staff of the European Center for the fight against terrorism within Europol and to provide for the corresponding commitment and payment appropriations for an amount of 2 million euros coming from a redeployment from the Internal Security Fund.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We have voted IN FAVOR of this report on the forecast of income and expenses of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017, because we welcome some measures of cuts in superfluous expenses that the rapporteur proposes, the general lines in which it moves are correct,and we choose to give our support at this point in the construction of the budget.This is not an obstacle for us to have shown our disagreement with several statements in this report, to which we table two amendments, since we consider that the budget of the European Parliament, in times of crisis like this, should always set an example of humility and austerity.and when these cuts are not an inconvenience to legislative work and parliamentary work and do not jeopardize jobs.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing. - The European Parliament can not and must not be exempted from the general austerity requirements that currently apply throughout Europe. Therefore, as in previous years, the number of staff and administrative costs continue to be cut across a broad spectrum in the European Parliament. We support this approach and maintain that the EU budget should not increase. However, in the wake of the series of terrorist attacks we have seen in Europe, it is clear that there is a need for a significant upgrade of the security measures around institutions such as the European Parliament. That is why we support the increases in the budget that relate to increased security. At the same time, we point out that these increased security measures have been adopted with broad political support in the Bureau of the European Parliament. We maintain our demand for more transparent rules for the audit of Parliament's expenditure, including the means made available to Members, and we emphasize that uniform, clear and effective rules must apply. We do not want to complicate or make the system more expensive by encouraging a budding of different auditing systems. Finally, we emphasize that both members and employees should always travel in the overall cheapest way possible. For MEPs, these are typically the cheapest flex tickets for changing meeting calendars.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against Parliament's spending forecast for 2017 as in my opinion the resources available to Parliament are not being used correctly.It has increased exponentially in spending on security and cybersecurity, while also increasing the budget with unnecessary expenses such as the renovation of offices.But on the contrary, it has been decided to cut the item for interpretation and the proposal to introduce sign language has not been accepted.If it is necessary to make cuts, these should be made in the area of the salary of MPs or travel expenses, since Parliament continues to pay for bussiness flights for MEPs.Finally, we continue with the perennial problem of waste of maintaining the two seats of the European Parliament.For these reasons I have voted absolutely against.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, but this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of MPs in the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities emphasized in Croatia, which does not really reflect the actual qualityactions.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the report on the estimates of revenue and expenditure of the European Parliament for 2017, as the budget has responded to the challenges currently facing the EU. The budget increase compared to 2016 represents 3.9 percent, of which up to 2.6% is invested in strengthening the EP's security and cyber security. In addition to security, the Secretary-General included among the main priorities of the 2017 budget the gradual abolition of the derogation for the Irish language, measures to strengthen the position of Members within their mandate and to make Parliament more attractive to the public and visitors. I also welcome Parliament's efforts to make its documents accessible with the greatest possible degree of transparency, accessibility and comprehensibility. The budget should therefore be presented to the general public in sufficient detail and in an accessible form on Parliament's website. This should enable citizens to better understand the activities, priorities and the corresponding expenditure structure of the institution. Therefore, I hope that this approach of openness will be perceived positively by the public and that the publication of the budget will also contribute to a greater degree of confidence in the European institutions.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The 2017 budget will continue and strengthen the institution's policy of saving in all areas where possible, without jeopardizing the quality of the working environment of Members and staff. The total level of estimated expenditure for 2017 will amount to EUR 1,900,873,000, which is 3.4% more than in the 2016 budget. In order for Irish to become an official language, extraordinary expenditure is required compared to the 2016 budget, namely 0 , 2% more. The current political and security situation (terrorist attacks in Europe) calls for greater security and cyber security for Parliament (+ 2.6% of the 2016 budget). With regard to safety, the renovation of entrances and the installation of bulletproof glazing is envisaged, and there is also a proposal to internalize the driver's service by creating more than a hundred new contract jobs. The interesting elements of the report are as follows: transparency and accessibility of the budget, identification of various areas for savings, "greener" rolling stock and strengthening of green public procurement. That is why I voted in favor of the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- There are good beginnings in the report on Parliament's estimates for the financial year 2017.In particular, priority objectives were proposed for the 2017 budget, including security and cybersecurity.However, the report does not show a concept for large savings in the EU budget.On the contrary, an increase in the total budget by EUR 1.9 billion is proposed, which corresponds to an increase of 3.4% compared to the previous year.In my opinion, this is completely unnecessary, as there are considerable savings potentials in the EU budget.These include, for example, cuts in the public funding of political parties and foundations at European level or a single location for the seats of the institutions of the European Union, which has already been called for by a large majority in Parliament in several resolutions.That is why I voted against this report.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- In the current economic climate, the European Parliament emphasizes the pragmatic, transparent and efficient use of resources to carry out its fundamental role.The most important tasks are considered to be general and cyber security and to support Members in the exercise of their mandate.The EP points out that while ensuring an adequate level of Parliament's funding is in line with the implementation of European democracy, it is recommended that possible savings be sought and that the efficiency of the use of public funds be further increased.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - This is the second comprehensive budget procedure to be implemented in the new legislature and this is the fourth procedure under the multiannual financial framework for the period 2014-2020.
