The Secretary General has proposed four priority objectives for the 2017 budget, namely: security and cybersecurity , the phasing out of the Irish language exemption, permanent measures to support Members in the exercise of their mandate and increasing Parliament's attractiveness to the public and visitors. In the current political and security context arising from the terrorist attacks in Europe, the 2017 budgetary procedure should result in an increase in Parliament’s security and cybersecurity. I welcome the expansion of the digital portal for Members (e-Portal), however, I would call on the Secretary-General to improve the current system of sending paper copies of salary certificates to Members, given the “paperless” work environment initiative. finally abolished by the end of 2017. Also, I believe that the e-Portal should automatically provide this service to all MPs electronically, which would result in significant time and money savings. I welcome the growing quality of advice and research available to Members and Committees, and I support this report.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I supported the report and fully agree that the European Parliament has a huge margin to make the use of taxpayers' money more efficient.One of the first steps towards savings should be a single seat for the European Parliament, which I have long supported.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the statement of estimates of the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017. The report also emphasizes, inter alia, that Parliament must have sufficient resources to carry out its core function of co-legislative and budgetary authority.This is also a fundamental task for Parliament, which we must constantly strengthen.Of course, in the current situation, we need to handle resources conscientiously and efficiently.As we have a major problem with citizens' trust in the institutions in recent years, I also support the budget being published in a clear way on the European Parliament's website.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: in writing.- The report was based on the logic of the general austerity budget and memoranda.Our positions on him are clearly against.Specifically for Parliament, we highlight issues of waste of money and improving its functioning, but we do not agree with the logics of austerity.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on Parliament's estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017. I agree with the highlights of the report, which emphasize the importance of physical and cyber security, and with the request for the Secretary-General to provide detailed information on current and future security and cyber security measures and the distribution of their costs. I agree with the rapporteur that I believe that all measures affecting security must be based on a clear assessment of Parliament's needs and that the measures must be proportionate to the risks involved. I also welcome the comment on Parliament's website that it should be made more informative and user-friendly for citizens. In addition, I welcome the proposals made in the spirit of the paperless initiative, which will not only increase work efficiency, but will also have a positive impact from an economic point of view.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- I followed the advice of my colleague Tarand.The share of Parliament's budget in 2017 should be kept below 20% of heading 5. I note that the level of the preliminary draft estimates for 2017, as adopted by the Bureau on 7 March 2016,corresponds to 19.26%, lower rate than that of 2016 (19.39%) and second lowest rate for eight years for heading 5. Its share is further reduced in heading 5 to reach 19.17% for 2017However, given the slowdown in economic activity in Member States, the inflation rate forecast for 2017 should not be taken as the main benchmark for increases in recurrent expenditure.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution, but I firmly opposed the measure concerning the internalisation of the chauffeur service. I do not feel it is appropriate to increase the spending on this service and would have concerns if the internalisation led to an increase in costs. It is premature at this stage and in this condition to consider this evolution of the car service.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The budget for 2017 should be marked by the continuation and strengthening of the institution's policy of increasing efficiency, without reducing the quality of the working environment of MPs and staff.Four priority goals have been proposed for the 2017 budget, which require extraordinary investments and an increase in the 2017 budget of 3.9 percent compared to the 2016 budget.As a number of proposals that could reasonably reduce the amount of the budget were not accepted, I voted against this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- It would support the European Parliament's estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017, provided that it votes, taking into account the draft statement of estimates of revenue and expenditure drawn up by the Committee on Budgets in accordance with Rule 96 (2).The Secretary-General for the 2017 budget proposed four priority objectives, namely: security and cyber security, the phasing out of the Irish derogation, ongoing measures to support Members in the exercise of their mandate, and to increase Parliament's attractiveness to the public and visitors.I myself regularly receive visitors and organized groups from Slovenia, and I also support them in this, so the last point of my priority goals is very important to me.I place the greatest emphasis on the first, security.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We have voted IN FAVOR of this report on the forecast of income and expenses of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017, because we welcome some measures of cuts in superfluous expenses that the rapporteur proposes, the general lines in which it moves are correct,and we choose to give our support at this point in the construction of the budget.This is not an obstacle for us to have shown our disagreement with several statements in this report, to which we table two amendments, since we consider that the budget of the European Parliament, in times of crisis like this, should always set an example of humility and austerity.and when these cuts are not an inconvenience to legislative work and parliamentary work and do not jeopardize jobs.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted against this recommendation for the Parliament expenditure for 2017 for lack of transparency between EP investment cost and normal functioning cost. The real decisions are made behind doors by the Secretary General of this house. Neither the Bureau nor the Budget committee have full access to information when requested. The lack in transparency in the process is very unfortunate and should be corrected. I am against the internalisation of the car service and chauffeurs, as the cost estimate for this is 3.6 million. The transparency of the increase in security costs from 37 million to 47 million is not clear as well. The cost for refurnishing new buildings, in particular the new building on the other side of Rue Belliard in Brussels, is not clear. In these times of economic crisis and difficult times for many families and SMEs, the EU institutions, in particular the house of European democracy, has to set an example. We should be very rigorous. These are only recommendations; the real vote on budget will take place in October.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This report underlines that the General Secretariat of the European Parliament wishes to increase expenditure by 4.3% compared to 2016, and thus push this budget to 1.9 billion euros.Parliament therefore adopts the adage that "well-ordered austerity starts with others".Rather than favoring budget increases, the European Parliament should make savings in its own spending.I vote against this text.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- In the light of the current political and security situation in Europe, the security and cyber security of Parliament need to be enhanced during the 2017 budgetary procedure.This is reflected in the proposal, which includes further budget adjustments for other reasons.Apart from certain points and modifications, I supported the package.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We have voted IN FAVOR of this report on the forecast of income and expenses of the European Parliament for the financial year 2017, because we welcome some measures of cuts in superfluous expenses that the rapporteur proposes, the general lines in which it moves are correct,and we choose to give our support at this point in the construction of the budget.This is not an obstacle for us to have shown our disagreement with several statements in this report, to which we table two amendments, since we consider that the budget of the European Parliament, in times of crisis like this, should always set an example of humility and austerity.and when these cuts are not an inconvenience to legislative work and parliamentary work and do not jeopardize jobs.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Parliament´s estimates of revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017. The report outlines the expected monetary flow of the European Parliament, analysing its revenues and expenditures for the coming year. There will be provisions aimed at achieving substantial savings and, in light of the recent terrorist attacks in Brussels, provisions aimed at reinforcing security of the Parliament’s premises, in order to guarantee the safety of Members and all employees.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Although the budget for the year 2017 will be finally adopted through the normal procedure during the month of autumn, this report includes several of the commitments of great importance that have already been reached in the last conciliation, so I believe it appropriate to vote on yourfavor.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ At a time when austerity is often a key part of national conversations it seemed to me unfair that there should be an increase in the European Parliament budget of 3.9% that was proposed by the Secretary—General of Parliament. There were specific aspects of the report that were positive such as the necessity for security and cybersecurity to be proportionate to the risks. Given the recent attacks in Brussels it is clear that there is a real and present threat to the parliament. I also noted Tarand’s call for increased accountability in the general expenses allowance, which notes the increasing number of MEPs including us in the Labour Party who are publishing their spending records. As public representatives, we have a clear responsibility to use the public’s money correctly and transparently in our work. While I also welcome Tarand’s call for budgetary restraint and the consideration of below 1.7% increases as it is not an overall cut, I felt that I could not in all good conscience back this report at a time when my colleagues in the Welsh Assembly and local Councillors in my area are grappling with massive cuts that have been imposed upon them.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted for this resolution.Although the internalisation of the driver service must not lead to an increase in costs.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- We note in this report the importance of being efficient in the use of public resources and completely transparent in accountability.The dematerialization and digitalization of processes should, however, always avoid any type of exclusion.What we do not follow is this fashion of austerity that always imposes a cost reduction that is always felt in the same items.We are sensitive to the issue of security, but we do not feed this security drift that makes this house look more and more like a prison or a fortress.We do not understand this reduction in personnel at the same time as the intention is to give more importance and centrality to the European Parliament.Nor do we follow up on fears about driver service.As we defend the interests of those who work, we also want this house to set an example, giving stability to its workers.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Parliament's estimates for the financial year 2017 provide for a budget of EUR 1 910 073 000.This means an increase of 3.9 percent compared to the 2016 budget.The report must therefore be rejected.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not vote in favor of the resolution of the EU Parliament on the estimate of the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure for the 2017 financial year.The report sets the total volume of its estimates for 2017 at EUR 1 900 873 000, an overall increase of 3.4% compared to the 2016 budget.Despite some austerity proposals and a rather critical attitude by Parliament, expenditure of 1.9 billion euros is simply too much.The European Parliament has no right of legislative initiative and is therefore not a real legislative body.In addition, it affords superfluous things like the Parlamentarium, which is also to have a branch in Berlin.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the statement of estimates of the European Parliament's revenue and expenditure for the financial year 2017. Parliament is using the funds to carry out its basic function as legislative and budgetary authority.I believe that, in the current economic and social context, resources need to be used diligently, pragmatically and effectively.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- Turkey applied for membership in 1987 and was declared a candidate country in 1999. To date, however, there are still many doubts regarding Turkey's entry into Europe.The Piri report, in fact, clearly highlights the limits of this acquisition, by virtue of the violations of the rule of law, as well as of fundamental rights and freedoms, and of the continuous repressions perpetrated, especially against the Kurdish community, cleverly concealed under the pretext offight against terrorism.Considering the latest events, particular attention is paid to the migration issue.The report, in this regard, takes note of the efforts made by the Turkish government and of their results, in my opinion, not so evident.For these reasons, I would have abstained, by virtue of the strong doubts expressed by the UNHCR on the migration issue.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- This report welcomes the agreement between Turkey and the EU on migration, which we oppose.In addition, it underlines "the great humanitarian contribution of Turkey" due to its role in welcoming refugees, when in reality it is herding refugees, fleeing the war, into concentration camps of people including women and minors, without fulfilling the basic conditionshygiene and violating the most fundamental human rights.With the EU-Turkey agreement and the funds given to Turkey to turn it into a prison for refugees who wish to request asylum in Europe, it continues in the line of an aggressive foreign policy and contrary to human rights, and as this agreement is acclaimed in this report, I decided to vote against.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This report deals with the process of Turkey’s accession to the EU. It highlights many of the problems Turkey faces, including human rights abuses, democratic rights and the ongoing mistreatment of refugees. We supported a number of amendments, including those calling for better treatment of refugees, and the removal of the PKK from the terror list, as a necessary step towards peace between Turkey and the Kurds. However, the report welcomes the inclusion of Turkey on the list of so-called ‘safe countries of origin’ for refugees. Despite the many problems Turkey faces, and without a resolution of the matter of Cyprus, the report is still supportive of further steps towards Turkey’s accession to the EU. We therefore abstained on the report.

name: Eric ANDRIEU
text: in writing.- I voted for this report.I deplore the decline in freedoms in Turkey, especially freedom of expression.Turkey is the country in the world that keeps the most journalists in prison and that is unacceptable.There is an urgent need for reforms in the area of justice and fundamental rights and freedoms.We call for the reestablishment of the separation of powers, and the development of an inclusive constitution.We also ask for the immediate resumption of peace negotiations with the PKK, whose return to violence we condemn, as well as the conduct of the Turkish authorities which amounts to collective punishment.Turkey must lift curfews, respect human rights and try those responsible for abuses (especially members of the special forces, whose action is appalling).As such, it is essential for the Union to play a role in the resumption of talks.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S & amp; D), in writing. - The European Parliament resolution on Turkey's accession process points in many respects to the setback in the areas of human rights, the independence of the judiciary and freedom of the press. It also calls on the Turkish government to end hostilities in southeastern Turkey, lift the siege of several cities in the region and resume peace talks with the Kurds. The report also condemns the violation of Greek airspace and Greek territorial waters by Turkey, calls for respect for the religious, national and property rights of the Greek minority and for the respect of the ecumenical character of the Ecumenical Patriarchate. Although it was not included in the original text, after my intervention and an amendment tabled in plenary, the non-removal by Turkey of casus belli against Greece is also condemned. Finally, although there is a separation of the accession process from the recent refugee agreement, I decided to abstain from the final vote as there was a clear call for the opening of new negotiating chapters despite the deteriorating situation in Turkey.

name: Pascal ARIMONT
text: written. - I voted against this text. It is right and good to brand the human rights violations and the violations of press freedom in Turkey with a clear statement. However, this must not be combined with a continuation of the accession negotiations - the text takes up the opening of further negotiation chapters. In principle, however, I am against Turkey's accession to the European Union. If we do not want to jeopardize our functioning and the original idea of ​​Europe, the European Union must not be expanded indefinitely. Increased cooperation with Turkey is definitely in the interests of the EU, for example with regard to combating the causes of the current refugee crisis or more effective combating of Islamist terror. However, important signs of confidence are missing. Negotiations with Turkey have now been going on for over ten years without any real progress in the area of ​​freedom of expression or justice. The opposite is the case.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe in further EU expansion, and therefore had no option but to vote against this progress report.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which discusses Turkey's progress towards membership of the European Union.The situation with regard to media freedom, respect for the rule of law and the situation of the Kurdish minority in the south-east of the country remain worrying.I agree that cooperation on migration should not be linked to accession negotiations.Turkey must meet the membership criteria.And this cannot be the subject of negotiations in exchange for cooperation on migration.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- On March 18, Chancellor Merkel and the other so-called "negotiators" of this agreement with Turkey actually gave in to all of Sultan Erdoğan's demands.Eternal turkeys of neo-Ottoman farce, the leaders who preside over the destinies of our adrift continent have signed a new blank check to the Turkish pyromaniac firefighter.The 3 billion euros previously allocated to Turkey have thus been doubled, all at the expense of our taxpayers.Worse, despite the Turks' obscure ties to Islamic State barbarians and despite Turkey allowing the smuggler mafia to thrive, it has decided to grant its 80 million citizens unrestricted access toSchengen area.What a fatal fool's market!

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - I approved this report on Turkey because it seemed balanced to me. On the one hand, he underlines the decline in respect for democracy and the rule of law in Turkey, which moves it away from the Copenhagen criteria, compliance with which conditions all access to the Union. On the other hand, he recalled that Turkey is a key strategic partner for the European Union and that active and credible negotiations would constitute an appropriate framework for exploiting the full potential of relations between the European Union and Turkey. In this regard, the report takes note of the relaunching of the negotiation process by the Union and hopes that the opening of new chapters can lead to concrete progress. Likewise, it strongly supports a structured, more frequent and open high-level political dialogue on key issues of common interest, such as migration, the fight against terrorism, energy, economy and trade.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - The 2015 Report on Turkey is characterized by maintaining good bilateral relations while requiring the Turkish Government to advance in different chapters of the accession negotiations and condemns the deterioration of democracy and human rights that has occurred in the last years. I voted in favor because I believe in a European Turkey, while at the same time I have a firm position that accession can only come if Turkey meets the Copenhagen Criteria. I have also rejected some GUE / NGL amendments because of their partial view in favor of the interests and postulates of the PKK. I do not agree with your proposal to remove the PKK from the EU list of terrorist organizations. The latest terrorist acts show that at least one important sector continues to bet on armed struggle as a solution to the conflict. On immigration and asylum, I defend the application of our common asylum policy in line with the Geneva Convention. Our obligations can never be outsourced to Turkey, a country that has proven to be unsafe for refugees. In no case can the agreements reached with Turkey be linked to the accession process.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Turkey has been a key strategic partner for the European Union for years. As a candidate in 1987 to join the then EEC, Turkey has had continuous and complicated relations with the Union, starting over the years virtuous processes of reform but also numerous backward steps that have compromised the affirmation of the rule of law within the its borders. In this particular historical moment, characterized by the presence of the conflict in Syria, the violence exerted by Daesh and the connected migrant crisis, Turkey is at the center of international attention. The 2.7 million refugees welcomed into Turkish territory demonstrate the republic's high sense of hospitality which, in other situations, clashes with restrictions on freedom of expression, the incarceration of journalists and limited access to the Internet. I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Turkey because I believe it supports the EU's efforts to promote respect for the rights of Turkish citizens and economic and political cooperation. Only by working together will the European Union and Turkey be able to resolve the crisis linked to the management of migratory flows and finally guarantee, in addition to the solution of the Cypriot question, the overcoming of the stalemate in the accession process.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We have voted to abstain on a text that is suitably harsh in denouncing the violation of human rights carried out systematically by the Turkish government against minorities, political opponents and journalists, demanding as to the criteria and conditions of access ofTurkey to the EU but absolutely contrary to political and legal responsibility regarding migratory co-management and the protection of the rights of people in situations of forced mobility.

name: Joëlle BERGERON
text: in writing. - Three billion euros. This is the price that our Europe, under the aegis of Mrs Merkel, has agreed to pay in Ankara to relieve our good conscience vis-à-vis the refugees fleeing Syria. This is the price Mr Erdoğan made us pay for us to consider his country as a "safe country", and even a country which fulfills the criteria to one day become the largest member state of the European Union. What hypocrisy! Should we recall the persecutions to which the Turkish Kurds have been victims for decades? Should we recall the countless imprisonments of journalists critical of Mr. Erdoğan's regime? Should we recall the occupation of Cyprus? Should we recall the regression of the secular state built by Atatürk? What a pitiful Munich spirit! Even though this report enumerates human rights violations in Turkey, the heads of state continue, in the name of a realpolitik which does not dare to speak its name, to veil its face, even if reports to us. manage that Ankara does not keep its word and dares to turn back refugees that Turkey is supposed to host in exchange for the manna that we pay it.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This 2015 report on Turkey is in fact a way of supporting its accession to the Union. The report also tries to present a common foreign policy of the Union to which Turkey should conform even though the sovereign Member States have their foreign policy. Turkey has no place in the Union either by its geography, its values, or even its standard of living, because we would quite simply be unable, in the current austerity context, to massively finance Turkey with funds Europeans. Finally, we cannot accept that a country whose regime takes an authoritarian turn and flouts freedom of expression, fundamental rights and the rights of minorities join the Union. I would also like to remind you that Turkey still refuses to recognize the Armenian genocide of 1915. Finally, I would like to point out that Turkey is already seeking to tap into the Union to manage its situation of migrants even though it is receiving substantial pre- membership and that it remains the main gateway for migrants to enter the Union, even the main link to enable the Islamic State to export its oil abroad. I therefore naturally voted against this text.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The 2015 report on Turkey is decidedly biased and makes crazy demands such as the admission of Turkish as an official EU language.There is no reference to the Armenian genocide, which Turkey still insists on denying after a century.The situation in Turkey is not as positive as the European Union wants us to believe;on the contrary, the freedoms of the press and expression are increasingly threatened.I therefore voted negative on this report.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: written.- I abstained in the vote.The resolution strongly criticizes Turkey, not least in the issue of democratic freedoms and rights, women's rights and LGBTQI issues, the attacks on free media, the country's role vis-à-vis IS and the Syrian war.It calls for further talks on the issue of Cyprus.On the Kurdish question, the resolution calls for an immediate ceasefire in south-eastern Turkey and the resumption of the peace process, but unfortunately names the PKK a terrorist organization.The resolution also does not distance itself from the deportation of refugees by the EU-Turkey agreement.Overall, I therefore chose to abstain in the final vote.I would also like to clarify that the Left Party demands recognition of the genocide of Armenians, but I did not vote in favor of such an amendment, as it was presented by the far right.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, which deals with Turkey's 2015 progress report. The European Parliament welcomes the significant progress made in the negotiations leading up to the reunification of Cyprus led by the United Nations. He welcomes the 2014 February 11 a joint declaration by the two leaders as a basis for the conclusion of the agreement and supporting the transformation of the Republic of Cyprus into a federation of two communities and two zones with one supreme authority, one international legal personality and one nationality. To ensure that both communities and zones are politically equal and provide equal opportunities for all, without prior agreement on the final agreement and in accordance with relevant UN Security Council resolutions and international law. In addition, Parliament welcomes the constructive attitude of both the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot island leaders, their determination and their tireless efforts to find a just, comprehensive and viable solution as soon as possible. The importance of resolving the decades-long Cyprus problem for the whole region and for Europe and the European Union must be emphasized, and therefore welcomes the possibility of a new referendum on reunification and calls on all parties to contribute to a positive outcome.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - Due to its economic and strategic location and its significant role in the region, Turkey is a strategic partner of the Union, emphasizes the report on Turkey voted on today, which discusses the country's progress in the European accession negotiations launched in 2005. It also examines the Turkish authorities' commitment to reforms and their implementation in the areas of justice, the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms. The document specifically highlights the country's importance in addressing the refugee and migration crisis. While supporting renewed political cooperation between the two sides on the crisis, he also stresses that cooperation on migration between the EU and Turkey should not be linked to the accession negotiation process. There is an urgent need for reforms in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights in Turkey. According to the report, in accordance with European values, Turkey must respect its commitments to European accession, guarantee fundamental rights and guarantee the cultural, social and political rights of the Kurdish national community. In the light of these arguments, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on Turkey for 2015, which, among other things, talks about how to separate migration cooperation from the EU accession negotiation process.Turkey deserves all possible praise for retaining the largest immigration population in the world, but also a country that is a major strategic partner for EU accession should make progress in the area of rule of law and fundamental values as a precondition for EU accession.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that Turkey is a strategic partner for the European Union on many fronts, such as those of the migration crisis or the Islamic State.However, I also believe that Turkey's decline in respect of human rights is something that the EU must worry about using its influence.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - More than ten years have passed since the start of the formal negotiations for Turkey's accession to the European Union. Since then, the latter has made important progress, moving considerably closer to meeting the Copenhagen criteria and assimilating much of the acquis communautaire. However, the pace of reforms has slowed considerably over the past few months. We are also witnessing a growing and worrying decline with respect to the protection of freedom of expression and association, as well as an increasingly unstable situation characterized by non-respect for the rights of ethnic-religious minorities and the LGBT community. Despite an important commitment to, for example, the reception of refugees, Turkey ranks among the countries with the largest number of journalists in prison in the world, also presenting a critical level of corruption. A European, democratic, transparent Turkey, endowed with an independent legal system and respectful of the minorities that make it up, could constitute an important link with the Middle Eastern and Muslim world, capable of promoting the stability of the entire region. In this sense, we must continue to work and dialogue to ensure that this fundamental process of integration is completed.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - The vote against the resolution is given not only for the usual reasons, but also by the fact that Turkish is requested to become the official language of the EU; there is still no reference to the Armenian genocide. The resolution provides for EU-Turkey cooperation on migrants to be separated from the ongoing negotiations on Turkey's accession to the European Union. The text praises Turkey for hosting the largest number of refugees in the world and stresses that it remains "a key strategic partner for the European Union". However, "progress on the rule of law and respect for fundamental values" and "more structured and frequent dialogue on key issues" are called for. The general pace of reforms in Turkey has not only slowed down, but in some areas, such as freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary, there have been setbacks. The joint EU-Turkey action plan on refugees and migration management should be implemented immediately. The urgent need for reforms of the judicial system, justice, freedom and security is reiterated.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of Turkey's annual progress report. The report praises that Turkey is the country in the world with the largest refugee population. Today the EU and Turkey face many common challenges and we need each other in order to find joint solutions. At the same time, the report is critical and shows that this year there has been a significant democratic setback, especially in the areas of freedom of expression, freedom of the press, the rule of law and the rights of minorities. The report urges Turkey to resume democratizing reforms once again, aligning itself with EU values ​​and is betting that the accession process can accelerate these necessary changes. The report addresses the situation in southeastern Turkey, where the most significant wave of violence in the last 20 years is taking place. It calls for an immediate ceasefire and for the resumption of the peace process, since there is no military solution to the Kurdish question. A conflict that has tens of thousands of displaced people.

name: Alain CADEC
text: in writing.- The text of the resolution on the 2015 report on Turkey is, as it stands, unacceptable.Certain paragraphs of the resolution call for a strengthening of relations between the European Union and Turkey through the resumption of accession negotiations and the opening of Chapters 23 (judiciary and fundamental rights) and 24 (justice, freedom and security.).I am resolutely opposed to Turkey's accession to the European Union.I consider that by continuing to negotiate with this country, we are lying to the Turkish people by making them hope one day to be part of it.I would remind you that the accession procedure requires unanimous agreement of the Member States.I voted against this resolution.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Turkey.The country remains a strategic partner for the EU.With the launch of the EU-Turkey action plan to counter the refugee crisis, Ankara is called upon to carry out a fundamental task in resolving one of the most serious emergencies in recent decades.However, Turkey is called upon to do much more to meet the Copenhagen criteria.The time has come to bring about an alignment with the parameters of the EU which necessarily involves the implementation of adequate and effective reforms.The efforts that we are sure Turkey will be able to make in carrying out the EU-Turkey action plan must be equal to the effort to strengthen the institutions and the process of democratization and modernization of the country.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report deals with the process of Turkey’s accession to the EU. It highlights many of the problems Turkey faces, including human rights abuses, democratic rights and the ongoing mistreatment of refugees. I supported a number of amendments, including those calling for better treatment of refugees, and the removal of the PKK from the terror list as a necessary step towards peace between Turkey and the Kurds. However, the report welcomes the inclusion of Turkey on the list of so-called ‘safe countries of origin’ for refugees. Despite the many problems Turkey faces, and without a resolution of the matter of Cyprus, the report is still supportive of further steps towards Turkey’s accession to the EU. I therefore abstained on the report.

name: David CASA
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey is a key strategic partner of the European Union and the ongoing dialogue is important in order to keep our good relations. I do have concerns about freedom of expression and assembly in Turkey, as well as human rights, and I believe that these matters need to remain on our radar. In parallel, I believe that cooperation with Turkey in different areas such as energy security – and especially the refugee crisis – is needed, and I therefore voted in favour of this resolution.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing.- I supported this report, which is much more critical of Turkey than in previous years.He points to the persisting problems in terms of respect for fundamental freedoms, freedom of speech, where journalists and academics are still imprisoned for their views, and freedom of assembly, as well as stopping the peace process with the Kurdish minority and increasing violence in the south-east.I also welcome the fact that the report clearly succeeded in separating Turkey's position in the current solution to the refugee crisis from the accession process that has been under way since 2005. Turkey must be clear that the EU will not back down in its criteria, even if its negotiating positionCurrent events may seem more advantageous.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: PPE), in writing. - Turkey continues to lag behind in the issue of respect for democracy and the rule of law. The pace of reforms in Turkey has slowed significantly in recent years, with some key areas falling behind and falling further away from meeting the Copenhagen criteria. Regarding Turkey's Cypriot obligations, we emphasize that the non-settlement of the Cyprus issue affects the development of EU-Turkey relations. We call on Turkey to fully comply with its obligation to fully and non-discriminatory implementation of the Additional Protocol to the EC-Turkey Association Agreement to all Member States, including the Republic of Cyprus, which could give a significant impetus to the negotiation process. We disagree with any attempt to open accession funds for Turkey without fulfilling its obligations to Cyprus and the EU.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The report contains several positive elements, as it points out the violations of fundamental rights and basic democratic principles in the candidate Turkey, which document the backwardness of the country. However, I believe that all this should have been emphasized more, given that a semi-authoritarian regime has been imposed in this country, which is increasingly flowing towards overt authoritarianism at home and is acting as an international unrest abroad. Furthermore, the recognition of Turkey's historical past, in terms of the genocides of Christian populations during and after the First World War, should be made a clear precondition for Turkey's further accession process. Since the report omits such references, I felt morally obliged to vote against it.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report especially taking into account the particular historical-political period in which we find ourselves, in which cooperation between the European Union and Turkey must be strengthened.The intent is to offer support to Turkey to stop hostilities in Syria and provide humanitarian aid to people in need.I also think that it is essential not to forget Turkey's strategic importance for the energy security of the European Union and that is why cooperation must be stimulated so that growth and development for both sides can be derived from this relationship.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey has been linked to the EU by an Association Agreement since 1964 and a customs union was established in 1995. The European Council granted the status of candidate country to Turkey in December 1999 and accession negotiations were opened in October 2005. Within the framework of accession negotiations, 14 chapters have been opened so far and one of these was provisionally closed. Preparations started for the opening of chapter 17-economic and monetary policy which would underpin the envisaged high level economic dialogue with Turkey.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing.- I was very pleased to see several provisions in this resolution that point to the real problems that exist in Turkey's accession to the EU.The resolution points to the undeniable setback in respect of democracy and the rule of law, deplores the setbacks in the area of freedom of expression and opinion, underlines that Turkey is the country that holds the record for the number of detained journalists,if with the increase in corruption (highlighted by Transparency International), it condemns the use of anti-terrorist legislation to settle accounts and illegitimate pressure on oppositions and is frightened by the high levels of violence against women, among many other aspects.Even so, the resolution expresses an optimistic view on the possibility of Turkey accessing the EU, which I cannot follow at the moment, so I abstain in the final vote.

name: Birgit COLLIN-LANGEN
text: written.- I voted for the report because Turkey is a key strategic partner for the EU.The basis for this strategic partnership is an intensive political dialogue between the EU and Turkey; in view of the current situation, this is particularly true in the area of foreign and security policy.A partnership must be based on the same values.The report shows the regression and the stalling of reforms in the areas of justice and fundamental rights.It is now up to Turkey, as a partner of the EU, to make concrete progress and actively commit to respecting our core values.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Each candidate country will be judged on its own merits. For me, respect for the rule of law is at the core of the negotiation process, including in particular the separation of powers, freedom of expression and of the media, human rights and democracy. I am concerned that the overall pace of reforms in Turkey has slowed down considerably in recent years. This is highlighted in the report, as is the concern on the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly and freedom of expression. In this sense, there has been a regression moving increasingly away from meeting the Copenhagen criteria to which candidate countries must adhere.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- This report welcomes the agreement between Turkey and the EU on migration, which we oppose.In addition, it underlines "Turkey's great humanitarian contribution" due to its role in welcoming refugees, when in reality it is crowding refugees, fleeing the war, into concentration camps of people including women and minors, without fulfilling the basic conditions.hygiene and violating the most fundamental human rights.With the EU-Turkey agreement and the funds given to Turkey to turn it into a prison for refugees who wish to seek asylum in Europe, it continues in the line of an aggressive foreign policy and contrary to human rights, and as this agreement is acclaimed in this report, I decided to vote against.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - In 1987, Turkey applied for accession to the European Economic Community, and in 1997 it was announced that the country fulfilled the conditions for EU membership. Accession negotiations started in 2005, but until Turkey agrees to the application of the Additional Protocol to the Ankara Association Agreement to Cyprus, eight negotiating chapters will not be opened and no chapter will be provisionally closed. Although Turkey is a functioning market economy and the country is increasingly aligning with the EU acquis, the overall pace of reform of the political criteria has slowed significantly, and some areas such as judicial independence, rule of law, freedom of expression and media have regressed . The security situation in Turkey is deteriorating rapidly due to the increasing violence between Kurds and the Turkish army and numerous terrorist attacks attributed to the Islamic State. The report highlights the resumption of the negotiation process following the adoption of the Joint Action Plan on Migration, but stresses that EU-Turkey cooperation on migration should not be dependent on the content, calendar and conditions of the accession negotiation process. In view of the many doubts that raised the report, I abstained.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing. - In its motion for a resolution, Parliament underlines that Turkey is a strategic partner for the Union and that active and credible negotiations would provide an appropriate framework for exploiting the full potential of EU-Turkey relations. Emphasizing the considerable slowdown in the pace of reforms in Turkey in recent years and the regression in some key areas such as independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly, freedom of expression, respect for human rights and the rule of law, a majority of MEPs say they are ready to reopen certain negotiating chapters with a view to Turkey's possible accession to the European Union. Opposed to the reopening of these negotiations and in line with France's position, I voted against this resolution with my colleagues from the French EPP delegation, considering that fundamental values ​​of the Union are not respected in Turkey.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted against this report on Turkey for the year 2015. Indeed, I am firmly opposed to any new opening of negotiating chapters with a view to Turkey's accession to the European Union.The European Union must be frank towards Turkey.Let us stop making Turkey believe that it will integrate the European Union and put in place the bases of a solid partnership.This is how the Union can continue to support Turkey in its necessary structural reforms.It is also essential that a regular dialogue be maintained in order to face together the major common challenges such as migration and terrorism.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I endorse the motion of the resolution because I cannot ignore the problems that the Turkish citizens are currently facing. The government continuously disregards the rule of law, human rights and democratic values. Corruption is thriving and the independence of the media is under threat. With regard to the latter, the violent takeover of the Turkish newspaper Zaman (and others) was illegal and contrary to the values that the EU (or any other democracy) stands for. In addition, its anti-terrorism laws seem to be in violation of the ECHR, which needs to be respected by Turkey. In addition, the resolution calls upon peace and stability in the Kurdish region and expresses over recent developments with regard to these populations. However, Turkey remains our partner, both on economic terms and politically. In this regard, the resolution recognises its efforts in countering ISIL and other areas of cooperation between us. With regard to the refugee crisis, I would have very much liked to see an EU solution to the refugee crisis. Since we have chosen not to, I can now, at least, welcome the call for closely monitoring that the EU funds to Turkey of EUR 3 billion, are properly spent.

name: Marielle DE SARNEZ
text: in writing.- For the past two years, there has been a serious decline in the freedoms of speech, expression and opinion in Turkey, whether online or not.Such restrictions on fundamental rights and violations of the rule of law must lead the Union to react firmly, in particular by making the aid it grants to Istanbul conditional on respect for democratic principles.It is, moreover, inconceivable that cooperation between the Union and Turkey as regards the reception of refugees, or migrants, should be subject to the opening of new chapters within the framework of Turkey's candidacy for theEuropean Union.More generally, the Union needs to take a break in its enlargement process in order to consolidate what has been achieved at 28. For us, Turkey's accession to the Union should not be in order.of the day of the European calendar.That is why I voted against this report.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- Our line has always been to oppose Turkey's accession to the European Union.This resolution mentions in particular the increasing participation of the Turkish Foreign Minister in the meetings of the European Foreign Affairs Council, which seems to me completely unacceptable since either one is in the Union and, in this case, one is entitled to a seat, orwe are not there and, in this case, we do not participate.It is sending a distorted message to our Turkish partners as well as to European citizens.For the same reasons, I oppose the inclusion of the Turkish language as the official language of the Union.I am for Turkey to be a privileged partner, but not a Member State of the Union, and this is why I have chosen to oppose this process by voting against this resolution and therefore refusing the opening ofnew negotiating chapters.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - Due to its economic and strategic location and its significant role in the region, Turkey is a strategic partner of the Union, emphasizes the report on Turkey voted on today, which discusses the progress made by the country in the 2005 European accession negotiations. It also examines the Turkish authorities' commitment to reforms and their implementation in the areas of justice, the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms. The document specifically highlights the country's importance in addressing the refugee and migration crisis. While supporting renewed political cooperation between the two sides on the crisis, he also stresses that cooperation on migration between the EU and Turkey should not be linked to the accession negotiation process. Reforms in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights are urgently needed in Turkey. We must call on Turkey to respect its commitments to European accession in accordance with European values, to guarantee fundamental rights, to guarantee the cultural, social and political rights of the Kurdish national community and, in the face of its own past, to formally recognize and endorse the Armenian genocide . In the light of these arguments, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: in writing. - This report proposed by Kati Piri is without concession on the deplorable situation facing freedoms in Turkey. Turkey is the country in the world that keeps the most journalists in prison. There is an urgent need for reforms in the area of ​​justice and fundamental rights and freedoms. The text calls for the reestablishment of the separation of powers, and the development of an inclusive constitution. In addition, he calls for the immediate resumption of peace negotiations with the PKK. He condemns the latter's return to violence, such as the conduct of the Turkish authorities which amounts to collective punishment. Here again, things are clear. Finally, they are concerned with the need not to confuse the accession process with the issue of migration (where it is specified that the subcontracting of the refugee crisis is not a credible long-term solution and where it is necessary. asked for a control mechanism to ensure the proper use of the three billion). Like my colleague, I would like to open chapters 23 (judiciary and fundamental rights) and 24 (justice, freedom and security). In my opinion, this is the best way to get Turkey to make progress in the field of human rights.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form.- I voted against the resolution on Turkey's progress because I strongly disagree with the views set out in it.I do not welcome the fact that Turkish is becoming an official language!I do not welcome the agreement between Turkey and the EU!Turkey is wringing the hands of the EU and it is managing the flow of refugees!I do not think that Turkey is sufficiently involved in the fight against ISIL.On the contrary, Turkey supports ISIL.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - Due to its economic and strategic location and its significant role in the region, Turkey is a strategic partner of the Union, emphasizes the report on Turkey voted on today, which discusses the progress made by the country in the 2005 European accession negotiations. It also examines the Turkish authorities' commitment to reforms and their implementation in the areas of justice, the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms. The document specifically highlights the country's importance in addressing the refugee and migration crisis. While supporting renewed political cooperation between the two sides on the crisis, he also stresses that cooperation on migration between the EU and Turkey should not be linked to the accession negotiation process. Reforms in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights are urgently needed in Turkey. We must call on Turkey to respect its commitments to European accession in accordance with European values, to guarantee fundamental rights, to guarantee the cultural, social and political rights of the Kurdish national community and, in the face of its own past, to formally recognize and endorse the Armenian genocide . In the light of these arguments, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Fredrick FEDERLEY
text: written.- The report is Parliament's comment on the Commission's Turkey report.The agreement with Turkey on migration issues clearly colored the resolution, as did the renewed EU membership negotiations.Through the way I voted, I was clear about the demands we place on Turkey, namely that, despite the agreement, Turkey must show clear improvements in the humanitarian field and that the EU must not stop taking responsibility for migration issues.If Turkey is to move closer to the EU, it must be clear in its work towards complying with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights.It is important that we make demands on Turkey in terms of democracy, diversity and human rights.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- Accession negotiations with Turkey were opened on 3 October 2005, but their outcome remains open.The country has pledged to respect the Copenhagen criteria, to undertake appropriate and effective reforms and to progressively align with the EU acquis.However, the report reports on the setback in respect of democracy and the rule of law in Turkey, the considerable slowdown in the overall pace of reforms in recent years and the setback in certain areas, such as the independence of the judiciary, thefreedom of assembly and expression and respect for human rights.I therefore consider it necessary for the Commission to reassess the way in which the negotiations have been conducted to date, as well as the way in which relations and cooperation between the EU and Turkey can be improved and intensified.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - We note in this report the most careful and subtle tone with which the accession process is addressed. A demonstration of the hypocrisy with which both are treated according to their geostrategic and political relevance. Care that will not be foreign to the recent criminal agreement signed between the EU and Turkey, in an inhumane response to the humanitarian crisis of refugees and migrants from the EU. This resolution praises and accepts it, bleaching it with apparent "concerns". We recall that the progress made in these negotiations served as a bargaining chip for the conclusion of the agreement. An agreement that is implemented with criminal actions from both the EU and Turkey, in clear confrontation with international law. The text omits issues such as state terrorism, conflict with the Kurds, or support for the so-called Islamic State in Syria. The resolution points, however, to some guidelines for the need to resolve the conflict in Cyprus, which keeps part of its territory occupied by Turkish military forces, a perspective that could contribute to the necessary and expected reunification of Cyprus, and which we support and value. Despite this, in view of the remaining provisions of the report, we voted against.

name: Santiago FISAS AYXELÀ
text: written.- I voted in favor as, like many in this House, I am concerned about the regression that Turkey has suffered in recent years, as regards the protection of Human Rights and the rule of law.I consider it necessary to call on Turkey to reach an immediate ceasefire and resume peace negotiations regarding the problem with the Kurds, and also to sign and ratify the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - The European Union and Turkey must continue meaningful negotiations, which will remain credible, and the opening of individual chapters will lead to concrete progress in various areas. Turkey must immediately take action against intimidation of journalists in all its forms and explain the illegal takeover of some newspapers. In the last two years, we can also see a deterioration in the situation of freedom of expression and opinion. Turkey must make a clear commitment to building the rule of law, reforming the judiciary and improving the security situation in the country. The situation in south-eastern Turkey, where the peace process has still not resumed, is also worrying. A separate chapter should be the negotiation process within the framework of the agreement between the European Union and Turkey in the field of migration, where Turkey is the most important partner for the European Union, as it currently has the largest migrant population.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against the report which among other things calls for Turkish to become an official language of the European Union.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. - I am voting against the report B8-0442 / 2016 as it recognizes that in Turkey human rights, freedom of expression, the rights of minorities (including Greeks) are being suppressed, that people are being arrested for expressing opinions. The resolution is characterized by unprecedented pro-Turkish views which are not based on any facts at all. Finally, this text expresses views in favor of the overthrow of the Republic of Cyprus and its replacement with a formation that will be based on racist policies and will violate the rights of the Greeks of Cyprus and at the same time legitimize the illegal invasion and continued occupation.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I believe active and credible negotiations provide a suitable framework for exploiting the full potential of EU-TR relations and I hope that the opening of chapters will lead to concrete progress. Turkey should act against intimidation of journalists in all its forms, condemn the violent and illegal take-over of several newspapers and stop serious backsliding, as over the past two years, on freedom of speech, expression and opinion, both on-line and off-line. I support the call for an immediate ceasefire in south—east Turkey and the resumption of the peace process, and urge the Turkish government to shoulder its responsibility to resume negotiations for a negotiated, comprehensive and sustainable solution to the Kurdish issue. The Kurdistan Workers’ Party (PKK), should lay down its arms, abandon terrorist tactics and use peaceful and legal means to voice its expectations. EU-Turkey cooperation on migration should be uncoupled from the EU accession negotiating process. Turkey is hosting the largest refugee population in the world, and is a key strategic partner for the EU, but we must have a more structured and frequent political dialogue on key thematic issues.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - Due to its economic and strategic location and its significant role in the region, Turkey is a strategic partner of the Union, emphasizes the report on Turkey voted on today, which discusses the progress made by the country in the 2005 European accession negotiations. It also examines the Turkish authorities' commitment to reforms and their implementation in the areas of justice, the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms. The document specifically highlights the country's importance in addressing the refugee and migration crisis. While supporting renewed political cooperation between the two sides on the crisis, he also stresses that cooperation on migration between the EU and Turkey should not be linked to the accession negotiation process. Reforms in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights are urgently needed in Turkey. We must call on Turkey to respect its commitments to European accession in accordance with European values, to guarantee fundamental rights, to guarantee the cultural, social and political rights of the Kurdish national community and, in the face of its own past, to formally recognize and endorse the Armenian genocide . In the light of these arguments, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - Due to its economic and strategic location and its significant role in the region, Turkey is a strategic partner of the Union, emphasizes the report on Turkey voted on today, which discusses the progress made by the country in the 2005 European accession negotiations. It also examines the Turkish authorities' commitment to reforms and their implementation in the areas of justice, the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms. The document specifically highlights the country's importance in addressing the refugee and migration crisis. While supporting renewed political cooperation between the two sides on the crisis, he also stresses that cooperation on migration between the EU and Turkey should not be linked to the accession negotiation process. Reforms in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights are urgently needed in Turkey. We must call on Turkey to respect its commitments to European accession in accordance with European values, to guarantee fundamental rights, to guarantee the cultural, social and political rights of the Kurdish national community and, in the face of its own past, to formally recognize and endorse the Armenian genocide . In the light of these arguments, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- Turkey is a key strategic partner for the EU, especially considering that it has been a candidate country since 2005. Therefore, despite being critical of the forms and substance of the agreement with the EU in the management of the refugee crisis,I voted in favor of the progress report on Turkey and I urge it to continue working together with the European Union on the path that the Turkish Government must continue to ensure the pace of the negotiations and unambiguously commit to respect the values and principlesdemocratic fundamentals of the Union.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of Turkey's annual progress report. The report recognizes that Turkey is the country with the largest refugee population. Today, the EU and Turkey face common challenges and the two partners need each other in order to find joint solutions. At the same time, the report regrets that this year there was a significant democratic setback, in particular in the areas of freedom of expression, freedom of the press, the rule of law and the rights of minorities. The report urges Turkey to resume democratic reforms and is betting that the EU accession process can accelerate these necessary changes. The report also addresses the situation in southeastern Turkey, where the largest wave of violence in 20 years is taking place. In this sense, an immediate ceasefire and the resumption of the peace process are called for, since there is no military solution to the Kurdish question. A conflict that has caused tens of thousands of displaced people.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - I voted in favor of Turkey's annual progress report. The report praises that Turkey is the country in the world with the largest refugee population. Today the EU and Turkey face many common challenges and we need each other in order to find joint solutions. At the same time, the report is critical and shows that this year there has been a significant democratic setback, especially in the areas of freedom of expression, freedom of the press, the rule of law and the rights of minorities. The report urges Turkey to resume democratizing reforms once again, aligning itself with EU values ​​and is betting that the accession process can accelerate these necessary changes. The report addresses the situation in southeastern Turkey, where the most significant wave of violence in the last 20 years is taking place. It calls for an immediate ceasefire and for the resumption of the peace process, since there is no military solution to the Kurdish question. A conflict that has tens of thousands of displaced people.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the 2015 report on Turkey because I support the need for a greater democratic push in the country, especially in the area of ​​freedom of expression, freedom of the media, the rule of law and minority rights. Today the European Union and Turkey face numerous challenges that still find ineffective solutions, from immigration to respect for human rights, and above all with respect to the freedom of expression of journalists. There is no doubt that Turkey is an essential partner in solving the migrant crisis, but at the same time it must be ensured that the rights of asylum seekers are fully respected. Furthermore, with this resolution the European Parliament intends to strongly condemn the intimidation directed at the media environment and I agree to express my deep concern about the deterioration in the last two years of the situation regarding the freedom of speech, expression and opinion. in the country. It is essential, in order to continue on the path of integration in the European context, that Turkey fully aligns itself with European values, principles and criteria: these are non-negotiable conditions for the Group of Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The assessment of the internal condition of Turkey is of enormous importance in view of the agreement that has just been concluded to deal with the refugee crisis.It is important to be aware of the domestic affairs of your trading partners.The aspect of recognizing the Republic of Cyprus as an independent country and EU member also plays a decisive role for us.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We have voted to abstain on a text that is suitably harsh in denouncing the violation of human rights carried out systematically by the Turkish government against minorities, political opponents and journalists, demanding as to the criteria and conditions of access ofTurkey to the EU but absolutely contrary to political and legal responsibility regarding migratory co-management and the protection of the rights of people in situations of forced mobility.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for this motion as it correctly identifies that a lot of progress remains to be made with Turkey on important matters such as rule of law, freedom of press and fundamental values. Turkey is a vitally important partner for the EU and this relationship must continue to develop in a positive manner than is in line with EU fundamental values.

name: Françoise GROSSETÊTE
text: in writing.- On Thursday April 14, I rejected a report on emergency measures to be taken by Turkey, which spoke in favor of continuing accession negotiations.Indeed, I consider that EU-Turkey cooperation on migration must be decoupled from the process of joining the Union.We cannot accept that Turkey uses migrants to cash its membership in the Union, membership which we are opposed to anyway.This report also highlights the decline in the rule of law and fundamental values in the country, where there is a worrying decline in freedom of expression and the independence of the judiciary.

name: Jytte GUTELAND
text: written.- We Swedish Social Democrats want to emphasize that we support the demand that Turkey should acknowledge the genocide of Armenians.We also want to emphasize that we welcome all efforts made to move forward in the reconciliation process in Cyprus, so that the parties can reach a settlement on the issue in accordance with the 2014 letter of intent.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - Due to its economic and strategic location and its significant role in the region, Turkey is a strategic partner of the Union, emphasizes the report on Turkey voted on today, which discusses the progress made by the country in the 2005 European accession negotiations. It also examines the Turkish authorities' commitment to reforms and their implementation in the areas of justice, the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms. The document specifically highlights the country's importance in addressing the refugee and migration crisis. While supporting renewed political cooperation between the two sides on the crisis, he also stresses that cooperation on migration between the EU and Turkey should not be linked to the accession negotiation process. Reforms in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights are urgently needed in Turkey. We must call on Turkey to respect its commitments to European accession in accordance with European values, to guarantee fundamental rights, to guarantee the cultural, social and political rights of the Kurdish national community, and to face its own past. In the light of these arguments, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The progress report on Turkey correctly highlights the setback observed in almost all sectors in the country. Violations of fundamental rights, the dismantling of the rule of law and the persecution of Kurds, journalists and academics in Turkey are issues that are thoroughly analyzed in the report and Turkey is urged to take immediate steps to change this situation. For the Cyprus issue there are very positive reports with the inclusion of the basic parameters of the form of the solution we seek. A solution that will be the result of the transformation of the Republic of Cyprus into an ICC with a sovereignty, an international personality and a citizenship, based on international law and the relevant UN resolutions. The need for the withdrawal of Turkish troops, the return of Famagusta and the opening of files that will lead to the fate of the missing is stressed. The settlement policy is also condemned. The report also has some negatives such as the reference to the opening of accession funds, the support for the EU-Turkey agreement on migration and NATO involvement in the Aegean. For these reasons we abstained.

name: Brian HAYES
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as I am in favour of continuing talks with Turkey.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - Due to its economic and strategic location and its significant role in the region, Turkey is a strategic partner of the Union, emphasizes the report on Turkey voted on today, which discusses the progress made by the country in the 2005 European accession negotiations. The document also examines the Turkish authorities' commitment to reforms and their implementation in the areas of justice, the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms. The document specifically highlights the country's importance in addressing the refugee and migration crisis. While supporting renewed political cooperation between the two sides on the crisis, he also stresses that cooperation on migration between the EU and Turkey should not be linked to the accession negotiation process. Reforms in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights are urgently needed in Turkey. We must call on Turkey to respect its commitments to European accession in accordance with European values, to guarantee fundamental rights, to guarantee the cultural, social and political rights of the Kurdish national community and, in the face of its own past, to formally recognize and endorse the Armenian genocide . In the light of these arguments, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Brice HORTEFEUX
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution on Turkey, which marks a worrying development in the position of the European Parliament with regard to Turkey's application for membership of the European Union. My position is constant and I would like to reiterate it: yes to Turkey as a privileged partner of the Union, no to its membership which, given the stagnation of negotiations concerning the chapters already open, is not close to arrive. I am worried that the positions taken by certain political groups in Parliament encourage the institutionalization of the participation of the Turkish Foreign Minister in meetings of the European Foreign Affairs Council, or the inclusion of the Turkish language as the official language of The union. This is the disguised path to membership. However, the European peoples are very clear on this subject: Turkey, which shares its borders with Syria, Iraq, Iran, Georgia - that is to say a highly unstable region -, has not intended to join the Union. Today we have a titanic job to do to reestablish control of our own external borders. Would we push the absurdity to the point of entrusting this task to a country whose infringements of freedoms are at the same time being criticized?

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I believe that the EU should praise Turkey for hosting such a tremendous amount of refugees. Turkey has become the largest refugee host in the world. As such, the EU should provide a significant economic package in order to take some of the strain off the Turkish economy. However, I firmly believe that EU-Turkey cooperation on migration should not be tied to Turkey’s EU accession negotiating process.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the Commission's report on Turkey for 2015, as it reflects my views as well. There has been a problem of setbacks in recent years in terms of respect for democracy and the rule of law and the slow implementation of reforms. The postponement of the Commission's 2015 progress report following the November 2015 Turkish elections was wrong, as it gave the impression that the EU was willing to go beyond fundamental rights violations in exchange for Turkish government co-operation on refugees. The strengthening of the political dialogue between the EU and Turkey in the field of foreign and security policy is positive. Turkey urgently needs judicial and human rights, justice and freedom reforms. There has been a serious setback in the past two years in terms of freedom of speech, expression and opinion, both online and in the traditional media. Turkey is invited to continue to work closely with the European Commission on new legislation in the preparation and implementation of existing legislation to ensure alignment with the EU acquis. It strongly condemns the terrorist attacks that took place in Turkey and expresses solidarity with the victims and with the citizens of Turkey.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- This report goes completely against our long-standing position, which is to reject, by all possible means, Turkish interference in the affairs of the European Union.The elements discussed in this text demonstrate once again the submission of the European authorities to the Turkish state, which is trying to lead the dance in exchanges with the Union.Furthermore, the desire to encourage the introduction of the Turkish language as the official language of the European Union is an aberration which I strongly oppose.My vote was obviously against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted against the report by my colleague Kati Piri concerning the report on Turkey 2015. Regardless of the fact that Turkey is not European, geographically or culturally, the policies undertaken by Turkey in terms of independence of thejustice, freedom of expression, respect for human rights and the rule of law continue to move it away from European standards.If cooperation between Turkey and the Union must legitimately be strengthened in terms of energy security, the fight against terrorism, or even the refugee crisis, this is an irresponsible lie towards citizens, Europeans and Turks alike,than to maintain wrongly the illusion that Turkey has a vocation to join the European Union.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this report which contains unacceptable parts.He proposes the opening of new membership chapters (n ° 23 and 24), yet I am against Turkey's accession to the Union.The report also welcomes an initiative to make Turkish an official language of the Union, even though the Cyprus issue is not yet settled.Finally, he proposes that the Turkish Minister for Foreign Affairs can participate in the Council of European Ministers when this is justified.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- The report calls for closer cooperation with Turkey, shows little criticism of the prevailing system, and the Cyprus issue is only considered hesitantly in the rare passages in the report and, in my opinion, completely inadequately.Overall, the report is in favor of Turkey joining, which is why I am voting against the report.
