name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written. - The 2015 Status Report on Turkey rightly states that Turkey has stepped backwards in terms of human rights, internal security, freedom of the press and freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and democratization. All these civilizing achievements can be found in the Copenhagen criteria of 1993, which serve as the basis for the admission of new members to the EU. In my view, a resumption of accession negotiations is unacceptable, particularly in view of these mistakes by Turkey. Unfortunately, the reopening of individual chapters of the negotiations is accepted so as not to endanger the refugee agreement with Turkey. This position is explained by the fact that the negotiations are hoping for a change in Turkey. I do not agree with this analysis, but have rejected the report because Turkey, and in particular President Erdoğan, promised a free hand in domestic politics thanks to their special role in the migration crisis, without having to deliver on democratization and human rights.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - Due to its economic and strategic location and its significant role in the region, Turkey is a strategic partner of the Union, emphasizes the report on Turkey voted on today, which discusses the progress made by the country in the 2005 European accession negotiations. It also examines the Turkish authorities' commitment to reforms and their implementation in the areas of justice, the rule of law, fundamental rights and freedoms. The document specifically highlights the country's importance in addressing the refugee and migration crisis. While supporting renewed political cooperation between the two sides on the crisis, he also stresses that cooperation on migration between the EU and Turkey should not be linked to the accession negotiation process. Reforms in the areas of justice, the rule of law and human rights are urgently needed in Turkey. We must call on Turkey to respect its commitments to European accession in accordance with European values, to guarantee fundamental rights, to guarantee the cultural, social and political rights of the Kurdish national community and, in the face of its own past, to formally recognize and endorse the Armenian genocide . In the light of these arguments, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Stelios KOULOGLOU
text: in writing. ‒ The report was quite critical of latest in events in Turkey, especially concerning democratic rights and freedom. However, the fact that the rapporteur wants to deepen relations with Turkey without Turkey meeting Copenhagen criteria is something that I cannot support. There is still a lot to be done from Turkey, before we could say that Turkey is respecting all freedoms and rights. This is why I voted abstention.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I have supported the report because Turkey is not only a candidate country for EU membership, but also our strategic partner. It is important to note that in recent years Turkey has been hit by one of the deadliest waves of terrorism in our time, while at the same time the country has been hosting the largest refugee population in the world and has been experiencing instability from the ongoing conflict in neighbouring Syria. Namely in the context of a complicated security situation, we should acknowledge Turkey’s commitment for reforms and alienation with the acquis. Although in slow pace, progress has been achieved in the areas of company law, financial services, financial control, the customs union and trans-European networks. In this regard, Turkey’s continual commitment to the fulfilment of the Copenhagen criteria should be viewed as an opportunity for Turkey to strengthen its institutions and continue its process of democratisation and modernisation.

name: Constance LE GRIP
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution adopted by Parliament on the situation in Turkey in 2015. Through this rejection, we, the Republicans, reaffirmed our deep reservations about the content of the botched, hasty and unbalanced agreement concluded between the European Union and Turkey. On the pretext that we must be able to count on the cooperation of the Turkish state to stop the flow of illegal migrants and refugees who pass through the "Balkan route" or cross the Mediterranean from the Turkish shore, to break down criminal networks smugglers, who we know are more and more linked to the "Islamic State" group, we cannot procrastinate on the issue of human rights, freedom of the press, minority rights and go through the caudine forks of the Sublime Porte! I also recalled by this vote my absolute opposition to the opening of negotiation chapters with a view to the possible accession of Turkey to the European Union, and in particular to the condition of lifting the visa requirement. for Turkish nationals wishing to travel to the Union asked by the Turkish government: there is no question for us, the Republicans, of giving in to Turkish blackmail!

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the annual report on Turkey.Even if this text contains an impressive series of fundamentally critical points about the Turkish government, it is still in line with Turkey's accession to the European Union.The amendment of the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group condemning the resumption of accession negotiations was rejected, although Turkey does not meet the conditions to be able to continue negotiating.The idea of Turkish membership is contrary to the interests of European nations.It is overwhelmingly rejected by the French and other European peoples.That is why Turkey's accession process must be brought to an end.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report, because it supports the process of accession to the Union of Turkey despite the troubled relations maintained by this state with the "Islamic State" group.The amendment of the ENL group which proposed to stop the accession negotiations was rejected by 551 votes against 80!Another amendment by the ENL group calling for recognition of the Armenian genocide was also rejected, but still obtained 159 votes.The icing on the cake: this report envisages making Turkish an official language of the Union!

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of Turkey's annual progress report. The report praises that Turkey is the country in the world with the largest refugee population. Today the EU and Turkey face many common challenges and we need each other in order to find joint solutions. At the same time, the report is critical and shows that this year there has been a significant democratic setback, especially in the areas of freedom of expression, freedom of the press, the rule of law and the rights of minorities. The report urges Turkey to resume democratizing reforms once again, aligning itself with EU values ​​and is betting that the accession process can accelerate these necessary changes. The report addresses the situation in southeastern Turkey, where the most significant wave of violence in the last 20 years is taking place. It calls for an immediate ceasefire and for the resumption of the peace process, since there is no military solution to the Kurdish question. A conflict that has tens of thousands of displaced people.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- This report welcomes the agreement between Turkey and the EU on migration, which we oppose.In addition, it underlines "the great humanitarian contribution of Turkey" due to its role in hosting refugees, when in reality it is crowding refugees, fleeing the war, into concentration camps of people including women and minors, without fulfilling the basic conditions.hygiene and violating the most fundamental human rights.With the EU-Turkey agreement and the funds given to Turkey to turn it into a prison for refugees who wish to request asylum in Europe, it continues in the line of an aggressive foreign policy and contrary to human rights, and as this agreement is acclaimed in this report, I decided to vote against.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- Accession negotiations with Turkey were opened in 2005 and are a fundamental starting point for a long and indefinite process based on strict conditions, motivation for reforms and respect for the legal framework.Today, Turkey still has candidate status, and the entire accession process has been slowed down due to the implementation of EU legislation.In some areas, such as freedom of expression and freedom of public assembly, there has been a significant setback and the security situation in Turkey has become very questionable.EU-Turkey negotiations and co-operation need to be improved.Therefore, the Union needs to make greater efforts to stabilize Turkey, especially in times of migrant crisis.Turkey, as a potential partner, has a key role to play in energy, trade and certain industrial products.I supported the report on Turkey because I believe that Turkey is a very important and strategic partner for the Union.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. - I am sorry to note that the level of democratic development in Turkey has fallen sharply in recent years. A number of reforms and various other innovations, the repression of the media, minorities and the army, as well as serious political polarization, do not bode well for fact or perspective. It is also not possible to see significant progress in the negotiations with the European Union. And perhaps most importantly, when it comes to Turkey's foreign affairs, apart from the positive relations with Azerbaijan and Northern Cyprus, in fact, in all other cases, they range from neutral to negative, which also applies to the region as a whole. More than that, in the case of Syria and Iraq, Ankara is not at all interested in the sovereignty of their borders. At the same time, there are serious concerns that Turkish intelligence is cooperating with the Islamic State on the same illegal oil trade, as well as contributing to the flourishing of the migrant and refugee crisis in Europe. While I unequivocally support the development of a productive and constructive relationship with Turkey, any negotiations with it must always bear in mind what has happened inside and outside it. Otherwise, normal dialogue and results will not be achieved. I voted in favor of the whole.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing. - Addressing the rule of law, democracy, respect for and protection of human rights and freedoms remains a challenge for Turkey, which requires reforms. Turkey has undergone significant economic growth, but often at the expense of the environment. There is a continuing need to increase transparency in all spheres, to eliminate corruption, to improve the quality of justice, to eliminate discrimination and to respect religious diversity, ethnic and gender equality. To this end, Turkey must not only adopt the necessary legislation, but must also ensure that it is respected and complied with. Despite many political and internal problems, EU cooperation with Turkey is one of the key issues in addressing the migration and refugee crisis. I consider it essential for the Commission to monitor on an ongoing basis the use of the Union's funds for Turkey to address this crisis, so that these funds are used transparently, efficiently and effectively and so that they are not misused.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I am voting against the motion for a resolution on the 2015 report on Turkey for the reasons I set out in detail in my speech at the European Parliament plenary session in Strasbourg on 13/4/2016, as well as because this report is not complete and substantiated.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This report on the progress of accession negotiations with Turkey falls in the midst of the migrant crisis. The Union offered 6 billion so that it "keeps" the Syrian refugees, even though Turkey's benevolence towards the "Islamic State" group no longer needs to be demonstrated. In addition, it is a real satisfaction given to the government of Erdoğan as it pursues its authoritarian agenda. The resolution notes this hardening against the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly, freedom of expression. It also calls for peaceful solutions to the Kurdish conflict and violations of Cypriot territory. But the "pursuit of enlargement" remains. Turkey can therefore continue its actions quietly, in particular against only local forces, in particular Kurds, which are fighting the "Islamic State" group. The Parliament even proposes to offer new import rights to Turkey for agricultural products, services and public procurement. He asked to take Turkey's opinion into account in the negotiations on TAFTA. Turkey is therefore virtually a de facto member of the Union. I vote against.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This report favorable to cooperation with Turkey ultimately supports its membership.I see that Turkey is playing a murky geopolitical game that we pretend not to understand.Following his complaints, let us note that the important financings which were granted to him were collected, without results.Finally, I oppose the spirit of this text, which militates for an ever wider Europe.Consequently, I voted against the text.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it presents a balanced view of the situation in Turkey, commending its efforts in the fight against the so-called Islamic State whilst also stressing the need for protection of rights.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - Enlargement is a mechanism which directly serves the emergence of the Union as a world power. To be credible, the Union must develop a fair approach to the membership of this country, whose importance for ensuring regional and, beyond that, global stability is a reality. Today, the Union and Turkey have forged a strategic relationship which enables them to develop enhanced cooperation to jointly face many challenges. However, concerns about respect for human rights, freedom of the press and assembly, gender equality and minorities (i.e. Roma, Kurds, Christians and Jews), among others, are very real and cannot be ignored. We cannot condone the impunity of the police, nor the modification of the law on the Internet, nor the violation of the rights of LGBTI people. We cannot accept breaches of the principle of the separation of powers. A credible accession process requires the restoration of trust between partners keen to develop a constructive political dialogue.

name: Miroslav MIKOLÁŠIK
text: in writing. - Turkey is undoubtedly our important neighbor and partner in many areas, such as energy and the related implementation of projects of common interest (Southern Gas Corridor) as part of the EU's strategy to diversify energy sources. The importance of Turkey is also evident in resolving the migration crisis. In this context, however, I strongly advocate that the recently signed agreement should under no circumstances constitute a gateway for Turkey to open new chapters in the accession process. This privilege must be based solely on the objective and transparent fulfillment of the Copenhagen criteria and must not be a promise to address the humanitarian crisis. Turkey has serious shortcomings in the area of ​​respect for human rights and freedoms, the rule of law, freedom, democracy, justice and security (addressing the Kurdish issue), and this situation continues to worsen instead of improving. Freedom of speech, independence of the media or religious freedom are principles on which we cannot compromise and which our international allies must strictly adhere to if they are interested in advancing to the so-called on the European road. The plight of Christian communities, which have long struggled to gain legal personality and are vainly invoking fundamental rights such as obtaining a building permit to build an adequate place to associate, has nothing to do with the status of Turks in the Member States of the Union. And we can no longer accept such a highly non-reciprocal state.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the progress report on Turkey since the negotiation process must continue and be accelerated. There is a need for more democracy, especially in the areas of freedom of expression, freedom of media, the rule of law and the rights of minorities. The resolution calls on Turkish authorities to fully adopt European values and the Copenhagen criteria.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The Commission has presented its 2015 report on Turkey. The report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on the proposal recalls Turkey's commitment to meeting the Copenhagen criteria, implementing appropriate and effective reforms and gradually moving closer to the acquis. In contrast, the pace of reforms in terms of political criteria has slowed and significant progress has been made in the area of ​​freedom of expression and assembly. Turkey still has the highest number of imprisoned journalists in the world and Freedom House, which monitors press and media freedom, says Turkey is still a country where there is no press freedom and only partial internet freedom. The report lists the key aspects of the accession negotiations: the rule of law, democracy, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms, the Kurdish peace process and the situation in south-eastern Turkey, and EU-Turkey cooperation on the refugee and migration crisis. and the progress of the reunification negotiations in Cyprus. I supported the motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - Turkey, in recent months, has been a permanent target of several terrorist attacks, perpetrated by the self-proclaimed Islamic State. The continuing war in Syria has caused a steady influx of refugees to the country, which necessitates a structured policy towards them. According to UNHCR data, Turkey is currently home to the largest refugee population in the world, around 2.7 million. This solidarity and effort must be shared by all countries and a policy of integration appropriate to the vulnerability of refugees must be achieved at multilateral level. Despite the importance of Turkey's role in trying to achieve some stability in the region, I note some setbacks in terms of respect for democracy and the rule of law, respect for human rights and fundamental freedoms. I believe that the dialogue between the Union and Turkey must continue to call for the necessary efforts to ensure the application of the rule of law that respects human dignity and promotes adequate human development.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I opposed the vote on this resolution, which provided for the opening of new negotiating chapters for Turkey's accession to the European Union, called for the Turkish language to become an official language of the European Union in the shortterm and proposed that the Turkish Foreign Minister be systematically invited to the Council.Turkey is neither geographically, historically nor culturally part of the European Union.It is therefore not intended to adhere to it.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: in writing.- I voted against the paragraphs which aimed to go further in the negotiations for Turkey's entry into the European Union.Turkey is a very big country that I respect.This is precisely why we must stop lying to the Turkish people: Europe is not intended to expand indefinitely.We must build a privileged partnership with our closest neighbor, but for that we must stop focusing on the false debate of their membership.Europe and Turkey have a future to build together, but Turkey's future is not to become a member of the European Union.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- Turkey is an essential partner for the European Union, particularly in the management of migratory flows to European countries.Its commitment to the fight against terrorism is also welcome, and I support the Turkish government's decision to allow coalition forces to use its military bases.However, I cannot accept that Turkey is instrumental in using the current crisis to get Parliament to continue the process of joining the European Union.While Turkey is far from respecting the convergence criteria to consider membership, even though the country is a major player in the Middle East and not in Europe, my position remains unchanged.I therefore voted against the resolution and would like to express my disappointment at seeing the European Parliament concede what, for the time being, should not be.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing. - Turkey is undoubtedly the Union's most important strategic partner, which is why I welcome the motion for a resolution, which emphasizes the need for active and credible negotiations, and seeks to provide an appropriate framework for exploiting EU-Turkey relations. I agree with the report's concern about the drastic slowdown in Turkey's pace of reform measures, especially in key areas such as respect for human rights, the independence of the judiciary, freedom of expression or the rule of law. I believe that Turkey is overconfident, so it is important to maintain the Union's significant strategic position. The issue of migrants should not be a reason for Turkey to develop a position of extortion, but we must acknowledge Turkey's significant role in the migrant crisis. It is also key for me to point out the topicality of the Kurdish issue, which the Turkish side often tries to put in the background. The report talks about the initiative of the President of the Republic of Cyprus to make Turkish an official language of the Union. I do not see it as timely to introduce this until Cyprus is reunited.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on Turkey following the conclusion drawn by my political group after a debate in which two big questions were raised regarding the good implementation and monitoring of the use of the money.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that the European Union must continue, in the current political context, to support its external partners with whom it has the same priorities: ensuring peace, democracy, security and prosperity.In this sense, today's report presents the state of relations, the progress, but also the regressions of Turkey in order to join the European Union.It is right that Turkey's economic development, good cooperation and commitment to the fight against terrorism, but also to the accommodation of migrants, is highlighted, as Turkey is the country with the largest number of refugees.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted against the report because the report does not take sufficient account of the current state of Turkey.Serious rule-of-law problems such as freedom of the media and the press or the Cyprus problem are not or not sufficiently addressed.Furthermore, the report does not take into account the fact that there is currently no prospect of Turkey joining the EU.

name: Kostas PAPADAKIS
text: NI), in writing. - The report recognizes Turkey as a "key strategic partner", supporting the EU imperialist interventions in the SE region. Mediterranean. The "routine" recommendations for "strengthening good neighborly relations", ending violations of Greek airspace and sea space are self-defeating, as the report merely mentions them in "bilateral disputes" with Greece, thus giving substance to Turkish claims. Individual criticisms of aspects of the intra-bourgeois conflict in Turkey cannot hide the fact that the report substantially reinforces the aggression of the Turkish bourgeoisie, as it advocates opening up accession negotiations, welcomes the dangerous EU-Turkey agreement its participation in the imperialist war in Syria, "recognizes Turkey's legitimate right to suppress terrorism" as a pretext for military operations against the Kurdish population. The EU promotes imperialist intervention by exploiting the reactionary, unpopular governments of countries such as Turkey. The SYRIZA-ANEL government, with its active participation in these dangerous plans, involves our people in incalculable risks of generalized conflict, "graying", co-management of the Aegean under a European Union umbrella. The people to put obstacles with their struggle in the plans of the imperialists, their monopolies and their unions.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing. - Considering that in 2005 the Commission started negotiations for Turkey's accession to the European Union; considering that, according to Article 49 of the Treaty on European Union, any European state that respects the values ​​of the EU and undertakes to promote them can apply for membership and that, to this end, Turkey has already taken the path economic and democratic reforms to align with the founding principles and values ​​of the European Union; considering, however, that many fundamental freedoms in the country are not yet guaranteed and that there is, on the contrary, an involution in respect for democracy; considering also that in recent weeks Turkey has seen its security and territorial stability severely undermined; finally considering that an agreement has recently been concluded between the EU and the Turkish government regarding the migrant crisis; Finally, considering that on the basis of the comments made so far, greater EU-Turkey cooperation is needed, I would vote in favor.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I consider the report is able to convey the necessary ambition on how the EU and Member States should continue to endeavour in relations with Turkey. I positively assess the relations as more sincere and straight to the point, especially in mutually understanding what can be shared and what will remain for the political elites of the future. I think the report was also able to reflect the important role Turkey is playing in the refugee crisis and correctly portray the distinction between the Turkish state, as a country, with its citizens and its invaluable culture, and the government of Turkey. In this sense, further negotiations and opening of chapters can keep on fostering the right frame for constructive dialogue and guidance.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support this resolution because it correctly identifies all the key issues, and I consider the recommendations set out in it to be the right recommendations for the progress of Turkish democracy, but also the EU's cooperation with Turkey and Turkey's approach to the EU. Turkey must strengthen its institutions and continue the process of democratization and modernization. When we talk about EU-Turkey cooperation on the refugee crisis, I think it is important to separate the negotiation process from the joint agreement between Turkey and the EU. In this regard, I would like to emphasize that Turkey must honor its obligations and avoid any forced illegal return of refugees to Syria. According to Amnesty International, some incidents of this kind have been observed including the forced return of women and children. As pointed out in the resolution, I believe that Turkey should use the three billion euros available to it from the Refugee Instrument in an appropriate way. Also, the protection of human rights is crucial, especially the rights of women and children, as well as the protection of religious minorities.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- I am concerned that, in the light of the setbacks observed in recent years in terms of respect for democracy and the rule of law in Turkey in general, the implementation of reforms in recent years has slowed down considerably.I welcome the strengthening of the EU-Turkey political dialogue in the field of foreign and security policy and the fact that in 2015 Turkey increased its compliance with EU statements and Council decisions.The fight against corruption should be one of Turkey's priorities.Turkey needs a renewed anti-corruption strategy and action plan, an independent anti-corruption body and a reliable record of investigations, court proceedings and judgments, and even high-level cases.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - We note in this report the most careful and subtle tone with which the accession process is approached, demonstrating the hypocrisy with which both are treated in terms of their geostrategic and political relevance. Care that will not be foreign to the recent and criminal agreement signed with Turkey, in an unacceptable response to the humanitarian crisis of refugees and migrants from the EU. This resolution praises and accepts it, bleaching it with apparent "concerns". We recall that the progress made in these negotiations served as a bargaining chip for the conclusion of the hideous agreement. An agreement that is implemented with criminal actions by both the EU and Turkey in clear confrontation with international law. The text omits it, but we do not forget the repressive stance of power in Turkey, the state terrorism it perpetrates, the conflict with the Kurds, or the support for the so-called Islamic State in Syria. The resolution points, however, to some guidelines for the need to resolve the conflict in Cyprus, which keeps part of its territory occupied by Turkish military forces, a perspective that could contribute to the necessary and expected reunification of Cyprus, and which we support and value. We voted against.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - I support the adoption of this annual report on Turkey, which focuses on the current state of EU-Turkey relations and the internal situation in that country. However, I find it very worrying that Turkey, as a candidate country, is not making greater efforts to improve respect for the principles of democracy and the rule of law, despite the declared effort to open further chapters in the accession negotiations. In particular, I find Turkey's approach to freedom of expression unacceptable, given the still high number of imprisoned journalists, but also because of the gradual nationalization of the media and the censorship of the Internet. Transparency International's assessment of the growing level of corruption is also very worrying. In this context, Turkey needs to adopt the necessary reforms in the areas of fundamental rights, justice, freedom and security. At the same time, however, I recognize that Turkey is our strategic partner, especially in the light of the refugee crisis, and that it is necessary to cooperate with it in this area. However, I would like to emphasize that cooperation in resolving the migration crisis cannot have the effect of any relief or reduction in the requirements for Turkey's accession to the EU or visa-free travel. Other issues of common interest also include the fight against terrorism, the economy, trade and energy. That is why it is necessary to continue to strengthen good neighborly relations and to intensify structured political dialogues.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - I voted against the resolution on the 2015 report on Turkey, presented by the European Commission in November 2015. I would like to recall that the current cooperation between the Union and Turkey in the context of the management of the migration crisis must be dissociated from the process of negotiating the country's accession to the Union. Specifically, although Turkey is a "key strategic partner" for the European Union, the overall pace of reforms in the country has slowed down in recent times, with worrying regressions in terms of freedom of expression, and even more. independence of the judiciary. The 2015 report on Turkey also indicates that the Kurdish peace process is a major issue. The negotiations on the reunification of Cyprus are also linked to Turkish policy. If a positive development were to take place in relations between Cyprus and Turkey, it would not change the fact that I remain opposed to Turkey's entry into the European Union at all.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - Accession negotiations with Turkey were opened on 3 October 2005 and the opening of these negotiations was the starting point of a long process, the outcome of which remains open. The report states that the EU must remain the anchor of reforms in Turkey, given the transformative power of the accession negotiations and the enlargement process. However, in view of the decline in respect for democracy and the rule of law in Turkey, the report expresses deep concern at the considerable slowdown in the overall pace of reforms in Turkey in recent years and the fact that there has been a setback. in certain areas, such as the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly and expression and respect for human rights and the rule of law, increasingly moving away from fulfilling the criteria to which the candidate countries must adhere. The report stresses, however, that Turkey is an important strategic partner for the EU and that active and credible negotiations will provide an adequate framework to harness the full potential of relations between the two parties. I voted in favor.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- This report expresses, in the light of the setback in respect of democracy and the rule of law in Turkey, its deep concern at the considerable slowdown in the overall pace of reforms in this country in recent years, with a substantial setback in terms ofcertain areas, such as the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly and expression and respect for human rights and the rule of law, increasingly moving away from fulfilling the Copenhagen criteria to which the candidate countries must adhere.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - This report urges Turkey to act against intimidation of journalists in all its forms, seriously condemns the violent and illegal takeover of several newspapers and highlights the setbacks in freedom of expression and opinion that are taking place in the country. The EU, consequently with its unwavering commitment to defending the rule of law and fundamental freedoms, calls on Turkey to undertake the necessary reforms in matters such as justice, security and freedoms. It also calls for the search for a ceasefire agreement in southeast Turkey and the resumption of the peace process to achieve a negotiated, comprehensive and sustainable solution to the Kurdish issue. On the other hand, I welcome the important steps that are being taken towards the reunification of Cyprus and I give my full support to a speedy solution for that country. Consequently, I voted in favor of this report, considering that it sets out and demands from Turkey both the progress made and the next steps that the country must take to guarantee a good quality of democracy and a lasting peace in its territory.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- I chose to abstain on the final vote of this report on Turkey in 2015, which underlines that Turkey is a key strategic partner for the European Union and that active and credible negotiations would constitute an appropriate framework to exploitall the potential of relations between Europe and Turkey, and who hopes that the opening of new negotiating chapters can lead to concrete progress.

name: Massimiliano SALINI
text: in writing. - The 2015 European Parliament report on Turkey and the advancement of the rule of law in this country is currently suffering from a delicate situation. Parliament, on the one hand, cannot avoid underlining the serious shortcomings still found in Turkey as regards respect for fundamental human rights, in particular for minorities, freedom of the media and the independence of the judiciary. On the other hand, Turkey is today unquestionably a strategic partner of the European Union in tackling the migration crisis that has persisted for several years and which led to the important agreement of 2016. This agreement now guarantees management of migratory flows towards the Europe that Europe itself, alone, would not be able to face. I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution presented because it strikes a fair balance between the issues that dominate the landscape of EU-Turkey relations today, urging the government of Ankara to become aware of its democratic deficit and asking that progress in the cooperation and bilateral relations between the two countries is conditional on compliance with the conditions set by Europe in this sense.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We have voted to abstain on a text that is suitably harsh in denouncing the violation of human rights carried out systematically by the Turkish government against minorities, political opponents and journalists, demanding as to the criteria and conditions of access ofTurkey to the EU but absolutely contrary to political and legal responsibility regarding migration co-management and the protection of the rights of people in situations of forced mobility.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I was able to agree to the 2015 progress report on Turkey.He takes a critical look at the political situation in Turkey and shows the country's many deficits, including in terms of democracy.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- This report welcomes the agreement between Turkey and the EU on migration, which we oppose.In addition, it underlines "the great humanitarian contribution of Turkey" due to its role in welcoming refugees, when in reality it is herding refugees, fleeing the war, into concentration camps of people including women and minors, without fulfilling the basic conditionshygiene and violating the most fundamental human rights.With the EU-Turkey agreement and the funds given to Turkey to turn it into a prison for refugees who wish to request asylum in Europe, it continues in the line of an aggressive foreign policy and contrary to human rights, and as this agreement is acclaimed in this report, I decided to vote against.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey remains a key strategic partner for the EU, and I supported this motion because it rightly identifies that there is a lot of progress that is needed on important matters such as rule of law, freedom of press and fundamental values. And I agree with report when it says that the EU-Turkey cooperation on migration should be uncoupled from the EU accession negotiating process. But I must stress that I welcome the fact that Turkey is hosting the largest refugee population in the world.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: in writing.- In the case of the European Parliament's resolution on Turkey, I voted against its adoption.Turkey is an important partner for Europe, but it is not a member of the EU.Also, its economic and geopolitical position cannot be overlooked, so it is necessary to constantly develop a dialogue with it.However, this dialogue must be conducted responsibly and confidently by the EU, and not in a way that turns a blind eye to political pressure on Turkey's bid for membership of the European Union.Nor can a democratic Europe overlook the police raids, harassment and intimidation of those involved in society, which are just one of many manifestations of the aggressive Turkish state power.I cannot identify with such an EU approach, which neglects gross violations of religious freedoms, human rights and freedom of expression in this country.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - I supported the Motion for a resolution - report on Turkey for 2015, as further rapprochement is needed with Turkey in terms of membership in the Union. In 2015, Turkey provided assistance to more than 2 million refugees from Syria and Iraq, and an action plan for refugees and migrants was welcomed by the European Council. The increase in the number of refugees is a challenge for the Turkish economy, which has spent over 6.7 billion euros on their care. The pace of reforms has weakened, largely due to long and complex elections. The Turkish government is trying to strengthen the process of joining the European Union, but some policies adopted in 2015, such as the rule of law, freedom of expression and assembly, run counter to European standards. Public administration reforms are moderate, the legal system is under great political pressure, and corruption is widespread. In the fight against organized crime, financial investigations and the freezing of funds are still underused. Civil society has continued to grow, but a comprehensive legal framework needs to be adopted to strengthen women's rights, the LGBT community and the social inclusion of Roma. Freedom of expression and assembly need to be improved. The Internet law, which allows content to be blocked without a court order, needs to be changed in line with European standards. The lack of progress in normalizing bilateral relations with Cyprus is also one of the political problems of the Turkish authorities.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The 2015 report on Turkey is very critical because, although Turkey is a key strategic partner, especially now in tackling the migration crisis, we cannot turn a blind eye to moving back on respect for democracy and the rule of law within Turkey. The overall pace of reforms in Turkey has slowed markedly in recent years and in some key areas, such as the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly, freedom of expression, respect for human rights and the rule of law, there is a serious deterioration and candidate countries must comply. In the resolution, we expressed great regret at the intimidation and prosecution of more than 1,000 academics who had signed the petition for peace. We condemned the violent and illegal takeover of several Turkish newspapers, including the latest case of the Zaman newspaper, and therefore called on the Turkish government to end political and economic pressure on independent media, website and social networking.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing. ‒ While recognizing Turkey’s enormous humanitarian contribution in hosting the largest refugee population in the world and its vital role in countering Daesh and ending hostilities in Syria, I remain very concerned about the recent backsliding of the country in its respect for democracy and the rule of law. My greatest concern is the disproportionate response of the Turkish authorities to internal terrorism that recently led to the death of hundreds of civilians and the destruction of entire towns in the south—east of the country, a situation from which all sides can only lose. Another grave worry is the serious regression over the past years in freedom of speech, the lack of a free press and the imprisonment of the highest number of journalists in the world, a situation which also branches out to Europe with the recent attempt of president Erdogan to silence critical voices in German media. I hope that, despite our interests related to the vital strategic partnership between the EU and Turkey, we can stay critical of these worrying developments and address them properly for the benefit of all Turkish citizens.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - Although I believe that Turkey is our strategic partner - in NATO and in terms of resolving the migration crisis - I voted against the European Parliament's report on the assessment of Turkey's accession process for 2015. This report clearly anticipates Turkey's accession to the EU and contains a controversial point. that Turkish should already become an official language of the EU, albeit in the context of the unification of Cyprus. Negotiations with Turkey must take place in such a way that it is clear that they do not have to be membership, but rather a privileged partnership. And the mention of Turkish as the official language of Cyprus and the EU is not part of this report. This insertion made the text of a more technical nature a great politician. Turkey has its historical, cultural and religious roots, which are very different from our European ones. That is why I do not support Turkey's accession to the EU. I support a privileged partnership between the two countries and I want us to have the best relations, including economic and trade relations. However, the report also rightly acknowledges that Turkey bears the brunt of the refugee crisis and also contains the fundamental challenges to Turkey that I agree with: respect for freedom of expression, the release of journalists and a peaceful solution to relations with the Kurds. The report further calls on Turkey to recognize the Republic of Cyprus and to end the settlement of the occupied territories of Cyprus by Turkish citizens.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The Commission publishes progress reports each year on all EU candidate countries. Accession negotiations with Turkey began on 3 October 2005, marking the starting point for a long and open process. The EU and Turkey today face common, major problems, such as the fight against ISIS / Daesh and the governance of displaced Syrians. The principles of the rule of law, in particular the separation of powers, freedom of expression and freedom of the media, human rights and democracy, are extremely important in the negotiation process. The report covers a variety of topics: the state of EU-Turkey relations, respect for the rule of law, democracy, human rights and fundamental freedoms, the Kurdish peace process and the situation in south-eastern Turkey, EU-Turkey cooperation in the refugee / migration crisis. reunification of Cyprus. It is noted that under the Erdogan regime, there has been a setback in democratic principles such as freedom of expression and the media. Violence and intimidation during the parliamentary elections and high levels of corruption are criticized. Turkey's participation in the global coalition to fight Islamic State is positive. The goal for the EU must be to ensure peace in Turkey. That is why I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution on the report on Turkey.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - The relationship between the European Union and Turkey has never been easy. The attitude of some EU Member States towards Turkey is to say the least ambiguous, sometimes even hostile. In the past, several EU Member States have slowed down on Turkey's accession to the EU. This while Turkey explicitly sought rapprochement during that period and made significant progress in legal and economic matters and in its relationship with the Kurds. Recently, however, relations with Turkey have become more complex. Turkey is rapidly moving towards an authoritarian regime, with organized violence against the opposition, the gagging of journalists and other violations of fundamental freedoms. Turkey is abusing the refugee crisis and blackmailing the European Union. The Greens are outraged by these gross violations and the increasingly authoritarianism of the Erdogan regime. The Greens support the progress report on Turkey. It advocates a difficult balance between further support for the Turkish accession process, while at the same time it is outspokenly critical of domestic developments. As Turkey now goes on and on, accession to the Union is completely out of the question. The country by no means meets the accession criteria.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written. - The 2015 Status Report on Turkey rightly states that Turkey is stepping backwards in terms of human rights, internal security, freedom of the press and freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and democratization. All these civilizing achievements can be found in the Copenhagen criteria, which serve as the basis for the admission of new members to the EU. Because of these mistakes by Turkey, I do not believe that a resumption of accession negotiations is acceptable. Unfortunately, the reopening of individual chapters of the negotiations is accepted so as not to endanger the refugee trade with Turkey. This position is explained by the fact that the negotiations are hoping for a change in Turkey. I do not agree with this analysis, but have rejected the report because Turkey, and in particular President Erdoğan, promised a free hand in domestic politics thanks to their special role in the migration crisis, without having to deliver on democratization and human rights.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Turkey is a candidate country and it is therefore necessary to monitor its development.Emphasis must be placed on respect for fundamental democratic values, freedom of the media and the rule of law.Through its report, the European Parliament wants to send a signal to Turkey that cooperation on migration should not be linked to accession negotiations, for which clear criteria apply.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - The European Parliament has adopted a resolution on the 2015 report on Turkey, issued annually by the European Commission as part of the evaluation of the accession process with Turkey. For example, the EP notes its concern at the slowdown in reforms and calls for the rule of law, which is a key component of European values, to be upheld. I personally respect Turkey as our ally in NATO and I also appreciate Turkish initiatives in addressing the refugee issue. However, I fundamentally protest against the violence that Turkey is committing against the Kurds. The Kurdish Workers' Party (PKK), whose terror I reject, is also developing a spiral of mutual hatred. But often Kurdish terror is a response to the terror of the Turkish armed forces. In my opinion, the resolution that I voted in favor of the Kurdish issue and the situation in south-eastern Turkey are balanced. The EP calls on the Turkish government to take responsibility for resuming negotiations to find a comprehensive and sustainable solution to the Kurdish issue and to overcome its reservations about the participation of the Kurds in the Geneva peace talks. It also expresses its concern at the situation in Cizre and Sur / Diyarbakir and strongly condemns the killing and injury of civilians. I also consider it premature to establish Turkish as the EU's working language in the context of the negotiations on the reunification of Cyprus.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - Accession negotiations with Turkey opened on 3 October 2005 and the opening of these negotiations is the starting point for a long and indefinite process based on fair and strict conditions and a commitment to reform. The EU remains committed to further enlargement as a key policy for promoting peace, democracy, security and prosperity in Europe. I would be concerned that, in the light of the setbacks observed in recent years in terms of respect for democracy and the rule of law in Turkey, the implementation of reforms has generally slowed down significantly. In some key areas, such as the independence of the judiciary and freedom of assembly, freedom of expression and respect for human rights and the rule of law, there has been a setback, significantly moving Turkey away from meeting the Copenhagen criteria that candidate countries must adhere to. I am in favor of a structured and more frequent and open high-level political dialogue on key thematic issues of common interest, such as migration, the fight against terrorism, energy, the economy and trade. Turkey should also further align its foreign policy with that of the EU, in line with the provisions of the negotiating framework. I would call on Turkey to step up its efforts to resolve current bilateral issues, including unresolved legal obligations and disputes with immediate neighbors over land and sea borders and airspace, in accordance with the provisions of the UN Charter and international law.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- Accession negotiations with Turkey for EU accession began in 2005.Negotiations have slowed due to the implementation of EU legislation.Cooperation and negotiations need to be improved due to Turkey's important role for the EU, especially in the economy and energy.An intensive dialogue between the EU and Turkey on migration is also needed.I support the 2015 report on Turkey.I believe that Turkey is an important strategic partner of the EU, primarily because of its unique geographical position.Turkey is a transit country important for the security of the whole of Europe and crucial for resolving the refugee crisis in Europe.I also support the financial resources given to Turkey to deal with the refugee problem.I believe that Turkey must be helped in the refugee crisis because it is an important issue that concerns the whole of the European Union.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I voted against the proposal.I welcome Turkey's progress in upholding democratic principles and human rights, but I have serious doubts as to whether the EU-Turkey resettlement agreement will live up to expectations.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on Turkey for 2015. Turkey still has a long way to go to adopt the values of the European Union.Regardless of the refugee or.the migrant crisis and the agreement we have reached with Turkey, we must not have any discounts for Turkey.We must insist on demands to improve the situation regarding freedom of the press and freedom of association, as only this is severely curtailed.Also problematic are the government's actions in the judiciary, the conflict with the Kurds and the escalation of violence in the southeast.Turkey needs to significantly improve these areas, and we must insist on that.No matter what.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- I supported the 2015 report on Turkey today because, in my opinion, it is generally balanced and criticizes what can be criticized and appreciates what can be appreciated.The report condemns discrimination and prosecution of journalists or academics who have publicly criticized the actions of the Turkish president, draws attention to the possible misuse of terrorism to violate civil liberties and rights, or to the need for further judicial reforms.The report commends Turkey's actions that have helped alleviate the migration crisis in Greece and the assistance that Turkey provides to refugees on its territory.With regard to visa liberalization, it is stated that the introduction of visa-free travel is only possible if the conditions already set are met.That is, I think, the appropriate position.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: GUE / NGL), in writing. - The resolution rightly denounces the violations of fundamental rights, the dissolution of the rule of law and the persecution of Kurds, journalists and academics in Turkey. The inclusion of key parameters of the form of the solution we seek is also positive. That is, a solution that will lead to the transformation of the Republic of Cyprus into an IGC with a sovereignty, an international personality and a citizenship, based on international law and the relevant UN resolutions. The condemnation of the settlement, the call to Turkey to open the files that will help determine the fate of the missing, to implement Resolution 550 on Famagusta, to lift its military presence in Cyprus and to actively support the negotiation process compose a a positive image of the Cyprus issues raised in the report. However, the report also contains negative references which we cannot ignore. Welcomes the unacceptable EU-Turkey agreement, which violates international law and is contrary to international conventions on refugees. There is also pressure to open Turkey's accession chapters 23 and 24, even though Turkey refuses to meet its Cypriot obligations and violates the human rights of its people on a daily basis. For these reasons we abstained.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: NI), in writing.- Turkey is not a European country and any EU approach to it must be done with caution and caution.It is unacceptable that any contact with Turkey should be guided solely on the basis of economic criteria and micro-political aspirations.Any improvement in relations with it is not acceptable as it illegally occupies the northern part of Cyprus and constantly violates Greek airspace.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report, agreeing with its critical assessment, with a strict focus on European democratic values. He points out, inter alia, the fact that the democratic rule of law within the meaning of the Copenhagen criteria has deteriorated during the EU-Turkey accession negotiations, which have been going on for more than a decade. The rights of the national and other minorities, women, the political opposition and, more recently, the press critical of the government, and even the personal safety of its representatives, are still being severely violated. At the same time, I accept that, after a long omission, this annual report is in favor of opening Chapters 23 and 24 of the accession negotiations, because it is precisely in this context that many shortcomings in the internal legal order and justice can be raised. The report also gives a fair picture of the important role that Turkey is playing in tackling the current refugee crisis and commends the cooperation with the EU in this area. At the same time, I also agree with the conclusion that, for this reason, the Union must not turn a blind eye to the shortcomings of Turkey in the areas of democracy, the rule of law and preparations for integration.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - In 2005, the European Union started accession negotiations with Turkey as the starting point for a long and open process based on fair and rigorous conditions and a commitment to reform. Each country that wants to join the EU must meet the criteria established by the Community, such as respecting the principles of democracy and the rule of law, freedom of speech and media, fighting corruption and organized crime, etc. Unfortunately, the pace of political reform in Turkey has slowed down significantly in recent years. and there has been a clear setback in the area of ​​freedom of expression and freedom of assembly. In addition, Turkey saw a decline in the rankings for the level of corruption, media freedom and doing business. It is imperative that the country returns to the path of democratic reforms, otherwise the pace of the accession process will remain at its current low level. Turkey is a key strategic partner for the Union, and further rapprochement between partners will be mutually beneficial. Therefore, the postulates contained in the report are absolutely right and should become an incentive for further reforms of Turkey.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ It is very important to understand the importance of EU relations with Turkey and to implement more measures which will lead  to concrete progress.  This report urges Turkey to act against intimidation of journalists and condemn the violent takeover of several newspapers. The European Union strongly supports the freedom of speech, expression and opinion, both online and offline. To match the EU’s commitment to the rule of law and fundamental freedoms, which are core European values, reforms of the judiciary, freedom and security are urgently needed in Turkey.  Regarding EU-Turkey cooperation on migration, I think this should be uncoupled from the EU accession negotiating process. The active and credible negotiations provide a suitable framework for exploiting the full potential of international relations.  Turkey remains a key partner for the EU, but needs strong progress on rule of law and fundamental values. For this reason I support this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - Parliament wished, through this resolution, to express its concern, given the setback in respect for democracy and the rule of law in Turkey, the considerable slowdown in the overall pace of reforms in Turkey in recent years and the regression observed in some key areas such as the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly, freedom of expression and respect for human rights and the rule of law, which plus the prospect of achieving the Copenhagen criteria that the candidate countries must meet. Parliament also stresses that Turkey is a key strategic partner for the European Union and that active and credible negotiations would constitute an appropriate framework for exploiting the full potential of relations between the European Union and Turkey. We want tangible progress and real commitment from Turkey. We strongly support a structured, more frequent and more open high-level political dialogue on key issues of common interest, such as migration, the fight against terrorism, energy, economy and trade.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted today in favour of the Turkey progress report for 2015 as it calls on the Commission and Council to reassess the whole strategy behind the accession process negotiations with Ankara.  With this vote, I also questioned the opening of new chapters, especially in light of recent domestic developments.  It is simply unacceptable to open new chapters when, at the same time, freedom of the media in Turkey is being restricted dramatically every day. Instead, Europe and Turkey urgently need an enhanced positive agenda with a focus on energy, foreign policy, civil society dialogue, trade and visa liberalisation.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- Turkey is a key strategic partner for the European Union.I believe that the intensification of the political dialogue between the European Union and Turkey on foreign and security policy, the fight against terrorism and the management of migratory flows is of mutual benefit.The threat of Daesh and terrorism is a common threat that will be able to be defeated better and faster if faced together.The agreement signed between the European Union and Turkey on migrants is a first step towards a common management of borders and migratory flows, but much remains to be done.The defense of human rights, the protection of minorities and the maintenance of the rule of law cannot be overshadowed.Together we can do a lot, but mutual commitment is needed.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I would support the 2015 report on Turkey, as the EU remains committed to further enlargement as a central policy for promoting peace, democracy, security and prosperity in Europe.Each candidate country will be assessed on the basis of its own achievements.The principles of the rule of law are extremely important in the negotiation process, especially the separation of powers, freedom of expression and freedom of the media, human rights and democracy, the fight against corruption and organized crime, good neighborly relations, freedom of religion, freedom of assembly and peaceful protest.combating discrimination against vulnerable groups.

name: Yana TOOM
text: in writing.- The report was not sufficiently critical of the human rights situation in the country, especially in view of the ongoing military activities in the regions where the Kurds live.Furthermore, the report did not allay my concerns about the 'refugee deal' - Europe should not depend on an unreliable partner such as President Erdoğan and offer visa-free travel to those who are clearly not ready to meet all the criteria.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We have voted to abstain on a text that is suitably harsh in denouncing the violation of human rights carried out systematically by the Turkish government against minorities, political opponents and journalists, demanding as to the criteria and conditions of access ofTurkey to the EU but absolutely contrary to political and legal responsibility regarding migratory co-management and the protection of the rights of people in situations of forced mobility.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written. - The 2015 Status Report on Turkey rightly states that Turkey is stepping backwards in terms of human rights, internal security, freedom of the press and freedom of expression, freedom of assembly and democratization. All these civilizing achievements can be found in the Copenhagen criteria, which serve as the basis for the admission of new members to the EU. Because of these mistakes by Turkey, I do not believe that a resumption of accession negotiations is acceptable. Unfortunately, the reopening of individual chapters of the negotiations is accepted so as not to endanger the refugee trade with Turkey. This position is explained by the fact that the negotiations are hoping for a change in Turkey. I do not agree with this analysis, but have rejected the report because Turkey, and in particular President Erdoğan, promised a free hand in domestic politics thanks to their special role in the migration crisis, without having to deliver on democratization and human rights.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted against this resolution as I consider that it takes a weak approach to Turkey’s relation to the EU and to the protection of its minorities and human rights. Moreover, big questions remain on the way that Turkey is complying with its international obligations regarding the deal with the EU. At this stage, it is not possible to give a positive stance on Turkey’s EU integration.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- Accession negotiations with Turkey began on 3 October 2005 and the opening of these negotiations is the beginning of a long and open-ended process based on fair and strict conditionality and a commitment to reform.As regards the political criteria, the pace of reforms has slowed down and significant steps have been taken in the area of freedom of expression and assembly.By my vote, I supported the position of the S&D Group.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We have voted to abstain on a text that is suitably harsh in denouncing the violation of human rights carried out systematically by the Turkish government against minorities, political opponents and journalists, demanding as to the criteria and conditions of access ofTurkey to the EU but absolutely contrary to political and legal responsibility regarding migration co-management and the protection of the rights of people in situations of forced mobility.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 report on Turkey. In light of recent developments in Europe, this year the resolution calls on the Commission and the Council to reassess the whole strategy behind the accession process negotiations with Ankara. I have always been a keen supporter of Turkey’s European aspirations, but recent events in the country raise concern about the full respect of the rule of law and most importantly about freedom of the media and freedom of expression. Additionally, I do share the opinion expressed in the text that Turkey’s accession process should not be linked to the refugee crisis: the country should be judged on its own merits and its cooperation with the EU on urgent migration issues should remain a separate matter.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Through this report, the European Parliament highlights the importance of Turkey as a strategic partner for the European Union.The report highlights certain areas in which the country should advance, such as the independence of the judiciary, freedom of assembly, freedom of expression, legal security or respect for human rights.The report also deals with issues of great importance in relation to European energy security, progress in the reunification of Cyprus, Turkey's participation in the grand coalition to fight Daesh and Turkey's role in managing the current migration crisis.Ultimately, we are talking about a complete report that deals with the issues that are on the table in relation to this country.For all these reasons, I consider it necessary to vote in their favor.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - I voted in favor of Turkey's annual progress report. Turkey is one of the countries in the world with the largest refugee population at this time. The EU and Turkey face many common challenges and we must find joint solutions. The report is critical and shows that this year there has been a significant democratic setback, especially in the areas of freedom of expression, freedom of the press, the rule of law and minority rights. The report urges Turkey to resume democratizing reforms again, aligning itself with EU values ​​and is betting that the accession process can accelerate these necessary changes. The report also addresses the situation in southeastern Turkey, where the most significant wave of violence in the last 20 years is taking place. It calls for an immediate ceasefire and for the resumption of the peace process, since there is no military solution to the Kurdish question. A conflict that has tens of thousands of displaced people.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ Turkey represents one of, if not the, most important partners for the EU in the coming years. On migration, energy and security, both north towards Russia and east towards the continuing violence in Syria and northern Iraq, as well as in resolving the frozen conflict in the Caucasus between Armenia and Azerbaijan, Turkey is an important partner, and it is vital to recognise this.  That said I would agree with the report’s view on a number of areas relating to human rights. There have been worrying signs that progress has not only stalled but is in danger of going into reverse, in particular with regard to journalistic freedoms. To build our partnership with Turkey further I would hope to see reform looking towards the upholding of fundamental human rights by the Turkish Government. It is important going forward that we work closely with Turkey on the migration crisis while recognising the work that Turkey has already done to help settle refugees as well as in the ongoing struggle against the terrorist group Daesh in Syria. I therefore voted in favour of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of the 2015 progress report on Turkey, as it calls on the European Commission and the Council of the European Union to reassess the whole strategy behind the accession negotiations with Ankara.It is simply unacceptable to open new chapters in the accession process when, at the same time, freedom of the press is drastically curtailed in Turkey.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - As every year, Parliament adopted a report on the situation in Turkey as part of its application for membership of the Union. In this text, Parliament deplores with rare firmness the setbacks in respect for democracy and the rule of law and the regressions observed in certain areas (independence of the judiciary, freedom of expression, respect for the rights of the man against academics, journalists and HDP activists ...). The Kurdish question, in particular, is largely dealt with there: the abuses of the security forces are denounced and the Turkish government is called upon to assume its responsibilities to resume negotiations with a view to reaching a lasting solution. Of which act. At the same time, however, the text adopts a sometimes absurd middle position, particularly in the context of the fight against terrorism. It is recalled that the PKK is on the list of terrorist organizations of the Union, which justifies the unjustifiable. 113 deputies voted for the amendment that I tabled to request the removal of the PKK from this list. In addition, the trade dimension is present, with a call to "take into account Turkish interests" in the TTIP negotiations. Finally, the Union-Turkey agreement on migrants is welcomed. Curious balancing act which led me to abstain.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- This report is ambiguous.On the one hand, Turkey's situation is criticized on several issues of fundamental rights violations.On the other hand, measures that are deeply negative are praised.We cannot agree on several aspects.Examples include migration and refugee policy, the situation of the Kurds and the attacks that the Turks have carried out, the neighborhood policy and the Turkish approach to the Syrian war, the financing of terrorist groups, the policy followed for the Cypriot situation.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The report calls for closer cooperation with Turkey.Since the report has few critical approaches and the Cyprus problem is approached almost naively, I voted against the report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution of the 2015 report on Turkey.The report highlights that concrete and credible negotiations can lay the foundations for fully exploiting EU-Turkey relations.I am convinced that cooperation with Turkey on migration should not be linked to accession negotiations and that a more structured and frequent political dialogue is needed.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I rejected the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the report on Turkey.This report deserves nothing more than a resounding no.The text calls for good neighborly relations between the EU and Turkey and calls on Turkey to continue to work closely with the Commission.This is nothing more than a preparation for Turkey's accession to the EU.We should ask the peoples of the Member States directly about this tactic with a view to Turkey's accession to the EU.The accession of the EU to Turkey opens the way for all Mediterranean countries to join the EU.And that is not acceptable.Not only is Turkey historically and geopolitically not part of the broader European landscape, it is also fundamentally different in terms of shared values.I clearly oppose this report.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I echo the grave concern expressed in this report about the worsening of human rights violations by Turkish authorities, as seen with the taking over of newspapers, oppression and harassment of journalists, persecution of the Kurdish minority, and violations of the rights of refugees in the country.  The EU’s dialogue with Turkey must centre on putting these wrongs to right. Any agreement between the EU with the Turkish Government must uphold human rights and humanitarian norms, including the rights of refugees and the principle of non-refoulement.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. - The recent agreement concluded by the European Council with Turkey has found the support of the Parliament but raises some important questions. On the one hand, Turkey's strategic role in tackling the refugee crisis is undeniable, considering that in 2015 alone it welcomed two million and 700,000 Syrians. On the other hand, the Group of Socialists and Democrats questions the current political situation in Turkey, where freedom of expression and of the press is not fully guaranteed and where the Kurdish conflict remains unresolved, and the consequent opportunity to enter into political agreements with it. . In line with the group, I therefore voted on the report presented by my socialist colleague Kati Piri. With this report, the European institutions commit themselves to monitor the state of democracy in Turkey and to commit themselves to a ceasefire on the Kurdish border. Only on the basis of respect for fundamental human rights will it be possible to start negotiations to integrate Turkey into the framework of European unification.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I have chosen to disagree with the European Parliament's report on Turkey.I am aware of the fact that Turkey is a strategic partner for the EU, but I am personally deeply concerned about the very slow pace of reforms and the decline in the level of respect for the principles of democracy and the rule of law.I see the problem with the dubious independence of the judiciary, the threatened freedom of assembly and expression or respect for human rights and the rule of law.Turkey is thus constantly moving away from meeting the Copenhagen criteria.Last but not least, I am also discouraged from supporting the report by the unresolved situation with Cyprus.I therefore believe that we should turn the debate on Turkey's accession to the EU into a debate on a strategic partnership with Turkey.

name: Jana ŽITŇANSKÁ
text: in writing.- I abstained on the 2015 State of Turkey report.The report critically assessed many of the problems currently facing Turkey, in particular the deteriorating human rights situation, the imprisonment of journalists, the suppression of freedom of expression and the overall slowdown in the pace of reforms needed.On the other hand, in the report, Parliament praised Turkey's hospitality for the large number of refugees it currently has on its territory and expressed concern at the ever-increasing danger of the terrorist threat in Turkey.However, in the context of the refugee crisis, the report made several references to a relocation system containing mandatory quotas for Member States with which I do not agree, which ultimately led me to decide to abstain in the final vote.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: in writing. - Turkey is a very important country in the immediate vicinity of the European Union, which already in the 1980s announced its aspirations for membership in the Community. However, despite the talks and negotiations that have been going on for many years, the prospect of full membership of Ankara in the EU is still receding. Despite many successes, especially in the economic arena, Turkey still faces many political problems that prevent the finalization of the accession process. This is not only about the conflicts and disputes that have been smoldering for many years, such as the question of the division of Cyprus or the lack of normalization in relations with Armenia, but also about new problems, especially taking military action against Kurds in Syria and Iraq and insufficient involvement in the fight against the Islamic State . Turkey's active involvement in the fight against illegal immigration to Europe deserves praise, but only time will show if and to what extent this commitment is sincere and effective. I support Turkey's European ambitions, but I would like to see a greater commitment by the Ankara authorities to tackling the most important challenges for Europe's security. I fully agree with the call in this report for Turkey to step up efforts to protect religious and ethnic minorities, especially Christians and Yazidis. Unfortunately, this report also contains many phrases which I cannot subscribe to, which is why I abstained.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the report on Turkey for 2015.EU-Turkey political cooperation on geopolitical challenges is intensive.Turkey is one of the EU's important strategic partners, and it is necessary to promote a peaceful and fair political dialogue on key issues of common interest, such as migration, the fight against terrorism, energy, the economy and trade.However, the findings, which point to a slowdown in the implementation of democratic reforms, respect for the rule of law and human rights, are worrying.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
