text: in writing.- Albania submitted its application for membership of the European Union in 2009, although already officially recognized by the European Commission as a potential candidate.The 2015 report presented on Albania certainly highlights the efforts and improvements made by the country, such as greater cooperation between the government and the opposition and the adoption of a law that bans convicts from political office.At the same time, however, the report highlights important critical points, especially with regard to the necessary reform of the judicial system, the fight against corruption and organized crime.These are aspects that the Albanian system has yet to improve according to European standards.I would have voted in favor, by virtue of the analysis and denunciation carried out in the report.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution since it continues in line with the views of Parliament towards the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship is reproduced between a rich and powerful center versus an impoverished and obedient periphery.The resolution put to the vote also seeks to influence the correlation of political forces that participate in the Albanian system.This aspect depends solely and exclusively on the will of the Albanians.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This report provides an update on Albania’s efforts to meet the hurdles required for EU membership. The report highlights some of the key problems facing Albania, including high unemployment and poverty rates, corruption, organised crime, child trafficking, freedom of the press, rule of law and judicial independence, and references the need for an improved political process, which is currently endangered by a lack of dialogue between parties. However, it welcomes Albania’s inclusion on the list of so-called ‘safe countries of origin’ for refugees, as well as welcoming Albania’s full alignment with the EU foreign and security policy, and economic structural reforms. As a result, I abstained on this report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe in further EU expansion, and therefore had no option but to vote against this progress report.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution, which deals with the 2015report on Albania.Parliament welcomes Albania's steady progress in implementing the five key priority reforms.However, calls on all political parties to step up their efforts to engage in a more constructive and genuine political dialogue, leading to the adoption and implementation of key reforms.Sustainable parliamentary cooperation between the ruling authorities and the opposition is crucial to Albania's EU accession process and to meeting the accession criteria.It is essential to live up to our commitment to building a democratic political culture, including ensuring openness to dialogue, negotiation and compromise, and to abandon boycotts and radicalism altogether.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This report, which remains in view of the accession of Albania to the European Union, multiplies the attempts to interfere in the territorial or energy policies of the country.Furthermore, he noted all the points - the power of organized crime, child labor, censorship of Albanian newspapers, etc. - for which the accession of this country to the Union seems to me more compromised than ever.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing. - The enlargement of the European Union must be understood as an opportunity to offer political stability and peaceful relations both to future new entrants and to current Member States. This European integration requires a series of reforms consistent with democratic identity, in particular strict respect for the rule of law and the fight against corruption and organized crime. I voted in favor of this report because Albania is gradually carrying out the appropriate reforms and I can only welcome this determination towards a democratic transition which offers, and will continue to offer in the future, a well-being to the Albanian community. . It is important that the country's public authorities do not slacken this pace, or even accelerate it in view of the strong implantation of corruption in the administrations and the lack of media independence, which are serious obstacles to a possible entry into the media. within the Union.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Albania because of its equanimity and pro-European vision on the situation and the future of Albania. The document shows the progress that has been made in the country in order to achieve the commitments established in the Stabilization and Association Agreement. At the same time, it recalls the long-delayed position from which it starts as a result of organized crime, the deficient judicial system, discrimination against minorities and women, unemployment, etc. I am particularly concerned about the trafficking of children in the country. Many children are exploited by their families to the point of being economically dependent on the livelihood they get on the streets. Albania is the country in Europe with the highest child begging. As long as Albanian children are slaves to this situation, society will be condemned not to come out of underdevelopment by mortgaging the lives of the new generations that should be the engine of the country's progress. I am also skeptical of the inclusion of Albania as a safe third country. In my opinion, Albania does not clearly meet the criteria established by Directive 2013/32 / EU. In 2014, it only accepted 7.8% of the asylum applications it received.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - In 2009, together with its entry into NATO, the Republic of Albania applied to join the European Union following the broad support of the Albanian political forces, and of public opinion, towards the European integration process. Over the years, the country has made considerable efforts in the reform process, which have resulted in plans and strategies for public administration reform and for the management of public funding. I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Albania because I believe it is essential to support its path of change and strengthening of the democratic system. Corruption always remains one of the major problems afflicting the country, but the government and the opposition have launched effective paths that can take the form of a systematic reform of the judicial system, aimed at strengthening the independence of the authorities and cooperation between them. Greater efforts are needed in the field of the protection of minors, in the creation of adequate environmental legislation and to address the issue of gender inequalities, but the Republic of Albania appears to be positively moving towards future EU membership.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We have voted to abstain, despite the fact that the resolution proposal advances in line with the integration perspective of the Balkan countries, for two reasons: the position it maintains with respect to the economic reforms that Albania is being asked to do and because theThe motion for a resolution includes a position on how to fight terrorism that we do not share.Additionally, this proposal is quite imprecise in the orientation in the fight against high-level organized crime, the treatment of the Roma minority and on the treatment in the fight against gender violence.The report includes positive aspects that we value as a whole, for which we will vote abstention.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- This 2015 report on Albania is still intended to support the country's accession process to the Union.On October 10, 2010, the Commission recommended granting Albania the status of candidate country to the Union.In May 2010, it already authorized citizens of Albania (such as those of Bosnia and Herzegovina) to travel to the countries of the Schengen area with a biometric passport and without a visa, thus further encouraging immigration to the countries.from Western Europe, like mine, France.Moreover, Albania suffers from serious internal problems and is a hub of the Union for various trafficking.Its public administration and judicial system are riddled with organized crime and corruption on all levels.Fundamental rights, especially of minorities, are rarely respected.I therefore voted against.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- I can only congratulate Albania for its commitment in the fight against the spread of Islamic terrorism.I welcome the rapporteur's recommendation urging the country to share its information more readily with EU Member States.However, sharing the fight against terrorists cannot constitute and be recalled as a prerequisite for yet another EU enlargement.That is why I voted against.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, which deals with the 2015 report on Albania. Parliament welcomes Albania's steady progress in implementing the five key priority reforms needed to open accession negotiations. He calls on the government, parliament and political parties to maintain their reform ambitions and to speed up the implementation of reforms and the speedy implementation of fundamental judicial reform, as proper and timely implementation of these reforms is essential. The European Parliament welcomes the constructive cooperation between both the ruling and opposition parties and the unanimous adoption by Parliament of a law banning the appointment and election of criminals to public office (the so-called decriminalization law). It also welcomes Albania's commitment to a comprehensive and thorough reform of the justice system and strongly encourages the Albanian authorities to proceed swiftly with the preparations for this fundamental reform in order to boost the confidence of citizens and businesses in the justice system. It also welcomes the close cooperation with the Venice Commission and encourages the continuation of the cooperation approach until the reform is adopted.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing.- In my opinion, Albania has taken continuous steps in the recent past to successfully start accession negotiations.It is also noteworthy that the country has stepped up its efforts in the fight against organized crime, drug trafficking, and human trafficking.The government’s recognition that civil society is essential to the establishment and development of a democratic society can have a positive impact on the governance of political and social processes.We expect further steps in the area of property rights and criminal proceedings, as well as active action to curb Islamic extremism.It is also important to stress that the country needs to increase its role in assisting regional cooperation processes.Based on all this, I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported the report on Albania for 2015, as it is very balanced and well prepared.Those of us who know Albania and have followed it in the past can safely admit that it has made great progress and that it has transformed relatively quickly from one of the most closed communist countries to a country with the right direction, orientation towards parliamentary democracy and respect.European values.I also agree with those who point out the great problems that still exist in Albania, especially in the field of corruption, organized crime, and it is right that through such reports and through the recommendations of the European Commission on the road to the European Union, such things be resolved.It is very important, however, that we enable Albania's economic development, that young Albanians do not look for perspective all over Europe, but that they find it at home.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this report and welcome Albania's continued progress in meeting key priorities for opening accession negotiations.Further efforts are needed, especially in the area of judicial reform, and I call on all political parties in Albania to reach a consensus on these issues.I believe that the opening of accession negotiations as soon as possible would give an even stronger impetus to the positive transformations of the country.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe that the progress made by Albania on the rule of law, reform of the judiciary, fight against corruption and organized crime, public administration reform and fundamental rights are extremely positive and that thethe government and the political and ruling class of the country must be encouraged and supported by the Union in pursuing this path.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - Albania has made important and steady progress in recent months on the way to future membership of the European Union. In this sense, important steps forward have been made or foreseen in many key sectors: consider the adoption of the public administration reform strategy 2015-2020, the public finance management reform strategy 2014-2020 or the strategy national anti-corruption 2015-2020 and the 2015-2017 action plan. However, in order for the accession negotiations to be effectively launched, the reform process must be encouraged and amplified to all those sectors in which Albania still faces significant limitations or difficulties in reform. Indeed, it is necessary to resolve the current shortcomings in the functioning of the judicial system, promoting greater independence and transparency of the same, firmly fighting corruption, the frequent mistreatment of suspects by the police, sexual discrimination, as well as drug trafficking and organized crime, all this by promoting the creation of effective integration programs capable of lowering high unemployment, especially among young people.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of the European Parliament's resolution on the 2015 report on Albania, as I appreciate that significant progress has been made in Albania's accession to the European Union.Since June 2014, it has been granted EU candidate status precisely to encourage the progress made by this Balkan state in the fight against corruption and organized crime.Unfortunately, without democratic structures, without a rule of law, without the independence of the media and the judiciary, but also without a consistent fight against corruption, EU membership cannot take place.Thus, there is a need for further intensification of reform efforts in these key areas, in order to open accession negotiations and strengthen its democratic transition.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- Necessary political and administrative reforms are underway in Albania, but have not yet reached a stage where EU accession negotiations could start.I vote against.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written.- The only controversial point of the report has been the change of procedure for the nomination of the director of the state public television.The report is considered to be balanced and satisfactory.The progress made by Albania in 2015 is welcomed, and the Government is requested to continue reform efforts and support Albania's European perspective.He believes that opening the accession negotiations as soon as possible will be a tangible incentive for the positive transformation of the country.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Albania because with the granting of the status of candidate country to Albania, the progress made by Tirana in recent years has been recognized, but reforms in some key areas will have to continue.The country is in a phase of strong political tension.The collaboration of all political forces, including the opposition, is necessary to continue the path towards the EU.Government and opposition must initiate political dialogue in Parliament.Increasing inter-party cooperation remains essential for achieving a sustainable reform process.Today the situation in Albania has changed profoundly.The real challenge for Albania is to facilitate the country's path towards greater economic and social stability.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report provides an update on Albania’s efforts to meet the hurdles required for EU membership. The report highlights some of the key problems facing Albania, including high unemployment and poverty rates, corruption, organised crime, child trafficking, freedom of the press, rule of law and judicial independence, and references the need for an improved political process, which is currently endangered by a lack of dialogue between parties. However, it welcomes Albania’s inclusion on the list of so-called ‘safe countries of origin’ for refugees, as well as welcoming Albania’s full alignment with the EU foreign and security policy, and economic structural reforms. As a result, I abstained on this report.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- This report intends to strengthen the dialogue between the European Union and Albania by highlighting the areas where improvement and therefore a greater investment of resources is needed.It is my task to try to shorten the distances not only between the institutions and individual Member States, but also with the other countries that are close to us as much as possible.We must not forget, in fact, that such dialogues can lead to opportunities for mutual growth and development and for this I have expressed myself in favor.I firmly believe that sustainable cooperation between government and opposition in Parliament is essential for Albania's EU accession process and for meeting the membership criteria.I also completely agree with the importance of them honoring their commitment to building a democratic political culture that includes openness to dialogue, negotiation and compromise.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ In June 2014, the European Council granted Albania candidate status. In the past year, Albania has implemented smoothly its obligations under the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA). Regular political and economic dialogue between the EU and Albania has continued through the relevant structures under the SAA. The government engaged in EU-related reforms and in addressing the five key priorities identified for the opening of accession negotiations. Albania continued to actively participate in high-level dialogue meetings, as well as in the related joint working groups on the five key priorities.

name: Carlos COELHO
text: in writing.- I think the report on Albania's progress is well done and balanced.The report highlights the progress made in reforming the judicial system, in the strategy for modernizing public administration, in fighting organized crime and in religious tolerance.The report also points out, however, widespread corruption in education, health care, the judicial system, public procurement, spatial planning and public administration, problems with the electoral system (highlighted by the OSCE / ODIHR) andmistreatment of suspects at police stations, among many other aspects.I cannot, however, vote in favor of a report that sees with some optimism the possibility of Albania joining the EU, so I abstain in the final vote.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call for protection of religious freedom and the rule of law as these are fundamental values of the European Union, and emphasise the need for constructive and sustainable political dialogue between political forces on EU-related reforms. This is essential to making further progress in the EU accession process; whereby fair play, constructive dialogue, cooperation and willingness to compromise between government and opposition is vital for a successful and sustainable reform process. It is of utmost importance for Albania to strengthen their efforts in the fight against the production and trafficking of drugs and narcotics, including by stepping up international and regional cooperation on human trafficking, better protection of and redress for victims, and an improved track record as regards investigation.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution since it continues in line with Parliament's views towards the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship is reproduced between a rich and powerful center versus an impoverished and obedient periphery.The Resolution put to the vote also seeks to influence the correlation of political forces that participate in the Albanian system.This aspect depends solely and exclusively on the will of the Albanians.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing.- The annual report on Albania's progress towards EU accession shows steady progress on the key systemic reforms needed to start accession negotiations.Nevertheless, Albania faces challenges such as the malfunctioning of the judicial system, the general politicization of the electoral process, widespread corruption, organized crime with a low number of final sentences, lack of professional, independent and pluralist public and private media, the rise of Islamic radicalization in society, etc., I welcome Albania's progress towards EU integration.I voted for.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- In this resolution, the Parliament welcomes the steady progress made by Albania in the reforms it is carrying out around the priority objectives, while encouraging the parliament and the political parties not to slow down the pace of reforms.Parliament underlines the shortcomings in the functioning of justice and calls for the acceleration of efforts to alleviate political interference, selective justice, corruption and lack of resources.It recommends that the Commission follow closely the progress of justice reform and encourages it to take into account the progress made by Albania in the five priority areas when considering the advisability of opening negotiations onmembership.Considering that Albania has made real progress in reform, and should be encouraged to pursue these developments, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported this resolution on the 2015 report on Albania.With this resolution, the European Parliament recalls the need to eradicate corruption and welcomes the adoption of the national anti-corruption strategy for 2015 to 2020 and the action plan for 2015 to 2017. It is also essential that theAlbania continues to develop an effective policy against radicalization.I would remind you, however, that the European Union must take a lasting pause in its enlargement policy.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing.- Albania has taken steady steps to start accession negotiations.It is also noteworthy that the country has stepped up its efforts in the fight against organized crime, drug trafficking, and human trafficking.The government’s recognition that civil society is essential to the establishment and development of a democratic society can have a positive impact on the governance of political and social processes.We expect further steps in the area of property rights and criminal proceedings, as well as active action to curb Islamic extremism.It is also important to stress that the country needs to increase its role in assisting regional cooperation processes.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form.- I supported the resolution on Albania's progress because I believe that this country is making real progress in the process of joining the EU, carrying out many reforms in key areas.But my support is not unconditional.Albania must recognize the Bulgarian minority living in the districts of Mala Prespa, Golo Bardo and Gora, which will fully win my support.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- The incoming echoes show the existence of political consensus and broad public support for the accession process in Albania which needs the reform process to proceed in a sustained manner, especially in the areas of the rule of law, reformthe judicial system and the fight against corruption and organized crime, administrative reform and the electoral system, as well as human rights.The report reports on the continued progress made by Albania with regard to reforms in the main priorities necessary for the opening of accession negotiations, and therefore the government, parliament and political parties must maintain the momentum of reforms and accelerate implementation.reforms.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The report echoes the usual set of considerations on EU integration processes, in this case, to address Albania's accession. As usual, the conditions for membership are identified, an attitude of interference and limitation of the sovereignty of countries and peoples applying for EU membership is adopted, insisting on the imposition of so-called structural reforms, in particular on issues such as justice, administration the electoral system, economic governance, or the fight against corruption and organized crime. The alignment of that country's positions with those of the EU is required, particularly with regard to foreign and border policy. We consider the unreasonable stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts regarding the country's integration are exposed. People have a legitimate right to decide on their future and to choose freely and sovereignly whether or not they want to join the EU, as well as to decide on their respective economic and social development strategies. The EU has no right to impose policies that are contrary to peoples' interests and desires. We voted against.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I abstained on the report because I am critical about the imposition of reforms by the EU, in particular in the economic and social areas.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- The European Parliament welcomes the progress made by Albania in meeting the key priorities for the opening of accession negotiations.All political forces and parties in the country need to take a constructive approach to implementing the necessary reforms, especially in the judiciary.The start of accession negotiations as soon as possible can result in a positive transformation in the country.I therefore welcome the adoption of the Public Administration Reform Strategy 2015-2020 and its Action Plan 2015-2017, as well as the Public Financial Management Reform Strategy 2014-2020, as well as the adoption of the Decentralization Strategy 2015-2020 and the Local Government Act., which increases the administrative and financial capacity of local government units and ensures consultations between the central government and local government.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against as I am not in favor of new enlargements of the European Union, especially for countries which still show considerable distances in some issues.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. - Albania expresses in the most official way expansionist aspirations to the detriment of neighboring countries. He consciously avoids controlling the borders, as a result of which drugs, weapons and illegal immigrants enter Greece. It has been suppressing for decades, at a steady pace, the human rights of the Greeks of the Northern Epirus. It destroys churches and illegally violates the property of the Greek Orthodox Church. In short, there has been no progress in Albania, which the report avoids mentioning, which is why I am voting against the 2015 report on Albania.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the steady progress in meeting the key priorities for opening accession negotiations and I support the call on all political parties to work constructively together for the implementation of the reforms. Further efforts are needed, in particular in the field of judicial reform. The success of the reform process depends on the existence of a democratic political environment. To secure the sustainability of the integration process all political parties need to cooperate and work constructively together. I support the call on the Commission to monitor closely the progress and to report to Parliament and the Council as soon as Albania has sufficiently advanced with the judicial reform, with a view to opening accession negotiations. I believe that the opening of accession negotiations, as soon as possible, will provide a tangible incentive for the positive transformation of the country.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing.- I have approved Parliament's motion for a resolution on the 2015 Albanian Country Report.Albania has made steady progress on the road to EU accession.I welcome the country's efforts to reform key areas.These include public administration reform and efforts to combat discrimination against vulnerable groups.However, they need to implement a substantial reform of the judiciary.We must support Albania with all our possible means, because the goal is to achieve EU accession, which will lead to further stability in the Western Balkans.Above all, to implement the reforms, we call on all political parties to make further efforts to launch a more constructive and genuine political dialogue.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report in light of the progress made by Albania in relation to key reforms indispensable for the opening of EU accession negotiations.However, Albania must continue to maintain the reformist momentum and accelerate the implementation of reforms.Similarly, Albania must take the appropriate decisions to continue and strengthen the fight against organized crime.There is no doubt that the European Parliament will support Albania in these processes.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the non-legislative resolution of the European Parliament, presented following statements by the Council and the Commission under Rule 123 of the regulation on the 2015 report on Albania. The small state overlooking the Adriatic has, in fact, made important and constant steps forward in recent years on the road to joining the European Union, despite the fact that many challenges and problems still remain to be solved quickly and in the most effective way possible. . In fact, for the official start of EU accession negotiations it is essential that Albania demonstrates its ability to implement an effective and efficient legal framework and that it proceeds on the path of reforms, which are the necessary instrument to modernize the country . I share the need to ensure freedom of the media and the protection of journalists who carry out their work and who have at times been subjected to threats and aggressions, as well as full respect for human rights and the principles of democracy. Finally, I applaud Albania's efforts to improve relations with Serbia and to promote commitment to cooperation and stability in the entire region, so as to establish stable good neighborly relations.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We have voted to abstain, despite the fact that the motion for a resolution advances in line with the integration perspective of the Balkan countries, for two reasons: the position it maintains with respect to the economic reforms that Albania is being asked to do and because theThe motion for a resolution includes a position on how to fight terrorism that we do not share.Additionally, this proposal is quite imprecise in the orientation in the fight against high-level organized crime, the treatment of the Roma minority and on the treatment in the fight against gender violence.The report includes positive aspects that we value as a whole, for which we will vote abstention.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- Albania is one of the poorest countries in Europe.The progress report promotes policies that find us opposed.While the country is plagued by very serious problems of corruption and political polarization, it is called upon to proceed with economic models that further complicate the position of ordinary people.It is for these reasons that, while supporting the country's accession process and the will of its citizens to join the Union, we have abstained from the report.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Albania. I am pleased that Albania shows steady progress in implementing reforms every year and is making efforts to move closer to the European Union. I consider the actions of the government to combat crime worthy of praise, as well as the adoption of the administration reform plan and efforts to consolidate public finances. It should be underlined in this context that the Albanian government is starting to engage in dialogue with various political forces and social partners. A strong civil society is an important pillar of democracy and only with its support can the necessary reforms be effectively introduced. Of course, there are still many challenges ahead of our Albanian neighbor. The Commission has rightly pointed out that Tirana still has a lot of work to do in terms of judicial reform and the fight against corruption. I believe that the European Union should continue to support important reforms and processes of change taking place in Albania. It is in our interest to have a stable, well-developing democracy in our immediate vicinity, which in the long term will be ready for membership in the Community.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ Albania has made significant progress with regard to its European integration process. However, the country still has important reforms to make in the judicial field. I look forward to Albania’s on-going progress with a view to opening EU accession negotiations.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the Motion for a resolution submitted following statements by the Council and the Commission pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure on the 2015 Report on Albania (2015/2896 (RSP)), given that there is visible progress in implementing reforms. What is still worrying is the lack of genuine and constructive political dialogue. It is necessary to maintain the commitment to building a democratic political culture that implies openness to dialogue, negotiations and compromises and in which there is no room for boycott and radicalism. In this regard, there is the problem of a lack of co-operation and compromise in the Albanian delegation, which makes it difficult for meaningful discussions in the EU-Albania Stabilization and Association Parliamentary Committee. The commitment to judicial and public administration reform, improving co-operation between the public sector and civil society, an atmosphere of religious tolerance, the fight against radicalization and Albania's overactive role in regional co-operation is commendable. On the other hand, there remain the problems of corruption, organized crime, poor environmental concerns, an underdeveloped market economy, interference with editorial autonomy among the media, and widespread self-censorship.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- This report is similar to the report on Turkey.Being naturally opposed to the enlargement of the Union, I voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the 2015 report by my colleague Knut Fleckenstein on Albania.I welcome the steady progress made by Albania in the reforms it is carrying out around the priority objectives.However, emphasis must be placed on the need to work on the problems that currently affect the functioning of justice, such as corruption and ineffective control mechanisms, political interference, weak accountability andselective justice.In addition, the importance of media freedom should be stressed and the implementation of the law on audiovisual media should be reinforced.This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which highlights the latest progress made by Albania in the field of reforms.In addition, the report welcomes the justice reform project, which is expected to help tackle a persistent problem in the country, that of corruption.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting against the resolution.Not only are many important points ignored, the wrong conclusions are drawn from them and measures are demanded that mean massive cuts in the sovereignty of the country.

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - Albania is a very controversial state in the Balkans. High demographic growth combined with backward infrastructure, a very poor state of industry and agriculture, together with historical concepts of "Greater Albania" and a literally tragic state of corruption, complete the picture of one of NATO's new member states. The report has difficulty finding positive action in government action and considers religious tolerance a success. From Lake Ochrický through the magical mountains with wild, still preserved nature to the interesting coast, there are many preconditions for the development of tourism, there is also an interesting natural wealth (including deposits of natural asphalt). The tragic state of the judiciary and the application of the adopted new laws are outlined in the report very carefully. I do not believe that the protection of the rights and freedoms of the LBTI community should take precedence over the national rights of minorities and the improvement of relations with neighboring states. Also, the development of renewable energy sources and environmental protection cannot be as important as the development of employment in industry and agriculture. Other attributes of modern society (apart from widespread corruption) are also in their infancy. Unfortunately, significant subsidies to NGOs only create another source of possible corruption. The whole possible picture is completed by the poor condition of the infrastructure. Unfortunately, the report does not fill the reader with historical optimism in any way and rightly emphasizes the need for further intensive comprehensive assistance in the implementation of the agreed measures. I therefore recommend that you take note of the report.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on Albania, which is in line with that country's accession to the European Union.The amendment of the Europe of Nations and Freedoms group opposing the accession negotiations has been rejected, while Albania does not meet the conditions to be able to negotiate.The idea of the systematic enlargement of the European Union is contrary to the interests of European nations.It is overwhelmingly rejected by the French and other European peoples.This is why we must put an end to this process.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it fits in with the perspective of the future membership of Albania.However, I am opposed in principle to any enlargement of the EU.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- I have not been able to vote in favor of this resolution since it continues in line with Parliament's views towards the candidate countries, in which a colonial relationship is reproduced between a rich and powerful center versus an impoverished and obedient periphery.The Resolution put to the vote also seeks to influence the correlation of political forces that participate in the Albanian system.This aspect depends solely and exclusively on the will of the Albanians.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- Albania has a lot of work to do to improve the rule of law, reform the judiciary and public administration.There are clear provisions in Albanian law on the protection of human rights, but they are not always respected and often the rights of minorities are not protected.Albania also needs to make further commitments to developing and strengthening its economy, in particular fiscal consolidation, competitiveness and stimulating economic growth.I supported the Report on Albania because progress in reforms is visible, but Albania still has a lot of work to do in reforming the judiciary and boosting the economy.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. - I am quite pleased that Albania has been able to go so far in its negotiations with the European Union over the last few years. It is hoped that it will continue to implement all the necessary and planned reforms - in particular as regards the independence of the judiciary, the fight against corruption and organized crime - in order to maximize its governance model. The same applies to education, economic and social reforms. It is thought that the main idea here should be to improve the quality of life of our citizens, not to integrate into the European Union as such, because the latter follows largely logically from the former. Looking at the wider context, I very much hope that in the future - and the sooner the better - Albanians will be able to develop, on the basis of mutual understanding, the most productive and favorable relations possible with their neighbors, especially Serbs, as they are currently the main concern. having regard to the same recent incident during the 2016 UEFA European Championship qualifying match.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- Albania is one of the poorest countries in Europe, with weak economic growth, underdeveloped infrastructure, which has an impact on all sectors of industry and tourism.It is the lack of infrastructure that significantly weakens Albania's otherwise relatively strong tourism potential.The political situation was affected by the collapse of the Albanian state in 1997 and also by the crisis in Kosovo.In order to make further progress in the integration process, Albania needs to carry out fundamental reforms in the judiciary, public administration, the electoral system, the elimination of corruption, the fight against crime and terrorism, but also in the areas of social affairs, health and education.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I oppose the motion for a resolution on the 2015 report on Albania for the reasons I set out in detail in my speech to the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/4/2016, and because this report is not complete and well-founded.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report that welcomes Albania’s progress, thus far, in reforms as part of the accession process. The report outlines the key priorities that Albania must address in order to construct a democratic political structure.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- This report on Albania is relatively balanced and focuses on the key issues for the country's development: endemic corruption, unemployment, organized crime, drug trafficking ... The resolution welcomes the improvements made in these areas.But it is to better impose a pace of reform on Albania with a view to eventual accession to the Union.Thus, the resolution calls for "not to slacken the pace of reforms, and even to accelerate it", whether for the strengthening of the rule of law or for privatizations, the objective being the advent of the sacrosanct.—Saint "market economy".Other policies would however be more beneficial to the population, in a country which has not seen any investment in its public infrastructure since the end of Enver Hoxha.I vote against this preaching — preached about a country with aggressively anti-Serbian governance.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This report is similar to the one on Turkey.Being opposed to the enlargement of the Union, I voted against this text.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this resolution regarding the progress that Albania made in 2015. The resolution comments on the need to improve Albania’s record of investigations, prosecutions and convictions at all levels, as this will contribute to the country’s efforts to combat organised crime. Lastly, the resolution also notes the positive steps that Albania has made in relation to religious tolerance.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing.- I welcome the efforts made by Albania to join the European Union.I particularly welcome the adoption by the government of an action plan against corruption, which sends a strong signal.It testifies both to awareness and political will as to the incompatibility between these practices and European values and achievements.However, it remains for Albania to persevere in the fight against corruption and organized crime and to make progress on the path leading to the establishment of the rule of law by continuing the reform of the judicial system, defending the freedom ofpress and preserving human and children's rights.I encourage Albania to also take environmental protection into consideration and call on it to consider the consequences of the deployment of hydropower plants and to consult the populations potentially affected.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the progress in Albania, which urges the government to keep to the reform efforts and supports Albania’s European perspective. It believes that the opening of accession negotiations, as soon as possible, will provide a tangible incentive for the positive transformation of the country.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The Foreign Affairs Committee's presentation on the 2015 report on Albania states that, although Albania has made steady progress on the road to EU accession, there are still problems that need to be addressed quickly and effectively in order to make further progress. In particular, it urges stepping up reform efforts in the areas of the rule of law, judicial reform, the fight against corruption and organized crime, administrative reform and fundamental rights. It notes that there is a political consensus on the EU accession process and that it enjoys broad public support in Albania. It welcomes the commitment to comprehensive and in-depth judicial reform and the adoption of a reform strategy for public administration and public finance management. Remains concerned about widespread corruption, condemns the ill-treatment of suspects in the police, overcrowding in prisons, inadequate medical care and poor conditions in detention facilities, and warns that institutional mechanisms to protect children's rights remain in place; are also insufficient. Stresses the importance of professional, independent and diverse public service broadcasting and private media; finds it worrying that there is widespread self-censorship among journalists, who are sometimes physically prevented from covering certain events. I voted in favor of the motion.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The status of candidate country for accession to the EU was granted to Albania in June 2014, and since then Albania has made efforts to achieve the necessary defined reforms, focusing on five priority areas: the judiciary, the public administration, the corruption, organized crime and human rights. Despite the efforts made to carry out the reforms, there are still some challenges that Albania will have to face in order to open accession negotiations, namely the promotion of a more constructive political dialogue both in inter-party relations and in the context of interinstitutional relations, the defense of fundamental rights, the protection of ethnic minorities, freedom of the press, the transparency of the electoral system, the fight against corruption, the improvement of the education system, the strengthening of the protection of human rights and the fight against radicalization and terrorism. In this sense, I vote in favor, as I believe it is important to monitor the implementation of reforms by the Albanian State, since the success of their implementation is essential for the opening of EU accession negotiations.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution, which notes that Albania is making progress in the reforms it is carrying out around the priority objectives set for the opening of accession negotiations, but that it must make important commitments, in particular in the field of rule of law and democracy as well as the fight against corruption and crime.The European Union must exercise the utmost vigilance in respecting all negotiating chapters before accepting further enlargement.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- Albania has been able to embark on the path of reforms and democratic political culture, and should be commended for this.It is now essential to strengthen the independence and the proper functioning of justice as well as political transparency, and to guarantee fundamental freedoms in the country.I would also like to congratulate the government on the implementation of measures to combat the scourge of organized crime, which undermines the economy and endangers social structures.It is in our common interest to support Albania in its reform and development process;I therefore obviously voted in favor of the resolution.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on Albania that monitors the steady progress made by Albania with respect to the key priority reforms required for opening accession negotiations.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ I endorse this resolution as it remains crucial to stability and prosperity in Europe that the EU continues to support the Western Balkans and Albania’s democratic transition towards EU membership by holding candidate and potential candidate countries to account for their reform progress or lack thereof.  This resolution sets out those specific areas in which Albania still has a lot of work to do in order to meet the requirements of the EU Enlargement Policy. The lack of independence of the judiciary from political branches, high unemployment rates, a flawed child protection system, excessive corruption particularly in education, healthcare and the judiciary, and socio-economic discrimination against Roma and Egyptian minorities, are particularly concerning in this regard. However, the resolution also stresses positive developments as evident in the strategy and law on decentralisation of governance to local governments, the spread and consolidation of religious tolerance and the willingness of the parliament to cooperate with civil society organisations.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted against the report because it only half-heartedly addresses the current problems facing the country, in particular the problem of minorities and the problem of organized crime.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- With regard to the proposal by rapporteur Knut Fleckenstein, I would like to vote in favor as Albania has already made important progress in the reforms necessary for its accession to the EU.Nonetheless, further progress is desirable, especially in the public administration system and the judiciary.Similarly, greater efforts are required, especially in the area of human rights protection, and in this regard collaboration between all Albanian political parties should be encouraged.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome Albania’s progress concerning the reforms on key priorities, but at the same time I  encourage the political parties to maintain the reform momentum and focus on advancing steadily on many fronts. The current state of the Balkans needs stronger EU support for candidates individually, and also for the entire region, to avoid big asymmetries in the progress of different candidates. Member States should build understanding about the risk of asymmetric situations.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support this resolution because it recognizes the progress that Albania has made and encourages further efforts that will bring Albania closer to European standards. I believe it is important to provide additional support to Albania. I would like to remind you that political dialogue between the parties is very important, and a boycott of the parliament is not effective for either side, least of all for the citizens. I therefore welcome the fact that all disagreements in this regard have been overcome and that both the opposition and the government are cooperating successfully with the Venice Commission. Although Albanian laws are in line with the EU acquis, the Albanian authorities need to focus more on their implementation, as also stated in the resolution. I want to emphasize that the fight against organized crime and corruption is essential for the progress of Albania, but also for the stability of the whole region. In this regard, I welcome the fact that Albania has adopted an anti-corruption strategy and strengthened international police co-operation. I hope that Albania will continue to work on its five priority reforms and continue to focus on European integration.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- I welcome Albania's continued progress in implementing reforms related to the five key priorities necessary to start accession negotiations.I commend Albania for continuing to be a constructive partner in the region and a proactive participant in regional cooperation.It is extremely important to preserve good neighborly relations, which are still crucial.I am concerned about widespread corruption, especially in education, health, the judiciary, public procurement, public-private partnership concessions, construction and spatial planning, local government and public services;local government needs to be strengthened.I welcome the adoption of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy for the period 2015-2020. I am pleased that, for the first time, the report covers an amendment I have tabled on the issue of waste management, especially marine litter.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The report replicates the traditional set of considerations on integration processes in the EU, in this case, Albania. The identification of conditions for accession continues, in the form of interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of accession to the EU, insisting on the implementation of structural reforms, in particular on issues such as justice, public administration, the electoral system , economic governance, or combating corruption and organized crime. The alignment of that country's positions with those of the EU is required, particularly with regard to foreign and border policy. We consider the unreasonable stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts regarding the country's integration are exposed. People are deprived of the legitimate right to decide on their future, which includes the free and sovereign choice of EU membership, but also the strategies for economic and social development. So is the EU matrix. One in which the ability to make decisions is distanced from citizens, in order to be able to impose policies that are contrary to their interests and desires. For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing.- I support the adoption of this report on Albania for 2015. I very much welcome the progress that Albania has made in reforming the priority areas that were a condition for opening accession negotiations.However, further steps are needed in the areas of the judiciary, public administration, the fight against corruption and organized crime, and last but not least, the rule of law.Only in this way will Albania consolidate its transition to democracy.I am sure that the progress made in these areas will be the right impetus to show Albania's willingness to become another member of the European Union.I also very much welcome Albania's progress in the fight against organized crime, which has resulted in a number of successful large-scale law enforcement operations, including in cooperation with the authorities of neighboring countries and EU Member States.I also appreciate the country's efforts to improve relations with Serbia and thus establish good neighborly relations.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing.- Albania has made steady progress on the road to EU membership in relation to reforms on key priorities required for the start of negotiations.Albania is committed to a complete and profound reform of the judiciary and public administration 2015-2020, on the reform strategy of the management of public funds 2014-2020 and in the fight against corruption and organized crime.It has also made a strong commitment in the fight against radicalization and terrorism and in the adoption of security strategies.For all of this, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I approved the 2015 report on Albania, which shows some progress made by the country, such as the reform of its judicial system.However, I express real concerns about the extent of corruption and organized crime in the country and call for full respect for the rule of law, a basic principle of the democracies of the European Union.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing.- Albania has been making steady progress towards EU accession and this report encourages the government, parliament and political parties to accelerate the momentum and implementation of reforms, while also urging the government to proceed rapidly with a thorough reform of the judicial system andto implement these reforms correctly and on time.The report also highlights some important factors for EU membership, such as the importance of all political forces engaging in a more constructive and genuine political dialogue that allows for the adoption and implementation of major reforms, through a democratic political culture that includes theopenness to dialogue, negotiation, commitment and the total exclusion of boycotts and radicalism.The document also states that sustainable cooperation in parliament between the government and the opposition is essential to fulfill the membership criteria.I voted in favor.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - In the text of this report, which was adopted, the Parliament welcomes the steady progress made by Albania in the reforms it is carrying out around the priority objectives, while encouraging the Albanian Parliament and the political parties not to let go the pace of reforms. The text voted on draws attention to the fact that, over time, a constructive dialogue between the political forces is essential for the process of accession to the European Union, but also for the adoption and implementation of the main reforms, while strongly insisting on the importance of maintaining their commitment to building a democratic political culture, characterized in particular by openness to dialogue, negotiation and compromise, and by the total exclusion of boycott and radicalism. The European Parliament also emphasizes the need to tackle the shortcomings which currently affect the functioning of justice, such as political interference, high corruption, ineffective control mechanisms, etc. while encouraging the European Commission to take into account the progress made by Albania in the five priority areas, when examining the advisability of recommending the opening of accession negotiations. I have chosen to abstain from this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this monitoring report by Albania.If it is a question of underlining Albania's commitment in the negotiation process, it is necessary that the country accelerate its pace of reforms, especially in the areas concerning the rule of law, the judicial system,fight against corruption, or even organized crime.It is essential to take action to strengthen human rights.I supported this text because it also calls on Albania to continue its economic reforms in order to stem the underground economy.Finally, it is a question of welcoming the constructive role played by Albania in the region and its desire to improve relations with Serbia.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We have voted to abstain, despite the fact that the resolution proposal advances in line with the integration perspective of the Balkan countries, for two reasons: the position it maintains with respect to the economic reforms that Albania is being asked to do and because theMotion for a resolution includes a position on how to fight terrorism that we do not share.Additionally, this proposal is quite imprecise in the orientation in the fight against high-level organized crime, the treatment of the Roma minority and on the treatment in the fight against gender violence.The report includes positive aspects that we value as a whole, for which we will vote abstention.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: written.- I support this resolution, which points out that Albania has carried out significant reform efforts to promote democracy, the rule of law and human rights.The government should be called upon to implement further reforms to continue on this path towards future EU membership.However, getting closer to the EU is not just about solving its internal problems.European integration and regional cooperation are closely intertwined.Albania has played a more constructive role in promoting regional stability and peace in the Western Balkans, and this should be continued.In the context of tense relations between Kosovo Albanians and Kosovo Serbs in Kosovo, citing the demonstrations that have taken place, Albania should continue to take greater responsibility for contributing to more peaceful relations between these two groups.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against the Resolution on the 2015 Report on Albania since it is aimed mainly at encouraging the process of integration of this country into the EU by demanding all kinds of structural socio-economic reforms that imply the reduction of social and labor rights ofthe popular classes as well as state public spending.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report on Albania which highlights my shared enthusiasm and delight over how much Albania has achieved in 2015, considering its apparent stagnation in previous years. The report also encourages the government of Albania to keep up these reform efforts, which the Albanian people cannot be kept waiting for any longer. Furthermore, I support the opening of accession negotiations with Albania as soon as possible, if not for the conditionality incentives and pressures that would transform the country in a positive way.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Albania is also making progress on its path to EU accession thanks to a broad political consensus and support from the general public in the country. Significant progress has been made on the rule of law, judicial reform, the fight against corruption and organized crime, public administration reform and fundamental rights, but Albania needs to further intensify its reform efforts in these areas. The report assesses very positively the constructive cooperation of governmental and opposition parties for the adoption of a law in parliament that prevents the appointment and election of criminals to public office. The Government of Albania is also involved in the fight against organized crime, which has led to several successful large-scale peacock enforcement operations, including in cooperation with the authorities of neighboring countries and EU Member States. Albania also received a positive assessment for the fact that Parliament adopted a resolution on the role of civil society in the country's democratic development and points to improved cooperation between state institutions and civil society organizations, including their participation in National Council for European Integration meetings. The report also welcomes Albania's commitment to the fight against radicalization and terrorism; on the contrary, criticism has been criticized for not yet ensuring the enforcement of property rights and the property registration process.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - In June 2014, Albania received the status of a candidate. Since then, Albania has had to address five key priorities: public administration reform, strengthening the judiciary, fighting corruption and organized crime, and protecting human rights. Fulfilling them will pave the way for the start of EU accession negotiations. The report is well written, politically balanced and also forward-looking, which clearly promotes Albania's EU membership perspective. Albania is making steady progress on its path to EU accession. However, it is important to be aware that many challenges still exist and need to be addressed quickly and effectively, especially in order for Albania to remain on this successful and targeted path to EU membership. I believe that reforms are urgently needed, especially in the area of ​​the legal system, as it is essential that it is as independent as possible from all possible external influences. It is also necessary to point out the problem of corruption and also the fact that the existing mechanisms for its prevention are not successful. It is positive that the environmental aspect is also included in the text. The construction of hydroelectric power plants in the protected area of ​​the Vjosa River is in conflict with European environmental standards and laws. As I consider the text of the resolution to be balanced and well written, I supported the resolution and voted in favor of its adoption.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Albania has made progress on key political and administrative reforms, but has not yet reached the point at which accession negotiations could begin.An important part is also judicial reform, which aims to address the most critical concerns of citizens, such as corruption or organized crime.These, together with the widespread self-censorship of journalists, corruption in education, healthcare and the judiciary, are the main reasons for MEPs' concerns and preventing Albania on its path to EU membership.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - In 2006, Albania signed the Stabilization and Association Agreement. After joining NATO and applying for accession to the European Union, on June 26, 2014, Albania was granted candidate status. Following progress in negotiations and implementation of reforms, Albania has established a National Council for European Integration, which should further facilitate the implementation of reforms. Primarily, the implementation of judicial reform is expected, which is a priority for a positive assessment in the 2016 report. There are also problems with corruption, human rights and organized crime that should be addressed as soon as possible. I support the Motion for a resolution on the 2015 report on Albania. I believe that Albania is constantly making progress in terms of EU membership, and I welcome the good cooperation of the political leadership in Albania with the EU institutions. For Croatia, Albania's accession is extremely important because Albania is key to further stabilizing the entire region. Also, Croatia's expertise and experience can greatly contribute to Albania's path to the EU.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on Albania in 2015. Albania has recently made progress and become a reliable partner of the European Union.If they want to make even more progress, they must be aware that this will only be possible with the participation of all political forces in the country.Judicial reform is very important to strengthen the rule of law in the country.However, there are other areas where we should make progress: the fight against corruption, public administration, media reform and electoral reform, which should be carried out by the 2017 elections. Albania must gradually adopt EU values in all areas, elections are a very important area, which must be democratic, free and fair.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- I supported the adoption of the resolution on the 2015 report on Albania, as the text of the report emphasizes the need to speed up, in particular, the reform of Albania's judicial system.Properly established and functioning institutions are a prerequisite for the good functioning of the state in other areas, and the EU is, of course, interested in making Albania a state and a useful partner in solving problems in a strategically important region of the Western Balkans.The promise of EU membership is a motivation to establish a functioning state, and only such a state can then become an EU member state.Albania needs to be assisted in fulfilling the conditions for membership, and a fair evaluation is the first step in this assistance.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the adoption of the Annual Report on Albania, in particular appreciating that Albania is perhaps the most far-reaching in the process of joining the Western Balkans to the European Union and is now one of our most promising partners as a candidate. In my opinion, the work of the European Parliament's rapporteur reflects precisely the responsible approach that is able to motivate the partner country by confirming the Albanian achievements and by demanding the correct and correct assignment of the integration tasks facing the country. We need this very much today in order to dynamize the EU enlargement process and renew its credibility. Among the areas highlighted in the report, strengthening the rule of law, the fight against corruption and organized crime are a priority for virtually all Western Balkan countries to meet the conditions for accession, but I see an opportunity to use Albania's encouraging progress as a positive example. country.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ Considering Albania’s achievements in its European integration process, we should positively encourage its steady progress in 2015 in meeting the key priorities for opening accession negotiations. I think the European Parliament should call on all political parties to work constructively together for the implementation of the reforms. This resolution urges the Albanian Government to keep up the reform efforts and supports the country’s European perspective. The rapporteur believes that the opening of accession negotiations will provide an incentive for the positive transformation of the country. Further efforts are needed, in particular, in the field of judicial reform. Also, the Commission needs to monitor progress closely and to report to Parliament and the Council as soon as Albania has sufficiently advanced with the necessary reforms, with a view to opening accession negotiations. I fully support this approach.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- With this resolution, Parliament welcomed the steady progress made by Albania in the reforms it is carrying out around the priority objectives set for the opening of accession negotiations.It encourages the government, parliament and political parties not to slacken the pace of reforms, or even to accelerate it, and invites them to quickly initiate a vast reform of the justice system;he also insisted on the importance of applying these reforms correctly and without delay.We call on all political parties to continue their efforts to establish a more constructive and authentic political dialogue in order to enable the adoption and implementation of essential reforms.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report on Albania, as I agree that considerable progress has been made with respect to the five key priorities required for opening accession negotiations. However, real progress in certain areas is still urgently needed. The full independence of the judicial system from political power, the fight against corruption and organised crime remain the greatest challenges. Another notable element is a more democratic political culture, including respect for human rights, and the protection and equal treatment of minorities. Moreover, Albania will need to make efforts in ensuring true media independence.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: written.- The implementation of reforms in Albania is related to the five key priorities necessary for the start of accession negotiations, which include a thorough reform of the judiciary, encouraging the government, parliament and political parties of Albania to maintain the implementation of the initiated reforms.As there is a political consensus in Albania on the process of accession to the European Union that enjoys broad public support, the relationship between the European Union and Albania contains a constructive dialogue that is necessary for successful and sustainable reform processes.I welcome the adoption of the National Anti-Corruption Strategy for 2015-2020 and the Action Plan for 2015-2017, and I believe that progress in judicial reform will significantly improve the fight against corruption and organized crime.Given Albania's great progress driven by a number of reforms, I supported this report.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I would support the 2015 report on Albania if I voted, because Albania is constantly making progress on its path to EU accession.All (potential) candidate countries are assessed on the basis of their achievements, and the timetable for accession is determined by the quality of the reforms needed.Challenges remain and need to be addressed swiftly and effectively in order to make further progress towards EU accession.Continuous progress, in particular in the areas of the rule of law, judicial reform, the fight against corruption and organized crime, public administration reform and fundamental rights, is key to the reform process.Albania needs to step up its reform efforts in these areas and on other key priorities in order to start accession negotiations and consolidate its transition to democracy.The EU has placed the rule of law at the heart of its enlargement process, stressing the need to strengthen economic governance and public administration in all Western Balkan countries.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We have voted to abstain, despite the fact that the motion for a resolution advances in line with the integration perspective of the Balkan countries, for two reasons: the position it maintains with respect to the economic reforms that Albania is being asked to do and because theThe motion for a resolution includes a position on how to fight terrorism that we do not share.Additionally, this proposal is quite imprecise in the orientation in the fight against high-level organized crime, the treatment of the Roma minority and on the treatment in the fight against gender violence.The report includes positive aspects that we value as a whole, for which we will vote abstention.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- Albania has made steady progress towards EU accession.At the same time, the report concludes that there are still problems that need to be addressed quickly and effectively in order to make further progress towards EU accession.By my vote, I supported the position of the S&D Group.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We have voted to abstain, despite the fact that the motion for a resolution advances in line with the integration perspective of the Balkan countries, for two reasons: the position it maintains with respect to the economic reforms that Albania is being asked to do and because theMotion for a resolution includes a position on how to fight terrorism that we do not share.Additionally, this proposal is quite imprecise in the orientation in the fight against high-level organized crime, the treatment of the Roma minority and on the treatment in the fight against gender violence.The report includes positive aspects that we value as a whole, for which we will vote abstention.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2105 report on Albania, as the country is looking to be on the right track towards EU membership. The planned ambitious judiciary reform will be of great help in the fight against corruption, which remains a cause of serious concern. Albania must keep focusing on implementing reforms in a series of key areas such as the rule of law, fundamental rights, public administration and the fight against organised crime.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Through this report, the European Parliament highlights the importance of continuing to advance in a constructive and sustainable dialogue between political forces as well as the implementation of basic reforms in the judicial system, financial transparency, financial control of political parties, the fight againstorganized crime, the protection of minority rights or the importance of freedom of the press.Ultimately, we are talking about a complete report that deals with the issues that are on the table in relation to this country.For all these reasons, I consider it necessary to vote in their favor.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report on Albania, as significant progress has been made on the five main priorities for opening accession negotiations.Of course, further progress is needed in certain areas, such as in the fight against corruption and the independence of the judicial system.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
