text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution weaves a wide range of recitals on Albania's integration process into the EU.Beyond the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of constraints towards accession, which confirm the extent of interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of accession to the EU, in particular on issues such as justice,public administration, the requirement of aligning that country's positions with those of the EU, particularly with regard to foreign and border policy.We consider the manorial stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts regarding the integration of the country are unacceptable, depriving people of the legitimate right to decide their future, where the free and sovereign choice of EU membership is inscribed,but also economic and social development strategies.For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- Because of the inadequate criticism of the organized crime prevailing in the country, I voted against this motion for a resolution.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Albania.The report examines Albania's European integration process, underlining the progress made in order to start accession negotiations.Despite this, further reforms, especially of the legal system, are needed.It is important that the Albanian government proceed with these reforms and support a European perspective.I firmly believe that starting accession negotiations as soon as possible will be a tangible incentive to improve the situation in the country.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not vote in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the 2015 report on Albania.I am against enlarging the EU to include more member states.The EU has such a large number of internal problems that must be resolved before it can accept new members.So far the EU has taken the path of deepening and enlargement at the same time.However, this has proven to be a dead end.The resulting problems are proving to be a burden for European cooperation.First, the EU must be fundamentally reformed before even remotely thinking about enlargement.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I agree with the report on Albania and welcome the progress that Albania has made in reforming the key priority areas that were a condition for opening accession negotiations.I firmly believe that the country will maintain this established trend and will also undertake a fundamental reform of the judiciary.The illicit drug and arms trade remains a major problem for Albania, but I personally appreciate the Albanian Government's commitment to the fight against organized crime, which has resulted in a number of successful operations, including in cooperation with the authorities of neighboring countries and EU Member States.I also consider it important for the Albanian Government to start working on improving the prospects of young people and to start investing in the modernization of education.In my opinion, the aim should be to improve young people's prospects for employment and employment and thus prevent a brain drain from the country.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the report on Albania for 2015.I welcome Albania's continued progress in the areas of the rule of law, judicial reform, the fight against corruption and organized crime, public administration reform and fundamental rights.It is important that Albania remains a constructive partner in the region and proactive in regional cooperation.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- In June 2008, the EU and Bosnia and Herzegovina concluded the Stabilization and Association Agreement, thus completing the first step in the process of European integration.An indispensable condition for entry into the Union is respect for the values and fundamental principles signed in the founding treaties and in European legislation.Unfortunately, the Bosnian system still shows important gaps in various sectors, such as political instability, reduced protection of fundamental freedoms and finally the unfair judicial system.However, the report seems to deny a priori and, in my opinion, without good reason, the referendum of the Republic of Srpska, focusing on the contrary on the respect of the commercial commitments made.I would have abstained from the vote, hoping for a future improvement of the report presented, perhaps paying more attention to the importance of the referendum, as a free expression of the right of peoples to self-determination.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - This is a triumphalist report that does not correspond to the reality of the country. In the report there is no recognition of the citizen protests of 2014, which germinated the seeds of authentic political and social change in the country and its modernization. You keep trying to work with a broken country and society. And we must not forget that it has been the EU itself that has contributed to Bosnia being a country of small local chieftains. Western powers preferred ethnic sectarianism over respecting the will of the people. In 2014 they had a great opportunity to rectify, when Bosnians took to the streets across the country asking to be treated as citizens, and not as numbers in an ethnic census; asking for more jobs and less national pride. This year they still have that opportunity, but the rapporteur is determined to ignore that reality. However, the decision to join the EU is a point of agreement between the Bosnian communities and a will of their institutions, for which I have abstained in the final vote.

name: Martina ANDERSON
text: in writing. – This report calls on Bosnia-Herzegovina to engage in various reforms, particularly against corruption and organised crime, human trafficking, the rule of law, discrimination on the basis of gender or sexuality, and reform of public administration. It also highlights some of the shortcomings of Bosnia-Herzegovina in the establishment of a democratic, multi-ethnic and stable state.  Despite these and other issues, the report strongly supports EU integration and the accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the EU. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S & amp; D), in writing.- As a member of the EP Socialist and Democrat political group, I welcome the request for Bosnia and Herzegovina to join the EU, which presents a unique opportunity.The report, which I voted in favor of, encourages the political leadership to continue implementing reforms and to make the country more functional and efficient on the road to the European Union.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ I do not believe in further EU expansion, and therefore had no option but to vote against this progress report.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report.Bosnia and Herzegovina still has efforts to make in the fight against corruption and respect for the rule of law, but we must bear in mind that any rapprochement with the Union will lead to more stability and prosperity.throughout the Western Balkans region.I would also like to point out that I am opposed to any enlargement of the Union.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this resolution, which deals with the 2015report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.I support the calls for the country's authorities to show determination in implementing reforms and making steady progress in the EU integration process, and to ensure transparency in the process of planning and implementing reforms.It is essential to pursue constitutional, legal and political reforms that will transform Bosnia and Herzegovina into a fully effective, inclusive and functioning state that guarantees equality and democratic representation of all its peoples and citizens, regardless of their ethnic origin and religion.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This report supports the "European perspective" of Bosnia, without a word for the unfavorable treatment suffered by the large - historic - minority of Bosnian Serbs.Also noteworthy are the various and varied attempts to interfere by Parliament in the country's internal policy, at the energy or ecological level.Of course, I voted against this report, which prepares the ground for this country's accession to the Union.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- Bosnia and Herzegovina presented its candidacy for membership of the European Union on February 15, 2016. This initiative should make the country more democratic and stimulate a real desire for European integration in these times of euroscepticism within statesmembers of the Union.I voted in favor of this report because it illustrates the progress and delays of a country in strong transition - a transition which will, in particular, strengthen the rule of law and the question of fundamental freedoms.At present, it is particularly worrying to note the polarization of Bosnian society in nationalist and separatist temptations, or the presence of corruption at the highest level of the state.Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to carry out the necessary reforms and I will be happy to read the next report on this issue.

name: Beatriz BECERRA BASTERRECHEA
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report, which is committed to further strengthening relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina. The text also welcomes the request for EU membership as well as the progress made by the Bosnian authorities in achieving the objectives set out in the Stabilization and Association Agreement. I believe that the Europeanisation of the Western Balkans is a goal to be achieved that will have repercussions in improving the quality of democracy in all countries, as well as in strengthening political and institutional stability. However, it cannot be ignored that this objective is simultaneously a challenge for the Union in a region where great political and ethnic divisions are still present, socio-economic standards remain far below those of the Community, and other international actors such as Russia They seek to influence these countries due to their geostrategic importance. In this regard, the EU must demonstrate its leadership in this region. We are facing an opportunity to influence full stability in the Western Balkans through their progressive integration into the European institutions.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Twenty years after the end of the terrible conflict in Bosnia and Herzegovina, the start of the country's accession process to the Union represents an important moment both from a political and a symbolic point of view. My support for the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina stems precisely from the awareness of the importance of the challenge that this request represents. It is an objective fact that in matters of strengthening the rule of law and democracy, the process underway is constituting a strong engine for improvement and development. As was aptly highlighted by the report, Bosnia, while still having strong polarizing forces of a secessionist nature within it, has undertaken to carry out a serious political dialogue to carry out those constitutional, political and legal reforms that would make the institutional system more solid. . Economic problems, organized crime and corruption remain serious issues that need to be addressed, but it will undoubtedly be possible to do so more effectively by increasing cooperation and links between the EU and the Balkan country.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We voted to abstain on this resolution, because despite having positive parts it continues to insist on the need for the EU to interfere in Bosnian politics, for example condemning the consultation of the people of the Republika Srbska on their sovereignty.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - I voted against this resolution, which is a monument of contempt for Bosnia and Herzegovina and its peoples, out of pure submission to the Euro-federalist ideology of unlimited enlargement of the EU. The parliamentarians who drafted this report shamelessly dare to give political and religious leaders instructions in Bosnia-Herzegovina: apparently, it is unbearable for the Brussels Eurobeaters that we can remain attached to the idea of ​​nation. Democracy is also pilloried in this report since the President of the Serbian Republic of Bosnia is clearly asked to postpone the referendum foreseen in on the judicial system at the state level of Bosnia and Herzegovina; as for the parliamentarians of the Serbian Republic of Bosnia, they are clearly reprimanded for daring, as representatives of the people, to take sovereign decisions on their destiny and which are contrary to the wishes of Brussels. Finally, the links of the Serbian Republic of Bosnia with Russia are almost assimilated to a declaration of war, this territory apparently not having the right to establish bilateral relations in matters of foreign policy in the best of its strategic interests.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The European Union should not interfere in the internal affairs of third countries such as holding a referendum in the Republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina.The peoples of this country have the right to express themselves freely without the unfair pressure of the European Union.I therefore voted against this resolution.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this resolution, which deals with the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. The European Parliament emphasizes the important role of civil society in protecting and promoting the rights of minorities in the country, as well as in fostering coherence and tolerance in society and raising people's awareness of the benefits of diversity. He calls for the future involvement of civil society in tackling ethnic exclusion in order to bring the country closer to EU membership. It also calls for better coordination between the competent authorities and civil society organizations in order to ensure better implementation of minority law. Parliament emphasized that education was a key factor in building and promoting a tolerant and inclusive society, as well as in promoting cooperation and cohesion, despite cultural, religious and ethnic differences, and therefore called for specific measures to be taken to begin segregating the education system. In addition, much needs to be done to improve the efficiency of the fragmented education system, while guaranteeing the right to equal access to education in all languages ​​of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the right of each community to educate children in their mother tongue. Parliament called on the authorities to ensure the effective implementation of the principles of inclusive education, including for children with disabilities.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - In my opinion, it is an important fact that the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina are at the heart of the reforms that have begun. Continuing reforms is essential to keep the country on track on the road to the EU. The full integration of coordination mechanisms has also begun. An anti-corruption action plan is also being adopted, which is a clear demonstration of the country's determination to tackle this phenomenon. Active steps have also been taken in the field of illegal arms trafficking, something in the fight against organized crime. In the light of all this, I am convinced that, despite all the difficulties, the EU institutions must continue to assist Bosnia and Herzegovina in democratization and the development of the rule of law, which is not only important for EU integration but also for the country's citizens and stability in the Balkans. It is important that the country’s leadership consistently opposes the spread of extremist Islamic views. Based on these, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- By voting in favor, I supported the motion for a resolution on the report on Bosnia and Herzegovina for 2015, prepared by Cristian Dan Preda on behalf of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.I would like to congratulate Bosnia and Herzegovina on its application to join the European Union and to say that I support this decision, as it clearly shows its pro-European orientation.Strong economic development is needed, on the other hand, to halt the rise of radicalism and extremism, which has been on the rise in Bosnia and Herzegovina over the past year.In such a poor country, where there is a lot of dissatisfaction, we also have the most ISIS fighters per capita.We are also fighting against this by joining Bosnia and Herzegovina to the European Union.

name: Mercedes BRESSO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this document because I believe it is important that the European Union and its Member States strive to support and help Bosnia and Herzegovina on its reform path to achieve satisfactory standards of democracy and the rule of law and,one day, may become a member of the EU.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - The European institutions must continue to encourage the reform process in Bosnia and Herzegovina for a future accession of the Balkan country to the EU, as an important driver of stability and national territorial cohesion. Some reforms aimed at facilitating future entry and harmonizing national legislation with the acquis communautaire have already been implemented (think for example the establishment of a national coordination mechanism on EU issues or the adoption of the position negotiation for the adaptation of the SAA) or are in the works. However, it is necessary to intensify and amplify this process to all those sectors which still present important elements of irreconcilability with the prospect of future accession. I am thinking in particular of the pressing need to guarantee pluralism and freedom of the media, the urgency of an effective application of all ECHR rulings, as well as the approval of reforms aimed at reducing corruption and guaranteeing the development of efficient, transparent and independent judicial system. Particular attention should then be paid to monitoring worrying phenomena such as the high presence, on Bosnian territory, of foreign figthers and firearms, as well as a widespread and dangerous nationalistic rhetoric capable of undermining the security and stability of the region.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - I spoke in favor of the motion for a resolution on the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina, taking into account both the country's progress and the steps it needs to take in order to become an EU Member State. The European Union has taken a renewed approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina, in order for it to make progress on EU membership, but also to address socio-economic and rule of law issues. To this end, the European Commission will allocate 1.5 billion euros over the next three years to support reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina and to develop infrastructure. Unfortunately, however, this country is facing challenges in terms of human rights and the protection of minorities. The legal and institutional framework for monitoring human rights requires substantial improvements and appropriate legislation to be effectively implemented.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- I vote against.The resolution calls on the Council to examine the accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the EU as soon as possible.The resolution condemns the idea of holding a referendum in Bosnia and Herzegovina because, it is said, this challenges the cohesion, sovereignty and integrity of the country.The negative vote is also given by my substantial opposition to further EU enlargements.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written.- The resolution welcomes the submission of an application for EU membership by Bosnia and Herzegovina.After a long period of stagnation, some positive progress is observed, encouraging the country and its political leadership to intensify reform efforts in order to streamline the functional state on its way to the EU.The positive message is underlined that the application for EU membership presents a unique opportunity for politicians and all citizens of the country to put aside national divisions and work together for a common future within the EU.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina because after years of constant postponement something is moving.The country has officially submitted its application for membership of the European Union.Now, to get the green light in the various steps of accession, the Balkan country will have to carry out demanding reforms, including constitutional ones.In a country that has never ceased to feel European, Europe is seen as the best solution to heal a disastrous economy, weakened by reckless privatization and youth unemployment close to 60%.Our role must be to facilitate this process of European integration and at the same time ask for a decisive and direct approach to the systemic and socio-economic reforms necessary to continue along the path of change and approximation to European standards.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: in writing. ‒ This report calls on Bosnia-Herzegovina to engage in various reforms, particularly against corruption and organised crime, human trafficking, the rule of law, discrimination on the basis of gender or sexuality, and reform of public administration. It also highlights some of the shortcomings of Bosnia-Herzegovina in the establishment of a democratic, multi-ethnic and stable state.  Despite these and other issues, the report strongly supports EU integration and the accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the EU. I therefore abstained on this report.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I have spoken in favor of this report because, like the previous ones, it seeks to create a dialogue with one of the countries that are close to our Union and which could also be part of it in the future.It is therefore our task to try to bring Bosnia and Herzegovina as close as possible to respecting our values.With this vote, I wanted to support a Union that is more inclusive and participates in current issues, even if these do not directly affect it, and I wanted to underline the need to bring about changes that guarantee a rule of law promoting values such asequality and democratic representation.I always remain of the idea, in fact, that the establishment of such stable and functioning cooperation links can only bring economic and social advantages to both parties.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The EU initiated in December 2014 a new approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina, which provides for the re-sequencing of the conditionalities in order for the country to progress towards the EU and address the outstanding socio-economic challenges it faces. This led to the entry into force of the Stabilisation and Association Agreement (SAA) between Bosnia and Herzegovina and the EU on 1 June 2015. It replaced the Interim Agreement (IA) which had been in force since 2008. In July, the country adopted a reform agenda aimed at tackling the difficult socio-economic situation and advancing the judicial and public administration reforms. Its implementation has started.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ Democratic elections cannot be achieved unless a wide range of other human rights and fundamental freedoms can be exercised on an ongoing basis without discrimination. In democratic processes, grassroots civil society plays an important role in peace-building, conflict resolution and reconciliation. Particularly youth participation in intercultural dialogue and exchange, as well as in the political sphere, are also of vital importance. I commend the adoption of the 2015-2019 anti-corruption strategy and action plan which now needs to be implemented through the backing of a proper budget allocation.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - This is a triumphalist report that does not correspond to the reality of the country. In the report there is no recognition of the citizen protests of 2014, which germinated the seeds of authentic political and social change in the country and its modernization. You keep trying to work with a broken country and society. And we must not forget that it has been the EU itself that has contributed to Bosnia being a country of small local chieftains. The Western powers preferred ethnic sectarianism to respecting the will of the people. In 2014 they had a great opportunity to rectify, when Bosnians took to the streets across the country asking to be treated as citizens, and not as numbers in an ethnic census; asking for more jobs and less national pride. This year they still have that opportunity, but the rapporteur is determined to ignore that reality. However, the decision to join the EU is a point of agreement between the Bosnian communities and a will of their institutions, for which I have abstained in the final vote.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - The Bosnia and Herzegovina progress report is part of the enlargement package adopted by the European Commission in November 2015. The committee found that the elections that took place in October 2014 were sufficiently efficient. The Parliamentary Assembly elected in them began to function and implement the necessary reforms. Bosnia and Herzegovina faces many difficulties in the field of respecting human and minority rights. Regarding the economic criterion, Bosnia and Herzegovina is in the early stage of implementing a functioning market economy. The difficult situation on the labor market has not changed, and unemployment increased from 27.6% to 62.7% among young people. All these problems are reflected in the report which, on the one hand, criticizes the lack of concrete progress and, on the other hand, highlights the EU's support for the necessary changes in the country. Bearing in mind the efforts of Bosnia and Herzegovina to regulate the internal situation, I voted in favor.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This motion for a resolution considers that an effective coordination mechanism for matters relating to the Union between the different levels of government is essential in order to ensure better interaction with the Union.Parliament also invites the delegation of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the Parliamentary Stabilization and Association Committee (CPSA) to make constructive progress towards the adoption of the rules of procedure at the next meeting of the CPSA.Parliament regrets that corruption remains a widespread phenomenon and calls on the authorities to improve the record of the effectiveness of investigations and prosecutions in high-level corruption cases.Supporting these goals, I voted in favor of this resolution.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported this resolution on the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.With this resolution, the European Parliament recalls that Bosnia and Herzegovina is seriously affected by the phenomenon of foreign fighters and that effective de-radicalization programs need to be implemented urgently.I welcome the adoption by Bosnia and Herzegovina of an action plan to combat trafficking in human beings, for the period 2016-2019, but I nevertheless recall the need for rapid and effective implementation..

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - It is an important fact that the citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina are at the heart of the reforms that have begun. Continuing reforms is essential to keep the country on track on the road to the EU. The full integration of coordination mechanisms has also begun. The anti-corruption action plan for 2015-2019 is also being adopted, which clearly demonstrates the country's determination to tackle this phenomenon. There have also been active steps in the area of ​​the illegal arms trade, something in the fight against organized crime. At the same time, it is necessary to implement the Sejdić-Finci and Zornić judgments and to develop a more balanced relationship between the peoples of the country and the federal units. In the light of all this, I am convinced that, despite all the difficulties, the EU institutions must continue to assist Bosnia and Herzegovina in terms of democratization and the development of the rule of law, which is not only important for EU integration but also for the country's citizens.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I supported the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina's progress, because the text contains very important recommendations to the country with a view to the accession process. There has been some progress in judicial reform and the fight against organized crime and corruption, but real results are still needed in these areas. In addition, Bosnia and Herzegovina faces many challenges in terms of human rights and the protection of minorities. In conclusion, I would like to say that Bosnia and Herzegovina is an extremely complex country and we must weigh all our recommendations very carefully.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing.- According to the report, there are still 84,500 internally displaced persons, as well as a huge number of refugees from Bosnia and Herzegovina in neighboring countries, across Europe and around the world.A situation that must be present in the challenges and progress made by the country towards future accession.Strong political support is an essential factor in making the country's institutional framework more effective and, therefore, the authorities must demonstrate their determination regarding the pursuit of institutional, economic and social reforms.One aspect that Bosnian political power must not neglect is the important role of civil society in consolidating peace and reconciliation and the participation of young people in intercultural dialogue and exchange.The significant contributions of cultural activists, artists, writers and academics are important for promoting dialogue and understanding between different groups in society.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The report replicates the usual set of considerations on EU integration processes, in this case referring to Bosnia and Herzegovina. It identifies conditions for accession, in a posture of clear interference and disrespect for the sovereignty of countries and peoples applying for EU membership, insisting on the implementation of structural reforms, in particular on issues such as justice, public administration, the electoral system, economic governance , or combating corruption and organized crime. The report calls for aligning that country's positions with those of the EU, in particular with foreign and border policies, as well as with security and defense policies. We consider the unreasonable stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts regarding the country's integration are exposed. People have a legitimate right to decide on their future and to choose freely and sovereignly whether or not they want to join the EU, as well as to decide on their respective economic and social development strategies. The EU has no right to impose policies that are contrary to peoples' interests and desires. We voted against.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I would be critical of the reform process which is linked to privatisation and liberalisation and ignores the social problems linked to this process. I reject the recommendations on foreign and security policy. I voted against.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- I welcome Bosnia and Herzegovina's application for membership of the European Union, as negotiations have been stuck in a stalemate for some time, and I therefore appreciate that positive progress has been made, but this should not stop the necessary reforms to help the countryto the European Union.The European Union must make a clear commitment to Bosnia and Herzegovina's European perspective.The application for membership of the European Union represents an opportunity for Bosnia and Herzegovina to unite around a common goal and thus start a long-term process that will require many reforms and commitments, so political leaders must respond promptly and constructively.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I am voting against as I am not in favor of new and immediate enlargements of the European Union.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing. - This text is an insult to democracy, as it characterizes the referendum as a challenge for cohesion. At the same time, it fails to recognize the historical, religious and cultural institutions that unite the Serbs with the Russians, asking the former to reject their history. In general, the whole text is characterized by anti-Serbian sentiments. Most notable is the fact that it accuses the Republika Srpska of alleged practices it pursues, while when they themselves - on a larger scale - are implemented by Turkey, Parliament avoids pointing it out. That is why I am voting against the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the presentation of an EU membership application by Bosnia and Herzegovina. After a long period of stalemate, there is some positive progress and I therefore encourage the country and its political leadership to intensify the reform efforts with a view to making the state more efficiently functional on its way towards the EU. The EU has to be unequivocally committed to the European perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina, stressing the need for the country to implement the Stabilisation and Association Agreement to make the EU membership application a success. The EU membership application of Bosnia and Herzegovina presents a unique opportunity for the country to unify around a common goal. The political leaders of the country need to work together constructively to respond to and fulfil the European aspirations of all Bosnia and Herzegovina citizens.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing.- I supported Parliament's motion for a resolution on the 2015 Country Report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.The stability of the Western Balkans is a strategic issue, and Bosnia is key in this regard.I welcome the new approach of the EU in order for the country to achieve further results towards EU accession.The cornerstone of this is the entry into force of the Stabilization and Association Agreement in 2015.The EU must be committed to Bosnia and Herzegovina's European perspective, but it is a bilateral process and the Bosnian administration must also be willing.Constitutional and political reforms to transform Bosnia and Herzegovina into an effective and fully functioning state in line with European standards need to be pursued.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report considering that Bosnia and Herzegovina must work to solve the prolonged political deadlock, which represents a serious impediment to the stabilization and development of the country.In the same way, it must commit to carry out the institutional, economic and social reforms necessary to improve the living conditions of the country's citizens and advance on the path towards EU membership.The fight against organized crime and corruption is essential.There is no doubt that addressing the socio-economic needs of citizens should be the priority for the authorities.Bosnia and Herzegovina has a long way to go in its process of becoming part of the EU, but from the European Parliament and the rest of the EU institutions we must support the country in the necessary reform program.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution presented following statements by the Council and the Commission under Rule 123 of the Regulation on the 2015 BiH report because I firmly believe in the need to integrate the Balkan country into the European context. Bosnia and Herzegovina is currently a potential candidate for membership of the European Union and in order to guarantee full status as a candidate country it is necessary to insist on the path of constitutional, legal and political reforms. Despite slight improvements, however, numerous critical issues remain, such as social, religious and political tensions within the Bosnian community that certainly do not help the process of reconciliation of society after the dramatic civil war in the 1990s. Corruption at all levels also continues to be a matter of great concern, first of all due to its degree of diffusion, even in senior offices, and the weakness of the legal framework is manifested in the politicization of the appointments of magistrates. Finally, I note the need to strengthen the institutional framework for the protection and respect of human rights and the principles of democracy, to guarantee freedom of expression and religious belief and to protect the rights of disabled people, ethnic minorities and LGBTI people. .

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- For years there has been a large majority in the population of Bosnia and Herzegovina for EU membership.Further reforms in the areas of rule of law, the economy, the fight against corruption and social policy are necessary to achieve this goal.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We voted to abstain on this resolution, because despite having positive parts it continues to insist on the need for the EU to interfere in Bosnian politics, for example condemning the consultation of the people of the Republika Srbska on their sovereignty.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- We do not oppose the will of Bosnia and Herzegovina for a closer relationship with the EU and ultimately accession to the Union.However, we disagree with the economic policies promoted by the EU in the country, with the privatization processes, etc. It is for these reasons that we abstained in this report.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. The continuation of the country's legal and socio-economic reforms is undoubtedly a key element for progress towards integration with the European Union. However, I believe that such changes cannot be fully achieved without an effective fight against corruption, the high level of which is worrying. In this context, it is necessary to create structures to prevent corruption, as well as to increase the effectiveness of its prosecution and conviction of the guilty with final court sentences. I also consider it extremely important to intensify activities in the area of ​​creating and promoting a tolerant and inclusive society, as well as ensuring the sustainability of the reconciliation process after the war. In this respect, education that supports unity and mutual understanding is undoubtedly important. There should also be more emphasis on the return of IDPs and refugees, a large number of whom still have not returned to their pre-war homes.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ I would like to congratulate Bosnia and Herzegovina on its progress in the last year. I hope this positive effort will continue with the country’s EU membership application.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the motion for a resolution tabled following statements by the Council and the Commission pursuant to Rule 123 (2) of the Rules of Procedure on the 2015 Report on Bosnia and Herzegovina in view of the progress made towards European integration processes and the unequivocal commitment European perspective of BiH. The application for EU membership submitted by BiH on 15 February 2016 is welcomed, and I expect that the European institutions will act quickly on this application. In this regard, it is important that the BiH Council of Ministers adopted a decision on 26 January 2016 on the establishment of a coordination mechanism for EU issues. Constitutional, legal and political reforms that would transform BiH into a fully effective and functional state need to be pursued. BiH still has major problems with corruption, judicial problems, economic problems and high unemployment, especially permanent unemployment and youth unemployment. In BiH, there is still insufficient cooperation between the government and the NGO sector, and the legal and institutional framework for respect for human rights needs to be improved. I support the Commission's decision to approve the export of milk and dairy products from BiH to the EU, as well as BiH's participation in the EU's Erasmus program. I believe that even greater support from European institutions is needed for BiH's European path.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- This text is a righteous interference in Serbian affairs which intends to conform them to the vision of the Union.Consequently, I voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Marc JOULAUD
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the 2015 report by my colleague Cristian Dan Preda on Bosnia and Herzegovina.With a view to the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina, a coordination mechanism is essential in order to ensure better interaction with the Union.However, corruption is still a widespread phenomenon.We must also insist on the independence of the media and the holding of free and autonomous elections.This resolution was adopted by a large majority, which I welcome.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which assesses each year the progress made by candidate and potential candidate countries.While the report highlights the progress made by Bosnia and Herzegovina in recent months, it is concerned about widespread corruption in the country.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I am voting against the resolution.Not only are many important points ignored, the wrong conclusions are drawn from them and measures are demanded that mean massive cuts in the sovereignty of the country.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: In written form. - For 21 years since the signing of the Dayton Peace Agreement, we have witnessed Bosnia and Herzegovina swinging in its democracy and finding it difficult to make progress on its path to the European Union. The country's complex ethno-religious composition continues to be a major focus of political opposition and a major obstacle to finding consensus on the reform agenda. Although the European Union has adopted a new approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina, according to which the Stabilization and Association Agreement entered into force on 1 June 2015, the country's authorities must continue to show determination in implementing institutional and socio-economic reforms. An approving step in this regard is the application for membership of the European Union and the Commission's first positive report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. That is why I believe that the country must make the best use of this opportunity. I believe that the European Union is the only actor that can give the necessary impetus to development. Now is the time for political and religious leaders to refrain from divisive nationalist rhetoric that polarizes society. Political dialogue must continue and the government must clearly demonstrate its willingness to put the country's citizens at the center of reforms.

name: Marine LE PEN
text: in writing.- I voted against the report on Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is in line with that country's accession to the European Union.The idea of the systematic enlargement of the European Union is contrary to the interests of European nations.It is overwhelmingly rejected by the French and other European peoples.This is why we must put an end to this process.The anti-Serbian content of the text is not to make it more acceptable.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it supports Bosnia's "European perspective".However, I am opposed in principle to any new EU membership.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - This is a triumphalist report that does not correspond to the reality of the country. In the report there is no recognition of the citizen protests of 2014, which germinated the seeds of authentic political and social change in the country and its modernization. You keep trying to work with a broken country and society. And we must not forget that it has been the EU itself that has contributed to Bosnia being a country of small local chieftains. Western powers preferred ethnic sectarianism over respecting the will of the people. In 2014 they had a great opportunity to rectify, when Bosnians took to the streets across the country asking to be treated as citizens, and not as numbers in an ethnic census; asking for more jobs and less national pride. This year they still have that opportunity, but the rapporteur is determined to ignore that reality. However, the decision to join the EU is a point of agreement between the Bosnian communities and a will of their institutions, for which I have abstained in the final vote.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- Bosnia and Herzegovina has submitted an official application for EU membership.This event is a clear indicator of BiH's European orientation.It now faces the demanding task of harmonizing national legislation with European legislation.First of all, it is necessary to adopt a Reform Program where the citizens of BiH will be in the focus of social, economic and institutional reforms, and all three nations will be equal.BiH needs an effective mechanism to coordinate all key EU issues.In addition to answering key questions, the mechanism should better align national legislation with Union legislation, its implementation and its successful implementation.Bosnia and Herzegovina needs strong political support for a better institutional structure.It is crucial that BiH continues with legal, political and constitutional reforms that will help formally and democratically shape the state.I supported this report because BiH needs support on the path to full membership.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. - With the first positive report from the European Commission on Bosnia and Herzegovina and the recent presentation of its formal sufficiency to join the European Union, I would like to congratulate Sarajevo on the progress it has made. The fact that there are often huge problems of ethnicity and religion, the sharp fragmentation of the system of government, widespread corruption, the lack of independence of the judiciary, and the country's own negative role as an indirect source of illegal weapons for further proliferation in Europe. Although there is still a long way to go and a number of reforms, I am pleased that the problems of the past are gradually disappearing, albeit often with external assistance, as the peoples of Bosnia and Herzegovina periodically strive to level their differences and work together for a bright future. And the only ones who can really determine the degree of this brightness are the people of Bosnia and Herzegovina themselves, no one else. In addition, I would like to point out that, like Albania, which has already been discussed today, Bosnia and Herzegovina absolutely needs to continue its efforts to improve relations with its neighbors, first and foremost with Serbia. The road to the European Union is not possible without quality long-term regional reconciliation. It is time to put an end to the Balkanisation process!

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted an application for EU membership in February 2016.The country has undergone a complex development, marked by long-standing internal ethnic conflicts that persist.In the process of integration, Bosnia and Herzegovina must continue to implement the political and economic reforms that are a precondition for the country's accession to the European Union.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I oppose the motion for a resolution on the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina, for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech to the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 13/4/2016, and because this report is not completeand documented.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report, which acknowledges the necessary criteria of the accession process. Notably, the report demarcates the need for independent media and the necessity to tackle corruption in order to become a democratic society.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - Bosnia and Herzegovina officially applied for the status of candidate for European integration on February 15th. Since its independence, Bosnia has not managed to overcome its primary challenges: mass unemployment, endemic corruption, partial justice and above all a constitutional and institutional architecture based on the recognition of constituent ethnic groups (Bosnian Muslims, Bosnian Serbs and Croats). As the European Court of Human Rights recently emphasized, it appears particularly problematic not to be able to declare oneself a simple "citizen of Bosnia and Herzegovina" without ethnic affiliation, in order to be able to stand for election. But for Parliament, rapprochement with the European Union and its neoliberal orthodoxy will naturally resolve these problems. Moreover, the United Kingdom and Germany have always pushed to put aside constitutional revisions in favor of European integration and yet another wave of social and fiscal dumping. The concerns of the report thus relate to the absence of a single unified economic zone on the territory, "which harms the business environment". I vote resolutely against it. The country's priority is the political stabilization of its federated entities and not European membership.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- This text is a well-meaning interference in Serbian affairs which intends to conform them to the vision of the European Union.Consequently, I voted against this text.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this resolution as it urges political leaders in Bosnia and Herzegovina to continue along the path of institutional, economic and social reform that will lead to EU membership.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: in writing. - I am delighted to note the democratic advances in Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH), 20 years after the Dayton agreement. The latter should be encouraged to continue its efforts on the path to European integration. Membership of the European Union brings with it the obligation to respect the European values ​​contained in the Copenhagen criteria. One of the most important community achievements is non-discrimination. It is therefore essential for the Bosnian government to apply an inclusive policy, including all its citizens, respecting and promoting the rights of the minorities present in the country. However, much progress remains to be made given the institutional and internal political complexity of the country. In order to initiate a political and democratic stabilization in accordance with the European model, it is necessary for BiH to pursue its development in accordance with the reforms recommended by the Union; in particular on the fight against corruption, social dialogue, human rights, the independence of the judiciary, the fight against terrorism, the social economy, etc.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The Commission presented its 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. The draft resolution of the Committee on Foreign Affairs on this welcomes the submission of Bosnia and Herzegovina's application for EU membership on 15 February 2016. It urges the continuation of constitutional and political reforms that will transform Bosnia and Herzegovina into an effective, inclusive and fully functioning state, ensuring equality and democratic representation for all state-building peoples and citizens, regardless of their ethnic or religious background. It calls on political and religious leaders to refrain from polarizing, nationalist and separatist rhetoric and to pursue political dialogue and activities aimed at building mutual respect, consensus and cooperation between legitimate political representatives, as well as protecting the diversity of society. Expresses its concern at the independent foreign and security policy of the Republika Srpska, which could undermine state policy, and condemns the law in force in the Republika Srpska, which undermines fundamental democratic rights to freedom of assembly, association and the media; . I supported the report of the Committee on Foreign Affairs.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - Since 1999, the European Union has established close relations with the countries of the Western Balkans region within the framework of its Stabilization and Association policy, based on Stabilization and Association Agreements that anticipate the accession processes of the countries in this region, as is the case with the agreement concluded between the European Communities, their Member States and Bosnia and Herzegovina. Bosnia and Herzegovina formalized its application for EU membership in February 2016. The commitment to accession implies the adoption of institutional, economic and social reforms, in order to bring its reality closer to EU standards, namely the approximation of the socio-economic level and respect for the rule of law principles in order to ensure better integration. In this sense, I vote in favor, as I consider the definition of a reform program, as well as its follow-up, crucial for Bosnia and Herzegovina to fulfill the necessary criteria for further integration.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- Bosnia and Herzegovina presented its candidacy for membership of the European Union on February 15, 2016. This resolution welcomes the desire for reform of the authorities of this country, which is illustrated in particular by the implementation of the reform program2015-2018.However, Bosnia still needs to make progress in the rule of law, democracy, anti-corruption and judicial reform before it can join the European Union, which needs to be extremely vigilant.respect for all negotiating chapters before accepting a new enlargement.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the resolution on Bosnia and Herzegovina because it presents a clear picture of the situation in the country.In particular, we recall that membership of the European Union is conditional, that a stable judicial system is necessary, and that fundamental freedoms must be guaranteed.Bosnia and Herzegovina has embarked on the path of reform and its efforts should be commended.Thus the resolution presents a first positive report and I encourage, by supporting this resolution, the pursuit of reforms by the government.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report on Bosnia and Herzegovina that reiterates the need for the authorities to show determination in pursuing institutional and socio-economic reforms with their effective implementation, thus taking steady steps towards an EU integration.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: in writing. ‒ The membership application submitted by Bosnia and Herzegovina in February this year shows that the country is taking important steps towards gaining EU membership. However, for Bosnia and Herzegovina to integrate into the European community as a democratic and functional state, further constitutional, political and legal reform is much needed.  The resolution stresses, amongst other things, that corruption, growing radicalisation amongst youth and the decreasing space of independent media are of particular concern. It further highlights that there are still structural problems causing societal division and preventing integration, the ‘two schools under one roof’ being an example hereof. Therefore, it is as important as ever that the EU continues to encourage reform in Bosnia and Herzegovina, which is essential for fostering societal and political stability in the Western Balkans region. It is for these reasons that I support this resolution.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- Bosnia and Herzegovina is currently confronted with considerable problems in the area of fundamentalist (political) Islam.That is why I think it is fatal to make further promises to the country about EU membership right now.Unfortunately, the report goes in precisely that direction, which is why I refused to approve it.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- With reference to the proposal by my colleague Cristian Dan Preda, I would vote positively.The conclusion of the Stabilization and Association Agreement with Bosnia and Herzegovina, together with the application for membership presented by the Sarajevo government last February, testify to the EU's will to encourage the involvement of Bosnia and Herzegovina from a European perspective.However, this also requires the commitment of the national authorities to implement substantial reforms in the economic, political and legal fields that would allow Bosnia and Herzegovina to comply with the Copenhagen criteria and make the acquis communautaire its own.Therefore, I would vote in favor.

name: Alojz PETERLE
text: in writing.- Bosnia and Herzegovina's application for membership of the European Union expresses the clear ambition of this European country.This is the European Commission's first more favorable report on BiH.The country has made significant progress on a coordination mechanism for issues related to the European Union.Now, however, the implementation that is essential for the credibility of a membership application is crucial.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I welcome the clearly stated position that seeks to guarantee equality and democratic representation of all three constituent peoples in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Unfortunately, Croats are a constituent people only on paper, and their political, civil, social and human rights are systematically violated. I also welcome the position calling on all levels of government in BiH to do everything they can to return displaced persons and refugees by introducing the necessary and implementing all necessary legislative and administrative measures, which I emphasized in one of my amendments. I am particularly pleased that the final text of the resolution includes the text of the amendment I proposed during the debate in the European Parliament's Foreign Policy Committee on the need for a harmonized legal framework for environmental protection and action against climate change, including transboundary pollution caused by oil refineries. Bosanski Brod. I also welcome the part of the report which calls for steps to be taken to guarantee media pluralism and broadcast in all official languages, including Croatian. Croats are the only constituent people in BiH who do not have a program in their language on national television. Finally, I regret that part of the text is not explicitly aimed at condemning hate speech that leads to discrimination against Croats as one of the three constituent peoples.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - I certainly want to commend the work of the rapporteur, Mr Preda. The result is a quality and objective report on BiH's progress in the past year, which was in many ways special for that country. BiH formally concluded the year of progress by submitting its candidacy for full membership. I see this as an important contribution to the much-needed exit from the Dayton to the Brussels phase of that country. The report registers progress, but also lists a number of areas where real results are needed in order for a membership application to be assessed as successful. We expect a final agreement on the establishment of an effective coordination mechanism. The other two key preconditions for progress, the full implementation of the reform agenda and the adaptation of the Stabilization and Association Agreement, have yet to take place. At the same time, it is necessary to prepare work on future political, electoral and constitutional reforms that will shape BiH into a functional, inclusive and efficient state based on the principles of federalism, subsidiarity, equality and equality of all its peoples and citizens. As the head of the EP delegation for relations with BiH, I am sorry for the failure to constitute a joint parliamentary body of the BiH Parliament and the EP. But we could not allow an attempt to transpose into the common rules of procedure provisions that include ethnic census. I hope that at the next meeting we will adopt common rules of procedure and with our work contribute to our common goal - the European future of BiH.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The report replicates the usual set of considerations on EU integration processes, in this case, Bosnia and Herzegovina. The identification of conditions for accession continues, in the form of interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of accession to the EU, insisting on the implementation of structural reforms, in particular on issues such as justice, public administration, the electoral system , economic governance, or combating corruption and organized crime. The alignment of that country's positions with those of the EU is required, namely with foreign and border policy, as well as with security and defense policies. We consider the unreasonable stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts regarding the country's integration are exposed. Peoples are deprived of the legitimate right to decide on their future, which includes the free and sovereign choice of EU membership, but also strategies for economic and social development. So is the EU matrix. One in which the ability to make decisions is distanced from citizens, in order to be able to impose policies that are contrary to their interests and desires. For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - First of all, I would like to unequivocally support the decision of the representatives of Bosnia and Herzegovina to apply for EU membership on 15 February 2016. However, there is still a long way to go to membership. Constitutional, legal and political reforms need to be pursued to make Bosnia and Herzegovina an effective and fully functioning inclusive state, guaranteeing equality and the democratic representation of all its constituent peoples and citizens, regardless of their ethnicity or religion. At the same time, changes need to be made to Bosnia and Herzegovina's electoral law in order to lay the foundations for truly democratic elections that reflect the country's sovereignty. As a Social Democrat, I support the greater involvement of civil society in protecting and promoting the rights of minorities in this country, as well as in strengthening social harmony, tolerance and understanding. I am very pleased that, after a long time, the report for 2015 is optimistic and that the people and statesmen in Bosnia and Herzegovina are directing their country to the European family.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I approved the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.It reports on the progress made by the country and encourages the national authorities to continue on the path of compliance with the fundamental rules of European democracies.However, many aspects still illustrate the notorious differences between this country and the Member States of the European Union, which do not allow considering the accession of Bosnia and Herzegovina to the Union.In this regard, my position is very clear: there will be no enlargement of the Union in the years to come.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-legislative and non-binding report. UKIP is against the further expansion of the EU. The system of annual reports on the progress of candidate and potential candidate countries towards alignment with the acquis communautaire is part of this process. As such we voted against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing.- This report welcomes the submission of Bosnia and Herzegovina's candidacy for EU membership on 15 February 2016. However, it states that it is also necessary to continue the constitutional, legal and political reforms that will transform Bosnia and Herzegovina into a fully effective state,inclusive and functional, guaranteeing equality and democratic representation of all peoples and citizens that comprise it.Furthermore, he stresses that it is important to ensure that all citizens are able to stand for election, to be elected and to perform functions at all political levels, under equal circumstances and regardless of their ethnic or religious origins.It is important to stress that the authorities must actively promote not only the principles of legitimate representation, federalism, decentralization and subsidiarity, but also European values and the importance of the European perspective.I voted in favor.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - This resolution welcomes the submission of the application for EU membership by Bosnia and Herzegovina. After a long period of stagnation, some positive progress has been observed, which encourages the country and its political leadership to intensify reform efforts in order to make Bosnia and Herzegovina an inclusive, effective and functional state. With this resolution, we reiterate the EU's unequivocal commitment to the European perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina, emphasizing the need for the country to implement the Stabilization and Association Agreement and all necessary reforms to make the application for membership the EU is a success. Likewise, political leaders are urged to refrain from the nationalist and secessionist rhetorical division that polarized society, the socio-economic needs of citizens must be the priority. For all this, I support this resolution and Bosnia and Herzegovina's request to join the EU. This opportunity should not be missed. Ensuring a better life for citizens has to be Bosnia and Herzegovina's political priority in the framework of its European integration process.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing.- The text adopted welcomes the first more positive report on Bosnia-Herzegovina and the application for membership of the European Union presented by this country on February 15, 2016. In the text voted on, Parliament is of the opinion that amechanism for effective coordination of Union matters between the different levels of government is essential in order to ensure better interaction with the Union, and at the same time welcomes the fact that the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovinaadopted the decision on a coordination system for the European integration of Bosnia and Herzegovina.I chose to abstain in the final vote on this report.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.This text welcomes the Bosnian voluntarism but nevertheless underlines that Bosnia must continue to implement important reforms.Indeed, it is essential that the Bosnian authorities pursue legal, socio-economic, political and constitutional reforms.It is also regrettable that the country has not brought its Constitution into conformity with judgments handed down by the European Court of Human Rights.The priority for European action in Bosnia and Herzegovina must be the fight against corruption and the independence of the judiciary.Finally, the text also calls for the full implementation of the Stabilization and Association Agreement (SAA).

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We voted to abstain on this resolution, because despite having positive parts it continues to insist on the need for the EU to interfere in Bosnian politics, for example condemning the consultation of the people of the Republika Srbska on their sovereignty.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- I voted against the Resolution on the 2015 Report on Bosnia and Herzegovina as it is mainly aimed at encouraging the integration process of this country into the EU by demanding all kinds of structural socio-economic reforms that imply the reduction of social rights andlabor of the popular classes as well as state public spending.Likewise, the resolution criticizes with a serious interference tone the political and administrative division of Bosnia and Herzegovina and does not respect the inalienable right of all the peoples of the world to self-determination.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ This report on Bosnia and Herzegovina gives a great overview of what improvements the country has made in the last year. I welcome the EU membership application and hope that this will be a positive step towards a better political situation in the country. The long process towards accession will require full commitment and enhanced reforms, both democratic and economic. While corruption and press freedoms are generally improving, as well as their commitment to a freer market, there is still much to do and reports like this remind us that the reform process is long, but also show an optimistic light on the development of a country which was embroiled with such violence only two decades ago.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - I supported the Motion for a Resolution on the Report on Bosnia and Herzegovina for 2015. With the reform program launched on July 1, 2015, BiH has begun to address the difficult socio-economic situation and progress is visible on legal and administrative changes, which is important to start BiH membership in the Union. Cooperation between parliaments at the state, municipal and Brčko District levels needs to be improved. The BiH Constitution needs to be amended because it violates the European Convention on Human Rights and has created a complex mix of institutions whose roles are often questioned. Further reforms are needed regarding the public administration system and the legal system. Measures against corruption have been adopted, but it is necessary to implement the adopted measures, which still do not receive enough political space, which results in a negative impact on citizens and institutions. There is also a need for a stronger fight against organized crime and an improvement in the legal and institutional framework for the protection of human rights in general, and especially for vulnerable groups such as the LGBT community, which is under constant threat and attack. In line with European standards, BiH is at a very early stage. More financial control is needed, the 2013 census is processed, the conditions for small and medium-sized enterprises, agriculture, energy, climate change policy and information and media are improved.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted an application for EU membership on 15 February 2016, so the country's representatives have a simple task ahead of them, so that the country can make progress in the EU integration process. Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to show determination to pursue institutional and socio-economic reforms, including their effective implementation, as well as to make steady progress in the EU integration process. Constitutional and political reforms need to be pursued, transforming Bosnia and Herzegovina into an effective, inclusive and fully functioning state, while guaranteeing equality and democratic representation of all its state-building nations and citizens, regardless of ethnicity or religion. Civil society must play an important role in this, in particular involving young people in intercultural dialogue as well as in the political sphere. Corruption, including high-level corruption, is a major problem today. It is important for Bosnia and Herzegovina to have a functioning and stable judiciary, political interference in judicial proceedings, the politicization of judicial appointment procedures, as well as the absence and objective system for assessing the professional qualifications of judges are inadmissible. Bosnia and Herzegovina also faces other challenges, including the adoption of national sectoral strategies in the areas of transport, energy and the environment.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - BiH is a country facing many difficulties and problems: corruption, organized crime, lack of freedom of the media and expression. High unemployment and poor economic situation in the country, which in turn leads to a brain drain, as educated people do not get jobs and are thus forced to look for opportunities abroad. On a positive note, BiH submitted a formal application for EU membership in February this year. I believe that despite the difficulties, with the encouragement and help of the EU, the situation in BiH can improve and improve. However, we must not let them down here, but offer them a helping hand. In certain respects, I am not satisfied with the text of the resolution. I find it most problematic to emphasize and call for the strengthening of the ethnic principle in a country that is already too divided and fragmented. No distinction should be made between the constituent peoples and other citizens of BiH. This seems to me to be contradictory to the judgments in Sejdić-Finci and Zornić, adopted by the European Court of Human Rights. I believe that the BiH institutions must take on the duty of resolving this issue, while standing by and supporting the European institutions, which is certainly not possible if the ethnic approach is supported. As I find this topic very problematic, I did not support the resolution and voted against its adoption.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- The European Parliament is determined to support Bosnia and Herzegovina on its path to Europe and calls on the country to continue on its path of reform.He considers constitutional, legal and political reforms and making steady progress in the integration process, as well as the fight against corruption, to be the most important.However, the proposed referendum in the Republika Srpska on the national judicial system of Bosnia and Herzegovina, which, according to MEPs, calls into question the cohesion, sovereignty and integrity of the country, is worrying.

name: Davor Ivo STIER
text: written. - EU accession is a comprehensive process that requires consensus on a Reform Program in which BiH citizens must be at the center of institutional, economic and social reforms. The EU has initiated a new approach to BiH in order for the country to move towards the EU and face exceptional socio-economic and rule of law challenges, enabling it to prepare for future membership, and in line with that approach, the Stabilization and Association Agreement entered into force on 1 June 2015. I would stress the importance of the role of civil society at the local level in the process of building peace and reconciliation, and in particular the participation of young people in intercultural dialogue and exchange, as well as in politics. I express my deep concern over the statements of the Minister of Internal Affairs of the Republika Srpska on the future training of special police units of the Republika Srpska in the Russian Federation and on the deepening of cooperation, especially regarding the exchange of information and the intention to purchase Russian military equipment. The electoral law and the electoral system must provide an opportunity for all three constituent peoples and all other citizens to freely and autonomously elect their legitimate political representatives of the institutions and authorities.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written. - On 1 June 2015, Bosnia and Herzegovina signed a Stabilization and Association Agreement with the European Communities and their Member States. After numerous positive developments towards the European Union, on February 15, 2016, BiH submitted its Application for EU Accession and thus received the status of a potential candidate. There are several major problems, including judicial reform and constitutional reform, that must be implemented in full for a candidacy to be assessed positively. Likewise, there are various political pressures on the media, the problem of freedom of speech and corruption, which is key to a successful democracy. I support the Motion for a Resolution on the 2015 Report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. I believe that the rapprochement of Bosnia and Herzegovina with the EU guarantees the cohesion and functionality of the country, ensures stability and prevents disintegration trends. In the foreseeable future, it is necessary to embark on a constitutional reform that will guarantee the equality of the constituent peoples, especially the Croats as the smallest. I believe that through negotiations with the European Commission, BiH should ensure the adjustment of the Stabilization and Association Agreement in order to maintain the traditional trade between Croatia and BiH.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on Bosnia and Herzegovina for 2015. The text is balanced and well reflects the situation in the country, especially as regards the issue of reforms and resolving outstanding issues on the way to the European Union.In recent years, Bosnia and Herzegovina has already adopted some important legislative amendments and some strategies, so reforms must continue if they are to take a step towards the EU.A big problem is youth unemployment, where Bosnia and Herzegovina needs to take more decisive steps.Many challenges still await this country, but it is well on its way.

name: Pavel SVOBODA
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina, which welcomes Bosnia and Herzegovina's first more positive evaluation report and its application for EU membership, submitted on 15 February 2016. The report rightly points out that the first premiseAnother positive development is the internal stability and the establishment of functional bodies reflecting the administrative and ethnic division of the country.Here, the European Parliament calls on those responsible for Bosnia and Herzegovina to move towards this goal.Only in this way is it possible to continue working to improve the judiciary, to fight organized crime and corruption, which are objectives whose fulfillment is a primary condition for possible future EU membership.

name: Tibor SZANYI
