text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report, also appreciating the good news for reviving EU enlargement policy, including the dynamisation of the accession process in the Western Balkans: for the first time in a long time, the Commission has given a fundamentally positive assessment of democratization and reform processes in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and as a result, the country submitted its formal application for EU membership two months ago. In assessing the report and the developments in Bosnia and Herzegovina, I have also borne in mind that it is also in the Union's interest to promote the integration capacity of our most difficult political and historical partner in the Western Balkans, to speed up the accession process and catch up with other countries in the region. The report is a good reflection of the EP's traditionally supportive, constructive attitude. I hope that the European Parliament's resolution will also be suitable for drawing the attention of the Commission's officials: the management of Bosnia's accession dossier, the hoped-for success of the preparations, will also be an important test for regaining the credibility of EU enlargement policy.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. ‒ This resolution notes some positive progress and encourages Bosnia and Herzegovina and its political leadership to intensify the reform efforts with a view to making the state more efficiently functional on its way towards the EU.  The European Parliament welcomes the presentation of an EU membership application by Bosnia and Herzegovina, which presents a unique opportunity for the country to unify around a common goal. This is the beginning of an important process that will require commitment and enhanced reform efforts. The political leaders of the country need to work together constructively to respond to and fulfil the EU aspirations of all Bosnia and Herzegovina citizens. The EU strategy, and especially this resolution, presents a unique opportunity for the politicians and all citizens of the country to leave aside the divisions along national lines and work together for a common future within the EU. I support the adoption of this report.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing.- With this resolution, the European Parliament wanted to welcome the Commission's first more positive report on Bosnia and Herzegovina and reiterates its unequivocal attachment to the European perspective of Bosnia and Herzegovina.We invite the authorities to show their determination to pursue institutional and socio-economic reforms, including their effective implementation, and to make steady progress towards the Union.We also call for transparency in the process of planning and implementing reforms in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Bosnia and Herzegovina has made efforts recently and it is now back on the path towards European integration. I welcome its efforts and the submission of its application for EU membership. This is why I voted in favour of this report.  However, the country will still need to make significant reforms to make this application successful. The areas that need most improvement are the full implementation and respect for the rule of law, the fight against corruption, and the resolution of socio-economic challenges. Moreover, reforming the public administration and getting public institutions to function efficiently in favour of the citizens remain a priority. A major focus should also be set on security, and combatting the phenomenon of returning foreign fighters.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing. - I would support the report on Bosnia and Herzegovina for 2015 if I voted. Accession to the EU is an inclusive process that requires consensus on a reform agenda. The citizens of Bosnia and Herzegovina must be at the heart of institutional, economic and social reforms. The EU has launched a new approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to move towards the EU and address open social, economic and rule of law challenges, enabling that country to prepare for future membership. In line with this approach, the Stabilization and Association Agreement entered into force on 1 June 2015. An effective mechanism is needed to coordinate European affairs between the various levels of government in order to ensure better interaction with the EU and to facilitate the coordination, implementation and enforcement of EU law, as well as to grant Bosnia and Herzegovina's application for EU membership. On 26 January 2016, the Council of Ministers of Bosnia and Herzegovina adopted a decision on the coordination system in the process of European integration in Bosnia and Herzegovina. Progress in this area will enable it to make good use of EU funding.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We voted to abstain on this resolution, because despite having positive parts it continues to insist on the need for the EU to interfere in Bosnian politics, for example condemning the consultation of the people of the Republika Srbska on their sovereignty.

name: István UJHELYI
text: in writing.- The EU remains committed to Bosnia and Herzegovina's European perspective, territorial integrity, sovereignty and unity.The EU has launched a new approach to Bosnia and Herzegovina in order to make further progress towards EU accession and meet the remaining socio-economic and rule of law challenges, thus enabling the country to prepare for future EU membership.Following this approach, the Stabilization and Association Agreement entered into force on 1 June 2015.By my vote, I supported the position of the S&D Group.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We voted to abstain on this resolution, because despite having positive parts it continues to insist on the need for the EU to interfere in Bosnian politics, for example condemning the consultation of the people of the Republika Srbska on their sovereignty.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the resolution on the 2015 Report on Bosnia and Herzegovina. The country submitted its formal application for EU membership on 15 February 2016 and the European Parliament strongly backed its European aspirations with this resolution, in particular calling on the Council to examine its membership application as early as possible. The authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina will nevertheless have to continue constitutional, legal and political reforms, as rampant corruption and increased pressure on the judiciary by political players remain issues of serious concern.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- Through this report, Parliament welcomes the fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted the application to access the EU on February 15, 2016. It also highlights the need to carry out reforms to have a functional and stable judiciary that ensures complianceof the laws and fight more decisively against corruption, as well as carry out reforms in the electoral system that favor the representativeness of all the citizens of the country.Ultimately, we are talking about a complete report that deals with the issues that are on the table in relation to this country.Therefore, I consider it necessary to vote in their favor.

name: Derek VAUGHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report. It was very positive to see Bosnia’s formal submission of an EU membership application; this is a vital step on the road to further reform and the piecing together of a nation and society that has suffered far too much in the Yugoslav wars. While those scars will always be there, it is important to recognise that Bosnia-Herzegovina has come a long way since the end of the war in 1995, and we must maintain this very positive momentum going forward to ensure that Bosnia sees full and proper reform of both government and civil society.  It is important that the path towards EU membership is a broad and inclusive process for the whole of society providing opportunities for Bosnians. It also represents a vital opportunity to build the spirit of amity in the Balkans. Where before there was only recrimination and violence there are now the first beginnings of accord and perhaps even understanding. We look forward to a year of significant reforms in Bosnia-Herzegovina for the benefit of all Bosnians.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted for this report.This report highlights positive progress and encourages Bosnia and Herzegovina, together with its political leaders, to further intensify reform plans.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - This motion for a resolution weaves a wide range of recitals on the process of Bosnia and Herzegovina's integration into the EU. Beyond the evaluation of the process, it points to a wide range of constraints towards accession, which confirm the extent of interference and loss of sovereignty imposed on countries and peoples in the process of accession to the EU, in particular on issues such as justice, the country's internal and political organization, the imposition of reforms such as the Growth and Employment Pact - and we know well what is behind these aggression pacts - the requirement to align that country's positions with those of the EU. We consider the manorial stance with which the recitals and conditions required to satisfy the precepts regarding the integration of the country are unacceptable, depriving people of the legitimate right to decide their future, where the free and sovereign choice of EU membership is inscribed, but also economic and social development strategies. For these reasons, we voted against.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- As the report does not deal with the problems that prevail in Bosnia and Herzegovina, I voted against this report.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.The report highlights the positive progress made by the country and encourages the government to step up reforms.I strongly support Bosnia and Herzegovina's start of accession negotiations, which represents a unique opportunity for the country to be united under a common goal.Despite this, the negotiation process will be long and will require a sustained effort to implement the necessary reforms.For this reason, the country's political leaders must work together constructively to meet Europe's requirements.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written.- I did not vote in favor of the European Parliament resolution on the 2015 report on Bosnia and Herzegovina.I am against enlarging the EU to include more member states.The EU has such a large number of internal problems that must be resolved before it can accept new members.So far the EU has taken the path of deepening and enlargement at the same time.However, this has proven to be a dead end.The resulting problems are proving to be a burden for European cooperation.First, the EU must be fundamentally reformed before even remotely thinking about enlargement.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ I welcome the country’s formal submission of an EU membership application. Bosnia-Herzegovina has come a long way since the end of the war in 1995 with its terrible legacy of ethnic violence, and so we must keep this positive momentum alive. It is important that the path towards EU membership is a broad and inclusive process for the whole of society. I look forward to a year of significant reforms in Bosnia-Herzegovina for the benefit of all Bosnians and in particular the country’s youth.  As a member of the delegation for relations with Bosnia and Herzegovina, I have made a commitment to developing a deep relationship with grassroots civil society organisations and, in particular, young people. I have made several visits to the country in order to get to know and build long-lasting trusting relationships with young people, who I believe hold the future of this country in their hands: they must not be let down. I believe that the EU must, in its relations with third countries, encourage and allow people-to-people contacts and give more consideration to the power of civil society. I have been particularly supportive of an EU-funded arts and democracy project, The Complete Freedom of Truth, which won the European Citizens Award last year.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing. - I have chosen to support this European Parliament report. I welcome the fact that Bosnia and Herzegovina applied for EU membership on 15 February 2016. However, I am aware of the need to pursue the constitutional, legal and political reforms that will make Bosnia and Herzegovina a functioning state guaranteeing the equality and democratic representation of all its constituent nations and citizens, regardless of their ethnicity or religion. I believe that it is also necessary to establish a fully functioning and stable judiciary, which is of the utmost importance to ensure the rule of law in the country and its further progress towards the EU. Personally, I welcome Bosnia and Herzegovina's active involvement in the Education and Training Platform in the Western Balkans and its continued participation in the Erasmus + program, which is very important in combating the country's very high youth unemployment.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- I supported the report on Bosnia and Herzegovina for 2015. I am pleased that Bosnia and Herzegovina has applied for EU membership.I want BiH to successfully pursue constitutional and political reforms, to transform itself into a modern and efficient state.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- The EU is moving further and further away from the fight against poverty target set by the Europe 2020 strategy and the report as a whole presents positive aspects for achieving this target for fighting poverty in the light of the increase in household spending.I agree that the way forward is to reduce the main expenses incurred by poor families for private consumption, directing existing projects in the field of renewable energy sources and energy efficiency towards families exposed to energy precariousness.I am in favor of introducing a minimum income to guarantee a decent life for all European citizens and also of recognizing the right to safe and clean water as a fundamental right.That said, I would have voted in favor of the text.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written.- The report supports the basic elements with which to develop a global plan to fight poverty: guaranteeing access to basic services (energy, water, health, education, housing…) in the face of the predatory logic of the market;the improvement of working and salary conditions on which the well-being of the working majority depends and a system of minimum income that complements social protection to guarantee, in an individualized and effective way, a decent income and life.Consequently, I have voted in favor.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: in writing.- This report, which aims to meet the objective of combating poverty, is part of the Europe 2020 strategy which plans to lift 20 million people out of poverty by that date.Two main axes are thus described: to encourage the increase in the incomes of poor households as well as to reduce expenditure, in particular through a better allocation of European funds.I opposed this text because in the field of the fight against poverty, measures such as the minimum wage or the tax shift clearly fall within the competence of the Member States.In addition, common European aid would be ineffective because the "type" of poverty varies from country to country.The only possible response is a targeted response from each Member State on its territory.Finally, the migration crisis and the stagnation of the economic crisis are evils that no European initiative manages to control.

name: Nikos ANDROULAKIS
text: S & amp; D), in writing. This report refers to the levels of poverty in the Union, which are unacceptably high and are directly linked to austerity policies and the economic crisis. The Commission and the Member States are called upon to make more efforts to tackle poverty, such as setting up a European Energy Observatory, suspending heating for households in dire financial straits and forecasting a minimum income of over 60% of the national average. income of all Member States. For the above reasons, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I sympathise with the aims of this report, I felt that I had little option but to vote against a report which considers that such matters are best dealt with by the European Union, further integration and legislation at an inappropriate level.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which aims to meet the poverty reduction objective of the Europe 2020 strategy. The establishment of a harmonization of social standards will enable the Union to increase integration into thehigher level and help reduce the inequalities that have widened since the onset of the crisis.

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this proposal, which aims to help reduce heating costs for poor families. 2008-2013 The number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU has risen from 117 to 122.6 million. In addition, 10 percent. EU citizens in 2015 had not paid the full amount of the utility bills (37% in the worst performing Member State), 12% EU citizens in 2014 were unable to heat their homes sufficiently (60% in the worst-performing Member State), 16% EU population in 2014 lived in a house with a pitched roof and wet walls (33% in the worst-off Member State). EU countries must sign a moratorium on disconnection of heating during the winter, which would prevent any household from cutting off its energy supply during the winter. To combat poverty, the proposal calls for increased support for poor families and investment in energy efficiency projects that can reduce heating bills. I agree that the EU is moving away from 2020. the goal of reducing the number of poor people in the EU by at least 20 million For its part, the European Commission must assess whether minimum income schemes can meet the basic needs of households. 2008-2013 The number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU has risen from 117 to 122.6 million.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. It called for the EU to create a definition for ‘energy poverty’, calls for investigating the possibility of an EU wide minimum income, wants an EU pillar of social rights and use of various EU funds. While UKIP supports more action to help those suffering poverty, it should be done by our own accountable national government, not by unelected bureaucrats in Brussels. If we left the EU we would have more money to help solve these problems and not be constrained by EU legislation which is making the situation worse.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- This report, designed as part of the Europe 2020 strategy, which plans to lift 20 million people out of poverty by 2020, focuses on family poverty in a context of rising costs of housing,'' energy and education, with the project of promoting an increase in the incomes of poor households by setting up a minimum wage and of promoting the reduction of their expenditure by establishing a tax shift targetingindustries with high energy density or subsidies granted by European funds.In addition to the infringements of the powers of sovereign states represented by such fiscal measures, they are inappropriate in that the types of poverty vary from state to state.The best solution remains a targeted intervention by each Member State and that is why I voted against this report.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I have of course supported this resolution which calls on the Commission and the Member States to invest fully in the fight against poverty and social exclusion and to adopt an integrated approach to fight against the various forms of poverty by means ofglobal approach bringing together economic policies, education policies, employment policies, energy policies, transport policies and social policies on the basis of best practices.The fight against poverty must obviously be among our top priorities when we know that more than 120 million Europeans are currently affected by this precarious situation, which is further accentuated by the austerity policies deployed in Europe following theliberal and banking crisis of 2008.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - The outbreak of the international economic crisis has strongly affected the economic and social conditions of European families. The decline in incomes, the rise in unemployment and the increase in the prices of basic goods and services have been the origin of a downward movement that has brought an impressive number of citizens to the social risk bracket: 122.6 million . The Europe 2020 strategy, approved by the Union, had set itself the strategic objective of reducing by 20 million, by 2020, the number of people living in conditions of poverty and social exclusion on our continent, but this requires being adapted to new conditions. Extraordinary action is needed by the Commission and the Member States to put in place all the measures necessary to address the scale of the problem. The development of new housing policies, more effective energy policies, the introduction of sustainable pension systems and minimum income systems can be adequate tools to combat a challenge of this magnitude. Although due to a technical problem with registration I was unable to cast my vote, I nevertheless communicated my intention to support the Meszerics report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written. - We voted in favor of this report as it focuses on analyzing household spending and the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which aims to reduce by 20 million people at risk of social exclusion. The Report has incorporated four aspects, two included in its general recommendations, which are very positive. In the first place, references to the need to increase investment in renewable energies and energy efficiency to tackle poverty are interesting insofar as they are linked to employment policies, energy transition, quality and affordable housing and reduction of health spending. Second, the text makes references to an adequate minimum income above the poverty line, which represents 60% of the average national income in all Member States. Thirdly, a call for better use, dissemination and information on European funds as well as extension beyond 2020 to FEAD is remarkable and positive. Finally, the reference to a moratorium on heating cuts in winter to ensure that no home is left without supply, is essential to tip our vote in favor.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing.- The Europe 2020 strategy plans to lift 20 million people out of poverty by 2020. In order to get closer to this objective, certain actions are being considered at European level.This text focuses in particular on the poverty of families in the context of the increase in the cost of housing, energy, and education.Unfortunately, even if the objective is laudable, the means and methods are not at all adapted to the situation.A European approach to the situation is already not possible and, likewise, nothing is mentioned about the crisis and the austerity policy in Europe or even about the arrival of migrants.The use of European funds has only a limited impact on the policies undertaken by the Member States and proposals such as the minimum wage or tax harmonization must be the responsibility of the States and not of the European Union.For all these reasons, I voted against.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- 22 million unemployed, of which 17 in the Eurozone, 5 million new poor and nearly 22 million families who are struggling to heat their homes.If in 2010 the Commission had expected to be able to solve the problem of poverty in five years, the data instead speak of an increase in the number of European citizens in difficulty.While presenting some positive elements, the report as a whole points to the same recipe that created them, the EU, as an antidote to the present problems.For all these reasons it is necessary not to support the text, with a vote of abstention.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report in order to combat energy poverty and reduce household spending. It should be noted that the European Union is moving away from the Europe 2020 poverty target, although the EU has a corresponding unrealized potential to reduce the high consumption costs of poor households by targeting existing renewable energy and energy efficiency projects to energy-poor households. realize the ambition of the Europe 2020 strategy and also the ambitions of energy efficiency, emissions and renewable energy sources. Various actors are encouraged to take further action through various means, but in the same direction. The Commission communication is a first step towards a European pillar of social rights in order to strengthen the European social dimension through an integrated approach, modernizing existing legislation and considering new instruments to support greater coherence over time. More social commitment from the EU is a long-standing unfulfilled political promise, and by creating a minimum income system and further improving social and labor rights and anti-discrimination legislation, the EU can seek to move to the next level of integration. Increasing the income of poor households is one of the key aspects of a successful Europe 2020 strategy and the fight against poverty, for the following two reasons. Inequality in the EU has been growing since the crisis began and one in six EU citizens still live in poverty or are at risk of experiencing it.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - The report finds that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States, blaming high overhead costs for the fight against poverty. Hungary is among these countries, thanks to the success of the overhead reduction, so it is gratifying that the report calls for an exchange of best practices between EU countries. The report also calls on the European Commission to give Member States more flexibility in the use of European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can better target EU funds to reduce energy poverty or improve housing. The report also calls on Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, such as insulation, solar energy and energy-efficient equipment. In accordance with the People's Party, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I supported the European Parliament's motion for a resolution on achieving the goal of reducing poverty in the face of rising household costs.Central to the report is research on how energy policy and consumer prices affect poverty, especially among disadvantaged groups.The report informs us of the priorities in finding the best possible ways to solve the financial problems of households facing poverty and proposes that certain measures be taken to combat it.

name: Renata BRIANO
text: in writing. - Over the last few years, thanks to the economic crisis that began in 2008, the number of European citizens at risk of poverty and those who suffer situations of significant material deprivation has been worrying and constantly increasing, a phenomenon that puts the achievement of the ambitious target set under the Horizon 2020 strategy of lifting 20 million people out of poverty. In order to respond adequately to this crisis situation and to ensure that the Commission's intention to adopt a "triple social A" does not remain a dead letter, the debate on the possible adoption of a framework directive on the introduction of a adequate minimum income above the poverty line, as well as about the introduction of new forms of taxation of large energy-intensive industries in order to find new resources to finance more incisive measures to combat poverty, while at the same time discouraging phenomena of inefficiency energy. With this in mind, particular attention should also be paid to people, often elderly or young, who find themselves in a precarious situation, promoting, for example, as the draft resolution in question proposes, a moratorium against cutting heating in the months winter, facilitating the use of cross-financing mechanisms between the various European funds.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- This report, which is part of the Europe 2020 strategy, plans to lift 20 million people out of poverty by 2020. Two main areas are described therein: promoting an increase in the income of poor households and reducing expenditure, in particular thanks to a better allocation of European funds.I opposed this text because a common European approach to the fight against poverty is inappropriate, so great are the macroeconomic differences between the Member States.The only adequate solution to this scourge is a targeted response from each national government in its territory.The migratory crisis and the stagnation of the economic crisis are moreover evils that no European initiative manages to control.That is why I voted against this report.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up. - The recent economic stagnation and declining competitiveness of national economies have meant a sharp decline in consumption and a visible increase in spending, which in turn has led to rising poverty levels. Although the global economy is in the process of recovering from the financial crisis, the IMF's economic growth forecasts for 2016 remain reserved, with an annual rate of only 3.4%. The global economy is experiencing a very slow growth rate for a long time to come, and international trade is facing many obstacles due to delays in finalizing international trade agreements. The fight against poverty at EU level must have the sustained support of all Member States, so that through the implementation of coordinated measures a minimum income above the poverty line can be established to counteract the long-term negative effects. I believe that we must give particular priority to circumstantial issues that lead to an increase in poverty and, implicitly, social exclusion. I spoke in favor of this resolution because I am convinced that, through firm and immediate action, we can make a concrete contribution to counteracting the phenomenon of poverty.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing. - I abstained. 5 million new poor, 22 million unemployed of which 17 belong to the eurozone: these are figures that alone eloquently describe the tragedy of many European citizens, summing up the failure of the "Europe" project and all its strategies of mere propaganda. The text, insisting on welfare measures, to be introduced always and above all for the benefit of vulnerable categories according to the community dogma, that is, not all citizens, but only Roma, refugees, migrants, etc., invokes as a paradoxical solution to resolve those hardships that the EU itself has created the usual recipe of "more Europe", even hoping for a greater mandatory involvement of the EU in the social policies of the eurozone countries. The fight against poverty, understood as the eradication of a chronic and structural problem that heavily affects the future of the new generations, many of which are already "lost", mainly involves economic intervention capable of positively impacting the medium and long term. This is why we need measures to increase the labor supply and income from work in the EU, we need to revive the competitiveness of our production system, it is urgent to immediately abandon the euro and to support in every way the rapprochement between training and the labor market. .

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - Today, poverty is the unfortunate reality in which millions of children in European societies live, thus deteriorating their chances for the future. The economic and financial crisis that began in 2008 has affected children and families across Europe, also having an impact on employment and social assistance systems. Increasing spending on housing, food, utilities, transportation, medical expenses or education-related expenses further complicates the situation for families, who, due to declining living standards, are finding it increasingly difficult to cope. Achieving the EU's poverty reduction target will require a combination of all efforts and tools at both EU and national level. Under the Europe 2020 strategy, Member States and the Union are committed to reducing poverty and social exclusion by at least 20 million people over the next decade. In this regard, I believe that by identifying indicators on poverty, complementary national social exclusion targets can be developed for all 28 Member States. A high quality of life of the population should be the goal of social development efforts and should measure social progress.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Report because it represents a qualitative leap for Parliament in the fight against poverty, inequality and social exclusion. This resolution brings together social protection policies, the right to decent housing and the fight against energy poverty, in a compendium of recommendations that update and innovate the positions of the European Parliament in the fight against poverty. After eight years of economic and financial crisis, data on inequality and poverty in Europe have not only not remitted but have worsened, especially in southern countries, such as Spain, where inequality conditions are worse than in any other country of the continent after four years of government of the Popular Party. That is why the need to act with innovative policies is highlighted, such as the moratorium against the disconnection of heating in the winter months, the establishment of a system of minimum income by countries that guarantees a decent income, although in this case the liberal groups and chamber conservatives have nuanced this end.

name: Enrique CALVET CHAMBON
text: written.- In conscience I vote against paragraph 19 of this report because it is grossly out of the very important issue that the proposal wants to combat.Permanently bringing up general ideas that do not point to the realization of the subject, in my opinion they do not help or to focus on the tragedy of poverty or the feminist cause because it trivializes it and makes it a routine leitmotif, I consider myself as a defender ofontological equality between the sexes as the most and it is for wanting to be more efficient also in that fight that I vote against said paragraph.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing.- Today I voted in favor of the report on achieving the goal of combating poverty in the light of the increase in household expenditure because in Europe there are 17 countries that have more than a fifth of their population in the category of the poor, 43 million European citizens, including many children who cannot count on the necessary nourishment every day.I am very concerned by the Commission's assessment that the 2020 poverty target "seems out of reach. Instead, efforts must be made to put in place an integrated EU poverty strategy based on objective indicators and with a timelineto ensure that the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy are met.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report as I support measures to prevent energy poverty in European households. However, there are some principles we should keep in mind, such as that these measures should not be abused. That is why I could not agree with that part of the text declaring a right to receive energy without actually paying for it.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: in writing. - Since 2008, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has gradually increased in most Member States. In 2014, one in four people residing in the EU was at serious risk of poverty, with women, children, young people with low education and migrants among the categories most at risk. The cause of the growth of poverty is undoubtedly the economic crisis and the consequent austerity policies have certainly not helped the already difficult recovery. The commitment of the Member States and the Commission must be unequivocal: we need to intervene with measures to help the most vulnerable families to overcome the moment of difficulty with dignity. It is neither conceivable nor more acceptable that in Europe there are numerous households unable to meet the costs of heating their own accommodation. A social dimension is also needed in energy policy: the Union's fight against destitution and poverty also involves reducing expenditure on energy consumption, which is the most important item in the family budget. Investments for the energy efficiency of housing and social housing and the development of renewable sources must be a priority for the States and the Commission. For these reasons, I voted in favor.

name: Ole CHRISTENSEN
text: in writing.- All households in Europe should have access to heat and energy all year round.We as Social Democrats agree with this. However, how access to heat and energy for households is financed is a national matter, since the formulation of social policy is generally a Member State competence under the Treaty.Therefore, the European Parliament should not take a position on whether private households themselves or the public sector are responsible for the costs associated with heat and energy.Consequently, we have abstained from voting for or against the fact that the costs associated with energy during the winter period are the responsibility of the public sector, and that the Commission should reduce energy costs for poor households.It is the competence of the Member States to decide on this.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- This report is a clear example of a policy in favor of the fight against poverty and that is why I voted in favor.The data presented to us today are alarming and therefore I believe that a concrete response from politics is necessary as soon as possible.This report lays the foundations for this, focusing on forms of renewable energy and energy efficiency for families exposed to energy precariousness.Furthermore, it seeks to redirect the various funds towards the most vulnerable families with the further aim of eliminating obstacles to accessing these resources.It is clear how energy and consumer price policies can have an impact on poverty in particular with regard to disadvantaged groups and for this reason I believe that to get closer to the objectives that this report highlights, cooperation of all states is necessarymembers.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ This own-initiative report aims to build bridges between social policy and energy policy in the European debate by stressing that the EU is getting further from the EU 2020 anti-poverty target, while the EU has relevant unmet potential for reducing major household costs of poor households through targeting existing renewable and energy efficiency projects on energy poor households. The report aims to meet the EU 2020 anti-poverty target and also meet energy efficiency, emission and renewable targets, and calls on multiple actors to take further steps with the help of various instruments but in the same direction

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. It called for the EU to create a definition for ‘energy poverty’, calls for investigating the possibility of an EU wide minimum income, wants an EU pillar of social rights and use of various EU funds. While UKIP supports more action to help those suffering poverty, it should be done by our own accountable national government, not by unelected bureaucrats in Brussels. If we left the EU we would have more money to help solve these problems and not be constrained by EU legislation which is making the situation worse.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ I support the call for more efficient, targeted and more carefully monitored use of the European Structural and Investment Funds so as to ensure that these effectively address living costs, social exclusion, housing deprivation, and the insufficient quality of the housing stock. I am also concerned with the gender gaps in remuneration, working hours and duration of working lives that women face during their working lives which, as the report correctly points out, have a direct effect on their lives as pensioners.   I also support greater flexibility for access to European funding by anti-poverty associations without adding administrative burdens for them. This should be linked to the active labour market policies aimed at assisting unemployed people to return to the labour market and find dignified jobs.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written.- The report supports the basic elements with which to develop a global plan to fight poverty: guaranteeing access to basic services (energy, water, health, education, housing…) in the face of the predatory logic of the market;the improvement of working and salary conditions on which the well-being of the working majority depends and a system of minimum income that complements social protection to guarantee, in an individualized and effective way, a decent income and life.Consequently, I have voted in favor.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - I consider the goal of fighting poverty to be a top priority for all Member States, in line with the Europe 2020 strategy. In recent years, the rising cost of living, the economic crisis and youth unemployment have created favorable conditions for proliferation poverty in all its aspects, as well as a vicious circle from which it is increasingly difficult to escape. In particular, it is clear that the high costs of housing in the presence of low incomes and, at the same time, the right not always guaranteed to access to healthy housing are issues that have a negative impact on the life of European citizens and on the economic recovery in Europe. Member states. Through my vote, therefore, I intend to support the adoption of a European strategy to end the problems of poverty, energy poverty and social exclusion, which combines the intervention of the Commission, diversified according to socio-economic contexts specific to each State, with the action of the Member States for a more effective use of European funds and for the continuous provision of social services, such as minimum income schemes, the reduction of energy costs for families, and equal access to adequate housing and healthcare.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up.- Since the beginning of the crisis, inequality in the EU has worsened and one in six Europeans is at risk of poverty.I voted in favor of modernizing legislation and developing new measures so that the anti-poverty goal set out in the EU 2020 Strategy is met.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: in writing. - Parliament's report on the fight against poverty in the light of overheads highlights high overhead costs in Member States and notes that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States. The report calls for the exchange of best practices between EU countries to improve the situation. The report calls on the European Commission to give Member States more flexibility in the use of European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can better target EU funds to reduce energy poverty or improve housing. Furthermore, it calls on the Member States to support the development of renewable energy sources or energy efficiency - e.g. investments in insulation, solar energy and energy efficient equipment. The EU definition of energy poverty (§ 34) was rejected by the People's Party, as there is no need for a new, non-objective poverty indicator. It is important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it would be essential to take into account the actual financial situation (eg home ownership, size of debts) instead of the current, partly self-reported, surveys. I supported the report.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - This report aims to create the linkages between social and energy policies, stressing that the EU is drifting away from the Europe 2020 goal of reducing poverty. The report calls for public commitment on the part of the EU through the minimum income framework and further changes to social and employment rights as well as anti-discrimination legislation. The report encourages the Commission to estimate measures to ensure an adequate minimum income above the poverty line of 60% of the national median income in all Member States. Another pillar of tackling poverty is reducing household costs with targeted EU funds. The report introduces the concept of a European moratorium on cutting off heating in winter, in order to ensure that no households can be cut off from their energy supply in winter for a certain period of time, and those in such a situation have been restored their energy supply, emphasizing that the bearing of the related costs is, according to the report, the responsibility of the public authority. Regrettably, despite the seriousness of the problem, I was unable to support this report, which proposes initiating policy-making debates, intervening by public authorities and increasing public spending, but without presenting any lasting and sustainable solutions based on an improved labor market and education and better public services. I abstained from voting.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- Combating poverty is one of the five measurable targets proposed for EU 2020, which encourages the adoption of national policies to protect women, in particular against the risk of poverty.In this context, I consider it important to reform macroeconomic, social and labor market policies in line with gender equality policies, as the objectives of combating poverty cannot be achieved without combating women's poverty.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This own-initiative report examines the possible repercussions of energy policies and consumer prices on poverty, in particular for disadvantaged groups.The report aims to find the best way to help households facing poverty and examines measures that could be taken to combat poverty as such.Considering that the Union is moving away from its objective of the 2020 strategy aimed at reducing the poverty of at least 20 million people in Europe, and that it is necessary to develop a strategy so that all households can meet their needsneeds, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I supported this report, which makes it possible to analyze the possible repercussions of energy policies and consumer prices on poverty.It proposes solutions with a view to achieving the objective of combating poverty enshrined in the Europe 2020 strategy, such as the development of employment and the guarantee of an income allowing a decent living.

name: Philippe DE BACKER
text: in writing. – I abstained from voting on this resolution. The objective of the initiative is righteous and a target to work to. Household incomes should increase and the fight against poverty is a continuous concern of us all. For all of these reasons, I did not vote against the resolution. However, I do not believe that the proposals made will reach this objective. They go against the free market principle and offer therefore only short-term solutions for which we will pay a high price in the long run. In sum, my goal is to reduce poverty and to increase household income. In addition, I completely agree that renewable energy should play a more prominent role in our lives. However, the only way to achieve these goals is research and development which will lead to employment. This requires large sums of investment that can only be attracted by creating an investor-friendly environment in a free market economy.

name: Angélique DELAHAYE
text: in writing.- I have chosen to vote in favor of the report entitled "Meeting the objective of combating poverty in the context of increasing household costs", because it is essential today to fight poverty more effectively.This is, moreover, an objective of the European Union for 2020, by reducing the number of people affected or threatened by poverty by 20 million.In this context, it seemed important to me to support a European definition of fuel poverty.Indeed, without such a definition, it seems difficult to me to fight effectively against.On the other hand, it is up to the Member States to set national minimum incomes and not to the European Commission, which is why I opposed this idea.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - The report finds that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States, blaming high overhead costs for the fight against poverty. Hungary is among these countries, thanks to the success of the overhead reduction, so it is gratifying that the report calls for an exchange of best practices between EU countries. The report also calls on the European Commission to give Member States a great deal of flexibility in the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can better target EU funds to reduce energy poverty or improve housing. The report also calls on Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, such as insulation, solar energy and energy-efficient equipment. In Hungary, the Home Heat Program will continue this year in Hungary, with which the Ministry of National Development will provide non-refundable support for the energy modernization and renovation of family houses starting from 1 July 2016 with a budget of HUF 5 billion. The People's Party said no to the EU's definition of energy poverty because there is no need for another, non-objective poverty indicator. It is important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it would be essential to take account of the actual financial situation instead of the current, partly self-reported, surveys. I voted in line with the People's Party, supporting the report as a whole.

name: Martina DLABAJOVÁ
text: in writing. ‒ Fighting poverty is important. EU Member States have in place the world’s best systems which protect the poorest and allow them, according to certain criteria, to benefit from minimum income schemes. This report, however, goes beyond this objective.  It steps into Member States’ competences to provide adequate support according to national practices. It also refrains from suggesting measures and incentives to re-integrate the most vulnerable parts of society into the labour market. This is why I decided to vote against this report.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form.- I voted against this report because it creates a link between poverty and energy, with complete disregard for other factors that need to be taken into account.In fact, immediate action is required, without offering lasting solutions aimed at the bigger picture.On top of that, a minimum income framework is proposed, while at the same time the specificities of the different Member States are clearly ignored, making it impossible to apply the same minimum standard to the whole of the EU.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - The report finds that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States, blaming high overhead costs for the fight against poverty. Hungary is among these countries, thanks to the success of the overhead reduction, so it is gratifying that the report calls for an exchange of best practices between EU countries. The report also calls on the European Commission to give Member States a great deal of flexibility in the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can better target EU funds to reduce energy poverty or improve housing conditions. The report also calls on Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, such as insulation, solar energy and energy-efficient equipment. In my country, Hungary, the Otthon Gaye program will continue this year as well, with which the Ministry of National Development will provide non-refundable support for the energy modernization and renovation of detached houses starting from 1 July 2016 with a budget of HUF 5 billion. For the EU definition of energy poverty (§ 34), the People's Party said no because there is no need for a new, non-objective poverty indicator. It is important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it would be essential to take into account the actual financial situation (eg home ownership, size of debts) instead of the current, partly self-reported, surveys. I voted in line with the People's Party, supporting the report as a whole.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: written.- The main objective of the draft report is to see how energy consumption policies and prices can have an impact on poverty, especially with regard to disadvantaged groups.The report also aims to find the best way to address the difficulties of households in poverty and considers the measures that could be taken to combat it.The principles of subsidiarity have been respected in matters such as income and minimum wage, the right to housing, rent control and the price of energy and, therefore, it has been an important report in accordance with the principles ofThe EU.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - The number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU has been increasing in recent years, reaching 122.6 million people. In 2013, 16.7% of the EU population was at risk of poverty after social transfers, 9.6% were in severe material deprivation and 10.7% of households belonged to the “very low labor intensity” category. Also according to the report, 10% of EU citizens had arrears on their utility bills, 12% of EU citizens were unable to keep their home adequately warm and 16% of the EU population lived in dwellings whose roofs they let water and humidity through the walls. I agree that an integrated strategy must be adopted to combat the various manifestations of poverty, through a holistic approach that establishes links between economic, labor, education, energy and transport policies and social policies based on best practices.

name: Edouard FERRAND
text: in writing.- Vote against: the best solution to the problem would be a targeted intervention by each Member State.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - The 5 million increase in the number of people at risk of poverty between 2008 and 2013, for a total of 122.6 million people across the European Union, is very significant. The number of people with severe material deprivation has increased to 45 million, as well as the number of people who cannot afford unexpected expenses. The report focuses, in this context, on the deprivations that households face, failing to cope with household charges, where electricity, gas and water stand out, goods that have increased significantly in recent years as a result of privatization of these sectors, their liberalization and deregulation. This situation has a particular impact on the elderly and children, due to the inability of certain households to pay for heating, with the harmful consequences that result. The report suggests a series of support measures: reducing the energy bill and investing in savings measures; the guarantee of a minimum income for each person; the strengthening of EU funds for the fight against poverty and social inclusion. It also mentions the importance of access to public services and the inalienable right to water. Despite a framework that does not differ from the EU's macroeconomic policies, the report has essentially positive aspects.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as I believe the EU through the ECB is actually causing poverty.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing. - Between 2008 and 2013, the number of poor people in the European Union increased from 117 million to more than 122 million. More than 16% of the population is at risk of poverty after social transfers, 9.6% were in a situation of severe material deprivation and 10.7% of households were identified with very low work intensity. Poor households spend most of their income on housing, utilities and food. According to European Union statistics on income and living conditions, 10% of citizens were in arrears on accounts in 2015, 12% were unable to maintain their homes and heat adequately in 2014, while 16% lived in leaky-roofed flats. Member States should focus more on energy efficiency projects in this way and help disadvantaged households in this way. The European Commission and the Member States must make greater efforts to achieve the goals of the fight against poverty. Financially vulnerable households need better protection against energy poverty and more support to improve their energy efficiency.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I abstain because, despite some clear and positive points, there are no effective measures in other parts of the report to tackle the increase in poverty and unemployment.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I am voting against the report on achieving the anti-poverty target given the rising household expenditure.Although the fight against poverty is a top priority for our Movement, I nevertheless strongly disagree with the Union's approach to the proposed solutions and I do not believe that these actions will achieve results.On the contrary, a more radical approach is needed, which, however, the Union is unable to accept and implement.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ Poverty levels in the Union are unacceptably high. Clearly, the increase in poverty is directly linked to the financial crisis and the subsequent austerity policies. I believe the Commission and the Member States must make more efforts to reach the anti-poverty targets, and that a minimum income scheme above the 60% national median income in all Member States, a European Energy Observatory and a winter heating disconnection moratorium are essential tools in this respect. Moreover, I believe financially vulnerable households need better protection against energy poverty and more support to improve their energy efficiency. I therefore support the call for a winter heating disconnection moratorium, to prevent energy cuts during winter months in case of financially vulnerable households, the call for an EU summit dedicated to the reduction of poverty and the support for a stronger role for consumers and for stronger consumer protection.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - The report finds that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States, blaming high overhead costs for the fight against poverty. Hungary is among these countries, thanks to the success of the overhead reduction, so it is gratifying that the report calls for an exchange of best practices between EU countries. The report also calls on the European Commission to give Member States a great deal of flexibility in the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can better target EU funds to reduce energy poverty or improve housing. The report also calls on Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, such as insulation, solar energy and energy-efficient equipment. In my country, Hungary, the Otthon Melege program will continue this year as well, with which the Ministry of National Development will provide non-refundable support for the energy modernization and renovation of family houses starting from 1 July 2016 with a budget of HUF 5 billion. For the EU definition of energy poverty (§ 34), the People's Party said no because there is no need for a new, non-objective poverty indicator. It is important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it would be essential to take into account the actual financial situation (eg home ownership, size of debts) instead of the current, partly self-reported, surveys. I voted in line with the People's Party, supporting the report as a whole.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - The report finds that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States, blaming high overhead costs for the fight against poverty. Hungary is among these countries, thanks to the success of the overhead reduction, so it is gratifying that the report calls for an exchange of best practices between EU countries. The report also calls on the European Commission to give Member States a great deal of flexibility in the use of the European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can better target EU funds to reduce energy poverty or improve housing conditions. The report also calls on Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, such as insulation, solar energy and energy-efficient equipment. In my country, Hungary, the Otthon Gaye program will continue this year as well, with which the Ministry of National Development will provide non-refundable support for the energy modernization and renovation of detached houses starting from 1 July 2016 with a budget of HUF 5 billion. For the EU definition of energy poverty (§ 34), the People's Party said no because there is no need for a new, non-objective poverty indicator. It is important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it would be essential to take into account the actual financial situation (eg home ownership, size of debts) instead of the current, partly self-reported, surveys. I voted in line with the People's Party, supporting the report as a whole.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report given the realization that the EU is increasingly moving away from the objective of fighting poverty set in the Europe 2020 Strategy. We must work with the objective of guaranteeing a greater social commitment on the part of theEU.Increasing the income of poor households is one of the fundamental elements of the success of the Europe 2020 Strategy and of the fight against poverty, especially considering that inequality in the EU has been increasing since the beginning of the crisis.From the European Parliament we must work so that no citizen is relegated to poverty and social exclusion.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this report because it represents a qualitative leap for Parliament in the fight against poverty, inequality and social exclusion. This resolution, through a set of recommendations that update and elevate in an innovative way the positions of the European Parliament in the fight against poverty, calls for social protection policies, the right to decent housing and the fight against energy poverty. After eight years of economic and financial crisis, statistics on inequality and poverty in Europe have worsened, especially in southern countries, particularly in Spain, where conditions of inequality are worse than in any other country on the continent after four years of government of the Popular Party. Therefore, the need to act with innovative policies is highlighted, such as the moratorium against the disconnection of heating in the winter months and the establishment of a system of minimum income by countries that guarantees a decent income, although in this case the liberals and conservatives of the European Parliament have put nuances to this extreme.

name: Eider GARDIAZABAL RUBIAL
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Report because it represents a qualitative leap for Parliament in the fight against poverty, inequality and social exclusion. This resolution brings together social protection policies, the right to decent housing and the fight against energy poverty, in a compendium of recommendations that update and innovate the positions of the European Parliament in the fight against poverty. After eight years of economic and financial crisis, data on inequality and poverty in Europe have not only not remitted but have worsened, especially in southern countries, such as Spain, where inequality conditions are worse than in any other country of the continent after four years of government of the Popular Party. That is why the need to act with innovative policies is highlighted, such as the moratorium against the disconnection of heating in the winter months, the establishment of a minimum income system by countries that guarantees a decent income, although in this case the liberal groups and chamber conservatives have nuanced this end.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- Poverty is still a problem within the EU.We must continue to fight this.I advocated these measures to prevent growing inequality among the population.

name: Sylvie GODDYN
text: in writing.- Considering the structural disparities between the Member States, it seems unthinkable to seek to standardize and homogenize social policies in the fight against poverty.Each of the Member States suffers from different types of poverty, the causes and responses of which are inevitably different.On the other hand, there are some common origins to the poverty of citizens of the Member States of the European Union: relocations encouraged by ultra-liberalism, organized dumping of which mass immigration is the instrument ... Nothing in this text is mentioned.attack these fundamental problems, vectors of precariousness throughout the Union.For these reasons, I voted against this text.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written. - We voted in favor of this report as it focuses on analyzing household spending and the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which aims to reduce by 20 million people at risk of social exclusion. The Report has incorporated four aspects, two included in its general recommendations, which are very positive. In the first place, references to the need to increase investment in renewable energies and energy efficiency to tackle poverty are interesting insofar as they are linked to employment policies, energy transition, quality and affordable housing and reduction of health spending. Second, the text makes references to an adequate minimum income above the poverty line, which represents 60% of the average national income in all Member States. Thirdly, a call for better use, dissemination and information on European funds as well as extension beyond 2020 to FEAD is remarkable and positive. Finally, the reference to a moratorium on heating cuts in winter to ensure that no home is left without supply, is essential to tip our vote in favor.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ 1 in 5 of the UK population live below the poverty line. We urgently need to address this problem in a comprehensive manner and that is why I support this report

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - The report finds that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States, blaming high overhead costs for the fight against poverty. Hungary is among these countries, thanks to the success of the overhead reduction, so it is gratifying that the report calls for an exchange of best practices between EU countries. The report also calls on the European Commission to give Member States more flexibility in the use of European Structural and Investment Funds so that EU funds can be better targeted at reducing energy poverty or improving housing conditions. The report also calls on Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, such as insulation, solar energy and energy-efficient equipment. For the EU definition of energy poverty (§ 34), the People's Party said no because there is no need for a new, non-objective poverty indicator. It is important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it would be essential to take into account the actual financial situation (eg home ownership, size of debts) instead of the current, partly self-reported, surveys. In line with the People's Party, I supported the report as a whole.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- We abstained as the report superficially addresses the problems of rising cost of living / housing, in particular with regard to the two key issues of minimum income and the introduction of a moratorium on household power outages.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ I was pleased to support this important report which highlights the fact that one in six Europeans live in poverty, or are at risk of poverty – in Ireland that figure is 16% and 3 out of every 10 children suffer deprivation - stark figures. We are all aware that poorer households spend a higher portion of their incomes on household costs such as food, compared with other more affluent households. The report highlights concrete measures that can be taken in order to try and meet the EU 2020 anti-poverty targets such as a winter heating disconnection moratorium, a possibility to extend the Fund for Aid to the Most Deprived, and measures to reduce energy poverty such as micro-loans to invest in energy efficiency. I also believe that a minimum income which takes into account the economic and social circumstances in each Member State and which is based on a life-cycle approach, can act as a safety net for those families at risk of, or living in, poverty.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the report on the achievement of the anti-poverty target in the light of rising costs for households. Unfortunately, progress towards one of the Europe 2020 goals of reducing the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion is insufficient. The report on tackling poverty in the light of rising costs for households raises a number of important issues that can bring us closer to solving this problem. I agree with the rapporteur that there are links between social and energy policies. Increasing the energy efficiency of households as well as making better use of modern and renewable energy sources will reduce the level of energy poverty, which is still experienced by many households in the Union. Due to the interdependencies, this topic requires a holistic approach. Therefore, I believe that in this area it is particularly important to introduce synergies between the various existing funds and to effectively manage resources for these purposes, both at the level of the Commission and the Member States, as well as at local level.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - The report finds that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States, blaming high overhead costs for the fight against poverty. Hungary is among these countries, thanks to the success of the overhead reduction, so it is gratifying that the report calls for an exchange of best practices between EU countries. The report also calls on the European Commission to give Member States more flexibility in the use of European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can better target EU funds to reduce energy poverty or improve housing. The report also calls on Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, such as insulation, solar energy and energy-efficient equipment. In my country, Hungary, the Otthon Melege program will continue this year as well, with which the Ministry of National Development will provide non-refundable support for the energy modernization and renovation of family houses starting from 1 July 2016 with a budget of HUF 5 billion. For the EU definition of energy poverty (§ 34), the People's Party said no because there is no need for a new, non-objective poverty indicator. It is important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it would be essential to take into account the actual financial situation (eg home ownership, size of debts) instead of the current, partly self-reported, surveys. I voted in line with the People's Party, supporting the report as a whole.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: in writing. ‒ It is absolutely unacceptable for poverty to increase in the Union. The Commission and the Member States must make greater efforts in order to meet anti-poverty targets. Minimum income schemes and a winter heating disconnection moratorium are first steps. Disadvantaged households need better protection against energy poverty.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written. - I voted in favor of the European Parliament resolution on achieving the goal of fighting poverty in the light of rising household costs, because I believe that the social dimension of Europe needs to be strengthened through an integrated approach and through the modernization of existing legislation. Inequality in the European Union is growing and the rate of citizens living on the brink of poverty is still too high. Therefore, I believe that raising the income of poor households is one of the key priorities of the Europe 2020 strategy and the fight against poverty. In this context, in order to reduce poverty, especially extreme poverty, it is necessary to effectively reduce household expenditures through better management of the funds allocated to it. I also believe that it is of particular importance to insist on the involvement of various actors and measures in this process in order to act in a coordinated manner in the fight against poverty and in achieving the goals of energy efficiency and renewable energy sources.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing. - The Europe 2020 strategy plans to lift 20 million people out of poverty by 2020. In order to get closer to this objective, certain actions are being considered at European level. This text focuses in particular on the poverty of families in the context of the increase in the cost of housing, energy and education. Poverty continues to grow as the crisis gets bogged down, and is further aggravated by the arrival of migrants, but no European initiative is able to reverse the trend ... European funds have only to a minor impact on the policies undertaken by the Member States, and policies such as the establishment of a minimum wage or the tax shift clearly fall within national competence. Obviously the "types" of poverty and the causes of poverty vary from one Member State to another, which is why a common European approach is ill-suited. The best solution would be a targeted intervention by each Member State to alleviate poverty in its territory. I therefore voted against this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. It called for the EU to create a definition for ‘energy poverty’, calls for investigating the possibility of an EU wide minimum income, wants an EU pillar of social rights and use of various EU funds. While UKIP supports more action to help those suffering poverty, it should be done by our own accountable national government, not by unelected bureaucrats in Brussels. If we left the EU we would have more money to help solve these problems and not be constrained by EU legislation which is making the situation worse.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the fight against poverty and social exclusion, which is one of the five objectives of the European Union for 2020. The Union has set itself the goal of reducing'at least 20 million the number of people affected or threatened by poverty.Unfortunately, we are still a long way from this goal.This report therefore intends to make proposals to achieve this.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I do not agree with this report.The rapporteur's proposals are aimed at a transfer union, which I reject.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of the report, as it calls for a holistic approach on poverty and social exclusion on the basis of best practices. 1 in 5 of the UK population live below the poverty line. Therefore, we urgently need to address this problem in a comprehensive manner.

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: in writing.- All households in Europe should have access to heat and energy all year round.We as Social Democrats agree with this. However, how access to heat and energy for households is financed is a national matter, since the formulation of social policy is generally a Member State competence under the Treaty.Therefore, the European Parliament should not take a position on whether private households themselves or the public sector are responsible for the costs associated with heat and energy.Consequently, we have abstained from voting for or against the fact that the costs associated with energy during the winter period are the responsibility of the public sector, and that the Commission should reduce energy costs for poor households.It is the competence of the Member States to decide on this.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: written.- The Meszerics report identifies rising costs of living in the EU, especially in terms of energy prices, and derives from this a claim by the EU to achieve the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy by expanding social transfers and other measures.The analysis is doubtful due to the current very low oil price and the deflationary economic environment.The approaches in the report mandate more regulation, in particular through national regulations on minimum wages and minimum incomes or the right to an energy supply in winter.Fundamental economic questions are neglected.It neither shows how the claims can be financed nor how the countries affected by the euro crisis are to overcome their difficulties.As a result, I rejected this general catalog of wishes for more transfers and social benefits.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - Given that the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU increased from 117 to 122.6 million between 2008 and 2013, I was very pleased with the report by my colleague Meszerics, who succeeded in writing a socially sensitive resolution on poverty reduction targets. with a view to increasing household costs. I believe that a person who really cares about the future of the less affluent and the socially disadvantaged could not have had the slightest problem with this report. For example, the resolution states that the privatization of water services has a negative impact on households suffering from or at risk of poverty. Although I understand that right-wing Czech MEPs may not like it, I do not understand how they may have a problem with the UN data on which the information was based. How can anyone have a problem with eradicating poverty, energy poverty, ensuring the availability of water and housing under economically affordable conditions? It was therefore a really shocking finding for me that these Czech MEPs - Dita Charanzová, Martina Dlabajová, Petr Ježek, Petr Mach, Pavel Telička, Evžen Tošenovský, Jan Zahradil and Jaromír Štětina - voted against this report. Everyone except my colleague Macha voted against their political groups in the vote, and I do not understand why they taught that with the report, which dealt with such sensitive topics.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - The report finds that poverty indicators have improved in only a few Member States, blaming high overhead costs for the fight against poverty. Hungary is among these countries, thanks to the success of the overhead reduction, so it is gratifying that the report calls for an exchange of best practices between EU countries.
