The report also calls on the European Commission to give Member States more flexibility in the use of European Structural and Investment Funds so that they can better target EU funds to reduce energy poverty or improve housing. The report also calls on Member States to support investments in renewable energy sources or energy efficiency, such as insulation, solar energy and energy-efficient equipment. In Hungary, Hungary, the Home Heat program will continue this year as well, with which the Ministry of National Development will provide non-refundable support for the energy modernization and renovation of family houses starting from 1 July 2016 with a budget of HUF 5 billion. For the EU definition of energy poverty (paragraph 34), the People's Party said no because there is no need for a new, non-objective poverty indicator. It is important for the Commission to work on the basis of objective data, for which it would be essential to take into account the actual financial situation (eg home ownership, size of debts) instead of the current, partly self-reported, surveys. I voted in line with the People's Party, supporting the report as a whole.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for the text because one of the five headline targets of Europe 2020 is to reduce poverty by lifting at least 20 million people out of the risk of poverty or social exclusion by 2020. In order to achieve these goals, firstly we should work to increase the incomes of poor households by improving the effectiveness of social and employment policies. Secondly, we should effectively reduce the household costs of poor households; in particular we should fight energy poverty through targeting existing renewable and energy efficiency projects on energy poor households.  In light of this, we should work to make energy affordable to all EU citizens. I believe that the fight against poverty in practice is a fight for the future of the EU and millions of Europeans, thereby it is our moral duty to lead it to successful end.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- I expressed my positive opinion on this proposal after having successfully reached compromises on some points that created discrepancies between the different groups.The noble proposal sets the objective of considering the measures in which energy policies and consumer prices can have a positive impact on poverty and the most disadvantaged families.Considering the increase in the percentage of energy poverty and in the light of the Union's role in providing effective and sustainable solutions for the facilitation of the most vulnerable consumers, the creation of a system that makes energy accessible at all costs seems appropriate and essential.Aid to families in difficulty must be a priority of our political action, both as income support and as incentives for consumption.I therefore supported this report and its commitment to a serious fight against poverty.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it is hypocritical.The EU pretends to fight fiercely against poverty when the sums it devotes to it are paltry.The report further obscures the grim reality that poverty finds its root causes in ultra-liberal EU policies.The passage which asks the Brussels Commission to fight against precarious work is, from this point of view, totally surreal!

name: Philippe LOISEAU
text: in writing.- I spoke against it.Indeed, within the framework of the Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has put in place two axes to achieve the objective set, namely to lift 20 million people out of poverty by 2020. It would therefore be a question of promotingincreasing the incomes of poor households and promoting spending cuts.At first glance, these measures appear to be a good remedy for the worsening poverty.However, it is the crisis that is bogged down and intensified with the arrival of migrants in mass that increases poverty.The European Union has a cowardly attitude in not tackling this problem head-on.In addition, it is up to each sovereign Member State to resolve family poverty and find a way to provide them with housing, energy and access to education.

name: Javi LÓPEZ
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Report because it represents a qualitative leap for Parliament in the fight against poverty, inequality and social exclusion. This resolution brings together social protection policies, the right to decent housing and the fight against energy poverty, in a compendium of recommendations that update and innovate the positions of the European Parliament in the fight against poverty. After eight years of economic and financial crisis, data on inequality and poverty in Europe have not only not remitted but have worsened, especially in southern countries, such as Spain, where inequality conditions are worse than in any other country of the continent after four years of government of the Popular Party. That is why the need to act with innovative policies is highlighted, such as the moratorium against the disconnection of heating in the winter months, the establishment of a minimum income system by countries that guarantees a decent income, although in this case the liberal groups and chamber conservatives have nuanced this end.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written.- The report supports the basic elements with which to develop a global plan to fight poverty: guaranteeing access to basic services (energy, water, health, education, housing…) in the face of the predatory logic of the market;the improvement of working and salary conditions on which the well-being of the working majority depends and a system of minimum income that complements social protection to guarantee, in an individualized and effective way, a decent income and life.Consequently, I have voted in favor.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written.- The European Union, in its intention to reduce poverty, is further and further from the goals set in the EU2020 strategy.Poverty and social exclusion are key determinants of a country's economy and indicators of a country's living conditions.In the Union, 11% of the population spends more than 40% of disposable income on housing costs, 10.8% of the population faces difficult conditions to maintain household heating, and 12 million more women than men live in poverty.The state of social exclusion and poverty has been further exacerbated by the impact of the crisis, which has affected all households and forced Member States to reduce social spending measures and focus on economic targets.I supported this report because it points to the burning problem of poverty and the need to define a minimum income as an instrument in reducing and preventing poverty.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. - The European Union is one of the most developed and richest places in the world, but unfortunately not everywhere there is an opportunity for people to live decently, according to their skills and aspirations. As can be seen, in 2013, 122.6 million people in the EU, or 16.7% of its population, were at risk of poverty. In 2008, there were 117 million. Given the trends of the last few years, I do not think that the statistics have become more positive. Although the Europe 2020 strategy aims to reduce the number of such people by 20 million by the end of the decade, this should not be the main thing, as the necessary effort must be put into practice, it simply provides a guide. I unequivocally join in calling on the Commission, and in particular the Member States themselves, to do their utmost and depend on them to combat poverty and social exclusion in Europe as effectively as possible. Within our existing social systems, which are, in fact, far from liberalism and maximum government interference, states are in one way or another responsible for social policy, health care and support for the poor. Access to clean water, winter heating resources and, importantly, support for our elderly, at least through fair pensions, must be at the heart of any Member State's social policy. However, there are countries where pensioners are in the worst financial situation compared to other sections of society. It is not possible to build the future effectively without thinking about those who helped build the present.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- In addition, I point out that in order to fight poverty and social exclusion in Europe, the policy of austerity must be abandoned and the European minimum income, the European minimum wage and the European unemployment benefit introduced.Elsewhere, I support the report on achieving the anti-poverty target in the light of rising household spending.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This is a proposal to increase the European budget for 2017 by 1.9 billion euros!This increase would be justified by security and cybersecurity spending, but also by more resources granted to deputies in the exercise of their mandates as well as by the costs associated with welcoming visitors.At a time of budgetary rigor, the "Europe of Nations and Freedoms" group advocates, for its part, operating economies of European bodies.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report that looks at how energy and consumer prices can have an impact on poverty levels, and the report identifies measures which can combat this.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing. - This report describes for us the grim situation of poverty in Europe. Between 2008 and 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the European Union rose from 117 million to 122.6 million. To meet the poverty reduction objective of the Europe 2020 strategy as well as the objectives of improving energy efficiency, reducing greenhouse gas emissions and using renewable energies, the report focuses on Union action on access to housing and the fight against fuel poverty. The report therefore calls on Member States to "apply reasonable rental policies". It also proposes a European moratorium on heating cuts in winter "in order to guarantee that no household can be deprived of energy during a defined winter period". Not a word on the responsibility for the economic disaster which breeds poverty! Benevolent blah. I will nevertheless vote for this text.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- I disapprove of the means used by the European Union to achieve its Europe 2020 objectives. The recommended minimum tax falls within the competence of the States.Poverty differs from state to state.Also, a common European approach would lack pragmatism.I believe that the most relevant means would be a targeted policy of each state on its territory.Consequently, I voted against this text.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I supported this report as it highlights the need to close the gap between the Union’s social policy and its energy policy, helping citizens across the EU to rise out of poverty while also contributing to achieving our European Union energy targets.

name: Louis MICHEL
text: written. - Europe has set itself ambitious energy targets. In order to meet international environmental agreements and at the same time become less dependent on the supply of energy from neighboring countries, the EU wants to increase the use of renewable energy sources, optimize energy efficiency and reduce greenhouse gases. In the pursuit of these goals, we cannot lose sight of Europe's other ambition, which is to ensure decent living conditions for all European citizens. And that is why bridges must be built between energy and social policies of the EU. Introducing a European moratorium on shutting off the heating during winter can protect vulnerable families from social exclusion. But to limit the risk of energy poverty, support for structural measures, such as making homes energy efficient, is needed. If everyone has equal access to energy and also has equal access to the benefits of energy efficiency, thereby reducing the phenomenon of energy poverty, it will also be easier for the EU and Member States to meet the ambitious energy and climate goals. fetch.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report on the anti-poverty target in the light of increasing household costs, since poverty levels in the Union are unacceptably high. The increase in poverty is directly linked to the financial crisis and the subsequent austerity policies. The Commission and the Member States must make more efforts to reach the anti-poverty targets. Minimum income schemes above the 60% national median income in all Member States, a European Energy Observatory and a winter heating disconnection moratorium are essential tools in this respect. Financially vulnerable households need better protection against energy poverty and more support to improve their energy efficiency.

name: Csaba MOLNÁR
text: in writing. - The report of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs links social policy with energy policy. Eliminating or at least reducing energy poverty can be an important element in achieving the anti-poverty goals of the Europe 2020 strategy, as the Union has significant untapped potential to reduce the main household costs of poor households through existing renewable energy and energy efficiency projects. Energy efficiency, emissions and renewable energy targets can also help achieve the Europe 2020 anti-poverty goals. An effective means of combating poverty, especially deep poverty, is to reduce household costs effectively by targeting the various funds more specifically to help the most vulnerable households and by removing obstacles to resource efficiency. The Europe 2020 strategy aims to achieve a 20% share of renewable energy consumption by 2020, a 20% increase in energy efficiency and a 20% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions (compared to 1990). More targeted use of EU funds to support households struggling with energy poverty will bring them closer to these goals. I supported the adoption of the report.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- The objective of the Europe 2020 strategy is to lift 20 million people out of poverty by 2020. Two axes are therefore proposed.First of all, to encourage the increase in the incomes of poor households by regulating minimum incomes and strengthening social rights in order to guarantee sufficient State aid.Then, encourage the reduction in spending by poor households, in particular by ensuring a better allocation of European funds.One of the problems with this report is that it does not address the issue of migrants, which is one of the causes of the impoverishment of European populations.Furthermore, the solutions he advocates run counter to the sovereignty of the Member States.We are therefore voting against.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing.- The cost of basic and essential goods and services has increased rapidly in recent years in many EU countries, resulting in an increase in household overheads.There are groups most vulnerable to this increase, such as single parents, elderly women, migrant women and people with disabilities.It is important to note that the number of people at risk or in situations of poverty or social exclusion has increased, despite the fact that the objective of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of people in this category by at least 20 million.I argue that the EU, as well as the Member States, should redouble its efforts in the fight against poverty and social exclusion, creating a uniform, holistic strategy against the various manifestations of poverty.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- Poverty continues to grow as the crisis gets bogged down, and is worsened by the arrival of migrants, but no European initiative is able to reverse the trend ... European funds have only to'' a minor impact on the policies undertaken by the Member States, and policies such as the establishment of a minimum wage or the tax shift clearly fall within national competence.Obviously the "types" of poverty and the causes of poverty vary from one Member State to another, which is why a common European approach is ill-suited.The best solution would be a targeted intervention by each Member State to alleviate poverty in its territory.I therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ 1 in 5 of the UK population live below the poverty line. We urgently need to address this problem in a comprehensive manner and that is why I support this report.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- The fight against poverty and social exclusion is one of the five priorities of the European Union for 2020. In this context, it has set itself the objective of reducing the number of people affected by at least 20 million.or threatened by poverty.This report makes proposals for achieving these objectives, in a difficult economic context in many Member States.This is the reason why I voted in favor.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this text because Europe must more than ever show its attachment to its founding value: solidarity.120 million Europeans risk falling into poverty, this observation is untenable.This is why, by voting for this report, I defended my attachment to the sustainability of the Fund for European Aid to the Most Deprived and the European Social Fund, which must be increased to face this challenge.In the fight against poverty, no one can be resigned.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - We welcome the Meszerics report with great interest and absolute consent, the main objective of which is the fight against poverty by bringing social policy and energy policy closer together in the European debate. Considering that inequalities in the European Union are increasing mainly due to the crisis and the risk that a European citizen could be exposed to risks of poverty, it is clear that adequate countermeasures must be found in a tight time frame. We therefore believe that the proposal to introduce a minimum income framework and an improvement in social labor rights are necessary tools to allow the European Union to advance in its social commitment. We also believe that to decrease the level of poverty it is necessary to reduce family spending through a better orientation of the various funds towards the most vulnerable families and the elimination of obstacles to access to resources. We trust in a better address of the European Union funds to families in energy precarious conditions may be the key to achieving this goal more quickly. Finally, the initiative introduces the concept of a European moratorium on the suspension of the heating service during the winter months, to protect families most in difficulty due to energy insecurity or at risk of heating interruptions due to non-payment of bills.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the objectives of the fight against poverty in the context of the increase in household costs, this one allowing an analysis of the consequences of the policies implemented to ensure stronger protection of households, in particularthe most disadvantaged.The definition of energy poverty provided by the report is also welcome, allowing a clarification of the challenges we face.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- A common Europe years ago was an ideal for many of us, a dream we managed to achieve together.The common single market, the protection of human rights, common European values, cultural diversity, free travel and many other achievements have enriched our lives for Europe.Despite these, however, poverty is also on a serious scale at European level, as we are experiencing at home in Slovakia.I believe that one of the challenges of European integration is to fight poverty.Creating a Europe where our achievements provide a sound basis for living standards, a Europe where it will be inconceivable for the citizens of the Union to starve and live in deep poverty.I therefore welcome the initiative, which highlights the importance of combating poverty and lists the policies and measures needed to do so.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that aims to build bridges between energy policy and social policy in a European debate by stressing that the EU is getting further from the EU 2020 anti-poverty target. Amongst the main pillars to fight against poverty is the effective reduction of household costs.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up.- I voted in favor of this report because the problem of poverty in the context of increasing current household spending is extremely current and more common, with more than 120 million European citizens being, according to official statistics, on the verge of poverty and social exclusion.The report adopted today proposes a series of measures that Member States can use to achieve the goal of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which is to reduce the number of people on the brink of poverty by at least 20%.It is important for the European Executive to work with Member States to adopt and promote an integrated strategy to combat poverty.It is largely about the adoption of economic and social laws, employment, education for economic development and, implicitly, the fight against poverty.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted against the report because it greatly expands the powers of the EU and further restricts the Member States' freedom of action.Moreover, it bears witness to an overly interventionist understanding of politics, which I strictly reject.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. It called for the EU to create a definition for ‘energy poverty’, calls for investigating the possibility of an EU wide minimum income, wants an EU pillar of social rights and use of various EU funds. While UKIP supports more action to help those suffering poverty, it should be done by our own accountable national government, not by unelected bureaucrats in Brussels. If we left the EU we would have more money to help solve these problems and not be constrained by EU legislation which is making the situation worse.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- Considering that the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, enshrined in Article 5 of the TFEU, are fundamental principles of the European Union, considering that the necessary greater involvement of the Member States in the definition of European policies must always be in line with the aforementioned principles,and that in some cases the definition of the same and the division of competences between the Member States and the EU is a source of confusion, and considering that greater dialogue between national parliaments and the European institutions can contribute to the respect of these principles and reduceso the so-called "yellow card" was used, I would like to express a favorable vote.

name: Eva MAYDELL
text: in writing. – The number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has increased in most Member States, Bulgaria being one of them. Overall, 24.5 % of the EU population were at risk of poverty or social exclusion in 2013. The primary aim of the report is to see how energy policies and consumer prices can have impact on poverty, especially with regard to disadvantaged groups. There is no doubt that reducing, and even abolishing, poverty should be on top of our agendas. Hence, I vote in favour of the report.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support the proposal to introduce concrete measures to prevent further increases in poverty. The poverty line has exceeded all limits and the situation is unsustainable. I place special emphasis on youth unemployment in the EU, which is growing day by day. I am also concerned about the position and number of women, which is far higher than the number of men living in poverty. I therefore welcome the emphasis on the importance of educating women and girls to strengthen their role at the cultural, social and political levels and to provide them with a dignified life. I support the measure by which each Member State would provide its citizens with adequate support, including a minimum income, and provide them with the necessary assistance to combat poverty. I am especially in favor of the introduction of a minimum pension that must not be lower than the poverty line, because it has been shown that in Croatia alone almost half a million pensioners live in poverty and do not have the means for basic living needs. The important fact is that poverty and social exclusion have an intergenerational component and, accordingly, access to education for children needs to be ensured, so I support policies aimed at preventing early school leaving.

name: Pina PICIERNO
text: in writing. - The level of poverty in Europe is intolerably high. Between 2008 and 2013, due to the economic crisis and the austerity policy that followed, the number of poor people in the European Union rose from 117 to more than 122 million. Poor families spend most of their income on housing, bills and food. According to European Union statistics, in 2015, 10% of citizens had overdue bills to pay and, in 2014, 12% were unable to heat their home adequately, while 16% lived in damp housing due to of water infiltrations. In such a situation and with house prices continuing to rise, the EU needs to do much more if it is to achieve its objectives to combat poverty. In particular, Member States should focus more on energy efficiency projects (which Italy is already doing) to help disadvantaged families and, at the same time, promote models of environmental sustainability. Another equally important measure, envisaged by the report, is the approval of a winter moratorium, to avoid cuts in the supply of energy to families in difficulty. Finally, I am also in favor of the creation of a European Energy Observatory.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written. - Between 2008 and 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU rose from 117 million to 122.6 million. The at-risk-of-poverty threshold is set at 60% of the national average of equivalent disposable income, and 12 million more women than men live in poverty in the EU. Factors contributing to this inequality are the gender pay gap and pensions, the large number of women with precarious jobs, and the fact that women are often forced to stay economically inactive for longer due to the unaffordable cost of childcare. I regret that the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion has increased, although the goal of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number in that category by at least 20 million. Member States should provide adequate support that is easy to obtain, which includes a minimum income above the poverty line for life as long as it takes and the different types of benefits needed to tackle poverty.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - The 5 million increase in the number of people at risk of poverty between 2008 and 2013, for a total of 122.6 million people across the European Union, is very significant. The number of people with severe material deprivation has increased to 45 million, as well as the number of people who cannot afford unexpected expenses. The report focuses, in this context, on the deprivations faced by households, failing to cope with domestic charges - where electricity, gas and water stand out, assets that have increased significantly in recent years as a result of privatization sectors, their liberalization and deregulation. This situation has a particular impact on the elderly and children, due to the inability of certain households to pay for heating, with the harmful consequences that result. The report suggests a series of support measures: reducing energy expenditure and investing in savings measures; the guarantee of a minimum income for each person; strengthening EU funds to fight poverty and social inclusion. It also mentions the importance of access to public services and the inalienable right to water. Despite a framework in line with the EU's economic macro-policy, the report has essentially positive factors. We voted in favor.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: in writing. - It is important for me, as a Social Democrat, to meet the poverty reduction target set in the 2020 strategy. Given that the EU is constantly moving away from this target, I am pleased to adopt this report, which seeks to highlight this issue while bridging the gap. between social and energy policy in the European debate. The report on meeting the poverty reduction target with regard to rising household costs focuses mainly on significant shortcomings in the effort to reduce high costs in poor households. To this end, it proposes targeting existing renewable energy and energy efficiency projects at poor households. Reducing costs for poor and most vulnerable households and removing barriers to resource efficiency is one of the EU's main pillars for combating poverty. In particular, I consider it important to properly target European funds to households that are in energy poverty. Given that there was a significant increase in the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion between 2008 and 2013, more energy needs to be invested in finding a solution to this issue. It is therefore necessary not to forget these people in need and to continue to draw attention and take action to combat poverty.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: in writing. - The problem of poverty and social exclusion must be actively addressed within the European Union as an advanced community and every effort must be made to eliminate this risk and to promote the achievement of at least minimum living standards by as many people as possible in each Member State. These problems cannot be solved with immediate effect, but every effort must be made constantly to create optimal conditions for reducing the risk of poverty and social exclusion. The key role in this is played by the individual Member States, which should be expected to be willing to pursue the common goal of the European Union and to raise the living standards of their citizens, and should therefore have their own national strategies to address this problem. they should be fully assisted by the European Commission. Undoubtedly, the European social and investment funds, which are to be used a priori to finance investments leading to the fulfillment of social benefits, are an important means of supporting poverty reduction.

name: Tomasz Piotr PORĘBA
text: in writing. - This own-initiative report aims to create the linkages between social and energy policies while underlining that the EU is drifting away from the Europe 2020 goal of reducing poverty. The rapporteur demands public commitment from the EU through the minimum income framework and further changes to social and employment rights as well as anti-discrimination legislation. The report shows that a minimum income is an essential instrument that should be introduced to ensure respect for the fundamental right to decent living conditions. Another pillar of tackling poverty is reducing household costs with targeted EU funds. This report includes descriptions of poverty and proposes to initiate policy-making debates, the intervention of public authorities and an increase in public spending, without however presenting any sustainable and sustainable solutions based on an improved labor market, education and better public services. I hereby abstain.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing. - The fight against poverty is a constant struggle. In 2013, around 16% of the European population was considered to be at risk of poverty after social transfers. At the same time, the European Union, in its Europe 2020 strategy, has set the objective of reducing by at least 20 million the number of people affected or threatened by poverty or social exclusion. For example, access to energy, and particularly heating, is a lever that we can use. In this regard, the resolution I voted on calls on Member States to sign a moratorium on winter heating cuts to ensure that no household can be deprived of energy during winter. More generally, the European Commission has also been invited to carry out an impact analysis on minimum income systems in the Member States, so that their levels are notably above the poverty line set at 60% of the national median income. Finally, the Member States will have to ensure that the authorities, at the different territorial levels, effectively mobilize European funds that can contribute to the fight against fuel poverty, social exclusion or even the poor quality of housing.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ UKIP voted against this non-binding and non-legislative report. It called for the EU to create a definition for ‘energy poverty’, calls for investigating the possibility of an EU wide minimum income, wants an EU pillar of social rights and use of various EU funds. While UKIP supports more action to help those suffering poverty, it should be done by our own accountable national government, not by unelected bureaucrats in Brussels. If we left the EU we would have more money to help solve these problems and not be constrained by EU legislation which is making the situation worse.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - Between 2008 and 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU increased from 117 to 122.6 million people. This report states that one way to contribute to solving the problem is by saving energy and improving efficiency in homes. In 2015, 10% of EU citizens had late payments on their utility bills; in 2014, 12% of EU citizens were unable to keep their home adequately warm and 16% of the EU population lived in dwellings whose roofs let water and moisture through the walls. This report invites the Commission to carry out an impact assessment on minimum income systems in the EU and to consider further measures taking into account the economic and social circumstances of each Member State. Furthermore, it wants to ensure that European, Structural and Investment Funds are used more efficiently by national, regional and local authorities, and calls on the Commission and the Member States to devote a summit to poverty reduction, extreme poverty, social exclusion and access to a dignified life. I voted in favor.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- Poverty levels in the EU are unacceptably high.The increase in poverty is directly linked to the financial crisis and the consequent austerity policies.The Commission and the Member States must now strive to achieve the anti-poverty objectives.A minimum income above 60% of the national average wage in all Member States and an energy observatory (for energy poverty) are some of the measures planned.

name: Inma RODRÍGUEZ-PIÑERO
text: written. - The role of the private sector in development has been, and continues to be, a highly debated topic. However, almost unanimously, the role that the private sector can, and should, play in development matters is recognized. It is important to highlight the importance of the measures carried out thanks to the European aid aimed at supporting the local private sector and promoting the social responsibility of companies in developing countries. We must not forget that it is the private sector that provides almost 90% of jobs in developing countries and that, therefore, it should be a priority partner for the fight against poverty and for the dissemination of the values ​​of democracy. and human rights that characterize the Union. Due to its importance, it is also a key piece for sharing knowledge between countries, for technology transfer and for investment in these countries. The commitment that is made in this report to continue promoting public-private partnerships of good practice and collaboration is what has led me to vote in favor of this report.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - The fight against poverty in all its forms deserves that we go beyond partisan divisions. It must be a priority for ethical and human reasons, but also because poverty represents a real economic waste. The main tools in this fight are the development of employment and the guarantee of an income allowing a decent living. The EU 2020 targets are far from being achieved. If the European Union is to earn its "social triple A", this trend must absolutely be reversed. We must be aware that poor households are particularly affected by different types of costs. This is the case for energy or housing, but also for food, health care or public services. We need coherent policies that integrate all the factors of poverty. Families living in poverty don't need speeches; they need concrete and practical actions. I hope that this own-initiative report will be heard by the Commission and by the Member States as a call to action.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - The fight against poverty and social exclusion is one of the five objectives that the European Union has set itself for 2020, with in particular this objective of reducing by 20 million the number of people affected or threatened by poverty. The situation is currently worrying and we are very far from this objective: between 2008 and 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the European Union rose from 117 million to 122.6 million. In 2013, 16.7% of the population of the European Union was at risk of poverty after social transfers, 9.6% was in a situation of severe material deprivation and 10.7% of households were considered to be very low labor intensity. I supported this text which calls for more investment in the fight against poverty and social exclusion and for an integrated approach. We must act as quickly as possible and develop real solidarity in the face of these alarming situations.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written. - We voted in favor of this report as it focuses on analyzing household expenditures and the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which aims to reduce by 20 million people at risk of social exclusion. The Report has incorporated four aspects, two included in its general recommendations, which are very positive. In the first place, references to the need to increase investment in renewable energies and energy efficiency to tackle poverty are interesting insofar as they are linked to employment policies, energy transition, quality and affordable housing and reduction of health spending. Second, the text makes references to an adequate minimum income above the poverty line, which represents 60% of the average national income in all the Member States. Thirdly, a call for better use, dissemination and information on European funds as well as extension beyond 2020 to FEAD is remarkable and positive. Lastly, the reference to a moratorium on winter heating cuts to ensure that no home is left without supply is essential to tip our vote in favor.

name: Christel SCHALDEMOSE
text: in writing.- All households in Europe should have access to heat and energy all year round.We as Social Democrats agree with this. However, how access to heat and energy for households is financed is a national matter, since the formulation of social policy is generally a Member State competence under the Treaty.Therefore, the European Parliament should not take a position on whether private households themselves or the public sector are responsible for the costs associated with heat and energy.Consequently, we have abstained from voting for or against the fact that the costs associated with energy during the winter period are the responsibility of the public sector, and that the Commission should reduce energy costs for poor households.It is the competence of the Member States to decide on this.

name: Sven SCHULZE
text: written.- I was able to vote in favor of the report on achieving the poverty reduction targets while budget costs rise.The own-initiative report aims to build a bridge between social and energy policies.It examines how far the EU is from meeting its 2020 poverty reduction target.The report sees great, untapped potential to significantly reduce the spending of poor households, for example by directing existing projects for renewable energies and energy efficiency towards energy-poor households.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: in writing.- The poverty rate in the EU is unacceptably high and we should return to the poverty reduction target set in the EU 2020 strategy. Statistics show that most household income is spent on housing costs, with around 11% of the EU populationspends more than 40% of disposable income on housing.The Commission and the Member States must make greater efforts to achieve the goals of the fight against poverty.That is why I support this report, which includes a number of important recommendations in this area.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written.- The report supports the basic elements with which to develop a global plan to fight poverty: guaranteeing access to basic services (energy, water, health, education, housing…) in the face of the predatory logic of the market;the improvement of working and salary conditions on which the well-being of the working majority depends and a system of minimum income that complements social protection to guarantee, in an individualized and effective way, a decent income and life.Consequently, I have voted in favor.

name: Czesław Adam SIEKIERSKI
text: in writing. - The various economic and trade consequences of the current crisis, which affects almost all sectors of the economy, are often highlighted, but less frequent is social issues. The crisis and the accompanying phenomena and changes often lead to an increase in household expenditure on utilities (electricity, water) and other costs of housing, medical care, education and professional development. Trends of this kind are extremely dangerous as they exacerbate the problem of poverty and the risk of social exclusion. This situation particularly affects people at risk of social exclusion and vulnerable groups. Particular attention should also be paid to counteracting the negative effects of the social crisis and insufficient income of households in rural areas, where depopulation is often the result. After crossing a certain border, as well as after the total outflow of people from a given area, it is very difficult to convince people to resettle it. Supporting positive economic and social trends in rural areas is a way to reduce unemployment by promoting self-employment in agriculture and other services. On the other hand, supporting young people considering farming is essential for the long-term development of rural Europe. Particular protection should be given to the unemployed, single-parent families, disabled people, sick and elderly people, minors and, for various reasons, at higher risk of social exclusion and poverty. One-person households, the number of which is growing in Europe, also deserve attention and the development of an appropriate approach.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ 20% of the UK population lives below the poverty line and we need urgent action to address this problem. This needs to be comprehensive and effective, which is why I have supported this report today. The UK, and other Member States, must make more efforts to reach the anti-poverty targets: meeting minimum income schemes above 60% of the national median income in all Member States, a European Energy Observatory and a winter heating disconnection moratorium are all essential tools in this respect.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written. - I supported the Report on achieving the goal of combating poverty in light of rising costs for households, given that it brings some changes to the currently unsustainable energy waste system and is focused on investing in sustainable energy sources and energy efficiency which will result in improved living conditions. conditions and reducing household costs and encouraging investment at the regional and local levels. From 2008 to 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion in the EU27 has been steadily rising and prices in the European energy market are converging, although purchasing power is not keeping pace. The 2012 Energy Efficiency Directive calls on Member States to develop programs to raise awareness of energy efficiency. The report emphasizes that Member States must adopt integrated frameworks to combat energy poverty, adopt a European moratorium on the exclusion of heating in winter, and use European Structural and Investment Funds at national, regional and local level. Also, the report proposes the use of tax revenues from industrial energy consumers for measures to help low-income households, which include measures aimed at energy efficiency and financing of social security systems, which may lead to less burden on labor costs.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - The EU has set itself five ambitious targets in the areas of employment, innovation, education, social inclusion and energy, or the fight against climate change to be achieved by 2020. Personally, I consider the Europe 2020 strategy to reduce the number of people at risk or suffering to be extremely important. poverty or social exclusion by at least 20 million. Unfortunately, the increase in family costs associated with the costs of housing, meals, services (electricity, gas, water), transport, healthcare, or even the costs of education pose a serious problem for achieving the poverty reduction target set in the Europe 2020 strategy. because I believe that the proposed measures and recommendations will achieve better results than before. At the same time, I expect individual Member States, in cooperation with national regional and local authorities, to ensure more efficient, targeted and thorough use of the European Structural and Investment Funds, in order to achieve the goal of combating poverty.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: in writing. - I supported the EMPL own-initiative report, which focuses on poverty reduction in the light of rising housing costs and in the context of energy poverty. Unfortunately, it is a reality that many people in the EU are living in difficult conditions, which is why I welcomed the report, which seeks to draw attention to this problem and aim to alleviate it. However, I have reservations about a number of means that this report offers to achieve the goals. We have been dealing with these matters for a long time, so it is not clear to me what specific, in addition to further drawing attention to this situation, the proposed summit on poverty reduction would bring. From my point of view, I also do not think that we should call on the Member States at this time to tackle poverty by increasing benefits, minimum incomes or housing subsidies. In short, the problem of poverty does not have such a simple solution. I therefore do not consider such a strategy to be effective, which is why I voted against in a number of split votes on this report.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion increased from 117 to 122.6 million in the EU between 2008 and 2013. In 2015, 10% of EU citizens fell behind in the payment of utility bills, and in 2014, 12% of EU citizens were unable to heat their homes adequately. It will be difficult to achieve the objectives of the Europe 2020 strategy to reduce poverty without changes in energy and social policies. The report contains various recommendations, but also calls on the Commission and the Member States to adopt a comprehensive approach to combating poverty and social exclusion, linking economic, employment, energy transmission and social policies. They are also urged to sign a moratorium on disconnecting winter heating and to provide the necessary upfront investment to reduce the energy costs of poor households. The European minimum income framework and the organization of a poverty reduction forum are encouraged. It is worrying that more than 50 million people across Europe today are facing energy shortages, along with growing inequality and dependence on energy consumption, which is why I supported the report.

name: Joachim STARBATTY
text: written.- The Meszerics report identifies rising cost of living in the EU, especially in terms of energy prices, and derives from this a claim by the EU to achieve the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy by expanding social transfer payments and other measures.The analysis is doubtful due to the currently very low oil price and the deflationary economic environment.The solution approaches in the report mandate more regulation, in particular through national regulations on minimum wages and minimum incomes or the right to an energy supply in winter.Fundamental economic questions are neglected.It is neither shown how the claims can be financed nor how the countries affected by the euro crisis are to overcome their difficulties.As a result, I rejected this general catalog of wishes for more transfers and social benefits.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Energy is an essential commodity on which our society depends.At the same time, it is a significant expense for European consumers, with 10% of households having energy arrears in 2015.In the fight against poverty, the European Parliament calls on the Member States to declare a moratorium on heating during the winter months, which will reduce the number of deaths and serious health consequences.At the same time, consumers should be better informed about their energy consumption and ways to reduce consumption and increase efficiency while reducing energy costs.

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: in writing. - The fight against poverty is certainly an important issue that deserves our attention, but I do not see it as beneficial to address this issue in the European Parliament's own-initiative and non-binding report, which has resulted in a set of difficult-to-grasp, often contradictory and unrealistic recommendations that do not reflect national specificities, and social systems of the individual Member States. Measures to reduce poverty, help the needy and other social issues should be addressed by the Member States through their competent authorities at national, regional and local level, so that the different conditions and needs of the groups concerned can be taken into account in each country. I therefore did not support the report on the goal of reducing poverty with a view to increasing household costs as a whole, and see it as an unnecessary and counterproductive interference with the national social policies of the Member States.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: written. - The N-VA delegation fully supports the European fight against poverty, but regrets the approach provided in the report. She therefore abstained. The N-VA believes that member states should achieve European poverty reduction goals, and the Union has a supporting role in this. However, the subsidiarity principle requires Member States to be left free in how they achieve these objectives. That is why the N-VA cannot support a European minimum income scheme. Incidentally, the report opts for a reasonably one-sided approach aimed at increasing government expenditure, without paying attention, for example, to avoiding the 'unemployment trap'. Also in the field of energy poverty, no account is taken of the broader framework and of alternative options for making people living in poverty use energy more efficiently. It is important to make people self-reliant instead of benefit-dependent; benefits should go to those who really need them.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: written.- One of the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy is to reduce the number of people at risk of poverty and social exclusion by 20 million.So far, this is difficult to achieve because that number grew from 117 to 122 million people between 2008 and 2013.A major shift would bring progress in energy savings and reduce the number of people at risk of poverty.Since the beginning of the crisis, youth unemployment has risen to 20%.I support the Report on Achieving the Poverty Reduction Goal in light of rising household costs.I believe that access to housing is a fundamental human right from which many other rights derive.Very often in households across the EU, access to housing and an increase in family consumption are the biggest expenditures and the political will of all EU member states and institutions is needed to solve this problem.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I voted against the proposal.I consider poverty and rising household costs to be serious problems, but the solutions presented would exacerbate these problems in the long term.The only real solution to poverty and rising household costs is to reduce the regulatory and tax burden in conjunction with a responsible monetary policy.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on achieving the goal of reducing poverty in the face of rising household costs.Official figures showing that poverty is on the rise, which is also at odds with the EU's strategic goal of the Europe 2020 strategy, are worrying, so we need swift and effective action.I supported the report because, among other things, it calls on the European Commission and the Member States to do their utmost in the fight against poverty and social exclusion and to take a comprehensive approach to combating its various forms.We must not hesitate in taking action on poverty, but we must be proactive.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The financial crisis that has affected the European Union in recent years and the austerity policy pursued by a number of Member States have led to an increase in the share of the population affected by poverty in the Union, from 117 million people in 2008 to 122 million in 2013. This phenomenon is reflected in the large share of food, housing and utility costs. Regarding current household expenditure, around 10% of the EU population cannot pay their utility bills, 12% do not have adequate heating and 16% live in unhealthy places. Against these worrying phenomena, the European institutions have designed thermal rehabilitation projects for housing, which are an important step forward. However, more measures are needed in this regard, such as the adoption of a moratorium at European level to ban the disconnection of those who cannot pay their bills during the winter, the establishment of a minimum guaranteed European income of 60% of the EU average wage. , organizing a European summit to fight poverty, more effectively protecting the interests of consumers. I believe that this is a very important document, which is why I support its adoption as a first step towards a more elaborate European strategy against poverty.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I spoke in favor of the text which calls on the Commission and the Member States to invest fully in the fight against poverty and social exclusion and to adopt an integrated approach to fight against its various forms by means of a comprehensive approach bringing together economic policies, education policies, employment policies, energy policies, transport policies and social policies on the basis of best practices. We ask, among other things, Member States to sign a moratorium on winter heating cuts to ensure that no household can be deprived of energy for a defined winter period and that those without it are reconnected. , stressing that the resulting costs are by their nature a public responsibility since social policies are primarily the responsibility of the authorities. States must also assess the measures necessary to meet thermal comfort standards set by the World Health Organization.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ Between 2008 and 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the EU increased from 117 million to 122.6 million. This development runs counter to the strategic objective of the EU that is defined in its Europe 2020 Strategy and which aims to reduce the number of people in or at risk of poverty and social exclusion by at least 20 million by 2020. Nevertheless, I voted against this report as I believe the measures proposed will not help in solving this situation. I also believe that some of the recommendations are purely national competences and that the EU should not legislate on such matters.

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- Social policy and energy policy should be closely related.The European Union is moving further and further away from the objective of combating poverty set by the Europe 2020 strategy.families affected by energy poverty.The rise in the income of the poorest households is the basis for a robust and lasting economic recovery.I would also like to draw attention to the fact that the number of women living in poverty exceeds that of men by 12 million and that throughout the Union women and their dependent children are disproportionately exposed to the risk ofpoverty or social exclusion.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - Mr President, I supported Mr Meszerics's report because it raises the issue of poverty as one that requires decisive action. According to data, between 2008 and 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the European Union rose from 117 to 122.6 million. - that's a big number. Therefore, the EU institutions cannot remain neutral on this issue. The Commission should call on the Member States to fully engage in the fight against poverty and social exclusion and to adopt an integrated strategy to combat the various manifestations of poverty. At European level, meanwhile, a comprehensive approach is needed, linking economic policy, employment policy, education energy and transport policy more closely with social policy, based on best practice in recent years. The European Union should give special support to the new Member States, such as Lithuania, in order to reconcile the differences between the old and the new Union in the field of socio-economic relations as soon as possible.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I would support the report on the achievement of the poverty reduction target in view of rising household costs if I voted.The initiative of the own-initiative report aims to build a bridge between social and energy policy in the European debate and to emphasize that the EU is moving away from its goal of reducing poverty by 2020, while the EU has many untapped opportunities to reducerenewables and energy efficiency in households suffering from energy shortages.Achieving the EU's 2020 poverty reduction target and the energy efficiency, emissions and renewables targets requires action by a number of actors through different instruments, but in the same direction.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written. - We voted in favor of this report as it focuses on analyzing household expenditures and the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which aims to reduce by 20 million people at risk of social exclusion. The Report has incorporated four aspects, two included in its general recommendations, which are very positive. In the first place, references to the need to increase investment in renewable energies and energy efficiency to tackle poverty are interesting insofar as they are linked to employment policies, energy transition, quality and affordable housing and reduction of health spending. Second, the text makes references to an adequate minimum income above the poverty line, which represents 60% of the average national income in all the Member States. Thirdly, a call for better use, dissemination and information on European funds as well as extension beyond 2020 to FEAD is remarkable and positive. Lastly, the reference to a moratorium on winter heating cuts to ensure that no home is left without supply is essential to tip our vote in favor.

name: Ulrike TREBESIUS
text: written.- The Meszerics report identifies rising cost of living in the EU, especially in terms of energy prices, and derives from this a claim by the EU to achieve the goals of the Europe 2020 strategy by expanding social transfer payments and other measures.The analysis is doubtful due to the currently very low oil price and the deflationary economic environment.The solution approaches in the report mandate more regulation, in particular through national regulations on minimum wages and minimum incomes or the right to an energy supply in winter.Fundamental economic questions are neglected.It is neither shown how the claims can be financed nor how the countries affected by the euro crisis are to overcome their difficulties.As a result, I rejected this general catalog of wishes for more transfers and social benefits.

name: Ramon TREMOSA i BALCELLS
text: in writing. ‒ I completely support this resolution, particularly regarding the moratorium on cutting energy services to families that, due to their complicated financial situation, cannot pay for it. In this regard, I hope that the Spanish Government reacts and follows this recommendation, as until now its only reaction has been to block the efforts of the Catalan Government to stop energy poverty by declaring its actions unconstitutional.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- The Europe 2020 strategy plans to lift 20 million people out of poverty by 2020. In order to get closer to this objective, certain actions are being considered at European level.This text focuses in particular on the poverty of families in the context of the increase in the cost of housing, energy, and education.Each state is responsible for the policies it pursues against poverty.Thus, the European Union does not have the prerogatives to establish a minimum wage.According to the principles of subsidiarity and proportionality, the Union does not have to carry out policies against poverty in the member countries.The best solution would be a targeted intervention by each Member State to alleviate poverty in its territory.I therefore voted against this project.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: signed up. - Between 2008 and 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty in the EU rose from 117 million to 122.6 million. This development runs counter to the EU's strategic goal set in the Europe 2020 Strategy, which aims to reduce the number of people affected or threatened by poverty and social exclusion by 20 million by 2020. In this perspective, this report establishes a link between energy poverty. and general poverty and emphasizes that this is the result of a number of underlying conditions, including high energy prices, health and disability issues, the type of heating system used in homes and the quality and energy performance of the housing stock. The report proposes, as a solution, the provision of microcredit or low-interest loans, for example through the European Investment Bank, to low-income families, to support their investments in renewable energy and energy efficiency. Another proposed aspect is related to increasing investments in the energy efficiency of social housing, through European funds, and guaranteeing access for all, especially the most disadvantaged people, to adequate housing. I therefore voted in favor of the Report on Combating Poverty in the Context of Increasing Current Household Expenditure.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written. - We have voted IN FAVOR of this report as it focuses on analyzing household spending and the objectives of the Europe 2020 Strategy, which aims to reduce by 20 million people at risk of social exclusion. The Report has incorporated four aspects, two included in its general recommendations, which are very positive. In the first place, references to the need to increase investment in renewable energies and energy efficiency to tackle poverty are interesting insofar as they are linked to employment policies, energy transition, quality and affordable housing and reduction of health spending. Second, the text makes references to an adequate minimum income above the poverty line, which represents 60% of the average national income in all Member States. Thirdly, a call for better use, dissemination and information on European funds as well as extension beyond 2020 to FEAD is remarkable and positive. Finally, the reference to a moratorium on heating cuts in winter to ensure that no home is left without supply, is essential to tip our vote in favor.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report drawn up by a colleague from the green group, which for the first time places the fight against energy poverty as a priority.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- This report's main objective is to analyze the impact of energy policies and consumer prices and their impact on the increase in poverty on the most socially disadvantaged groups.The report aims to find the best way to deal with the difficulties of households facing poverty and sets out a series of measures necessary to be able to fight poverty.For this reason, I consider it necessary to vote in their favor.

name: Elena VALENCIANO
text: written. - I voted in favor of this Report because it represents a qualitative leap for Parliament in the fight against poverty, inequality and social exclusion. This resolution brings together social protection policies, the right to decent housing and the fight against energy poverty, in a compendium of recommendations that update and innovate the positions of the European Parliament in the fight against poverty. After eight years of economic and financial crisis, data on inequality and poverty in Europe have not only not remitted but have worsened, especially in southern countries, such as Spain, where inequality conditions are worse than in any other country of the continent after four years of government of the Popular Party. That is why the need to act with innovative policies is highlighted, such as the moratorium against the disconnection of heating in the winter months, the establishment of a minimum income system by countries that guarantees a decent income, although in this case the liberal groups and chamber conservatives have nuanced this end.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- The introduction of a European moratorium on shutting off the heating during the winter months can protect vulnerable families from social exclusion.But to limit the risk of energy poverty, support for structural measures, such as making homes energy efficient, is necessary.In this way, a bridge can be built between the energy policy and the social policy of the European Union.That is why I voted for this report.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - Between 2008 and 2013, the number of people at risk of poverty or social exclusion in the European Union rose from 117 million to 122.6 million, or 16.7% of the population. This development runs counter to the objective defined in the Europe 2020 strategy of reducing the number of people affected or threatened by poverty by at least 20 million by 2020. The adopted report calls on the Commission and the Member States to adopt a comprehensive approach to fight poverty by bringing together social, economic, education, employment, energy and transport policies, and to sign a moratorium on heating cuts in winter. It also recommends carrying out an impact analysis on minimum income schemes in the European Union and making better use of structural funds. This own-initiative report does a fairly good analysis of the situation. It is unfortunate that this is only wishful thinking that does not call into question the very origin of this development: austerity policies. I voted in favor of the report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The report focuses, in the current context of poverty, on the deprivations that households are faced with, failing to make ends meet with housing expenses - where electricity, gas and water stand out (which have been increase, as a result of privatization and deregulation practices). Accordingly, the report promotes a series of support measures: to reduce energy expenditure and to invest in savings measures; guaranteeing a minimum income for each person; and a strengthening of EU funds for the fight against poverty and social inclusion. It also mentions the importance of access to public services and the right to water as something alienable. Thus, it is considered that the report has essentially positive factors, despite the framework (Europe 2020, European Semester), but that it is not valued as such throughout it. The group proposes to vote in favor, and it is proposed to vote in favor as well.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The report aims at areas that are far outside the EU's contractually guaranteed powers.Therefore it is to be rejected.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ As an anti-austerity politician, I am delighted by the adoption of this report setting out a programme to tackle poverty and rising household costs across Europe. The report represents a step towards the European pillar of social rights, and affirms that there can be no fight against poverty without a fight against gender inequality.  As a lead on the report on behalf of the Women’s Rights Committee, I particularly welcome the inclusion of a strong gender perspective. The financial crisis and subsequent austerity measures can be seen to negatively affect women more than men, causing a feminisation of poverty.  When women do not have enough money to pay the bills, it is their dependents who also suffer, particularly children and elderly relatives. Women are more likely to be in precarious employment, so managing household budgets to ensure that children are warm, clothed and fed can be very challenging when energy and other utility costs are high. The U.K. is the world’s 6th richest country and it is scandalous that so many of our youngest citizens are living in poverty. When a child goes to school hungry they cannot concentrate so their education suffers. That is why a holistic approach to energy policy is required.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing.- The Union has few competences in the social field.Therefore, its measures against poverty are ineffective.The social systems of many Member States are based on a subsistence level, which should cover the costs of accommodation, food, energy, medicine and the like.But the amount calculated by officials is sometimes not enough to preserve the human dignity of those living in poverty.The solution is not to divide poverty into energy, food, health and other, as this report does.Thinking about social policy needs to change.Set minimum standards for a dignified life.To give every EU citizen a roof over their head, food, clothes and the necessary healthcare.If we can ensure this for the poor of Syria, we must also be able to take care of our own citizens.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: written.- One of the great challenges of the Europe 2020 Strategy is to reduce inequality, improve social and labor rights and strengthen legislation against discrimination.All these phenomena have been strengthened since the beginning of the crisis and continue to increase.Currently, one in six European citizens lives in poverty or at risk of poverty.For all these reasons, I support this report, which studies the impact of energy policies and consumer prices on poverty and whose objective is to analyze what is the best way to combat the difficulties faced by this profile of households and apply the best measures toit.

name: Flavio ZANONATO
text: in writing. - I believe that the report on combating poverty is fundamental. Since the start of the crisis, the number of people in poverty in Europe has increased from 117 million to 122 million. These large-scale data are also reflected in a small way in the city I come from, Padua: think for example of the fact that in the last two years the number of users of Caritas has increased by 39%. Fighting poverty is a political commitment. This is why I actively participated in the drafting of the text, presented by my colleague from the S & amp; D group Ruza Tomasic, presenting a series of amendments. In particular, I underline the importance of articles dedicated to housing, which commit Member States and European institutions to formulate concrete proposals to solve the serious problem of public housing. Too many families, in fact, live today in conditions of hardship due to too small or unhealthy homes. The Group of Socialists and Democrats will ensure that these commitments are respected both at European level and in the various Member States.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- The report on achieving the goal of reducing poverty in the face of rising household costs, which I supported, finds that inadequate housing and insufficient heating have a detrimental effect on human health, education and inclusion in society and the labor market, especially the most vulnerable.Poverty and social exclusion need to be tackled holistically, through economic, employment, energy transfer and social policies, taking into account established good practice.

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing.- This report addresses one of the nerve centers of development policies: the role of the private sector in the framework of these policies.This relationship is, in our view, extremely skewed in favor of the private sector and corporate profit, described as the panacea for all ills.This view of the economy also touches on sectors such as essential public services.Because of the incompatibility of these positions with our political program, I would have decided to vote against.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: written. - I voted against this report on the private sector and development. Among other points that we reject, the report asks the European Commission to support and finance development cooperation policies that give the private sector a predominant role through what are known as public-private alliances. We are once again facing a defense of the privatization of development policies using the funds that the EU allocates for cooperation as instruments to enable new fields of business for the private sector with public money. Despite the fact that the report includes some amendments presented by our political group demanding the participation and consultation of civil society organizations or the need for member states to implement the UN Guiding Principles on Human Rights and Business in their national plans We reject outright that development cooperation is oriented towards the achievement of benefits by the private sector.

name: Louis ALIOT
text: in writing.- I voted against this motion for a resolution on the private sector and development.I am indeed deeply opposed to public-private partnership in the context of development.I consider that in this configuration there is a high level of corruption and consequently that these contributions do not constitute aid to the beneficiary population.This text is moreover completely disconnected from realities since, in addition to wanting to considerably increase the funds which are already high, the vision here is to tackle the European economic scheme in developing countries while we know the low level of results ofthis one.In addition, the text omits to speak of the main development problems such as natural resources, which are a major issue in this context, financial expropriation, the sovereignty of the States concerned.I therefore opposed this text.

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: in writing. ‒ Whilst I support the principle of international development and recognise the role which the private sector can play in creating progress, this report leans far too heavily on the Commission to achieve this goal and I therefore voted against the final resolution. However, I supported some amendments, specifically those respecting the sovereign rights of nations and the amendment on the need to improve the financial sector in developing nations.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because I believe that the role of the private sector in development needs to be reassessed.It is important to integrate businesses into development aid, as population growth and increased incomes in the countries concerned are expected to lead to a strong growth of the global middle class and indeed a significant increase in the level of consumption..

name: Zigmantas BALČYTIS
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this proposal on private sector and development. In developing countries, population and income growth should lead to global middle-class population growth, which is expected to reach 5 billion by 2030, leading to a significant increase in consumption. In 2030, demand for food, water and energy is projected to increase by 50% and 40% respectively. and 30 percent. One of the most important aspects of the EU's added value to the private sector agenda is its political weight and its reputation for dialogue with partner governments and local authorities. Although communication is still unclear at the level of commitments to be made, Country Strategy Papers, National Indicative Programs and budget support can be the most valuable tools in initiating business environment reforms in partner countries.

name: Gerard BATTEN
text: in writing. ‒ This report is something UKIP supports in essence and would advocate on a national level. The increase in the private sector in developing nations has led to positive results for the poorest nations and people. Unfortunately, due to a matter of principle we cannot support this report because of the heavy inclusion of the Commission and the EU which UKIP are principally against.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: in writing.- I opposed this report which enjoins the Member States of the European Union to disburse more than two billion dollars in aid to develop the private sector in Africa, whose role in development is considered crucial.In addition to the weight of this aid for European taxpayers, the report focuses on a concept of unlimited growth which we are well placed to know is only an illusion.In addition, the report does not foresee anything to respond to the vagaries of significant economic growth, such as increased demands for water or energy.Finally, nothing is said about problems specific to Africa, such as land expropriation or corruption.This text, an attempt to interfere with African states, only aims to place the Western economic pattern on these developing countries, at a time when the West perceives its limits.

name: Hugues BAYET
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which emphasizes that private sector investment in development can contribute to the achievement of the United Nations sustainable development goals.But the report also considers that to this end, the private sector should make commitments with regard to good governance, poverty reduction and wealth creation through sustainable investments, the reduction of inequalities as well asaction in favor of human rights, environmental standards and the empowerment of local economies.The report also underlines the importance of supporting the local private sector in developing countries through, for example, access to finance and action in favor of entrepreneurship.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of the Deva report on the private sector and development. This is an important text that effectively underlines the strong and positive link that exists between public investment, private investment and development in many international contexts.
