The full realization of the new Sustainable Development Goals, presented by the United Nations in 2015, constitutes an important test bed to demonstrate how a virtuous collaboration between public and private entities can guarantee a reduction in the poverty index and a positive growth of small and medium-sized enterprises. The European Union can do a lot in this context thanks to the experience it has gained over the years in supporting the business world. The launch of public-private partnerships at local and regional level in the agri-food sector, in training programs and in professional health care programs can be a model for many poor countries on the road to development. Through its experience, the EU can play a fundamental role of facilitation and mediation in many contexts, setting up appropriate sectoral and multilateral platforms which, involving NGOs, governments, businesses and civil society, can overcome the unintended difficulties that can arise in collaboration between different realities.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: written.- We have voted AGAINST this Report for various reasons.The report welcomes the Commission's initiative that endorses the private sector as an important partner in achieving development, while recognizing that private sector investment in developing countries can contribute to the achievement of theUnited Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDG).On the other hand, the report asks the Commission to promote the support and financing of the development mechanism aimed at the private sector, mixing the latter with the public sector, in order to take advantage of private flows with public money.These mechanisms are profit-oriented, not aligned with the principles of development effectiveness and have no impact on poverty reduction and the achievement of the SDGs.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: in writing. - This report is based on the role of the private sector in the development of African countries, in particular, and it estimates that the necessary aid should be greater than more than US $ 2 billion potentially coming from the coffers of our States , unless we further develop public-private partnerships. The main option proposed is unbridled growth when the economic or ecological situation makes this impossible and a continually rising curve is unlikely. It is believed that development sectors conducive to development are mainly energy, electricity or transport. The text also insists on bureaucratic problems or on important issues such as sustainable development, which is obviously not enough for the development of the countries concerned. This text actually seeks to model a globalized governance model and policies that have not worked for other countries (what about state sovereignty?) But for example forgets to deal with problems of corruption or natural resources. I therefore voted against.

name: Mara BIZZOTTO
text: in writing.- The report on the private sector and development, while resulting in some passages that can be fully shared, is overall not very transparent.In fact, all the details on the roles, skills and powers of the various key players in projects of interest to our territories are missing.For this and other unclear passages, I preferred to abstain from voting.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which deals with the private sector and development. In developing countries, population and income growth should lead to global middle-class population growth, which is expected to reach 5 billion by 2030, leading to a significant increase in consumption. In 2030, demand for food, water and energy is projected to increase by 50% and 40% respectively. and 30 percent. In this sector, total value is increasingly seen not as an expression of philanthropy but as a way to achieve economic success. In developing countries, private sector investment in energy, electricity and transport projects is projected to generate mostly double-digit returns. Small, medium and micro-enterprises in developing countries face a much stricter regulatory burden than the EU, often operate in the shadow economy and lack legal protection. Based on the 2014 The World Bank's Business report is the biggest regulatory burden in the poorest countries. In order for businesses to thrive, priority should be given not only to cutting red tape and improving the general business environment, but also to creating an environment conducive to private initiative, the inclusion and maintenance of small, medium and micro-enterprises in the formal economy.

name: Andrea BOCSKOR
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries. That is why I voted in favor of the report.

name: Franc BOGOVIČ
text: in writing.- I also supported the Report on the Private Sector and Development prepared by the Committee on Development.The private sector provides about 90% of jobs in developing countries.It is therefore an important partner in the fight against poverty.With the necessary innovations in low-carbon, resource-efficient solutions, it will play an important role in the sustainable growth of the green economy in developing countries.The European Commission places special emphasis on strengthening local micro, small and medium-sized enterprises.It provides significant grants for a number of activities and services and takes care of appropriate reforms to strengthen and develop the private sector.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: written.- I support this Report on the Private Sector and Development.The role of the private sector in development has been increasing in recent years, with the aim of growing the middle class in developing countries.In new global challenges, such as climate change, the private sector can play a key role as private individuals can bring expertise, innovation and efficiency to policy development.However, the role of the private sector is also full of responsibilities and development goals must not be distorted.

name: Steeve BRIOIS
text: in writing.- I voted against this motion for a resolution on the private sector and development.I am indeed deeply opposed to public-private partnership in the context of development.I consider that there is, in this configuration, a high level of corruption and consequently that these contributions do not constitute aid to the beneficiary population.This text is, moreover, completely disconnected from realities since, in addition to wanting to considerably increase the funds which are already high, the vision here is to tackle the European economic scheme in developing countries while we know the low level ofresults of it.In addition, the text omits to speak of the main development problems such as natural resources, which are a major issue, financial expropriation and the sovereignty of the states concerned.I therefore opposed this text.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: signed up.- Private investment in the public sector contributes to increasing the efficiency of public investment.Public-private partnerships in the field of development have successfully contributed to reducing the poverty of the most marginalized.Support for development partnerships through coordination between Member States and international organizations and the private sector is an important impetus for the economies of developing countries.Micro-enterprises can play a key role in development strategies due to their characteristics in order to adapt more easily to market needs.I voted in favor of this report because I am convinced that promoting private initiatives in developing countries creates an attractive environment for investment.

name: Gianluca BUONANNO
text: in writing.- The report highlights several aspects, which can also be shared in part, of the importance of the private sector within EU development and cooperation initiatives and projects;the transition concerning the agricultural sector (with the specific reference to the preventive involvement of resident populations) and the development of social services is largely sustainable;too "general" the invitation and the modalities of involvement of the EIB (European Investment Bank) whose actual activity does not have much feedback and yet another call for cooperation from developing countries, still too weak.However, lacking the necessary prerequisite on the balance sheet of existing activities (relegated to a few lines in the introduction) that can justify a new impulse regarding the involvement of the private sector, I abstained.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: signed up. - It is necessary to identify new sustainable and effective tools to invest in the growth and development of people and businesses, with industrialization being an engine of well-being and development. I support the expansion of the private sector in order to ensure individual freedom and economic efficiency. Social security or insecurity are considered fundamental social problems. From an economic point of view, the security of individuals is influenced by their financial independence, in other words, lack of income, poverty automatically attract and the feeling of insecurity. It is widely acknowledged that having a decent job is the best way out of poverty. The private sector provides about 90% of jobs in developing countries and is therefore a key partner in the fight against poverty. Full and productive employment, as well as decent work, including the implementation of labor standards, are essential for tackling inequality and social exclusion. The new agenda should aim at eradicating poverty in all its forms and achieving sustainable development in a balanced and integrated way.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - Today I voted in favor of this report to ensure a stronger role for the private sector in development cooperation. I welcome the Commission's initiative to support the private sector in becoming, together with other governmental and non-governmental development organizations and inclusive business models such as cooperative and social enterprises, an important partner in achieving inclusive and sustainable development in the framework of the United Nations Millennium Development Goals, which presupposes a commitment by the private sector to good governance, poverty reduction and wealth creation through sustainable investment, as well as the reduction of inequalities, the promotion of human rights human and environmental standards and the empowerment of local economies. I stress the need to see how the private sector can be further involved in the framework of the European Neighborhood Policy, to help create economic growth and jobs in Europe's neighborhood, for example through access to capital. I believe that the public and private sectors are most effective when they work together to create a healthy environment for business investment and activity and lay the foundations for economic growth.

name: Alberto CIRIO
text: in writing.- I could only agree with the content of this report, especially aware of the importance that the private sector has towards the development of third countries and that it brings numerous advantages in the most disparate sectors (from employment to agricultural production)becoming an essential partner in the fight against poverty.The intent of this report is to establish a framework for action that will give a stronger role to the private sector in developing countries and to make it a major player in the economic and social growth of these countries.I therefore totally agree, especially when the premises of this document are to aim for inclusive growth and to create decent employment.In fact, I believe that involving the European and international business sector is the fundamental premise for achieving sustainable development.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: in writing. ‒ The private sector can be an engine of inclusive growth by generating decent jobs, contributing public revenue and providing affordable goods and services. If it invests in suitable innovation and business models, it can also improve poor people’s lives by boosting their productive activities. The Commission assists developing countries in their economic reforms and private sector development initiatives.

name: Jane COLLINS
text: in writing. – This report is something UKIP supports in essence and would advocate on a national level. The increase in the private sector in developing nations has led to positive results for the poorest nations and people. Unfortunately, due to a matter of principle we cannot support this report because of the heavy inclusion of the Commission and the EU which UKIP are principally against.

name: Therese COMODINI CACHIA
text: in writing. ‒ The cooperative sector worldwide has about 800 million members in over 100 countries and is estimated to account for more than 100 million jobs around the world. I believe that all partnerships and alliances with the private sector must focus on shared value priorities that align business goals with the EU’s development objectives. In this respect, the EU has a fundamental role as a facilitator and coordinator. We need to strengthen the role of the private sector in implementing the future Sustainable Development Goals, based on the aid effectiveness principle supported through EU added value towards achieving these same goals.

name: Javier COUSO PERMUY
text: written. - I voted against this report on the private sector and development. Among other points that we reject, the report asks the European Commission to support and finance development cooperation policies that give the private sector a predominant role through what are known as public-private alliances. We are once again facing a defense of the privatization of development policies using the funds that the EU allocates for cooperation as instruments to enable new fields of business for the private sector with public money. Despite the fact that the report includes some amendments presented by our political group demanding the participation and consultation of civil society organizations or the need for member states to implement the UN Guiding Principles on Human Rights and Business in their national plans We reject outright that development cooperation is oriented towards the achievement of benefits by the private sector.

name: Andrea COZZOLINO
text: in writing. - The public sector today provides an important part of the aid granted in order to promote the sustainable economy in developing countries. However, in these countries the private sector accounts for 90% of jobs and the same percentage of wages. Therefore, even if the interventions emanating from governments remain an important tool of development policy, the role of the private sector should be further considered. For example, in these countries, it would be useful to promote partnerships based on cooperation between private and public actors. However, although private actors have played and continue to play a key role in the economy of these countries, they should ensure an ecologically sustainable economic model and a model that fosters the economic empowerment of women. The European Parliament resolution on the private sector and development recognizes and encourages, on the one hand, the role of private actors in development policy but, on the other, determines the conditions to be respected for greater coordination with private actors. Seeing these recommendations as important, I voted in favor of the resolution on the private sector and development.

name: Andi CRISTEA
text: signed up.- Globally, there is no significant project that has not been done in a public-private partnership.I voted in favor of SMEs in developing countries facing greater constraints than those within the European Union.Creating an enabling environment, as well as maintaining them in the formal economy, is a priority.

name: Edward CZESAK
text: in writing. - The report responds to the Commission communication "A greater role for the private sector in achieving sustainable and inclusive growth in developing countries" adopted on 13 May 2014. The document highlights the essential role that the private sector can play in achieving the goals of our development strategy. a situation where the estimated amount of resources needed annually in developing countries is USD 2.4 billion more than the amounts currently spent. The private sector drives prosperity and economic growth in any market economy and creates 90% of jobs and income, and produces 84% ​​of GDP in developing countries. The report focuses primarily on potential public-private partnerships in areas ranging from infrastructure, energy and water management to other sectors where public funding is insufficient, such as healthcare or education, support for local private sector in developing countries, and extending the mandate of the European Investment Bank to lend to third countries and combine EU funding instruments in general. With this in mind, I voted in favor of the report.

name: Viorica DĂNCILĂ
text: signed up.- As the private sector is the engine of economic growth in all market economies, I believe it is necessary to consider how it can be more involved in sectors such as agriculture, education, green technologies, research and innovation, health services.and property rights, sectors that remain largely untapped.

name: Michel DANTIN
text: in writing.- This own-initiative report sets up an action framework to strengthen the role of the private sector in developing countries, with a view to achieving inclusive and sustainable growth.Considering that the private sector has a key role in the development and growth of States, and in particular of developing countries, I supported this report.

name: Rachida DATI
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report on the private sector and development because it aims, in particular, to strengthen the capacities of cooperatives, micro-enterprises and local SMEs and to involve them in the dialogue on the policies to be followed.The report also notes the importance of putting in place anti-corruption measures, ensuring good governance and the rule of law and thus enabling the development of the private sector.

name: Andor DELI
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: In written form. - I supported the report of my colleague Deva, because I, like him, think that private initiative is the main engine for the development of an economy. Support for it in developing countries will accelerate the removal of these countries from the list of developing countries and their inclusion in the list of developed countries. The problem is also noted here that aid is almost always received by large companies, and SMEs are usually exposed to more regulation and pressure, and at the same time they employ more than half of those employed in these countries, which is a problem that needs to be addressed. to pay serious attention. An example is shown of how investments can be attracted in these countries, namely through public-private partnerships - a way that has shown its effectiveness. I hope that the measures in the report will help these countries.

name: Norbert ERDŐS
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: in writing. - Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (MSMEs) are the backbone of all market economies, but face much heavier regulatory burdens in developing countries than in the European Union. The private sector is the engine of wealth creation and economic growth in all market economies, generating 90% of jobs and income in developing countries; it also represents 84% ​​of the GDP of developing countries and has the capacity to create a sustainable basis for the mobilization of domestic resources, reducing inequalities. I therefore agree that private investment in developing countries, if properly regulated, can contribute to the achievement of the UN Sustainable Development Goals, and the Commission should continue to be engaged in the debates on Agenda 2030, while recognizing the diversity of the sector private sector and the challenges of poverty reduction for the most marginalized and the most difficult to achieve.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - In general, the report shows greater concern with creating favorable conditions for companies in developing countries than with supporting sovereign development and free from the constraints of the “outstretched hand”. There is also an undisguised neocolonialist and neoliberal vision. Public-Private Partnerships (PPP) appear as an inevitability, affirming the need to extend them to more sectors of activity. In other words, the idea is to export (impose?) A development model based on anti-social and neoliberal policies implemented in the European Union. Despite some improvements made during the process of discussing the report, this is a bad report. Here are some of the ideas it contains: - SMEs face too heavy a regulatory burden in developing countries (we add: compromising business opportunities for European companies); - PPPs have been concentrated in the energy, infrastructure and telecommunications sectors, “while the potential of sectors such as agriculture, education, green technologies, research and innovation, healthcare and property rights continues, in general, unexplored ”; - Clear and unjustified privilege of the private sector vis-à-vis the public sector, namely with regard to EU support, - Defense of the “modernization” of regulatory frameworks, creating an environment favorable to private initiatives. Among other negative aspects.

name: Raffaele FITTO
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of implementing a stronger role for the private sector for the growth of developing countries.There is currently no single significant development project in the world that does not consult and work with private investors.Furthermore, recent estimates clearly show that private sector investments in developing countries often achieve high rates of return in energy and transport projects.In particular, there is tremendous potential to engage the private sector in developing market-based solutions to agricultural challenges and food security, such as training local farmers to improve farming techniques by increasing their access.to financing.I believe that supporting the private sector is a winning development strategy for the European Union.

name: Luke Ming FLANAGAN
text: in writing. – I voted against as the report is neoliberal in its thinking.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: in writing.- The role of the private sector in development has increased in recent years and is gradually being reassessed.Population and income growth in developing countries is set up to create a strong world middle class population that will require significantly higher levels of consumption.In addition, in the context of continuing declining sources of new global challenges, such as climate change, the private sector could play a key role, as this layer can bring innovation, expertise and efficiency to development policy.The private sector's development roles should be clearly defined so as to ensure full ownership and non-distortion of development goals.

name: Lorenzo FONTANA
text: in writing.- I abstain because, despite some positive points, there are only weak reminders and plans for the future.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: NI), in writing.- I am voting against the report on the private sector and development, as it is not possible for the Union to want to achieve development in third countries and to have funds for it, at a time when Member States are literally one step ahead of disaster andMillions of Europeans are below the poverty line.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of aid resources declining and new global challenges, such as climate change, the private sector will play a key role since these donors can bring innovation, expertise and effectiveness in development policy. However, the role of the private sector in development should be well-defined to ensure that there is full accountability and that development goals are not distorted. I would like to express my satisfaction for the outcome of the negotiations; this is a very-balanced report in which the crucial role of the private sector in development is recognised and positively assessed without ignoring the need to frame their work and to ensure that poverty reduction is their main goal when involved in development. I am especially in favour of supporting efforts to better frame the methodology and services that can be covered by public-private partnerships (PPPs), ensuring access to PPPs to firms not only from donor countries, and avoiding the risk of supporting EU companies through EU development funding.

name: Kinga GÁL
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries.

name: Ildikó GÁLL-PELCZ
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report taking into account that despite the difficult financial situation that many of the Member States are going through, the EU must continue to bet on development and contribute to it.However, in order to achieve this high objective in the current circumstances, we must value the importance of including the private sector in it.The association of private and public aid is already a fact in multiple economic sectors in developing countries, so we must continue to legislate to guarantee maximum transparency and the achievement of development objectives.

name: Jens GIESEKE
text: written.- The share of the private sector in developing countries is around 80%.We have to make greater use of this for the development of prosperity, trade, economic development and innovation in the countries.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: written.- We have voted against this Report for various reasons.The report welcomes the Commission's initiative that endorses the private sector as an important partner in achieving development, while recognizing that private sector investment in developing countries can contribute to the achievement of theUnited Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDG).On the other hand, the report asks the Commission to promote the support and financing of the development mechanism aimed at the private sector, mixing the latter with the public sector, in order to take advantage of private flows with public money.These mechanisms are profit-oriented, not aligned with the principles of development effectiveness and have no impact on poverty reduction and the achievement of the SDGs.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: signed up. - The private sector is the backbone of the economy and public policies must be designed for the development of the private sector, especially SMEs. According to the United Nations Development Program's Human Poverty Index, 1.2 billion people earn less than $ 1.25 a day, and that should worry us all. Poverty can only be achieved through economic development and, in particular, private sector development. I voted in favor of this report because I support the development of the private sector, especially SMEs. I welcome the provision that it is reiterated that the EU has a responsibility to support a fair global tax regime, the imposition of mandatory country-by-country public reporting requirements for transnational corporations, which currently create unfair competition for SMEs in many cases. The report contains many proposals that can bring economic growth and development to SMEs, job growth and increase the income of every citizen.

name: Theresa GRIFFIN
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of the Sustainable Development Goals signed last year at the UN, the world has put forward an ambitious development agenda for the next 15 years with the intention of eliminating poverty and ensuring that no-one gets left behind. I voted in favour of this report because the private sector can and should play a greater role in development in order to help bridge the gap between national development aid and the needs of developing countries. The involvement must be well regulated and ensure that that poverty reduction is the main goal of private companies when involved in development.

name: András GYÜRK
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: GUE / NGL), in writing.- The role of the private sector in development has grown significantly in recent years.However, placing private funding at the heart of the development agenda is a major cause for concern, with no equal emphasis on building a strong and effective regulatory environment.For these reasons we voted against the report.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: in writing. ‒ The private sector generates 90 % of jobs and income in developing countries and is the engine of wealth creation and economic growth in all market economies. According to the United Nations, the private sector accounts for 84% of GDP in developing countries and has the capacity to provide a sustainable base for domestic resource mobilisation, leading to less aid dependency, as long as it is properly regulated. Private sector investment in developing countries could contribute to achieving the UN Sustainable Development Goals if properly regulated. To this effect, the private sector should commit to ensuring good governance, poverty reduction and wealth creation through sustainable investment, as well as to reducing inequalities, promoting human rights and environmental standards and empowering local economies. The EU should promote the local private sector in developing countries, e.g. through access to finance and by promoting entrepreneurship. For these reason I voted for the resolution.

name: György HÖLVÉNYI
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: written.- I voted in favor of the Report on the Private Sector and Development (2014/2205 (INI)), given the fact that the private sector is a driver of wealth creation and economic growth and is responsible for 90% of jobs and income in developing countries, and according toaccording to UN data, the private sector accounts for 84% of GDP in developing countries.The EU needs to play a world-leading role in the fight against poverty and sustainable development, and the role of the private sector is increasingly important in view of budget cuts for support.In addition to public grants and cooperation with the public sector of developing countries, it is necessary to create conditions for private investment, public-private partnerships, involve the EU banking sector and create conditions for private sector development in developing countries and strengthening civil society organizations.I support the above steps in the report that need to be taken to make the private sector a sustainable partner in development policy.

name: Jean-François JALKH
text: in writing.- The report is based on the role of the private sector in the development of African countries in particular.He estimates that the necessary aid should exceed more than 2 billion dollars, all of which would potentially come out of the coffers of our States, unless we further develop public-private partnerships.It is clarified that the taxpayers would probably not be inclined to pay this… The report focuses completely on the concept of unlimited growth, with, as a corollary, the increase in demands for energy, food, water, without indicating of courserecipe to answer these very serious questions.The only option a priori proposed is perpetual "growth" and economic success, through private investment, the absolute goal being growth without brakes, when we know that it is impossible ... I naturally votedagainst this text.

name: Diane JAMES
text: in writing. – This report is something UKIP supports in essence and would advocate on a national level. The increase in the private sector in developing nations has led to positive results for the poorest nations and people. Unfortunately, due to a matter of principle we cannot support this report because of the heavy inclusion of the Commission and the EU which UKIP are principally against.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report which calls for new innovative ways to mobilise private capital in the fight against global poverty as part of a broader approach to development. Estimates of the incremental global spending needed in developing countries reach USD 2.4 trillion per year more than what is currently being spent. I believe the private sector has a crucial role to play in helping people to lift themselves out of poverty. It is the key to sustainable growth and wealth creation. For this purpose, we have to help developing countries create an environment friendly for private initiatives by cutting red tape and improving the general business climate.

name: Philippe JUVIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report, which follows on from the Commission communication which proposes a framework for action to strengthen the role of the private sector in developing countries.The private sector provides 90% of jobs in developing countries, so it is an essential partner in the fight against poverty.It also has a role to play as an investor in sustainable agricultural production in order to meet the challenge of feeding 9 billion people by 2050.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written.- I agree with this report.The rapporteur gives market forces an upgrading and therefore more important role in development cooperation.

name: Afzal KHAN
text: in writing. ‒ I supported the report. In the context of the Sustainable Development Goals signed last year at the UN, the world has put forward an ambitious development agenda for the next 15 years with the intention of eliminating poverty and ensuring that no-one gets left behind.  However, there is a gap between the amount of money that is needed in order to make this agenda a success and the amount that the public sector is able to give in the form of development aid. The private sector can and should play a greater role in development in order to help bridge the gap between national development aid and the needs of developing countries. The involvement must be well regulated and ensure that poverty reduction is the main goal of private companies when involved in development.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: in writing. - It is tragicomic how the authors of some reports try to obscure the true meaning of the text by omitting one important word. E.g. In his motion for a European Parliament resolution on the private sector and development, Nirj Deva talks about how it is necessary to help developing countries, in particular by promoting business development. It is not exactly written anywhere in the text, but it is clear that we are talking mainly about multinational corporations, which this time will treat local people and the interests of developing countries with respect and feeling. Then that people on the left believe in utopia. Nirj Deva also does not mention the word privatization. However, read this part of his text carefully: "Given that public-private partnerships in developing countries are currently largely formed in the energy, infrastructure and telecommunications sectors, while potential in sectors such as agriculture, water management, hygiene, education, green technologies, research and innovation, health care and property rights continue to be largely untapped. ” evil and voracious. But we will still tell them that it is for their good. I voted against the resolution.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries.

name: Ilhan KYUCHYUK
text: in writing. ‒ I voted for the resolution because it clearly recognises the importance of the private sector in development and the primary objective of EU development cooperation in reducing poverty. The private sector has the potential to contribute to a sustainable, efficient and long—term development, because economic development is a key to eradicating poverty. Of course, this aim could be completed only by promoting human rights and by strengthening democracy, good governance and the rule of law. The European Union should strengthen corporate social responsibility, and the public-private partnerships within the post-2015 development agenda should have a strong focus on poverty reduction.

name: Giovanni LA VIA
text: in writing.- Having reached compromises on certain points in the resolution, I express my support for the system proposed by the Commission to enhance the private sector in developing countries.To date, 90% of the jobs in these countries are offered by private individuals who contribute to the sustainable growth of the country, a phenomenon that makes the fight against poverty possible.For the reasons mentioned above, the private sector continues to grow by creating agreements with governments, sponsors and non-governmental organizations (NGOs).Following the results obtained, we can consider the effort made so far by the Commission to be positive and I therefore vote in favor of the realization of new, more strategic projects that contribute to the creation of jobs and the formation of an inclusive and sustainable development.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: in writing.- I voted against this report because it is obsessed with public-private partnerships (PPP).However, I am hostile to PPPs, which are almost always bargains for large private groups, to the detriment of sound management of public funds.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: written. - I voted against this report on the private sector and development. Among other points that we reject, the report asks the European Commission to support and finance development cooperation policies that give the private sector a predominant role through what are known as public-private alliances. We are once again facing a defense of the privatization of development policies using the funds that the EU allocates for cooperation as instruments to enable new fields of business for the private sector with public money. Despite the fact that the report includes some amendments presented by our political group demanding the participation and consultation of civil society organizations or the need for member states to implement the UN Guiding Principles on Human Rights and Business in their national plans We reject outright that development cooperation is oriented towards the achievement of benefits by the private sector.

name: Antonio LÓPEZ-ISTÚRIZ WHITE
text: written. - This report was created to create a strategy aimed at the private sector. It should be noted that the private sector creates 90% of the jobs in partner countries, in addition to representing 84% of GDP and providing a sustainable base for the mobilization of domestic resources. Similarly, it should be noted that private sector investments in developing countries have achieved high rates of return. The report insists that public-private partnerships should be exploited to a greater extent in sectors such as agriculture, education, healthcare, and property rights, among others. Finally, it calls on the European Investment Bank and the EU delegations to use their experience and knowledge in collaboration with private companies to achieve a development policy that counts on the commitment of the European business sector. Personally, I believe that the report should be approved as working with the private sector is essential for development.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: written. - The private sector is an important driver of national wealth creation and economic growth in all market-oriented economies. He is credited with achieving long-term sustainable development. However, sustainable development cannot be achieved when there are administrative barriers and various regulations, as is the case with developing countries. In addition to the barriers present, SMEs in developing countries lack the legal protection that will allow them to operate smoothly in the market. The key is to create a favorable business environment without unnecessary administrative and regulatory barriers for SMEs to get involved in the so-called. formal sector of the economy which would encourage further growth of the private sector. This can only be done with effective and well-designed public-private partnerships that make private and public finances available. Creating public-private partnerships makes it easier to respond to macroeconomic challenges and risks, political risks and achieve sustainable development. I supported this report because it points to the importance of small and medium-sized enterprises and their impact on the economy. They form the backbone of all market economies towards prosperity growth and the realization of sustainable development, so removing bureaucratic barriers and concluding public-private partnerships is key to the further development of the private sector in developing countries.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: in writing. - With the private sector accounting for around 84% of GDP in developing countries, any European Union support for such regions should focus, among other things, on this area, which usually - but not always - employs the majority of all local workers. SMEs (micro, small and medium-sized enterprises) in developing countries are often a cornerstone of the national economy and society, as they provide an opportunity both to provide for their families and to strengthen social ties and thus promote social integration. Consequently, the EU could clearly share its experience, which has already proved its worth, on access to finance (say microcredit, which has proved its worth in a number of countries, especially in Bangladesh), employment and, consequently, social policy reform and the modernization of banking and tax policy. in several cases around the world. I agree that it is also fundamentally important to promote positive and productive cooperation between the private and public sectors. It will also gradually be able to guarantee effective change in education, health, and agriculture and innovation, where real progress is not possible without such a symbiotic relationship. Of course, it is very important to always take into account local specificities, which, as a kind of basis, could also contribute to quality development.

name: Vladimír MAŇKA
text: in writing.- The private sector can play an important role in the fight against poverty and in the development of society, subject to certain rules.The growing population in developing countries will reach an increase in the middle class to 5 billion in 2030.This will increase the pressure on increasing demands on energy consumption and resources, where demand for food is expected to increase by 50%, water by 40% and energy by 30%.All this will require the search for new innovative solutions.In this process, it is necessary to use the potential of the private sector as a source of special experience and a basis for the mobilization of domestic resources.According to UN statistics, the private sector currently accounts for 84% of GDP in partner countries and provides employment for 90% of the employed population.Therefore, it is necessary to look for all ways to facilitate business and create public-private partnerships.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: ECR), in writing.- I oppose the report on the private sector and development for the reasons I mentioned in detail in my speech at the Plenary Session of the European Parliament in Strasbourg on 14/4/2016 and because this report is not complete and documented.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing.- I voted against this text.This report aims to promote the role of the private sector in the development of Least Developed Countries (LDCs).He points out some structural obstacles, such as bureaucracy and even corruption.However, he advocates objectives that are difficult to achieve in terms of public aid to LDCs.In addition, the draft report advocates greater recourse to intergovernmental bodies, which is not an appropriate solution.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: in writing. ‒ I voted to support this report that outlines the significant role that the private sector has in providing jobs and in helping to combat poverty in developing countries.

name: Jean-Luc MÉLENCHON
text: in writing.- The report starts from a biased observation.The private sector would generate 90% of jobs and income in developing countries.But what jobs and at what price?The report notes the weakness of public resources, curbed by IMF loans.Rather than promoting real public policies in these countries, it therefore advocates public-private partnerships.These contracts entrust a private operator with the project management and operation of collective equipment.Behind the legal novelty lies a powerful tool for the expropriation of citizens and public authorities.Worse, the report invites the private sector to participate in the design of public development policies.Finally, the report asks diplomats on the spot to train, such as sales representatives, to sell the concept to African countries.In the end, we are hopeful that the private sector will reduce land grabbing.I vote against.

name: Joëlle MÉLIN
text: in writing.- The report provides for aid of more than 2 billion euros for the private sector in African countries.In addition, the dogma of (unlimited) growth is reaffirmed, linked to that of sustainable development.Endless growth is a liberal myth, our infinite desire will collide with the finitude of our resources.In addition, I believe that sustainable development is an incantatory formula that disguises the madness and the damage of the project.Finally, the panel that oversaw the research and development program includes 250 multinationals, which do not have many rules other than making a profit.Consequently, I voted against this text.

name: Roberta METSOLA
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report, which assesses the role of the private sector in development overseas. Private investment in developing countries, and support for local private sector initiatives, are crucial in the eradication of poverty and stabilising democracy.

name: Marlene MIZZI
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted in favour of the report since the role of the private sector in development has increased in the last years and is progressively being debated. Population and income growth in developing countries is set to drive a growing global middle-class population who will demand significantly higher levels of consumption. Furthermore, in the context of aid resources declining and new global challenges, such as climate change, the private sector might play a key role since these donors can bring innovation, expertise and effectiveness in development policy. However, the role of the private sector role in development should be well-defined to ensure that there is full accountability and that development goals are not distorted.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: in writing.- This report estimates that the aid necessary for the development of African countries should exceed 2 billion dollars and financed by public-private partnerships.However, the targeted development is purely illusory and no investment to solve the serious problems (food, water, energy) is proposed.We are voting against this text which calls for funding projects which will only benefit multinationals, and which will only amplify the problems of land expropriation, corruption and loss of sovereignty of African states.

name: Cláudia MONTEIRO DE AGUIAR
text: in writing. - The main objective of EU development cooperation, under Article 208 TFEU, is to eradicate poverty and must be conducted within the framework of the principles and objectives of the Union's external action. The Treaty on European Union, Article 3 (5) states that the EU's objective in its relations with the outside world is to contribute to sustainable development, solidarity and mutual respect, free and fair trade, the eradication of poverty and the protection of human rights, and that the private sector has the potential to contribute towards sustainable and efficient development in the long term. Development is primarily the responsibility of the State, the framework for development aid must be defined by governments and this task is primarily a matter for the public sector, but it is important to underline that the fight against poverty requires public policies, as well as the involvement of the public. private sector, since it has an important influence on society and development. I advocate increasing private sector involvement in EU development policy and projects.

name: Sophie MONTEL
text: in writing.- This report is incomplete: nothing on natural resources, important issues for developed countries and multinationals, very little is said about land expropriation or corruption, etc.I therefore vote against this text.

name: Claude MORAES
text: in writing. ‒ I voted in favour of this report because the private sector can and should play a greater role in development in order to help bridge the gap between national development aid and the needs of developing countries. The involvement must be well regulated and ensure that that poverty reduction is the main goal of private companies when involved in development.

name: Nadine MORANO
text: in writing.- This report proposes measures to involve the public and private sectors in the development of developing countries.I voted for.

name: Elisabeth MORIN-CHARTIER
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of the Deva report on the private sector and development. The private sector provides 90% of jobs in developing countries. It is therefore an essential partner in the fight against poverty. It also has a role to play as an investor in sustainable agricultural production in order to meet the challenge of feeding 9 billion people by 2050. Given the capacity of the private sector to generate inclusive and sustainable growth in developing countries, in particular businesses, employers 'and workers' associations and organizations, play an increasingly active role in development, both as a source of funding and as partners of public authorities , non-governmental organizations (NGOs). A recent evaluation of EU private sector development assistance between 2004 and 2010 confirmed the Commission's significant contribution to private sector development in partner countries and identified ways to improve future programs and strategies, in particular with a view to emphasizing the creation of decent jobs and mainstreaming private sector participation into all EU support activities.

name: Alessia Maria MOSCA
text: in writing. - We welcome the report on the private sector and development. Indeed, it is necessary for the European Union to be able to further stimulate the investment of private funds in the Community economy. This is because, even today, a deficit of public investments remains and the involvement of the private sector appears to be the most appropriate solution. The European Commission, led by President Juncker, launched a Strategic Investment Fund in 2014 which, already in 2015, was able to generate a significant leverage effect, thus increasing the amount of investments made in the Union. It is also known the ability of investments, especially those in the manufacturing sector, to reduce market-related poverty, creating employment and well-being among working citizens. In the coming decades, global population growth and rising income in developing countries today will generate greater consumption of food, water and energy. For this reason it is necessary that EU actors concentrate part of their investments in developing countries, where even if greater volatility and uncertainty remain, capital returns are surprisingly high and guarantee indigenous populations well-being and employment, especially if oriented towards creation of sustainable well-being.

name: Renaud MUSELIER
text: in writing.- The private sector is, as we know, essential for development.It provides most of the economic activity through its role of investor and job creator.In developing countries, the private sector provides nearly 90% of jobs and is an important partner of public authorities, NGOs and donors.I therefore voted in favor of this text to support the work of the European Parliament in terms of development aid and allow the establishment of the proposed strategic framework to strengthen the role of the private sector, and thus achieve inclusive growth andsustainable.

name: Victor NEGRESCU
text: in writing. ‒ I have voted for this report that will engage European and international enterprise sectors in order to achieve sustainable development in areas such as agriculture, land tenure and property rights, sustainable energy and green sectors, education, healthcare and sanitation.

name: Norica NICOLAI
text: signed up. - I voted in favor of this report, which is concerned with creating conditions for development for the private sector at Member State level. I am glad that the European Parliament is trying to stimulate a sector that plays a key role in terms of economic growth, with private companies contributing about 80% to the GDP of the member countries, being also a source of job creation. In this regard, the report voted on today proposes a series of measures that the European Union and the Member States must promote in order to develop the private sector. It is essential for national governments to adopt development strategies focused on cooperatives, SMEs and small producers, this being one of the provisions of this document. I also welcome the report's proposal to encourage the concept of women entrepreneurs in the strategies of the Member States, by proposing training programs and with a view to improving a long-term goal of the European Union: gender equality.

name: Franz OBERMAYR
text: written.- I voted in favor of the report because it can actually provide new impetus for development cooperation and, in particular, can point out new financing options.

name: Margot PARKER
text: in writing. ‒ This report is something UKIP supports in essence and would advocate on a national level. The increase in the private sector in developing nations has led to positive results for the poorest nations and people. Unfortunately, due to a matter of principle we cannot support this report because of the heavy inclusion of the Commission and the EU which UKIP are principally against.

name: Aldo PATRICIELLO
text: in writing.- Considering that population growth in developing countries will require more investment to support development in the coming years, considering that, according to some estimates, private sector investments in developing countries are often associated with high rates of return, also considered, that the involvement of private investors in agricultural development could be a stimulus for the development of cultivation techniques, encourage employment and promote sustainable development, considering, finally, that greater collaboration between public and private can be beneficial for these countries, I would like to vote in favor of the motion for a resolution.

name: Marijana PETIR
text: written. - I support measures that would bring order and improve the functioning of the private sector. We know that the private sector is a driver of wealth creation and economic growth in all market economies, and it is also responsible for 90% of jobs in developing countries. I believe that fair and progressive taxation combined with the criteria of welfare and social justice has a key role to play in reducing inequality through the redistribution of wealth from higher-income citizens to the needs of the country. A public-private partnership modeled on the business of developed countries would result in a higher employment rate and a better life for our citizens. I welcome the proposal to step up efforts to promote the economic empowerment of women and to establish a support mechanism for women entrepreneurs. All the more so as the savings-driven approach to women's financial inclusion has proven successful. I believe that harmonizing good governance, the rule of law, anti-corruption measures, public financial management and effective public institutions would make progress in the private sector, which means that citizens would live better.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: written.- The role of the public sector is key to achieving the goals of sustainable development.The private sector is a driver of wealth creation and economic growth in all market economies and is responsible for 90% of jobs and income in developing countries.Fair and progressive taxation combined with the criteria of welfare and social justice has a key role to play in reducing inequality through the redistribution of wealth from higher-income citizens to the most needy in the country.More public investment is needed in public services accessible to all, especially in terms of the transport sector, access to water for human consumption, health and education.I welcome the role that foreign private sector investment in developing countries plays in accelerating domestic development.I further emphasize the importance of encouraging responsible investment that supports local markets and helps reduce poverty.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: in writing. - In general, the report shows greater concern with creating favorable conditions for companies in developing countries than with supporting sovereign development and free from the constraints of the “outstretched hand”. There is also an undisguised neocolonialist and neoliberal vision. Public-Private Partnerships (PPP) appear as an inevitability, affirming the need to extend them to more sectors of activity. In other words, the idea is to export (impose?) A development model based on anti-social and neoliberal policies implemented in the European Union. Despite some improvements made during the process of discussing the report, this is a bad report. Here are some of the ideas it contains: - SMEs face too heavy a regulatory burden in developing countries (we add: compromising business opportunities for European companies); - PPPs have been concentrated in the energy, infrastructure and telecommunications sectors, “while the potential of sectors such as agriculture, education, green technologies, research and innovation, healthcare and property rights continues, in general, unexplored ”; - Clear and unjustified privilege of the private sector vis-à-vis the public sector, namely with regard to EU support; - Defense of the “modernization” of regulatory frameworks, creating an environment favorable to private initiatives. Among other negative aspects.

name: Salvatore Domenico POGLIESE
text: in writing. - The private sector provides 90% of jobs in developing countries and is therefore a key interlocutor in the fight against poverty and hunger. The report sets out a strategic framework that ensures that investments made by private companies benefit society as a whole, especially women, young people and the poor. It is therefore necessary that investments have as a priority the creation of lasting jobs, especially for the weakest social groups, and which favor the gradual transition from an informal to a formal economy. By ensuring a more favorable and safer environment for businesses, they will be able to invest more and more responsibly and each individual will benefit from the economic opportunities created by the private sector. I voted in favor of this report because only by making the private sector an active partner in development cooperation will the European Union be able to deliver on its commitment to promoting justice and peace in the world.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: in writing. - Strengthening the role of the private sector is undoubtedly an important activity that will contribute to the development of less developed countries and the promotion of sustainable development. Partnerships with the private sector, while fully aware of the private sector's commitment to good governance, can demonstrably contribute to reducing poverty and inequality, creating wealth through sustainable investment and promoting human rights, delivering environmental benefits and strengthening the local economy. Private investment in transport, access to drinking water, health and education will be key to strengthening living standards and competitiveness and maximizing support for sustainable development. Any support for effective cooperation between the private and public sectors is thus desirable and deserves full support, while adhering to the transparency of this common approach and the fulfillment of the European Union's development objectives. In the future, every effort will also have to be made to eliminate all the obstacles which, unfortunately, small and medium-sized enterprises and micro-enterprises are constantly facing. Great care must be taken with cooperation between the private and public sectors in the field of agriculture, as this partnership will require high-quality and legible legislation setting clear rules.

name: Franck PROUST
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report which specifies the importance of private sector players for development, and particularly in countries beyond European borders.Specifically, annual global spending in developing countries is not high enough and so far too much taxpayer support.Participating in development in areas that need it is a win-win for everyone: for populations and states which are not yet sufficiently integrated into the global economy, but also for our European companies which will find new levers of growth in the countriesin development.Finally, the role of the European Investment Bank (EIB) must be emphasized so that it participates more in the project financing effort.

name: Julia REID
text: in writing. ‒ This report is something UKIP supports in essence and would advocate on a national level. The increase in the private sector in developing nations has led to positive results for the poorest nations and people. Unfortunately, due to a matter of principle we cannot support this report because of the heavy inclusion of the Commission and the EU which UKIP are principally against.

name: Sofia RIBEIRO
text: in writing. - The private sector is the engine of wealth creation and economic growth in all market economies, generating 90% of jobs and income in developing countries, which represents 84% ​​of GDP. This report recognizes that private investment in developing countries, if properly regulated, can contribute to the achievement of the UN Sustainable Development Goals. Accordingly, this report calls on the EU and the Member States to develop a concrete strategy to ensure alignment of the private sector with the development priorities of national governments and civil society in developing countries. The document asks European institutions and bodies to establish a clear, structured, transparent and accountable framework that regulates partnerships and alliances with the private sector in developing countries. At the same time, it calls for the creation, at EU level, of sectoral and multilateral platforms that bring together the private sector, CSOs, NGOs, think tanks, partner governments, donors, cooperative organizations, social enterprises and other stakeholders stakeholders to overcome the lack of trust between partners and solve the challenges that arise from collaborative interventions in favor of development. I gave my positive vote.

name: Liliana RODRIGUES
text: in writing.- The crucial role of the private sector in development is recognized here and assessed positively, but without ignoring the need to frame its work and ensure that poverty reduction is its main objective when involved in development.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: in writing. - This report, which I voted for, takes up a communication from the Commission and proposes a framework for action to strengthen the role of the private sector in developing countries. The private sector provides 90% of jobs in developing countries and is, as such, an essential partner in the fight against poverty. The private sector also plays an essential role as an investor in sustainable agricultural production (and thus attempt to meet the challenge of feeding 9 billion people by 2050 ...). A recent evaluation of EU private sector development assistance between 2004 and 2010 confirmed the Commission's significant contribution to private sector development in partner countries and identified ways to improve future programs and strategies, in particular with a view to emphasizing the creation of decent jobs and mainstreaming private sector participation into all EU support activities.

name: Tokia SAÏFI
text: in writing. - I voted in favor of this report, which highlights the link between the private sector and development policy. It is essential to remember that the private sector represents 84% ​​of the GDP of developing countries and is therefore a key player in development policy and the fight against poverty. This text recommends the development of a long-term strategy with the private sector, particularly in order to stimulate and increase investments. These partnerships with the private sector should be based on common values ​​and priorities, specific development objectives and be managed in cooperation with partner countries. A second axis developed in this report is support for the local private sector in developing countries by supporting microenterprises which often face significant regulatory constraints. This is to encourage European and international companies to contribute to the objectives of sustainable development and to the implementation of standards established at international level. I supported this text since it specifies that public-private partnerships established within a precise framework, structured, transparent and accompanied by a clear distribution of responsibilities constitute important opportunities for the development of partner countries, particularly in terms of employment and investment.

name: Lola SÁNCHEZ CALDENTEY
text: written.- We have voted AGAINST this Report for various reasons.The report welcomes the Commission's initiative that endorses the private sector as an important partner in achieving development, while recognizing that private sector investment in developing countries can contribute to the achievement of theUnited Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDG).On the other hand, the report asks the Commission to promote the support and financing of the development mechanism aimed at the private sector, mixing the latter with the public sector, in order to take advantage of private flows with public money.These mechanisms are profit-oriented, not aligned with the principles of development effectiveness and have no impact on poverty reduction and the achievement of the SDGs.

name: Maria Lidia SENRA RODRÍGUEZ
text: written. - I voted against this report on the private sector and development. Among other points that we reject, the report asks the European Commission to support and finance development cooperation policies that give the private sector a predominant role through what are known as public-private alliances. We are once again facing a defense of the privatization of development policies using the funds that the EU allocates for cooperation as instruments to enable new fields of business for the private sector with public money. Despite the fact that the report includes some amendments presented by our political group demanding the participation and consultation of civil society organizations or the need for member states to implement the UN Guiding Principles on Human Rights and Business in their national plans We reject outright that development cooperation is oriented towards the achievement of benefits by the private sector.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of the Sustainable Development Goals which were signed at the UN last year, the EU – and moreover the world – has committed itself to an ambitious development agenda for the next fifteen years, with the intention of eliminating poverty and ensuring that no-one gets left behind. I am very much in support of this report, which echoes this commitment made at the UN, and it highlights the gap between the amount of money that is needed to make this agenda a reality and the amount of money that the public sector is actually able to give in the form of development aid.  Which is why, in lieu of comprehensive public sector involvement, I support the notion that the private sector can and should play a greater role in the development towards bridging the gap between national development aid and the needs of those countries who are still developing. This involvement needs to be extremely well regulated, to avoid misuse of money, and it needs to ensure that poverty reduction is the main goal of private companies when they are involved in development projects across the world.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: written.- I have chosen to abstain from this Report, and this explanation of vote arises as a critique of the current system of evaluating the work of Members of the European Parliament solely on the basis of the statistical number of parliamentary activities highlighted in Croatia.representative action.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - I consider the private sector to be a key driver of economic growth, and I think that at a time of budget cuts, it is playing an even more important role in development in supporting political priorities. I supported the resolution because I believe that the measures we will take will help to ensure sustainable economic growth, poverty reduction and a higher standard of living. We should also give greater support to this sector because it contributes to sustainable, efficient and long-term development in the long term and generates up to 90% of jobs and income in all market economies and in developing countries. I am sorry that, despite the fact that up to 45 million jobseekers are employed each year in developing countries, as many as 34% of companies in 41 countries admit that they cannot find the workers they need. I am convinced that only a strong private sector achieving economic growth can ensure sustainable development goals that contribute to common progress. However, I consider it essential to promote responsible investment that will help stimulate local markets, better jobs, higher wages and better and more affordable goods and services.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: in writing. - The private sector accounts for 84% of GDP in developing countries and has the capacity to provide a sustainable basis for domestic resource mobilization, which can lead to less dependence on other aid. The report notes that private sector investment in developing countries, if properly regulated, can contribute to achieving the United Nations sustainable development goals. The local private sector in developing countries needs to be supported, as micro, small and medium-sized enterprises may face much heavier regulatory burdens than in the EU and lack legal protection and property rights. Attention is shifted to the regulation and coordination of the private sector strategy towards sustainable development goals and to the achievement of the goals of the own development strategy of developing countries. The report contains a number of controversial paragraphs related to the so-called Public-Private Partnerships, which include education, agriculture and other areas, as well as the Commission's role in supporting the private sector in developing countries. The fact that the private sector is seen as a player for development can also be controversial. That is why I did not support the report in plenary, but abstained.

name: Bart STAES
text: written. - The increasing pressure on public finances and the need for additional resources to address global challenges means that European policymakers increasingly see the private sector as a co-development actor. In line with this, this report calls for more public-private partnerships and the creation of an interesting investment climate in developing countries. However, as Greens, we do not blindly believe in the private sector and the trickle-down effect of private investment in the development sector. Private financing can be useful, but should never be a substitute for public development funds. Public resources and public-public partnerships must remain the first option of the European Union's development efforts.
