Only as a second option and under strict conditions can the Commission call on the private sector. The use of private resources must be transparent and contribute to the central objectives of European development policy. Human rights violations and tax evasion must be avoided at all times. Thanks to an alternative majority, we have significantly revised the pro-business discourse of this report. It now takes into account the dangers of private involvement and provides the necessary security mechanisms. Only under these conditions do we see a role for the private sector.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing.- Long-term support from the private sector is very important for achieving the goals of sustainable development of the regions.The private sector is the driving force behind wealth creation and economic growth in all market economies and generates 90% of jobs and income in developing countries and accounts for 84% of GDP.The EU considers the private and public sectors to be most effective when they work together to create a healthy environment for investment, entrepreneurship and the foundations for economic growth.The EU emphasizes that all partnerships and alliances with the private sector must focus on priorities of common value, combining business objectives with EU development objectives.

name: Richard SULÍK
text: in writing.- I supported the proposal and fully agree with the importance of the private sector in development aid.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of the report on the private sector and development.The private sector is already playing a very important role in tackling the effects of the crisis, but it may play an even more important role in the future.Appropriate regulation to encourage private sector investment in developing countries is essential.This will speed up the achievement of the United Nations' sustainable development goals.Nevertheless, the report made it clear that ODA must remain a key tool for eradicating all forms of poverty and meeting basic social needs in developing countries, and that it cannot be replaced by private funding.

name: József SZÁJER
text: in writing. - In developing countries, about 90 percent of jobs are provided by the private sector, so its role in the fight against poverty is essential. It will also play a key role in sustainable agricultural production, especially given that 9 billion people will need to be provided by 2050. As the potential of the private sector encourages sustainable development in developing countries, the role of private sector actors is also becoming an increasingly important factor in international development. Given that, according to a recent evaluation by the Commission, EU assistance has made a significant contribution to strengthening the private sector in developing countries between 2004 and 2010, building on these successes, the Commission proposes to adopt a strategic framework that could further strengthen private sector ownership. contribute to a long-term strategy for sustainable development in those partner countries.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: in writing. - To develop local economies and further reduce poverty, we need a huge injection of capital. Its current shortage can only be filled with greater involvement of the private sector. Here it is important to involve the European Union, which should provide technical support for European public enterprises in partner countries. I am glad that Parliament's report has so unequivocally supported the promotion of public-private partnerships (PPP), because it is this type of activity that can lead to long-term development based on new and innovative technologies. If we want to provide decent work for millions of people living in poverty, then we must see this as a mutual opportunity, not a problem. The adopted document rightly highlights the need to establish a multilateral dialogue platform at EU level, where the private sector, NGOs, think tanks, donors, governments and other stakeholders could more easily cooperate on development and build mutual trust more effectively. It often happens that development aid is not properly adjusted to the needs or is duplicated by many entities. There is no doubt that the private sector should play a larger and more important role in development cooperation and efforts to reduce inequality and poverty. It is this sector that is the basis for the development of any economy, and business and development goals do not contradict but complement each other.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: signed up. - The European Union's financial assistance for the development of poor countries around the world is a significant tool that has made remarkable progress in many areas of interest, such as health, education and agriculture. However, the assistance provided by the European institutions and the Member States cannot cover all the investment needs of developing countries. That is why it is necessary to involve private partners in existing projects, as this can generate an additional influx of financial or other resources. The establishment of public-private partnerships can be a solution for achieving the Millennium Development Goals, but only insofar as they comply with the existing regulations of transparency and accountability in the field, avoiding the promotion of private interests that may be contrary to public development goals. From this point of view, I appreciate the contribution of the private sector to the development of the world's poor countries, through its expertise, through the spirit of innovation and efficiency. However, I believe that all this must be put at the service of achieving the development goals set at international level by the European Union, while respecting existing standards and avoiding disguised subsidies. This report is just a first step in the right direction.

name: Marc TARABELLA
text: in writing. - I voted for the text. Indeed, as we begin to reassess our commitments abroad, the role of the private sector in development occupies an increasingly important place in the debates. Despite many successes, it is estimated that annual global spending in developing countries is expected to be US $ 2.4 trillion higher than it is now - a burden that the already heavily taxed taxpayer will not be. probably not inclined to endure. As imperfect as a public-private partnership may be, there is currently no development project in the world that is not implemented in consultation and cooperation with private investors. In addition, population growth and rising incomes in developing countries are expected to lead to strong growth of the global middle class, estimated at 5 billion people by 2030, leading to a significant increase in the level of consumption. The demand for food, water and energy is expected to increase by 50%, 40% and 30% respectively by 2030. Now is the time to act.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: in writing. ‒ The role of the public sector can be fundamental to the achievement of Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and therefore needs to be encouraged. This is why I voted in favour of this text. The private sector generates 90% of jobs and income in developing countries. Investing in the development of the private sector can lessen dependency on aid, reduce poverty, increase tax income and create sustainable wealth. The support of local micro, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMMEs) should particularly be encouraged, to unleash their wealth creation potential. In fact, although they represent 60% of jobs in the developing countries, they are often burdened by heavy regulation, lack legal protection and frequently operate in the informal economy due their small size. However, support of the private sector must be carried out while making sure that it is properly regulated, transparent and respectful of all labour laws, and that the support is carried out without distorting local market conditions

name: Patrizia TOIA
text: in writing.- The European Union must work to promote a sustainable economy in the world to ensure the development of a more equitable and democratic society.Particular attention should be paid to the cooperative model which has always promoted a careful and respectful economy of the territories in which the members make the business live.The cooperative movement plays an active part in the development cooperation processes and we cannot ignore it.It is necessary to enhance and support lasting development while respecting local customs and traditions in the credit, food, rural, agri-food, fisheries, environment, aquaculture and social services sectors.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- I would support the report on the private sector and development if I voted.As we re-evaluate our overseas commitments, we increasingly discuss the role of the private sector in development.Despite many undisputed successes in developing countries, they are estimated to need $ 2.4 trillion more per year than is currently spent globally - a burden that already burdened taxpayers are unlikely to be willing to take on.Although the partnership in the form of private and public aid is incomplete, there is no significant development project in the world that does not involve consultation and cooperation with private investors.The High Level Group, which advises UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon on the post-2015 development agenda, consulted the CEOs of 250 companies from 30 countries and concluded that sustainability should be included in corporate strategies in order totake advantage of market opportunities for sustainable growth.

name: Estefanía TORRES MARTÍNEZ
text: written.- We have voted AGAINST this Report for various reasons.The report welcomes the Commission's initiative that endorses the private sector as an important partner in achieving development, while recognizing that private sector investment in developing countries can contribute to the achievement of theUnited Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDG).On the other hand, the report asks the Commission to promote the support and financing of the development mechanism aimed at the private sector, mixing the latter with the public sector, in order to take advantage of private flows with public money.These mechanisms are profit-oriented, not aligned with the principles of development effectiveness and have no impact on poverty reduction and the achievement of the SDGs.

name: Mylène TROSZCZYNSKI
text: in writing.- This report addresses the issue of aid to Africa's development by the private sector.He specifies that the consequences of these investments should be growth for the private sector.This growth would then be unlimited and that is what underlies the whole issue.The intention of the text is in fact to copy the European economic model in Africa and I know all the harmful consequences that this can entail.I therefore follow the approach of my colleague Louis Aliot who voted against in committee while voting against in turn.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: written.- We have voted against this Report for various reasons.The report welcomes the Commission's initiative that endorses the private sector as an important partner in achieving development, while recognizing that private sector investment in developing countries can contribute to the achievement of theUnited Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDG).On the other hand, the report asks the Commission to promote the support and financing of the development mechanism aimed at the private sector, mixing the latter with the public sector, in order to take advantage of private flows with public money.These mechanisms are profit-oriented, not aligned with the principles of development effectiveness and have no impact on poverty reduction and the achievement of the SDGs.

name: Ramón Luis VALCÁRCEL SISO
text: written.- The report proposes that the private sector take a greater role in developing countries, since the private sector is responsible for 90% of jobs in developing countries and is therefore an essential partner in the fightagainst poverty.It is important to promote this sector in developing countries, which is why I consider it necessary to vote in favor of this report.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: written.- I voted in favor of this report, which aims to mobilize private capital in new innovative ways in the fight against world poverty, as part of a broader approach to development.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: in writing. - The management of "public" development assistance (ODA) is increasingly transferred to the private sector due to sacrosanct budgetary constraints. In fact, development policies are increasingly being delivered to the interests of private investors. Although this report calls in particular for an increase in public investments in education, access to drinking water or health, we are pushing for the development of public-private partnerships (PPP). We even go so far as to congratulate ourselves on these partnerships in the field of education when they must be "profitable" and there is no longer any need to recall the abuses and the damage caused by these practices. We even go so far as to propose strengthening public technical assistance to the private sector for the establishment of these PPPs by recommending that the European Union delegations be trained on site for this purpose. Integrating the private sector and the neoliberal logic into the design of official development assistance is, to say the least, dangerous for the recipient countries. Developed states would do better to meet their 45-year-old and still unfulfilled commitments (0.7% of GNI), with rare exceptions. I voted against this report.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing.- This is yet another report aimed at clearing up the real causes of poverty and development, which lie fundamentally in the nature of capitalism and its predatory essence.In making the case for private initiative and public-private partnerships, it is essential to guarantee the maintenance of a system that is not capable of responding to the needs and desires of humanity.Only the overthrow of this system, with its replacement by a mixed, planned economy and at the service of human beings, that is, of socialist society, will be able to reverse this course of underdevelopment, of war and of dependence.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: written.- The call for and the granting of a more important role for market forces in development cooperation, in order to create real change for the people on the ground, is praiseworthy.

name: Beatrix von STORCH
text: written. - I acknowledge the rapporteur's efforts on the private sector and development. One can clearly see his stringent endeavor to limit the focus to functioning measures that can really have a positive effect on the well-being and prosperity in developing countries. The rapporteur is particularly interested in private, market-based and subsidiary aid measures. Of course, but the rapporteur is not to be blamed for that, this is an issue that is of no concern to the EU. The social behavior of economic actors should not be an issue for a parliament. Parliaments determine the regulatory framework within which economic activity takes place. Special rules on the subject of development aid set a different, different framework, and that is not needed. After all, these rules do not have to be standardized by the EU, so that there is a violation of the subsidiarity principle. There is really no need for the Commission to come up with things like a sustainable development agenda after 2030 here.

name: Julie WARD
text: in writing. ‒ In the context of the Sustainable Development Goals signed last year at the UN, the global community has put forward an ambitious development agenda for the next 15 years with the intention of eliminating poverty and ensuring that no-one gets left behind. However, there is a gap between the amount of money that is needed in order to ensure this agenda is successful and the amount that the public sector is able to give in the form of development aid.  The private sector can and should play a greater role in development in order to help bridge the gap between national development aid and the needs of developing countries. However, the recent Panama papers revelations on the facilitation of tax avoidance practices by EU Member States have shown that there must be protections in place to stop the exploitation of developing countries by foreign investors.   Labour MEPs voted to support a report calling on greater investment from the private sector in international development but only if this investment is well regulated and serves development goals, chief amongst which is poverty reduction.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: in writing.- I welcome this report because I believe that the country's prosperity is the result of its citizens' efforts to live a better life.Today, the European Union has the tools to significantly support people's efforts in relation to developing countries.In mutual dialogue, we are gradually improving them, whether it is official development assistance or the removal of barriers to access to the European market.In the future, however, we could pay more attention to family business.In traditional cultures, it is the form of economic activity that helps to overcome poverty the most.The multi-generational dimension of family businesses is also a guarantee of social responsibility and contributes to sustainable development more than other forms of business.

name: Pablo ZALBA BIDEGAIN
text: written.- The private sector is increasingly important in developing countries, where it is already the source of 90% of jobs and, with it, a key pillar in the fight against poverty.On the other hand, this sector is of vital importance for investment in sustainable agricultural production, especially if we take into account the forecasts made for 2050, when the world population is expected to reach 9 billion.Bearing these two arguments in mind, I am confident in the vital importance of the private sector and that it must be empowered, and therefore I support this report.

name: Tomáš ZDECHOVSKÝ
text: in writing.- I voted in favor of this report because I am fully aware of the potential of the private sector to achieve long-term sustainable development.Personally, I believe that the private and public sectors work most effectively when they work together to create a healthy environment for investment, business activity and building the foundations for economic growth.EU countries should continue to support developing countries in raising their own resources, for example through national tax systems, and in the fight against illicit financial flows and corruption, as they lose several hundred billion euros a year.In this regard, I consider it necessary to lay down effective international rules against tax avoidance and evasion.

name: Milan ZVER
text: in writing.- The report on the private sector and development, which I supported, states that the role of the public sector is essential for achieving the goals of sustainable development, as it creates as much as 90% of jobs.I agree with the recommendation that a legal framework and a long-term strategy need to be created for measures that give a greater role to the private sector in developing countries.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item is the Commission statement on the impact of the immigration crisis on the EU transport sector (2016/2653 (RSP)).

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I welcome the opportunity to address with you the impact of the immigration crisis on the transport sector in the European Union. As you are all well aware, given the unprecedented inflow of refugees, several Member States have introduced internal border controls. Though temporary, they hamper the proper functioning of the Schengen area. Because of current security threats, controls are, in addition, being applied to certain means of transportation as well as at borders. The transport sector is particularly sensitive to these measures. Consequently, the reintroduction of internal border controls on a broader and more permanent basis would not only impede the mobility of citizens in the Schengen countries, it would also undermine the timelessness and seamlessness of the free exchange of goods within the European Union. This currently accounts for more than EUR 2 800 billion in value and 1 700 million tons in volume. The Commission has analysed the consequences of a systematic reintroduction of border controls at internal borders. First results show that, in the short term, increased waiting times at borders and terminals would affect passengers and trade. In the long run, reduced traffic and trade volumes would severely affect the economy. Document checking procedures would entail additional expenses for Member States’ budgets for equipment, personnel and new facilities. The road freight sector would be particularly exposed, as prompt delivery is one of the important parameters for competitive advantage, and small and medium-sized enterprises, the backbone of the road transport industry, would be the most affected. With many operating on very small profit margins, any increased costs would either be passed to the end consumers or put the survival of many transport companies in jeopardy. Expressed in numbers, the Commission estimates that full re-establishment of border controls to monitor the movement of people within the Schengen area would generate immediate direct costs to the European Union economy ranging between EUR 5 billion and 18 billion a year. Long—term and indirect effects are more difficult to quantify, but available evidence suggests that re—establishing internal border controls would have substantial negative effects on the whole European economy. The volume of intra—European trade would go down, whereas related costs would go up, chiefly affecting Member States highly dependent on intra—EU trade. 1.7 billion citizens working across borders would be affected, in particular in those Member States such as Slovakia, Estonia, Hungary and Belgium where cross-border commuting is very important. The good functioning of the cross-border labour market could thus be hampered. I believe that these initial estimates clearly demonstrate the serious negative impact of a possible suspension of free movement without internal border controls in the Schengen area, which is an essential element for economic growth in the European Union and, in particular, for the performance of the transport sector. Therefore, closing borders between Member States should be only a temporary measure, and controls should be lifted as soon as possible. In its communication of 4 March entitled ‘Back to Schengen, a Roadmap’ the Commission has outlined its plan and schedule for getting back to a normally-functioning Schengen by the end of 2016. The longer internal border controls remain in place, the more difficult and costly it will be to restore the favourable business environment which the Schengen area aims to provide. As economic actors adapt to the new reality, a return to the previous situation will not be immediate or guaranteed. Please let me assure you that we will work hard to get the Schengen system and the internal market functioning normally again by the end of this year. I am looking forward to hearing your views on the matter and on how we can best work together to safeguard the single market.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: for the PPE Group. - I would like to begin by saying that the migration crisis is really a matter for all EU countries, that is understandable. It is a big mistake for some EU leaders to think that they can avoid this migration crisis in any way. I think we will all bear the consequences of their decisions. I was very interested in the Commissioner's speech, because the figures she gave correspond to other independent studies, and I think it is a great pity that the representatives of some factions on my right, in particular, are not represented here at all. I think that if they call for the closure of the EU's borders, they should hear these numbers. They should listen to what the Commissioner has said and what corresponds to independent studies in the very case of the closure of the Schengen borders, as they are calling for. I think that the loss of the main achievement of European integration - the free movement of people and goods - can be truly irreplaceable. The creation of an area without internal borders, which allows the free movement of people and goods, has brought significant benefits to companies not only in Europe but also, of course, in dealings with third countries. Schengen is thus one of the main means by which European citizens can enjoy their freedoms and the internal market prospers and develops. Unfortunately, due to the consequences of the migration wave, which the EU as a whole has not yet been able to cope with, this system is in jeopardy. With it, of course, the concept of transport based on this system. Border controls and traffic restrictions negatively affect transport on both roads and railways, trade and transport as a whole. I therefore now see it as an absolute priority in the transport sector to tackle these problems. Our goal must be, first and foremost, to address the serious shortcomings at the external borders. Another task is to keep Schengen functioning, as its loss would be really huge, as the Commissioner has indicated.

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Dear Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! Right at the beginning I would like to make it clear once again that this is by no means a pure migration crisis, but a solid European political crisis. We see that when we look at the last few weeks and months. What is the situation like? 28 member states fail miserably in solving a humanitarian emergency which, if it were tackled jointly and seriously coordinated at EU level, would be more than feasible on an economically and politically stable continent like Europe. But as the transport policy spokesman for the Socialist Group, I would like to mention the effects on European transport in this debate. Instead of finding a common solution, some Member States are now starting to cook their own soup. Most of them can think of nothing better than to pull up their national borders again and thereby dissolve one of the greatest advantages of the European Union, the so-called Schengen area. Not only does it fail to find a solution to the problem, but it affects European transport and the freedom of travel of the more than 400 million people in the European Union who benefit from it, who make 1.25 billion trips a year. The economy has long been sounding the alarm, because border controls - as already mentioned by colleagues - delay delivery times, make working hours more difficult for employees and ultimately harm consumers - that is, all of us, because we then have to pay more for them and because we ultimately also last longer have to wait. I would like to give a clear example, Commissioner, of how the negative effects of national border controls are illustrated using the example of logistics. Logistics experts expect additional costs of around 50 euros per hour and per truck, which result from additional waiting times due to border controls. Using the example of the German-Austrian border, where around 8 million toll vehicles drive back and forth in both directions every year, this would mean around 400 million euros in additional costs. Scenarios like these would add up if the Schengen area came to an end, and according to a study by the Bertelsmann Foundation, the entire European Union would have to cope with a loss of 407 billion euros in gross domestic product by 2025. Therefore, the message to the Commission, the Member States and the Council again: A return to a Europe with borders is not a solution, and it does not solve a humanitarian emergency.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Transport is the bloodstream of the European economy. Each serious disturbance in the proper functioning of this sector brings losses to entrepreneurs, causes delays in deliveries, and, consequently, decreasing revenues and rising costs, creating the risk of layoffs in many industries. The previous year and the escalation of the immigration crisis is an unprecedented problem that the transport industry is dealing with in practice. In recent months, I have received a lot of signals from owners of transport companies and truck drivers from the Kuyavian-Pomeranian Voivodeship, who described the working conditions in the Calais area. Attacks on cars while driving, threats, thefts, attempts to break into trailers in order to illegally cross the United Kingdom border are the daily lives of truck drivers not only from my home city of Bydgoszcz, but from all over Poland, which has been a key player on the road transport market for many years in the European Union. I am very happy to finally be able to tell you about these problems here in this forum, where we so rarely deal with the real problems of the people who elected us, whom we represent here. Looking at images from the access roads to the port of Calais and seeing lorry drivers pelted with stones, it is impossible to ignore the fact that these attacks are perpetrated by illegal immigrants. Who bears the cost of these attacks? Who finances additional securing of trailers or monitoring inside trucks? After all, who risks their health and life working in such difficult conditions? Of course, the drivers themselves, as well as their employers, whose daily losses go into thousands of euros. This particular example is only one of the many visible expressions of the impact of the immigration crisis on the transport sector in the European Union. The temporary closure of rail connections between Member States, thousands of attempts to break into the Eurotunnel, massive uncontrolled movement of small boats and pontoons in the Mediterranean, and finally the Member States' gradual unilateral reintroduction of border controls in the Schengen area - this is the present day of the European transport sector. Do we want his immediate future to look that way too? Will concrete action be taken only when, in addition to financial losses, pictures of victims of traffic accidents caused by a lack of proper control over the movement of waves of illegal immigrants across Europe appear on the front pages of newspapers? I would like to call for more commitment from the European Commission, especially for enterprises and transport companies, also in the form of real support for financing investments that increase the safety of transport workers and compensation for losses incurred in connection with the ongoing immigration crisis. We invest huge amounts of money in infrastructure in the European Union. We must help its users in a situation where their safety and working conditions are threatened by an irresponsible and inconsistent European immigration policy. Our task is to do everything to support the Member States on the external borders of the Union and regain real influence on how many people come to Europe. If our external borders are not sealed, no ad hoc solutions will help and the Schengen area will simply cease to exist. The economic costs of such a scenario, not only for my country, would be enormous. In other words, I would like to call on the Commission to ensure that the law that already exists today is consistently respected and enforced.

name: Matthijs van MILTENBURG
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - It must be emphasized that the refugee crisis is above all a humanitarian crisis and that human suffering cannot be expressed in figures, but the consequences for the transport sector are also very serious. In response to refugee flows, Member States have introduced unilateral, uncoordinated, temporary border controls. This affects the free movement of people and goods. As a result, Schengen is under great pressure and we have heard the Commissioner say that, according to the European Commission, the end of Schengen could cost the European economy EUR 5-18 billion annually, which is confirmed by a number of different think tanks in Europe. It is estimated that systematic border checks would cost road transport billions alone. Additional costs in the order of 1.7 to 7.5 billion per year! It is clear that a fundamental European approach is needed to solve the refugee problem, with a genuine European Border and Coast Guard, with a single common approach to asylum and migration procedures in all Member States, broadening the possibilities of legal migration, but also - very important - with a return to Schengen as soon as possible without internal border controls. This is desperately needed to better manage the refugee crisis, first of all from a humanitarian point of view, but also in the interest of a functioning transport sector. I call on the Commission to make the impact of the refugee crisis on the transport sector more transparent and to go beyond those few paragraphs in the road map for a return to Schengen. I call on the Commission to assess the economic damage for, among others, road hauliers, shipowners, ports, rail companies, to discuss this regularly with the European Parliament and to report on it, so that it becomes clear that Europe does pay a price for the current fragmentation of the approach to the refugee crisis by the different Member States.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, I have to say with regard to this debate that there are many aspects that I applaud and other aspects that seriously concern me. On the one hand, I agree that it is necessary to address the phenomenon of migration from a multidimensional perspective in order to implement effective and sustainable solutions in the medium and long term. For example, it is very important to underline the role of merchant vessels, the role they play in the search and rescue of vessels adrift in European waters. According to data from the Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, the Mediterranean is the world's deadliest maritime migration route and - as we know - these vessels are so fragile and so small that it is difficult to detect them with current systems of satellite technology. In this context, commercial fleets and their crews play a role in locating, assisting and humanitarian management for which they are not always prepared, either logistically or professionally, in addition to risking possible economic and legal sanctions both from their companies and from of the authorities of the States when they arrive at port. For all these reasons, it is necessary to improve the capacities of the Member States to carry out humanitarian search and rescue operations, as well as to make equipment, training and action protocols available to commercial ships. That said, there are many aspects of this approach that concern me. I am concerned that the focus of the debate is limited exclusively to issues related to competitiveness and the proper functioning of the internal market. I am well aware that these issues are very important to us, but do you know what is really alarming when it comes to this debate? What is really alarming is the proliferation and consolidation of refugee trafficking mafias, which capture their victims in stations and offer transport services at prices such as 1,000 euros, for example, per person, transporting them in a truck, when they would have much cheaper options, but they don't know about them because nobody informs them. They are criminal networks that take advantage of the desperate situation of these people, and we cannot look the other way when many of them die because of these means of transport, as was the case of at least fifty people who died by suffocation in a refrigerated truck that was found in Austria. They are completely unprotected and lack information. It's a shame, ladies and gentlemen, this is a shame. There is also much talk about the need to protect the proper functioning of the Schengen area. And I wonder: if we are so concerned about the fluidity of movements in the European Union, if it is so important, why have we accepted an agreement with the United Kingdom that scandalously violates the principle of free movement? Or is it that in this Europe of ours the same problems are sometimes first class and sometimes second class? We have a responsibility that we are ignoring, that we are not paying attention to, and this Union is only saved with more democracy and by putting human rights at the center.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we are being asked to debate the impact of the refugee crisis on the European transport sector. Let me tell you, first of all, that this wording bothers me the most. When we count, since June 2015, nine refugees dead near the Channel Tunnel, it is not the rail sector that has been impacted. When, in August 2015, seventy refugees died in a refrigerated truck in Austria, it was not the road transport that was to be pitied. When, in the Mediterranean, there have been 4,000 deaths per year since 2014, it is not maritime transport that is paying the heaviest price. This type of reasoning, which consists of pointing the finger at refugees, I will tell you where it is found: sometimes in speeches, especially from the ENF group! Last week, the rapporteur, Ms Arnautu, from the National Front, presented to the Committee on Transport and Tourism her report on the revision of the regulation on coast guards and border guards, in which she basically told us that , what is regrettable about the refugee crisis is - and I quote it - "that several hundred commercial vessels were forced, in 2015, to turn aside to participate in rescue operations". Let's be serious, the problem is not the refugees, it may still be the smugglers, at a pinch - it is the conflict that is bogged down in Syria and elsewhere, and it is above all the incapacity Member States to organize a dignified welcome for all these people. So, to the Commission and to my colleagues here, I make an urgent request: we cannot decently study the impact of the refugee crisis until we have first tried everything to contain this crisis. On my territory, I can tell you, there is a mayor, Damien Carême, mayor of the city of Grande-Synthe, who has set up a humanitarian camp to welcome refugees with dignity, while, moreover, other refugees in other countries, especially in Bulgaria, are tied up, and in Austria, they even decide to build a wall. The European response must be up to par, otherwise it is a shame for the European Union. We all have a responsibility in the words we choose, in the rhetoric we hold, but also in the actions we do and commit. Therefore, let's stop pushing the bill on refugees!

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - I have been sitting here for six and a half years and I feel that I have learned to think in a European Union way. Don’t get me wrong, that doesn’t mean I’ve risen a lot mentally in terms of experience, but I’ve started to figure out the cunning, manipulative way of selling their mostly bizarre ideas to the public, right, through the minions or maid press - respect for the exception from the press. What I mean? Now, for example, the Commissioner has come here to make dramatic announcements about how much it will cost Europe and European taxpayers, etc., to close internal borders in the face of mass migration. A logical solution would be to stop this mass migration then. Of course, that's not what happens. I can already see it announced at the next meeting - so this is in preparation for it - the only solution is legal migration. Admitting everyone, everyone without restriction, legally. Even that would be okay, ladies and gentlemen, if the countries that wanted them were to receive them, and these perverted, bizarre ideas that they are now preparing, with this so-called debate, would not force them, e.g. To Hungary. Thank you very much. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162 (8))

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- I often disagree with what Mrs Morvai is saying, and this time I have not been able to stand it, and I would like to ask you, Madam Member, what you are specifically based on, the view that the closure of Schengen borders will not affect EU countries?When you ask the Commissioner, how did they come up with these amounts, then I ask you, do you have a clear view that this will not have a financial impact on EU countries?

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: blue-card answer. – I am extremely grateful for the question because this means that the translation was probably improper, so I am telling it now in English. I fully agree that there are enormous costs of closing the internal borders, among others to my Hungarian citizens as well. The answer should be to stop mass migration, but this is not what you are going to do. Today’s session was a preparation to the next session or the one after the next, in which you will declare that all migration should be legal and we Hungarians do not want it so do not try to force it on us. This is all I wanted to say.

name: Andor DELI
text: - President! In addition to the economic crisis that has been going on here for several years and the ever-intensifying competition, freight companies have had to face another problem: the consequences of migration. Due to the increased, frequent, stricter border controls, they are able to deliver fewer goods to the customer in the same time, but at the same time their transportation costs have increased due to the longer travel time. Not to mention unpredictability, time-sensitive shipments, bribing passengers and environmental impacts. For all these reasons, it is very important to emphasize that we cannot allow the four fundamental freedoms and the single internal market to be jeopardized, and the proper functioning of the Schengen system is essential for this. And for that, it is essential that we follow the rules it prescribes. Nor can the fact that truck drivers work in the European road network, with all its challenges and dangers, be neglected. Truck drivers are at risk, facing much greater challenges than before. In their case, a safe work environment has gained new, enhanced meaning and importance. It is therefore important to ensure a safe working environment for professional drivers and the protection of drivers in the transport network, in accordance with Directive 89/391 / EEC on the protection of the health of workers. We must not forget tourism either, as this sector is extremely sensitive to terrorist attacks and the threat of them. If we know that tourism accounts for almost 10% of European GDP, it is clear that the whole economy could be severely affected by losses in tourism. In my opinion, there is a need to create a support mechanism that would make it possible to repair the losses incurred by transport operators, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, and tourism. I ask the Commission to consider this suggestion.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: - Mr President, we are here to see, once again, the high price we must pay in the European Union for a historical lack of policy coordination and the demonstration that watertight compartments and national selfishness, combined, are lethal to our citizens and our development. The absent, erratic and erroneous, intergovernmental and atrociously fragmented, and selfish policy of care for immigrants and asylum seekers on European territory is now paying us a still low bill, but which may mean the beginning of the end, since Schengen It is one of the landmarks of the more united, more integrated and more social Europe that we have desired from its origin. And still, Commissioner, we support today the Commission's intention to maintain Schengen and to fight to reopen the borders as soon as possible, while introducing better formulas for the humanitarian management of migrants and asylum seekers, avoiding the torture of wander lost and mistreated through our territory. And to think that we, the transport, could have been the solution: that we could have established the safe humanitarian corridors that we asked from the beginning, in which transport could precisely have meant a solution to avoid deaths and suffering; that creating, also, a humanitarian airlift from Greece to the countries that pledged to receive the contingents of applicants agreed by the Council, instead of launching them onto the roads and tracks of Europe, would surely have also improved the current solution. But the fragmentation of late and erroneous decisions puts us before our responsibility. We therefore support today the measures to reopen the borders as soon as possible and the establishment of coordinated measures to facilitate transport and its service with the safety of workers and transporters. And we also denounce before the Commission the growing drift of national governments to impose their own rules to hinder the free movement of our carriers and workers. Our call today is to overcome, in the face of continuous errors by the Council, the fragmentation of decisions within the Commission itself. Commissioner, the European internal market cannot be developed by ignoring social rights and human rights.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, colleagues, Commissioner, we are once again witnessing a debate on illegal immigration, and once again it is as if we speak different languages, although there is a translation into all the official languages. However, it seems to me that there are colleagues in the House who do not understand the difference between refugees and illegal immigrants and do not make that difference. All the worse for them, then they are surprised and cry when there are attacks in Paris and Brussels, but these are other topics. In addition to the many social problems and the growing threat of terrorist attacks, the crisis with illegal immigrants is having a major impact on the European economy, in particular the transport sector. International carriers are extremely concerned that, if the crisis deepens, more and more Member States will tighten border controls, and this will have a negative impact on the functioning of the internal market and lead to millions in losses for the transport sector. According to the European Commission, the losses will be between 5 and 18 billion euros, which will increase the cost of transport services and discourage people from traveling in Europe. In order to preserve Schengen and therefore the functioning of the single internal market, we must strengthen the control of our external borders, such as the Bulgarian border, and we must end this hypocrisy for some countries to be admitted to the Schengen area and others not, because for us Bulgarians it is no longer important to be in this space because it brings us nothing. And not to conclude shameful agreements with Turkey and ask it to protect our borders, as we voted today, when we called for Turkish to become the official language of the European Union - a sensible mistake, but another time. Only in this way will we strengthen the free movement of people and goods in the Union. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) (Rule 162 (8)) (Rules of Procedure)

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: blue card question.- I just wanted to remind the deputy that the terrorists were neither refugees nor immigrants, they were European citizens.Therefore, no one here has been wrong.The one who may have been wrong is you.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: answer a question asked by picking up a blue card.- Dear colleague, this was not a big question, but rather a statement, ie.violation of European Parliament rules, but I will still answer you.Welcome to our border, to our border between Bulgaria and Turkey, and then we will talk about who are refugees, who are illegal immigrants, etc.If you claim that the many young men in their thirties with military looks and training are mothers with children, I think you are wrong.But still, welcome!

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, this week we have extensively discussed the humanitarian and political consequences for Europe of the refugee crisis. Putting border controls back into operation will add 18 billion additional costs to transport alone, according to an estimate by the European Commission itself. This amount triples the funds that we are going to allocate to finance the agreement with Turkey. If we add to this figure that investments in the trans-European transport networks will lose profitability, if controls return, and that the saturation of our transport networks already costs us 1% of our gross domestic product today, I want to ask you two questions: what can the Commission do to prevent unilateral, and sometimes populist, measures against the freedom of movement of people and goods within the Union, and secondly, what measures are projected to face these costs that will make the economy of our entire Union.

name: Marie-Christine VERGIAT
text: - Mr President, thank you for the effort you are making to speak in all the languages ​​of the European Union. Yes, merchant ships are deviating from their route to save lives. More than 800 ships saved more than 40,000 people in 2014, mainly in the Mediterranean. We must salute them; they did their duty against all odds and, for their part, respected international law. The UNHCR warns us, however, that more and more ships are changing their route to avoid areas where they might come across migrant boats. They fear, of course, the economic consequences, but especially legal ones, of their military engagement. Thirty thousand dead for the Mediterranean alone since 2000; 3,770 in 2015, an absolute record. Yes, the European continent has become the most deadly in the world for migrants. Italy was able to lead by example in 2014, but the Union only released an additional five million, while the Italian operations had cost 95 million euros. The responsibility of smugglers and traffickers is rightly pointed out. We are freeing up resources, including military ones. These operations are expensive and will have only a limited effect. They only affect lamp workers. The networks of traffickers are constantly reorganizing themselves by making migrants take more and more risks, and at increasingly colossal costs, including within the European Union. This traffic is now their third source of income, after drugs and weapons, and it is often the same people who pull the strings. The more we close the borders, the more we play the game of smugglers. Since 2000, more than 13 billion euros have been used to close borders. With what result? This money would be more useful for saving lives and respecting international law as well as the rights of migrants and refugees. The European Union and its Member States must participate in resolving the global humanitarian crisis unfolding before our eyes. Yes, we must reopen internal borders, implement a large-scale European operation for rescue at sea, open humanitarian corridors for refugees and legal access routes for migrants, so as not to force them to take risks. Yes, if the Member States took their responsibilities by respecting international law and European law, we would not need this surreal debate.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I would like to thank the Commissioner for her report and the information with which I fully agree. I wrote about the possible threat of Schengen in one article in the Czech Republic and our experts calculated that only for the Czech Republic would the immediate abolition of Schengen for transport would have the impact of losing half a billion euros a year, ie. the figures of 15 to 18 billion as an immediate loss in the first year when internal borders are introduced throughout the EU are, in my opinion, correct. There are a number of other things that would happen if the internal borders were restored, it would also have an impact on commuters. Many people work in a neighboring country and go to work every day. This would have an impact on tourism, especially in the case of, say, short-term day trips. In short, well, the impacts would be huge, the losses would be not only economic, but also, let's say, spiritual, because people would travel less, visit less, etc. What is important and the numbers that should still be heard here are the numbers concerning with the credibility of Schengen as such. Research clearly shows that today, a large number of Schengen Europeans do not believe that a large number of Europeans say they would prefer to rebuild their internal borders. In my opinion, because they feel that the EU and Europe as such are not coping with the refugee crisis. I think, Commissioner, when we feel the importance of Schengen and that we must not lose it, you should take into account the views of the public and, accordingly, hold a debate on what further measures to put on the table and propose in the fight against the refugee crisis. . Personally, I am afraid and I feel in the Czech Republic that, for example, the mandatory introduction of refugee quotas will not bring the credibility and faith of citizens in the solution and, on the contrary, will endanger Schengen as such.

name: Francisco ASSIS
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, the partial suspension of Schengen is one of the most negative consequences of the refugee crisis that we are facing. The European Union has not been up to the task of tackling this very serious problem. But when I talk about the European Union, I am not talking about the European Commission, because, in fact, the European Commission has tried to come up with a set of solutions to face the refugee crisis. This cannot be undervalued here. The problem is in the behavior of some Member States. In fact, at the moment, what we have seen is the fact that several Member States of the European Union are adopting behaviors that objectively violate the spirit underlying the European project. We see every day that there are governments in several Member States today that promote a discourse of exclusion, an ultra-nationalist discourse, often a discourse even with a xenophobic character. This has very negative consequences. One of them is precisely the one we are dealing with today and which has to do with the suspension of the rules of the Schengen area. Now, Schengen is vital to the European project. One of the pillars of the European project is precisely the principle of free movement. And before we even do an analysis of the resulting negative economic impact, we have to focus on the essential issue, which has to do with the European project. And this European project is currently being called into question by this type of behavior. But, in addition, this also has very negative consequences, which have already been mentioned here, from a strictly economic point of view and from a strictly financial point of view. That is why my appeal to the European Commission is to continue its efforts - which it has been making, incidentally - to draw the attention of the various Member States to the need to remain faithful to the European spirit.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: - Last month I drove with a Dutch truck driver to England. It was an overnight ride and for me, but also for him, it was actually quite exciting, because despite the evacuation of the camp at Calais, he still did not feel safe. The advice of his employer was: after Ghent or in Belgium it would be better not to stop at all! Indeed, near the French border, we saw the refugees walking along the highway. And incidents keep occurring. Take the month of March for example: stowaways found in a truck in IJmuiden, several collisions near Calais. The list of incidents is still growing. I understand the Commission when it says: "we are concerned about the economic effects of closing the borders", but may I ask you from this place, in addition to focusing on better cooperation in Europe, better reception and registration, also to ensure better protection for workers in the transport sector.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I knew there were problems in relation to the transport sector and migration, but I did not realise that they were as bad as has been outlined – although the figures presented to us are extremely vague. When you talk about a cost of between EUR 5 and EUR 18 billion, is it EUR 5 billion or is it EUR 18 billion? That is a big difference. I think we should be more accurate in that regard. Nevertheless, this is a very serious issue. I know from speaking to people in Ireland, especially in the haulage area – whose annual dinner I will actually be attending on Saturday night – that they have had huge problems going to the continent, especially at Calais. As the last speaker pointed out, they feel their lives are at risk, and many of the things that have happened are absolutely extraordinary. So we have to move to try and deal with that situation in the interests of our own citizens, who are delivering their goods right across the European Union. To do that, I think the Commission is, in fairness, trying to legalise the migration. Without it being legal, you cannot make progress because, if you have a situation where anything illegal is tolerated, then you have chaos. That has been the situation up until now, and the Commission is trying to deal with it. The only way we can do it is if all Member States cooperate.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: - Mr President.Dear colleagues!What are we talking about here?We are talking here that the migration crisis is having a major impact on the transport sector.But the migration crisis will have a major impact on all areas and, above all, on the whole European project.If we analyze the reasons why such a huge migration crisis has come to our common European home, the answer is one: there are huge mistakes in foreign policy that we - we say 'we', I mean the European Union - have made in several decisions in each Member State.years.Migrants come from countries to which we Europeans, let us be honest, have brought war.From the regions where we, our colleagues and our arms companies sell arms.Migrants do not come from anywhere, they are now asking for help from us, from the European Union - that is the most important thing.Thanks!

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - Mr. President, Schengen is definitely one of the greatest values achieved by the European Union.Schengen is not just a smooth border crossing, Schengen is not just fewer rows or practically mostly nowhere even there are rows on the border lines where we have Schengen.Schengen is much more than that.Schengen is a symbol.And that is why we must preserve Schengen and we must preserve it.We have to do everything.The migrant crisis is a great burden.It is not easy for us.We know we are talking about money, we know we are talking about big expenses, but Schengen is a symbol of our freedom.And that is why I expect the Commission, I expect the Member States, to really do everything we can to preserve Schengen.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, we are talking about borders, Schengen and the migrant crisis, and therefore we have to talk about the Mediterranean. The Mediterranean Sea is today the most deadly area on the planet for migrants. Without safe and legal means to reach Europe, thousands of people are thrown into the hands of smugglers and traffickers, risking their lives in boats worthy of the name. We must not forget that the European Union's maritime borders in the Mediterranean are external borders and that, unlike land borders, they cannot be closed or walls can be built there, as many would like to do. The maritime transport sector has been at the forefront of search and rescue operations and, only in the first half of 2015, merchant ships were responsible for rescuing almost a third of migrants rescued in the Mediterranean, putting this sector under enormous pressure. Commissioner, for all of this I understand that the importance of a serious, holistic and concerted approach by the European Union to the migrant crisis in the Mediterranean cannot be further emphasized, as well as to underline the importance of the activity carried out by the European Maritime Safety Agency in this field, and whose role needs to be strengthened.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. - Thank you for this interesting exchange of views and thoughts. Of course, the Commission is very busy addressing the refugee crisis - that is one of its top priorities - and doing everything in its power to act as a preventive measure against terrorism. Today, however, we are talking to each other about the impact of the migration crisis on transport, so let us now focus on that further. The introduction of border controls - it is very clear - must be temporary. This must come to an end by the end of this year, so in eight months' time. In my introduction I referred to the roadmap that the Commission has drawn up and that was presented to you on 4 March last, a roadmap to get Schengen functioning normally again. We have discussed this very extensively and our starting point is - a premise that is also shared in this hemisphere - that Schengen is one of the most important successes of European integration, that we should cherish it and that we will therefore do everything we can to do it. to get Schengen functioning normally again. We know - as is stated in that communication - that the cost of not respecting Schengen, the cost of losing Schengen in many respects, in terms of freedom as well as finances, would be enormous. So our goal is to get back to normal as soon as possible, to lift border controls as soon as possible. In that roadmap, we also set out the conditions that must be met and what Member States must do to make this possible. The Commission will monitor the situation closely, both at the internal and external borders. I assure you we will! Estimates have been made of costs and impact. These come up to an amount between a certain amount and a much higher amount (both way too high), but we will further analyze the data that becomes available to us and continue to analyze new information so that we get a more complete overview of the potential costs for Europe. However high those costs will be, our intention is to bring Schengen back to normal. We know that the costs for the transport sector and for the Member States are very high, that we are all very badly affected - even if, of course, it is not only the transport sector that is affected. However, if we turn our backs on Schengen and let everything run its course, it will also entail very high costs for the entire economy, for the citizens of Europe and for the functioning of cross-border work and other matters. That is why I am once again relying on good mutual cooperation in order to eventually also end this crisis and restore our internal market, our free movement of goods, services, capital and people, certainly in the interest of the transport sector. It goes without saying that all Members of the Commission and, of course, in particular Commissioner Bulc, who is responsible for transport, will continue to play our coordinating role, including between Member States, because that is of course very important. Thank you for this interesting debate.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Oral Question to the Commission by Ismail Ertug, Lucy Anderson, Francisco Assis, Georges Bach, Miriam Dalli, Isabella De Monte, Karoline Graswander-Hainz, Merja Kyllönen, Miltiadis Kyrkos, Bogusław Liberadzki, Marian-Jean Marinescu, Markus Pieper, Herbert Reul, Olga Sehnalova, Claudia Tapardel, Pavel Telička, Kathleen Van Brempt, Wima van de Campa, Kosma Złotowski, Roberts Zīle, Gesine Meissner, Peter Simon, Gabriele Preuß, Susanne Melior, Norberta Westphus, Bernd Lange, Petra Kammerevert, Maria Noichl, Iris Hoffmann, Ulrika Rodust, Arne Lietza, Evelyne Gebhardt, Jens Geier, Jo Leinen, Joachim Schuster, Constanze Krehl, Udo Bullmann, Jutta Steinruck, Martina Werner, Michael Cramer, Jakobäcker von Weizer,on the automatic steering of vehicles (O-000004/2016 - B8-0358 / 2016) (2016/2632 (RSP)).

name: Ismail ERTUG
text: Author. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! First of all, I believe that we were right to put this issue on the agenda. Because, in my opinion, this is an important issue for the future of the European Union as far as technical development is concerned. The automotive sector is currently developing rapidly. While advanced driver assistance systems have been gradually introduced and optimized over the past ten years, the industry has just heralded the next step towards partially automated driving. This year, the first vehicle models with partially automated functions such as the self-parking and collision warning system or the traffic jam assistant will come onto the market. The development of the first generation of fully autonomous vehicles is already in full swing. Researchers and developers are now already speaking of 2020 as the starting year for their series use. In the United States of America, field tests with driverless vehicles in regular traffic have been taking place for some time. So we see that the industry has already made great strides. The potential of autonomous driving is not limited to the automotive sector, it can also bring about fundamental changes for other industries such as logistics, agriculture or mining. A rethinking of urban planning, especially in the area of ​​mobility, spatial planning or traffic flow control, will also be possible through autonomous driving. However, while research and industry are in the middle of the advanced development phase of autonomous vehicles and society is already discussing possible fields of application of this new type of technology, unfortunately there are no approaches, concepts or even strategies for handling and use that are at least externally recognizable at EU level autonomous vehicles. However, there are a number of fundamental procedural and safety-related questions that must be dealt with by the European Commission in the form of regulations, not only because they set the course for future-oriented, safe and efficient transport in the EU, But also because we give our European industry investment security through clear guidelines and framework conditions, strengthen it in global competition with other regions, especially the USA and Asia, create new jobs and keep old ones. In order to achieve this, the European Commission has to deal thoroughly with the following questions and find sustainable answers: First of all, there is the question of what is known as liability. Since the technology in autonomous vehicles will take over the most fundamental of all tasks, namely controlling the vehicle, it must be clarified who is liable in accident situations. Has the European Commission already considered how the current liability rules should be adapted? Then there are also open questions about data protection and cybersecurity. The exchange of data between vehicles, but also between vehicle and infrastructure, must lead to an efficient and safe flow of traffic in autonomous driving. How does the European Commission intend to secure data on vehicles and citizens and protect the system infrastructure from cyber attacks? There are also open questions in the area of ​​infrastructure. Can autonomous vehicles be integrated into the existing transport infrastructure? Or: what adjustments would have to be made and what role should the Member States and the European Union play in funding? And finally: When it comes to type approvals, I see further question marks. Dear Commissioner, Autonomous vehicles require special test and inspection procedures. These will but not sufficiently and clearly taken into account by the currently applicable type approval legislation.With this in mind, does the Commission intend to revise relevant rules such as the UNECE rules?In view of all these numerous questions, which my colleagues here in plenary will certainly add, I would like to ask you, Commissioner, whether the European Commission has started to work out a strategy for autonomous driving in the EU.Would you also agree with me that in view of the economic and social importance of this topic, the preparation of a Green Paper on autonomous driving is more than overdue?

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, connected, cooperative and automated driving offer great potential to improve road safety, traffic flows and the overall efficiency and environmental performance of the transport system. There is a need to create more synergies and to enhance cooperation at European level. The Amsterdam Declaration endorsed this morning in the framework of the Transport Informal Council is very clear on this point and sees this as a prerequisite for the elaboration of a European strategy on connected and automated driving. The fact that this Council is happening today in Amsterdam is the reason why my colleague, Violeta Bulc, is not here. She is there, so you have to deal with me this afternoon. The Commission has launched a dialogue with Member States, public authorities and private stakeholders through the Cooperative Intelligent Transport Systems Platform – the C-ITS Platform – to the GEAR 2030 and the High-Level Round Table between the telecoms and automotive industries, chaired by Commissioner Oettinger. With a strong spirit of partnership, the Commission is working towards a shared European strategy on connected and automated driving as part of the energy union, research, innovation and competitiveness strategy. Research and innovation are thus also being addressed. Vehicle automation technology has developed very quickly, from increasingly sophisticated driver assistance systems intended to improve road safety, and indeed driving comfort, already on the market, to fully automated vehicles that could participate in normal traffic in the short and medium term. However, safety must never be compromised. I want to be very clear that the process towards automation should ensure that it will provide clear road safety benefits by removing, not adding, risks. The first question referred to the challenges posed by automation. The existing legal framework defining the rules of behaviour for road users will need to be adapted to allow automated driving and to ensure safety for all road users. This includes a review not only of the international conventions on road traffic, in particular the Vienna Road Traffic Convention, but also the Member States’ highway codes. Work in the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe is already under way on the international framework. It is crucial to ensure the highest possible level of security of communications and the protection of data and privacy at all times. These are indeed key elements for raising public acceptance. Several initiatives are taking place on security in the framework of the digital single market strategy in terms of privacy under the new general Data Protection Regulation. There will be one data protection law applicable across the European Union. Data protection has been addressed also in the framework of the so-called C-ITS Platform. Concerning liability, the GEAR 2030 initiative on highly automated vehicles is now taking up the issue with the aim to understand if and what is changing with further levels of automation. Then we have road construction. Road construction will probably be affected if we want to maximise benefits from this new technology. These aspects are being assessed also in the C-ITS Platform, and the results will be fed into the GEAR 2030 initiative. Also, the upgrade of the relevant cellular communication networks is being discussed in the context of the relevant High-Level Round Table on connected and automated driving. Finally, a few remarks regarding testing and inspection procedures and vehicle-type approval. Highly—automated vehicles can, to a large extent, already comply with conventional-type approval requirements, for instance general construction and emissions. Discussions are also ongoing at UNECE level with a view to updating the relevant regulations in this are also.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: for the PPE Group. - I have to regret a little that such an important point is not included until Thursday afternoon, but there is nothing we can do about it, we have to come to terms with this. I also regret that Marine Le Pen's group and other very skeptical factions did not come to this point or the point of migration. We probably have to come to terms with that, too. I largely agree with what the author of this question, Mr Ertug, said. The automotive industry is really on the imaginary threshold of a new era. It's like moving from a flying balloon to an airplane, to the cockpit of an airplane. Automotive manufacturers, in conjunction with computer experts, are testing the first generation of fully autonomous vehicles, which should appear in normal operation in the coming years. This is a truly historic turning point. However, as the latest available data shows, the path will not be easy. According to recently released statistics from the state of California - one of the few countries in the world that allows the testing of autonomous cars in its territory - in 15 months of test operation, test drivers reported almost 3,000 cases of failure. E.g. Mercedes-Benz alone had to report 1,051 cases of autonomous driving failure, operating only 2 vehicles in California. These are indeed extremely serious issues, and the aspect of road safety cannot be left out in this context. It is clear that in certain cases it will not be possible to prevent such an accident of an autonomously driven vehicle in normal road traffic, despite all technical progress. Then there is the question that is being asked, and that is the responsibility for the driving of the vehicle itself, but also for the consequences associated with such driving. I would therefore also like to ask the Commission: how should the current liability legislation be specifically amended? I have registered from the Commissioner that she mentioned the need to amend the Vienna Convention on Road Traffic of 1968, and of course I certainly agree with that.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, thank you for the generosity. The automotive industry is clearly in a hurry to reinvent itself. An era of cars with oil, with gasoline, with drivers ends, and we are faced with a new world, the world of digitization, technical development and robots, which little by little try to replace human beings. And it is good if they avoid us - as has been said - tiring or dangerous tasks, but the task of driving, I still believe that it generates many emotions and many vocations. And although it is true that in road safety we have managed to make the driver a culprit, I still believe that you have to be very careful and a lot of caution. In the case of airplanes, it has already happened to us. The airplanes were so automated that when the moment of crisis arrived, the pilot could not recover the controls of an airplane that was automated, but automated not by a higher authority, but by other engineering men who can also incur limitations and errors. Therefore, I believe that it is very important that, in the face of exaggerated optimism, we take into account the impacts of these steps. I believe that everything that can help us and avoid accident victims, of course. Now, if the only objective that we are seeing little by little is to save drivers, machinists, taxi drivers, truckers, etc. (because there is talk of cooperative driving, but sometimes it is simply a reduction of the social rights of drivers), you have to be very careful. And also, in the event that we are not going to drive, finally, the vehicles or drive them from outside (which is another thing, because we talk about autonomous driving as if nobody were going to drive them, but the drones are also driven by someone from outside), the question is in what way and with what risks and with what legal framework. And yet, while the engineers are generating autonomous driving, we find that the contamination has not yet been solved. Perhaps it would also be more important to put more impact on reducing pollution. And as for the trucks or cars in which, as the Commissioner says, you can read or talk, I too would lovingly remember that to see if it is going to turn out that we are going to end up reinventing the road rail. And it only remains for us to remember that we are going for the fourth railway package and we have not managed to harmonize the rules. Therefore, I hope that in the case of automated vehicles we will be able to establish the legislative and agreed and consensual framework that we need before starting to shoot each one on their own, which is a bit of what we are seeing. Because the different pilot projects that we attend are not all interoperable or coherent. I therefore absolutely support what my colleague Mr Ertug has said, the urgent need to present a white paper, a book where all these aspects are dealt with precisely to avoid fragmentation, inconsistencies, social impact. Because, in addition, there is a need to establish that social rights and infrastructure costs and priorities, that is, the economic impact on the public and private, have to be measured very, very sensitively before starting to give an idea that we are going to finish everyone reading and chatting in the car as it takes us, which I think is what we all do on the train.

name: Kosma ZŁOTOWSKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! We need to start designing the future of the transport sector today, especially as each day brings new ideas and innovations for which our law and infrastructure are not yet prepared. Unmanned vehicles are an idea that is not only in the design phase, but in real tests and is an important point in the long-term plans of many automotive companies. This technological revolution in the automotive industry can help solve many of the problems that we face today in the context of mobility, environmental protection and safety. Intelligent autonomous vehicles mean better functioning traffic management systems, an opportunity to reduce the number of road accidents caused by drivers, a more economical use of resources and - as we saw last week - revolution in the transport of goods. However, such changes require solid preparation and a thorough assessment of all potential effects, also from the point of view of the future of the labor market. I believe that the European Commission should be involved in the preparation of the necessary analyzes regarding the wide use of unmanned vehicles.

name: Dita CHARANZOVÁ
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I would say to the Commissioner that we have heard all about the wonders of what automated driving can bring. I personally am very much looking forward to seeing my car fully connected and self-driving in the future but, as legislators, for all the excitement, there are so many questions that must not be overlooked in the design of our regulations.
