How do we best adapt our industrial policy? How do we ensure that these vehicles are safe, both on the road and from cyber—attacks? How do we protect consumer rights while sharing more data? How do we deal with liability? The issues are so complex that we cannot deal with them alone. Our traditional car industry must be part of any dialogue as we create a harmonised legal framework which is much larger than the technical aspects, and we must do this in partnership with all stakeholders. The industry itself, however, must proactively think about issues like privacy, cyber security, data management, road management and new business models. We need an automotive industry that is fully aware that it has to change and update quickly. If it does not, non-EU companies, including non-car companies, will set the standards. The future of connected vehicles, our business growth and our economies as a whole will be based on how we use technologies to improve citizens’ experiences and their lives in general. For all these reasons, we can make the driving experience better and our towns safer. Let us do it, but let us do it now.

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, dear colleagues, we already have the connected car, the independent car will undoubtedly arrive in ten years, and here is the arrival of the autonomous car. It is a small revolution that deserves revolutionary changes. We are in the process of inventing, in this hemicycle, the law of robots. Legislation is therefore essential, with real questions. In the event of an accident, who will be responsible, since it will no longer be the driver? Will it be the builder? The OEMs? Internet players? How to be sure that the manufacturer has done things well upstream so that the automated car meets all the standards in force? It's over, driving schools! We now need a real new traffic code in order to guarantee road safety. But above all, transparency is needed so that passengers, but also employees, are not hostages to the fierce competition between manufacturers and, through them, European states. Because we can see it today in the tests of polluting emissions of vehicles: no manufacturer complies with European standards, and it is the citizens themselves who are penalized. We can see this through the national inquiries made in France or Belgium, following the Volkswagen scandal that occurred last year, and on which our Parliament is conducting a real inquiry. So, I say it calmly, in its communication, the European Commission speaks of a need for international cooperation between States and their builders. I would even go further: we need a European approval agency, as of today, on polluting emissions tests and, tomorrow, on automation. This logically leads to the question, of course, of fuel. How will these vehicles run? Is it a question of giving diesel a second youth? Of course not! This fuel is known to cause thousands of cancers each year, and it's just another scam for consumers. So what good is it? You have to think of a car that really pollutes less. Ditto on the car itself. If the automated car is a way of reviving the competitiveness of the automotive sector to again crush other modes of transport, to revive, all the more, congestion in cities, and if it is so that it is shaped for the city ​​and not for pedestrians, what's the point? On the contrary, let us make the automated car a pillar of sustainable urban mobility by developing, for example, that of carsharing, in particular. Finally, there are other challenges that must be addressed. When will states decide to launch consultations with cities and local communities to review traffic plans? It is all the land use planning that needs to be reviewed. What guarantees will ensure that the automated car, already connected and soon to be intelligent, respects data protection? And, finally, what will become of the millions of Europeans who work as drivers? We made a lot of hay, in particular, as soon as the VTC appeared. Most often, lawmakers remain petrified in the face of the battle between taxis and Uber. But, ultimately, in the end, they will all be faced with a fait accompli. So what will they do? Will they burn their automated cars to prevent their entry into service? Mr. President, it is the car which is in the process of making its revolution. So much the better, we need it. But let's also learn from the mistakes manufacturers have made in recent years, and remember that the technology won't work if there aren't smart human beings behind it.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: - Mister President! Dear colleagues, I am of course very happy that we can exchange ideas with the Commission on autonomous driving at an early stage. It is the second side of the coin that is called: digitization and Industry 4.0. No other topic has the potential to change our road traffic so profoundly. We are only at the beginning of the use of fully autonomous, driverless vehicles, but it is time to ensure the necessary legal adaptation of the applicable legal framework. Self-driving cars are not only a great opportunity to increase road safety - after all, over 90 percent of all motor vehicle accidents are due to human error. They also contribute to increasing the sustainability of road traffic - by lowering fuel consumption, improving the flow of traffic and reducing traffic jams. And thirdly, they strengthen the European Union as an industrial and research location. Technical solutions are on the market, which is not least shown by the tests on motorways in Germany. Now we have to clarify what happens to data protection. I am thinking of protection against hacker attacks as well as the rights of use for information obtained. And then there are the liability issues to be clarified if an inevitable crash does occur. We even have to consider ethical issues. After all, one day a vehicle will decide in a fraction of a second whether it will drive against the tree or the living being next door while avoiding it. Let us revise the legal framework such as the Vienna Convention on Road Traffic of 1968 and adapt it to the 21st century - Europe-wide.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Mr President, those of us who have, for example, watched Star Trek or read Isaac Asimov’s Sally will know about the concept of autonomous driving, and even flying. The current level of technological development allows for a limited vehicle autonomy, which is bound to increase over time. One of the main issues is obviously safety. The electronic and other systems involved have to be highly advanced and cover a massive number of behavioural and traffic probabilities. Therefore, testing and inspection procedures which are quite different from those for ordinary vehicles are of utmost importance. Another principal issue is security. You would not want to be kidnapped while still in your own car when it suddenly rushes off course. As a result, I fully support the idea that the Commission, alongside national governments, should soon start drawing up a respective strategy for this area of transportation. Having said that, we should never forget about Skynet/Terminator, with virtual intelligence turning into artificial intelligence and robots some day receiving rights of their own in a few decades, and that soon we might have to deal with the question of how much control we ourselves have over our own lives.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I believe that the progression of autonomous driving technology raises a number of legal and institutional challenges which, in this case, can only be addressed in a coherent way at European level. And, in this case, not only the regulations are compromised but, especially, also the strategy of public investments, which are critical to be able to guarantee connectivity between vehicles and vehicles with the infrastructures and which are linked to programs such as the deployment of broadband networks or the Galileo program itself, which accumulate delays and budget cuts. For this reason, my first concern is what they plan to do in terms of investment coordination in order to guarantee that these vehicles can take advantage of all their capabilities throughout the Union, because it would be sad if problems related to State-to-State non-compliance with investment commitments raise again borders within the Union for the operation of this type of vehicles. Secondly, I would like to know whether this issue will force a review of the plans already approved for the trans-European transport networks. And finally, tell you that the characteristics of autonomous driving vehicles will modify the performance of the profession of professional transporter. They will affect the training of the occupants of transport vehicles and some of their current functions, and may require a review of the conditions of access and the exercise of this profession. Can you advance any question in this regard? Because in his first speech he made no mention of it.

name: Andor DELI
text: “Virtually all of the technology that exists today allows us to be able to drive vehicles without driver intervention. In addition to the clear positives, there are also a host of challenges and potential disadvantages, such as the issue of responsibility, which has already been mentioned a lot, the drastic reduction of management-related jobs, the issue of privacy, etc. We need to pay attention to safety, which must be a priority, especially for the most vulnerable in transport: pedestrians and cyclists. Communication between vehicles is also part of the road to self-driving vehicles. Using this could already be useful in sharing road information with each other. I believe that this technology should be extended to all vehicles, especially trucks. This would save time and fuel, improve the working conditions of hauliers and bring us closer to achieving our environmental goals. The most important task is to create a legal framework that allows the sustainable use of this new technology and at the same time facilitates further developments. Reconciling different interests and goals presents us with a major challenge, but at the same time, unstoppable technological developments make it urgent to establish a regulatory framework as soon as possible. The Commission can count on the assistance of the European Parliament in this process.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - The debate that is taking place here is extremely interesting, Commissioner. I think it would really be worthwhile for the European Commission to produce a book, a summary of issues related to autonomous vehicles, and those that the public sector, the individual states and, ideally, the EU will have to respond to. In principle, I see three areas where the issue of autonomous vehicles concerns us as representatives of individual states and the EU. These are, firstly, the legal issues that have been mentioned here, then the issues of adapting transport infrastructure as the second issue, and the third issue, which is also the issue of cyber security mentioned several times. On legal issues, I think it would be very good for any changes in the law to take place at European level, because, in accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, it would be very wrong for each Member State to adapt its national legal regimes to the possible introduction of autonomous vehicles. The strongest issue that has been mentioned here and that is related to this is the issue of liability for damage, where it will have to be made clear who is responsible for the damage caused by the operation of such an autonomous vehicle. Manufacturer, user, these are things that will need to be discussed. The issue of infrastructure adaptation is also a topic that should be European. It is not possible for each state to address this issue independently and adapt transport infrastructure in a different way. Obviously, these cars do not differentiate all the brands that exist today. These are topics that belong to Europe.

name: Anne SANDER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the autonomous car is a technological dream on the way to becoming a reality. Semi-autonomous cars are already being marketed today, which park by themselves, turn by themselves and brake by themselves. Tomorrow, the driver will only be a passenger in his own car. The savings in time and comfort could obviously be immense, but it is above all in the area of ​​safety that progress is most expected, since most of the 26,000 annual deaths on European roads are due to human error. How many lives can we save with new technologies? However, many obstacles remain, and many questions remain and need to be resolved. These questions have already been mentioned; I call them back. Who will be responsible in the event of an accident? How to adapt our road and telecommunications infrastructures? How to coordinate the action of the different road users? In addition, self-driving cars will necessarily be connected cars, which also raises questions. How to make sure that they cannot be hacked and what will happen to data protection? If we manage to respond in a coordinated manner to these questions, Europe will have the means to become the leader of this new industrial revolution.

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: - Currently, the automotive sector is developing rapidly due to the development of technologies. Advanced assistance systems for drivers are already a reality. Soon we will have partially autonomous driving, fully autonomous parking systems, collision avoidance and assistance in traffic jams, and, in the not too distant future, fully autonomous driving. The European Commission needs to come up with a strategy and a plan to update the legislation, which urgently needs to adapt to the new reality: existing legislation on liability, data protection, cyber security - many arguments have been put here - existing legislation on type-approval The type of vehicles must be analyzed and reviewed in the next period. In addition, existing or future projects to improve the current transport infrastructure of the Member States must already take into account these developments and innovations in the automotive sector.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Mr President, I found this discussion fascinating, and arising from it I have just a few questions which the Commissioner may be able to answer, or at least we will get answers in due course. Firstly, what is the likelihood of public acceptability for autonomous vehicles on the roads, especially in the transitional period, when there may be very few initially and then more and more in due course? Secondly, liability in the event of an accident has been mentioned: is it the passenger’s or the owner’s, who may not be a passenger at that particular time? I think that is a very important question which will have to be looked at. We also have the whole question of costs. Is there any idea about how much these vehicles are likely to cost? Will costs be more or less than the vehicles we have now? And, of course, there is the crucial question arising out of COP21 and climate change: will it lead to more or less emissions? That is hugely important.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Mr President, colleagues, thank you, colleagues, for bringing up such an important, interesting and timely issue. Technology is evolving extremely fast and we need to keep up with that time. I believe that autonomous driving will be a radical revolution in the automotive and transport sectors, for which we must prepare now. The European Union is one of the leading forces in the field of innovation and technology, which also obliges us to lead in the proposals for regulating traffic with this new type of vehicle. According to the car sector and in my country, autonomous driving will help increase road safety, but safety depends on the new road rules anyway.

name: Ivan JAKOVČIĆ
text: - A lot of questions have been raised today, Madam Commissioner.When it comes to autonomous driving, the safety issue is at the forefront.However, a number of other issues arise, such as social, ethical, environmental, technological and security issues in terms of data protection.We opened a series of questions.Of course, one of the bigger problems will be infrastructure.Who will fund all the necessary infrastructure for vehicles that will have autonomous driving?However, what I want to emphasize here is the following: this is an opportunity for the European Commission to take the momentum of the development of the car industry at European level as a momentum for many other industries within the European Union.Let us not just allow this opportunity not to be seized and all to dissipate again into the Member States.We will not succeed otherwise.Try to lead this at the level of the European Union.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. - Members of the European Parliament, thank you for your valuable contribution. Here we are confronted with new technologies, with developments that are in fact in full development, developments of which we now see the beginning, but certainly not the end. I think it is normal that we ask ourselves a lot of questions and that is precisely why we have to follow this file, these developments, closely. A lot of questions have been asked or a lot of aspects mentioned that we have to take into account: scientific research and innovation, competitiveness, security, liability, the consequences on the labor market, data protection, the protection of privacy, financing. Who is going to pay the costs of the road infrastructure, of the development of the communication infrastructure? Public investment, private investment, public-private partnership, who knows what it will be? Traffic regulations, ensure the protection of the vulnerable road users. Testing, vehicle inspections, driving instructions. The influence on emissions, on our climate development. Those are just a few questions, maybe more to come! I imagine that today's debate is just the first debate in a very long line. I think we are at the start of a long journey that we will hopefully take together to understand all the implications, to also guide these new developments in a positive way, because that will be very much needed. There will be consequences for the transport sector, for society as such, but also for our competitive position. That journey has, of course, already begun, in the sense that the European institutions already set up a platform - I have already referred to it - in 2014, the C-ITS platform, a cooperative platform that works together and that follows everything that happens. The first milestone has already been set, with a note, a final report that was delivered in January 2016. The Commission intends to publish a master plan later this year to further monitor and supervise these developments. There is also a high level group on the automotive industry, to which I already referred in my introduction, "GEAR 2030" and this one is also busy developing a road map. Within the framework of GEAR 2030, a wide consultation on autonomous driving has also been started and for all these reasons together and also because the Commission plans to come up with a master plan, I can tell you that there is not immediately a plan this year to come up with a green paper. But there will certainly be a document. That will no doubt be communicated to here too and I think we will sit here many more times, with the ten of us, Mr President, or hopefully sometimes with some more Members of Parliament, to discuss this important file and its development. to follow. Let us also work well together here and bring this to a successful conclusion. There is much to discuss. There is a lot of new development going on. Let's see that as a positive challenge.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.
